original: Yāya vīthiyā sūriye gacchante vassavalāhakā devaputtā sūriyābhitāpasantattā attano🔽vimānato na nikkhamanti, kīḷāpasutā hutvā na vicaranti, tadā kira sūriyassa vimānaṃ🔽pakatimaggato adho otaritvā vicarati, tassa oruyha caraṇeneva candavimānampi adho🔽oruyha carati taggatikattā, tasmā sā vīthi udakābhāvena ajānurūpatāya “ajavīthī”ti
analyzed: vīthiyā sūriye gacchante vassa valāhakā deva puttā sūriya abhitāpa santattā attano  vimānataḥ na nikkhamanti kīḷā pasutāḥ hutvā na vicaranti tadā kira sūriyassa vimānam  pakati maggataḥ adhas otaritvā vicarati tassa oruyha caraṇena iva canda vimānam pi adhas  āruyha carati taggatikattā tasmā sā vīthi udaka abhāvena aja anurūpa tāya ajavīthī iti
translated: When the sun moves along that path, the rain-cloud gods do not emerge from their abodes and do not wander about, being addicted to play, because they are satisfied by the heat of the sun.🔽Then, it seems, the sun’s palace descends from the path and moves below it.🔽Because it moves below, the moon’s palace also moves below it, for the moon follows the sun.🔽Therefore that path is called “the path of the water buffalo” because it is not suitable for the water buffalo, that is, for the rain-cloud gods, owing to the absence of water.

original: samaññaṃ gatā. Yāya pana vīthiyā sūriye gacchante vassavalāhakā devaputtā sūriyābhitāpābhāvato
analyzed: samaññam gatā yāya pana vīthiyā sūriye gacchante vassa valāhakā deva puttā sūriya abhitāpa abhāvato
translated: When the sun moves along that path, the rain-cloud gods do not emerge from their abodes because they are heated by the sun’s rays. They do not go out to play. Then, it seems, the sun’s mansion descends from the path it normally travels and moves below. By its descending in this way, the moon’s mansion also descends. Because the moon’s mansion moves in the same plane as the sun’s, it is called the “path of the ass” because it is not in the right place for the water.

original: abhiṇhaṃ attano vimānato bahi nikkhamitvā kīḷāpasutā ito cito ca vicaranti, tadā🔽kira sūriyavimānaṃ pakatimaggato uddhaṃ āruhitvā vicarati, tassa uddhaṃ āruyha caraṇeneva
analyzed: abhiṇham attanaḥ vimānataḥ bahi nikkhamitvā kīḷā pasutāḥ itas citas ca vicaranti tadā  kira sūriya vimānam pakati maggataḥ uddham āruhitvā vicarati tassa uddham āruyha caraṇena iva
translated: When the sun moves along that path, the rain-cloud gods emerge from their abodes because they are not heated by the sun’s rays. They go out to play here and there.

original: candavimānampi uddhaṃ āruyha carati taggatikattā, taggatikatā ca samānagatinā vātamaṇḍalena
analyzed: canda vimānam pi uddham āruyha carati taggatikattā taggatikatā ca samāna gatinā vātamaṇḍalena
translated: Then, it seems, the sun’s mansion ascends from the path it normally travels and moves above. By its ascending in this way, the moon’s mansion also ascends. Because the moon’s mansion moves in the same plane as the sun’s, it is called the “path of the ass” because it is not in the right place for the water.

original: vimānassa phellitabbattā, tasmā sā vīthi udakabahubhāvena nāgānurūpatāya “nāgavīthī”ti
analyzed: vimānassa phellitabba ttā tasmā sā vīthi udaka bahu bhāvena nāga anurūpa tāya nāgavīthī iti
translated: because the mansions are shaken. That is why that path is known as the “Nāga path” because of the abundance of water and because of its suitability to nāgas.

original: samaññaṃ gatā. Yadā sūriyo uddhamanāruhanto, adho ca anotaranto pakatimaggeneva gacchati,
analyzed: samaññam gatāḥ yadā sūriyaḥ uddham anāruhantaḥ adho ca pakati maggena iva gacchati
translated: When the sun rises and does not set below but goes on its course as usual,

original: tadā vassavalāhakā yathākālaṃ, yathāruci ca vimānato nikkhamitvā sukhena vicaranti,
analyzed: tadā vassa valāhakāḥ yathākālam yathāruci ca vimānataḥ nikkhamitvā sukhena vicaranti
translated: then the rain-bearing clouds emerge from their mansions in time and as they wish and move about happily.

original: tena kālena kālaṃ vassanato loke utusamatā hoti, tāya utusamatāya hetubhūtāya sā
analyzed: tena kālena kālam loke utu samatā hoti tāya utu samatāya hetu bhūtāya sā
translated: At that time, because of the regularity of the seasons in the world due to the rain falling at the right time,

original: candimasūriyānaṃ gati gavānurūpatāya “govīthī”ti samaññaṃ gatā. Tena vuttaṃ “ajavīthī”tiādi.
analyzed: candima sūriyānam gati gavā anurūpa tāya govīthī iti samaññam gatā tena vuttam aja vīthi itiādi
translated: that path is known as the “Go path” because of its suitability to the course of the sun and moon. That is why it is said, “the Ajavīthī, etc.”

original: Evaṃ “kati nesaṃ vīthiyo”ti pañhaṃ vissajjetvā “kathaṃ vicarantī”ti pañhaṃ vissajjetuṃ
analyzed: evam kati na īsam vīthiyaḥ ti pañham vissajjetvā katham vicaranti iti pañham vissajjetum
translated: Having thus answered the question, “How many are their paths?,” to answer the question, “How do they move?”

original: “candimasūriyā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha sineruto bahi nikkhamantīti sinerusamīpena taṃ
analyzed: candima sūriya atiādi vuttam tattha sinerutaḥ bahi nikkhamanti iti sineru samīpena tam
translated: it is said, “The sun and moon,” etc. Herein, “going out beyond Sineru” means that, going round Sineru

original: padakkhiṇaṃ katvā gacchantā tato gamanavīthito bahi attano tiriyagamanena cakkavāḷābhimukhā
analyzed: padakkhiṇam katvā gacchantā tatas gamana vīthitaḥ bahi tiriya gamanena cakkavāḷa abhimukhā
translated: on its near side, they go out beyond that path of going by their own crosswise movement and face the Cakkavāḷa.

original: nikkhamanti. Anto vicarantīti evaṃ cha māse khaṇe khaṇe sineruto apasakkanavasena
analyzed: nikkhamanti antar vicaranti iti evam cha māse khaṇe khaṇe sinerutaḥ apasakkana vasena
translated: They move about inside. They move about inside in this way: for six months they move out of Sineru by the time it takes for a dust mote to fall.

original: tato nikkhamitvā cakkavāḷasamīpaṃ pattā, tatopi cha māse khaṇe khaṇe apasakkanavasena
analyzed: tatas nikkhamitvā cakkavāḷa samīpam pattā tatas api cha māse khaṇe khaṇe apasakkana vasena
translated: Having moved out, they reach the vicinity of the Cakkavāḷa. For six months they move out by the time it takes for a dust mote to fall.

original: nikkhamitvā sinerusamīpaṃ pāpuṇantā anto vicaranti. Idāni tamevatthaṃ saṅkhepena
analyzed: nikkhamitvā sineru samīpam pāpuṇantāḥ antar vicaranti idāni tam evattham saṅkhepena
translated: Having moved out, they reach the vicinity of Sineru. Now, in order to explain that same matter in brief, “By them” is said.

original: vuttaṃ vivarituṃ “tehī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Sinerussa, cakkavāḷassa ca yaṃ ṭhānaṃ vemajjhaṃ,🔽tassa, sinerussa ca yaṃ ṭhānaṃ vemajjhaṃ, tena gacchantā “sinerusamīpena vicarantī”ti
analyzed: vuttam vivaritum tehi itiādi vuttam sinerussa cakkavāḷassa ca yam ṭhānam vemajjham  tassa sinerussa ca yam ṭhānam vemajjham tena gacchantā sineru samīpena vicaranti iti
translated: The place that is the middle of Sineru and the Cakkavāḷa,

original: vuttā, na sinerussa aggāḷindaallīnā. Cakkavāḷasamīpena caritvāti etthāpi eseva nayo.
analyzed: vuttā na sinerussa cakkavāḷa samīpena caritvā iti ettha api esā iva nayo
translated: by that, and the place that is the middle of Sineru, by that, they are said to move about in the vicinity of Sineru, not clinging to the peak of Sineru. Having moved about in the vicinity of the Cakkavāḷa, the same method applies here.

original: Majjhenāti sinerussa, cakkavāḷassa ca ujukaṃ vemajjhena maggena. Citramāse majjhenāti etthāpi eseva nayo.
analyzed: majjhena ati sinerussa cakkavāḷassa ca ujukam vemajjhena maggena citra māse majjhena ati ettha api esā iva nayaḥ
translated: In the middle. In the middle of Sineru and the Cakkavāḷa by a straight path. In the middle of the variegated months, the same method applies here.

original: Ekappahārenāti ekavelāya, ekeneva vā attano ekappahārena. Majjhanhikoti ṭhitamajjhanhiko
analyzed: eka pahārena ati eka velāya ekena iva vā attano eka ppahārena majjhanhikaḥ ti ṭhita majjhanhikaḥ
translated: In one day: in one period of time, or by his own one day.

original: kālo hoti. Tadā hi sūriyamaṇḍalaṃ uggacchantaṃ hutvāpi imasmiṃ dīpe ṭhitassa upaḍḍhameva
analyzed: kālaḥ hoti tadā hi sūriya maṇḍalam uggacchantam hutvā api imasmin dīpe ṭhitassa upaḍḍham eva
translated: The time is midday. For then the sun’s orb, though rising, appears to one standing in this island only half risen,

original: dissati, uttarakurūsu ṭhitassa ogacchantaṃ hutvā. Evañhi ekavelāyameva tīsu dīpesu ālokakaraṇaṃ.🔽Yesu kattikādinakkhattasamaññā, tānipi tārakarūpāni yevāti vuttaṃ “sesatārakarūpāni
analyzed: dissati uttarakurūsu ṭhitassa ogacchantam hutvā evam hi tīsu dīpesu āloka karaṇam  yesu kattikā ādi nakkhatta samaññā tāni api tāraka rūpāni yeva ati vuttam sesa tāraka rūpāni
translated: and to one standing in Uttarakuru it appears to be rising. Thus the illumination of the three continents is done in one period of time.🔽The other star-forms are the stars called Kattika, etc., which are also star-forms.

original: cā”ti, nakkhattasaññitatārakarūpato avasiṭṭhatārakarūpānīti attho. Ubhayānipi tāni
analyzed: ca ati nakkhatta saññita tāraka rūpataḥ avasiṭṭha tāraka rūpāni iti atthaḥ ubhayāni pi tāni
translated: The meaning is: the remaining star-forms that are called “stars.” Both of these

original: devatānaṃ vasanakavimānānīti veditabbāni. Rā-saddo tiyati chijjati etthāti ratti,
analyzed: devatānam vasanaka vimānāni iti veditabbāni rāsaddaḥ tiyati chijjati ettha ati
translated: should be understood as celestial mansions in which the deities dwell. Night is so called because the sound of beings ceases here;

original: sattānaṃ saddassa vūpasamanakāloti attho. Dibbanti sattā kīḷanti jotanti etthāti
analyzed: sattānam saddassa vūpasamana kālaḥ ti attho dibbanti sattā kīḷanti jotanti ettha ati
translated: the meaning is, the time when the sound of beings subsides.🔽Day is so called because beings play and shine here.

original: divā. Sattānaṃ āyuṃ minanto viya siyati antaṃ karotīti māso. Taṃ taṃ kiriyaṃ arati
analyzed: divā sattānam āyum minantaḥ viya siyati antam karoti iti māsaḥ tam tam kiriyam
translated: The month is so called because it measures the life of beings, as it were, and makes an end of it.

original: vattetīti utu. Taṃ taṃ sattaṃ, dhammappavattiñca saṅgamma vadanto viya sarati vattetīti saṃvaccharo.
analyzed: vatteti iti utu tam tam sattam dhamma ppavattiñca saṅgamma vadantaḥ viya sarati vatteti iti saṃvaccharaḥ
translated: “It is a season” : it is a season in the sense of “it goes” , because it goes by, or because it is remembered as “it goes” .

original: 122. Vivajjanaṃ vivajjo, so eva vevajjaṃ, vaṇṇassa vevajjaṃ vaṇṇavevajjaṃ, vaṇṇasampattiyā
analyzed: vivajjanam vivajjaḥ saḥ eva vevajjam vaṇṇassa vevajjam vaṇṇa vevajjam vaṇṇa sampattiyā
translated: “Disappearance” is “disappearance” . The disappearance of colour is “colour-disappearance” .

original: vigamo, tassa pana atthitā “vaṇṇavevajjatā”ti vuttā. Tenāha “vivajjabhāvo”ti. Tesanti🔽vaṇṇavantānaṃ sattānaṃ. Atimānappaccayāti dubbaṇṇavambhanavasena atikkamma attano🔽vaṇṇaṃ paṭicca mānapaccayā, mānasampaggaṇhananimittanti attho. Sātisayo raso etissā
analyzed: vigamaḥ tassa pana atthi tā vaṇṇa vevajja tā ti vuttā tena āha vivajja bhāvaḥ ti tesan ti  vaṇṇavantānam sattānam atimāna ppaccayā ti dubbaṇṇa vambhana vasena atikkamma attanaḥ  vaṇṇam paṭicca māna paccayāḥ māna sampaggaṇhana nimittanti attho sa atisayaḥ rasaḥ etissā
translated: It is the absence of the excellence of colour. But its presence is called “the state of having colour-disappearance” .🔽“That” :🔽of beings who are possessed of colour. “With the condition of over-estimation” : with the condition of over-estimation by way of despising those who are ugly. The meaning is: with the cause of the occurrence of conceit.

original: atthīti rasāti laddhamānāya, anubhāsiṃsūti anurodhavasena bhāsiṃsu. Lokuppattivaṃsakathanti🔽lokuppattivaṃsajaṃ paveṇīkathaṃ, ādikāle uppannaṃ paveṇīāgatakathanti attho. “Anupatantī”tipi pāṭho, so evattho.
analyzed: atthi iti laddha mānāya anubhāsiṃsu iti anurodha vasena bhāsiṃsu  loka uppatti vaṃsa jam paveṇī katham ādi kāle uppannam paveṇī āgata kathanti atthaḥ anupatanti iti pi pāṭhaḥ saḥ evattho
translated: “It has the meaning of ‘having a relish’ ,” thus it is “having a relish” . They spoke in conformity with it, thus they “spoke in conformity with it” .

original: Bhūmipappaṭakapātubhāvādivaṇṇanā
translated: “The story of the lineage of the origin of the world” : the story of the lineage of the origin of the world. The meaning is: the story that has come down by tradition from ancient times. The reading “anupatantī” is also correct. The meaning is the same.

original: 123. Ediso hutvāti ahicchattakasadiso hutvā.
analyzed: edisaḥ hutvā iti ahicchattaka sadisaḥ hutvā
translated: Having become like that: having become like a snake’s hood.

original: 124. Padālatāti “padā”ti evaṃnāmā ekā latā, sā pana yasmā sampannavaṇṇagandharasā, tasmā “bhaddalatā”ti vuttā. Nāḷikāti nāḷivalli. Ahāyīti nassi.
analyzed: padālatā ati padā ati evaṃnāmā ekā latā sā pana sampanna vaṇṇa gandha rasā tasmā bhaddalatā ati vuttā nāḷikā ati nāḷivalli ahāyī iti nassi
translated: Padālatā: a creeper named “padā” . But because it has good colour, smell, and taste, it is called “bhaddalatā” . Nāḷika: a bamboo creeper. Ahāyi: it has disappeared.

original: 125. Akaṭṭhapākoti akaṭṭheyeva ṭhāne uppajjitvā paccanako, nīvāro viya sañjāto hutvā
analyzed: akaṭṭha pāko ti akaṭṭheya iva ṭhāne uppajjitvā paccanakaḥ nīvāraḥ viya sañjātaḥ hutvā
translated: Akaṭṭhapāka: it is ripe in the place where it grows, not in the threshing floor, like rice.

original: nippajjanakoti attho. Kaṇo “kuṇḍaka”nti ca vuccati. Thusanti taṇḍulaṃ pariyonandhitvā
analyzed: nippajjanakaḥ ti attho kaṇaḥ kuṇḍakanti ca vuccati thusanti taṇḍulam
translated: It is born, it arises, thus it is nipphajjanaka . Kaṇa is also called kuṇḍaka . Thus: the husk that remains after the rice is threshed.

original: ṭhitattaco, tadabhāvato “akaṇo, athuso”ti sāli vutto. “Paṭivirūḷha”nti idaṃ pakkabhāvassa
analyzed: tad abhāvataḥ a kaṇaḥ a thusaḥ ti vuttaḥ paṭivirūḍhanti idam pakka bhāvassa
translated: Akaṇa, athusa: rice is called “without husk” and “without chaff” because of the absence of that . “Paṭivirūḷha” is said to be the cause of its ripeness.

original: kāraṇavacanaṃ. Paṭivirūḷhato hi taṃ pakkanti. Yasmiṃ ṭhāne sāyaṃ pakko sāli gahito,
analyzed: kāraṇa vacanam paṭivirūḍhataḥ hi tam yasmin ṭhāne sāyam gahitaḥ
translated: For it is ripe because it has grown. In the place where the rice that was ripe in the evening was gathered,

original: tadeva ṭhānaṃ dutiyadivase pāto pakkena sālinā paripuṇṇaṃ hutvā tiṭṭhatīti āha “sāyaṃ
analyzed: tat eva ṭhānam dutiya divase pāto pakkena sālinā paripuṇṇam hutvā tiṭṭhati iti āha sāyam
translated: that place was filled up in the morning with the rice that was ripe in the morning. Thus it is said: “In the evening

original: gahitaṭṭhānaṃ pāto pakkaṃ hotī”tiādi. Alāyitanti lāyitaṭṭhānampi tesaṃ kammappaccayā
analyzed: gahita ṭṭhānam pāto pakkam hoti itiādi alāyitanti lāyita ṭṭhānam pi tesam kamma ppaccayā
translated: and the place where it is kept becomes ripe in the morning.’ ‘Not stored’ means not stored in a place where it is kept.

original: alāyitameva hutvā anūnaṃ paripuṇṇameva paññāyati, na kevalaṃ paññāyanameva, atha
analyzed: alāyitam eva hutvā anūnam paripuṇṇam eva paññāyati na kevalam paññāyanam eva atha
translated: and the place where it was kept is empty in the morning.’ ‘Not lacking’ means that the place where it was stored is not lacking in it, for it is all there, complete, not less by a grain. It is not only that it is seen to be there,

original: kho tathābhūtameva hutvā tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: kho tathābhūtam eva hutvā tiṭṭhati
translated: but it is there in that very form.

original: Itthipurisaliṅgādipātubhāvavaṇṇanā🔽126. “Manussakāle”ti idaṃ pubbe manussabhūtānaṃyeva tattha idāni nikantivasena uppatti🔽hotīti katvā vuttaṃ, devatānampi purimajātiyaṃ itthibhāve ṭhitānaṃ tattha virāgādipurisattappaccaye
analyzed: itthi purisa liṅga ādi pātubhāva vaṇṇanā  manussa kāle ti idam pubbe manussa bhūtānam yeva tattha idāni nikanti vasena uppatti  hoti iti katvā vuttam devatānam pi purima jātiyam itthi bhāve ṭhitānam tattha virāga ādi purisa tta paccaye
translated: The manifestation of the sex, etc., of beings🔽The words ‘in the human world’ are said because it is only those who have been human beings in the past who are reborn there now through attachment. Even though the sex of deities is manifested in accordance with their past human sex,

original: asati tadā itthiliṅgameva pātubhavati. Purisattapaccayeti “attanopi anissaratā, sabbakālaṃ
analyzed: asati tadā itthi liṅgam eva pātubhavati purisa atta paccayā iti attanaḥ api a nissara tā sabbakālam
translated: if there is no condition for the manifestation of the male sex, etc., then the female sex is manifested. ‘The male sex’: the fact that one is not one’s own master, the fact of being subject to another at all times,

original: parāyattavuttitā, rajassalatā vañcatā, gabbhadhāraṇaṃ, paṭhamāya pakatiyā nihīnapakatitā,
analyzed: parāyatta vutti tā rajassala tā vañca tā gabbha dhāraṇam paṭhamāya pakatiyā nihīna pakati tā
translated: the fact of being covered with dust, the fact of being deceitful, the fact of bearing a child in the womb, the fact of being by nature inferior to the male,

original: sūravīratābhāvo, ‘appakā janā’ti ‘hīḷetabbatā’ti evamādi ādīnavapaccavekkhaṇapubbakampi
analyzed: sūra vīra tā bhāvaḥ appakā janāti hīḷetabba tā ti evamādi ādīnava paccavekkhaṇa pubbakam pi
translated: the fact of being without the qualities of a hero and a warrior, the fact of being despised as ‘a low-born woman,’ ‘a contemptible woman,’ and so on, after reflecting on the disadvantages in this way,

original: itthibhāve ‘alaṃ itthibhāvena, na hi itthibhāve ṭhatvā cakkavattisiriṃ, na sakkamārabrahmasiriyo
analyzed: itthi bhāve alam itthi bhāvena na hi itthi bhāve cakkavatti sirim na
translated: “In the female state there is no sufficiency in the female state. For it is not possible to experience the glory of a Wheel-Turning Monarch, the glory of Sakka, of Brahmā,

original: paccanubhavituṃ, na paccekabodhiṃ, na sammāsambodhiṃ adhigantuṃ sakkā’ti evaṃ itthibhāvavirajjanaṃ,
analyzed: paccanubhavitum na paccekabodhim na sammāsambodhim adhigantum sakkā ati evam itthi bhāva virajjanam
translated: by remaining in the female state, nor is it possible to attain individual enlightenment or supreme enlightenment.” So he becomes dispassionate towards the female state in this way.

original: ‘yathāvuttaādīnavavirahato uttamapakatibhāvato sampadamidaṃ purisattaṃ nāma seṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: yathāvutta ādīnava virahataḥ uttama pakati bhāvataḥ sampadam idam purisattam nāma seṭṭham
translated: “The male state is the best, the highest, in the sense of being free from the danger described and in the sense of being the natural state of the highest kind.

original: uttamaṃ, ettha ṭhatvā sakkā etā sampattiyo sampāpuṇitu’nti evaṃ purisattabhāve sambhāvanāpubbakaṃ
analyzed: uttamam ettha ṭhatvā sakkāḥ etāḥ sampattiyaḥ sampāpuṇitun ti evam purisa atta bhāve sambhāvanā pubbakam
translated: For it is possible to attain these kinds of distinction by remaining in the male state.” So he forms the aspiration and makes the wish preceded by respect for the male state in this way.

original: patthanāṭhapanaṃ, ‘tattha ninnapoṇapabbhāracittatā’ti” evamādike purisabhāvassa paccayabhūte
analyzed: patthanā ṭhapanam tattha ninna poṇa pabbhāra citta tā ati evamādike purisa bhāvassa paccaya bhūte
translated: “The mental states of inclination, resolve, and longing” are the states that are the conditions for the male state, beginning with the words, “In the female state there is no sufficiency in the female state.”🔽Having fulfilled and increased,

original: dhamme. Pūretvā vaḍḍhetvā. Paccakkhaṃ bhūtaṃ, sadisañca diṭṭhadhammikaṃ, samparāyikañca
analyzed: dhamme pūretvā vaḍḍhetvā paccakkham bhūtam sadisam ca diṭṭhadhammikam samparāyikam ca
translated: having seen the actual danger and the danger similar to it in this visible world and in the life to come,

original: suvipulaṃ anatthaṃ acintetvā purisassa kāmesu micchācaraṇaṃ kevalaṃ itthiyaṃ āsāpatti
analyzed: su vipulam anattham a cintetvā purisassa kāmesu micchā caraṇam kevalam itthiyam āsāpatti
translated: a man should not think of any great and extensive misfortune, and he should not commit sexual misconduct with a woman out of mere desire.

original: phalenevāti āsāāpatti itthibhāvāvahāpi hotiyeva. Tanninnapoṇapabbhārabhāvena tannikantiyā🔽nimittabhāvāpattitoti vuttaṃ “puriso itthattabhāvaṃ labhanto kāmesumicchācāraṃ nissāya
analyzed: phalena iva ati itthi bhāva āvahā api hotiyā iva tad ninna poṇa pabbhāra bhāvena tad nikantiyā  nimitta bhāva āpattitaḥ ti vuttam purisaḥ itthatta bhāvam labhanto kāmesum icchā ācāram nissāya
translated: Because of the state of being intent upon that, that is, because of the state of being bent upon that,🔽because of the state of being a woman, it is said that “he who obtains the state of being a woman does so by means of sexual misconduct.”🔽That time, that is, the first period of time mentioned above.

original: labhatī”ti. Tadāti yathāvutte paṭhamakappikakāle. Pakatiyāti sabhāvena. Mātugāmassāti

original: paccayalābhena vipaccituṃ laddhokāsatāya kusalato akusalaṃ balavataraṃ hotīti, tathābhūtampi
analyzed: paccaya lābhena vipaccitum laddha ukāsa tāya kusalataḥ akusalam balavataram hoti iti tathābhūtam pi
translated: the unprofitable is stronger than the profitable because it has the opportunity to ripen by the acquisition of conditions.

original: taṃ yathā vipākadāne laddhokāsassa kusalassāpi avasaro hoti, tathā laddhapaccayaṃ
analyzed: tam yathā vipāka dāne laddha ukāsassa kusalassa api avasaraḥ hoti tathā laddha paccayam
translated: and so it is given opportunity to do so, just as profitable action does when it is given opportunity to yield its result.

original: paṭisandhidānābhimukhaṃ kusalaṃ paṭibāhitvā paṭisandhiṃ dentaṃ tiracchānayoniyaṃ🔽nibbattāpetīti. “Akusalaṃ balavataraṃ hotī”ti ettha “akusalaṃ ce balavataraṃ hoti,
analyzed: paṭisandhi dāna abhimukham kusalam paṭibāhitvā paṭisandhim dentam tiracchāna yoniyam  nibbattāpeti iti akusalam balavataram hoti iti ettha akusalam ce balavataram hoti
translated: Then, when the profitable is about to give rebirth-linking, it prevents that and gives rebirth-linking that leads to an animal womb.

original: taṃ kusalaṃ paṭibāhitvā”ti vuttanayeneva atthaṃ vatvā tesu kusalaṃ ce balavataraṃ
analyzed: tam kusalam paṭibāhitvā iti vutta nayena iva attham vatvā tesu kusalam ce balavataram
translated: As to the words “Unprofitable action is stronger,” the meaning should be understood in the way already stated thus, “If the unprofitable is stronger, it prevents the profitable and gives rebirth-linking” .

original: hoti, tañca akusalaṃ paṭibāhitvā manussayoniyaṃ nibbattāpeti, akusalaṃ pavattivedanīyaṃ
analyzed: hoti tat ca akusalam paṭibāhitvā manussa yoniyam nibbattāpeti akusalam pavatti vedanīyam
translated: But if the profitable is stronger, it prevents the unprofitable and gives rebirth-linking that leads to the human world.

original: hoti, atha naṃ taṃ kāṇampi karoti khujjampi pīṭhasappimpi kucchirogādīhi vā upaddutaṃ.
analyzed: hoti atha nam tam kāṇam pi karoti khujjam pi pīṭhasappim kucchi roga ādīhi vā upaddutam
translated: If the unprofitable is to be experienced in a course of action, then it makes him one-eyed or lame or crippled or hunchbacked or a leper or afflicted with some such malady.

original: Evaṃ so pavattiyaṃ nānappakāraṃ dukkhaṃ paccanubhavatīti idaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “sukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī
analyzed: evam so pavattiyam nānappakāram dukkham paccanubhavati iti idam sandhāya vuttam sukha dukkha ppaṭisaṃvedī
translated: So he experiences suffering in various ways in the course of his existence. This is what is referred to in the words “he feels pleasure and pain” .

original: hotī”ti. Tatrāyaṃ vinicchayo – vuttakāle vā kārena samānabalesu kusalākusalakammesu
analyzed: hoti iti tatra ayam vinicchayaḥ vutta kāle vā kārena samāna balesu kusala akusala kammesu
translated: Here is the working out of the permutations in the case of profitable and unprofitable kamma of equal strength that is ready to yield its fruit:

original: upaṭṭhahantesu maraṇassa āsannavelāyaṃ yadi balavatarāni kusalajavanāni javanti,🔽yathāupaṭṭhitaṃ akusalaṃ paṭibāhitvā kusalaṃ vuttanayena paṭisandhiṃ deti. Atha balavatarāni
analyzed: upaṭṭhahantesu maraṇassa āsanna velāyam yadi balavatarāni kusala javanāni javanti  yathā upaṭṭhitam akusalam paṭibāhitvā kusalam vutta nayena paṭisandhim deti atha balavatarāni
translated: When they are attending on him, if profitable impulsions impel more strongly at the time of the nearness of death,🔽then they ward off the unprofitable that has presented itself and give rebirth-linking in the way already described.🔽But if unprofitable impulsions impel more strongly,

original: akusalajavanāni javanti, yathāupaṭṭhitaṃ kusalaṃ paṭibāhitvā akusalaṃ vuttanayeneva
analyzed: akusala javanāni javanti yathā upaṭṭhitam kusalam paṭibāhitvā akusalam vutta nayena iva
translated: then they ward off the profitable that has presented itself and give rebirth-linking in the way already described.

original: paṭisandhiṃ deti. Taṃ kissa hetu? Ubhinnaṃ kammānaṃ samānabalavabhāvato, paccayantarasāpekkhato
analyzed: paṭisandhim deti tam kissa hetu ubhinnam kammānam samāna balava bhāvataḥ paccaya antara sa apekkhato
translated: And why is that? Because both kinds of kamma are of equal strength, and because they are dependent on other conditions.

original: cāti, sabbaṃ vīmaṃsitvā gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: ca ati sabbam vīmaṃsitvā gahetabbam
translated: So it should be understood that all this must be investigated.

original: Bodhipakkhiyabhāvanāvaṇṇanā🔽138. Bodhi vuccati maggasammādiṭṭhi, cattāri ariyasaccāni bujjhatīti katvā, sabhāvato,
analyzed: bodhi pakkhiya bhāvanā vaṇṇanā  bodhi vuccati magga sammādiṭṭhi cattāri ariya saccāni bujjhati iti katvā sabhāvato
translated: The explanation of the meditation subject consisting in mindfulness of breathing🔽is finished.🔽Enlightenment is the right view of the path, so called because it illuminates the four noble truths.

original: taṃsabhāvato ca tassā pakkhe bhavāti bodhipakkhiyā, sativīriyādayo dhammā, tesaṃ
analyzed: tad sabhāvato ca tassā pakkhe bhavāti bodhi pakkhiyā sati vīriya ādayaḥ dhammā tesam
translated: The states consisting in mindfulness, energy, and the rest are enlightenment factors because they exist in association with enlightenment, which is their nature.

original: bodhipakkhiyānaṃ. Paṭipāṭiyāti bodhipakkhiyadesanāpaṭipāṭiyā. Bhāvanaṃ anugantvāti
analyzed: bodhi pakkhiyānam paṭipāṭiyā ati bodhi pakkhiya desanā paṭipāṭiyā bhāvanam anugantvā iti
translated: The meditation subject consisting in the enlightenment factors is the meditation subject for developing those enlightenment factors.🔽The order should be in the forward order.

original: anukkamena pavattaṃ bhāvanaṃ patvā. Tenāha “paṭipajjitvā”ti. Saupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā
analyzed: anukkamena pavattam bhāvanam patvā tena āha paṭipajjitvā iti sa upādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā
translated: and he reached the development that had arisen in due course. Hence it was said above: “having practiced” .

original: vasena khīṇāsavassa seṭṭhabhāvaṃ lokassa pākaṭaṃ katvā dassetuṃ sakkā, na itarāya
analyzed: vasena khīṇāsavassa seṭṭha bhāvam lokassa pākaṭam katvā dassetum sakkā na itarāya
translated: The state of being the world’s chief can be shown in the case of one who has destroyed the taints by means of the element of extinction with substrate remaining,🔽but not in the case of one by means of the element of extinction without substrate remaining,

original: sabbaso apaññattibhāvūpagamane tassa adassanatoti vuttaṃ “parinibbātīti kilesaparinibbānena
analyzed: sabbaso apaññatti bhāva upagamane tassa adassanato ti vuttam parinibbāti iti kilesa parinibbānena
translated: because the latter is not seen to have gone over to the state of being completely unclassifiable. Hence it was said: “he attains extinction” by means of the extinction of defilements.

original: parinibbāyatī”ti. Vinivattetvāti tato catuvaṇṇato nīharitvā.
analyzed: parinibbāyati iti vinivattetvā ati tatas catuvaṇṇataḥ nīharitvā
translated: “Having turned away” : having taken away from the four castes.

original: 140. Tamevatthanti “khīṇāsavova devamanussesu seṭṭho”ti vuttamevatthaṃ.
analyzed: tam eva attham ti khīṇāsavaḥ iva deva manussesu seṭṭhaḥ ti vuttam eva attham
translated: “That same matter” : the matter stated thus: “Only he who has destroyed the taints is the chief among gods and men.”

original: Seṭṭhacchedakavādamevāti jātibrāhmaṇānaṃ seṭṭhabhāvasamucchedakameva kathaṃ. Dassetvā
analyzed: seṭṭha chedaka vādam eva ati jāti brāhmaṇānam seṭṭha bhāva samucchedakam eva katham dassetvā
translated: “The doctrine of the annihilation of the chief” : the doctrine that the chiefness of the brahmins by birth is annihilated.🔽Having shown, having spoken.

original: bhāsitvā. Suttantaṃ vinivattetvāti pubbe lokiyadhammasandassanavasena pavattaṃ aggaññasuttaṃ
analyzed: bhāsitvā suttantam vinivattetvā ti pubbe lokiya dhamma sandassana vasena pavattam aggañña suttam
translated: “Having turned away the sutta” : having taken away from the Aggivessana sutta, which occurs in the way of showing mundane states,

original: “sattannaṃ bodhipakkhiyānaṃ dhammānaṃ bhāvanamanvāyā”tiādinā tato vinivattetvā nīharitvā
analyzed: sattannam bodhi pakkhiyānam dhammānam bhāvanam anvāyāti ādinā tatas vinivattetvā nīharitvā
translated: by means of the words: “The practice of the seven factors of enlightenment” , etc.

original: tena asaṃsaṭṭhaṃ katvā. Āvajjantāti samannāharantā. Anumajjantāti pubbenāparaṃ atthato vicarantāti.
analyzed: tena a saṃsaṭṭham katvā āvajjanta ati samannāharantā anumajjanta ati pubbena aparam atthataḥ vicarantā ati
translated: and so he did not associate with them. They were reflecting : they were giving attention to it. They were pondering : they were investigating it in meaning by way of the previous and the subsequent.

original: Aggaññasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā.
analyzed: aggañña sutta vaṇṇanāya līna attha ppakāsanā
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the word “līna” in the commentary on the Agganñā Sutta is finished.

original: 5. Sampasādanīyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sampasādanīya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Sampasādanīya Sutta is finished.

original: Sāriputtasīhanādavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Lion’s Roar of Sāriputta is finished.

original: 141. Pāvārenti sañchādenti sarīraṃ etenāti pāvāro, vatthaṃ. Pāvaraṇaṃ vā pāvāro,
analyzed: pāvārenti sañchādenti sarīram etena ati pāvāraḥ vattham pāvaraṇam vā pāvāraḥ
translated: Pāvāra means a cloth. Pāvāra is a cloth that covers the body. Or pāvāra is a covering.

original: “vatthaṃ dussa”nti pariyāyasaddā eteti dussameva pāvāro, so etassa bahuvidho anekakoṭippabhedo🔽bhaṇḍabhūto atthīti dussapāvāriko. So kira pubbe daharakāle dussapāvārabhaṇḍameva
analyzed: vattham dussanti pariyāya saddāḥ ete iti dussamā iva pāvāro saḥ etassa bahuvidhaḥ aneka koṭi ppabhedaḥ  bhaṇḍa bhūtaḥ atthi iti dussapāvāriko so kira pubbe dahara kāle dussa pāvāra bhaṇḍam eva
translated: These are synonyms: cloth, cloth, cloth. Therefore cloth is a pāvāra. It is a pāvāra that has many kinds, that has many divisions in the millions.

original: bahuṃ pariggahetvā vāṇijjaṃ akāsi, tena naṃ seṭṭhiṭṭhāne ṭhitampi “pāvāriko” tveva
analyzed: bahum pariggahetvā vāṇijjam akāsi tena nam seṭṭhi ṭhāne ṭhitam pi pāvārikaḥ tu eva
translated: It is said that in the past, in his youth, he made a living by collecting many kinds of cloth pāvāra goods and trading in them. Therefore, even though he was placed in the position of a merchant, they still knew him as “Pāvārika.”

original: sañjānanti. Bhagavatīti iti-saddo ādiattho, pakārattho vā, tena bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: sañjānanti bhagavati iti iti saddo ādi attho pakāra atthaḥ vā tena bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā
translated: Bhagavatī : the word iti has the meaning of “thus” or the meaning of “because.” By that he approached the Blessed One and said:

original: therena vuttavacanaṃ sabbaṃ saṅgaṇhāti. “Kasmā evaṃ avocā”ti tathāvacane kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: therena vutta vacanam sabbam saṅgaṇhāti kasmai evam avoca ati tathā vacane kāraṇam
translated: He gathers up all that the Elder said. “Why did he say it?” He asks the reason for the saying in this way.

original: pucchitvā “somanassapavedanattha”nti kasmā payojanaṃ vissajjitaṃ, tayidaṃ ambaṃ puṭṭhassa
analyzed: pucchitvā somanassa pavedana ttham ti kasmā payojanam vissajjitam tayā idam puṭṭhassa
translated: “For the purpose of announcing his own happiness,” he replies the purpose. This is like the man who, when asked about a mango,

original: labujaṃ byākaraṇasadisanti? Nayidamevaṃ cintetabbaṃ. Yā hissa therassa tadā bhagavati🔽somanassuppatti, sā niddhāritarūpā kāraṇabhāvena coditā, tasmā evaṃ avocāti, sā eva
analyzed: byākaraṇa sadisanti na yidam evam cintetabbam yā hi ssa therassa tadā bhagavati  sā niddhārita rūpā kāraṇa bhāvena coditā tasmai evam avocāti sā eva
translated: answers by talking about a breadfruit tree. But this should not be thought. For the Elder’s happiness on that occasion🔽in the Blessed One was remembered by him and then brought forward as the reason, and that is why he said it.

original: ca yasmā niddhāritarūpā pavedanavasena bhagavato sammukhā tathāvacanaṃ payojeti,
analyzed: ca yasmai niddhārita rūpā bhagavataḥ sammukhā tathā vacanam
translated: And since that very happiness was remembered by him and then brought forward as the purpose by his announcing it in the Blessed One’s presence in this way,

original: tasmā “attano uppannasomanassapavedanattha”nti payojanabhāvena vissajjitaṃ.
analyzed: tasmai attanaḥ uppanna somanassa pavedana tthanti payojana bhāvena vissajjitam
translated: “For the purpose of announcing his own happiness that had arisen” is the reply as the purpose.

original: Tatrāti tasmiṃ somanassapavedane. Vihāre nivāsaparivattanavasena sunivatthanivāsano. Ābhujitvāti ābandhitvā.
analyzed: tatra ati tasmin somanassa pavedane vihāre nivāsa parivattana vasena sunivattha nivāsanaḥ ābhujitvā ati ābandhitvā
translated: “There” is in that announcement of his own happiness. “Having put on his waistband” means having put on his lower robe by way of changing his dwelling. “Having fastened it” means having fastened it.

original: Samāpattito vuṭṭhāya “aho santo vatāyaṃ ariyavihāro”ti samāpattisukhapaccavekkhaṇamukhena
analyzed: samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāya aho santaḥ vata ayam ariya vihāro ti samāpatti sukha paccavekkhaṇa mukhena
translated: Having emerged from the attainment, he reviewed the bliss of the attainment with the words, “How peaceful this Ariyan state of attainment is!”

original: attano guṇe anussarituṃ āraddho, ārabhitvā ca nesaṃ taṃ taṃ sāmaññavisesavibhāgavasena
analyzed: attanaḥ guṇe anussaritum āraddhaḥ ārabhitvā ca nesam tam tam sāmañña visesa vibhāga vasena
translated: He began to recollect his own special qualities, and having begun, he recollected them by way of the various distinctions of the special qualities of the monk’s life.

original: anussari. Tathā hi “samādhī”ti sāmaññato gahitasseva “paṭhamaṃ jhāna”ntiādinā visesavibhāgo,
analyzed: anussari tathā hi samādhi iti sāmaññataḥ gahitassa iva paṭhamam jhāna nti ādinā visesa vibhāgaḥ
translated: For thus the distinction of the special qualities of the first jhāna, etc., is pointed out by way of the general term “concentration” .

original: “paññā”ti sāmaññato ca gahitasseva “vipassanāñāṇa”ntiādinā visesavibhāgo uddhaṭo.
analyzed: paññā iti sāmaññato ca gahitassa iva vipassanā ñāṇa nti ādinā visesa vibhāgaḥ uddhaṭaḥ
translated: And the distinction of the special qualities of the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers is pointed out by way of the general term “wisdom” .

original: “Lokiyābhiññāsu dibbacakkhuñāṇasseva gahaṇaṃ therassa itarehi sātisayanti dassetu”nti
analyzed: lokiya abhiññāsu dibba cakkhu ñāṇassa iva gahaṇam therassa itarehi dassetunti
translated: “The Elder’s inclusion of only the knowledge of the divine eye among the mundane kinds of direct knowledge is intended to show that it is superior to the others” .

original: vadanti, pubbenivāsañāṇampi pana “kappasatasahassādhikassā”tiādinā kiccavasena dassitameva,
analyzed: vadanti pubbenivāsa ñāṇam pi pana kappa sata sahassa adhikassa ati ādinā kicca vasena dassitam eva
translated: But the knowledge of the recollection of past lives is also shown by way of its function in the passage: “For more than a hundred thousand eons” .

original: lakkhaṇahāravasena vā itaresaṃ pettha gahitatā veditabbā.🔽Atthappabhedassa sallakkhaṇavibhāvanavavatthānakaraṇasamatthaṃ atthe pabhedagataṃ
analyzed: lakkhaṇa hāra vasena vā itaresam pa ittha gahita tā veditabbā  attha ppabhedassa sat lakkhaṇa vibhāvana vavatthāna karaṇa samattham atthe pabheda gatam
translated: Or the inclusion of the others here should be understood by way of the selection of their characteristics.

original: ñāṇaṃ atthapaṭisambhidā. Tathā dhammappabhedassa sallakkhaṇavibhāvanavavatthānakaraṇasamatthaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇam attha paṭisambhidā tathā dhamma ppabhedassa sat lakkhaṇa vibhāvana vavatthāna karaṇa samattham
translated: The knowledge that is able to discern, analyze, and determine the divisions of meaning is the discrimination of meaning. Likewise, the knowledge that is able to discern, analyze, and determine the divisions of the Dhamma is the discrimination of the Dhamma.

original: dhamme pabhedagataṃ ñāṇaṃ dhammapaṭisambhidā. Niruttipabhedassa sallakkhaṇavibhāvanavavatthānakaraṇasamatthaṃ
analyzed: dhamme pabheda gatam ñāṇam dhamma paṭisambhidā nirutti pabhedassa sat lakkhaṇa vibhāvana vavatthāna karaṇa samattham
translated: Knowledge of the classification of ideas is the discrimination of ideas.🔽Knowledge of the classification of language is the discrimination of language.

original: niruttiyaṃ pabhedagataṃ ñāṇaṃ niruttipaṭisambhidā. Paṭibhānappabhedassa sallakkhaṇavibhāvanavavatthāna🔽karaṇasamatthaṃ paṭibhāne pabhedagataṃ ñāṇaṃ paṭibhānapaṭisambhidā. Ayamettha saṅkhepo,
analyzed: niruttiyam pabheda gatam ñāṇam nirutti paṭisambhidā paṭibhāna ppabhedassa sat lakkhaṇa vibhāvana vavatthāna  karaṇa samattham paṭibhāne pabheda gatam ñāṇam paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ
translated: Knowledge of the classification of perspicuity is the discrimination of perspicuity.🔽This is the brief account here;

original: vitthāro pana visuddhimagge, taṃ saṃvaṇṇanāsu vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Sāvakavisaye
analyzed: vitthāraḥ pana visuddhi magge tam saṃvaṇṇanāsu vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ sāvaka visaye
translated: the detailed account should be understood as in the Visuddhimagga and in the commentaries.🔽Knowledge of the classification of disciples’ special qualities is knowledge of the disciples’ perfections.

original: paramukkaṃsagataṃ ñāṇaṃ sāvakapāramiñāṇaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ viya sabbañeyyadhammesu.
analyzed: param ukkaṃsa gatam ñāṇam sāvaka pārami ñāṇam sabbaññu taññāṇam viya sabba ñeyya dhammesu
translated: It is like knowledge of all kinds, in all its aspects, that is to say, knowledge of all that can be known.🔽For this too has no separate preliminary work;

original: Tassāpi hi visuṃ parikammaṃ nāma natthi, sāvakapāramiyā pana sammadeva paripūritattā
analyzed: tassa api hi visum parikammam nāma natthi sāvaka pāramiyā pana sammat eva paripūrita ttā
translated: but it is reached by the mere fulfilment of the disciples’ perfections,🔽and it is reached by the mere attainment of the supreme path.

original: aggamaggasamadhigamenevassa samadhigamo hoti. Sabbaññutaññāṇasseva sammāsambuddhānaṃ
analyzed: agga magga samadhigamena iva assa samadhigamaḥ hoti sabbaññu ta ññāṇassa iva sammāsambuddhānam
translated: It is only in the case of the knowledge of omniscience that the Blessed One,

original: yāva nisinnapallaṅkā anussaratoti yojanā.
analyzed: yāva nisinna pallaṅkā anussarato ti yojanā
translated: who is fully enlightened, can recollect it while sitting on the seat of enlightenment.

original: Bhagavato sīlaṃ nissāya guṇe anussaritumāraddhoti yojanā. Yasmā guṇānaṃ bahubhāvato
analyzed: bhagavataḥ sīlam nissāya guṇe anussaritum āraddhaḥ iti yojanā yasmai guṇānam bahu bhāvataḥ
translated: The construction is: “having taken the Blessed One’s virtue as the basis, he began to recollect his special qualities.” Since the qualities are many,

original: nesaṃ ekajjhaṃ āpāthāgamanaṃ natthi, sati ca tasmiṃ anirūpitarūpeneva anussaraṇena
analyzed: ekajjham āpātha āgamanam natthi sati ca tasmin a nirūpita rūpena iva anussaraṇena
translated: they cannot all come within the focus of attention at once. And when they do, they must be recollected without being discriminated.

original: bhavitabbaṃ, tasmā thero savisaye ṭhatvā te anupadaṃ sarūpato anussari, anussaranto
analyzed: bhavitabbam tasmā thero sa visaye ṭhatvā te anupadam sarūpataḥ anussari anussarantaḥ
translated: Therefore, the Elder, remaining in the domain of virtue, recollected the special qualities in their proper sequence, in their individual essence.

original: ca sabbapaṭhamaṃ sīlaṃ anussari, taṃ dassento “bhagavato sīlaṃ nissāyā”ti āha, sīlaṃ🔽ārabbhāti attho. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Yasmā cettha thero ekekavasena bhagavato🔽guṇe anussaritvā tato paraṃ catukkapañcakādivasena anussari, tasmā “cattāro iddhipāde”ti
analyzed: ca sabba paṭhamam sīlam anussari tam dassentaḥ bhagavataḥ sīlam nissāya ati āha sīlam  ārabbha ati attho sesa padesu pi esā iva nayaḥ yasmā ca ittha theraḥ ekeka vasena bhagavataḥ  guṇe anussaritvā tato param catukka pañcaka ādi vasena tasmā cattāro iddhipādā iti
translated: Recollecting them in this way, he first recollected virtue. Showing this, the Exalted One said: “Having taken the Blessed One’s virtue as the basis.”🔽The meaning is: “having made virtue the point of departure.” The same method applies to the other terms.🔽But since the Elder recollected the Blessed One’s special qualities one by one, and then recollected them in groups of four, five, etc.,

original: yathā nāma puriso suviduggaṃ mahāgahanaṃ mahāvanaṃ chindanto antarantarā nisānasilāyaṃ
analyzed: yathā nāma purisaḥ suviduggam mahā gahanam mahā vanam chindantaḥ antar antarā nisāna silāyam
translated: Just as a man cutting a very difficult, large, dense jungle of trees might sharpen his axe from time to time on a stone,

original: pharasuṃ sunisitaṃ karoti, evameva nisānasilāsadisiyo samāpattiyo antarantarā samāpajjitvā
analyzed: pharasum su nisitam karoti evam eva nisāna silāsa disiyaḥ samāpattiyaḥ antar antarā samāpajjitvā
translated: so too, the bodhisattva enters the jhānas and the immaterial states from time to time,

original: ñāṇassa tikkhavisadasūrabhāvaṃ sampādetuṃ anulomapaṭilomato paccekaṃ paṭiccasamuppādaṅgavasena
analyzed: ñāṇassa tikkha visada sūra bhāvam sampādetum anuloma paṭilomato paccekam paṭiccasamuppāda aṅga vasena
translated: and he comprehends the principle of conditionality in forward and reverse order by way of the factors of the dependent origination, in order to bring about the sharpness, clarity and brightness of his knowledge.

original: sammasanto divase divase lakkhakoṭilakkhakoṭiphalasamāpattiyo samāpajjati, taṃ sandhāya
analyzed: sammasantaḥ divase divase lakkha koṭi lakkha koṭi phala samāpattiyaḥ samāpajjati tam sandhāya
translated: He enters the jhānas and immaterial states, which are like the stone, and which are worth a hundred or a thousand samāpattis, day by day.

original: vuttaṃ ‘catuvīsati…pe… mahāvajirañāṇaṃ nissāyā’ti”. Nanu bhagavato samāpattisamāpajjane
analyzed: vuttam catuvīsatipe mahāvajira ñāṇam nissāya ati nanu bhagavato samāpatti samāpajjane
translated: With reference to him it is said: “Having relied on the great diamond-like knowledge, which is worth a hundred or a thousand samāpattis, and which is the means to the attainment of the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers” .

original: parikamme payojanaṃ natthīti? Nayidaṃ ekantikaṃ. Tathā hi vedanāpaṭippaṇāmanādīsu
analyzed: parikamme payojanam natthi iti na idam ekantikam tathā hi vedanā paṭippaṇā mana ādīsu
translated: But does not the Exalted One have no need for preliminary work in order to enter upon samāpatti? This is not absolute. For in the case of the alteration of feeling, etc.,🔽he entered upon the jhānas and immaterial states with preliminary work. But in the case of the attainment of the supernormal powers,

original: savisesaṃ parikammapubbaṅgamena samāpattiyo samāpajji. Apare pana “lokiyasamāpattisamāpajjane
analyzed: sa visesam parikamma pubbaṅgamena samāpattiyaḥ samāpajji apare pana lokiya samāpatti samāpajjane
translated: he entered upon them without preliminary work. In the case of the attainment of the mundane jhānas and immaterial states,

original: parikammena payojanaṃ natthi. Lokuttarasamāpattisamāpajjane tajjaṃ parikammaṃ icchitabbamevā”ti vadanti.
analyzed: parikammena payojanam natthi lokuttara samāpatti samāpajjane tajjam parikammam icchitabbam eva ati vadanti
translated: There is no need for preliminary work in the case of the attainment of the supramundane jhānas. But preliminary work is required for the attainment of the supramundane jhānas.”

original: “Aparamparā”ti padaṃ yesaṃ desanāya atthi, te aparampariyāva. Kusalapaññattiyanti🔽kusaladhammānaṃ paññāpane. Anuttaroti uttamo. Upanissaye ṭhatvāti ñāṇūpanissaye ṭhatvā🔽yādiso pubbūpanissayo pubbayogo, tattha patiṭṭhāya. Mahantato saddahati paṭipakkhavigamena🔽ñāṇassa viya saddhāyapi tikkhavisadabhāvāpattito. Avasesaarahantehīti pakatisāvakehi.
analyzed: aparamparā ti padam yesam desanāya atthi te kusala paññattiyanti  kusala dhammānam paññāpane anuttaro ti uttamaḥ upanissaye ṭhatvā ati ñāṇa upanissaye ṭhatvā  yādisaḥ pubba upanissayaḥ pubba yogo tattha patiṭṭhāya mahantataḥ saddahati paṭipakkha vigamena  ñāṇassa viya saddhāya api tikkha visada bhāva āpattitaḥ avasesa arahantehi iti pakati sāvakehi
translated: “Without a break” : those whose teaching is without a break are “without a break.” In the announcement of profitable dhammas :🔽in the announcement of profitable dhammas. Incomparable : supreme. Having stood in the condition : having stood in the condition of knowledge.

original: Asīti mahātherā paramatthadīpaniyaṃ theragāthāvaṇṇanāyaṃ nāmato uddhaṭā. Cattāro🔽mahātherāti mahākassapaanuruddhamahākaccānamahākoṭṭhikattherā. Tesupi aggasāvakesu
analyzed: asi iti mahā therā paramatthadīpaniyam theragāthāvaṇṇanāyam nāmataḥ uddhaṭā cattāro 🔽mahā therā ti mahākassapa anuruddha mahākaccāna mahākoṭṭhika therā tesu pi aggasāvakesu

original: sāriputtatthero paññāya visiṭṭhabhāvato. Sāriputtattheratopi eko paccekabuddho tikkhavisadañāṇo
analyzed: sāriputta theraḥ paññāya visiṭṭha bhāvataḥ sāriputta therataḥ pi ekaḥ paccekabuddhaḥ tikkha visada ñāṇo
translated: The Elder Sāriputta was distinguished for his understanding. And a certain Paccekabuddha was distinguished for his understanding, which was keener and clearer than that of the Elder Sāriputta.🔽Because of the greatness of his aspiration and because of the accumulation of his knowledge.

original: abhinīhāramahantatāya sambhatañāṇasambhārattā. Satipi paccekabodhiyā avisesesu bahūsu
analyzed: abhinīhāra mahanta tāya sambhata ñāṇa sambhāra ttā sati pi pacceka bodhiyā avisesesu bahūsu
translated: Although there is no difference in the enlightenment of Paccekabuddhas,

original: ekajjhaṃ sannipatitesu pubbayogavasena lokiye visaye siyā kassaci ñāṇassa visiṭṭhatāti
analyzed: ekajjham sannipatitesu pubba yoga vasena lokiye visaye siyā kassaci ñāṇassa visiṭṭha tā ti
translated: when they assemble together, one of them may be distinguished for his knowledge in the field of the mundane sciences, by virtue of his previous practice.

original: dassetuṃ “sace panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. “Sabbaññubuddhova buddhaguṇe mahantato saddahatī”ti
analyzed: dassetum sace pana iti ādi vuttam sabbaññu buddhaḥ iva buddha guṇe mahantataḥ saddahati iti
translated: In order to show this, the following sutta is stated: “If, bhikkhus, a number of bhikkhus were to assemble together, and if the bhikkhu who was the most distinguished of them for length of time in the bhikkhu’s state were to attain arahatship, and if he were to declare: ‘I have destroyed all defilements and attained arahatship,’ and if he were to die at that very moment, he would not be able to demonstrate the Buddha-qualities. Only a Buddha, fully enlightened, would be able to demonstrate the Buddha-qualities in their greatness.”

original: idaṃ heṭṭhā āgatadesanāsotavasena vuttaṃ. Buddhā hi buddhaguṇe mahattaṃ paccakkhatova
analyzed: idam heṭṭhā āgata desanā sota vasena vuttam buddhāḥ hi buddha guṇe mahattam paccakkhataḥ iva
translated: This statement is made on the basis of the teaching heard by the Buddha in a previous birth. For the Buddhas see the greatness of the Buddha-qualities with their own eyes,

original: passanti, na saddahanavasena.
analyzed: passanti na saddahana vasena
translated: not on the basis of hearsay.

original: Idāni yathāvuttamatthaṃ upamāya vibhāvetuṃ “seyyathāpi nāmā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Gambhīro🔽uttānoti gambhīro vā uttāno vāti jānanatthaṃ. “Evamevā”tiādi yathādassitāya upamāya
analyzed: idāni upamāya vibhāvetum seyyathā api nāma ati ādi āraddham 🔽uttānaḥ ti gambhīraḥ vā uttānaḥ vā ati jānana attham evam eva atiādi yathā dassitāya upamāya
translated: Now, in order to illustrate by means of a simile the meaning just stated, the following sutta is begun: “Suppose, bhikkhus, there were a deep lake in a mountain recess, clear, limpid, and undisturbed,🔽so that a man with eyes could see shells, gravel, and pebbles, and also shoals of fish swimming about and resting.”

original: upameyyena saṃsandanaṃ. Buddhaguṇesu appamattavisayampi lokiyamahājanassa ñāṇaṃ apavattitarūpeneva
analyzed: upameyyena saṃsandanam buddha guṇesu appamatta visayam pi lokiya mahā janassa ñāṇam apavattita rūpena iva
translated: and the simile is the corresponding. The knowledge of ordinary people of the world, whose range is limited to the things of the world, is confined to the things of the world.

original: pavattati anavattitasabhāvattāti vuttaṃ “ekabyāma…pe… veditabbā”ti. Tattha ñātaudakaṃ
analyzed: pavattati anavattita sabhāva ttā iti vuttam eka byāmape veditabbā ti tattha ñātaudakam
translated: It does not extend beyond them, because it is not of the nature to do so. Therefore it is said: “It should be understood as a cubit of water, etc.”🔽Herein, “like a cubit of known water” means like a cubit of water whose measure is known.

original: viyāti pamāṇato ñātaudakaṃ viya. Ariyānaṃ pana tattha attano visaye pavattanakañāṇaṃ
analyzed: viyāti pamāṇataḥ ñātaudakam viya ariyānam pana tattha attanaḥ visaye pavattanaka ñāṇam
translated: But the knowledge of the Noble Ones, which occurs in their own range,

original: pavattitarūpeneva pavattati attano paṭivedhānurūpaṃ, abhinīhārānurūpañca avattitasabhāvattāti🔽dassento “dasabyāmayottenā”tiādimāha. Tattha paṭividdhasaccānampi paṭipakkhavidhamanapubbayogavisesavasena🔽ñāṇaṃ sātisayaṃ, mahānubhāvañca hotīti imamatthaṃ dassetuṃ sotāpannañāṇassa dasabyāmaudakaṃ
analyzed: pavattita rūpena iva pavattati paṭivedha anurūpam abhinīhāra anurūpam ca  dassentaḥ tattha paṭividdha saccānam pi paṭipakkha vidhamana pubba yoga visesa vasena  ñāṇam sa atisayam mahā anubhāvañca hoti iti imam attham dassetum sotāpanna ñāṇassa dasa byāma audakam
translated: occurs in the nature of extending, because it is of the nature to do so, in accordance with their own penetration and in accordance with their aspiration.🔽Showing this, he says: “By a ten-cubit rope,” etc.🔽Herein, in order to show the meaning: “The knowledge of stream-enterers, etc., becomes more and more powerful and more and more sublime by the special effort of removing the opposing side,”

original: opammabhāvena dassetvā tato paresaṃ dasuttaradiguṇadasaguṇaasītiguṇavisiṭṭhaṃ udakaṃ
analyzed: opamma bhāvena dassetvā tatas paresam dasa uttara diguṇa dasaguṇa asīti guṇa visiṭṭham udakam
translated: he shows the ten-cubit water as the simile for the knowledge of stream-enterers, and then the water distinguished by ten, a hundred, a thousand, and eighty-four thousand cubits,

original: opammaṃ katvā dassitaṃ. Nanu evaṃ sante buddhaguṇā parimitaparicchinnā, therena ca
analyzed: opammam katvā dassitam nanu evam sante buddha guṇā parimita paricchinnā therena ca
translated: The Buddha’s qualities are shown by way of a simile.🔽But if that is so, then the Buddha’s qualities are limited and defined, and the Elder has fallen into the error of defining and knowing them?

original: te paricchijja ñātāti āpajjatīti? Nāpajjatīti dassento “tattha yathā so puriso”tiādimāha.
analyzed: te paricchijja ñātā ati āpajjati iti na āpajjati iti dassento tattha yathā saḥ purisaḥ iti ādim āha
translated: To show that he has not fallen into that error, the Master says, “Herein, just as that man,” etc.

original: Tattha so purisoti so caturāsītibyāmasahassappamāṇena yottena caturāsītibyāmasahassaṭṭhāne🔽mahāsamudde udakaṃ minitvā ṭhito puriso. So hi therassa upamābhāvena gahito. Dhammanvayenāti
analyzed: tattha saḥ purisaḥ ti saḥ caturāsīti byāma sahassa ppamāṇena yottena caturāsīti byāma sahassa ṭṭhāne  mahā samudde udakam minitvā ṭhitaḥ puriso saḥ hi therassa upamā bhāvena gahitaḥ dhamma anvayena ati
translated: Herein, that man: the man who, having measured out water in the great ocean with a water-pot measuring four cubits in height and four spans in circumference,

original: anumānañāṇena. Tañhi siddhaṃ dhammaṃ anugantvā pavattanato “dhammanvayo”ti vuccati,
analyzed: anumāna ñāṇena tat hi siddham dhammam anugantvā pavattanataḥ dhamma anvayaḥ ti vuccati
translated: stood there. He is taken as the simile for the Elder. By the method of inference: by the knowledge of inference. For that is called “the method of inference” because it occurs by following a known fact.

original: tathā anvayavasena atthassa bujjhanato anvayabuddhi, anumeyyaṃ anuminotīti anumānaṃ,
analyzed: tathā anvaya vasena atthassa bujjhanataḥ anvaya buddhi anumeyyam anuminoti iti anumānam
translated: Similarly, it is called “the knowledge of inference” because it awakens to the meaning by the method of inference. It is called “inference” because it infers what is to be inferred.

original: nidassane diṭṭhanayena anumeyyaṃ gaṇhātīti “nayaggāho”ti ca vuccati. Tenāha “dhammanvayenā”tiādi.
analyzed: nidassane diṭṭhanayena anumeyyam gaṇhāti iti nayaggāhaḥ ti ca vuccati tena āha dhamma nvayena atiādi
translated: And it is called “the grasping of the method” because it grasps what is to be inferred by the method seen in the demonstration. Therefore he said, “By the method of inference,” etc.

original: Svāyaṃ dhammanvayo na yassa kassaci hoti, atha kho tathārūpassa aggasāvakassevāti
analyzed: svā ayam dhamma anvayaḥ na yassa kassaci hoti atha kho tathārūpassa aggasāvakassa iva āti
translated: This is not the case with anyone else, but only with a chief disciple of such a kind.🔽Therefore it is said: “Standing in the knowledge of a chief disciple.”

original: āha “sāvakapāramiñāṇe ṭhatvā”ti. Yadi thero buddhaguṇe ekadesato paccakkhe katvā
analyzed: āha sāvaka pārami ñāṇe yadi theraḥ buddha guṇe eka desato paccakkhe katvā
translated: If the Elder had seen the Buddha’s qualities only in part,

original: tadaññe nayaggāhena gaṇhi, nanu evaṃ sante buddhaguṇā parimitaparicchinnā āpannāti?
analyzed: tad aññe naya ggāhena nanu evam sante buddha guṇā parimita paricchinnā āpannā ati
translated: and had grasped the rest by inference, would not the Buddha’s qualities then have been limited and finite?

original: Nayidaṃ evanti dassento “anantā aparimāṇā”ti.
analyzed: na yidam evanti dassentaḥ anantā
translated: To show that this is not so, it is said: “infinite, immeasurable.”

original: “Saddahatī”ti vatvā puna tamevatthaṃ vibhāvento “therena hi…pe… bahutarā”ti āha.
analyzed: sat dahati iti vatvā puna āha
translated: After saying “he believed,” the Elder again elucidated the same idea, saying: “For the Elder … would have been more.”

original: Kathaṃ panāyamattho evaṃ daṭṭhabboti evaṃ adhippāyabhedakaṃ upamāya saññāpetuṃ “yathā
analyzed: katham pana ayam atthaḥ evam daṭṭhabbaḥ iti evam adhippāya bhedakam upamāya saññāpetum yathā
translated: But how should this idea be regarded? In order to show this by means of a simile that distinguishes the intention, it is said: “Just as …

original: kathaṃ viyā”tiādi vuttaṃ “upamāyamidhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānantī”ti
analyzed: katham viya atiādi vuttam upamāyam idha ekacce viññū purisāḥ bhāsitassa attham ājānanti iti
translated: Some wise men understand the meaning of what is said by means of a simile.”

original: ito nava ito navāti ito majjhaṭṭhānato yāva dakkhiṇatīrā nava ito majjhaṭṭhānato
analyzed: itas nava itas nava ati itas majjha ṭṭhānataḥ yāva dakkhiṇa tīrā nava itas majjha ṭṭhānataḥ
translated: From here nine times nine: from this central point to the southern shore nine times, from this central point to the northern shore nine times,

original: yāva uttaratīrā nava. Idāni yathāvuttamatthaṃ suttena samatthetuṃ “buddhopī”ti gāthamāha.
analyzed: yāvaḥ uttara tīrāḥ nava idāni yathāvuttam attham suttena samatthetum buddhaḥ api iti gātham āha
translated: and nine up to the northern bank. Now, in order to establish the meaning stated by the text, he said the stanza beginning with “Buddhopi.”

original: Yamakayugaḷamahānadīmahogho viyāti dvinnaṃ ekato samāgatattā yugaḷabhūtānaṃ mahānadīnaṃ mahogho viya.
analyzed: yamaka yugaḷa mahā nadī mahā oghaḥ viyāti ekatas yugaḷa bhūtānam mahā nadīnam mahā oghaḥ
translated: Like the great flood of the twin rivers Yamuṇa and Godāvarī: like the great flood of the two rivers that have come together as one.🔽Having made it worthy: having made it worthy, suitable,

original: Anucchavikaṃ katvāti yoyaṃ mama pasādo buddhaguṇe ārabbha ogāḷho hutvā uppanno, taṃ
analyzed: anucchavikam katvā iti yaḥ yam mama pasādaḥ buddha guṇe ārabbha ogāḍhaḥ hutvā uppannaḥ tam
translated: in conformity with the faith that has arisen in me, having plunged into the Buddha’s special qualities.

original: anucchavikaṃ anurūpaṃ katvā. Paṭiggahetuṃ sampaṭicchituṃ añño koci na sakkhissati
analyzed: anucchavikam anurūpam katvā paṭiggahetum sampaṭicchitum aññaḥ koci na sakkhissati
translated: No one else is able to receive it, to accept it,

original: yāthāvato anavabujjhanato. Paṭiggahetuṃ sakkoti tassa hetuto, paccayato, sabhāvato,
analyzed: yāthāvataḥ an avabujjhanataḥ paṭiggahetum sakkoti tassa hetutaḥ paccayataḥ sabhāvato
translated: because he does not understand it as it really is. He is able to receive it because he has the cause, the condition, the nature,🔽the function, and the fruit of it, because he has penetrated it thoroughly.

original: kiccato, phalato sammadeva paṭivijjhanato. Pūrattanti puṇṇabhāvo. Paggharaṇakāleti
analyzed: kiccato phalato sammat eva paṭivijjhanato pūrattanti puṇṇa bhāvaḥ paggharaṇa kāle ti
translated: The fullness: the state of being full. At the time of the outpouring:

original: vikiraṇakāle, patanakāleti attho. “Pasanno”ti iminā pasādassa vattamānatā dīpitāti
analyzed: vikiraṇa kāle patana kāle iti attho pasannaḥ iti iminā pasādassa vattamāna tā dīpitā ati
translated: at the time of the scattering, at the time of the falling down, is the meaning. “Pasanno” shows the present state of the faith.

original: “uppannasaddho”ti imināpi saddhāya paccuppannatā pakāsitāti āha “evaṃ saddahāmīti
analyzed: uppanna saddhaḥ ti iminā api saddhāya paccuppanna tā pakāsitā ati āha evam saddahāmi iti
translated: “Uppannasaddho” shows the presentness of the faith. Therefore he said: “I have faith thus”

original: attho”ti. Abhiññāyatīti abhiñño, adhiko abhiñño bhiyyobhiñño, so eva atisayavacanicchāvasena🔽“bhiyyobhiññataro”ti vuttoti āha “bhiyyataro abhiññāto”ti. Dutiyavikappe pana abhijānātīti
analyzed: attho ti abhiññāyati iti abhiññaḥ adhikaḥ abhiññaḥ bhiyyobhiñño saḥ eva atisaya vacana icchā vasena  bhiyyobhiññataraḥ iti vuttaḥ ti āha bhiyyataraḥ abhiññāto ti dutiya vikappe pana abhijānāti iti
translated: ‘I have understood’ is ‘understanding’ . One who has understanding is ‘one who has understanding’ . One who has more understanding is ‘one who has more understanding’ . He is so called because of the wish to express superiority.

original: abhiññā, abhivisiṭṭhā paññā, bhiyyo abhiññā etassāti bhiyyobhiñño, so eva atisayavacanicchāvasena🔽bhiyyobhiññataro, svāyamassa atisayo abhiññāya bhiyyobhāvakatoti āha “bhiyyatarābhiñño🔽vā”ti. Sambujjhati etāyāti sambodhi, sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, aggamaggañāṇañca. Sabbaññutaññāṇapadaṭṭhānañhi
analyzed: abhiññā abhivisiṭṭhā paññā bhiyyas abhiññā etassa ati bhiyyobhiñño so eva atisaya vacana icchā vasena  bhiyyobhiññataraḥ svāyam assa atisayaḥ abhiññāya bhiyyobhāva kato ti āha bhiyyatara abhiññaḥ  vā ati sambujjhati etāya ati sambodhi sabbaññu taññāṇam agga magga ñāṇañca sabbaññu taññāṇa padaṭṭhānam hi
translated: ‘One who has more understanding’ is said. But in the second analysis ‘he understands’ is ‘understanding’ . It is understanding that is distinguished. One who has more understanding is ‘one who has more understanding’ . He is so called because of the wish to express superiority.🔽‘One who has more understanding’ is said. ‘One who has more understanding’ is said.

original: aggamaggañāṇaṃ, aggamaggañāṇapadaṭṭhānañca sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ sambodhi nāma. Tattha
analyzed: aggamagga ñāṇam aggamagga ñāṇa padaṭṭhānañca sabbaññuta ññāṇam sambodhi nāma tattha
translated: ‘He awakens to’ is ‘awakening’ . It is the knowledge of omniscience and the knowledge of the path of Arahantship. For the knowledge of the path of Arahantship is the proximate cause for the knowledge of omniscience, and the knowledge of omniscience is the proximate cause for the knowledge of the path of Arahantship. This is called ‘awakening’ .

original: padhānavasena tadatthadassane paṭhamavikappo, padaṭṭhānavasena dutiyavikappo. Kasmā
analyzed: padhāna vasena tad attha dassane paṭhama vikappo padaṭṭhāna vasena dutiya vikappo kasmā
translated: Herein, the first analysis is by way of the endeavour to see that meaning, and the second analysis is by way of the proximate cause. Why?

original: panettha arahattamaggañāṇasseva gahaṇaṃ, nanu heṭṭhimānipi bhagavato maggañāṇāni
analyzed: pana ittha arahatta magga ñāṇassa iva gahaṇam nanu heṭṭhimāni pi bhagavataḥ magga ñāṇāni
translated: But here only the knowledge of the path of arahatship is meant. Are not the Blessed One’s other paths of knowledge

original: savāsanameva yathāsakaṃ paṭipakkhavidhamanavasena pavattāni. Savāsanappahānañhi ñeyyāvaraṇappahānanti?
analyzed: sa vāsanam eva yathāsakam paṭipakkha vidhamana vasena pavattāni sa vāsanā pahānam hi ñeyya āvaraṇa ppahānam ti
translated: also the abandoning of the defilements together with their traces, since they occur by way of the removal of their opposites according to their respective spheres?

original: Saccametaṃ, taṃ pana aparipuṇṇaṃ paṭipakkhavidhamanassa vippakatabhāvatoti āha “arahattamaggañāṇe
analyzed: saccam etam tam pana aparipuṇṇam paṭipakkha vidhamanassa vippakata bhāvato ti āha arahatta magga ñāṇe
translated: This is true, but that is incomplete, since the removal of the opposites is not yet concluded. Therefore it is said: “or in the knowledge of the path of arahatship.”

original: vā”ti. Aggamaggavasena cettha ariyānaṃ bodhittayapāripūrīti dassetuṃ “arahattamaggeneva
analyzed: vāti agga magga vasena ca ittha ariyānam bodhi ttaya pāripūrī iti dassetum arahatta maggena iva
translated: Here, in order to show that the three kinds of enlightenment of the noble ones are fulfilled by way of the highest path, it is said: “only in the knowledge of the path of arahatship.”

original: hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Nippadesāti anavasesā. Gahitā hontīti arahattamaggena gahitena adhigatena🔽gahitā adhigatā honti. Sabbanti tehi adhigantabbaṃ. Tenāti sambodhinā sabbaññutaññāṇapadaṭṭhānena
analyzed: hi itiādi vuttam nippadesā ati anavasesā gahitā honti iti arahatta maggena gahitena adhigatena  gahitāḥ adhigatāḥ honti sabbanti tehi adhigantabbam tena ati sambodhinā sabbaññuta ññāṇa padaṭṭhānena
translated: “Without remainder” means without exception. “Are included” means that they are included, attained, by the knowledge of the path of arahatship.

original: arahattamaggañāṇena.
analyzed: arahatta magga ñāṇena
translated: “All” means all that is to be attained by that . “By that” means by the knowledge of the path of arahatship, which is the basis for the knowledge of omniscience, for perfect enlightenment.

original: 142. Khādanīyānaṃ uḷāratā sātarasānubhāvenāti āha “madhure āgacchatī”ti. Pasaṃsāya
analyzed: uḷāra tā sāta rasa anubhāvena ati āha madhure āgacchati iti
translated: The excellence of the food is due to its taste and nutritive value. Therefore it is said: “it comes to be sweet.” Praise

original: uḷāratā visiṭṭhabhāvenāti āha “seṭṭhe”ti, obhāsassa uḷāratā mahantabhāvenāti vuttaṃ
analyzed: uḷāra tā visiṭṭha bhāvena ati āha seṭṭhā iti obhāsassa uḷāra tā mahanta bhāvena ati vuttam
translated: “Excellent” : in the sense of pre-eminent, distinguished.🔽“Vast” : in the sense of great, of magnitude.

original: “vipule”ti. Usabhassa ayanti āsabhī, idha pana āsabhī viyāti āsabhī. Tenāha “usabhassa
analyzed: vipulā iti usabhassa ayanti āsabhī idha pana āsabhī viyāti āsabhī tena āha usabhassa
translated: “Like the bull’s” : āsabhī . Here, however, āsabhī is like a bull .🔽Therefore it is said: “like the bull’s voice” .

original: vācāsadisī”ti. Yena pana guṇenassā taṃsadisatā, taṃ dassetuṃ “acalā asampavedhī”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Yato kutoci anussavanaṃ anussavo. Vijjāṭṭhānesu kataparicayānaṃ ācariyānaṃ🔽taṃ tamatthaṃ viññāpentī paveṇī ācariyaparamparā. Kevalaṃ attano matiyā “itikira
analyzed: vācā sadisī iti yena pana guṇena assā taṃsadisa tā tam dassetum acalā a sampavedhī iti  vuttam yatas kutoci anussavanam anussavaḥ vijjāṭṭhānesu kata paricayānam ācariyānam  tam tam attham viññāpentī paveṇī ācariya paramparā kevalam attanaḥ matiyā itikira
translated: “Immovable, unshakable” : this is said in order to show the quality by which it is like that .🔽“Tradition” : the transmission of the meaning of this and that by teachers who have made a study of the fields of knowledge .🔽“Conjecture” : the mere supposition by one’s own mind of “thus” or “thus” .

original: evaṃkirā”ti parikappanā itikira. Piṭakassa ganthassa sampadānato sayaṃ sampadānabhāvena🔽gahaṇaṃ piṭakasampadānaṃ. Yathāsutānaṃ atthānaṃ ākārassa parivitakkanaṃ ākāraparivitakko.
analyzed: evaṃkira ati parikappanā itikira piṭakassa ganthassa sampadānataḥ sayam sampadāna bhāvena  gahaṇam piṭaka sampadānam yathā sutānam atthānam ākārassa parivitakkanam ākāra parivitakkaḥ
translated: “Tradition and conjecture” : the combination of the two.🔽“Tradition and conjecture” : the combination of the two.🔽“Tradition and conjecture” : the combination of the two.

original: Tatheva “evameta”nti diṭṭhiyā nijjhānakkhamanaṃ diṭṭhinijjhānakkhanti. Āgamādhigamehi
analyzed: tathā iva evam etat ti diṭṭhiyāḥ nijjhāna khamanam diṭṭhi nijjhāna kkhanti āgama adhigamehi
translated: “Tradition and conjecture” : the combination of the two.

original: vinā takkamaggaṃ nissāya takkanaṃ takko. Anumānavidhiṃ nissāya nayaggāho. Yasmā buddhavisaye🔽ṭhatvā bhagavato ayaṃ therassa codanā, therassa ca so avisayo, tasmā “paccakkhato🔽ñāṇena paṭivijjhitvā viyā”ti vuttaṃ. Sīhanādo viyāti sīhanādo, taṃsadisatā cassa
analyzed: vinā takka maggam nissāya takkanam takkaḥ anumāna vidhim nissāya naya ggāhaḥ yasmai buddha visaye  ṭhatvā bhagavataḥ ayam therassa codanā therassa ca so avisayaḥ tasmā paccakkhato  ñāṇena paṭivijjhitvā viyā ti vuttam sīha nādaḥ viyā ti sīha nādaḥ tad sadisa tā ca assa
translated: and “reasoning” is the taking up of a line of thought by way of conjecture. “Inference” is the taking up of a line of thought by way of a method of inference.🔽Since the Exalted One, who is the Buddha, is the one who is being accused, and since this is not the province of the Elder, it is said: “having penetrated it by knowledge that is direct perception.”

original: seṭṭhabhāvena, so cettha evaṃ veditabboti dassento “sīhanādo”tiādimāha. Neva dandhāyantenāti
analyzed: seṭṭha bhāvena so ca ittha evam veditabbaḥ iti dassento sīhanādaḥ iti ādim āha na iva dandhāyantena iti
translated: “Like the lion’s roar”: the lion’s roar is the lion’s cry. The meaning is that it is like that.🔽“Neither slowly nor hurriedly”:

original: na mandāyantena. Na bhaggarāyantenāti aparisaṅkantena.🔽Anuyogadāpanatthanti anuyogaṃ sodhāpetuṃ. Vimaddakkhamañhi sīhanādaṃ nadanto atthato
analyzed: na mandāyantena na bhaggarāyantena ati a parisaṅkantena  anuyoga dāpana attham ti anuyogam sodhāpetum vimadda khaman hi sīha nādam nadantaḥ atthataḥ
translated: not slowly, not hurriedly.🔽“In order to give an answer”: in order to purify the accusation. For one who roars the lion’s roar, which is a roar of confidence,

original: tattha anuyogaṃ sodheti nāma. Anuyuñjanto ca naṃ sodhāpeti nāma. Dātunti sodhetuṃ.
analyzed: tattha anuyogam sodhā iti nāma anuyuñjantaḥ ca nam sodhāpa iti nāma dātunti sodhetum
translated: purifies the accusation by answering it. And one who is being accused purifies the accusation by answering it.🔽“To give” means “to purify.”

original: Keci “dānattha”nti atthaṃ vadanti, tadayuttaṃ. Na hi yo sīhanādaṃ nadati, so eva
analyzed: keci attham vadanti tat ayuttam na hi yaḥ sīha nādam nadati saḥ eva
translated: Some say that the meaning of “to give” is “to give an answer.” But that is not correct. For one who roars the lion’s roar is not the same as one who gives an answer.

original: tattha anuyogaṃ detīti yujjati. Nighaṃsananti vimaddanaṃ. Dhamamānanti tāpayamānaṃ,
analyzed: tattha anuyogam deti iti vimaddanam dhamamānanti tāpayamānam
translated: Herein, he gives him a hint means he gives him a hint. He presses him means he presses him. He torments him means he torments him.

original: tāpanañcettha gaggariyā dhamāpanasīsena vadati. Sabbe teti sabbe te atīte niruddhe
analyzed: tāpanam ca ittha gaggariyā dhamāpana sīsena vadati sabbe te iti sabbe te atīte niruddhe
translated: Herein, he speaks of tormenting by way of the tormenting of the bellows. All those means all those past extinct

original: sammāsambuddhe, tenetaṃ dasseti – ye te ahesuṃ atītaṃ addhānaṃ tava abhinīhārato
analyzed: sammāsambuddhe tena itam dasseti ye te ahesum atītam addhānam tava abhinīhārataḥ
translated: Perfect Buddhas. He shows this: “You might know the mental behaviour in the world of the Buddhas who were before your aspiration

original: oraṃ sammāsambuddhā, tesaṃ tāva sāvakañāṇagocare dhamme paricchindanto mārādayo viya🔽buddhānaṃ lokiyacittacāraṃ tvaṃ jāneyyāsi. Ye pana te abbhatītā tato parato chinnavaṭumā
analyzed: sammāsambuddhā tesam tāva sāvaka ñāṇa gocare dhamme paricchindantaḥ māra ādayaḥ viya  buddhānam lokiya citta cāram tvam jāneyyāsi ye pana te abbhatītā tatas paratas chinna vaṭumā
translated: and who were Perfect Buddhas, and who were within the range of knowledge of the disciples.”🔽But those who are past, who are beyond that, who have cut off the cycle,

original: chinnapapañcā pariyādiṇṇavaṭṭā sabbadukkhavītivattā sammāsambuddhā, tesaṃ sabbesampi
analyzed: chinna papañcā pariyādiṇṇa vaṭṭā sabba dukkha vītivattā sammāsambuddhā tesam sabbesam pi
translated: who have cut off proliferation, who have crossed over the cycle, who have overcome all suffering, who are Perfect Buddhas, of all of them

original: sāvakañāṇassa avisayabhūte dhamme kathaṃ jānissasīti.
analyzed: sāvaka ñāṇassa avisaya bhūte dhamme katham jānissasi iti
translated: how will you know the states which are not within the range of knowledge of the disciples?”

original: Anāgatabuddhānaṃ panāti pana-saddo visesatthajotano, tena atītesu tāva khandhānaṃ
analyzed: anāgata buddhānam pana ati pana saddaḥ visesa attha jotanaḥ tena atītesu tāva khandhānam
translated: But as for the future Buddhas, the word “but” is a demonstrator of a distinction. Therefore, as for the past, the aggregates,

original: bhūtapubbattā tattha siyā ñāṇassa savisaye gati, anāgatesu pana sabbaso asañjātesu
analyzed: bhūta pubba ttā tattha siyā ñāṇassa sa visaye gati anāgatesu pana sabbaso a sañjātesu
translated: It might be argued that since the past has already been, it is possible for knowledge to reach it. But how can it be possible for knowledge to reach the future which has not yet come into existence at all?

original: kathanti imamatthaṃ joteti. Tenāha “anāgatāpī”tiādi. “Cittena paricchinditvā viditā”ti
analyzed: katham ti imam attham tena āha anāgatā api itiādi cittena paricchinditvā viditā ati
translated: This is the point he illustrates. Hence he says, “As regards the future too,” etc.

original: kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu atītānāgate sattāhe eva pavattaṃ cittaṃ cetopariyañāṇassa visayo,
analyzed: kasmā vuttam nanu atīta anāgate sattāhe eva pavattam cittam cetas pariya ñāṇassa visayo
translated: Why is it said, “having discerned with his mind”? Is not the mind that occurs only in the past and future seven days the object of the knowledge of penetration of minds?🔽Is it not so that the object of the knowledge of penetration of minds is only that which occurs in the past and future seven days?

original: na tato paranti? Nayidaṃ cetopariyañāṇakiccavasena vuttaṃ, atha kho pubbenivāsaanāgataṃsañāṇavasena
analyzed: na tatas paranti na yidam cetas upariya ñāṇa kicca vasena vuttam atha kho pubbenivāsa anāgataṃsa ñāṇa vasena
translated: This is not said in terms of the function of the knowledge of penetration of minds. Rather, it is said in terms of the knowledge of past lives and the knowledge of the future.

original: vuttaṃ, tasmā nāyaṃ doso.
analyzed: vuttam tasmā na ayam doso
translated: Therefore, there is no fault here.

original: Viditaṭṭhāne na karoti sikkhāpadeneva tādisassa paṭikkhepassa paṭikkhittattā, setughātato
analyzed: vidita ṭṭhāne na karoti sikkhāpadena iva tādisassa paṭikkhepassa paṭikkhitta ttā setu ghātato
translated: He does not do it in the known place, because such a prohibition has been prohibited by the training rule, and because of the bridge-breaking.

original: ca. Kathaṃ pana thero dvayasambhave paṭikkhepameva akāsi, na vibhajja byākāsīti āha
analyzed: ca katham pana theraḥ dvaya sambhave paṭikkhepam eva akāsi na vibhajja byākāsi iti āha
translated: But how did the Elder only prohibit when there was a duality, and not explain by dividing? He says

original: “thero kirā”tiādi. Pāraṃ pariyantaṃ minotīti pāramī, sā eva ñāṇanti pāramiñāṇaṃ,
analyzed: theraḥ kirāti ādi pāram pariyantam minoti iti pāramī sā eva pārami ñāṇam
translated: “The Elder, it is said,” etc. It measures the end, the limit, thus it is a pāramī. That itself is knowledge, thus it is pāramiñāṇa.

original: sāvakānaṃ pāramiñāṇaṃ sāvakapāramiñāṇaṃ, tasmiṃ. Sāvakānaṃ ukkaṃsapariyantagate jānane
analyzed: sāvakānam pāramiñāṇam sāvaka pāramiñāṇam tasmin sāvakānam ukkaṃsa pariyanta gate jānane
translated: “Knowledge of disciples’ perfections” is knowledge of disciples’ perfections. In that, in the knowledge of disciples that is limited to the maximum of disciples’ knowledge,

original: nāyaṃ anuyogo, atha kho sabbaññutaññāṇe sabbaññutāya jānane. Keci pana “sāvakapāramiñāṇeti
analyzed: na ayam anuyogaḥ atha kho sabbaññu ta ññāṇe sabbaññu tāya jānane keci pana sāvaka pārami ñāṇā iti
translated: this is not the pursuit. Rather, it is in the knowledge of omniscience, in the knowledge of omniscience. But some say that the meaning of “knowledge of disciples’ perfections”

original: sāvakapāramiñāṇavisaye”ti atthaṃ vadanti. Tathā sesapadesupi. Sīla..pe… samatthanti
analyzed: sāvaka pārami ñāṇa visayā iti attham vadanti tathā sesa padesu pi sīlape
translated: is “in the domain of knowledge of disciples’ perfections.” So too in the other passages. “Able in virtue, etc.,”

original: sīlasamādhipaññāvimuttisaṅkhātakāraṇānaṃ jānanasamatthaṃ. Buddhasīlādayo hi buddhānaṃ
analyzed: sīla samādhi paññā vimutti saṅkhāta kāraṇānam jānana samattham buddha sīla ādayaḥ hi buddhānam
translated: means able to know the reasons called virtue, concentration, understanding, and deliverance. For the Buddha’s virtue, etc.,

original: buddhakiccassa, parehi “buddhā”ti jānanassa ca kāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: buddha kiccassa parehi buddhā ati jānanassa ca kāraṇam
translated: are the reason for the Buddha’s work and for others’ knowledge of him as a Buddha.

original: 143. Anumānañāṇaṃ viya saṃsayapiṭṭhikaṃ ahutvā “idamida”nti yathāsabhāvato ñeyyaṃ
analyzed: anumāna ñāṇam viya saṃsaya piṭṭhikam a hutvā idam idam ti yathā sabhāvataḥ ñeyyam
translated: Without being based on doubt as in inferential knowledge, it holds the knowable as it is, thus it is a state of awareness of dhammas.

original: dhāreti nicchinotīti dhammo, paccakkhañāṇanti āha “dhammassa paccakkhato ñāṇassā”ti.
analyzed: dhāreti nicchinoti iti dhammaḥ paccakkha ñāṇanti āha dhammassa paccakkhataḥ ñāṇassa ati
translated: “Knowledge of dhammas” is knowledge of dhammas as dhammas.

original: Anuetīti anvayoti āha “anuyogaṃ anugantvā”ti. Paccakkhasiddhañhi atthaṃ anugantvā
analyzed: anueti iti anvayaḥ iti āha anuyogam anugantvā iti paccakkha siddham hi attham anugantvā
translated: “Pursuit” is what follows. He said “after pursuing the pursuit” because the meaning established by direct knowledge is what is followed.

original: anumānañāṇassa pavatti diṭṭhena adiṭṭhassa anumānanti veditabbo. Vidite vedakampi
analyzed: anumāna ñāṇassa pavatti diṭṭhena adiṭṭhassa anumānanti veditabbaḥ vidite vedakam pi
translated: The occurrence of the knowledge of inference should be understood as the inferring of what is not seen from what is seen.🔽The knowledge of what is known is in fact just what is known. Hence it is said: “The knowledge of inference is the taking of a clue from a fact known.”

original: ñāṇaṃ atthato viditameva hotīti “anumānañāṇaṃ nayaggāho vidito”ti vuttaṃ. Viditoti
analyzed: ñāṇam atthataḥ viditam eva hoti iti anumāna ñāṇam naya ggāhaḥ vidito ti vuttam viditoti
translated: “Known” means penetrated, reached, attained; the meaning is, understood.

original: viddho paṭiladdho, adhigatoti attho. Appamāṇoti aparimāṇo mahāvisayattā. Tenāha “apariyanto”ti.🔽Tenāti apariyantattā, tena vā apariyantena ñāṇena, eteneva thero yaṃ yaṃ anumeyyamatthaṃ
analyzed: viddhaḥ paṭiladdhaḥ adhigato ti attho appamāṇaḥ ti aparimāṇaḥ mahā visaya ttā tena āha apariyantaḥ iti  tena ati apariyanta ttā tena vā apariyantena ñāṇena etena iva theraḥ yam yam anumeyyam attham
translated: “Immeasurable” means immeasurable, having a great scope. Hence it is said, “boundless.”

original: ñātukāmo hoti, tattha tatthassa asaṅgamappaṭihaṭaanumānañāṇaṃ pavattatīti dasseti.
analyzed: ñātu kāmaḥ hoti tattha tatthassa asaṅgam appaṭihaṭa anumāna ñāṇam pavattati iti dasseti
translated: “Thereby”: because of its boundlessness, or by means of that boundless knowledge. By this the Elder shows that whatever matter he wishes to infer, his knowledge of inference occurs unobstructed and unhindered in that matter.

original: Tenāha “so iminā”tiādi. Tattha imināti iminā kāraṇena. Pākārassa thirabhāvaṃ uddhamuddhaṃ
analyzed: tena āha saḥ iminā atiādi tattha iminā ati iminā kāraṇena pākārassa thira bhāvam uddham uddham
translated: Hence he says, “Thereby,” etc. Herein, “thereby” means by this reason.

original: āpetīti uddhāpaṃ, pākāramūlaṃ. Ādi-saddena pākāradvārabandhaparikhādīnaṃ saṅgaho
analyzed: āpa iti iti uddhāpam pākāra mūlam ādi saddena pākāra dvāra bandha parikhā ādīnam saṅgahaḥ
translated: The “rampart” is the root of the wall. By the word “etc.” the inclusion of the gate-houses, moats, etc., of the rampart should be understood.

original: veditabbo. Paccante bhavaṃ paccantimaṃ. Paṇḍitadovārikaṭṭhāniyaṃ katvā thero attānaṃ
