analyzed: veditabbaḥ paccante bhavam paccantimam paṇḍita dovārika ṭṭhāniyam katvā theraḥ attānam
translated: The “frontier region” is what exists in the border region. Having made himself the wise gatekeeper, the Elder

original: dassetīti dassento “ekadvāranti kasmā āhā”ti codanaṃ samuṭṭhāpesi. Yassā paññāya
analyzed: dasseti iti dassento eka dvāram ti kasmai āha ati codanam samuṭṭhāpesi yassā paññāya
translated: “He shows” : he who shows, having raised the question, “Why did he say ‘one door’?”

original: vasena puriso “paṇḍito”ti vuccati, taṃ paṇḍiccanti āha “paṇḍiccena samannāgato”ti.🔽Taṃtaṃitikattabbatāsu chekabhāvo byattabhāvo veyyattiyaṃ. Medhati sammosaṃ hiṃsati🔽vidhamatīti medhā, sā etassa atthīti medhāvī. Ṭhāne ṭhāne uppatti etissā atthīti
analyzed: vasena puriso paṇḍito ti vuccati tam paṇḍiccanti āha paṇḍiccena samannāgato ti  cheka bhāvaḥ byatta bhāvaḥ veyyattiyam medhati sammosam hiṃsati  vidhamati iti medhā sā etassa atthi iti medhāvī ṭhāne ṭhāne uppatti etissā atthi iti
translated: “He is endowed with wisdom” : he said “he is endowed with wisdom” in the sense of the wisdom by means of which a person is called “wise” .🔽“He is endowed with cleverness” : cleverness is the state of being clever, the state of being skilled, in the various things to be done. It is cleverness because it destroys, it kills, it crushes, forgetfulness.🔽“He is endowed with understanding” : he who has that is called “endowed with understanding” .

original: ṭhānuppattikā, ṭhānaso uppajjanakapaññā. Anupariyāyanti etenāti anupariyāyo, so eva
analyzed: ṭhāna uppattikāḥ ṭhānaso uppajjanaka paññāḥ anupariyāyanti etena ati anupariyāyaḥ saḥ eva
translated: “He is endowed with knowledge that arises in the right place” : the knowledge that arises in the right place is called “knowledge that arises in the right place” .

original: pathoti anupariyāyapatho, parito pākārassa anusaṃyāyanamaggo. Pākārabhāgā sandhātabbā🔽etthāti pākārasandhi, pākārassa phullitappadeso. So pana heṭṭhimantena dvinnampi
analyzed: patho ti anupariyāya patho paritas pākārassa anusaṃyāyana maggo pākāra bhāgā sandhātabbā  ettha ati pākāra sandhi pākārassa phullita ppadeso so pana heṭṭhimantena dvinnam pi
translated: “He is endowed with the right path” : the right path is called “the right path” . It is the path that goes around the outer wall.🔽“He is endowed with the joints of the wall” : the joints of the wall are called “the joints of the wall” .🔽But that is said by way of the separation of the two bricks at the bottom. Therefore he said: “The place where two bricks are separated” .

original: iṭṭhakānaṃ vigamena evaṃ vuccatīti āha “dvinnaṃ iṭṭhakānaṃ apagataṭṭhāna”nti. Chinnaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: iṭṭhakānam vigamena evam vuccati iti āha dvinnam iṭṭhakānam apagata ṭṭhānanti chinna ṭṭhānanti
translated: “He is endowed with the place where it is broken” :

original: chinnabhinnappadeso, chinnaṭṭhānaṃ vā. Tañhi “vivara”nti vuccati.
analyzed: chinna bhinna ppadeso chinna ṭṭhānam vā tat hi vivaranti vuccati
translated: The place where it is cut or broken is called the “gap” .

original: Kiliṭṭhanti malīnaṃ. Upatāpentīti kilesapariḷāhena santāpenti. Vibādhentīti pīḷenti.🔽Uppannāya paññāya nīvaraṇehi na kiñci kātuṃ sakkāti āha “anuppannāya paññāya uppajjituṃ
analyzed: malīnam upatāpenti iti kilesa pariḷāhena santāpenti vibādhenti iti pīḷenti  uppannāya paññāya nīvaraṇehi na kiñci kātum sakkā iti āha anuppannāya paññāya uppajjitum
translated: Soiled means soiled with stains. They torment means they torment with the fever of defilements. They obstruct means they oppress.🔽When understanding has arisen, the hindrances cannot do anything to it. That is why he says, “They do not give it room to arise” .🔽Because they do not give it room to arise by destroying its conditions.

original: na dentī”ti. Tasmāti paccayūpaghātena uppajjituṃ appadānato. Catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu
analyzed: na denti iti tasmā ati paccaya upaghātena uppajjitum appadānataḥ catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu
translated: In the four foundations of mindfulness

original: suṭṭhu ṭhapitacittāti catubbidhāyapi satipaṭṭhānabhāvanāya sammadeva ṭhapitacittā.
analyzed: suṭṭhu ṭhapita cittā ati catubbidhāya api sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanāya sammat eva ṭhapita cittā
translated: Well established in the mind means well established in the mind by the development of the four foundations of mindfulness in all four ways.

original: Yathāsabhāvena bhāvetvāti aviparītasabhāvena yathā paṭipakkhā samucchijjanti, evaṃ bhāvetvā.
analyzed: yathā sabhāvena bhāvetvā ati aviparīta sabhāvena yathā paṭipakkhāḥ samucchijjanti evam bhāvetvā
translated: Having developed them according to their true nature means having developed them in such a way that their opposites are completely suppressed.

original: Purimanaye satipaṭṭhānāni, bojjhaṅgā ca missakā adhippetāti tato aññathā vattuṃ “apicetthā”tiādi
analyzed: purima naye satipaṭṭhānāni bojjhaṅgā ca missakā adhippetā ti tatas aññathā vattum apica itthā atiādi
translated: In the first method the foundations of mindfulness and the enlightenment factors are intended as mixed. Therefore, in order to explain them in a different way, it is said: “Here, however, they are” , etc.

original: vuttaṃ. Missakāti samathavipassanāmaggavasena missakā. “Catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā”tiādito
analyzed: vuttam missakā ti samatha vipassanā magga vasena missakā catūsu sati paṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhita cittā ati āditaḥ
translated: Mixed means mixed by way of the path of serenity and insight. “With the mind well established in the four foundations of mindfulness” , etc.

original: vuttattā satipaṭṭhāne vipassanāti gahetvā “satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṃ bhāvetvā”ti🔽vuttattā, maggapariyāpannānaṃyeva ca nesaṃ nippariyāyabojjhaṅgabhāvato, tesu ca sabbaso
analyzed: vutta ttā sati paṭṭhāne vipassanā iti gahetvā satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtam bhāvetvā ati  vutta ttā magga pariyāpannānaṃ yeva ca nesam nippariyāya bojjhaṅga bhāvato tesu ca sabbaso
translated: “Since it is said ‘in the foundations of mindfulness,’ and since it is said ‘having developed the seven factors of enlightenment in accordance with reality,’🔽and since they are factors of enlightenment only in the sense of the path, and since when they are completely attained by the Lord of the World,

original: adhigatesu lokanāthena sabbaññutaññāṇampi adhigatameva hotīti “bojjhaṅge maggo, sabbaññutaññāṇañcāti
analyzed: adhigatesu lokanāthena sabbaññu ta ññāṇam pi adhigatam eva hoti iti bojjhaṅge maggo sabbaññu ta ññāṇañca ati
translated: omniscience is attained too, the question would be a good one if it were taken as meaning ‘the factors of enlightenment, the path, and omniscience.’

original: gahite sundaro pañho bhaveyyā”ti mahāsivatthero āha, na panevaṃ gahitaṃ porāṇehīti
analyzed: gahite sundaraḥ pañhaḥ bhaveyya iti mahāsiva theraḥ āha na pana ivam gahitam porāṇehi iti
translated: But the ancient teachers did not take it like that,” said the Elder Mahā-Siva.

original: adhippāyo. Itīti vuttappakāraparāmasanaṃ. Theroti sāriputtatthero.
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ iti iti vutta ppakāra parāmasanam theraḥ iti sāriputta theraḥ
translated: “Thus” refers to the kind of question already mentioned. “The elder” is Sāriputta.

original: Tatthāti tesu paccantanagarādīsu. Nagaraṃ viya nibbānaṃ tadatthikehi upagantabbato,🔽upagatānañca parissayarahitasukhādhigamanaṭṭhānato. Pākāro viya sīlaṃ tadupagatānaṃ
analyzed: tattha iti tesu paccanta nagara ādīsu nagaram viya nibbānam tad atthikehi upagantabbataḥ  upagatānam ca parissaya rahita sukha adhigamana ṭhānato pākāraḥ viya sīlam tad upagatānam
translated: “There” is in those towns, etc., that are near. Nibbāna is like a town because those who want it go to it,🔽and because it is the place where those who have gone to it find the bliss free from all dangers. Virtue is like a rampart because it guards those who have gone to it

original: parito ārakkhabhāvato. Pariyāyapatho viya hirī sīlapākārassa adhiṭṭhānabhāvato. Vuttañhetaṃ
analyzed: paritas ārakkha bhāvato pariyāya pathaḥ viya hirī sīla pākārassa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: from all around. Conscience is like a bypath because it is the foundation of the virtue-rampart. For this is said:

original: “pariyāyapathoti kho bhikkhu hiriyā etaṃ adhivacana”nti. Dvāraṃ viya ariyamaggo nibbānanagarappavesanaañjasabhāvato.
analyzed: pariyāya pathaḥ ti kho bhikkhu hiriyā etam adhivacanan ti dvāram viya ariya maggaḥ nibbāna nagara ppavesana añjasa bhāvato
translated: The noble path is like a door, because it is the means of entry to the city of nibbana.

original: Paṇḍitadovāriko viya dhammasenāpati nibbānanagarapaviṭṭhapavisanakānaṃ sattānaṃ sallakkhaṇato.
analyzed: paṇḍita dovārikaḥ viya dhamma senāpati nibbāna nagara paviṭṭha pavisanakānam sattānam sat lakkhaṇato
translated: The general of the Dhamma is like a wise gatekeeper, because he observes beings who have entered the city of nibbana.

original: Dinnoti dāpito, sodhitoti attho.
analyzed: dinnaḥ ti dāpito sodhito ti attho
translated: “Given”: offered. “Purified”: cleansed.

original: 144. Nipphattidassanatthanti siddhidassanatthaṃ, adhigamadassanatthanti attho. “Pañcanavutipāsaṇḍe”ti
analyzed: nipphatti dassana tthan ti siddhi dassana ttham adhigama dassana tthan ti attho pañcanavuti pāsaṇḍā iti
translated: “For the purpose of showing the fruit”: for the purpose of showing the attainment, for the purpose of showing the realization.

original: idaṃ yasmā thero paribbājako hutvā tato pubbeva nibbānapariyesanaṃ caramāno te te
analyzed: idam yasmā theraḥ paribbājakaḥ hutvā tatas pubbā iva nibbāna pariyesanam caramāno te te
translated: “In the ninety-one schools”: the Elder, before he became a wanderer, while wandering about in search of nibbana,

original: pāsaṇḍino upasaṅkamitvā nibbānaṃ pucchi, te nāssa cittaṃ ārādhesuṃ, taṃ sandhāya🔽vuttaṃ. Te pana pāsaṇḍā heṭṭhā vuttā eva. Tatthevāti tassayeva bhāgineyyassa desiyamānāya
analyzed: pāsaṇḍino upasaṅkamitvā nibbānam pucchi te na assa cittam ārādhesum tam sandhāya  vuttam te pana pāsaṇḍāḥ heṭṭhā vuttāḥ eva tattha iva ati tassa yā iva bhāgineyyassa desiyamānāya
translated: approached these various sectarians and asked about nibbana. They did not satisfy his mind.🔽This is what is meant by the above statement.🔽These sectarians have already been mentioned above.🔽“Right there” means in the very place where his sister’s son was being taught.

original: desanāya. Parassa vaḍḍhitaṃ bhattaṃ bhuñjanto viya sāvakapāramiñāṇaṃ hatthagataṃ
analyzed: desanāya parassa vaḍḍhitam bhattam bhuñjantaḥ viya sāvaka pāramiñāṇam hattha gatam
translated: As if he were eating another’s food that had been prepared for him,

original: akāsi adhigacchi. Uttaruttaranti heṭṭhimassa heṭṭhimassa uttaraṇato atikkamanato🔽uttaruttaraṃ, tato eva padhānabhāvaṃ pāpitatāya paṇītapaṇītaṃ. Uttaruttaranti vā
analyzed: akāsi adhigacchi uttaruttaranti heṭṭhimassa heṭṭhimassa uttaraṇataḥ atikkamanataḥ  uttaruttaram eva padhāna bhāvam pāpitatāya paṇīta paṇītam uttaruttaranti vā
translated: He made, he reached. Higher and higher: higher than the lower, beyond the lower,🔽because of the transcending, the surmounting, of the lower.🔽Or higher and higher means higher and higher up. Higher and higher and more and more excellent: more and more excellent, more and more sublime, is the meaning.

original: uparūpari. Paṇītapaṇītanti paṇītataraṃ, paṇītatamañcāti attho. Kaṇhanti kāḷakaṃ saṃkilesadhammaṃ.
analyzed: upari upari paṇīta paṇītanti paṇītataram paṇītatamam ca ati attho kaṇhanti kāḷakam saṃkilesa dhammam
translated: Dark and bright: black, of the nature of defilement,

original: Sukkanti odātaṃ vodānadhammaṃ. Savipakkhaṃ katvāti pahātabbapahāyakabhāvadassanavasena🔽yathākkamaṃ ubhayaṃ savipakkhaṃ katvā. “Ayaṃ kaṇhadhammo, imassa ayaṃ pahāyako”ti
analyzed: sukkam ti odātam vodāna dhammam sa vipakkham katvā iti pahātabba pahāyaka bhāva dassana vasena  yathākkamam ubhayam sa vipakkham katvā ayam kaṇha dhammo imassa ayam pahāyako ti
translated: and white, of the nature of purification.🔽Having made them with their opposites: having made both the dark and the bright with their opposites by showing the abandoning of what is to be abandoned.

original: evaṃ kaṇhaṃ paṭibāhitvā desanāvasena nīharitvā sukkaṃ, “ayaṃ sukkadhammo, iminā ayaṃ🔽pahātabbo”ti evaṃ sukkaṃ paṭibāhitvā kaṇhaṃ. Saussāhanti phaluppādanasamatthatāvasena
analyzed: evam kaṇham paṭibāhitvā desanā vasena nīharitvā sukkam ayam sukka dhammaḥ iminā ayam  pahātabbā ti evam sukkam paṭibāhitvā kaṇham saussāhanti phala uppādana samattha tā vasena
translated: “This is a dark state; this is the opposite of it”🔽in this way he rejected the dark by means of the teaching, by means of the bright, and he rejected the bright by means of the dark.🔽With root-cause: with root-cause in the sense of being able to produce fruit.

original: sabyāpāraṃ. Tenāha “savipāka”nti. Vipākadhammanti attho.
analyzed: sa byāpāram tena āha sa vipākanti vipāka dhamman ti attho
translated: Therefore it is said, “with result” . The meaning is: with the nature of result.

original: Tasmiṃ desite dhammeti tasmiṃ vuttanayena bhagavā tumhehi desite dhamme ekaccaṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: tasmin desite dhamme ti tasmin vutta nayena bhagavā tumhehi desite dhamme ekaccam dhammam
translated: In the Dhamma taught by you: in the Dhamma taught by you in the way stated, the Exalted One, having known and penetrated a certain Dhamma,

original: nāma sāvakapāramiñāṇaṃ jānitvā paṭivijjhitvā. Taṃjānane hi vutte catusaccadhammajānanaṃ
analyzed: nāma sāvaka pāramiñāṇam jānitvā paṭivijjhitvā tad jānane hi vutte catu sacca dhamma jānanam
translated: having known it, he penetrated the knowledge of the perfection of the disciple. For when it is said that he knew it, the knowledge of the Four Noble Truths

original: avuttasiddhanti. “Catusaccadhammesū”ti idaṃ porāṇaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttākāradassanaṃ.
analyzed: avutta siddhanti catu sacca dhammesu iti idam porāṇa aṭṭhakathā ayam vutta ākāra dassanaṃ
translated: is implied. “In the Dhamma of the Four Noble Truths” is the way it is stated in the old commentaries.

original: Vipakkho pana parato āgamissati. Etthāti “dhammesu niṭṭhaṃ agama”nti etasmiṃ pade.
analyzed: vipakkhaḥ pana paratas āgamissati ettha ati dhammesu niṭṭham agamanti etasmim pade
translated: But the opposite will be stated later on. Here: in the words, “he came to the conclusion about the Dhamma.”

original: Therasallāpoti therānaṃ sallāpasadiso vinicchayavādo. Kāḷavallavāsīti kāḷavallavihāravāsī.🔽Idānīti etarahi “idāhaṃ bhante”tiādivacanakāle. Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāneti “dhammesu niṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: thera sallāpaḥ iti sallāpa sadisaḥ vinicchaya vādo kāḷavalla vāsī iti kāḷavalla vihāra vāsī  idāni iti etarahi idā aham bhante ti ādi vacana kāle imasmim pana ṭhāne iti dhammesu niṭṭham
translated: The elders’ discussion: a discussion like that of the elders, a doctrinal discussion. The residents of Kāḷavall: the residents of the Kāḷavall monastery.

original: agama”nti imasmiṃ padese, imasmiṃ vā niṭṭhānakāraṇabhūte yoniso parivitakkane. “Imasmiṃ
analyzed: agamanti imasmin padese imasmin vā niṭṭhāna kāraṇa bhūte parivitakkane imasmin
translated: Now: at the present time, at the time of the words, “I have come to the conclusion, venerable sir.” But here: in the words, “he came to the conclusion about the Dhamma.” Or here: in the proper reflection that is the cause for coming to the conclusion.

original: pana ṭhāne buddhaguṇesu niṭṭhaṅgato”ti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu sāvakapāramiñāṇasamadhigatakāle
analyzed: pana ṭhāne buddha guṇesu niṭṭhaṅgato ti kasmā vuttam nanu sāvaka pārami ñāṇa samadhigata kāle
translated: Why is it said, “he came to the conclusion about the Buddha-qualities in this place”? Did he not come to the conclusion about the knowledge of the perfection of the disciple at the time he attained concentration?

original: eva thero buddhaguṇesu niṭṭhaṅgatoti? Saccametaṃ, idāni pana taṃ pākaṭaṃ jātanti
analyzed: eva theraḥ buddha guṇesu saccam etam idāni pana tam pākaṭam jātanti
translated: So the Elder Thera has reached certainty in the Buddha’s special qualities? That is true, but now it has become evident.

original: evaṃ vuttaṃ. Sabbanti “catusaccadhammesū”tiādi sumattherena vuttaṃ sabbaṃ. Arahatte
analyzed: evam vuttam sabbam nti catu sacca dhammesu utiādi sumattherena vuttam sabbam arahatte
translated: So it was said. All: all that was said by the Elder Sumana beginning with “in the four noble truths.”

original: niṭṭhaṅgatoti etthāpi vuttanayeneva anuyogaparihārā veditabbā. Yadipi dhammasenāpati🔽“sāvakapāramiñāṇaṃ mayā samadhigata”nti ito pubbepi jānātiyeva, idāni pana asaṅkhyeyyāparimeyyabhede
analyzed: niṭṭhaṅgato ti ettha api vutta nayena iva anuyoga parihārāḥ veditabbāḥ yadi pi dhammasenāpati  sāvaka pāramiñāṇam mayā samadhigatan ti itas pubbe pi jānātiyā iva idāni pana asaṅkhyeyya aparimeyya bhede
translated: Has reached certainty in Arahantship: here too the question and answer should be understood in the way already stated.

original: buddhaguṇe nayaggāhavasena pariggahetvā kiccasiddhiyā tasmiṃ ñāṇe niṭṭhaṅgato ahosīti
analyzed: buddha guṇe naya ggāha vasena pariggahetvā kicca siddhiyā tasmim ñāṇe niṭṭhaṅgataḥ ahosi iti
translated: Although the General of the Dhamma knew before this that he had attained the knowledge of the disciple in higher training that sur-passes that of all others, he now reached certainty in that knowledge as the fulfilment of his task by apprehending the Buddha’s special qualities, which are of an incalculable and immeasurable number, by the method of the guide-lines.

original: dassento “mahāsivatthero…pe… dhammesūti sāvakapāramiñāṇe niṭṭhaṅgato”ti avoca.
analyzed: dassentaḥ dhammesu iti sāvaka pāramiñāṇe niṭṭhaṅgato ti avoca
translated: So showing this, the Elder Maha Siva said: “The Elder Sumana has reached certainty in the four noble truths, that is, in the knowledge of the disciple in higher training that sur-passes that of all others.”

original: Buddhaguṇā pana nayato āgatā, te nayaggāhato yāthāvato jānanto sāvakapāramiñāṇe tathājānanavasena
analyzed: buddha guṇā pana nayataḥ āgatā te naya ggāhataḥ yāthāvataḥ jānantaḥ sāvaka pārami ñāṇe tathā jānana vasena
translated: But the Buddha’s special qualities are reached by the method. Knowing them as they really are by the method of the guide-lines, he reached certainty in the knowledge of the disciple in higher training by knowing them in that way.

original: niṭṭhaṅgatattā sāvakapāramiñāṇameva tassa aparāparuppattivasena, tena tena bhāvetabbakiccabahutāvasena🔽ca “dhammesū”ti puthuvacanena vuttaṃ. Anantāparimeyyānaṃ anaññavisayānaṃ buddhaguṇānaṃ
analyzed: niṭṭhaṅga tattā sāvaka pāramiñāṇam eva tassa apara apara uppatti vasena tena tena bhāvetabba kicca bahu tā vasena  ca dhammesu iti puthuvacanena vuttam ananta aparimeyyānam anañña visayānam buddha guṇānam
translated: The Elder’s faith in the Blessed One is exceedingly great because of his discernment of the Blessed One’s qualities, which are infinite and immeasurable and not within the domain of others, by means of the method stated in the verse.

original: nayato pariggaṇhanena therassa sātisayo bhagavati pasādo uppajjatīti āha “bhiyyosomattāyā”tiādi.
analyzed: nayataḥ pariggaṇhanena therassa sa atisayaḥ bhagavati pasādaḥ uppajjati iti āha bhiyyosomattāya atiādi
translated: The Elder’s faith is exceedingly great because of his discernment of the Blessed One’s qualities, which are infinite and immeasurable and not within the domain of others, by means of the method stated in the verse.

original: “Suṭṭhu akkhāto”ti vatvā taṃ evassa suṭṭhu akkhātataṃ dassetuṃ “niyyāniko maggo”ti
analyzed: suṭṭhu akkhātoti vatvā tam eva assa suṭṭhu akkhāta tam dassetum niyyānikaḥ maggo ti
translated: Having said that the Dhamma is well proclaimed, he says “it is a path leading to Nibbana” in order to show that it is well proclaimed.

original: vuttaṃ. Svākkhātatā hi dhammassa yadatthaṃ desito, tadatthasādhanena veditabbā. Phalatthāya
analyzed: vuttam svākkhāta tā hi dhammassa yad attham desitaḥ tad attha sādhanena veditabbā phala tthāya
translated: For the well-proclaimedness of the Dhamma should be understood as the accomplishment of its purpose.

original: niyyātīti anantaravipākattā, attano uppattisamanantarameva phalanipphādanavasena
analyzed: niyyāti iti anantara vipāka ttā attanaḥ uppatti samanantaram eva phala nipphādana vasena
translated: It leads to Nibbana because it has immediate result. The meaning is that it occurs by producing its fruit immediately next to its own arising.🔽Or alternatively, it leads out from the round of rebirths, thus it is a path leading out ; or it has the nature of leading out.

original: pavattatīti attho. Vaṭṭacārakato niyyātīti vā niyyāniko, niyyānasīloti vā. Rāgadosamohanimmadanasamatthoti
analyzed: pavattati iti atthaḥ vaṭṭa cārakataḥ niyyāti iti vā niyyānikaḥ niyyāna sīlaḥ iti vā rāga dosa moha nimmadana samatthaḥ ti
translated: It is able to crush greed, hate, and delusion,

original: idhāpi “pasannosmi bhagavatīti dassetī”ti ānetvā sambandho. Vaṅkādīti ādi-saddena🔽jimhakuṭile, aññe ca paṭipattidose saṅgaṇhāti. Bhagavā tumhākaṃ buddhasubuddhatā
analyzed: idha api pasannaḥ asmi bhagavati iti dasseti iti ānetvā sambandhaḥ vaṅka ādi iti ādi saddena  jimha kuṭile aññe ca paṭipatti dose saṅgaṇhāti bhagavā tumhākam buddha subuddha tā
translated: Here too the connection is made by bringing in the words “I have confidence in the Blessed One” to show that the Elder had confidence in the Blessed One’s virtue.🔽The word “etc.” in “crookedness, etc.” includes the faults of practice such as being a jackal, etc.

original: viya dhammasudhammatā, saṅghasuppaṭipatti ca dhammesu niṭṭhaṅgamanena sāvakapāramiñāṇe🔽niṭṭhaṅgatattā mayhaṃ suṭṭhu vibhūtā supākaṭā jātāti dassento thero “svākkhāto bhagavatā
analyzed: viya dhamma su dhamma tā saṅgha su paṭipatti ca dhammesu niṭṭhaṅgamanena sāvaka pāramiñāṇe  niṭṭhaṅga tattā mayham suṭṭhu vibhūtā su pākaṭā jātā ati dassento thero su ākkhātaḥ bhagavatā
translated: The Blessed One’s virtue is well purified, and his state of being a Buddha is well purified, and the good practice of the Community is well purified, in the sense of reaching completion in the knowledge of the disciple’s perfection, since the Elder had reached completion in that.

original: dhammo, suppaṭipanno saṅghoti pasīdi”nti avoca.
analyzed: dhammo suppaṭipanno saṅghaḥ iti pasīdinti avoca
translated: Thus showing that, he said: “The Dhamma is well proclaimed by the Blessed One, the Community of disciples is well-practicing.”

original: Kusaladhammadesanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: kusala dhamma desanā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the profitable ideas

original: 145. Anuttarabhāvoti seṭṭhabhāvo. Anuttaro bhagavā yena guṇena, so anuttarabhāvo,
analyzed: anuttara bhāvaḥ ti seṭṭha bhāvaḥ anuttaraḥ bhagavā yena guṇena so anuttara bhāvaḥ
translated: . The state of being unsurpassed: the state of being best. The Blessed One is unsurpassed by reason of what special quality?🔽That is the state of being unsurpassed.

original: taṃ anuttariyaṃ. Yasmā tassāpi guṇassa kiñci uttaritaraṃ natthi eva, tasmā vuttaṃ
analyzed: tam anuttariyam yasmā tassa api guṇassa kiñci uttaritaram natthi eva tasmā vuttam
translated: Since there is nothing higher than that quality, it is said:

original: “sā tumhākaṃ desanā anuttarāti vadatī”ti. Kusalesu dhammesūti kusaladhammanimittaṃ.
analyzed: sā tumhākam desanā anuttarā iti vadati iti kusalesu dhammesu iti kusala dhamma nimittam
translated: “He says that your teaching is unsurpassed.” In profitable ideas: the profitable ideas are the sign of profitable ideas.

original: Nimittatthe hi etaṃ bhummaṃ, tasmā kusaladhammadesanāhetupi bhagavāva anuttaroti
analyzed: nimitta atthe hi etam bhummam tasmā
translated: For this is a locative in the sense of a basis. So the meaning is: “The Blessed One is unsurpassed as the teacher of profitable states because he is the basis for the teaching of profitable states.”

original: attho. Bhūmiṃ dassentoti visayaṃ dassento. Kusaladhammadesanāya hi kusalā dhammā
analyzed: atthaḥ bhūmim dassento ti visayam dassento kusala dhamma desanāya hi kusalāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: “Showing the basis”: showing the domain. For profitable states are the domain of the teaching of profitable states.

original: visayo. Vuttapadeti “kusalesu dhammesū”ti evaṃ vuttavākye, evaṃ vā vuttadhammakoṭṭhāse.🔽“Pañcadhā”ti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu chekaṭṭhenapi kusalaṃ icchitabbaṃ “kusalo tvaṃ rathassa🔽aṅgapaccaṅgāna”ntiādīsūti ? Saccametaṃ, so pana chekaṭṭho kosallasambhūtaṭṭheneva🔽saṅgahitoti visuṃ na gahito. “Kacci nu bhoto kusalaṃ, kacci bhoto anāmaya”nti jātake
analyzed: visayaḥ vutta pade ti kusalesu dhammesu iti evam vutta vākye evam vā vutta dhamma koṭṭhāse  pañcadhā iti kasmai vuttam nanu chekaṭṭhena api kusalam icchitabbam kusalaḥ tvam rathassa  aṅga paccaṅga ananti ādīsu iti saccam etam so pana cheka ṭṭho kosalla sambhūta ṭṭhena iva  saṅgahitaḥ uti visum na gahitaḥ kacci nu bhoto kusalam kacci bhoto anāmayanti jātake
translated: “The words”: the words thus stated, namely, “in profitable states”; or the profitable states thus stated.

original: āgatattā “jātakapariyāyaṃ patvā ārogyaṭṭhena kusalaṃ vaṭṭatī”ti vuttaṃ. “Taṃ kiṃ
analyzed: āgata ttā jātaka pariyāyam patvā ārogya ṭṭhena kusalam vaṭṭati iti vuttam tam kim
translated: Why is it said “in five ways”? Should not profitable be wished for in the sense of single too, since in such passages as “You are skilled in the parts and subdivisions of a chariot” , it is a single thing that is called profitable? —It is true, but that sense of single is included in the sense of source of skill, so it is not taken separately. And it is said that in the passage “Are you comfortable, are you at your ease? ” , which occurs in the Jātaka Commentary , profitable is allowable in the sense of health.

original: maññatha, gahapatayo, ime dhammā kusalā vā akusalā vā sāvajjā vā anavajjā vā”tiādīsu
analyzed: maññatha gahapatayo ime dhammā kusalāḥ vā akusalāḥ vā sāvajjāḥ vā anavajjāḥ vā iti ādīsu
translated: “What do you think of this, householders, are these states profitable or unprofitable, reprehensible or blameless?” ,

original: suttapadesesu “kusalā”ti vuttadhammā eva “anavajjā”ti vuttāti āha “suttantapariyāyaṃ
analyzed: sutta padesesu kusalā ati vutta dhammā eva anavajjā ati vuttā iti āha suttanta pariyāyam
translated: In the Suttas, the states called “profitable” are called “blameless.” Hence he said: “The profitable is found in the Suttas by way of the blameless.”

original: patvā anavajjaṭṭhena kusalaṃ vaṭṭatī”ti. Abhidhamme “kosalla”nti paññā āgatāti yonisomanasikārahetukassa🔽kusalassa kosallasammūtaṭṭho, darathābhāvadīpanato niddarathaṭṭho, “kusalassa katattā🔽upacitattā”ti vatvā iṭṭhavipākaniddisanato sukhavipākaṭṭho ca abhidhammanayasiddhoti
analyzed: patvā anavajja ṭṭhena kusalam vaṭṭati iti abhidhamme kosallanti paññā āgatā ati yoni somanasikāra hetukassa  kusalassa kosalla sammūta ṭṭhaḥ daratha abhāva dīpanataḥ niddaratha ṭṭhaḥ kusalassa kata ttā  upacita ttā iti vatvā iṭṭha vipāka niddisanato sukha vipāka ṭṭho ca abhidhamma naya siddho ti
translated: In the Abhidhamma, “skill” is understanding. The meaning of “skill” is the meaning of profitable in the sense of being accompanied by skill, since it is the cause of right reflection.🔽The meaning of “free from torpor” is the meaning of profitable in the sense of being free from torpor, since it shows the absence of torpor. The meaning of “having pleasant experience” is the meaning of profitable in the sense of having pleasant experience, since it is stated that “because profitable has been done, accumulated, pleasant experience will be experienced,” and this is established by the method of the Abhidhamma.

original: āha “abhidhamma…pe… vipākaṭṭhenā”ti. Bāhitikasutte bhagavato kāyasamācārādike vaṇṇentena
analyzed: āha abhidhammape vipāka ṭṭhena ati bāhitika sutte bhagavato kāya samācāra ādike vaṇṇentena
translated: In the Bāhitikasutta, the treasurer of the Dhamma, while praising the Blessed One’s bodily conduct, etc.,

original: dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena “yo kho mahārāja kāyasamācāro anavajjo”ti kusalo kāyasamācāro
analyzed: dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena yaḥ kho mahā rāja kāya samācāraḥ anavajjaḥ ti kusalaḥ kāya samācāraḥ
translated: said to King Pasenadi: “Any bodily conduct, great king, that is blameless is profitable bodily conduct.”

original: rañño pasenadissa vutto. Na hi bhagavato sukhavipākakammaṃ atthīti sabbasāvajjarahitā
analyzed: raññaḥ pasenadissa vuttaḥ na hi bhagavataḥ sukha vipāka kammam atthi iti sabba sāvajja rahitā
translated: For the Blessed One has no profitable kamma that would have a pleasant experience as its fruit, since he is devoid of all that is blameworthy.

original: kāyasamācārādayo “kusalā”ti vuttā, idha pana “kusalesu dhammesū”ti bodhipakkhiyadhammā
analyzed: kāya samācāra ādayaḥ kusalā ti vuttāḥ idha pana kusalesu dhammesu iti bodhi pakkhiya dhammā
translated: The bodily conduct, etc., are called “profitable” in the sense of being blameless, but here the states that are requisites of enlightenment are called “profitable” in the sense of being supramundane.

original: “kusalā”ti vuttā, te ca samathavipassanā maggasampayuttā ekantena sukhavipākā evāti🔽avajjarahitatāmattaṃ upādāya anavajjattho kusala-saddoti āha “imasmiṃ pana…pe… daṭṭhabba”nti.
analyzed: kusalā ati vuttā te ca samatha vipassanāḥ magga sampayuttāḥ ekantena sukha vipākāḥ evā ti  avajja rahita tā mattam upādāya anavajja attho kusala saddo ti āha imasmin pana pe daṭṭhabbanti
translated: And they are exclusively of happy result because they are associated with the path.🔽So the word “profitable” should be understood here in the sense of blameless, according to the method stated.

original: Evañca katvā “phalasatipaṭṭhānaṃ pana idha anadhippeta”nti idañca vacanaṃ samatthitaṃ
analyzed: evam ca katvā phala sati paṭṭhānam pana idha idam ca vacanam samatthitaṃ
translated: And when it is so understood, the statement “But the fruition attainment is not intended here”

original: hoti savipākasseva gahaṇanti katvā.
analyzed: hoti sa vipākassa iva gahaṇanti katvā
translated: is also justified, since only what has kamma as its result is included.

original: “Cuddasavidhenā”tiādi satipaṭṭhāne vuttanayena veditabbaṃ. Paggahaṭṭhenāti kusalapakkhassa
analyzed: cuddasavidhena atiādi sati paṭṭhāne vutta nayena veditabbam paggaha ṭṭhena āti kusala pakkhassa
translated: The profitable is of fourteen kinds, etc., should be understood in the way given in the Description of the Meditations .🔽As upholding: as having the nature of upholding the profitable side.

original: paggaṇhanasabhāvena. Kiccavasenāti anuppannākusalānuppādanādikiccavasena. Tato eva
analyzed: paggaṇhana sabhāvena kicca vasena ati anuppanna akusala anuppādana ādi kicca vasena tatas eva
translated: As function: as the function of preventing unprofitable things arising, and so on.🔽That is why it is fourfold.🔽As success: as having the nature of arising.

original: cassa catubbidhatā. Ijjhanaṭṭhenāti nippajjanasabhāvena. Chandādayo eva iddhipādesu
analyzed: cassa catubbidha tā ijjhan aṭṭhena ati nippajjana sabhāvena chanda ādayaḥ eva iddhipādesu
translated: The bases for success are will, endeavour,

original: visiṭṭhasabhāvā, itare avisiṭṭhā, tesampi viseso chandādikatoti āha “chandādivasena nānāsabhāvā”ti.
analyzed: visiṭṭha sabhāvāḥ itare avisiṭṭhā tesam pi visesaḥ chanda ādikato ti āha chanda ādi vasena nānā sabhāvā iti
translated: The other faculties are not distinguished. Their distinction is due to zeal, etc. That is why he said “distinguished by zeal, etc.”

original: Adhimokkhādisabhāvavasenāti pasādādhimokkhādisalakkhaṇavasena. Upatthambhanaṭṭhenāti
analyzed: adhimokkha ādi sabhāva vasena āti pasāda adhimokkha ādi salakkhaṇa vasena upatthambhana ṭṭhena ati
translated: By the nature of their characteristics, etc.: by the nature of their characteristics consisting in confidence, resolution, etc.🔽By their function of supporting: by their function of supporting associated states.

original: sampayuttadhammānaṃ upatthambhanakabhāvena. Akampiyaṭṭhenāti paṭipakkhehi akampiyasabhāvena.
analyzed: sampayutta dhammānam upatthambhanaka bhāvena akampiya ṭṭhena ati paṭipakkhehi akampiya sabhāvena
translated: By their function of unshakability: by their nature of being unmoved by their opposites.

original: Salakkhaṇenāti adhimokkhādisabhāvena. Niyyānaṭṭhenāti saṃkilesapakkhato, vaṭṭacārakato
analyzed: sa lakkhaṇena āti adhimokkha ādi sabhāvena niyyāna aṭṭhena ati saṃkilesa pakkhataḥ vaṭṭa cārakataḥ
translated: By their individual essences: by the nature of their characteristics consisting in confidence, etc.

original: ca niggamanaṭṭhena. Upaṭṭhānādināti upaṭṭhānadhammavicayapaggahasampiyāyanapassambhanasamādhānaajjhupekkhanasaṅkhātena
analyzed: ca niggamana aṭṭhena upaṭṭhāna ādinā ati upaṭṭhāna dhamma vicaya paggaha sampiyāyana passambhana samādhāna ajjhupekkhana saṅkhātena
translated: By their function of outlet: by their function of escape from the defilement class and from the round of rebirths.🔽By their appearance, etc.: by their individual essences consisting in the appearances of serenity, insight, energy, support, investigation, exertion, faith, resolution, steadiness, and equanimity.

original: attano sabhāvena. Hetuṭṭhenāti nibbānassa sampāpakahetubhāvena. Dassanādināti dassanābhiniropanapariggahasamuṭṭhāpanavodāpanapaggahupaṭṭhānasamādhānasaṅkhātena attano sabhāvena.
analyzed: attanaḥ sabhāvena hetuṭṭhena ati nibbānassa sampāpaka hetu bhāvena dassana ādinā ati dassana abhiniropana pariggaha samuṭṭhāpana vodāpana paggaha upaṭṭhāna samādhāna saṅkhātena attanaḥ sabhāvena
translated: By their function of cause: by their function of causing the realization of Nibbāna.

original: Sāsanassa pariyosānadassanatthanti sāsanaṃ nāma nippariyāyato sattatiṃsa bodhipakkhiyadhammā.
analyzed: sāsanassa pariyosāna dassana atthanti sāsanam nāma nippariyāyato sattatiṃsa bodhi pakkhiya dhammā
translated: For the purpose of showing the end of the Dispensation: the Dispensation is the thirty-seven states partaking of enlightenment in the ultimate sense.

original: Tattha ye samathavipassanāsahagatā, te sāsanassa ādi, maggapariyāpannā majjhe, phalabhūtā
analyzed: tattha ye samatha vipassanā sahagatā te sāsanassa ādi magga pariyāpannā majjhe phala bhūtā
translated: Herein, the states of serenity and insight are the beginning of the Dispensation, those included in the path are the middle, and those that are fruits are the end.

original: pariyosānaṃ, taṃdassanatthaṃ. Tenāha “sāsanassa hī”tiādi.
analyzed: pariyosānam taṃ dassana attham tena āha sāsanassa hi itiādi
translated: For the purpose of showing that, it is said: “The Dispensation’s end” , etc.

original: Puna etadānuttariyaṃ bhanteti yathāraddhāya desanāya nigamanaṃ. Vuttasseva atthassa
analyzed: punar etat ānuttariyam bhante ti yathā āraddhāya desanāya nigamanam vuttassa iva atthassa
translated: Again, this is unsurpassed, venerable sir: this is the conclusion of the teaching as begun.🔽For the statement again of the meaning already stated is called a conclusion.

original: puna vacanañhi nigamanaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃ desananti taṃ kusalesu dhammesu desanāppakāraṃ,
analyzed: puna vacanam hi nigamanam vuttam tam desanan ti tam kusalesu dhammesu desanā ppakāram
translated: The teaching: the teaching of the kinds of profitable states,

original: desanāvidhiṃ, desetabbañca, sakalaṃ vā sampuṇṇaṃ anavasesaṃ abhijānāti abhivisiṭṭhena
analyzed: desanā vidhim desetabbam ca sakalam vā sampuṇṇam anavasesam abhijānāti abhivisiṭṭhena
translated: the method of teaching, and what is to be taught, or the whole of it in its entirety without exception, he knows with the knowledge that is pre-eminent

original: ñāṇena jānāti, asesaṃ abhijānanato eva uttari upari abhiññeyyaṃ natthi. Itoti bhagavatā
analyzed: ñāṇena jānāti asesam abhijānanataḥ eva uttari upari abhiññeyyam natthi itas ti bhagavatā
translated: because of knowing it without exception, there is nothing further to be known above that. From this: from what has been known by the Blessed One.

original: abhiññātato. Añño paramatthavasena dhammo vā paññattivasena puggalo vā ayaṃ nāma
analyzed: abhiññātataḥ aññaḥ paramattha vasena dhammaḥ vā paññatti vasena puggalaḥ vā ayam nāma
translated: There is no other state in the ultimate sense or person in the conventional sense

original: yaṃ bhagavā na jānātīti idaṃ natthi na upalabbhati sabbasseva sammadeva tumhehi abhiññātattā.
analyzed: yam bhagavā na jānāti iti idam natthi na upalabbhati sabbassa iva sammat eva tumhehi abhiññāta ttā
translated: “What the Blessed One does not know” is not found, is not obtained, because all of it is known by you in every way.

original: Kusalesu dhammesu abhijānane, desanāyañca bhagavato uttaritaro natthi.
analyzed: kusalesu dhammesu abhijānane desanāyan ca bhagavataḥ uttaritaraḥ natthi
translated: In the knowing of profitable ideas, and in teaching, there is none higher than the Blessed One.

original: Āyatanapaṇṇattidesanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: āyatana paṇṇatti desanā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Bases

original: 146. Āyatanapaññāpanāsūti cakkhādīnaṃ, rūpādīnañca āyatanānaṃ sambodhanesu, tesaṃ
analyzed: āyatana paññāpanāsu iti cakkha ādīnam rūpa ādīnam ca āyatanānam sambodhanesu tesam
translated: The Description of the Bases Thread is the teaching in the “Description of the Bases” Thread, which is in the “Questions on the Bases” , of the eye, etc., and visible data, etc., as bases, in the sense of their being taught

original: ajjhattikabāhiravibhāgato, sabhāgavibhāgato, samudayato, atthaṅgamato, āhārato, ādīnavato,
analyzed: ajjhattika bāhira vibhāgato sa bhāga vibhāgato samudayataḥ atthaṅgamataḥ āhārataḥ ādīnavato
translated: by a division into internal and external, by a division into similar and dissimilar, by origin, by disappearance, by nutriment, by danger,

original: nissaraṇato ca desanāyanti attho.
analyzed: nissaraṇataḥ ca desanāyanti attho
translated: and by escape.

original: Gabbhāvakkantidesanāvaṇṇanā🔽147. Gabbhokkamanesūti gabbhabhāvena mātukucchiyaṃ avakkamanesu anuppavesesu, gabbhe🔽vā mātukucchismiṃ avakkamanesu. Pavisatīti paccayavasena tattha nibbattento pavisanto
analyzed: gabbhā vakkanti desanā vaṇṇanā  gabbha ukkamanesu iti gabbha bhāvena mātukucchiyam avakkamanesu anuppavesesu gabbhe  vā mātukucchismim avakkamanesu pavisati iti paccaya vasena tattha nibbattento pavisanto
translated: The Description of the Descent into the Womb🔽In the “Descent into the Womb” Thread is the descent into the womb by the state of embryo, the entry into the mother’s womb, the descent into the womb,

original: viya hotīti katvā vuttaṃ. Ṭhātīti santānaṭṭhitiyā pavattati, tathābhūto ca tattha
analyzed: viya hoti iti katvā vuttam ṭhāti iti santāna ṭṭhitiyā pavattati tathābhūtaḥ ca tattha
translated: or the entry into the womb, the mother’s womb. He enters: he becomes one who enters there by means of conditions, as if he were entering. He stays: he occurs in the continuity of existence. And he is so

original: vasanto viya hotīti āha “vasatī”ti. Pakatilokiyamanussānaṃ paṭhamā gabbhāvakkantīti🔽pacuramanussānaṃ gabbhāvakkanti desanāvasena idha paṭhamā. “Dutiyā gabbhāvakkantī”tiādīsupi
analyzed: vasantaḥ viya hoti iti āha vasati iti pakati lokiya manussānam paṭhamā gabbhāvakkanti iti  pacura manussānam gabbha avakkanti desanā vasena idha paṭhamā dutiyā gabbha avakkanti iti ādīsu pi
translated: The first descent into the womb of ordinary human beings is🔽the first here in the sense of the teaching of the descent into the womb of ordinary human beings.

original: evaṃ yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: evam yojanā veditabbā
translated: The construction should be understood in the same way in the passages beginning “The second descent into the womb” .

original: Alamevāti yuttameva.
analyzed: alam eva ati yuttam eva
translated: “It is enough” means it is suitable.

original: Khipituṃ na sakkontīti tathā vātānaṃ anuppajjanameva vadati. Sesanti puna “etadānuttariya”tiādi pāṭhappadesaṃ vadati.
analyzed: khipitum na sakkonti iti tathā vātānam anuppajjanam eva vadati punar pāṭha ppadesam vadati
translated: “He cannot throw it off” means he cannot bring about the non-arising of the winds in that way. The rest is the passage beginning “This is the unsurpassed” .

original: Ādesanavidhādesanāvaṇṇanā🔽148. Parassa cittaṃ ādisati etehīti ādesanāni, yathāupaṭṭhitanimittādīni, tāni eva
analyzed: ādesana vidhā desanā vaṇṇanā  parassa cittam ādisati etehi iti ādesanāni yathā upaṭṭhita nimitta ādīni tāni eva
translated: The explanation of the description of the modes of description🔽The modes of description are the signs, etc., that appear as they are described.🔽They are called “modes of description” because they are established in an undifferentiated form.

original: aññamaññassa asaṃkiṇṇarūpena ṭhitattā ādesanavidhā, ādesanābhāgā, tāsu ādesanavidhāsu.
analyzed: aññamaññassa asaṃkiṇṇa rūpena ṭhita ttā ādesana vidhā ādesanā bhāgā tāsu ādesana vidhāsu
translated: The description is the parts of the description.

original: Tenāha “ādesanakoṭṭhāsesū”ti. Āgatanimittenāti yassa ādisati, tassa, attano ca upagatanimittena,
analyzed: tena āha ādesana koṭṭhāsesu iti āgata nimittena ati yassa ādisati tassa attano ca upagata nimittena
translated: The sign that has come is the sign that has come to the person who is described and to oneself.

original: nimittappattassa lābhālābhādiādisanavidhidassanassa pavattattā “idaṃ nāma bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: nimitta ppattassa lābha a lābha ādi ādi sana vidhi dassanassa pavatta ttā idam nāma bhavissati iti
translated: Because the appearance of the sign is the occurrence of the six modes beginning with obtaining and not obtaining, etc., it is said, “It will be such and such.”

original: vuttaṃ. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “evampi te mano”tiādinā parassa cittādisanameva āgataṃ, taṃ
analyzed: vuttam pāḷiyam pana evam pi te manaḥ ti ādinā parassa āgatam tam
translated: But in the text only the other’s mind, etc., are given as the sign, with the words, “So too, his mind” , etc.,

original: nidassanamattaṃ katanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tathā hi “idaṃ nāma bhavissatī”ti vuttasseva🔽atthassa vibhāvanavasena vatthu āgataṃ. Gatanimittaṃ nāma gamananimittaṃ. Ṭhitanimittaṃ
analyzed: nidassana mattam katam ti daṭṭhabbam tathā hi idam nāma bhavissati iti vuttassa iva  atthassa vibhāvana vasena vatthu āgatam gata nimittam nāma gamana nimittam ṭhita nimittam
translated: and that should be understood as stated by way of illustration. For the subject is given by way of the elucidation of the meaning stated as “It will be such and such.”

original: nāma attano samīpe ṭhānanimittaṃ, parassa gamanavasena, ṭhānavasena ca gahetabbanimittaṃ.
analyzed: nāma attanaḥ samīpe ṭhāna nimittam parassa gamana vasena ṭhāna vasena ca gahetabba nimittam
translated: The sign of going is the sign of the other’s going. The sign of standing is the sign of the other’s standing, which is the sign to be apprehended by way of his standing near oneself.

original: Manussānaṃ paracittavidūnaṃ, itaresampi vā savanavasena parassa cittaṃ ñatvā kathentānaṃ
analyzed: manussānam para citta vidūnam itaresam pi vā savana vasena parassa cittam ñatvā kathentānam
translated: Having known the other’s mind by hearing the sound of those who know the minds of others among men, or of those who speak after knowing the minds of others among the rest,

original: saddaṃ sutvā. Yakkhapisācādīnanti hiṅkārayakkhānañceva kaṇṇapisācādipisācānaṃ, kumbhaṇḍanāgādīnañca.
analyzed: saddam sutvā yakkha pisāca ādīnam ti hiṅkāra yakkhānam ca iva kaṇṇa pisāca ādi pisācānam kumbhaṇḍa nāga ādīnam ca
translated: having heard the sound. Yakkhas, pisācas, etc., are the yakkhas that make a hissing sound, the pisācas that are kaṇṇapisācas, etc., and the kumbhaṇḍas, nāgas, and so on.

original: Vitakkavipphāravasenāti vipphārikabhāvena pavattavitakkassa vasena. Uppannanti tato
analyzed: vitakka vipphāra vasena āti vipphārika bhāvena pavatta vitakkassa vasena uppannanti tatas
translated: By the means of the diffusion of thought: by the means of the thought that occurs by diffusion. Arisen: arisen from that.

original: samuṭṭhitaṃ. Vippalapantānanti kassaci atthassa abodhanato virūpaṃ, vividhaṃ vā palapantānaṃ.🔽Suttapamattādīnanti ādi-saddena vedanāṭṭakhittacittādīnaṃ saṅgaho. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: samuṭṭhitam vippalapantānam ti kassaci atthassa a bodhanataḥ virūpam vividham vā palapantānam  ādi saddena vedanā aṭṭa khitta citta ādīnam saṅgahaḥ mahā aṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: Chattering: chattering without making known to anyone the meaning of the thought.🔽By the means of the sound of the diffusion of thought: by the means of the sound of the diffusion of thought.

original: pana “idaṃ vakkhāmi, evaṃ vakkhāmīti vitakkayato vitakkavipphārasaddo nāma uppajjatī”ti🔽āgatattā jāgarantānaṃ pakatiyaṃ ṭhitānaṃ avippalapantānaṃ vitakkavipphārasaddo kadāci
analyzed: pana idam vakkhāmi evam vakkhāmi iti vitakkayataḥ vitakka vipphāra saddaḥ nāma uppajjati iti  āgata ttā jāgarantānam pakatiyam ṭhitānam a vippalapantānam vitakka vipphāra saddo kadāci
translated: In the Great Commentary, however, it is said: “When one thinks, ‘I will speak thus, I will speak thus,’ the sound of the diffusion of thought arises.”🔽Therefore it is understood that the sound of the diffusion of thought sometimes arises in those who are awake and are not chattering, but are standing in their normal state. This is what is called “muttering” in the world.

original: uppajjatīti viññāyati, yo loke “mantajappo”ti vuccati. Yassa mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ asotaviññeyyatā
analyzed: uppajjati iti viññāyati yaḥ loke manta jappo ti vuccati yassa mahā aṭṭhakathā ayam a sota viññeyya tā
translated: In the Great Commentary it is said that it is not audible to the ear.

original: vuttā. Tādisañhi sandhāya viññattisahajameva “jivhātālucalanādikaravitakkasamuṭṭhitaṃ
analyzed: vuttā tādisam hi sandhāya viññatti sahajam eva jivhā tālu calana ādi kara vitakka samuṭṭhitam
translated: It is said that the sound of the diffusion of thought arises in one who is muttering, and that it is accompanied by intimation, and that it arises from the thought that causes the movement of the tongue and palate, etc.

original: sukhumasaddaṃ dibbasotena sutvā ādisatīti sutte vutta”nti ānandācariyo avoca. Vuttalakkhaṇo
analyzed: sukhuma saddam dibba sotena sutvā ādisati iti sutte vuttanti ānanda ācariyaḥ avoca vutta lakkhaṇo
translated: The teacher Ānanda said that it is so stated in the sutta because he heard the faint sound with the divine ear and then told it.

original: eva pana nātisukhumo attano, accāsannappadese ṭhitassa ca maṃsasotassāpi āpāthaṃ
analyzed: eva pana na ati sukhumaḥ attanaḥ acca āsanna ppadese ṭhitassa ca maṃsa sotassa api āpātham
translated: But it can be known that the sound is not too faint to come within the range of the fleshly ear of one standing near him.🔽“His”: of that person.

original: gacchatīti sakkā viññātuṃ. Tassāti tassa puggalassa. Tassa vasenāti tassa vitakkassa
analyzed: gacchati iti sakkā viññātum tassa ati tassa puggalassa tassa vasena ati tassa vitakkassa
translated: “By that”: by that thought.

original: vasena. Evaṃ ayampi ādesanavidhā cetopariyañāṇavaseneva āgatāti veditabbā. Keci pana
analyzed: vasena evam ayam pi ādesana vidhā cetaḥ pariya ñāṇa vasena iva āgatā ati veditabbā keci pana
translated: So this mode of telling is to be understood as coming within the range of the knowledge of penetration of minds too.

original: “tassa vasenāti tassa saddassa vasenā”ti atthaṃ vadanti, taṃ ayuttaṃ. Na hi saddaggahaṇena
analyzed: tassa vasena ati tassa saddassa vasena ati attham vadanti tam ayuttam na hi sadda ggahaṇena
translated: But some say that the meaning of “by that” is “by that sound.” That is incorrect.

original: taṃsamuṭṭhāpakacittaṃ gayhati, saddaggahaṇānusārenapi tadatthasseva gahaṇaṃ hoti,🔽na cittassa. Eteneva yadeke “yaṃ vitakkayatoti yamatthaṃ vitakkayato”ti vatvā “tassa
analyzed: tad samuṭṭhāpaka cittam gayhati sadda gahaṇa anusārena api tad atthassa iva gahaṇam hoti  na cittassa etena iva yat eke yam vitakkayato ti yam attham vitakkayato ti vatvā tassa
translated: For when a sound is apprehended, the consciousness that originates it is not apprehended. Only the meaning of that is apprehended by the process of inference from the apprehension of the sound,🔽not the consciousness.

original: vasenāti tassa atthassa vasenā”ti vaṇṇenti, tampi paṭikkhittaṃ.
analyzed: vasena ati tassa atthassa vasena ati vaṇṇenti tam pi paṭikkhittam
translated: This is why some, after saying that “what he thinks” is “what he thinks about,” then say that “by that” is “by that meaning.”

original: Manasā saṅkharīyantīti manosaṅkhārā, vedanāsaññā. Paṇihitāti purimaparibandhavinayena
analyzed: manasā saṅkharīyanti iti manaḥ saṅkhārā vedanā saññā paṇihitā ati purima paribandha vinayena
translated: “They are mental formations because they are formed by the mind” : they are feeling and perception. “They are directed” : they are directed, placed, by the prior condition of the training in the abandoning of defilements.

original: padhānabhāvena nihitā ṭhapitā. Tenāha “cittasaṅkhārā suṭṭhapitā”ti. Vitakkassa vitakkanaṃ
analyzed: padhāna bhāvena nihitā ṭhapitā tena āha citta saṅkhārā su ṭhapitā ati vitakkassa vitakkanam
translated: Hence it is said: “The mental formations are well directed” . “He will think thoughts” : the thinking of thoughts is the arising of thoughts.

original: nāma uppādanamevāti āha “pavattessatī”ti. “Pajānātī”ti pubbe vuttapadasambandhadassanavasena
analyzed: nāma uppādanam eva ati āha pavattessati iti pajānāti iti pubbe vutta pada sambandha dassana vasena
translated: Hence it is said: “he will cause to occur” . “He understands” : he brings about the seeing of the connection between the terms stated previously.

original: āneti. Āgamanenāti jhānassa āgamanaṭṭhānavasena. Pubbabhāgenāti maggassa sabbapubbabhāgena🔽vipassanārambhena. Ubhayaṃ petaṃ yo sayaṃ jhānalābhī, adhigatamaggo ca aññaṃ tadatthāya🔽paṭipajjantaṃ disvā “ayaṃ iminā nīhārena paṭipajjanto addhā jhānaṃ labhissati, maggaṃ
analyzed: āne ti āgamanena ati jhānassa āgamana ṭṭhāna vasena pubbabhāgena ati maggassa sabba pubbabhāgena  vipassanā ārambhena ubhayam yaḥ sayam jhāna lābhī adhigata maggo ca aññam tad atthāya  paṭipajjantam disvā ayam iminā nīhārena paṭipajjantaḥ addhā jhānam labhissati maggam
translated: “By the coming” : by the coming of the jhāna as a place of coming. “By the prior portion” : by the prior portion of the path.🔽“By the beginning” : by the beginning of insight. This is said with reference to one who has attained jhāna and realized the path himself and who, seeing another practicing for that purpose, knows by inference without the knowledge of supernormal power:

original: adhigamissatī”ti abhiññāya vinā anumānavasena jānāti, taṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. Tenāha
analyzed: adhigamissati iti abhiññāya vinā anumāna vasena jānāti tam dassetum vuttam tena āha
translated: “This one, practicing in this way, will certainly attain jhāna and realize the path.”

original: “āgamanena jānāti nāmā”tiādi. Anantarāti vuṭṭhitakālaṃ sandhāyāha. Tadā hi pavattavitakkapajānaneneva
analyzed: āgamanena jānāti nāma atiādi anantarā iti vuṭṭhita kālam sandhāya āha tadā hi pavatta vitakka pajānanena iva
translated: “He knows by his coming” and so on. “Immediately” : this is said referring to the time of arising. For at that time he knows the thought that has arisen.

original: jhānassa hānabhāgiyatādivisesapajānanaṃ.🔽Kiṃ panidaṃ cetopariyañāṇaṃ parassa cittaṃ paricchijja jānantaṃ iddhicittabhāvato
analyzed: kim pana idam cetaḥ pariya ñāṇam parassa cittam paricchijja jānantam iddhi citta bhāvato
translated: “He knows by coming” means by the knowledge of supernormal power. “Immediately” means immediately after emerging. For it is by knowing the thought that occurs then that he knows the distinction of the jhāna’s being subject to retrogressing, and so on.🔽But does not this knowledge of penetration of minds, by discerning another’s cognizance, know all cognizances without distinction as being due to supernormal power?

original: avisesato sabbesampi cittaṃ jānātīti? Noti dassento “tatthā”tiādimāha. Na ariyānanti
analyzed: avisesataḥ sabbesam pi cittam jānāti iti no ti dassento tattha atiādim āha na
translated: To show that it does not he said “Therein” .

original: yena cittena te ariyā nāma jātā, taṃ lokuttaracittaṃ na jānāti appaṭividdhabhāvato.
analyzed: yena cittena te ariyāḥ nāma jātā tam lokuttara cittam na jānāti a paṭividdha bhāvataḥ
translated: He does not know the noble ones’ cognizance: he does not know the supramundane cognizance by means of which they are called “noble ones” because it is not penetrated.

original: Yathā hi puthujjano sabbesampi ariyānaṃ lokuttaracittaṃ na jānāti appaṭividdhattā,
analyzed: yathā hi puthujjanaḥ sabbesam pi ariyānam lokuttara cittam na jānāti appaṭividdha ttā
translated: For just as the worldling does not know the noble ones’ supramundane cognizance because it is not penetrated,

original: evaṃ ariyopi heṭṭhimo uparimassa lokuttaracittaṃ na jānāti appaṭividdhattā eva. Yathā
analyzed: evam ariyaḥ api heṭṭhimaḥ uparimassa lokuttara cittam na jānāti appaṭividdha ttā eva yathā
translated: so too the noble one does not know the higher one’s supramundane cognizance because it is not penetrated.

original: pana uparimo heṭṭhimaṃ phalasamāpattiṃ na samāpajjati, kiṃ evaṃ so tassa lokuttaracittaṃ
analyzed: pana uparimaḥ heṭṭhimam phala samāpattim na samāpajjati kim evam so tassa lokuttara cittam
translated: But just as he does not attain the higher fruit, so too he does not know the higher one’s supramundane cognizance.

original: na jānātīti codanaṃ sandhāyāha “uparimo pana heṭṭhimassa jānātī”ti, paṭividdhattāti
analyzed: na jānāti iti codanam sandhāya āha uparimaḥ pana heṭṭhimassa jānāti iti
translated: “He does not know” refers to the accusation. “But the higher one knows the lower one” is the opinion.

original: adhippāyo. “Uparimo heṭṭhimaṃ na samāpajjatī”ti vatvā tattha kāraṇamāha “tesañhī”tiādi.
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ uparimaḥ heṭṭhimam na samāpajjati iti vatvā tattha kāraṇam āha tesam hi itiādi
translated: “The higher one does not attain the lower one” is the statement. The reason is given there: “Because they are … .”

original: Tesanti ariyānaṃ. Heṭṭhimā heṭṭhimā samāpatti bhūmantarappattiyā paṭippassaddhikappā.
analyzed: tesanti ariyānam heṭṭhimā heṭṭhimā samāpatti bhūmantara ppattiyāḥ paṭippassaddhi kappā
translated: “They” are noble ones. The lower attainment is one that has been suppressed by the attainment of a higher plane.

original: Tenāha “tatrupapattiyeva hotī”ti, na uparibhūmipatti. Nimittādivasena ñātassa kadāci
analyzed: tena āha nimitta ādi vasena ñātassa kadāci
translated: Therefore it is said: “It is only the attainment of that plane that occurs, not the attainment of a higher plane.” It is possible that what is known by way of the sign, etc., may sometimes fail,

original: byabhicāropi siyā, na pana abhiññāñāṇena ñātassāti āha “ceto…pe… natthī”ti. “Taṃ
analyzed: byabhicāraḥ api siyā na pana abhiññā ñāṇena ñātassa ati āha natthi iti taṃ
translated: but what is known by the direct knowledge of the higher consciousness does not fail. Therefore it is said: “There is no failure of the higher … .”

original: bhagavā”tiādi sesaṃ nāma.
analyzed: sesam nāma
translated: “The Blessed One … .” The rest is clear.

original: Dassanasamāpattidesanāvaṇṇanā🔽149. Brahmajāleti brahmajālasuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ. Uttarapadalopena hesa niddeso. Ātappanti
analyzed: dassana samāpatti desanā vaṇṇanā  brahmajāla iti uttara pada lopena ha isa niddesaḥ
translated: The explanation of the teaching of the attainment of the state of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is ended.🔽“Brahma-jā” is the explanation of the word brahma-jāla in the Brahmajāla Sutta. This is the indication by dropping the first part of the word. “Exertion” is energy. Exertion is the opposite of laziness and of all the side of defilement.

original: vīriyaṃ ātappati kosajjaṃ sabbampi saṃkilesapakkhanti. Kusalavīriyasseva hettha gahaṇaṃ
analyzed: vīriyam ātappati kosajjam sabbam pi saṃkilesa pakkhanti kusala vīriyassa iva ha ittha gahaṇam
translated: Here only profitable energy is included.

original: appamādādipadantarasannidhānato. Padahitabbatoti padahanato, bhāvanaṃ uddissa vāyamanatoti
analyzed: appamāda ādi pada antara sannidhānato padahitabbato ti padahanataḥ bhāvanam uddissa vā āyamanato ti
translated: because of the proximity of the other terms beginning with “diligence” .🔽“To be exerted” : to be exerted by way of the act of exertion, or to be exerted by way of the act of striving with the aim of development.

original: attho. Anuyuñjitabbatoti anuyuñjanato. Īdisānaṃ padānaṃ bahulaṃkattuvisayatāya icchitabbattā
analyzed: atthaḥ anuyuñjitabbato ti anuyuñjanataḥ īdisānam padānam bahulaṃkattu visaya tāya icchitabba ttā
translated: “To be applied” : to be applied by way of the act of application.

original: ātappapadassa viya itaresampi kattusādhanatā daṭṭhabbā. Paṭipattiyaṃ nappamajjati
analyzed: ātappa padassa viya itaresam pi kattu sādhana tā daṭṭhabbā paṭipattiyam na ppamajjati
translated: Since it is desired that such terms as these should have as their domain the act,🔽the function of the other terms should be seen to be the same as that of the term “diligence” .🔽“He is not negligent in practice by means of this” : diligence .🔽“He is not forgetful by means of this” : mindfulness .

original: etenāti appamādo, satiavippavāso. Sammā manasi karoti etenāti sammāmanasikāro, tathāpavatto
analyzed: etena ati appamādaḥ sati a vippavāso sammā manasi karoti etena ati sammāmanasikāro tathā pavatto
translated: “He rightly directs his mind by means of this” : right direction of mind .

original: kusalacittuppādo. Bhāvanānuyogameva tathā vadati. Desanākkamena paṭhamā, dassanasamāpatti🔽nāma karajakāye paṭikkūlākārassa sammadeva dassanavasena pavattasamāpattibhāvato.🔽Nippariyāyenevāti vuttalakkhaṇadassanasamāpattisannissayattā, dassanamaggaphalabhāvato
analyzed: kusala cittuppādaḥ bhāvanā anuyogam eva tathā vadati desanā kkamena paṭhamā dassana samāpatti  nāma karaja kāye paṭikkūla ākārassa sammad eva dassana vasena pavatta samāpatti bhāvato  nippariyāyena iva āti vutta lakkhaṇa dassana samāpatti sannissaya ttā dassana magga phala bhāvataḥ
translated: The arising of wholesome consciousness occurring thus is the development of concentration.🔽The first fruition of recluseship is the fruition of stream-entry.🔽It is called “fruition” because it occurs as the support for the fruition attainment .

original: ca paṭhamasāmaññaphalaṃ pariyāyena vinā dassanasamāpatti.
analyzed: ca paṭhama sāmañña phalam pariyāyena vinā dassana samāpatti
translated: It is called “recluseship” because it is the path and fruition .🔽It is called “first” because it is the first to be reached by the path of stream-entry.

original: Atikkamma chavimaṃsalohitaṃ aṭṭhiṃ paccavekkhatīti tāni apaccavekkhitvā aṭṭhimeva🔽paccavekkhati. Aṭṭhiārammaṇā dibbacakkhupādakajjhānasamāpattīti vuttanayena aṭṭhiārammaṇā🔽dibbacakkhuadhiṭṭhānā paṭhamajjhānasamāpatti. Yo hi bhikkhu ālokakasiṇe catutthajjhānaṃ🔽nibbattetvā taṃ pādakaṃ katvā adhigatadibbacakkhuñāṇo hutvā saviññāṇake kāye aṭṭhiṃ🔽pariggahetvā tattha paṭikkūlamanasikāravasena paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ nibbatteti, tassāyaṃ🔽paṭhamajjhānasamāpatti dutiyā dassanasamāpatti. Tena vuttaṃ “aṭṭhi aṭṭhī”tiādi. Yo
analyzed: atikkamma chavi maṃsa lohitam aṭṭhim paccavekkhati iti tāni a paccavekkhitvā aṭṭhim eva  paccavekkhati aṭṭhi ārammaṇā dibba cakkhu pādaka jjhāna samāpatti iti vutta nayena aṭṭhi ārammaṇā  dibba cakkhu adhiṭṭhānā paṭhama jhāna samāpatti yaḥ hi bhikkhu āloka kasiṇe catuttha jhānaṃ  nibbattetvā tam pādakam katvā adhigata dibba cakkhu ñāṇaḥ hutvā sa viññāṇake kāye aṭṭhim  pariggahetvā tattha paṭikkūla manasikāra vasena paṭhamam jhānam nibbatteti tassa ayam  paṭhama jhāna samāpatti dutiyā dassana samāpatti tena vuttam aṭṭhi aṭṭhi itiādi yaḥ
translated: He looks upon the bones, passing over the skin, flesh and blood: he passes over the skin, flesh and blood and looks only at the bones. The attainment of jhāna based on the divine eye, which has bones as its object: the attainment of the first jhāna based on the divine eye, which has bones as its object, in the way already described. For a bhikkhu who has attained the fourth jhāna in the light kasiṇa and, making that the basis, has acquired the knowledge of the divine eye, and who, having discerned bones in a living body with consciousness, produces the first jhāna by means of attention given to repulsiveness in regard to them, this is the attainment of the first jhāna. The second is the attainment of seeing. Hence ‘Bones, bones’ is said.🔽

original: panettha pāḷiyaṃ dvattiṃsākāramanasikāro vutto, so maggasodhanavasena vutto. Tattha🔽vā kataparicayassa sukheneva vuttanayā aṭṭhipaccavekkhaṇā samijjhatīti. Tenevettha
analyzed: pana ittha pāḷiyam dvattiṃsa ākāra manasikāro vutto so magga sodhana vasena vuttaḥ tattha 🔽vā kata paricayassa sukhena iva vutta nayā aṭṭhi paccavekkhaṇā samijjhati iti tena iva itthā
translated: He contemplates the bone, transcending skin, flesh, and blood: he does not contemplate the skin, flesh, and blood, but he contemplates only the bones. Contemplation of the bones is the attainment of jhāna based on the divine eye, which is the preliminary-work concentration: in the way already described, the attainment of the first jhāna based on the bones as a kasiṇa is the divine eye, which is the resolve. For when a bhikkhu develops the fourth jhāna in the light kasiṇa and, making that the basis, obtains the knowledge of the divine eye and, as the discernment of what is pleasing and agreeable, discerns a skeleton in a conscious body, he produces the first jhāna in him. This is the attainment of the first jhāna. The second is the attainment of seeing. But the thirty-two aspects of foulness mentioned in the text are mentioned for the purpose of purifying the path. For the contemplation of the bones, which has been practised there, succeeds easily in one who has already had practice in them. That is why it is said:

original: “imaṃ cevā”ti “atikkamma cā”ti ca-saddo samuccayattho vutto. Taṃ jhānanti yathāvuttaṃ
analyzed: imam ca iva ati atikkamma ca iti ca saddo samuccaya tthaḥ vuttaḥ tam jhānam ti yathā vuttam
translated: The word “and” is used in the sense of “and also” .🔽The jhāna is the first jhāna described in the way beginning, “Quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unprofitable things” .

original: paṭhamajjhānaṃ. Ayanti ayaṃ sakadāgāmiphalasamāpatti. Sātisayaṃ catusaccadassanāgamanato
analyzed: paṭhama jhānam ayanti ayam sakadāgāmi phala samāpatti sa atisayam catu acca dassana āgamanato
translated: The “coming” is the coming to the fruit of once-returner.🔽The “going” is the second kind of coming, which is the coming to the fruit of non-returner by way of the path of non-returner.

original: pariyāyena vinā mukhyā dutiyā dassanasamāpatti. Yāva tatiyamaggā vattatīti āha “khīṇāsavassa
analyzed: pariyāyena vinā mukhyā dutiyā dassana samāpatti yāva tatiya maggā vattati iti āha khīṇāsavassa
translated: The “going” is the third kind of coming, which is the coming to the fruit of arahantship by way of the path of arahantship.

original: vasena catutthā dassanasamāpatti kathitā”ti.
analyzed: vasena catutthā dassana samāpatti kathitā ati
translated: The “going” is the fourth kind of coming, which is the coming to the fruit of arahantship by way of the path of non-returner.

original: Pāḷiyaṃ purisassa cāti ca-saddo byatireke, tena yathāvuttasamāpattidvayato vuccamānaṃyeva
analyzed: pāḷiyam purisassa ca ati ca saddaḥ byatireke tena yathā vutta samāpatti dvayataḥ vuccamānam yeva
translated: The word “and” in the text is used in the sense of “also.” It thus shows the difference between the two kinds of coming mentioned above.

original: imassa visesaṃ joteti. Avicchedena pavattiyā sotasadisatāya viññāṇameva viññāṇasotaṃ,🔽tadetaṃ viññāṇaṃ purimato anantarapaccayaṃ labhitvā pacchimassa anantarapaccayo hutvā
analyzed: imassa visesam jotā iti avicchedena pavattiyā sota sadisa tāya viññāṇam eva viññāṇa sotam  tat etam viññāṇam purimataḥ anantara paccayam labhitvā pacchimassa anantara paccayaḥ hutvā
translated: The “stream” is consciousness itself, which flows on in continuity.🔽It is called a “stream” because it occurs as a condition, being antecedent and similar, for the subsequent consciousness.

original: pavattatīti ayaṃ assa sotāgatatāya sotasadisatā, tasmā pajānitabbabhāvena vuttaṃ
analyzed: pavattati iti ayam assa sota āgata tāya sota sadisa tā tasmā pajānitabba bhāvena vuttam
translated: Therefore it is said that it should be known as a stream.

original: ekameva cettha viññāṇaṃ, tasmā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “viññāṇasotanti viññāṇamevā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ekam eva ca ittha viññāṇam tasmai aṭṭhakathā ayam viññāṇa sotam ti viññāṇam eva ati vuttam
translated: But here there is only consciousness, and that is why it is said in the commentary, “The stream of consciousness is consciousness itself.”

original: Dvīhipi bhāgehīti orabhāgaparabhāgehi. Idhaloko hissa orabhāgo, paraloko parabhāgo
analyzed: dvīhi pi bhāgehi iti orabhāga parabhāgehi idha lokaḥ hissa orabhāgaḥ para lokaḥ parabhāgaḥ
translated: With the two parts: with the near part and the far part. For this world is the near part, and the other world is the far part.

original: dvinnampi vasenetaṃ sambandhanti. Tenāha “idhaloke patiṭṭhita”ntiādi. Viññāṇassa🔽khaṇe khaṇe bhijjantassa kāmaṃ natthi kassaci patiṭṭhitatā, taṇhāvasena pana taṃ
analyzed: dvinnam pi vasena itam tena āha idha loke patiṭṭhita ntiādi viññāṇassa  khaṇe khaṇe bhijjantassa kāmam natthi kassaci patiṭṭhita tā taṇhā vasena pana taṃ
translated: This is connected with both, thus it is said: “It is established in this world” and so on.

original: “patiṭṭhita”nti vuccatīti āha “chandarāgavasenā”ti. Vuttañhetaṃ –🔽“Kabaḷīkāre ce bhikkhave āhāre atthi rāgo, atthi nandī, atthi taṇhā, patiṭṭhitaṃ🔽tattha viññāṇaṃ viruḷhaṃ. Yattha patiṭṭhitaṃ viññāṇaṃ viruḷhaṃ…pe… atthi tattha āyatiṃ
analyzed: patiṭṭhitanti vuccati iti āha chanda rāga vasena ati vuttam ha etam  kabaḷīkāre ce bhikkhave āhāre atthi rāgaḥ atthi nandī atthi taṇhā patiṭṭhitam  tattha viññāṇam viruḷham yattha patiṭṭhitam viññāṇam viruḷham pe atthi tattha āyatim
translated: Although consciousness is broken up moment by moment, it is nevertheless said to be “established” in the sense of craving, and that is why it is said: “By desire and lust.” For this is said:

original: punabbhavābhinibbattī”tiādi.
translated: “Bhikkhus, if there is desire and lust for solid food, consciousness is established there and comes to growth. Where consciousness is established and comes to growth, bhikkhus, there is a descent of mentality-materiality. Where there is a descent of mentality-materiality, there is the growth of what is subject to birth … there is the growth of suffering. … If there is desire and lust for contact … for mental volition … for consciousness, consciousness is established there and comes to growth. Where consciousness is established and comes to growth, bhikkhus, there is a descent of mentality-materiality. Where there is a descent of mentality-materiality, there is the growth of what is subject to birth … there is the growth of suffering” .

original: Kammanti kusalākusalakammaṃ, upayogavacanametaṃ. Kammato upagacchantanti kammabhāvena
analyzed: kammanti kusala akusala kammam upayoga vacanam etam kammataḥ kamma bhāvena
translated: Kamma : this is a word for profitable and unprofitable kamma. It is said figuratively. It goes to kamma : it is of the nature of kamma.

original: upagacchantaṃ, viññāṇanti adhippāyo. Abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇañhi yena kammunā sahagataṃ,
analyzed: upagacchantam viññāṇanti adhippāyaḥ abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇam hi yena kammunā sahagatam
translated: and the intention is that it is the consciousness that is approaching. For the consciousness of kamma-formation

original: aññadatthu tabbhāvameva upagataṃ hutvā pavattati. Idhaloke patiṭṭhitaṃ nāma idha🔽katūpacitakammabhāvūpagamanato. Kammabhavaṃ ākaḍḍhantanti kammaviññāṇaṃ attanā sampayuttakammaṃ
analyzed: tad bhāvam eva upagatam hutvā pavattati idha loke patiṭṭhitam nāma idha  katu upacita kamma bhāva upagamanataḥ kamma bhavam kamma viññāṇam attanā sampayutta kammaṃ
translated: is in fact that which has approached the state of being of the kamma with which it is associated. That called “established in this world” is so called🔽because it has approached the state of being of the kamma stored up here. It draws along the kamma-process: the rebirth-linking consciousness draws along the kamma associated with itself by giving rebirth-linking.

original: javāpetvā paṭisandhinibbattanena tadabhimukhaṃ ākaḍḍhantaṃ. Teneva paṭisandhinibbattanasāmatthiyena🔽paraloke patiṭṭhitaṃ nāma attano phalassa tattha patiṭṭhāpanena. Keci pana “abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇaṃ🔽parato vipākaṃ dātuṃ asamatthaṃ idhaloke patiṭṭhitaṃ nāma, dātuṃ samatthaṃ pana paraloke
analyzed: javāpetvā paṭisandhi nibbattanena tad abhimukham ākaḍḍhantam tena iva paṭisandhi nibbattana sāmatthiyena  para loke patiṭṭhitam nāma attano phalassa tattha patiṭṭhāpanena keci pana abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇam  paratas vipākam dātum asamattham idha loke patiṭṭhitam nāma dātum samattham pana para loke
translated: Because of the fact that it is able to give rebirth-linking,

original: patiṭṭhitaṃ nāmā”ti vadanti, taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ “ubhayato abbocchinna”nti vuttattā.
analyzed: patiṭṭhitam nāma ati vadanti tam tesam matimattam ubhayatas abbocchinnam ti vutta ttā
translated: it is called “established in the next world” because it establishes its own fruit there. But some say that the consciousness of kamma-formation is called “established in this world” because it is unable to give its ripening in the next world, and it is called “established in the next world” because it is able to give it there. That is their opinion.

original: Yañca tehi “paraloke patiṭṭhita”nti vuttaṃ, taṃ idhalokepi patiṭṭhitameva. Na hi
analyzed: yat ca tehi para loke patiṭṭhitanti vuttam tat idha loke pi patiṭṭhitam eva na hi
translated: And what is said by them to be “established in the world beyond” is established in this world too. For

original: tassa idhaloke patiṭṭhitabhāvena vinā paraloke patiṭṭhitabhāvo sambhavati. Sekkhaputhujjanānaṃ
analyzed: tassa idha loke patiṭṭhita bhāvena vinā para loke patiṭṭhita bhāvo sambhavati sekkha puthujjanānam
translated: without being established in this world, it cannot be established in the world beyond.

original: cetopariyañāṇanti sekkhānaṃ, puthujjanānañca cetaso paricchindanakañāṇaṃ. Kathitaṃ🔽paricchinditabbassa cetaso chandarāgavasena patiṭṭhitabhāvajotanato.
analyzed: cetaḥ pariya ñāṇan ti sekkhānam puthujjanānam ca cetaso paricchindana kañāṇam kathitaṃ  paricchinditabbassa cetasaḥ chanda rāga vasena patiṭṭhita bhāva jotanato
translated: The knowledge of others’ minds of trainees and ordinary men is the knowledge of discerning the mind of a trainee and of an ordinary man. It is said🔽to be “established by lust and greed” in order to show the state of being established in the world by means of lust and greed in the object discerned.

original: Catutthāya dassanasamāpattiyā tatiyadassanasamāpattiyaṃ vuttappaṭikkhepena attho veditabbo.

Dutiyajjhānaṃ dutiyāti ettha pana “aṭṭhikavaṇṇakasiṇavasena paṭiladdhadutiyajjhānaṃ🔽dutiyā dassanasamāpattī”ti vadanti, tatiyajjhānampi tatheva paṭiladdhaṃ. translated: The moment the sign is seen, the stage is reached. Another method: here there is nothing new in the first jhāna as the first seeing-attainment. But in the case of the second jhāna, etc., they say that the second jhāna is the second seeing- attainment when it is reached by means of the white kasiṇa, and so on. And the third jhāna is likewise reached in the same way. But the third jhāna is the third seeing-attainment in the case of a bhikkhu who, having produced the fourth jhāna in the light kasiṇa and made that his basis, has acquired the divine eye and, after resolving upon the third jhāna, has taken up a skeleton kasiṇa with consciousness and, after resolving upon the third jhāna, has produced the three lower jhānas in that. The third jhāna is the third seeing-attainment in the case of one who, after resolving upon the divine eye knowledge that has become the basis for the third jhāna, has taken up a skeleton kasiṇa with consciousness and, after resolving upon the third jhāna, has produced the three lower jhānas in that.🔽

translated: and having done so, the fourth jhāna of one who has acquired the knowledge of the divine eye is the fourth kind of direct-knowledge attainment. Herein,

analyzed: paṭhamā dassana samāpatti aṭṭhi ārammaṇa dutiya jhāna pādakaḥ dutiya maggaḥ dutiyā dassana samāpatti
