translated: “Seen” : the visible-form base is seen, and what is seen is what is visible, what is being seen, what will be seen, and what one would see if one were to see with the eye in the absence of visual consciousness.

original: sati samavāye passeyyaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ “diṭṭhaṃ” tveva gahitaṃ kālavisesassa anāmaṭṭhabhāvato.🔽“Suta”ntiādīsupi eseva nayo. Sutanti saddāyatanaṃ sotabbato. Mutanti sanissayena
analyzed: sati samavāye passeyyam tam sabbam diṭṭham tu eva gahitam kāla visesassa a nāmaṭṭha bhāvato  sutanti ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ sutanti sadda āyatanam sotabbataḥ mutanti sa nissayena
translated: All this is included in the term “seen,” because the distinction of time is not mentioned.🔽The same method applies to the terms “heard,” etc. “Heard” : the sound base is heard, and what is heard is what is audible, what is being heard, what will be heard, and what one would hear if one were to hear with the ear in the absence of auditory consciousness.

original: ghānādiindriyena sayaṃ patvā pāpuṇitvā gahetabbaṃ. Tenāha “patvā gahetabbato”ti.
analyzed: ghāna ādi indriyena sayam patvā pāpuṇitvā gahetabbam tena āha patvā gahetabbato ti
translated: “Sensed” : what is to be sensed by the nose, etc., is to be sensed by oneself, having reached it by way of the nose, etc., as one’s own.

original: Viññātanti vijānitabbaṃ, taṃ pana diṭṭhādivinimuttaṃ viññeyyanti āha “sukhadukkhādidhammāyatana”nti.
analyzed: viññātanti vijānitabbam tam pana diṭṭha ādi vinimuttam viññeyyanti āha sukha dukkha ādi dhamma āyatanam ti
translated: “Cognized” : what is to be cognized is what is cognizable, and that is distinct from what is seen, etc. The author of the commentary says: “The bases of the dhammas such as pleasure and pain.”

original: Pattanti yathā tathā pattaṃ, hatthagataṃ adhigatanti attho. Tenāha “pariyesitvā vā
analyzed: pattanti yathā tathā pattam hattha gatam adhigatan ti tena āha pariyesitvā vā
translated: “Reached” : what is reached in such and such a way is what is reached, what is in one’s hand, what is attained. The author of the commentary says: “Having sought for it,

original: apariyesitvā vā”ti. Pariyesitanti pattiyāmatthaṃ pariyiṭṭhaṃ, taṃ pana pattaṃ vā
analyzed: a pariyesitvā vā ati pariyesitanti patti yāmattham pariyiṭṭham tam pana pattam vā
translated: or without having searched.” “Having searched” means having searched for the sake of obtaining a bowl. But that bowl, whether it is

original: siyā appattaṃ vā ubhayathāpi pariyesitamevāti āha “pattaṃ vā appattaṃ vā”ti. Padadvayenāpi🔽dvippakārampi pattaṃ, dvippakārampi pariyesitaṃ, tena tena pakārena tathāgatena abhisambuddhanti🔽dasseti. Cittena anusañcaritanti copanaṃ apāpetvā citteneva anusaṃcaritaṃ, parivitakkitanti
analyzed: siyā appattam vā ubhayathā api pariyesitam eva ati āha pattam vā appattam vā iti pada dvayena api  dvi pakāram pi pattam dvi pakāram pi pariyesitam tena tena pakārena tathāgatena abhisambuddhanti  dasseti cittena anusañcaritanti copanam a pāpetvā cittena iva anusaṃcaritam parivitakkitanti
translated: Or without having searched for it.” “Having searched for it” means having searched for it with the aim of obtaining it. But that bowl may be obtained or not obtained; in both cases it is “having searched for it.” Therefore he said: “whether obtained or not obtained.” By the two phrases

original: attho. Pītakanti ādīti ādi-saddena lohitakaodātādi sabbaṃ rūpārammaṇavibhāgaṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: atthaḥ pītakan ti ādi iti ādi saddena lohitaka odāta ādi sabbam rūpa ārammaṇa vibhāgam saṅgaṇhāti
translated: he shows that the bowl is of two kinds and that it is searched for in two ways, and that it is discovered by the Tathāgata in such and such a way. “Having mentally explored” means having explored it with the mind alone without making a mental note of it. The meaning is: having mentally reflected on it. “Yellow” and so on: by the word “and so on” he includes all the distinctions of material objects such as red, white, and so on.

original: Sumanoti rāgavasena, lobhavasena, saddhādivasena vā sumano. Dummanoti byāpādavitakkavasena,
analyzed: su mano ti rāga vasena lobha vasena saddhā ādi vasena vā su mano dummano ti byāpāda vitakka vasena
translated: “Glad” means glad through lust, through greed, or through faith and so on. “Sad” means sad through ill will and worry,

original: vihiṃsāvitakkavasena vā dummano. Majjhattoti aññāṇavasena vā ñāṇavasena vā majjhatto.
analyzed: vihiṃsā vitakka vasena vā dummanaḥ majjhatto ti aññāṇa vasena vā ñāṇa vasena vā majjhatto
translated: or sad through the thought of harming. “Indifferent” means indifferent through ignorance or through knowledge.

original: Eseva nayo sabbattha. Tattha tattha ādi-saddena saṅkhasaddo paṇavasaddo, pattagandho
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ sabbattha tattha tattha ādi saddena saṅkha saddo paṇava saddo patta gandho
translated: And so in all cases. Herein, the word “etc.” should be regarded as including the sound of a conch, the sound of a bheri-drum, the smell of a leaf,

original: pupphagandho, pattaraso phalaraso, upādinnaṃ anupādinnaṃ, majjhattavedanā kusalakammaṃ
analyzed: puppha gandhaḥ patta rasaḥ phala rasaḥ upādinnam anupādinnam majjhatta vedanā kusala kammaṃ
translated: the smell of a flower, the taste of a leaf, the taste of a fruit, the clung-to, the unclung-to, the neutral feeling, profitable action,

original: akusalakammanti evaṃ ādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: akusala kamman ti evam ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: and unprofitable action.

original: Appattanti ñāṇena asampattaṃ, aviditanti attho. Tenāha “ñāṇena asacchikata”nti. Tatheva
analyzed: appattam ti ñāṇena a sampattam aviditam ti attho tena āha ñāṇena a sacchikatam ti tathā iva
translated: “Not yet attained”: not yet reached by knowledge; not yet known is the meaning. Hence he said “not yet realized by knowledge.”

original: gatattāti tatheva ñātattā abhisambuddhattā. Gata-saddena ekatthaṃ buddhiatthanti
analyzed: gata ttā ati tathā iva ñāta ttā abhisambuddha ttā gata saddena ekattham buddhi attham ti
translated: “Gone to”: gone to in the same way; known in the same way; fully known in the same way. The word “gone” has the meaning of “known in the same way” and “fully known in the same way.”

original: attho. “Gatiatthā hi dhātavo buddhiatthā bhavantī”ti akkharacintakā.
analyzed: atthaḥ gati atthāḥ hi dhātavaḥ buddhi atthāḥ bhavanti iti akkhara cintakā
translated: For the etymologists say “The verbal roots gam and gam are synonymous.”

original: Abyākataṭṭhānādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: abyākata ṭṭhāna ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the terms “unexplained,” etc.,

original: 189. “Asamataṃ kathetvā”ti vatvā samopi nāma koci natthi, kuto uttaritaroti dassetuṃ
analyzed: asamatam kathetvā iti vatvā samaḥ api nāma koci natthi kutas uttaritaro ti dassetum
translated: After the words “having spoken of the incomparable,” it might be thought that there is no one at all who is equal, so how should there be one superior? In order to show this he said “unsurpassed.”

original: “anuttarata”nti vuttaṃ. Sā panāyaṃ asamatā, anuttaratā ca sabbaññutaṃ pūretvā ṭhitāti
analyzed: anuttara tat ti vuttam sā pana ayam asama tā anuttara tā ca sabbaññu tam pūretvā ṭhitā ati
translated: But this incomparability and this un-surpassability are established in him as fulfilling omniscience.

original: dassetuṃ “sabbaññuta”nti vuttaṃ. Sā sabbaññutā saddhammavaracakkavattibhāvena loke
analyzed: dassetum sabbaññu tat ti vuttam sā sabbaññu tā saddhamma vara cakkavatti bhāvena loke
translated: “Omniscience” is said in order to show that. That omniscience is manifested in the world🔽through the state of being a universal monarch of the true Dhamma.🔽Thus, “the state of being a king of the Dhamma” is said in order to show that. In the same way,

original: pākaṭā jātāti dassetuṃ “dhammarājabhāvaṃ kathetvā”ti vuttaṃ. Tathā sabbaññubhāvena
analyzed: pākaṭā jātā ati dassetum dhammarāja bhāvam kathetvā iti vuttam tathā sabbaññu bhāvena
translated: showing that the Teacher, through his omniscience,

original: ca satthā imesu diṭṭhigatavipallāsesu evaṃ paṭipajjatīti dassento “idānī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: ca satthā imesu diṭṭhi gata vipallāsesu evam paṭipajjati iti dassentaḥ idāni iti ādim āha
translated: acts in this way with regard to the perversions of views, he says “now” and so on.

original: Tattha sīhanādanti abhītanādaṃ seṭṭhanādaṃ. Seṭṭhanādo hesa, yadidaṃ ṭhapanīyassa
analyzed: tattha sīha nādanti abhīta nādam seṭṭha nādam seṭṭha nādaḥ ha isa yat idam ṭhapanīyassa
translated: Herein, the lion’s roar is the fearless roar, the best roar. For this is the best roar, namely, the showing of the state of being a question to be set aside.

original: pañhassa ṭhapanīyabhāvadassanaṃ. Ṭhapanīyatā cassa pāḷiāruḷhā eva “na heta”ntiādinā.
analyzed: pañhassa ṭhapanīya bhāva dassanam ṭhapanīya tā ca ssa pāḷi āruḷhā eva na hetanti ādinā
translated: And the state of being a question to be set aside is stated in the text itself with the words “not so” and so on.

original: Yathā upacitakammakilesena itthattaṃ āgantabbaṃ, tathā naṃ āgatoti tathāgato, satto.
analyzed: yathā upacita kamma kilesena itthattam āgantabbam tathā nam āgataḥ iti tathāgataḥ satto
translated: The being who has come to this existence through the accumulation of kamma and defilements is a “thus come” being .

original: Tathā hi so rūpādīsu satto visattoti katvā “satto”ti ca vuccati. Itthattanti ca paṭiladdhattā
analyzed: tathā hi saḥ rūpa ādīsu sattaḥ visattaḥ iti katvā satto iti ca vuccati itthattat ti ca paṭiladdha ttā
translated: For he is called a “thus come” being because he is a being who has come thus in the sense of being bound to material form, and so on.

original: tathā paccakkhabhūto attabhāvoti veditabbo.
analyzed: tathā paccakkha bhūtaḥ atta bhāvaḥ ti veditabbaḥ
translated: And the “thus” should be understood as the individual existence that is directly experienced by him.

original: “Atthasaṃhitaṃ na hotī”ti iminā ubhayattha vidhuratādassanena niratthakavippalāpataṃ
analyzed: attha saṃhitam na hoti iti iminā ubhayattha vidhura tā dassanena niratthaka vippalāpa tam
translated: “It is not connected with profit” : by this he shows that it is devoid of profit in both ways, and he explains the futility of that doctrine.

original: tassa vādassa vibhāveti, ubhayalokatthavidhurampi samānaṃ “kiṃ nu kho vivaṭṭanissita”nti🔽koci āsaṅkeyyāti tadāsaṅkānivattanatthaṃ “na ca dhammasaṃhita”nti vuttaṃ. Tenāha
analyzed: tassa vādassa vibhāveti ubhaya lokattha vidhuram pi samānam kim nu kho vivaṭṭa nissitanti  koci āsaṅkeyyā ti tad āsaṅkā nivattana attham na ca dhamma saṃhitan ti vuttam tena āha
translated: “It is not connected with the good life” : since it is devoid of profit in both worlds, someone might suspect that it is connected with the round of rebirths.🔽To prevent such a notion, the Master says, “It is not connected with the good life.”🔽“It is not connected with the supramundane good life” : although it is not connected with the round of rebirths, someone might suspect that it is connected with the supramundane good life.🔽To prevent such a notion, the Master says, “It is not the beginning of the holy life.”

original: “navalokuttaradhammanissitaṃ na hotī”ti. Yadipi taṃ na vivaṭṭogataṃ hoti, vivaṭṭassa
analyzed: nava lokuttara dhamma nissitam na hoti iti yadi api tam na vivaṭṭa ugatam hoti vivaṭṭassa
translated: “It is not the beginning of the holy life” : although it is not the beginning of the holy life, someone might suspect that it is connected with the holy life.🔽To prevent such a notion, the Master says, “It is not the holy life.”🔽“It is not the holy life” : although it is not the holy life, someone might suspect that it is connected with the holy life.🔽To prevent such a notion, the Master says, “It is not the fruit of the holy life.”🔽“It is not the fruit of the holy life” : although it is not the fruit of the holy life, someone might suspect that it is connected with the fruit of the holy life.🔽To prevent such a notion, the Master says, “It is not the way to the fruit of the holy life.”🔽“It is not the way to the fruit of the holy life” : although it is not the way to the fruit of the holy life, someone might suspect that it is connected with the way to the fruit of the holy life.

original: pana adhiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ nu khoti koci āsaṅkeyyāti tadāsaṅkānivattanatthaṃ “na ādibrahmacariyaka”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pana adhiṭṭhāna bhūtam nu kho ti koci āsaṅkeyya ati tad āsaṅkā nivattana attham na ādi brahmacariyakantiādi vuttaṃ
translated: To prevent such a notion, the Master says, “It is not the penetration of the way to the fruit of the holy life.”

original: 190. Kāmaṃ taṇhāpi dukkhasabhāvattā “dukkha”nti byākātabbā, pabhavabhāvena pana sā
analyzed: kāmam taṇhā api dukkha sabhāva ttā dukkhanti byākātabbā pabhava bhāvena pana sā
translated: “It is not the penetration of the way to the fruit of the holy life” : although it is not the penetration of the way to the fruit of the holy life, someone might suspect that it is connected with the penetration of the way to the fruit of the holy life.

original: tato visuṃ kātabbāti “taṇhaṃ ṭhapetvā”ti vuttaṃ. Tenāha “tasseva dukkhassa pabhāvikā”tiādi.
analyzed: tatas visum kātabbā ti taṇham ṭhapetvā iti vuttam tena āha tassa iva dukkhassa pabhāvikā tiādi
translated: To prevent such a notion, the Master says, “It is not the penetration of the penetration of the way to the fruit of the holy life.”🔽“It is not the penetration of the penetration of the way to the fruit of the holy life

original: Nanu ca avijjādayopi dukkhassa samudayoti? Saccaṃ samudayo, tassā pana kammassa vicittabhāvahetuto,
analyzed: nanu ca avijjā ādayaḥ api dukkhassa samudayo ti saccam samudayo tassā pana kammassa vicitta bhāva hetuto
translated: Are not ignorance, etc., also the origin of suffering? They are indeed the origin, but craving is the origin in the highest sense because it is the cause of the diversity of kamma, and because it is the specific condition for the origin of suffering.

original: dukkhuppādane visesapaccayabhāvato ca sātisayo samudayaṭṭhoti sā eva suttesu tathā
analyzed: dukkha uppādane visesa paccaya bhāvato ca sa atisayaḥ samudaya ṭṭhaḥ ti sā eva suttesu tathā
translated: Therefore it is only craving that is stated as the origin in the suttas.🔽“Craving is the origin of suffering” is said.

original: vuttā. Tenāha “taṇhā dukkhasamudayoti byākata”nti. Ubhinnaṃ appavattīti dukkhasamudayānaṃ🔽appavattinimittaṃ. “Dukkhaparijānano”tiādi maggakiccadassanaṃ, tena maggassa bhāvanatthopi
analyzed: vuttā tena āha taṇhā dukkha samudayo ti byākatam ti ubhinnam appavattī iti dukkha samudayānam  a pavatti nimittam dukkha parijānanā ti ādi magga kicca dassanam tena maggassa bhāvanā atthaḥ api
translated: The cause of the non-occurrence of both is the cause of the non-occurrence of suffering and its origin.🔽The phrase “the full understanding of suffering” and so on shows the function of the path. Therefore it should be understood that the purpose of developing the path is also shown by this phrase.

original: atthato dassitovāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Na hi bhāvanābhisamayena vinā pariññābhisamayādayo
analyzed: atthataḥ dassito vā ati daṭṭhabbam na hi bhāvanā abhisamayena vinā pariññā abhisamaya ādayaḥ
translated: For without the realization of development, the realization of full understanding, etc., is impossible.

original: sambhavantīti. Saccavavatthāpanaṃ appamādapaṭipattibhāvato asammohakalyāṇakittisaddādinimittatāya
analyzed: sambhavanti iti sacca vavatthāpanam appamāda paṭipatti bhāvataḥ asammoha kalyāṇa kitti sadda ādi nimitta tāya
translated: The establishment of the truths is the cause of the non-delusion of the good person by the sound of his good report, etc., because it is the foundation for the practice of heedfulness.

original: yathā sātisayaṃ idhalokatthāvahaṃ, evaṃ yāva ñāṇassa tikkhavisadabhāvappattiyā abhāvena
analyzed: yathā sa atisayam idha lokattha āvaham evam yāva ñāṇassa tikkha visada bhāva ppattiyāḥ abhāvena
translated: It is the cause of the attainment of the highest good in this world to the extent that it leads to the attainment of the sharpness and clarity of knowledge.

original: navalokuttaradhammasampāpakaṃ na hoti, tāva tattha tattha sampattibhave abbhudayasampatti
analyzed: nava lokuttara dhamma sampāpakam na hoti tāva tattha tattha sampatti bhave
translated: and it does not bring about the attainment of the nine supramundane states, then it is only the attainment of the various kinds of success in the world of men and gods that is included in it.

original: anugatameva siyāti vuttaṃ “etaṃ idhalokaparalokatthanissita”nti. Navalokuttaradhammanissitanti
analyzed: anugatam eva siyā iti vuttam etam idha loka para loka attha nissitanti nava lokuttara dhamma nissitanti
translated: That is why it is said that it is “based on this world and the next.”

original: navavidhampi lokuttaradhammaṃ nissāya pavattaṃ tadadhigamūpāyabhāvato. Yasmā saccasambodhaṃ
analyzed: navavidham pi lokuttara dhammam nissāya pavattam tad adhigama upāya bhāvataḥ yasmā sacca sambodham
translated: Based on the nine supramundane states: it occurs based on the nine supramundane states, because they are the means to their attainment.🔽Since the life of purity in the Dispensation is lived with the aim of the penetration of the truths,

original: uddissa sāsanabrahmacariyaṃ vussati, na aññadatthaṃ, tasmā etaṃ saccavavatthāpanaṃ
analyzed: uddissa sāsana brahmacariyam vussati na aññadattham tasmai etam sacca vavatthāpanam
translated: not for any other purpose, the ascertainment of the truths

original: “ādipadhāna”nti vuttaṃ paṭhamataraṃ citte ādātabbato.
analyzed: ādi padhānam ti vuttam paṭhamataram citte ādātabbataḥ
translated: is called the “initial footing” because it is to be taken up first in the mind.

original: Pubbantasahagatadiṭṭhinissayavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pubbanta sahagata diṭṭhi nissaya vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the view accompanied by the past,

original: 191. Taṃ mayā byākatamevāti taṃ mayā tathā byākatameva, byākātabbaṃ nāma mayā abyākataṃ
analyzed: tam mayā byākatam eva ati tam mayā tathā byākatam eva byākātabbam nāma mayā a byākatam
translated: That has been declared by me: that has been declared by me in that way. There is nothing to be declared that has not been declared by me.

original: natthīti byākaraṇāvekallena attano dhammasudhammatāya buddhasubuddhataṃ vibhāveti.
analyzed: na atthi iti byākaraṇa avekallena attanaḥ dhamma su dhamma tāya buddha su buddha tam vibhāveti
translated: By the completeness of his declaration he reveals his own perfect knowledge of the Dhamma as a Buddha, perfectly enlightened.🔽That is why it is said that he “roars his lion’s roar.”

original: Tenāha “sīhanādaṃ nadanto”ti. Purimuppannā diṭṭhiyo aparāparuppannānaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ
analyzed: tena āha sīha nādam nadanto ti purima uppannāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ apara apara uppannānam diṭṭhīnam
translated: The views that arose in the past are the proximate cause for the views that arise later.

original: avassayā hontīti “diṭṭhiyova diṭṭhinissayā”ti vuttaṃ. Diṭṭhigatikāti diṭṭhigatiyo,
analyzed: avassayāḥ honti iti diṭṭhiyaḥ uva diṭṭhi nissayā ti vuttam diṭṭhi gatikā ati diṭṭhi gatiyaḥ
translated: ‘They are not to be relied on’ is said because ‘views are the reliance of views.’ ‘They have views’ means ‘they have a course of views.’

original: diṭṭhippavattiyoti attho. Idameva dassanaṃ saccanti “sassato attā ca loko cā”ti idameva
analyzed: diṭṭhi ppavattiyaḥ ti attho idam eva dassanam saccanti sassataḥ attā ca loko ca ati idam eva
translated: ‘This view alone is true’ means ‘the self and the world are eternal.’

original: dassanaṃ saccaṃ amoghaṃ aviparītaṃ. Aññesaṃ vacanaṃ moghanti “asassato attā ca loko🔽cā”ti evamādikaṃ aññesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ vacanaṃ moghaṃ tucchaṃ, micchāti attho.
analyzed: dassanam saccam amogham aviparītam aññesam vacanam mogham ti a sassataḥ attā ca loko  ca ati evamādikam aññesam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam vacanam mogham tuccham micchā ati attho
translated: ‘The words of others are false’ means ‘the self and the world are not eternal.’

original: Na sayaṃ kātabboti asayaṃkāroti āha “asayaṃkato”ti, yādicchikattāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: na sayam kātabbo ti asayaṃkāro ti āha asayaṃkato ti yādicchika ttā ati adhippāyo
translated: ‘It should not be done by oneself’ means ‘it should not be done by oneself’ .

original: 192. Atthi khoti ettha kho-saddo pucchāyaṃ, atthi nūti ayamettha atthoti āha “atthi
analyzed: atthi kho ti ettha kho saddo puccha ayam atthi nu ti ayam ettha attho ti āha atthi
translated: ‘Is there’ : the word kho in the question is used in the sense of ‘is there?’ . ‘This is said’ means ‘this is said.’

original: kho idaṃ āvuso vuccatī”tiādi. Āvuso yaṃ tumhehi “sassato attā ca loko cā”ti vuccati,
analyzed: kho idam āvuso vuccati itiādi āvuso yam tumhehi sassataḥ attā ca loko ca ati vuccati
translated: ‘Friend, this is said’ means ‘friend, this is said by you: “the self and the world are eternal.”

original: idamatthi kho idaṃ vācāmattaṃ, no natthi, tasmā vācāvatthumattato tassa yaṃ kho te
analyzed: idam atthi kho idam vācāmattam no natthi tasmā vācāvatthumattato tassa yam kho te
translated: This is said, this is mere words, it is not not so, therefore, from the mere words of the subject,

original: evamāhaṃsu “idameva saccaṃ moghaṃ añña”nti, taṃ tesaṃ nānujānāmīti evamettha attho
analyzed: evam āhaṃsu idam eva saccam mogham tam tesam na anujānāmi iti evam ettha atthaḥ
translated: and they say: “This alone is the truth, other ideas are worthless,” I do not allow that. This is the meaning here.

original: ca yojanā ca veditabbā. Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ brahmajālaṭīkāyaṃ vuttameva.
analyzed: ca yojanā ca veditabbā yam pana ittha vattabbam tam brahmajālaṭīkāyam vuttam eva
translated: And the interpretation should be understood. But what should be said here has already been said in the Brahmajāla Commentary.

original: Diṭṭhipaññattiyāti diṭṭhiyā paññāpane “evaṃ esā diṭṭhi uppannā”ti tassā diṭṭhiyā
analyzed: diṭṭhi paññattiyā ti diṭṭhiyāḥ paññāpane evam esā diṭṭhi uppannā ti tassā diṭṭhiyā
translated: As to the description of views: in the description of views as “arisen thus, this view has arisen”

original: samudayato, atthaṅgamato, assādato, ādīnavato, nissaraṇato ca yāthāvato paññāpane.
analyzed: samudayataḥ atthaṅgamataḥ assādataḥ ādīnavataḥ nissaraṇataḥ ca yāthāvataḥ paññāpane
translated: in the description of views as to their origination, their disappearance, their satisfaction, their unsatisfactoriness, and their escape from them in accordance with actuality.

original: Aviparītavuttiyā samena ñāṇena samaṃ kañci neva samanupassāmi. Adhipaññattīti abhiññeyyadhammapaññāpanā.🔽Yaṃ ajānantā bāhirakā diṭṭhipaññattiyeva allīnāti tañca paññattito ajānantā thāmasā
analyzed: aviparīta vuttiyā samena ñāṇena samam kañci na iva samanupassāmi adhipaññattī iti abhiññeyya dhamma paññāpanā  yam a jānantā bāhirakā diṭṭhi paññattiyā iva tam ca paññattitaḥ a jānantā thāmasā
translated: I do not see anyone else who is equal to the Blessed One in right conduct, in right behaviour, in right striving, in right practice, in right discrimination, in right knowledge, in right insight, in right freedom. As to the description of what is to be directly known: the description of ideas that are to be directly known.🔽Because outsiders, not knowing that, are devoted only to the description of views, and not knowing that description, they speak with obstinacy,

original: parāmāsā abhinivissa voharanti. Ettha ca yāyaṃ “diṭṭhipaññatti nāmā”ti vuttā diṭṭhiyā🔽diṭṭhigatikehi evaṃ gahitatāya vibhāvanā, tattha ca bhagavato uttaritaro nāma koci
analyzed: parāmāsāḥ abhinivissa voharanti ettha ca yā ayam diṭṭhi paññatti nāma ati vuttā diṭṭhiyā 🔽diṭṭhigatikehi evam gahita tāya vibhāvanā tattha ca bhagavataḥ uttaritaraḥ nāma koci
translated: with over-estimation, and with misapprehension. And here the description of views that was called “the description of views” is a description of views as they are apprehended by those who hold views.🔽The elucidation of that is this: “Herein, there is no one at all who is superior to the Blessed One in regard to the description of what is to be directly known, or who is equal to the Blessed One in regard to the description of what is to be directly known.”

original: natthi, svāyamattho brahmajāle vibhāvito eva. “Adhipaññattī”ti vuttā pana vibhāviyamānā
analyzed: natthi svāyamatthaḥ brahmajāle vibhāvito eva adhipaññattī iti vuttā pana vibhāviyamānā
translated: But this meaning has been elucidated in the Brahmajāla Sutta itself.🔽But when the “higher discovery” is elucidated,

original: lokassa nibbidāhetubhāvena bahulīkārāti tassā vasena bhagavā anuttarabhāvaṃ pavedento
analyzed: lokassa nibbidā hetu bhāvena tassā vasena bhagavā anuttara bhāvam pavedentaḥ
translated: the Blessed One, in proclaiming his unsurpassedness by way of that,🔽“I do not see any other recluse or brahmin,” etc., and he thus uttered his lion’s roar.

original: ‘neva attanā samasamaṃ samanupassāmī’ti sīhanādaṃ nadī”ti keci. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana🔽“yañca vuttaṃ ‘paññattiyā’ti yañca ‘adhipaññattī’ti, ubhayametaṃ atthato eka”nti
analyzed: na iva attanā samasamam samanupassāmi iti sīhanādam nadī iti keci aṭṭhakathāyam pana  yat ca vuttam paññattiyā ati yat ca adhipaññatti iti ubhayam etam atthataḥ ekam ti
translated: But in the Commentary it is said:🔽“What is said by ‘discovery’ and what is said by ‘higher discovery’ are both the same in meaning.

original: “idha pana paññattiyāti etthāpi paññatti ceva adhipaññatti ca adhippetā, adhipaññattīti
analyzed: idha pana paññattiyā ati ettha api paññatti ca iva adhipaññatti ca adhippetā adhipaññattī iti
translated: Here in the phrase ‘by discovery’ both discovery and higher discovery are intended, and in the phrase ‘by higher discovery’ both are also intended.

original: etthāpī”ti ca vuttā, ubhayassapi vasenettha bhagavā sīhanādaṃ nadīti viññāyati. Ubhayaṃ🔽petaṃ atthato ekanti ca paññattibhāvasāmaññaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, na bhedābhāvato. Tenāha
analyzed: ettha api iti ca vuttā ubhayassa api vasena ittha bhagavā sīhanādam nadī iti viññāyati ubhayam  atthataḥ ekam ti ca paññatti bhāva sāmaññam sandhāya vuttam na bheda abhāvataḥ tena āha
translated: Thus it is evident that the Blessed One uttered his lion’s roar by way of both.🔽But it is said that both are the same in meaning, and this is said with reference to the similarity of their being discoveries, not with reference to the non-existence of their difference. Therefore it is said:

original: “bhedato hī”tiādi. Khandhapaññattīti khandhānaṃ “khandhā”ti paññāpanā dassanā pakāsanā
analyzed: bhedataḥ hi itiādi khandha paññatti iti khandhānam khandhā ati paññāpanā dassanā pakāsanā
translated: “For if there were no difference,” and so on. The discovery of the aggregates is the discovery, the seeing, the manifestation, of the aggregates as “aggregates.”

original: ṭhapanā nikkhipanā. “Ācikkhati dasseti paññāpeti paṭṭhapetī”ti āgataṭṭhāne hi paññāpanā
analyzed: ṭhapanā nikkhipanā ācikkhati dasseti paññāpeti paṭṭhapeti iti āgata ṭṭhāne hi paññāpanā
translated: and “placing” is “depositing.” For in the passage beginning, “He describes, shows, makes known, reveals, points out, and explains” ,

original: dassanā pakāsanā paññatti nāma, “supaññattaṃ mañcapīṭha”nti āgataṭṭhāne ṭhapanā nikkhipanā
analyzed: dassanā pakāsanā paññatti nāma su paññattam mañca pīṭhanti āgata ṭṭhāne ṭhapanā nikkhipanā
translated: “placing” is “showing,” “making known,” “pointing out,”

original: paññatti nāma, idha ubhayampi yujjati.
analyzed: paññatti nāma idha ubhayampi yujjati
translated: and “depositing” is “placing.” And both are appropriate here.

original: Diṭṭhinissayappahānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: diṭṭhi nissaya ppahāna vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the abandoning of reliance on views

original: 196. Pajahanatthanti accantāya paṭinissajjanatthaṃ. Yasmā tena pajahanena sabbe diṭṭhinissayā
analyzed: pajahana attham ti accantāya paṭinissajjana attham yasmā tena pajahanena sabbe diṭṭhi nissayā
translated: “For the purpose of abandoning”: for the purpose of giving up completely. Because by this abandoning all reliance on views

original: sammadeva atikkantā honti vītikkantā, tasmā “samatikkamāyāti tasseva vevacana”nti
analyzed: sammat eva atikkantāḥ honti vītikkantā tasmai samatikkamāya ati tassa iva
translated: are completely transcended, overcome, therefore it is a synonym for “transcending” .

original: avoca. Na kevalaṃ satipaṭṭhānā kathitamattā, atha kho veneyyasantāne patiṭṭhāpitāti
analyzed: avoca na kevalam sati paṭṭhānā kathita mattā atha kho veneyya santāne patiṭṭhāpitā ati
translated: The foundations of mindfulness are not merely taught, but are also established in the mental continuum of the disciples.

original: dassetuṃ “desitā”ti vatvā “paññattā”ti vuttanti āha “desitāti kathitā. Paññattāti
analyzed: dassetum desitā iti vatvā paññattā ati vuttan ti āha desitā ati kathitā paññattā ati
translated: In order to show this, he says, “taught” means “described,” and “established” means “placed.”

original: ṭhapitā”ti. Idāni satipaṭṭhānadesanāya diṭṭhinissayānaṃ ekantikaṃ pahānāvahabhāvaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapitā ti idāni sati paṭṭhāna desanāya diṭṭhi nissayānam ekantikam pahāna āvaha bhāvam
translated: Now, the fact that the teaching of the foundations of mindfulness is the means for the complete abandoning of reliance on views is shown by the following:

original: dassetuṃ “satipaṭṭhānabhāvanāya hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha satipaṭṭhānabhāvanāyāti iminā
analyzed: dassetum sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanāya hi itiādi vuttam tattha sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanāya ati iminā
translated: “By the development of the foundations of mindfulness” is said in order to show this. Herein, “by the development of the foundations of mindfulness” is said in order to show the cause.

original: tesaṃ bhāvanāya eva nesaṃ pahānaṃ, desanā pana tadupanissayabhāvato tathā vuttāti
analyzed: tesam bhāvanāya eva na isam pahānam desanā pana tad upanissaya bhāvato tathā vuttā ti
translated: “By the development of the foundations of mindfulness” is said in order to show that. Herein, by this phrase “by the development of the foundations of mindfulness” he shows that their abandoning is due to their development alone, and that the teaching is stated thus because it is a condition for that development.

original: dasseti. Sesaṃ sabbaṃ suviññeyyamevāti.
analyzed: dassa iti sesam sabbam su viññeyyam eva ati
translated: The rest is all easily intelligible.

original: Pāsādikasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā.🔽7. Lakkhaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: lakkhaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The elucidation of the meaning of the brief statements is ended.

original: Dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇavaṇṇanā🔽199. Abhinīhārādiguṇamahattena mahanto purisoti mahāpuriso, so lakkhīyati etehīti🔽mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni. Taṃ mahāpurisaṃ byañjayanti pakāsentīti mahāpurisabyañjanāni.
analyzed: abhinīhāra ādi guṇa mahattena mahantaḥ puriso ti mahā purisaḥ saḥ lakkhīyati etehi iti  mahāpurisa lakkhaṇāni tam mahāpurisam byañjayanti pakāsenti iti mahāpurisa byañjanāni
translated: The Description of the Thirty-two Characteristics of a Great Man🔽The thirty-two characteristics of a great man are called “great man’s characteristics” because they are the means by which a great man is recognized.🔽They are also called “great man’s marks” because they make a great man manifest.

original: Mahāpuriso nimīyati anumīyati etehīti mahāpurisanimittāni. Tenāha “ayaṃ…pe… kāraṇānī”ti.
analyzed: mahāpurisaḥ nimīyati anumīyati etehi iti mahāpurisa nimittāni tena āha ayam pe kāraṇāni iti
translated: They are also called “great man’s signs” because a great man is inferred from them. That is why it is said: “These are the reasons why they are called ‘great man’s characteristics’” .🔽They bear the recitation of the characteristics, thus they are characteristics;

original: 200. Dhārentīti lakkhaṇapāṭhaṃ dhārenti, tena lakkhaṇāni te sarūpato jānanti, na
analyzed: dhārenti iti lakkhaṇa pāṭham dhārenti tena lakkhaṇāni te sarūpataḥ jānanti na
translated: by them he knows them as they are, not as they are not.

original: pana samuṭṭhānatoti dasseti. Tenāha “no ca kho”tiādi, tena anaññasādhāraṇametaṃ,🔽yadidaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇānaṃ kāraṇavibhāvananti dasseti. Kasmā āhāti yathāvuttassa
analyzed: pana samuṭṭhānato ti dasseti tena āha no ca kho tiādi tena anañña sādhāraṇam etam  yat idam mahāpurisa lakkhaṇānam kāraṇa vibhāvananti dasseti kasmai āha ati yathā vuttassa
translated: but he shows the reason for their arising. Hence he says, “but not by that” , etc. He shows that this is not shared by others.

original: suttassa samuṭṭhānakāraṇaṃ pucchati, ācariyo “aṭṭhuppattiyā anurūpattā”ti vatvā tamevassa
analyzed: suttassa samuṭṭhāna kāraṇam pucchati ācariyaḥ aṭṭhuppattiyā anurūpa ttā ti vatvā tam eva assa
translated: Why did he say? He asks the reason for the sutta as stated. The teacher, saying “because it is suitable to the origin of the story,”

original: aṭṭhuppattiṃ vitthārato dassetuṃ “sā panā”tiādimāha. Sabbapāliphulloti sabbaso samantato
analyzed: aṭṭhuppattim vitthārataḥ dassetum sā pana atiādim āha sabba pāli phullaḥ ti sabbaso samantataḥ
translated: explains that origin in detail, beginning with “But that” . All in full flower : all around, completely,

original: vikasitapuppho. Vikasanameva hi pupphassa nipphatti. Pāricchattako viyāti anussavaladdhamattaṃ
analyzed: vikasita pupphaḥ vikasanam eva hi pupphassa nipphatti pāricchattakaḥ viyāti anussava laddha mattam
translated: blossomed. For the blossoming is the fruit of a flower. Like the pāricchattaka : they say this, taking the pāricchattaka as just arisen.

original: gahetvā vadanti. Uppajjatīti labbhati, nibbattatīti attho.🔽Yena kammenāti yena kusalakammunā. Yaṃ nibbattanti yaṃ yaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ nibbattaṃ. Dassanatthanti
analyzed: gahetvā vadanti uppajjati iti labbhati nibbattati iti atthaḥ  yena kammena ati yena kusala kammunā yam nibbattanti yam yam lakkhaṇam nibbattam dassana ttham ti
translated: Arises : is obtained. The meaning is: is produced.🔽By what kamma : by what profitable kamma. Whatever mark : whatever mark is produced. For the purpose of showing :

original: tassa tassa kusalakammassa sarūpato, kiccato, pavattiākāravisesato, paccayato, phalavisesato
analyzed: tassa tassa kusala kammassa sarūpataḥ kiccataḥ pavatti ākāra visesataḥ paccayataḥ phala visesataḥ
translated: for the purpose of showing the likeness of that profitable kamma, its function, its mode of operation, its condition, and its special fruit.

original: ca dassanatthaṃ, eteneva paṭipāṭiyā uddiṭṭhānaṃ lakkhaṇānaṃ asamuddesakāraṇavibhāvanāya
analyzed: ca dassana attham etena iva paṭipāṭiyā uddiṭṭhānam lakkhaṇānam a samuddesa kāraṇa vibhāvanāya
translated: and for the purpose of showing the reason for not explaining the characteristics in the same order in which they are stated,

original: kāraṇaṃ dīpitaṃ hoti samānakāraṇānaṃ lakkhaṇānaṃ ekajjhaṃ kāraṇadassanavasenassa
analyzed: kāraṇam dīpitam hoti samāna kāraṇānam lakkhaṇānam ekajjham kāraṇa dassana vasena assa
translated: the reason is shown by the method of stating the reason for the characteristics in one place because they have the same reason.

original: pavattattā. Evamāhāti “bāhirakāpi isayo dhārentī”tiādinā iminā iminā pakārena āha.
analyzed: evam āha ati bāhirakā api isayaḥ dhārenti iti ādinā iminā iminā pakārena āha
translated: Thus he said: he said in this way, in this manner, beginning with “Outsiders too recite them.”

original: Suppatiṭṭhitapādatālakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: suppatiṭṭhita pāda tā lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the characteristic of “having well-planted feet”

original: 201. “Purimaṃ jātinti purimāyaṃ jātiyaṃ, bhummatthe etaṃ upayogavacana”nti vadanti.
analyzed: purimam jātinti purimāyam jātiyam bhummatthe etam upayoga vacananti vadanti
translated: “In his previous birth”: in his previous existence. They say that this is a locative of place.

original: “Pubbe nivutthakkhandhasantāne ṭhito”ti vacanato accantasaṃyoge vā upayogavacanaṃ.
analyzed: pubbe nivuttha kkhandha santāne ṭhitaḥ iti vacanataḥ ac ca anta saṃyoge vā upayoga vacanam
translated: Or it is a locative of reason in the sense of “standing in the continuity of aggregates previously lived through.”

original: Yattha yattha hi jātiyaṃ mahāsatto puññakammaṃ kātuṃ ārabhati, ārabhato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: yattha yattha hi jātiyam mahāsatto puñña kammam kātum ārabhati ārabhataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: For wherever the Great Being began to perform meritorious deeds in his various births,

original: accantameva tattha puññakammappasuto hoti. Tenāha “daḷhasamādāno”tiādi. Sesapadadvayepi
analyzed: accantam eva tattha puñña kamma ppasuto hoti tena āha daḷha samādāna uti ādi sesa pada dvaye pi
translated: from the time he began to do so he was wholly intent on meritorious deeds. Hence it is said, “he was one who had made a firm resolve.” In the case of the other two terms too,

original: eseva nayo. Nivutthakkhandhā “jātī”ti vuttā khandhavinimuttāya jātiyā abhāvato, nibbattilakkhaṇassa
analyzed: esā iva nayaḥ nivuttha khandhā jāti iti vuttā khandha vinimuttāya jātiyāḥ abhāvataḥ nibbatti lakkhaṇassa
translated: The aggregates that have been reborn are called “birth” because there is no birth of aggregates that is free from rebirth, and because the characteristic of arising is not intended here.

original: ca vikārassa idha anupayujjanato. Jātavasenāti jāyanavasena. “Tathā”ti iminā “pubbe🔽nivutthakkhandhā”ti imaṃ padaṃ upasaṃharati. Bhavanavasenāti paccayato nibbattanavasena.
analyzed: ca vikārassa idha anupayujjanataḥ jāta vasena ati jāyana vasena tathā ati iminā pubbe  nivuttha kkhandhā ti imam padam upasaṃharati bhavana vasena ati paccayataḥ nibbattana vasena
translated: By means of birth: by means of the state of being born. “Thus” refers back to the words “the aggregates that have been reborn.” By means of the state of becoming: by means of the state of being produced from conditions.

original: Nivutthavasenāti nivusitatāvasena. Ālayaṭṭhenāti āvasitabhāvena. Nivāsattho hi niketattho.🔽Tatthāti devalokādimhi. Ādi-saddena ekaccaṃ tiracchānayoniṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Na sukaranti
analyzed: nivuttha vasena āti nivusita tā vasena ālaya ṭṭhena ati āvasita bhāvena nivāsa tthaḥ hi niketa tthaḥ  tattha ati deva loka ādimhi ādi saddena ekaccam tiracchānayonim saṅgaṇhāti na
translated: By means of the state of being reborn: by means of the state of being reborn. By means of the state of being a resting place: by means of the state of being a dwelling place. For the meaning of “resting place” is the meaning of “dwelling place.”

original: devagatiyā ekantasukhatāya, duggatiyā ekantadukkhatāya, dukkhabahulatāya ca puññakiriyāya
analyzed: deva gatiyāḥ ekanta sukha tāya duggatiyāḥ ekanta dukkha tāya dukkha bahula tāya ca puñña kiriyāya
translated: There: in the divine world, etc. The word “etc.” includes a certain animal womb. It is not easy: because the coming together of the conditions is difficult, it is not easy to find an opportunity for the performance of merit, because the divine world is entirely pleasant and the unhappy worlds are entirely painful.

original: okāso na sulabharūpo paccayasamavāyassa dullabhabhāvato, uppajjamānā ca sā uḷārā,
analyzed: okāsaḥ na sulabha rūpaḥ paccaya samavāyassa dullabha bhāvataḥ uppajjamānā ca sā uḷārā
translated: When it arises, it is great,

original: vipulā ca na hotīti gativasenāpi khettavisesatā icchitabbā “tiracchānagate dānaṃ🔽datvā sataguṇā dakkhiṇā pāṭikaṅkhitabbā, puthujjanadussīle dānaṃ datvā sahassaguṇā
analyzed: vipulā ca na hoti iti gati vasena api khetta visesa tā icchitabbā tiracchāna gate dānam  datvā sataguṇā dakkhiṇā pāṭikaṅkhitabbā puthujjana dussīle dānam datvā sahassaguṇā
translated: and it is not extensive. So the distinction of field should be understood also according to the destiny. “When a gift is given to animals, a hundred-fold reward is expected;🔽when a gift is given to unvirtuous ordinary people, a thousand-fold reward is expected” .

original: dakkhiṇā pāṭikaṅkhitabbā”ti vacanato. Manussagatiyā pana sukhabahulatāya puññakiriyāya🔽okāso sulabharūpo paccayasamavāyassa ca yebhuyyena sulabhabhāvato. Yañca tattha dukkhaṃ
analyzed: dakkhiṇā pāṭikaṅkhitabbā ti vacanataḥ manussa gatiyā pana sukha bahula tāya puñña kiriyāya  okāso sulabha rūpo paccaya samavāyassa ca yebhuyyena sulabha bhāvataḥ yat ca tattha dukkham
translated: But in the human world, because of the abundance of pleasure, the opportunity for making merit is easy to obtain, and the coming together of the conditions is mostly easy to obtain.

original: uppajjati, tampi visesato puññakiriyāya upanissayo hoti, dukkhūpanisā saddhāti. Yathā
analyzed: uppajjati tam pi visesataḥ puñña kiriyāya upanissayaḥ hoti dukkha upanisā saddhā ati yathā
translated: And whatever suffering arises there is a special condition for making merit, since faith is conditioned by suffering .

original: hi ayoghanena satthake nipphādiyamāne tassa ekantato aggimhi tāpanaṃ, udakena vā🔽temanaṃ chedanakiriyāsamatthatāya na visesapaccayo, tāpetvā pana samānayogato udakatemanaṃ
analyzed: hi ayaḥ ghanena satthake nipphādiyamāne tassa ekantataḥ aggimhi tāpanam udakena vā  temanam chedana kiriyā samattha tāya na visesa paccayo tāpetvā pana samāna yogataḥ udaka temanam
translated: For just as when a sword is being tempered in a forge, the exclusive heating in the fire and the exclusive cooling in water are not special conditions for the making of the sword,

original: tassā visesapaccayo, evameva sattasantānassa ekantadukkhasamaṅgitā dukkhabahulatā
analyzed: visesa paccayaḥ evam eva satta santānassa ekanta dukkha samaṅgi tā dukkha bahula tā
translated: but the heating and the cooling are special conditions for the making of the sword when they alternate; so too, the exclusive presence of suffering in the mental continuity and the abundance of suffering are not special conditions for making merit,🔽but when they alternate with pleasure, they are special conditions for making merit.

original: ekantasukhasamaṅgitā sukhabahulatā ca puññakiriyāsamatthatāya na visesapaccayo, sati
analyzed: ekanta sukha samaṅgi tā sukha bahula tā ca puñña kiriyā samattha tāya na visesa paccayaḥ sati
translated: and the possession of complete happiness and the abundance of happiness are not specific conditions for the ability to perform meritorious deeds, because they are not the cause of that ability.

original: pana samānayogato dukkhasantāpane, sukhumabrūhane ca laddhūpanissayā puññakiriyā🔽samatthatāya sambhavati, tathā sati uppajjamānā puññakiriyā mahājutikā mahāvipphārā
analyzed: pana samāna yogataḥ dukkha santāpane sukhuma brūhane ca laddha upanissayā puñña kiriyā  samattha tāya sambhavati tathā sati uppajjamānā puñña kiriyā mahā jutikā mahā vipphārā
translated: and the possession of complete happiness and the abundance of happiness are not specific conditions for the performance of merit because of the possibility of the performance of merit in the presence of suffering and the absence of happiness.🔽But when the performance of merit is possible in the presence of happiness, it arises with a supporting condition,

original: paṭipakkhacchedanasamatthā hoti. Tasmā manussabhāvo puññakiriyāya visesapaccayo.
analyzed: paṭipakkha chedana samatthā hoti tasmā manussa bhāvaḥ puñña kiriyāya visesa paccayo
translated: and then it is of great brilliance and great effectiveness and is capable of cutting off its opposite. Therefore the human state is a specific condition for the performance of merit.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “tattha na sukaraṃ, manussabhūtasseva sukara”nti.
analyzed: tena vuttam tattha na sukaram manussa bhūtassa iva sukaran ti
translated: That is why it was said above: “It is not easy for one who is not a human being, but it is easy for one who is a human being.”

original: Atha “manussabhūtassā”ti ettha ko vacanattho? “Manassa ussannatāya manussāti, sūrabhāvasatimantatābrahmacariyayogyatādiguṇavasena
analyzed: atha manussa bhūtassa ati ettha kaḥ vacana atthaḥ manassa ussanna tāya manussā ati sūra bhāva satimanta tā brahmacariya yogya tā ādi guṇa vasena
translated: Now, what is the meaning of the words manussabhūtassa? It is because of the state of being uplifted in mind that they are called “human beings” . The meaning is that they are called “human beings” because of such qualities as the state of being fragrant, the state of being possessed of mindfulness, and the state of being fit for celibacy.

original: upacitamanakā ukkaṭṭhaguṇacittāti attho. Ke pana te? Jambudīpavāsino sattavisesā. Tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: upacita manakā ukkaṭṭha guṇa cittā ti attho ke pana te jambudīpa vāsino satta visesā tena āha bhagavā
translated: But who are they? They are the seven kinds of human beings who live in Jambudīpa. Hence the Blessed One said:

original: ‘Tīhi, bhikkhave, ṭhānehi jambudīpakā manussā uttarakuruke ca manusse adhiggaṇhanti deve ca tāvatiṃse. Katamehi tīhi? Sūrā satimanto idha brahmacariyavāso’ti.
analyzed: tīhi bhikkhave ṭhānehi jambudīpakāḥ manussāḥ uttarakuruke ca manusse adhiggaṇhanti deve ca tāvatiṃse katamehi tīhi sūrā satimantaḥ idha brahmacariya vāsā iti
translated: ‘In three ways, monks, the human beings of Jambudīpa surpass the human beings of Uttarakuru and the Tāvatiṃsa devas. In what three ways? They are brave, mindful, and they live the holy life here.’

original: Tathā hi buddhā bhagavanto, paccekabuddhā, aggasāvakā, mahāsāvakā, cakkavattino,
analyzed: tathā hi buddhāḥ bhagavanto paccekabuddhāḥ aggasāvakāḥ mahāsāvakāḥ cakkavattino
translated: For thus the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, the Paccekabuddhas, the chief disciples, the great disciples, the Wheel-turning Monarchs,

original: aññe ca mahānubhāvā sattā tattheva uppajjanti. Te hi samānarūpāditāya pana saddhiṃ
analyzed: aññe ca mahā anubhāvā sattā tattha iva uppajjanti te hi samāna rūpa āditāya pana saddhim
translated: and other greatly powerful beings are reborn there. But because they are similar in appearance, etc.,

original: parittadīpavāsīhi itaramahādīpavāsinopi manussā tveva paññāyiṃsū”ti keci. Apare pana
analyzed: paritta dīpa vāsīhi itara mahā dīpa vāsinaḥ api manussā tu eva paññāyiṃsu iti keci apare pana
translated: the human beings of the small continents are also called human beings, just as the human beings of the great continents are.”

original: bhaṇanti “lobhādīhi, alobhādīhi ca sahitassa manassa ussannatāya manussā. Ye hi sattā
analyzed: bhaṇanti lobha ādīhi alobha ādīhi ca sahitassa manassa ussanna tāya manussāḥ ye hi sattā
translated: But others say that human beings are so called because of the predominance of greed, etc., and non-greed, etc., in the mind. For those beings

original: manussajātikā, tesu visesato lobhādayo, alobhādayo ca ussannā, te lobhādiussannatāya
analyzed: manussa jātikā tesu visesataḥ lobha ādayaḥ alobha ādayaḥ ca ussannā te lobha ādi ussanna tāya
translated: who are human beings have greed, etc., and non-greed, etc., in predominance. Because of the predominance of greed, etc.,

original: apāyamaggaṃ, alobhādiussannatāya sugatimaggaṃ, nibbānagāmimaggañca paripūrenti, tasmā
analyzed: apāya maggam alobha ādi ussanna tāya sugati maggam nibbāna gāmi maggañca paripūrenti tasmai
translated: they fulfil the path to the states of deprivation and the path to the good destinations and the path to the unformed,🔽but not so the beings of the other planes.

original: lobhādīhi, alobhādīhi ca sahitassa manassa ussannatāya parittadīpavāsīhi saddhiṃ🔽catudīpavāsino sattavisesā manussāti vuccantī”ti. Lokiyā pana “manuno apaccabhāvena
analyzed: lobha ādīhi alobha ādīhi ca sahitassa manassa ussanna tāya paritta dīpa vāsīhi saddhiṃ  catu dīpa vāsinaḥ satta visesāḥ manussā ti vuccanti iti lokiyā pana manuno apacca bhāvena
translated: and the mind associated with greed, etc., and non-greed, etc., is called “human” because it is exalted in comparison with the mind of the inhabitants of the four continents, which is like a small lamp.🔽But the mundane kind is called “human” because it is the opposite of the divine kind.

original: manussā”ti vadanti. Manu nāma paṭhamakappiko lokamariyādāya ādibhūto sattānaṃ hitāhitavidhāyako
analyzed: manussā ati vadanti manu nāma paṭhama kappikaḥ lokam ariyādāya ādi bhūtaḥ sattānam hita ahita vidhāyakaḥ
translated: The being called Manu was the first to reach the limit of the world-sphere in the first aeon. He was the one who brought about the welfare of beings and who directed them to do what ought to be done and to avoid what ought not to be done,

original: kattabbākattabbatāsu niyojanatāvasena pituṭṭhāniyo, yo sāsane “mahāsammato”ti vuccati
analyzed: kattabba akattabba tāsu niyojana tā vasena pitu ṭṭhāniyaḥ yaḥ sāsane mahāsammato ti vuccati
translated: and so he was like a father. He is called “the Great Elect” in the Dispensation.

original: amhākaṃ mahābodhisatto, paccakkhato, paramparā ca tassa ovādānusāsaniyaṃ ṭhitā sattā
analyzed: amhākam mahā bodhisatto paccakkhataḥ paramparā ca tassa ovāda anusāsaniyam ṭhitā sattā
translated: Our Great Being was his descendant, and beings who remained in the advice and instruction of his lineage

original: puttasadisatāya “manussā, mānusā”ti ca vuccanti. Tato eva hi te “mānavā, manujā”ti
analyzed: putta sadisa tāya manussāḥ mānusāḥ ti ca vuccanti tatas eva hi te mānavāḥ manujāḥ ti
translated: are called “men” , “human beings” , because they are like his sons. That is why they are also called “men” , “human beings” ,🔽and “people” .

original: ca voharīyanti. Manussabhūtassāti manussesu bhūtassa jātassa, manussabhāvaṃ vā pattassāti
analyzed: ca voharīyanti manussa bhūtassa ati manussesu bhūtassa jātassa manussa bhāvam vā pattassa ati
translated: The meaning is: “come to be among men,” “born among men,” or “attained human existence.”

original: attho. Ayañca nayo lokiyamahājanassa vasena vutto. Mahābodhisattānaṃ pana santānassa
analyzed: atthaḥ ayam ca nayaḥ lokiya mahājanassa vasena vuttaḥ mahā bodhisattānam pana santānassa
translated: And this method is stated with reference to the ordinary man of the world. But the mental continuum of the Great Being

original: mahābhinīhārato paṭṭhāya kusaladhammapaṭipattiyaṃ sammadeva abhisaṅkhatattā tesaṃ
analyzed: mahā abhinīhārato paṭṭhāya kusala dhamma paṭipattiyam sammat eva abhisaṅkhata ttā tesam
translated: and because they have well and truly resolved to undertake the practice of profitable things from the time of their great resolution,

original: sugatiyaṃ, attano uppajjanaduggatiyañca nibbattānaṃ kusalakammaṃ garutaramevāti dassetuṃ
analyzed: sugatiyam attanaḥ uppajjana duggatiyam ca nibbattānam kusala kammam garutaram eva ati dassetuṃ
translated: their profitable kamma is the more weighty in the case of those who are reborn in a happy destination and in the case of those who are reborn in a miserable destination.

original: “akāraṇaṃ vā eta”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: akāraṇam vā etat tiādi vuttam
translated: “There is no reason for that” is said in order to show this.

original: Evarūpe attabhāveti hatthiādiattabhāve. Ṭhitena katakammaṃ na sakkā sukhena dīpetuṃ
analyzed: evarūpe attabhāve iti hatthi ādi attabhāve ṭhitena kata kammam na sakkā sukhena dīpetum
translated: In such a state of being: in the state of being as an elephant, etc. The kamma done by one who is standing cannot be easily demonstrated

original: loke appaññātarūpattā. Sukhena dīpetuṃ “asukasmiṃ dese asukasmiṃ nagare asuko nāma🔽rājā, brāhmaṇo hutvā imaṃ kusalakammaṃ akāsī”ti evaṃ suviññāpayabhāvato. Thiraggahaṇoti
analyzed: loke appaññāta rūpa ttā sukhena dīpetum asukasmin dese asukasmin nagare asukaḥ nāma  rājā brāhmaṇaḥ hutvā imam kusala kammam akāsi iti evam su viññāpaya bhāvataḥ thira ggahaṇaḥ ti
translated: because it is not well known in the world. It can be easily demonstrated by saying, “In such a place, in such a town, such a king,

original: asithilaggāhī thāmappattaggahaṇo. Niccalaggahaṇoti acañcalaggāhī tattha kenacipi
analyzed: a sithila ggāhī niccala ggahaṇo ti a cañcala ggāhī tattha kenacipi
translated: having been a brahmin, did this profitable kamma,” because it is well known. Firmly: not loosely. Having reached firmness: having reached steadiness. Steadily: not unsteadily. There is nothing that can

original: asaṃhāriyo. Paṭikuṭatīti saṃkuṭati, jigucchanavasena vivaṭṭati vā. Pasāriyatīti vitthataṃ🔽hoti vepullaṃ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: paṭikuṭati iti saṃkuṭati jigucchana vasena vivaṭṭati vā pasāriyati iti vitthatam 🔽hoti vepullam pāpuṇāti
translated: remove it. It shrinks: it shrinks back, turns away, out of disgust. It spreads out: it becomes extended, it reaches growth.

original: Taveso mahāsamuddasadisoti eso udakogho teva mahāsamuddasadiso.🔽Dīyati etenāti dānaṃ, pariccāgacetanā. Diyyanavasenāti deyyadhammassa pariyattaṃ
analyzed: tava isaḥ mahā samudda sadisaḥ ti esaḥ udaka oghaḥ tā iva mahā samudda sadisaḥ  dīyati etena ati dānam pariccāga cetanā diyyana vasena ati deyya dhammassa pariyattam
translated: “This is like the great ocean”: this flood of water is like the great ocean.🔽“Giving is the act of giving”: the volition of giving up. “By giving”: having made over the gift,

original: katvā pariccajanavasena dānaṃ. Saṃvibhāgakaraṇavasenāti tasseva attanā saddhiṃ parassa
analyzed: katvā pariccajana vasena dānam saṃvibhāga karaṇa vasena ati tassa iva attanā saddhim parassa
translated: giving is by the act of giving up. “By sharing”: by the act of sharing with another

original: saṃvibhajanavasena saṃvibhāgo, tathāpavattā cetanā. Sīlasamādāneti sīlassa sammadeva
analyzed: saṃvibhajana vasena saṃvibhāgaḥ tathā pavattā cetanā sīla samādāne iti sīlassa sammad eva
translated: together with oneself. The volition that occurs thus is “sharing”. “By undertaking virtue”: by the proper

original: ādāne, gahaṇe pavattaneti attho. Taṃ pavattikālena dassento “pūraṇakāle”ti āha. Mātu
analyzed: ādāne gahaṇe pavattane iti attho tam pavatti kālena dassento pūraṇa kāla iti āha mātu
translated: undertaking, the taking up, the performance of virtue, is the meaning. Showing the time of its performance, he said, “at the time of filling up” .

original: hito matteyyo, yassa pana dhammassa vasena so “matteyyo”ti vuccati, so matteyyatāti
analyzed: hitaḥ matteyyaḥ yassa pana dhammassa vasena so matteyyaḥ iti vuccati saḥ matteyya tā ati
translated: “One who is dear to his mother” is a “mother’s darling.” The state of being a mother’s darling is

original: āha “mātu kātabbavatte”ti. Eseva nayo “petteyyatāyā”tiādīsu. Aññataraññataresūti
analyzed: āha mātu kātabba vattā iti esa eva nayaḥ petteyya tāya atiādīsu aññatara aññataresu uti
translated: the state of being dear to one’s mother. He said “in the duties to be done by a mother” . The same method applies to “father’s darling” and so on.

original: aññamaññavisiṭṭhesu aññesu, te pana kusalabhāvena vuttā kusalāti āha “evarūpesū”ti.
analyzed: aññamañña visiṭṭhesu aññesu te pana kusala bhāvena vuttā kusalā ati āha evarūpesu iti
translated: “In any one of these”: in any one of the others, that is, in those distinguished from each other. But they are called “good” because they are wholesome. He said “in such as these” .

original: Adhikusalesūti abhivisiṭṭhesu kusalesu, sā pana abhivisiṭṭhatā upādāyupādāya hoti.
analyzed: adhi kusalesu iti abhivisiṭṭhesu kusalesu sā pana abhivisiṭṭha tā upādāya upādāya hoti
translated: “Among the profitable” means among the most excellent profitable. But that most excellentness is according to the kind of clinging.

original: Yaṃ panettha ukkaṃsagataṃ adhikusalaṃ, tadukkaṃsanayena idhādhippetanti taṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: yam pana ittha ukkaṃsa gatam adhi kusalam tat ukkaṃsa nayena idha adhippetan ti tam dassetuṃ
translated: But the most excellent profitable that is here intended is that which is referred to in the way of praising it.

original: “atthi kusalā, atthi adhikusalā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Nanu paññāpāramisaṅgahañāṇasambhārabhūtā
analyzed: atthi kusalā atthi adhikusalā atiādi vuttam nanu paññāpārami saṅgaha ñāṇa sambhāra bhūtā
translated: “There are profitable ideas, there are more profitable ideas” and so on is said in order to show that.

original: kusalā dhammā nippariyāyena sabbaññutaññāṇapaṭilābhapaccayā kusalā nāma, ime pana
analyzed: kusalāḥ dhammāḥ nippariyāyena sabbaññu taññāṇa paṭilābha paccayā kusalāḥ nāma ime pana
translated: Are not profitable ideas, which are the equipment for the knowledge consisting in the round-up of the perfection of understanding, profitable in the true sense of the word because they are a condition for the acquisition of the knowledge of omniscience?

original: mahāpurisalakkhaṇanibbattakā puññasambhārabhūtā kasmā tathā vuttāti? Sabbesampi mahābodhisattasantānagatānaṃ
analyzed: mahā purisa lakkhaṇa nibbattakā puñña sambhāra bhūtā kasmā tathā vuttā ati sabbesam pi mahā bodhisatta santāna gatānam
translated: But why are these, which are the equipment for merit that produces the Great Man’s special qualities, spoken of in that way?

original: pāramidhammānaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇapaṭilābhapaccayabhāvato. Mahābhinīhārato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: pārami dhammānam sabbaññu ta ññāṇa paṭilābha paccaya bhāvataḥ mahā abhinīhārataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: Because they are a condition for the acquisition of the knowledge of omniscience of all the ideas that are the perfection of the Great Enlightened One’s continuity.🔽For from the time of the Great Man’s great resolution onwards,

original: hi mahāpuriso yaṃ kiñci puññaṃ karoti, sabbaṃ taṃ sammāsambodhisamadhigamāyeva pariṇāmeti.
analyzed: hi mahā purisaḥ yam kiñci puññam karoti sabbam tam sammāsambodhi samadhigamāya iva pariṇāmeti
translated: whatever merit he does, he dedicates it all to the discovery of the supreme perfect enlightenment.

original: Tathā hi sasambhārābyāso, dīghakālābyāso, nirantarābyāso, sakkaccābyāsoti cattāro
analyzed: tathā hi sa sambhāra abyāsaḥ dīgha kāla abyāsaḥ nirantara abyāsaḥ sakkacca abyāsaḥ iti cattāro
translated: Thus there are four kinds of dedication: dedication with equipment, dedication without interruption, dedication without delay, and dedication with urgency.

original: abyāsā caturadhiṭṭhānaparipūritasambandhā anupubbena mahābodhiṭṭhānā sampajjanti.
analyzed: abyāsā catur adhiṭṭhāna paripūrita sambandhā anupubbena mahā bodhiṭṭhānā sampajjanti
translated: and the four foundations of mindfulness, which are the cause for the non- wasting of the wholesome roots, are fulfilled, and then the great enlightenment is gradually reached.

original: Sakimpīti pi-saddena anekavārampi kataṃ vijātiyena antaritaṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Abhiṇhakaraṇenāti
analyzed: sa kimpi iti pi saddena aneka vāram pi katam vijātiyena antaritam saṅgaṇhāti abhiṇha karaṇena ati
translated: “Again and again” : the word “again” includes what is done many times and what is separated by other kinds of kamma. “By repeated practice” :

original: bahulīkārena. Upacitanti uparūpari vaḍḍhitaṃ. Piṇḍīkatanti piṇḍaso kataṃ. Rāsīkatanti
analyzed: bahulīkārena upacitanti upari upari vaḍḍhitam piṇḍīka tanti rāsīka tanti
translated: by repeated performance. “Accumulated” : increased more and more. “Made into a heap” :

original: rāsibhāvena kataṃ. Anekakkhattuñhi pavattiyamānaṃ kusalakammaṃ santāne tathāladdhaparibhāvanaṃ🔽piṇḍībhūtaṃ viya, rāsībhūtaṃ viya ca hoti. Vipākaṃ pati saṃhaccakāribhāvattā cakkavāḷaṃ
analyzed: rāsi bhāvena katam aneka kkhattum hi pavattiyamānam kusala kammam santāne tathā laddha paribhāvanam  piṇḍībhūtam viya rāsībhūtam viya ca hoti vipākam cakkavāḷam
translated: made into a mass. For wholesome kamma that is performed many times becomes like a heap and a mass in the continuity of aggregates that have been so developed.

original: atisambādhaṃ bhavaggaṃ atinīcaṃ, sace pane taṃ rūpaṃ siyāti adhippāyo. Vipulattāti
analyzed: ati sambādham bha vaggam ati nīcam sace pane tam rūpam siyāti adhippāyaḥ vipula ttā ti
translated: If it were to be a material form, it would be too large, and the world would be too crowded and the highest existence too low. But the intention is that it would be a material form if it were possible. “Extensive” :

original: mahantattā. Yasmā pana taṃ kammaṃ mettākaruṇāsatisampajaññāhi pariggahitatāya durasamussāritaṃ
analyzed: mahanta ttā yasmā pana tam kammam mettā karuṇā sati sampajaññāhi pariggahita tāya dura samussāritam
translated: great. But because that kamma is well-perfumed by loving-kindness, compassion, mindfulness, and clear comprehension, it is not easily overcome.

original: pamāṇakaraṇadhammanti pamāṇarahitatāya “appamāṇa”nti vattabbataṃ arahati, tasmā “appamāṇattā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pamāṇa karaṇa dhammanti pamāṇa rahita tāya appamāṇanti vattabba tam arahati tasmā appamāṇa ttā iti vuttam
translated: It is worthy of being called “immeasurable” because it is devoid of measure. Therefore it is said, “because of its immeasurability.”🔽It is “supreme” because it is the most excellent of all kinds of happiness.🔽It “surpasses” because it stands surpassing the fruit by its greatness.

original: Adhibhavatīti phalassa uḷārabhāvena abhibhuyya tiṭṭhati. Atthato paṇītapaṇītānaṃ
analyzed: adhibhavati iti phalassa uḷāra bhāvena abhibhuyya tiṭṭhati atthato paṇīta paṇītānam
translated: In the sense of the acquisition of excellent and inferior kinds of wealth.🔽“He obtains in abundance” means he obtains in excess.

original: bhogānaṃ paṭilābho evāti āha “atirekaṃ labhatī”ti. Adhigacchatīti vindati, nibbattamānova
analyzed: bhogānam paṭilābhaḥ eva ati āha atirekam labhati iti adhigacchati iti vindati nibbattamānā iva
translated: “He attains” means he finds. The meaning is that he is endowed with it as soon as he is reborn.

original: tena samannāgato hotīti attho. Ekadesena aphusitvā sabbappadesehi phusanato sabbappadesehi🔽phusantiyo etesaṃ pādatalānaṃ santīti “sabbāvantehi pādatalehī”ti vuttaṃ. Yathā nikkhipane
analyzed: tena samannāgataḥ hoti iti attho ekadesena a phusitvā sabba ppadesehi phusanataḥ sabba ppadesehi  phusantiyaḥ etesam pāda talānam santi iti sabbāvantehi pāda talehi iti vuttam yathā nikkhipane
translated: Because they touch all parts without leaving out a part, they touch all parts.🔽Because all parts of the soles of his feet are even and not depressed, they are even.

original: sabbe pādatalappadesā saṃhaccakārino aninnatāya samabhāvato, evaṃ uddharaṇepīti vuttaṃ
analyzed: sabbe pāda tala ppadesā saṃhacca kārinaḥ aninna tāya sama bhāvataḥ evam uddharaṇe pi iti vuttam
translated: Because they are even in the sense of being without depressions, it is said, “He touches the ground evenly, places the feet evenly.”

original: “samaṃ phusati, samaṃ uddharatī”ti. Idāni imassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇassa samadhigamena
analyzed: samam phusati samam uddharati iti idāni imassa mahā purisa lakkhaṇassa samadhigamena
translated: Now, with the attainment of this great man’s mark,

original: laddhabbanissandaphalavibhāvanamukhena ānubhāvaṃ vibhāvetuṃ “sacepi hī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: laddhabba nissanda phala vibhāvana mukhena ānubhāvam vibhāvetum sace pi hi itiādi vuttam
translated: The passage beginning with “If he so wishes” is stated to show the power of the Blessed One by way of the manifestation of the fruit of the merit he has acquired.🔽Herein, a hell is a pit. He enters it by attaining the state of equality with it.

original: Tattha narakanti āvāṭaṃ. Anto pavisati samabhāvāpattiyā. “Cakkalakkhaṇena patiṭṭhātabbaṭṭhāna”nti
analyzed: tattha narakam ti āvāṭam antar pavisati sama bhāva āpattiyā cakka lakkhaṇena patiṭṭhātabba ṭṭhānam ti
translated: The passage “he stands on the mark of the wheel” is stated🔽because the mark of the wheel also touches the place where the sole of the foot touches.

original: idaṃ yaṃ bhūmippadesaṃ pādatalaṃ phusati, tattha cakkalakkhaṇampi phusanavasena patiṭṭhātīti🔽katvā vuttaṃ. Tassa pana tathā patiṭṭhānaṃ suppatiṭṭhitapādatāya evāti suppatiṭṭhitapādatāya
analyzed: idam yam bhūmi ppadesam pāda talam phusati tattha cakka lakkhaṇam pi phusana vasena patiṭṭhāti iti  katvā vuttam tassa pana tathā patiṭṭhānam suppatiṭṭhita pāda tāya eva ati suppatiṭṭhita pāda tāya
translated: But his standing in that way is due to his having well-placed feet.

analyzed: na asakkhiṃsu aññadatthu sayam eva vighāta byasanam pāpuṇiṃsu ca iva sāvaka ttam ca pavedesuṃ  kamma nti ādīsu kammam nāma buddha bhāvam uddissa katu upacitaḥ lakkhaṇa saṃvattaniyo
translated: They were unable to do so, and they fell into misfortune and disaster, and they declared themselves to be disciples.🔽As regards “kamma” , etc., kamma is the accumulation of merit performed with the aim of Buddhahood and which leads to the characteristics.

original: puññasambhāro. Tenāha “satasahassakappādhikānī”tiādi. Kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma tasseva🔽puññasambhārassa karaṇakāle kenaci akampanīyassa daḷhāvatthitabhāvassa anucchaviko
analyzed: tena āha sata sahassa kappa adhikāni itiādi kamma sarikkhakam nāma tassa eva  puñña sambhārassa karaṇa kāle kenaci a kampanīyassa daḷha avatthita bhāvassa anucchavikaḥ
translated: Therefore it is said: “More than a hundred thousand aeons” , etc. The “counterpart sign” is similar to that kamma.🔽It is the sign that accompanies the firm and unshakable state of mind which is fit to be the cause of the accumulation of merit,

original: suppatiṭṭhitapādatāsaṅkhātassa lakkhaṇassa parehi avikkhambhanīyatāya ñāpakanimittabhāvo,
analyzed: suppatiṭṭhita pāda tā saṅkhātassa lakkhaṇassa parehi a vikkhambhanīya tāya ñāpaka nimitta bhāvaḥ
translated: which cannot be shaken by others, and which is the cause of the characteristic called “having well-planted feet.”

original: svāyaṃ nimittabhāvo tasseva lakkhaṇassāti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma…pe…
analyzed: nimitta bhāvo tassa iva lakkhaṇassa ati aṭṭhakathāyam kammasarikkhakam
translated: This sign is the characteristic itself, and therefore it is said in the commentary: “The counterpart sign is …

original: mahāpurisalakkhaṇa”nti vuttaṃ. Ṭhānagamanesu pādānaṃ daḷhāvatthitabhāvo lakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: mahāpurisa lakkhaṇan ti vuttam ṭhāna gamanesu pādānam daḷha avatthita bhāvaḥ lakkhaṇam
translated: the characteristic of a Great Man” . The characteristic is the firm and unshakable state of mind of the feet in the act of walking.

original: nāma. Pādānaṃ bhūmiyaṃ samaṃ nikkhipanaṃ, pādatalānaṃ sabbabhāgehi phusanaṃ, samameva
analyzed: nāma pādānam bhūmiyam samam nikkhipanam pāda talānam sabba bhāgehi phusanam samam eva
translated: The feet are placed evenly on the ground, the soles of the feet touch the ground all over, and the feet are placed down evenly and

original: uddharaṇaṃ, tasmā suṭṭhu samaṃ sabbabhāgehi patiṭṭhitā pādā etassāti suppatiṭṭhitapādo,
analyzed: uddharaṇam tasmā suṭṭhu samam sabba bhāgehi patiṭṭhitāḥ pādāḥ etassa ati su patiṭṭhita pādaḥ
translated: It is well-set because it is well-levelled, and it is level because it is well-set.🔽The state of that is called “well-set feet.”

original: tassa bhāvo suppatiṭṭhitapādatāti vuccati lakkhaṇaṃ. Suṭṭhu samaṃ bhūmiyā phusaneneva🔽hi nesaṃ tattha daḷhāvatthitabhāvo siddho, yaṃ “kammasarikkhaka”nti vuttaṃ. Lakkhaṇānisaṃsoti
analyzed: tassa bhāvaḥ suppatiṭṭhita pāda tā ti vuccati lakkhaṇam suṭṭhu samam bhūmiyā phusanena iva  hi na īsam tattha daḷha avatthita bhāvo siddho yam kamma sarikkhakan ti vuttam lakkhaṇa anisaṃso ti
translated: The meaning is: the state of having well-set feet.

original: lakkhaṇapaṭilābhassa udrayo, lakkhaṇasaṃvattaniyassa kammassa ānisaṃsaphalanti attho.
analyzed: lakkhaṇa paṭilābhassa udrayaḥ lakkhaṇa saṃvattaniyassa kammassa ānisaṃsa phalanti attho
translated: The meaning of “characteristic” is: the meaning of the fruit of the profitable action that leads to the obtaining of the characteristic.

original: Nissandaphalaṃ pana heṭṭhā bhāvitameva.
analyzed: nissanda phalam pana heṭṭhā bhāvitam eva
translated: But the outcome fruit is already stated below .

original: 203. Kammādibhedeti kammakammasarikkhakalakkhaṇa lakkhaṇānisaṃsavisaññite vibhāge.
analyzed: kamma ādi bhede iti vibhāge
translated: The meaning of “distinction” is: the distinction consisting in the action, the action’s similarity, the characteristic, and the fruit of the characteristic.

original: Gāthābandhaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, attho pana apubbaṃ natthīti adhippāyo. Porāṇakattherāti
analyzed: gāthābandham sandhāya vuttam atthaḥ pana apubbam natthi iti adhippāyaḥ porāṇaka ttherā ti
translated: This is said with reference to the metrical arrangement, but there is no new meaning, is the intention.🔽The ancient teachers are the teachers of the commentaries.

original: aṭṭhakathācariyā. Vaṇṇanāgāthāti thomanāgāthā vuttamevatthaṃ gahetvā thomanāvasena
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā cariyā vaṇṇanā gāthā ati thomanā gāthā vuttam eva attham gahetvā thomanā vasena
translated: The verses of the commentary are the verses of the commentary that take the meaning stated above and state it in the form of a verse.

original: pavattattā. Aparabhāge therā nāma pāḷiṃ, aṭṭhakathañca potthakāropanavasena samāgatā
analyzed: pavattattā apara bhāge therāḥ nāma pāḷim aṭṭhakatham ca potthaka āropana vasena samāgatā
translated: because it is the way of the world. Later on, however, the elders, who were called “great elders” because they had assembled in the form of a book with the text and the commentary,

original: mahātherā, ye sāṭṭhakathaṃ piṭakattayaṃ potthakāruḷhaṃ katvā saddhammaṃ addhaniyaciraṭṭhitikaṃ
analyzed: mahā therāḥ ye sa aṭṭhakatham piṭaka ttayam potthaka āruḷham katvā saddhammam addha niya cira ṭṭhitikam
translated: made the true Dhamma last for a long time by making the three Piṭakas with the commentary into a book.

original: akaṃsu. Ekapadikoti “daḷhasamādāno ahosī”tiādipāṭhe ekekapadagāhī. Atthuddhāroti
analyzed: ekapadikaḥ iti daḷha samādānaḥ ahosi iti ādi pāṭhe ekeka pada gāhī
translated: “A single line” : one who takes up each line in the text beginning “He was one who had taken up the training rules” . “A single meaning” :

original: tadatthassa sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ gāthābandhavasena uddharaṇato atthuddhārabhūto, tayidaṃ🔽pāḷiyaṃ āgatapadāni gahetvā gāthābandhavasena tadatthavicāraṇabhāvadassanaṃ, na pana
analyzed: tad atthassa sukha ggahaṇa attham gāthābandha vasena uddharaṇataḥ atthuddhāra bhūtaḥ  pāḷiyam āgata padāni gahetvā gāthābandha vasena tad attha vicāraṇa bhāva dassanam na pana
translated: one who has extracted the meaning in the form of a verse for the sake of easy grasping of that meaning. This is the meaning of “one who has extracted the meaning.”

original: dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena ṭhapitabhāvapaṭikkhipananti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena ṭhapita bhāva paṭikkhipananti daṭṭhabbam
translated: This is shown by the fact that he takes the words that occur in the text and considers their meaning in the form of a verse, but it should not be taken to mean that he rejects the fact that the Dhamma is deposited in the Dhamma-treasury.

original: Kusaladhammānaṃ vacīsaccassa bahukārataṃ, tappaṭipakkhassa ca musāvādassa mahāsāvajjataṃ
analyzed: kusala dhammānam vacīsaccassa bahu kāra tam tad paṭipakkhassa ca musāvādassa mahā sāvajja tam
translated: In order to show the great benefit of truthful speech and the great danger of its opposite, lying,

original: dassetuṃ anantarameva kusalakammapathadhamme vadantopi tato vacīsaccaṃ nīharitvā
analyzed: dassetum anantaram eva kusala kamma patha dhamme vadantaḥ api tatas vacīsaccam nīharitvā
translated: the Buddha, after teaching the Dhamma of the profitable courses of action, took out truthful speech and taught it separately.

original: katheti sacceti vā sannidhāneva “dhamme”ti vuccamānā kusalakammapathadhammā eva yuttāti
analyzed: kathā iti saccā iti vā sannidhānā iva dhammā iti vuccamānā kusala kammapatha dhammā eva yuttā ati
translated: Or else, when the word “Dhamma” is spoken of in the presence of the truth, it is only the wholesome courses of action that are appropriate.

original: vuttaṃ “dhammeti dasakusalakammapathadhamme”ti. Gobalībaddañāyena vā ettha attho🔽veditabbo. Indriyadamaneti indriyasaṃvare. Kusalakammapathagghaṇenassa vārittasīlameva
analyzed: vuttam dhamme ti dasa kusala kammapatha dhamme ti go balībaddañāyena vā ettha atthaḥ  veditabbaḥ indriya damana iti indriya saṃvare
translated: Therefore it is said: “Dhamma means the ten wholesome courses of action.” Or else, the meaning should be understood here by way of the method of extension.🔽“In taming the faculties” means in the restraint of the faculties. Or else, since the virtue that is restrained by the wholesome courses of action is included,

original: gahitanti itarampi saṅgahetvā dassetuṃ saṃyamasseva gahaṇaṃ katanti “saṃyameti sīlasaṃyame”ti
analyzed: itaram pi saṅgahetvā dassetum saṃyamassa iva gahaṇam saṃyama iti sīla saṃyama iti
translated: it is said: “Restraint means restraint of virtue” in order to show that the restraint is included by taking the virtue.

original: vuttaṃ. Suci vuccati puggalo yassa dhammassa vasena, taṃ soceyyaṃ, kāyasucaritādi.🔽Etasseva hi vibhāgassa dassanatthaṃ vuttampi cetaṃ puna vuttaṃ, manosoceyyaggahaṇena
analyzed: vuttam suci vuccati puggalaḥ yassa dhammassa vasena tam soceyyam kāya su carita ādi  etassa iva hi vibhāgassa dassana attham vuttam api ca itam puna vuttam manosoceyya ggahaṇena
translated: “Purity” is said to be a person by means of whose Dhamma, and that is the purity of body, etc.

original: vā jhānādiuttarimanussadhammānampi saṅgaṇhanatthaṃ soceyyaggahaṇaṃ. Ālayabhūtanti
analyzed: vā jhāna ādi uttari manussa dhammānam pi saṅgaṇhana attham soceyya gahaṇam ālaya bhūtanti
translated: This is said again in order to show the same division, although it has already been said. Or else, the mention of purity is in order to include the higher states of the human Dhamma, such as the jhānas, etc., by the mention of mental purity.🔽“The basis” means the foundation of serenity and insight.

original: samathavipassanānaṃ adhiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ. Uposathakammanti uposathadivase samādiyitvā
analyzed: samatha vipassanānam adhiṭṭhāna bhūtam uposatha kammanti uposatha divase samādiyitvā
translated: “The observance-day ceremony” is undertaken on the observance-day.

original: samācaritabbaṃ puññakammaṃ uposatho sahacaraṇañāyena. “Avihiṃsāyāti sattānaṃ aviheṭhanāyā”ti
analyzed: samācaritabbam puñña kammam uposathaḥ sahacaraṇa ñāyena a vihiṃsāya ati sattānam a viheṭhanāya ati
translated: “Meritorious deeds should be done” means the observance of the Uposatha together with the right conduct. “Non-harming” means not harming living beings.

original: vadanti, taṃ pana sīlaggahaṇeneva gahitaṃ. Tasmā avihiṃsāyāti karuṇāyāti attho. Avihiṃsāggahaṇeneva
analyzed: vadanti tam pana sīla ggahaṇena iva gahitam tasmai avihiṃsāya ati karuṇāya ati attho avihiṃsā ggahaṇena iva
translated: and the meritorious action to be performed is the Uposatha, which is the companion of the way. “Non-harming” is the non-afflicting of beings, they say. But that is included by the undertaking of virtue. Therefore the meaning of “non-harming” is “compassion.” And by the undertaking of non-harming

original: cettha appamaññāsāmaññena cattāropi brahmavihārā upacārāvatthā gahitā lakkhaṇahāranayena.
analyzed: ca ittha appamaññā sāmaññena cattāro api brahmavihārāḥ upacāra avatthāḥ gahitāḥ lakkhaṇa hāra nayena
translated: the four divine abodes are included in the stage of access by the method of taking the characteristic.

original: Sakalanti anavasesaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ. Evamettha kāmāvacarattabhāvapariyāpannattā lakkhaṇassa
analyzed: sakalanti anavasesam paripuṇṇam evam ettha kāmāvacara tta bhāva pariyāpanna ttā lakkhaṇassa
translated: “Complete” means without remainder, perfect. Thus here, because of being included in the state of the sense-sphere, the characteristic

original: taṃsaṃvattanikakāmāvacarakusaladhammā eva pāramitāsaṅgahapuññasambhārabhūtakāyasucaritādīhi🔽dvādasadhā vibhattā eva. Gāthāyaṃ “sacce”tiādinā dasadhā saṅgayha dassitā. Esa nayo sesalakkhaṇepi.
analyzed: tad saṃvattanika kāmāvacara kusala dhammāḥ eva pāramitā saṅgaha puñña sambhāra bhūta kāya su carita ādīhi  dvādasadhā vibhattā eva gāthā ayam sacca iti ādinā dasadhā saṅgayha dassitā esa nayo sesa lakkhaṇe pi
translated: is the sense-sphere wholesome states that are conducive to it, which are included in the perfection of giving, etc., and are the basis for the accumulation of merit.🔽They are divided into twelve as the bodily good conduct, etc., which are the basis for the perfection. In the verse they are shown by being included in ten ways, beginning with “truth.” The same method applies to the other characteristics.

original: Aṃnubhīti gāthāsukhatthaṃ akāraṃ sānunāsikaṃ katvā vuttaṃ. Byañjanāni lakkhaṇāni
analyzed: aṃnubhi iti gāthā sukha attham akāram sa anunāsikam katvā vuttam byañjanāni lakkhaṇāni
translated: “Experienced” is said with the vowel a added to the end of the word “experienced” for the sake of the meter. The characteristics are the syllables.

original: ācikkhantīti veyañjanikā. Vikkhambhetabbanti paṭibāhitabbaṃ tassāti mahāpurisassa,
analyzed: ācikkhanti iti veyañjanikāḥ vikkhambhetabbam ti paṭibāhitabbam tassa ti mahāpurisassa
translated: “She describes” : she is a fortune-teller. “Should be removed” : should be warded off from him, the Great Man,

original: tassa vā mahāpurisalakkhaṇassa. Lakkhaṇasīsena cettha taṃsaṃvattanikapuññasambhāro vuccati.
analyzed: tassa vā mahāpurisa lakkhaṇassa lakkhaṇa sīsena ca ittha taṃsaṃvattanika puñña sambhāraḥ vuccati
translated: or from the mark of a Great Man. But here the mark of a Great Man is said to be the merit that leads to it.

original: Pādatalacakkalakkhaṇavaṇṇanā🔽204. Bhayaṃ nāma bhīti, taṃ pana ubbijjanākārena, uttasanākārena ca pavattiyā duvidhanti
analyzed: bhayam nāma bhī ti tam pana ubbijjana ākārena uttasana ākārena ca pavattiyā duvidhanti
translated: The explanation of the mark of wheels on the feet.🔽“Fear” is fright. But since it occurs in the mode of being terrified and in the mode of trembling, it is twofold.

original: āha “ubbegabhayañceva uttāsabhayañcā”ti. Tadubhayampi bhayaṃ vibhāgena dassetuṃ “tatthā”tiādi
analyzed: āha ubbega bhayam ca iva uttāsa bhayam ca ati tat ubhayam pi bhayam vibhāgena dassetum tattha atiādi
translated: Therefore it is said: “fear of being terrified and fear of trembling.” In order to show the two kinds of fear in detail, it is said: “Herein, what is fear of being terrified? “

original: vuttaṃ. Apanūditāti yathā corādayo viluppanabandhanādīni parassa na karonti, katañca
analyzed: vuttam apanūditā ti yathā cora ādayaḥ viluppana bandhana ādīni parassa na karonti katam ca
translated: “Removed” : just as thieves, etc., do not cause others to be robbed, bound, etc., and what has been done

original: paccāharaṇādinā paṭipākatikaṃ hoti, evaṃ yathā ca caṇḍahatthiādayo dūrato parivajjitā
analyzed: pacca āharaṇa ādinā paṭipākatikam hoti evam yathā ca caṇḍahatthi ādayaḥ dūratas
translated: is removed by the return of the property, etc., so too, just as fierce elephants, etc., are avoided from a distance,

original: honti, aparivajjite tassa yathā ṭhāne ṭhitehi abhibhavo na hoti, evaṃ apanūditā.
analyzed: honti a parivajjite tassa yathā ṭhāne ṭhitehi abhibhavaḥ na hoti evam apanūditā
translated: and when they are not avoided, they are overcome by those who stand in their proper place, so too, they are removed.

original: Ativāhetīti atikkāmeti. Taṃ ṭhānanti taṃ sāsaṅkaṭṭhānaṃ. Asakkontānanti upayogatthe🔽sāmivacanaṃ, asakkonteti attho. Asakkontānanti vā anādare sāmivacanaṃ. Saha parivārenāti🔽saparivāraṃ. Tattha kiñci deyyadhammaṃ dento yadā tassa parivārabhāvena aññampi deyyadhammaṃ
analyzed: ativāheti iti atikkāmeti tam ṭhānam ti tam sāsaṅka ṭṭhānam a sakkontānam ti upayoga tthe  sāmi vacanam a sakkonta iti atthaḥ a sakkontānam anti vā anādare sāmi vacanam saha parivārena ati  sa parivāram tattha kiñci deyya dhammam dentaḥ yadā tassa parivāra bhāvena aññam pi deyya dhammam
translated: Exceeds: exceeds the limit. That place: that place of danger. Those unable: the genitive is in the sense of instrument; the meaning is, those who are unable. Or the genitive is in the sense of disregard; the meaning is, those who are unable to disregard. Together with his retinue: together with his retinue.
