There, when he gives some gift, if he gives another gift as a member of the retinue of the first giver,

original: deti, evaṃ tassa taṃ dānamayaṃ puññaṃ saparivāraṃ nāma hoti.🔽Tamatthaṃ vitthārena dassetuṃ “tattha anna”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha yathā deyyadhammaṃ
analyzed: deti evam tassa tam dāna mayam puññam sa parivāram nāma hoti  tam attham vitthārena dassetum tattha anna nti ādi vuttam tattha yathā deyya dhammam
translated: Exceeds: exceeds the limit. That place: that place of danger. Those who cannot: the genitive is in the sense of object; the meaning is, those who cannot . Or the genitive is in the sense of disregard; the meaning is, those who cannot . Together with his retinue: together with his retinue. Herein, when he gives a gift to someone, if he gives another gift as well on account of the other’s being his retinue, then that merit consisting in giving on his part is called “with retinue.”

original: tassa annadānassa parivāro, evaṃ tassa sakkaccakaraṇaṃ pīti dassento “atha kho”tiādimāha.🔽Yāgubhattaṃ datvāva adāsīti yojanā. Esa nayo ito paratopi. Suttaṃ vaṭṭetīti cīvarassa
analyzed: tassa anna dānassa parivāraḥ evam tassa sakkacca karaṇam pi iti dassentaḥ atha kho ti ādim āha  yāgu bhattam adāsi iti yojanā esa nayaḥ itas paratas pi suttam vaṭṭeti iti cīvarassa
translated: To show the meaning of that in detail, “Herein, food” is said, etc. Herein, just as the gift is the retinue of the giving of food, so the giving respectfully is the retinue of the giving of food. Showing this, he said, “Then the Elder” , etc.

original: sibbanasuttakaṃ duvaṭṭativaṭṭādivasena vaṭṭitaṃ akāsi. Rajananti alliādirajanavatthuṃ.
analyzed: sibbana suttakam duvaṭṭati vaṭṭa ādi vasena vaṭṭitam akāsi rajananti alli ādi rajana vatthum
translated: The construction is: after giving the gruel and rice, he gave the cloth. The same method applies to the rest. He had the robe sewn: he had the robe sewn by sewing it together twice, etc. He dyed it: he dyed it with the dye of lac, etc.

original: Paṇḍupalāsanti rajanupagameva paṇḍuvaṇṇaṃ palāsaṃ.
analyzed: rajan upagam iva paṇḍu vaṇṇam palāsam
translated: “Pale-leaf” : a leaf that is pale-colored like the morning twilight.

original: Heṭṭhimānīti annādīni cattāri. Nisadaggahaṇeneva nisadapotopi gahito. Cīnapiṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhimāni iti anna ādīni cattāri nisada ggahaṇena iva nisada poto api gahitaḥ cīna piṭṭham
translated: “Lower” : the four beginning with food. By the word “couch” is included also a couch-cover. “Chinese silk” :

original: sindhurakacuṇṇaṃ. Kojavanti uddalomiekantalomiādikojavattharaṇa. Suvibhattaantarānīti
analyzed: sindhuraka cuṇṇam suvibhatta antarāni iti
translated: red ochre powder. “Bedspread” : a bedspread of wool, cotton, etc. “Well-defined” :

original: suṭṭhu vibhattaantarāni, etena cakkāvayavaṭṭhānānaṃ suparicchinnataṃ dasseti.🔽Laddhābhisekā khattiyā attano vijite visavitāya brāhmaṇādike catūhi saṅgahavatthūhi
analyzed: suṭṭhu vibhatta antarāni etena cakka avayava ṭṭhānānam su paricchinna tam dasseti  laddha abhisekā khattiyā attanaḥ vijite visavitāya brāhmaṇa ādike catūhi saṅgaha vatthūhi
translated: well-defined in the middle; this shows that the places of the spokes are well-defined.

original: rañjetuṃ sakkonti, na itarāti āha “rājānoti abhisittā”ti. Rājato yathāladdhagāmanigamādiṃ
analyzed: rañjetum sakkonti na itarā iti āha rājāno ti abhisittā iti rājataḥ yathā laddha gāma nigama ādim
translated: Having received consecration, kings are able to delight the brahmans, etc., in their own realm by the four means of attraction, because of their sovereignty. The others are not. Therefore it is said: “The anointed are called ‘kings’ ” .

original: issaravatāya bhuñjantīti bhojakā, tādiso bhogo etesaṃ atthi, tattha vā niyuttāti
analyzed: issaravatāya bhuñjanti iti bhojakā tādisaḥ bhogaḥ etesam atthi tattha vā niyuttā ati
translated: The “enjoyers” are those who enjoy the village, town, etc., obtained from the king, because of their sovereignty. They have such enjoyment, or they are appointed to it.

original: bhogikā, te eva “bhogiyā”ti vuttā. Saparivāraṃ dānanti vuttanayena saparivāradānaṃ.
analyzed: bhogikā te eva bhogiyā iti vuttā sa parivāram dānam ti vutta nayena sa parivāra dānam
translated: Therefore they are called “enjoyers” . “With retinue” : the giving with retinue, in the way stated.

original: Jānātūti “sadevako loko jānātū”ti iminā viya adhippāyena nibbattaṃ cakkalakkhaṇanti
analyzed: jānātu uti sa devakaḥ lokaḥ jānātu uti iminā viya adhippāyena nibbattam cakka lakkhaṇanti
translated: “Let him know”: the mark of the wheel is produced with the intention “Let the world with its gods know.”

original: lakkhaṇasseva kammasarikkhatā dassitā. Evaṃ sati tikameva siyā, na catukkaṃ, tasmā
analyzed: lakkhaṇassa iva kamma sarikkha tā dassitā evam sati tikam eva siyā na catukkam tasmā
translated: So the similarity of the action is shown in the case of the mark itself. If that were so, there would be only three, not four,

original: cakkalakkhaṇassa mahāparivāratāya ñāpakanimittabhāvo kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma. Tenevāha
analyzed: cakka lakkhaṇassa mahā parivāra tāya ñāpaka nimitta bhāvaḥ kammasarikkhakam nāma tena iva āha
translated: so the similarity of the action is called the state of being a sign that makes known because the mark of the wheel has a great retinue. That is why it is said

original: “saparivāraṃ…pe… jānātūti nibbatta”nti. “Dīghāyukatāya taṃ nimitta”nti ca vakkhati,
analyzed: jānātu uti nibbattanti dīgha āyuka tāya tam nimittam ti ca vakkhati
translated: “Let him know” is produced with the intention “Let the world with its gods know” and “That sign is for long life” and

original: tathā “taṃ lakkhaṇaṃ bhavati tadatthajotaka”nti ca. Nissandaphalaṃ pana paṭipakkhābhibhavo
analyzed: tathā tam lakkhaṇam bhavati tad attha jotakan ti ca nissanda phalam pana paṭipakkha abhibhavaḥ
translated: “That mark is for the purpose of showing that.” But the result of kamma in the form of the opposite of the cause should be regarded as

original: daṭṭhabbo. Tenevāha gāthāyaṃ “sattumaddano”ti.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ tena iva āha gāthā ayam
translated: “the dispeller of enemies” in the verse.

original: 205. Etanti etaṃ gāthābandhabhūtaṃ vacanaṃ, taṃ panatthato gāthā evāti āha “imā tadatthaparidīpanā gāthā vuccantī”ti.
analyzed: etat ti etam gāthābandha bhūtam vacanam tam pana atthataḥ gāthāḥ eva ati āha imāḥ tad attha paridīpanāḥ gāthāḥ vuccanti iti
translated: “That”: the words that constitute the verse; but in meaning it is the verse itself. That is why it is said, “These verses are spoken for the purpose of showing the meaning of that.”

original: Puratthāti vā “pure”ti vuttatopi pubbe. Yasmā mahāpuriso na atītāya ekajātiyaṃ, nāpi
analyzed: puratthā ti vā purā iti vuttatas pi pubbe yasmā mahā purisaḥ na atītāya eka jātiyam na api
translated: “Previously”: “before” is also said as “before that.” Because the Great Man is not in the one birth that is past,

original: katipayajātīsu, atha kho purimapurimatarāsu tathāva paṭipanno, tasmā tattha paṭipattiṃ🔽dassetuṃ “pure puratthā”ti vuttaṃ. Imissāpi jātiyaṃ atītakālavasena “purepuratthā”ti
analyzed: katipaya jātīsu atha kho purima purimatarāsu tathāva paṭipanno tasmā tattha paṭipattim  dassetum pure puratthā iti vuttam imissā api jātiyam atīta kāla vasena pure puratthā ti
translated: and in the previous existences he had practised in the same way, therefore it is said “in the past, in former times” in order to show the practice there.🔽And in this existence, in the past, it is said “in the past, in former times”🔽

original: vattuṃ labbhāti tato visesanatthaṃ “purimāsu jātīsū”ti vuttanti āha “imissā”tiādi.
analyzed: vattum labbhā ti tatas visesana attham purimāsu jātīsu iti vuttanti āha imissā atiādi
translated: and in the previous births before that he was practising in the same way, therefore it is said ‘in the past’ in order to show the practice there. And it is allowable to say ‘in the past’ with reference to the past time of this very birth too, so in order to distinguish it it is said ‘in previous births’ . This is the meaning of ‘in this’ and so on.

original: Keci “imissā jātiyā pubbe tusitadevaloke katakammapaṭikkhepavacana”nti vadanti, taṃ
analyzed: keci imissā jātiyā pubbe tusita deva loke kata kamma paṭikkhepa vacananti vadanti tam
translated: Some say that this is a statement of the kind of action done in the Tusita heaven before this birth.🔽But that is their own idea, because there is no such action there.

original: tesaṃ matimattaṃ tattha tādisassa katakammassa abhāvato. Apanūdanoti apanetā. Adhimuttoti yuttapayutto.🔽Puññakammenāti dānādipuññakammena. Evaṃ santeti satamattena puññakammena ekekaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: tesam matimattam tattha tādisassa kata kammassa abhāvataḥ apanūdanaḥ ti apanetā adhimuttaḥ iti yutta payuttaḥ  puñña kammena ati dāna ādi puñña kammena evam santā iti sata mattena puñña kammena ekekam lakkhaṇam
translated: ‘Remover’ is one who removes. ‘Devoted to’ means intent upon.

original: nibbatteyya, evaṃ sati. Na rocayiṃsūti kevalaṃ satamattena puññakammena lakkhaṇanibbattiṃ
analyzed: nibbatteyyaḥ evam sati na rocayiṃsu iti kevalam satamattena puñña kammena lakkhaṇa nibbattim
translated: ‘Meritorious deeds’ means deeds of merit such as giving. ‘If it were so’ means if it were by means of only a hundred meritorious deeds that each mark was produced. ‘It would not be right’ means that the production of the marks by means of only a hundred meritorious deeds

original: na rocayiṃsu aṭṭhakathācariyā. Kathaṃ pana rocayiṃsūti āha “anantesu panā”tiādi.
analyzed: na rocayiṃsu aṭṭhakathā cariyā katham pana rocayiṃsu iti āha anantesu pana atiādi
translated: The teachers of the commentary did not accept it. But how did they accept it? He said, “But in the case of infinite worlds” and so on.🔽“Each action”: each action of giving, etc., that is a prior action.

original: Ekekaṃ kammanti ekekaṃ dānādipubbakammaṃ. Ekekaṃ sataguṇaṃ katvāti anantāsu lokadhātūsu
analyzed: ekekam kamman ti ekekam dāna ādi pubba kammam ekekam sataguṇam katvā iti anantāsu lokadhātūsu
translated: “Each multiplied a hundred times”: in the infinite world systems🔽there are as many beings as there are grains of sand in the river Ganges.

original: yattakā sattā, tehi sabbehi paccekaṃ satakkhattuṃ katāni dānādipuññakammāni yattakāni,
analyzed: yattakā sattā tehi sabbehi paccekam satakkhattum katāni dāna ādi puñña kammāni yattakāni
translated: Each of the meritorious actions of giving, etc., performed by all of them a hundred times each

original: tato ekekaṃ puññakammaṃ mahāsattena sataguṇaṃ kataṃ “sata”nti adhippetaṃ, tasmā idha
analyzed: tatas ekekam puñña kammam mahāsattena sataguṇam katam sata nti adhippetam tasmai idha
translated: is what is meant by “a hundred” here. Therefore

original: sata-saddo bahubhāvapariyāyo, na saṅkhyāvacanoti dasseti “satagghi sataṃ devamanussā”tiādīsu
analyzed: sata saddaḥ bahu bhāva pariyāyaḥ na saṅkhyā vacanaḥ ti dasseti satak hi satam deva manussa ati ādīsu
translated: he shows that the word “hundred” here is a term for a multitude, not a numeral, as in such passages as “a hundred gods and men” .

original: viya. Tenāha “tasmā satapuññalakkhaṇoti imamatthaṃ rocayiṃsū”ti.
analyzed: tena āha tasmai sata puñña lakkhaṇo ti imam attham rocayiṃsu iti
translated: Therefore they accepted the meaning “a hundred characteristics of merit.”

original: Āyatapaṇhitāditilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: āyata paṇhita āditi lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the three characteristics beginning with “long”

original: 206. Sarasacuti nāma jātassa sattassa yāvajīvaṃ jīvitvā pakatiyā maraṇaṃ. Ākaḍḍhajiyassa
analyzed: sarasacuti nāma jātassa sattassa yāvajīvam jīvitvā pakatiyā maraṇam ākaḍḍhajiyassa
translated: “Natural death” is the death of a being that has lived out its life span. “Death by violence” is the death of a being that has not lived out its life span.

original: dhanudaṇḍassa viya pādānaṃ antomukhaṃ kuṭilatāya antovaṅkapādatā. Bahimukhaṃ kuṭilatāya
analyzed: dhanu daṇḍassa viya pādānam antomukham kuṭila tāya antovaṅka pāda tā bahimukham kuṭila tāya
translated: They are not bent outwards because of the outward bent of crookedness.🔽They are not splay-footed because of deficiency in the middle of the soles.

original: bahivaṅkapādatā. Pādatalassa majjhe ūnatāya ukkuṭikapādatā. Aggapādena khañjanakā
analyzed: bahivaṅka pāda tā pāda talassa majjhe ūna tāya ukkuṭika pāda tā agga pādena khañjanakā
translated: The toes are not in a claw, like those of a bear, because of the upward bent of crookedness.🔽They are not in a bunch, like those of a hare, because of the bent of crookedness at the sides.🔽He has a well-upright body because of the absence of stooping.🔽He has hands with fingers that are rounded, like those of a peacock’s tail or like a bun, because of the absence of the flatness of a spade or an axe.

original: aggakoṇḍā. Paṇhippadesena khañjanakā paṇhikoṇḍā. Unnatakāyenāti anonatabhāvena samussitasarīrena.🔽Muṭṭhikatahatthāti āvudhādīnaṃ gahaṇatthaṃ katamuṭṭhihatthā. Phaṇahatthakāti aññamaññaṃ🔽saṃsaṭṭhaṅgulihatthā. Idamettha kammasarikkhakanti idaṃ imesaṃ tiṇṇampi lakkhaṇānaṃ
analyzed: agga koṇḍā paṇhi ppadesena khañjanakā paṇhi koṇḍā unnata kāyena ati anonata bhāvena samussita sarīrena  muṭṭhi kata hatthā ti āvudha ādīnam gahaṇa attham kata muṭṭhi hatthā phaṇa hatthakā iti aññamaññam  saṃsaṭṭha aṅguli hatthā idam ettha idam imesam tiṇṇam pi lakkhaṇānaṃ
translated: He has hands with fingers that are close together, like those of a Brahmä, because of the absence of the gaps between the fingers of a monkey.🔽This is the similarity of action here in this case.🔽The fact that the long fingers and the straightness of the body are the signs that foretell the quality of long life in the Tathāgata is the similarity of action here in this case.

original: tathāgatassa dīghāyukatāya ñāpakanimittabhāvo ettha āyatapaṇhitā, dīghaṅgulitā brahmujugattatāti
analyzed: tathāgatassa dīgha āyuka tāya ñāpaka nimitta bhāvaḥ ettha āyata paṇhi tā dīgha aṅguli tā brahmu jugatta tā ati
translated: The fact that the long toes and the straightness of the body are the signs that foretell the quality of long life in the Tathāgata is the similarity of action here in this case.

original: etasmiṃ lakkhaṇattaye kammasarikkhakattaṃ. Nissandaphalaṃ pana anantarāyatādi daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: etasmin lakkhaṇa ttaye nissanda phalam pana anantarāyata ādi daṭṭhabbam
translated: But the result of kamma in accordance with the cause should be understood as the absence of hindrance, and so on.

original: 207. Bhāyitabbavatthunimittaṃ uppajjamānampi bhayaṃ attasinehahetukaṃ pahīnasinehassa
analyzed: bhāyitabba vatthu nimittam uppajjamānam api bhayam atta sineha hetukam pahīna sinehassa
translated: fear is abandoned too, since there is no longer any reason for it.

original: tadabhāvatoti āha “yathā mayhaṃ maraṇato bhayaṃ mama jīvitaṃ piya”nti. Suciṇṇenāti
analyzed: tad abhāvataḥ iti āha yathā maraṇataḥ bhayam mama jīvitam su ciṇṇena ati
translated: That is why he said: “As long as there is fear of death in me, my life is dear to me.”

original: suṭṭhu katūpacitena sucaritakammunā.🔽Cavitvāti saggato cavitvā. “Sujātagatto subhujo”ti ādayo sarīrāvayavaguṇā imehi lakkhaṇehi
analyzed: suṭṭhu katu upacitena su carita kammunā  cavitvā iti saggataḥ cavitvā sujāta gatto su bhujo ti ādayo sarīra avayava guṇāḥ imehi lakkhaṇehi
translated: “Well developed”: well practiced and accumulated.🔽“Having passed on”: having passed on to the heavenly world.🔽The qualities of the limbs of the body mentioned in the passage beginning with “well-formed body, well-formed limbs” are stated to show that they are invariably conjoined with the characteristics.

original: avinābhāvinoti dassetuṃ vuttā. Cirayapanāyāti attabhāvassa cirakālaṃ pavattanāya.
analyzed: avinābhāvino ti dassetum vuttā cira yapanāya iti attabhāvassa cira kālam pavattanāya
translated: “For the duration of a long time”: for the duration of a long life.🔽That is why he said: “for the duration of a long life.”

original: Tenāha “dīghāyukabhāvāyā”ti. Tatoti cakkavattī hutvā yāpanato. Vasippattoti jhānādīsu
analyzed: tena āha dīgha āyuka bhāvāya ati tatoti cakkavattī hutvā yāpanataḥ vasi patto ti jhāna ādīsu
translated: “After that”: after living as a wheel-turning monarch.🔽“Having attained mastery”: having attained mastery in the jhānas, etc.,

original: vasībhāvañceva cetovasibhāvañca patto hutvā, kathaṃ iddhibhāvanāya iddhipādabhāvanāyāti
analyzed: vasībhāvam ca iva cetaḥ vasi bhāvam ca pattas hutvā katham iddhi bhāvanāya iddhipāda bhāvanāya ati
translated: and mastery over the mind. The meaning is: by the development of supernormal power, by the development of the bases of supernormal power.

original: attho. Yāpeti cirataranti yojanā.
analyzed: atthaḥ yāpa iti cirataranti yojanā
translated: The construction is: “he maintains himself for a longer time.”

original: Sattussadatālakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sattussada tā lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the characteristic of being well-endowed with the seven treasures.

original: 208. Raso jāto etesanti rasitāni, mahārasāni. Tenāha “rasasampannāna”nti. Piṭṭhakhajjakādīnīti🔽pūpasakkhalimodakādīni. Ādi-saddena pana kadaliphalādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Piṭṭhaṃ pakkhipitvā
analyzed: rasaḥ jātaḥ rasitāni mahārasāni tena āha piṭṭha khajjaka ādīni iti  pūpa sakkhali modaka ādīni ādi saddena pana kadali phala ādim saṅgaṇhāti piṭṭham pakkhipitvā
translated: They are relished because they are born of juice, thus they are relished, are great relishes. Hence he said “rich in juice” . Cakes, etc.,🔽means sweetmeats, pastries, sweet cakes, etc. But by the word “etc.” the plantain fruit, etc., are included. A sweetmeat made by cooking rice with the husk on,

original: pacitabbapāyasaṃ piṭṭhapāyasaṃ. Ādi-saddena tathārūpabhojjayāguādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: pacitabba pāyasam piṭṭha pāyasam ādi saddena tathārūpa bhojja yāgu ādim saṅgaṇhāti
translated: is a rice-sweetmeat. But by the word “etc.” such things as rice-gruel of that kind are included.

original: Idha kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma sattussadatālakkhaṇassa paṇītalābhitāya ñāpakanimittabhāvo. Iminā nayena tattha tattha lakkhaṇe kammasarikkhakaṃ niddhāretvā yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: idha kamma sarikkhakam nāma sattu ssada tā lakkhaṇassa paṇīta lābhi tāya ñāpaka nimitta bhāvaḥ iminā nayena tattha tattha lakkhaṇe kamma sarikkhakam niddhāretvā yojetabbam
translated: Herein, the sign of the kind of action similar to the characteristic is the sign of the kind of action that is the cause of the acquisition of the excellence of the seven good qualities of the alms food. In this way the kind of action similar to the characteristic should be extracted in each instance and applied.🔽The supreme giver of the best and choicest food,

original: 209. Uttamo aggarasadāyakoti sabbasattānaṃ uttamo lokanātho aggānaṃ paṇītānaṃ rasānaṃ🔽dāyako. Uttamānaṃ aggarasānanti paṇītesupi paṇītarasānaṃ. Khajjabhojjādijotakanti
analyzed: uttamaḥ agga rasa dāyakaḥ iti sabba sattānam uttamaḥ loka nāthaḥ aggānam paṇītānam rasānam  dāyakaḥ uttamānam agga rasānam ti paṇītesu pi paṇīta rasānam khajja bhojja ādi jotakam ti
translated: is the supreme one of all beings, the Helper of the world, the giver of the best and choicest food.🔽The best of the best and choicest food,🔽is the best of the choicest food. The announcement of the acquisition of the cakes, etc.,

original: khajjabhojjādilābhajotakaṃ. Lābhasaṃvattanikassa kammassa phalaṃ “lābhasaṃvattanika”nti
analyzed: khajja bhojja ādi lābha jotakam lābha saṃvattanikassa kammassa phalam lābha saṃvattanikanti
translated: is the announcement of the acquisition of the cakes, etc. The fruit of the kind of action that is conducive to acquisition is “conducive to acquisition” .

original: kāraṇūpacārena vadati. Tadatthajotakanti vā tassa paṇītabhojanadāyakattasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: kāraṇa upacārena vadati vā tassa paṇīta bhojana dāyaka tta saṅkhātassa
translated: He speaks by way of a reason. Or else, it is a reasoner of the meaning of that, that is, of his giving of the fine food.

original: atthassa jotakaṃ. Tadādhigacchatīti ettha ā-kāro nipātamattanti āha “taṃ adhigacchatī”ti.
analyzed: atthassa jotakam tadā adhigacchati iti ettha ākāraḥ nipāta mattam ti āha tam adhigacchati iti
translated: The syllable ā is a mere particle. He comes to that, he comes to it.

original: Lābhiruttamanti ra-kāro padasandhikaro.
analyzed: rakāraḥ pada sandhi karaḥ
translated: The syllable ra is a word-connector.

original: Karacaraṇādilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kara caraṇa ādi lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the characteristics of hands, feet, etc.

original: 210. Pabbajitaparikkhāraṃ pattacīvarādiṃ gihiparikkhāraṃ vatthāvudhayānasayanādiṃ.
analyzed: pabbajita parikkhāram patta cīvara ādim gihi parikkhāram vattha avudha yāna sayana ādim
translated: The requisites of a monk are the bowl, the robe, etc., and the requisites of a layman are clothes, ornaments, vehicles, beds, etc.

original: Sabbanti sabbaṃ upakāraṃ. Makkhetvā nāseti makkhibhāve ṭhatvā. Telena viya makkhetīti🔽satadhotatelena makkheti viya. Atthasaṃvaḍḍhanakathāyāti hitāvahakathāya. Kathāgahaṇañcettha
analyzed: sabbam ti sabbam upakāram makkhetvā nāseti makkhi bhāve ṭhatvā telena viya makkheti iti  makkheti viya attha saṃvaḍḍhana kathāya ati hita āvaha kathāya kathā gahaṇam ca ittha
translated: All means all that is useful. Having smeared, he destroys. Having become a smearing, he destroys.🔽Smearing as with oil means smearing as with oil a hundred times washed. By means of talk that increases welfare means by means of talk that brings about welfare. The mention of talk

original: nidassanamattaṃ. Paresaṃ hitāvaho kāyapayogopi atthacariyā. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana vacīpayogavaseneva atthacariyā vuttā.
analyzed: nidassana mattam paresam hita āvaho kāya payogaḥ api attha cariyā aṭṭhakathā ayam pana vacī payoga vasena iva attha cariyā vuttā
translated: here is by way of illustration only. The bodily activity that brings about the welfare of others is also service. But in the commentary only verbal activity is mentioned as service.

original: Samānattatāyāti sadisabhāve samānaṭṭhāne ṭhapanena, taṃ panassa samānaṭṭhāne ṭhapanaṃ
analyzed: samānatta tāya ati sadisa bhāve samāna ṭhapanena tam panassa samāna ṭṭhāne ṭhapanam
translated: Sameness of state: by placing in the same state, in the same position. And that placing in the same state is

original: attasadisatākaraṇaṃ, sukhena ekasambhogatā, attano sukhuppattiyaṃ; tassa ca dukkhuppattiyaṃ
analyzed: atta sadisa tā karaṇam sukhena eka sambhoga tā attano sukha uppattiyam tassa ca dukkha uppattiyam
translated: making oneself the same as him, sharing with him, in the production of pleasure for oneself and in the production of pain for him.

original: tena attano ekasambhogatāti āha “samānasukhadukkhabhāvenā”ti. Sā ca samānasukhadukkhatā
analyzed: tena attanaḥ eka sambhoga tā ti āha samāna sukha dukkha bhāvena ati sā ca samāna sukha dukkha tā
translated: Therefore it is said, “By having the same pleasure and pain.” And that sameness of pleasure and pain

original: ekato nisajjādinā pākaṭā hotīti taṃ dassento “ekāsane”tiādimāha. Na hi sakkā ekaparibhogo
analyzed: ekatas nisajja ādinā pākaṭā hoti iti tam dassentaḥ eka āsana iti ādim āha na hi sakkā eka paribhogaḥ
translated: becomes evident by sitting together, etc., so in showing that he said “on the same seat,” etc. For it is not possible to make a sharing of one’s own self

original: kātuṃ jātiyā hīnattā. Tathā akariyamāne ca so kujjhati bhogena adhikattā, tasmā dussaṅgaho.
analyzed: kātum jātiyāḥ hīna ttā tathā a kariyamāne ca saḥ kujjhati bhogena adhika ttā tasmā dussaṅgahaḥ
translated: because of inferiority of birth. And if that is not done, he is annoyed because of the difference in wealth. Therefore he is difficult to associate with.

original: Na hi so ekaparibhogaṃ icchati jātiyā hīnabhāvato. Na akariyamāne ca kujjhati bhogena
analyzed: na hi saḥ eka paribhogam icchati jātiyāḥ hīna bhāvataḥ na a kariyamāṇe ca kujjhati bhogena
translated: For he does not want a sharing of one’s own self because of inferiority of birth. And if that is not done, he is not annoyed because of the difference in wealth.

original: hīnabhāvato. Ubhohīti jātibhogehi. Sadisopi susaṅgaho ekasadisabhāveneva itarena
analyzed: hīna bhāvataḥ jāti bhogehi sadisaḥ api su saṅgahaḥ eka sadisa bhāvena iva itarena
translated: Both: by birth and by wealth. One who is equal is easy to associate with because of the sameness of state with the other,

original: saha ekaparibhogassa paccāsīsāya, akaraṇe ca tassa kujjhanassābhāvato. Adīyamānepi
analyzed: saha eka paribhogassa a karaṇe ca tassa a dīyamāne pi
translated: since he consents to a sharing of one’s own self and is not annoyed if that is not done. And even if he is not given anything,🔽he is not annoyed.

original: kismiñci āmise akariyamānepi saṅgahe. Na pāpakena cittena passati pesalabhāvato.
analyzed: kismiñci āmise a kariyamāne pi saṅgahe na pāpakena cittena passati pesala bhāvato
translated: He does not look at them with a wicked mind, because they are good people.🔽And because of that, their use is also … .

original: Tato eva paribhogopi…pe… hoti. Evarūpanti gihī ce, ubhohi sadisaṃ; pabbajito ce,
analyzed: tatas eva hoti evarūpanti gihī ce ubhohi sadisam pabbajito ce
translated: If the other is a layman, he should be like him in both respects; if he is an ordained person,

original: sīlavantanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: sīlavantanti adhippāyo
translated: he should be like him in virtue.

original: Susaṅgahitāva hontīti suṭṭhu saṅgahitā eva honti daḷhabhattibhāvato. Tenāha “na bhijjantī”ti.
analyzed: su saṅgahitāḥ ava honti iti suṭṭhu saṅgahitāḥ eva honti daḷha bhatti bhāvataḥ tena āha na bhijjanti iti
translated: They are well-disposed: they are well-disposed, because they are devoted to him. Therefore it is said, “they do not break.”

original: Dānādisaṅgahakammanti dānādibhedaṃ parasaṅgaṇhanavasena pavattaṃ kusalakammaṃ.
analyzed: dāna ādi saṅgaha kamman ti dāna ādi bhedam para saṅgaṇhana vasena pavattam kusala kammam
translated: The action of inclusion by means of giving, etc.: the profitable action that occurs by way of the inclusion of others through giving, etc.🔽He is not despised, not disregarded, not treated with contempt.

original: 211. Anavaññātena aparibhūtena sambhāvitena. Pamodo vuccati hāso, na appamodenāti
analyzed: an avaññātena a paribhūtena sambhāvitena pamodaḥ vuccati hāsaḥ na appamodena ati
translated: Joy is said to be laughter. Not without joy:

original: ettha paṭisedhadvayena so eva vutto. So ca odagyasabhāvattā na dīno dhammūpasañhitattā
analyzed: ettha paṭisedha dvayena so eva vuttaḥ saḥ ca odagya sabhāvattā na dīnaḥ dhamma upasañhita ttā
translated: here the same thing is expressed by a pair of opposites. And that is not low because it has the nature of buoyancy,🔽and it is not connected with the womb because it is associated with the Dhamma.

original: na gabbhayuttoti āha “na dīnena na gabbhitenāti attho”ti. Sattānaṃ agaṇhanaguṇenāti yojanā.
analyzed: na gabbha yutto ti āha na dīnena na gabbhitena ati attho ti sattānam a gaṇhana guṇena ati yojanā
translated: Therefore it is said, “The meaning is: not low, not connected with the womb.”

original: Atiruciranti ativiya rucirakataṃ, taṃ pana passantānaṃ pasādāvahanti āha “supāsādika”nti.
analyzed: ati ruciram ti ativiya rucira katam tam pana passantānam pasāda āvahanti āha su pāsādikam ti
translated: “Very lovely” : made very lovely. But it is said that “very inspiring” because it inspires confidence in those who see it.

original: Suṭṭhu chekanti ativiya sundaraṃ. Vidhātabboti vidhātuṃ sandisituṃ sakkuṇeyyo. Piyaṃ
analyzed: suṭṭhu sundaram vidhātabbaḥ ti vidhātum sandisitum sakkuṇeyyaḥ piyam
translated: “Very well-proportioned” : very beautiful. “To be measured” : to be measured and compared.🔽“He speaks pleasantly” : he speaks pleasantly, as in “all-knower” .

original: vadatīti piyavadū yathā “sabbavidū”ti. Sukhameva sukhatā, taṃ sukhataṃ. Dhammañca
analyzed: vadati iti piya vadū yathā sabba vidū iti sukham eva sukhatā tam sukhatam dhammam ca
translated: “Happiness” is the state of happiness. That state of happiness is the Dhamma

original: anudhammañcāti lokuttaradhammañceva tassa anurūpapubbabhāgadhammañca.
analyzed: anudhammañca ati lokuttara dhammañca iva tassa anurūpa pubbabhāga dhammañca
translated: and the principles in conformity with it.

original: Ussaṅkhapādādilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā🔽212. “Atthūpasaṃhita”nti iminā vaṭṭanissitā dhammakathā vuttāti āha “idhalokaparalokatthanissita”nti.🔽“Dhammūpasaṃhita”nti iminā vivaṭṭanissitā, tasmā dasakusalakammapathā vivaṭṭasannissayā
analyzed: ussaṅkha pāda ādi lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā  attha upasaṃhitanti iminā vaṭṭa nissitā dhamma kathā vuttā ti āha idhaloka para loka attha nissitanti  dhamma upasaṃhitanti iminā vivaṭṭa nissitā tasmā dasa kusala kamma pathā vivaṭṭa sannissayā
translated: The explanation of the characteristics beginning with “having well-rounded feet”🔽By the words “connected with welfare” a talk on the Dhamma connected with the round of rebirths is meant. Therefore it is said: “connected with the welfare of this world and the next.”🔽By the words “connected with the Dhamma” a talk on the Dhamma connected with the cessation of the round of rebirths is meant. Therefore the ten courses of wholesome kamma should be understood as the support for the cessation of the round of rebirths.

original: veditabbā. Nidaṃsesīti sandassesi te dhamme paccakkhe katvā pakāsesi. Nidaṃsanakathanti
analyzed: veditabbā nidaṃsesi iti sandassesi te dhamme paccakkhe katvā pakāsesi nidaṃsana kathan ti
translated: “He demonstrated” : he demonstrated those things by making them manifest.

original: pākaṭakaraṇakathaṃ. Jeṭṭhaṭṭhena aggo, pāsaṃsaṭṭhena seṭṭho, pamukhaṭṭhena pāmokkho,
analyzed: pākaṭa karaṇa katham jeṭṭha ṭṭhena aggaḥ pāsaṃsa ṭṭhena seṭṭhaḥ pamukha ṭṭhena pāmokkhaḥ
translated: The explanation of the making evident. He is foremost in the sense of being the eldest; best in the sense of being praiseworthy; supreme in the sense of being the chief;

original: padhānaṭṭhena uttamo, hitasukhatthikehi pakārato varaṇīyato rajanīyato pavaroti evaṃ
analyzed: padhāna ṭṭhena uttamaḥ hita sukha atthikehi pakārataḥ varaṇīyataḥ rajanīyataḥ pavaroti evam
translated: most excellent in the sense of being pre-eminent; incomparable in the sense of being worthy of choice, of being worthy of love, of being worthy of preference. Thus,

original: atthavisesavācīnampi “aggo”tiādīnaṃ padānaṃ bhāvatthassa bhedābhāvato “sabbāni aññamaññavevacanānī”ti āha.
analyzed: attha visesa vācīnam pi agga uti ādīnam padānam bhāva tthassa bheda abhāvato sabbāni aññamañña vevacanāni iti āha
translated: although these terms “foremost,” etc., express different meanings, he says that “all are synonyms for each other” because there is no difference in the meaning of the word “being.”

original: Uddhaṅgamanīyāti suṇantānaṃ uparūpari visesaṃ gamentīti uddhaṅgamanīyā. Saṅkhāya
analyzed: uddhaṅgamanīyā ati suṇantānam upari upari visesam gamenti iti uddhaṅgamanīyā saṅkhāya
translated: They lead upwards: they lead to a higher and higher distinction for those who listen to them.

original: adho piṭṭhipādasamīpe eva patiṭṭhitattā adhosaṅkhā pādā etassāti adhosaṅkhapādo.
analyzed: adhas piṭṭhi pāda samīpe eva patiṭṭhita ttā adhosaṅkhā pādāḥ etassa ati adhosaṅkha pādaḥ
translated: He has short heels because his heels are short, that is, because they are placed low, near the back of the foot.

original: Saṅkhāti ca gopphakānamidaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: ca gopphakānam idam nāmam
translated: “Short” is a name for the ankles.

original: 213. Dhammadānayaññanti dhammadānasaṅkhātaṃ yaññaṃ.
analyzed: dhamma dāna yaññanti dhamma dāna saṅkhātam yaññam
translated: The sacrifice of the gift of the Dhamma: the sacrifice called the gift of the Dhamma.

original: Suṭṭhu saṇṭhitāti sammadeva saṇṭhitā. Piṭṭhipādassa upari pakatiaṅgulena caturaṅgule jaṅghāpadese nigūḷhā apaññāyamānarūpā hutvā ṭhitāti attho.🔽Eṇijaṅghalakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: suṭṭhu saṇṭhitā ti sammat eva saṇṭhitā piṭṭhi pādassa upari pakati aṅgulena catur aṅgule jaṅghā apadese nigūḷhā a paññāyamāna rūpā hutvā ṭhitā ati attho 🔽eṇijaṅgha lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: Well-rounded: well-proportioned. The meaning is that the calf-part of the foot is hidden, not apparent, concealed by the leg-bone, which is four fingerbreadths above the heel.

original: 214. Sippanti sikkhitabbaṭṭhena “sippa”nti laddhanāmaṃ sattānaṃ jīvikāhetubhūtaṃ
analyzed: sippanti sikkhitabba ṭṭhena sippanti laddha nāmam sattānam jīvikā hetu bhūtam
translated: Skill: the means of livelihood, which has got the name of “skill” in the sense of what should be trained in, and which is a cause for creatures’ livelihood.

original: ājīvavidhiṃ. Jīvikatthaṃ, sattānaṃ upakāratthañca veditabbaṭṭhena vijjā, mantasatthādi.
analyzed: ājīva vidhim jīvika attham sattānam upakāra attham ca veditabba ṭṭhena vijjā manta sattha ādi
translated: Knowledge: the mantras, texts, etc., which should be understood in the sense of livelihood and of help to creatures.

original: Caranti tena sugatiṃ, sukhañca gacchantīti caraṇaṃ. Kammassakatāñāṇaṃ uttarapadalopena
analyzed: caranti tena sugatim sukham ca gacchanti iti caraṇam uttara pada lopena
translated: They go by it to a good destination and to happiness: thus it is a going . The knowledge of ownership of kamma is called “kamma” by dropping the final syllable.🔽He said “kamma means the understanding of the knowledge of ownership of kamma.”

original: “kamma”nti vuttanti āha “kammanti kammassakatājānanapaññā”ti. Tāni cevāti pubbe vuttahatthiādīni
analyzed: kammanti vuttanti āha kammanti kammassaka tā jānana paññā ti tāni ca iva āti pubbe vutta hatthi ādīni
translated: And those: and those elephants, etc., mentioned above.

original: ceva. Satta ratanānīti muttādīni satta ratanāni. Ca-saddena rañño upabhogabhūtānaṃ🔽vatthaseyyādīnaṃ saṅgaho. Rañño anucchavikānīti rañño paribhuñjanayogyāni. Sabbesanti
analyzed: ca iva satta ratanāni iti mutta ādīni satta ratanāni ca saddena raññaḥ upabhoga bhūtānam  vattha seyya ādīnam saṅgahaḥ raññaḥ anucchavikāni iti raññaḥ paribhuñjana yogyāni sabbesanti
translated: Seven treasures: the seven treasures of the elephant, etc., beginning with the elephant treasure.🔽By the word “and” the king’s requisites such as clothes, beds, etc., are included.🔽Fit for a king: suitable for the king to use.🔽All: this is a collective term for all those mentioned under the heading “fit for a king.”

original: “rājārahānī”tiādinā vuttānaṃ sabbesaṃyeva ekajjhaṃ gahaṇaṃ. Buddhānaṃ parisā nāma
analyzed: rāja arahāni iti ādinā vuttānam sabbesam yeva ekajjham gahaṇam buddhānam parisā nāma
translated: The Community of the Enlightened One’s disciples is called

original: odhiso anodhiso ca samitapāpā, tathatthāya paṭipannā ca hotīti vuttaṃ “samaṇānaṃ
analyzed: odhisaḥ anodhisaḥ ca samita pāpā tathatthāya paṭipannā ca hoti iti vuttam samaṇānam
translated: both limited and unlimited. It consists of those who have abandoned evil and entered upon the way. So it is said “of the ascetics

original: koṭṭhāsabhūtā catasso parisā”ti.
analyzed: koṭṭhāsa bhūtā catasso parisā ti
translated: The four assemblies are like the four parts of the body.”

original: Sippādivācananti sippānaṃ sikkhāpanaṃ. Pāḷiyampi hi “vācetā”ti vācanasīsena sikkhāpanaṃ
analyzed: sippa ādi vācanam ti sippānam sikkhāpanam pāḷiyam pi hi vāceta ati vācana sīsena sikkhāpanam
translated: Teaching of crafts, etc.: teaching of crafts. For in the texts too the teaching is shown under the heading of “teaching” .

original: dassitaṃ. Ukkuṭikāsananti taṃtaṃveyyāvaccakaraṇena ukkuṭikassa nisajjā. Payojanavasena
analyzed: dassitam ukkuṭikā āsanan ti taṃtaṃveyyāvacca karaṇena ukkuṭikassa nisajjā payojana vasena
translated: Sitting cross-legged: sitting cross-legged by the performance of the various duties. The purpose is

original: gehato gehaṃ gāmato gāmaṃ jaṅghāyo kilametvā pesanaṃ jaṅghapesanikā. Likhitvā pātitaṃ
analyzed: gehataḥ geham gāmataḥ gāmam kilametvā pesanam jaṅgha pesanikāḥ likhitvā pātitam
translated: that one should go from house to house, from village to village, and tire one’s legs. The sending of a message is “the sending of a message by the legs.”🔽It is like a message sent by writing, because it is incomplete.

original: viya hoti aparipuṇṇabhāvato. Anupubbauggatavaṭṭitanti gopphakaṭṭhānato paṭṭhāya yāva
analyzed: viya hoti a paripuṇṇa bhāvataḥ anupubba auggata vaṭṭitanti gopphaka ṭṭhānataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva
translated: The gradual increase of the flesh: because of the gradual increase all around of the accumulation of flesh, beginning from the ankle,

original: jāṇuppadesā maṃsūpacayassa anukkamena samantato vaḍḍhitattā anupubbena uggataṃ hutvā
analyzed: maṃsu upacayassa anukkamena samantataḥ vaḍḍhita ttā anupubbena uggatam hutvā
translated: it is “gradually increased” and “well rounded.”

original: suvaṭṭitaṃ. Eṇijaṅghalakkhaṇanti saṇṭhānamattena eṇimigajaṅghāsadisajaṅghalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: su vaṭṭitam eṇi jaṅgha lakkhaṇam ti saṇṭhāna mattena eṇi miga jaṅghā sadisa jaṅgha lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic of the deer’s foot: the characteristic of the leg, which is like the leg of a deer, only in shape.

original: 215. “Yatupaghātāyā”ti ettha ta-kāro padasandhikaro, anunāsikalopena niddesoti āha
analyzed: ya t upaghātāya iti ettha takāro pada sandhi karo anunāsika lopena niddeso ti āha
translated: “For the purpose of warding off” : here the syllable ta is a word connector. The syllable na is elided by the elision of the nasal sound before a sibilant.

original: “ya”ntiādi. “Uddhaggalomā sukhumattacotthatā”ti vuttattā codakena “kiṃ pana aññena🔽kammena aññaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ nibbattatī”ti codito, ācariyo “na nibbattatī”ti vatvā “yadi🔽evaṃ idha kasmā lakkhaṇantaraṃ kathita”nti antolīnameva codanaṃ pariharanto “yaṃ🔽pana nibbattatīti…pe… idha vutta”nti āha. Tattha yaṃ pana nibbattatīti yaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ🔽vuccamānalakkhaṇanibbattakena kammunā nibbattati. Taṃ anubyañjanaṃ hotīti taṃ lakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: yanti ādi uddhagga lomā sukhuma tta cottha tā ati vutta ttā codakena kim pana aññena  kammena aññam lakkhaṇam nibbattati iti coditaḥ ācariyaḥ na nibbattati iti vatvā yadi  evam idha kasmai lakkhaṇa antaram antolīnam eva codanam pariharantaḥ yam  pana nibbattati itipe idha vuttan ti āha tattha yam pana nibbattati iti yam lakkhaṇam  vuccamāna lakkhaṇa nibbattakena kammunā nibbattati tam anubyañjanam hoti iti tam lakkhaṇam
translated: “Ya” etc. Since it is said that the hair of the head is straight and fine, the questioner asks, “But is it not the case that one characteristic is produced by another kamma?” The teacher replies, “No,” and when asked, “If so, why is another characteristic mentioned here?” he answers, “But that which is produced … is mentioned here.” Herein, that which is produced is the characteristic that is produced by the kamma that produces the characteristic called “produced.” That is a secondary mark: that characteristic is a secondary mark.

original: vuccamānassa lakkhaṇassa anukūlalakkhaṇaṃ nāma hoti. Tasmā tena kāraṇena idha eṇijaṅghalakkhaṇakathane
analyzed: vuccamānassa lakkhaṇassa anukūlalakkhaṇam nāma hoti tasmā tena kāraṇena idha eṇijaṅgha lakkhaṇa kathane
translated: “Ya” etc. Since it is said that the hair of the head grows upwards and is fine and soft, the questioner asks: “But is it not the case that one characteristic is produced by one kamma?” The teacher replies: “It is not produced by that kamma.” The questioner then asks: “If that is so, why is another characteristic mentioned here?” The teacher replies: “But that which is produced by that kamma, etc.” Herein, that which is produced by that kamma, by the kamma that produces the characteristic being described, is a secondary characteristic. That characteristic is a characteristic that is in conformity with the characteristic being described. For that reason, in the description of the characteristic of having legs like an antelope’s, another characteristic, namely, “the hair of the head grows upwards and is fine and soft,” is mentioned.

original: “uddhaggalomā sukhumattacotthatā”ti lakkhaṇantaraṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Sukhumacchavilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uddhagga lomā sukhuma taca uttha tā ti lakkhaṇa antaram vuttam 🔽
translated: The explanation of the characteristic of having fine skin is finished.

original: 216. Samitapāpaṭṭhena samaṇaṃ, na pabbajjāmattena. Bāhitapāpaṭṭhena brāhmaṇaṃ, na jātimattena.
analyzed: samita pāpa ṭṭhena samaṇam na pabbajjā mattena bāhita pāpa ṭṭhena brāhmaṇam na jāti mattena
translated: The ascetic is one who has cast off evil, not merely one gone forth; the brahmin is one who has cast off evil, not merely one born of good family.

original: Mahantānaṃ atthānaṃ pariggaṇhanato mahatī paññā etassāti mahāpañño. Sesapadesupi🔽eseva nayoti āha “mahāpaññādīhi samannāgatoti attho”ti. Nānattanti yāhi mahāpaññādīhi
analyzed: mahantānam atthānam pariggaṇhanataḥ mahatī paññā etassa ati mahāpañño sesa padesu pi  esā iva nayo ti āha mahāpaññā ādīhi samannāgatoti attho ti nānattam ti yāhi mahāpaññā ādīhi
translated: He has great understanding because he has grasped great matters. The meaning of the rest of the terms should be understood in the same way.🔽The diversity of the great understanding, etc., is the diversity of the great understanding, etc., themselves.🔽The difference is this. The Blessed One is called “greatly wise” because he possesses great understanding, etc.,

original: samannāgatattā bhagavā “mahāpañño”tiādinā kittīyati, tāsaṃ mahāpaññādīnaṃ idaṃ nānattaṃ ayaṃ vemattatā.
analyzed: samannāgata ttā bhagavā mahā paññā uti ādinā kittīyati tāsam mahā paññā ādīnam idam nānattam ayam vematta tā
translated: and the diversity of the great understanding, etc., is the diversity of the great understanding, etc., themselves.

original: Yassa kassaci visesato arūpadhammassa mahattaṃ nāma kiccasiddhiyā veditabbanti tadassā
analyzed: yassa kassaci visesataḥ arūpa dhammassa mahattam nāma kicca siddhiyā veditabbanti tat assā
translated: The difference is this. The greatness of any immaterial state should be understood as success in its function.

original: kiccasiddhiyā dassento “mahante sīlakkhandhe pariggaṇhātīti mahāpaññā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: kicca siddhiyā dassentaḥ mahante sīlakkhandhe pariggaṇhāti iti mahāpaññāti ādim āha
translated: To show that success in its function, he said, “He grasps the great aggregate of virtue,” etc.

original: Tattha hetumahantatāya, paccayamahantatāya, nissayamahantatāya, pabhedamahantatāya,
analyzed: tattha hetu mahanta tāya paccaya mahanta tāya nissaya mahanta tāya pabheda mahanta tāya
translated: Herein, the aggregate of virtue is great through the greatness of its cause, through the greatness of its conditions, through the greatness of its support, and through the greatness of its variety.

original: kiccamahantatāya, phalamahantatāya, ānisaṃsamahantatāya ca sīlakkhandhassa mahantabhāvo🔽veditabbo. Tattha hetu alobhādayo. Paccayo hirottappasaddhāsativīriyādayo. Nissayo🔽sāvakabodhipaccekabodhisammāsambodhiniyatatā, taṃsamaṅgino ca purisavisesā. Pabhedo
analyzed: kicca mahanta tāya phala mahanta tāya ānisaṃsa mahanta tāya ca sīlakkhandhassa mahanta bhāvaḥ  veditabbaḥ tattha hetu alobha ādayaḥ paccayaḥ hira uttappa saddhā sati vīriya ādayaḥ nissayo  sāvaka bodhi pacceka bodhi sammāsambodhi niyata tā tad samaṅginaḥ ca purisa visesā pabhedaḥ
translated: The greatness of the virtue aggregate should be understood as to cause, as to root cause, as to condition, as to support, as to classification, as to function, and as to benefit.

original: cārittavārittādivibhāgo. Kiccaṃ tadaṅgādivasena paṭipakkhavidhamanaṃ. Ānisaṃso piyamanāpatādi.🔽Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana visuddhimagge, ākaṅkheyyasuttādīsu ca āgatanayeneva
analyzed: cāritta vāritta ādi vibhāgaḥ kiccam tad aṅga ādi vasena paṭipakkha vidhamanam ānisaṃsaḥ piya manāpata ādi  ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana visuddhi magge ākaṅkheyya sutta ādīsu ca āgata nayena iva
translated: Herein, the cause is non-greed, etc., The root cause is non-greed, etc., and the support is conscience and shame. The condition is faith, mindfulness, and energy. The support is the certainty of the disciple vehicle, the individual vehicle, and the supreme vehicle, and the distinction of persons who possess that . The classification is the division into virtue of undertaking, virtue of restraint, etc. The function is the warding off of opposing qualities by means of the factors of conversion, etc. The benefit is the attainment of the kinds of supernormal power, etc., and the states beginning with the freedom of mind by avoidance of indulgence in and reaction to sense desires.🔽This is the brief treatment of the matter here. The detailed explanation should be understood according to the method stated in the Visuddhimagga and in the Ākaṅkheyya Sutta, etc.🔽And the greatness of the concentration aggregate, etc., should be understood in the appropriate way in detail according to this method.

original: veditabbo. Iminā nayena samādhikkhandhādīnampi mahantatā yathārahaṃ vitthāretvā veditabbā.🔽Ṭhānāṭhānānaṃ pana mahāvisayatāya, sā bahudhātukasutte āgatanayena veditabbā. Vihārasamāpattiyo
analyzed: veditabbaḥ iminā nayena samādhi kkhandha ādīnam pi mahanta tā yathāraham vitthāretvā veditabbā 🔽ṭhānāṭhānānam pana mahā visaya tāya sā bahudhātukasutte āgata nayena veditabbā vihāra samāpattiyaḥ
translated: But the bases and their objects are to be understood according to the method stated in the Bahudhātuka Sutta .🔽The jhānas and the supernormal powers

original: samādhikkhandhaniddhāraṇanayena veditabbā. Ariyasaccānaṃ sakalasāsanasaṅgahato, so
analyzed: samādhi kkhandha niddhāraṇa nayena veditabbā ariya saccānam sakala sāsana saṅgahato so
translated: It should be understood by the method of the determination of the aggregate of concentration.🔽The four noble Truths are great because of the inclusion of the entire dispensation.🔽They are great because of the method of the exposition of the four noble Truths, the method of the exposition of the four foundations of mindfulness, and the method of the exposition of the four fruits of recluseship.

original: saccavibhaṅga- taṃsaṃvaṇṇanāsu āgatanayena, satipaṭṭhānā dīnaṃ satipaṭṭhānavibhaṅgādīsu,
analyzed: sacca vibhaṅga tad saṃvaṇṇanāsu āgata nayena sati paṭṭhānāḥ dīnam sati paṭṭhāna vibhaṅga ādīsu
translated: The four foundations of mindfulness are great because of the method of the exposition of the four foundations of mindfulness, etc.🔽The four fruits of recluseship are great because of the production of the great benefit, the great happiness, the great welfare, and the great security.

original: taṃsaṃvaṇṇanāsu ca āgatanayena, sāmaññaphalānaṃ mahato hitassa, mahato sukhassa,🔽mahato atthassa, mahato yogakkhemassa nibbattibhāvato, santapaṇītanipuṇaatakkāvacarapaṇḍitavedanīyabhāvato🔽ca; abhiññānaṃ mahāsambhārato, mahāvisayato, mahākiccato, mahānubhāvato, mahānibbattito
analyzed: tad saṃvaṇṇanāsu ca āgata nayena sāmañña phalānam mahataḥ hitassa mahataḥ sukhassa  mahataḥ atthassa mahataḥ yogakkhemassa nibbatti bhāvataḥ santa paṇīta nipuṇa a takkāvacara paṇḍita vedanīya bhāvataḥ  ca abhiññānam mahā sambhārataḥ mahā visayataḥ mahā kiccataḥ mahā anubhāvataḥ mahā nibbattito
translated: They are great because of the state of being to be experienced by the wise who are peaceful, sublime, subtle, and beyond reasoning.🔽The eight kinds of direct knowledge are great because of the great equipment, the great domain, the great function, the great influence, and the great production.

original: ca, nibbānassa madanimmadanādimahattasiddhito mahantatā veditabbā.
analyzed: ca nibbānassa mada nimmadana ādi mahat ta siddhitaḥ mahanta tā veditabbā
translated: Nibbana is great because of the establishment of the greatness of the state of being the supreme, the excellent, the distinguished, the sublime, the auspicious, the security, the refuge, the unsurpassed, the unsurpassable, the guide, the leader, the forerunner, the overlord, the goal, the ultimate, the auspicious, the auspicious supreme, the auspicious unsurpassed, the auspicious beyond reasoning, the auspicious beyond reasoning supreme, the auspicious beyond reasoning unsurpassed, the auspicious beyond reasoning beyond reasoning, the auspicious beyond reasoning beyond reasoning supreme, the auspicious beyond reasoning beyond reasoning unsurpassed, the auspicious beyond reasoning beyond reasoning beyond reasoning, the auspicious beyond reasoning beyond reasoning beyond reasoning supreme, and the auspicious beyond reasoning beyond reasoning beyond reasoning unsurpassed.

original: Puthupaññāti etthāpi vuttanayānusārena attho veditabbo. Ayaṃ pana viseso – nānākhandhesu🔽ñāṇaṃ pavattatīti “ayaṃ rūpakkhandho nāma…pe… ayaṃ viññāṇakkhandho nāmā”ti evaṃ pañcannaṃ
analyzed: puthu paññā ti ettha api vutta naya anusārena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ayam pana visesaḥ nānā khandhesu 🔽ñāṇam pavattati iti ayam rūpa kkhandho nāma pe ayam viññāṇa kkhandho nāma ati evam pañcannam
translated: “Varied wisdom”: the meaning should be understood in the way already stated. But there is this difference: knowledge occurs in the various aggregates.

original: khandhānaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ pavattati. Tesupi “ekavidhena rūpakkhandho,
analyzed: khandhānam nānākaraṇam paṭicca ñāṇam pavattati tesu pi ekavidhena rūpakkhandho
translated: And in regard to these aggregates, knowledge occurs contingent upon the diversity of their individual characteristics, as follows: “The materiality aggregate is of one kind;

original: ekādasavidhena rūpakkhandho. Ekavidhena vedanākkhandho, bahuvidhena vedanākkhandho.
analyzed: ekādasavidhena rūpa kkhandhaḥ ekavidhena vedanā kkhandhaḥ bahuvidhena vedanā kkhandhaḥ
translated: the materiality aggregate is of eleven kinds. The feeling aggregate is of one kind; the feeling aggregate is of many kinds.

original: Ekavidhena saññākkhandho. Ekavidhena saṅkhārakkhandho. Ekavidhena viññāṇakkhandho,
analyzed: ekavidhena saññā kkhandhaḥ ekavidhena saṅkhāra kkhandhaḥ ekavidhena viññāṇa kkhandhaḥ
translated: The perception aggregate is of one kind; the formations aggregate is of one kind; the consciousness aggregate is of one kind;

original: bahuvidhena viññāṇakkhandho”ti evaṃ ekekassa khandhassa atītādibhedavasenāpi nānākaraṇaṃ
analyzed: bahuvidhena viññāṇa kkhandho ti evam ekekassa khandhassa atīta ādi bheda vasena api nānākaraṇam
translated: the consciousness aggregate is of many kinds.” And knowledge occurs contingent upon the diversity of their past and future states, etc.,

original: paṭicca ñāṇaṃ pavattati. Tathā “idaṃ cakkhāyatanaṃ nāma…pe...idaṃ dhammāyatanaṃ nāma.
analyzed: paṭicca ñāṇam pavattati tathā idam cakkhāyatanam nāma pe idam dhammāyatanam nāma
translated: as follows: “This is the eye base … This is the mental-data base.

original: Tattha dasāyatanā kāmāvacarā, dve catubhūmakā”ti evaṃ āyatanānaṃ nānattaṃ paṭicca
analyzed: tattha dasa āyatanā kāmāvacarā dve evam āyatanānam nānattam paṭicca
translated: Herein, ten bases are of the sense sphere; two are of four planes.” Thus knowledge occurs contingent upon the diversity of the bases.

original: ñāṇaṃ pavattati. Nānādhātūsūti “ayaṃ cakkhudhātu nāma…pe… ayaṃ manoviññāṇadhātu nāma.
analyzed: ñāṇam pavattati nānā dhātūsu iti ayam cakkhu dhātu nāma pe ayam manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu nāma
translated: As regards the diversity of the elements: “This is the eye element … This is the mind-consciousness element.

original: Tattha soḷasa dhātuyo kāmāvacarā, dve dhātuyo catubhūmikā”ti evaṃ nānādhātūsu ñāṇaṃ
analyzed: tattha soḷasa dhātuyaḥ kāmāvacarāḥ dve dhātuyaḥ catu bhūmikā ati evam nānā dhātūsu ñāṇam
translated: Herein, sixteen elements are of the sense sphere; two elements are of four planes.” Thus knowledge occurs contingent upon the diversity of the elements.

original: pavattati, tayidaṃ upādinnakadhātuvasena vuttaṃ. Paccekabuddhānampi hi dvinnañca
analyzed: pavattati tayā idam upādinnaka dhātu vasena vuttam paccekabuddhānam pi hi dvinnam ca
translated: This is said with reference to the aggregates that are clung to. For the Paccekabuddhas and the Buddhas have no aggregates that are clung to.

original: aggasāvakānaṃ upādinnakadhātūsu evaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ pavattati, tañca kho
analyzed: aggasāvakānam upādinnaka dhātūsu evam nānākaraṇam paṭicca ñāṇam pavattati tat ca kho
translated: This is said with reference to the aggregates of clinging. For the knowledge of the Paccekabuddhas and the two chief disciples also occurs in this way with reference to the aggregates of clinging of others.

original: ekadesatova, na nippadesato. Anupādinnakadhātūnaṃ pana lakkhaṇādimattameva jānanti,
analyzed: eka desataḥ va na nippadesataḥ anupādinnaka dhātūnam pana lakkhaṇa ādimattam eva jānanti
translated: But that knowledge occurs only partially, not exhaustively. They know only the mere characteristics of the aggregates of non-clinging,

original: na nānākaraṇaṃ. Sabbaññubuddhānameva pana “imāya nāmadhātuyā ussannattā imassa rukkhassa
analyzed: na nānākaraṇam sabbaññu buddhānam eva pana imāya nāmadhātuyā ussanna ttā imassa rukkhassa
translated: but not their diversity. Only the omniscient Buddhas know the diversity of the aggregates of clinging and the aggregates of non-clinging.

original: khandho seto, imassa kāḷo, imassa maṭṭho, imassa bahalattaco, imassa tanutaco. Imassa
analyzed: khandho seto imassa kāḷaḥ imassa maṭṭho imassa bahalattacaḥ imassa tanutacaḥ imassa
translated: “In this tree the trunk is white because of the predominance of this element, this one is black, this one is smooth, this one has thick bark, this one has thin bark.

original: pattaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādivasena evarūpaṃ. Imassa pupphaṃ nīlaṃ, imassa pītakaṃ, lohitakaṃ,
analyzed: pattam vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādi vasena evarūpam imassa puppham nīlam imassa pītakam lohitakam
translated: This one’s leaves are of such and such a colour, shape, etc. This one’s flowers are blue, yellow, red, white, fragrant, odourless,

original: odātaṃ, sugandhaṃ, duggandhaṃ. Phalaṃ khuddakaṃ, mahantaṃ, dīghaṃ, vaṭṭaṃ, susaṇṭhānaṃ,🔽dussaṇṭhānaṃ, maṭṭhaṃ, pharusaṃ, sugandhaṃ, duggandhaṃ, madhuraṃ, tittakaṃ, ambilaṃ,
analyzed: odātam sugandham duggandham phalam khuddakam mahantam dīgham vaṭṭam su saṇṭhānam 🔽dussaṇṭhānam maṭṭham pharusam sugandham duggandham madhuram tittakam ambilam
translated: This one’s fruit is small, large, long, round, well-shaped, ill-shaped, smooth, rough, fragrant, odourless, sweet, sour, bitter,

original: kaṭukaṃ, kasāvaṃ. Kaṇṭako tikhiṇo, atikhiṇo, ujuko, kuṭilo, kaṇho, nīlo, odāto hotī”ti
analyzed: kaṭukam kasāvam kaṇṭakaḥ tikhiṇaḥ atikhiṇaḥ ujukaḥ kuṭilaḥ kaṇhaḥ nīlaḥ odātaḥ hoti iti
translated: and bitter, and astringent. The thorn is sharp, very sharp, straight, crooked, black, blue, white.

original: dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ pavattati.
analyzed: dhātu nānattam paṭicca ñāṇam pavattati
translated: Knowledge occurs in regard to the variety of elements.

original: Nānāpaṭiccasamuppādesūti ajjhattabahiddhābhedato ca nānāpabhedesu paṭiccasamuppādaṅgesu.🔽Avijjādiaṅgāni hi paccekaṃ paṭiccasamuppādasaññitāni. Tenāha saṅkhārapiṭake “dvādasa
analyzed: nānā paṭiccasamuppādesu iti ajjhatta bahiddhā bhedato ca nānā apabhedesu paṭiccasamuppāda aṅgesu  avijjā ādi aṅgāni hi paccekam paṭiccasamuppāda saññitāni tena āha saṅkhārapiṭake dvādasa
translated: In the various kinds of dependent origination: in the various kinds of factors of dependent origination distinguished as internal and external.🔽For each of the factors beginning with ignorance is called dependent origination. Hence it is said in the Paṭiccasamuppāda Paṭṭhāna: “Twelve conditions, twelve kinds of dependent origination” .

original: paccayā dvādasa paṭiccasamuppādā”ti. Nānāsuññatamanupalabbhesūti nānāsabhāvesu niccasārādivirahitesu
analyzed: paccayāḥ dvādasa paṭiccasamuppādā ati nānā suññatama anupalabbhesu nānā sabhāvesu nicca sāra ādi virahitesu
translated: In the various kinds of voidness, in the various kinds of void states devoid of permanence, substantiality, etc.🔽In the various kinds of non-apprehension, in the various kinds of things that are not apprehended as female, male, soul, etc.🔽The letter ma is used here to connect the words.

original: suññatabhāvesu tato eva itthipurisaattattaniyādivasena anupalabbhanasabhāvesu pakāresu.🔽Ma-kāro hettha padasandhikaro. Nānāatthesūti atthapaṭisambhidāya visayabhūtesu paccayuppannādivasena
analyzed: suññata bhāvesu tatas eva itthi purisa attatta niya ādi vasena anupalabbhana sabhāvesu pakāresu  makāraḥ ha ittha pada sandhi karaḥ nānā atthesu ti attha paṭisambhidāya visaya bhūtesu paccaya uppanna ādi vasena
translated: In the various kinds of meanings: in the various kinds of meanings such as the conditioned, etc., which are the domain of the discernment of meaning .

original: nānāvidhesu atthesu. Dhammesūti dhammapaṭisambhidāya visayabhūtesu paccayādivasena
analyzed: nānāvidhesu atthesu dhammesu ti dhamma paṭisambhidāya visaya bhūtesu paccaya ādi vasena
translated: In the various kinds of dhammas: in the various kinds of dhammas such as the conditions, etc., which are the domain of the discernment of dhammas .

original: nānāvidhesu dhammesu. Niruttīsūti tesaṃyeva atthadhammānaṃ niddhāraṇavacanasaṅkhātesu🔽nānāniruttīsu. Paṭibhānesūti atthapaṭisambhidādīsu visayabhūtesu “imāni ñāṇāni idamatthajotakānī”ti
analyzed: nānāvidhesu dhammesu tesam yeva attha dhammānam niddhāraṇa vacana saṅkhātesu  nānā niruttīsu paṭibhānesu uti attha paṭisambhidā ādīsu visaya bhūtesu imāni ñāṇāni idam attha jotakāni iti
translated: In the various ideas. In the various kinds of phrasing: in the various kinds of phrasing called words of definition for those same ideas and meanings.

original: tathā tathā paṭibhānato upatiṭṭhanato “paṭibhānānī”ti laddhanāmesu nānāñāṇesu. “Puthunānāsīlakkhandhesū”tiādīsu
analyzed: tathā tathā paṭibhānataḥ upatiṭṭhanataḥ paṭibhānāni iti laddha nāmesu nānā ñāṇesu puthu nānā sīla kkhandhesu utiādīsu
translated: In the various kinds of expression: in the various kinds of knowledge called “expressions” because they are established by being expressed thus and thus in the various kinds of object consisting of the discernment of meaning, etc., as “These kinds of knowledge illuminate this meaning” .

original: sīlassa puthuttaṃ vuttameva, itaresaṃ pana vuttanayānusārena suviññeyyattā pākaṭameva.
analyzed: sīlassa puthuttam vuttam eva itaresam pana vutta naya anusārena su viññeyya ttā pākaṭam eva
translated: In the various kinds of aggregates of virtue, etc.: here the virtue’s variety has already been stated. But the others’ is evident since it is easily understood by the method already stated.

original: Yaṃ pana abhinnaṃ ekameva nibbānaṃ, tattha upacāravasena puthuttaṃ gahetabbanti āha
analyzed: yam pana abhinnam ekam eva nibbānam tattha upacāra vasena puthuttam gahetabban ti āha
translated: But the ununified extinction is to be taken as variety by way of the conventional usage there, which is why he said

original: “puthujjanasādhāraṇe dhamme samatikkammā”ti, tenassa madanimmadanādipariyāyena puthuttaṃ paridīpitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: puthujjana sādhāraṇe dhamme samatikkamma ati tena assa mada nimmadana ādi pariyāyena puthuttam paridīpitam hoti
translated: “having completely surpassed the ideas shared by worldlings” . So its variety is demonstrated by the method of “intoxicant-free” , etc.

original: Evaṃ visayavasena paññāya mahattaṃ, puthuttaṃ dassetvā idāni sampayuttadhammavasena
analyzed: evam visaya vasena paññāya mahattam puthuttam dassetvā idāni sampayutta dhamma vasena
translated: Having thus shown the greatness and variety of understanding by way of its object, he now shows it by way of the states associated with it.

original: hāsabhāvaṃ, pavattiākāravasena javanabhāvaṃ, kiccavasena tikkhādibhāvaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: hāsa bhāvam pavatti ākāra vasena javana bhāvam kicca vasena tikkha ādi bhāvam dassetum
translated: and the state of laughter, the state of impulsion by way of the mode of its occurrence, and the state of sharpness, etc., by way of its function.

original: “katamā hāsapaññā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha hāsabahuloti pītibahulo. Sesapadāni tasseva
analyzed: katamā hāsa paññā iti ādi vuttam tattha hāsa bahulo ti pīti bahulo sesa padāni tassa eva
translated: “What is laughing wisdom?” and so on is said in order to show these. Herein, having much laughter means having much joy. The other terms are synonyms for that.

original: vevacanāni. Sīlaṃ paripūretīti haṭṭhapahaṭṭho udaggudaggo hutvā ṭhapetvā indriyasaṃvaraṃ🔽tassa visuṃ vuttattā anavasesasīlaṃ paripūreti. Pītisomanassasahagatā hi paññā abhirativasena
analyzed: vevacanāni sīlam paripūreti iti haṭṭha pahaṭṭhaḥ udagga udaggaḥ hutvā ṭhapetvā indriya saṃvaram  tassa visum vutta ttā anavasesa sīlam paripūreti pīti somanassa sahagatā hi paññā abhirati vasena
translated: Fulfills virtue means that being elated, uplifted, and joyful, he fulfills virtue without exception,🔽apart from the virtue of restraint of the sense faculties, because that is mentioned separately.🔽For wisdom accompanied by joy and happiness occurs in regard to the object as if it were expanded and unfolded by over-flowing,🔽but not so that accompanied by equanimity.

original: ārammaṇe phullitavikasitā viya pavattati, na evaṃ upekkhāsahagatā. Puna sīlakkhandhanti
analyzed: ārammaṇe phullita vikasitā viya pavattati na evam upekkhā sahagatā puna
translated: Again, virtue means

original: ariyasīlakkhandhamāha. “Samādhikkhandha”ntiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: ariya sīla kkhandham āha samādhi khandha nti ādīsu pi esā iva nayo
translated: he says the aggregate of noble virtue. The same method applies in the case of the aggregates of concentration,🔽wisdom, and deliverance.

original: Sabbaṃ taṃ rūpaṃ aniccato khippaṃ javatīti yā rūpadhamme “aniccā”ti sīghavegena pavattati,
analyzed: sabbam tat rūpam aniccataḥ khippam javati iti yā rūpa dhamme aniccā ati sīgha vegena pavattati
translated: All that materiality is quickly impulsioned as impermanent means that which occurs rapidly and swiftly in regard to material dhammas as “impermanent”

original: paṭipakkhadūrabhāvena pubbābhisaṅkhārassa sātisayattā indena vissaṭṭhavajiraṃ viya
analyzed: paṭipakkha dūra bhāvena pubba abhisaṅkhārassa sa atisaya ttā indena vissaṭṭha vajiram viya
translated: because of the great intensity of the prior volition due to the remoteness of the opposite. Like a cart drawn by a pair of oxen,

original: lakkhaṇaṃ avirajjhantī adandhāyantī rūpakkhandhe aniccalakkhaṇaṃ vegasā paṭivijjhati,
analyzed: lakkhaṇam a virajjhantī a dandhāyantī rūpa kkhandhe anicca lakkhaṇam vegasā paṭivijjhati
translated: She penetrates the characteristic of impermanence in the materiality aggregate by way of the impulsion of insight.

original: sā javanapaññā nāmāti attho. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Evaṃ lakkhaṇārammaṇikavipassanāvasena
analyzed: sā javana paññā nāma ati attho sesa padesu pi esā iva nayaḥ evam lakkhaṇa ārammaṇika vipassanā vasena
translated: The meaning is that she has the kind of understanding that is called “impulsion.” The same method of explanation applies to the other terms.

original: javanapaññaṃ dassetvā balavavipassanāvasena dassetuṃ “rūpa”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: javana paññam dassetvā balava vipassanā vasena dassetum rūpa nti ādi vuttam tattha
translated: Having thus shown the kind of understanding that is called “impulsion” by means of insight that has the characteristics as its object, he now said “Rūpa” in order to show it by means of strong insight.

original: khayaṭṭhenāti yattha yattha uppajjati, tattha tattheva bhijjanato khayasabhāvattā.🔽Bhayaṭṭhenāti bhayānakabhāvato. Asārakaṭṭhenāti asārakabhāvato attasāravirahato,🔽niccasārādivirahato ca. Tulayitvāti tulanabhūtāya vipassanāpaññāya tuletvā. Tīrayitvāti🔽tāya eva tīraṇabhūtāya tīrayitvā. Vibhāvayitvāti yāthāvato pakāsetvā paccakkhaṃ katvā.
analyzed: khaya ṭṭhena ati yattha yattha uppajjati tattha tattha iva bhijjanataḥ khaya sabhāva tā  bhaya ṭṭhena ati bhayānaka bhāvataḥ asāraka ṭṭhena ati asāraka bhāvataḥ atta sāra virahato  nicca sāra ādi virahato ca tulayitvā iti tulana bhūtāya vipassanā paññāya tuletvā tīrayitvā ati  tāya eva tīraṇa bhūtāya tīrayitvā vibhāvayitvā ati yāthāvataḥ pakāsetvā paccakkham katvā
translated: Herein, as to the meaning of destruction: because of the nature of destruction, since it is destroyed where it arises.🔽As to the meaning of terror: because of its terrifying nature. As to the meaning of insubstantiality: because of its unsubstantial nature, because of the absence of a substantial self,

original: Vibhūtaṃ katvāti pākaṭaṃ katvā. Rūpanirodheti rūpakkhandhanirodhahetubhūte nibbāne
analyzed: vibhūtam katvā ati pākaṭam katvā rūpa nirodha iti rūpa kkhandha nirodha hetu bhūte nibbāne

As to the meaning of slavery: because of the nature of slavery, since it is slavery. As to the meaning of change: because of the nature of change, since it changes. As to the meaning of emptiness: because of the nature of emptiness, since it is empty. As to the meaning of voidness: because of the nature of voidness, since it is void. original: ninnapoṇapabbhārabhāvena. Idāni sikhāppattavipassanāvasena javanapaññaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: ninna poṇa pabbhāra bhāvena idāni sikhāppatta vipassanā vasena javana paññam dassetuṃ

analyzed: puna rūpa ntiādi vuttam vuṭṭhāna gāmini vipassanā vasena ati keci
translated: “Rūpa” and so on is said. “By way of the insight that leads to emergence” some say.

original: Ñāṇassa tikkhabhāvo nāma savisesaṃ paṭipakkhapahānena veditabboti. “Khippaṃ kilese
analyzed: ñāṇassa tikkha bhāvaḥ nāma sa visesam paṭipakkha pahānena veditabbaḥ ti khippam kilese
translated: The sharpness of knowledge is to be understood by the complete abandoning of its opposite. “It cuts off the defilements quickly,

analyzed: chindati iti tikkha paññā iti vatvā te pana kilese vibhāgena dassentaḥ uppannam kāma vitakka nti ādim āha
translated: therefore it is sharp knowledge” is said. But in order to show those defilements in detail, he said “arisen sensual thought” and so on.

original: Tikkhapañño khippābhiñño hoti, paṭipadā cassa na calatīti āha “ekasmiṃ āsane cattāro
analyzed: tikkha paññaḥ khippa abhiññaḥ hoti paṭipadā cassa na calati iti āha ekasmim āsane cattāro
translated: One who has sharp knowledge has quick direct-knowledge, and his practice does not waver, therefore he said “in one seat the four noble paths …

analyzed: ariya magga āpe adhigatāḥ honti itiādi
translated: are attained” and so on.

analyzed: sabbe saṅkhārā aniccāḥ dukkhāḥ vipariṇāma dhammā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khaya dhammā
translated: “All formations are impermanent, painful, and subject to change; they are conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction,

original: vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā”ti yāthāvato dassanena saccappaṭivedho ijjhati,
analyzed: vaya dhammāḥ virāga dhammāḥ nirodha dhammāḥ ti yāthāvataḥ dassanena sacca ppaṭivedho ijjhati
translated: subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation,” the penetration of the truths by the way of seeing as they really are succeeds,

original: na aññathāti kāraṇamukhena nibbedhikapaññaṃ dassetuṃ “sabbasaṅkhāresu ubbegabahulo
analyzed: na aññathā ti kāraṇa mukhena nibbedhika paññam dassetum sabba saṅkhāresu ubbega bahulo
translated: “Not otherwise” : in order to show penetrative understanding by way of cause, it is said: “He becomes one who frequently experiences dread in regard to all formations. ”

original: hotī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ubbegabahuloti vuttanayena sabbasaṅkhāresu abhiṇhapavattasaṃvego.
analyzed: hoti itiādi vuttam tattha ubbega bahulaḥ ti vutta nayena sabba saṅkhāresu abhiṇha pavatta saṃvegaḥ
translated: Herein, he becomes one who frequently experiences dread means he frequently experiences the urgency of the matter in regard to all formations in the way stated.

analyzed: uttāsa bahulo ti ñāṇa uttāsa vasena sabba saṅkhāresu bahusas etena ādīnava anupassanam āha
translated: He becomes one who frequently experiences fear means he frequently experiences fear in regard to all formations by way of the fear of knowledge. By this he shows the contemplation of danger.
