translated: But by “one who frequently experiences disgust” he shows the contemplation of dispassion. By “one who frequently experiences dispassion” and so on he shows the successive arising of that.🔽He becomes one who frequently turns away means he becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations. He becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations means he becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations by way of the contemplation of disenchantment.🔽He becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations means he becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations by way of the contemplation of disenchantment.

original: tathā vā pavattitavimokkhamukho. Nibbijjhanaṃ nibbedho, so etissā atthi, nibbijjhatīti
analyzed: tathā vā pavattita vimokkha mukhaḥ nibbijjhanam nibbedhaḥ saḥ etissā atthi nibbijjhati iti
translated: He becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations means he becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations by way of the contemplation of disenchantment.🔽He becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations means he becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations by way of the contemplation of disenchantment.🔽He becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations means he becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations by way of the contemplation of disenchantment.🔽He becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations means he becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations by way of the contemplation of disenchantment.🔽He becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations means he becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations by way of the contemplation of disenchantment.🔽He becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations means he becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations by way of the contemplation of disenchantment.🔽He becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations means he becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations by way of the contemplation of disenchantment.🔽He becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations means he becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations by way of the contemplation of disenchantment.

original: vā nibbedhikā, sā eva paññā nibbedhikapaññā. Yaṃ panettha atthato avibhattaṃ, taṃ🔽heṭṭhā vuttanayattā, uttānatthattā ca suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: vā nibbedhikā sā eva paññā nibbedhika paññā yam pana ittha atthataḥ a vibhattam tam 🔽heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā uttāna attha ttā ca su viññeyyam eva
translated: He becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations means he becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations by way of the contemplation of disenchantment.🔽He becomes one who frequently turns away from all formations means he

original: 217. Pabbajitaṃ upāsitāti ettha yādisaṃ pabbajitaṃ upāsato paññāpaṭilābho hoti, taṃ
analyzed: pabbajitam upāsitā ti ettha yādisam pabbajitam upāsato paññā paṭilābhaḥ hoti tam
translated: “One who has gone forth and is served” : in order to show what kind of one who has gone forth should be served so that one may attain understanding,

original: dassetuṃ “paṇḍitaṃ pabbajita”nti vuttaṃ. Upāsanañcettha upaṭṭhānavasena icchitaṃ,
analyzed: dassetum paṇḍitam pabbajitan ti vuttam upāsanam ca ittha upaṭṭhāna vasena icchitam
translated: it is said, “a wise one who has gone forth.” And here the service is intended as attendance,

original: na upanisīdanamattenāti āha “payirupāsitā”ti. Atthanti hitaṃ. Abbhantaraṃ karitvāti
analyzed: na upanisīdana mattena ati āha payiḥ upāsitā ati hitam abbhantaram karitvā iti
translated: not merely sitting in his presence. Therefore it is said, “one who has been served.” “Meaning” is benefit. “Having made it one’s own” means having made it one’s own inner possession.

original: abbhantaragataṃ katvā. Tenāha “atthayutta”nti. Bhāvanapuṃsakaniddeso cāyaṃ, hitūpasañhitaṃ
analyzed: abbhantara gatam katvā tena āha attha yuttam ti bhāva napuṃsaka niddeso ca ayam hitu upasañhitam
translated: Therefore it is said, “one who is devoted to the meaning.” And this is a masculine substantive in the locative case. The meaning is, “having made it connected with benefit.”

original: katvāti attho. Antara-saddo vā cittapariyāyo “yassantarato na santi kopā”tiādīsu🔽viya. Tasmā atthantaroti hitajjhāsayoti attho.🔽Paṭilābhatthāya gatenāti paṭilābhatthāya pavattena, paṭilābhasaṃvattaniyenāti attho.
analyzed: katvā iti atthaḥ antara saddaḥ vā citta pariyāyaḥ yassa antarataḥ na santi kopa ati ādīsu  viya tasmai atthantarā ati  paṭilābha tthāya gatena ati paṭilābha tthāya pavattena paṭilābha saṃvattaniyena ati attho
translated: Or the word “meaning” is a synonym for “mind,” as in such passages as “There are no agitations in his mind” .🔽Therefore “one who has a different meaning” means one who has a beneficial disposition.🔽“One who has gone forth for the sake of attainment” means one who has gone forth for the sake of attaining, one who is devoted to the attainment of, the meaning.

original: Uppāde ca nimitte ca chekāti uppādavidhimhi ceva nimittavidhimhi ca kusalā. Uppādanimittakovidatāsīsena
analyzed: uppāde ca nimitte ca uppāda vidhimhi ca iva nimitta vidhimhi ca kusalāḥ uppāda nimitta kovida tā sīsena
translated: “Skilled in the sign and in the arising” means skilled in the method of arising and skilled in the method of the sign.

original: cettha lakkhaṇakosallameva dasseti. Atha vā sesalakkhaṇānaṃ nibbattiyā buddhānaṃ,🔽cakkavattīnañca uppādo anumīyati, yāni tehi laddhabbaānisaṃsāni nimittāni, tasmiṃ
analyzed: ca ittha lakkhaṇa kosallam eva dasseti atha vā sesa lakkhaṇānam nibbattiyā buddhānam  cakkavattīnam ca uppādaḥ anumīyati yāni tehi laddhabba ānisaṃsāni nimittāni tasmin
translated: Herein, he shows skill in characteristics. Or alternatively, the arising of Buddhas and Wheel-turning Monarchs is inferred from the appearance of the other characteristics, and the signs of the benefits to be obtained by them are inferred from their arising.

original: uppāde ca nimitte ca anuminanādivasena chekā nipuṇāti attho. Ñatvā passissatīti ñāṇena
analyzed: uppāde ca nimitte ca anuminana ādi vasena chekā nipuṇā ati atthaḥ ñatvā passissati iti ñāṇena
translated: And the meaning is that he is clever, skilled, in the inference, etc., of those signs.

original: jānitvā passissati, na cakkhuviññāṇenāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: jānitvā passissati na cakkhu viññāṇena ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: He will see by means of knowledge, not by means of eye-consciousness, is the intention.

original: Atthānusāsanīsūti atthānaṃ hitānaṃ anusāsanīsu. Yasmā anatthapaṭivajjanapubbikā sattānaṃ
analyzed: attha anusāsanīsu iti atthānam hitānam anusāsanīsu yasmai anattha paṭivajjana pubbikā sattānam
translated: In the “advice about benefit” : in the advice about benefits, about what is beneficial.

original: atthapaṭipatti, tasmā anatthopi paricchijja gahetabbo, jānitabbo cāti vuttaṃ “atthānatthaṃ
analyzed: attha paṭipatti tasmai anatthaḥ api paricchijja gahetabbaḥ jānitabbaḥ ca ati vuttam atthānattham
translated: Since the practice of what is beneficial for beings comes about preceded by the avoidance of what is unprofitable, therefore what is unprofitable should be taken as something to be discerned and grasped, and it should be known, is what is said.

original: pariggāhakāni ñāṇānī”ti, yato “āyupāyakosallaṃ viya apāyakosallampi icchitabba”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pariggāhakāni ñāṇāni iti yatas āyu pāya kosallam viya apāya kosallam pi icchitabbam ti vuttam
translated: The kinds of knowledge that discern what is profitable and what is unprofitable are like the skill in profitable means and the skill in unprofitable means, which is why it is said that “skill in unprofitable means should be desired too.”

original: Suvaṇṇavaṇṇalakkhaṇavaṇṇanā🔽218. Paṭisaṅkhānabalena kodhavinayena akkodhano, na bhāvanābalenāti dassetuṃ “na
analyzed: 🔽paṭisaṅkhāna balena kodha vinayena akkodhanaḥ na bhāvanā balena ati dassetum na
translated: The description of the characteristic of golden-coloured skin.

original: anāgāmimaggenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Evaṃ akkodhavasikattāti evaṃ maghamāṇavo viya na kodhavasaṃ🔽gatattā. Nābhisajjīti kujjhanavaseneva na abhisajji. Yañhi kodhassa uppattiṭṭhānabhūte
analyzed: anāgāmi maggena atiādi vuttam evam akkodha vasikattā ati evam magha māṇavaḥ viya na kodha vasam  gata ttā na abhisajji iti kujjhana vasena iva na abhisajji yat hi kodhassa uppatti ṭṭhāna bhūte
translated: So he is not subject to anger, like the young brahmin Magha.

original: ārammaṇe upanāhassa paccayabhūtaṃ kujjhanavasena abhisajjanaṃ, taṃ idhādhippetaṃ,
analyzed: ārammaṇe upanāhassa paccaya bhūtam kujjhana vasena abhisajjanam tat idha adhippetam
translated: He did not attack with anger: he did not attack with anger in the sense of being annoyed. For what is intended here is the attacking with anger in the sense of being annoyed, which is a condition for annoyance in the object that is the occasion for the arising of anger.🔽It is not the attacking in the sense of being greedy. Hence he said “like a twisted creeper” ,

original: na lubbhanavasena. Tenāha “kuṭilakaṇṭako viyā”tiādi. So hi yattha laggati, taṃ khobhento
analyzed: na lubbhana vasena tena āha kuṭilakaṇṭakaḥ viyāti ādi saḥ hi yattha laggati tam khobhento
translated: for a creeper clings by twisting round a tree, shaking it.

original: eva laggati. Tattha tatthāti tasmiṃ tasmiṃ mammaṭṭhāne. Mammanti phuṭṭhamattepi rujjanaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: eva laggati tattha tattha ati tasmim tasmim mamma ṭṭhāne rujjana ṭṭhānam
translated: In this and that place: in this or that place of clinging. Clinging is a place of irritation even when touched lightly.🔽The first-arisen: the first to arise.

original: Pubbuppattikoti paṭhamuppanno. Tato balavataro byāpādo laddhāsevanatāya cittassa🔽byāpajjanato. Tato balavatarā patitthiyanāti sātisayaṃ laddhāsevanatāya tato byāpādāvatthāyapi
analyzed: pubbuppattikaḥ ti paṭhama uppannaḥ tatas balavataraḥ byāpādaḥ laddha āsevana tāya cittassa  tatas balavatarā sa atisayam laddha āsevana tāya tatas
translated: Ill will is stronger than that because of the perversion of the mind that comes from its repeated practice.

original: balavatarā patitthiyanā paccatthikabhāvena thāmappattito.
analyzed: balavatarā patitthiyanā paccatthika bhāvena thāma appattitaḥ
translated: The state of being hostile is stronger than that because of the perversion that comes from its repeated practice, which is stronger than the state of ill will, since it is the attainment of a footing by way of enmity.

original: Sukhumattharaṇādīti ādi-saddena paṇītabhojanīyādīnampi saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo bhojanadānassapi🔽vaṇṇasampadānimittabhāvato. Tenāha bhagavā “bhojanaṃ bhikkhave dadamāno dāyako paṭiggāhakānaṃ…pe…
analyzed: sukhuma tharaṇa ādi iti ādi saddena paṇīta bhojanīya ādīnam pi saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo bhojana dānassa api  vaṇṇa sampadā nimitta bhāvataḥ tena āha bhagavā bhojanam bhikkhave dadamānaḥ dāyakaḥ paṭiggāhakānam pe
translated: “Fine bedding, etc.”: the word “etc.” should be understood to include fine food, etc.,🔽because giving food is a cause for the perfection of beauty.🔽Thus the Blessed One said: “When giving food, a giver gives life, gives beauty, gives strength, gives agility, gives confidence” .

original: āyuṃ deti, vaṇṇaṃ detī”ti tathā ca vakkhati “āmisadānena vā”ti.
analyzed: āyum deti vaṇṇam deti iti tathā ca vakkhati āmisa dānena vāti
translated: And he said: “By giving material things” .🔽“Rain” : a cloud, or Pajjunna himself.

original: 219. Ti adāsi. Devoti megho, pajjunno eva vā. Varataroti uttamataro. Pabbajjāya visadisāvatthādi
analyzed: ti adāsi devo ti megho pajjunno eva vā varataro ti uttamataro pabbajjāya visadisa avattha ādi
translated: “Better” : more excellent.

original: bhāvato na pabbajjāti apabbajjā, gihibhāvo. Acchādenti kopīnaṃ paṭicchādenti etehīti
analyzed: bhāvataḥ na pabbajja ati apabbajjāḥ gihi bhāvaḥ a chādenti kopīnam paṭicchādenti etehi iti
translated: “Not going forth” : the state of a layman, which is different from going forth.🔽“Clothing” : garments, because they cover the private parts.

original: acchādanāni, nivāsanāni, tesaṃ acchādanānañceva sesa vatthānañca kojavādi uttamapāvuraṇānañca.🔽Vināsoti katassa kammassa avipaccitvā vināso.
analyzed: acchādanāni nivāsanāni tesam acchādanānam ca iva sesa vatthānam ca kojava ādi uttama pāvuraṇānam ca  vināsaḥ ti katassa kammassa a vipaccitvā vināsaḥ
translated: “Clothing” : under-garments, because they cover the upper parts of the body.

original: Kosohitavatthaguyhalakkhaṇavaṇṇanā🔽220. Samānetāti sammadeva ānetā samāgametā. Rajje patiṭṭhitena sakkā kātuṃ bahubhatikasseva
analyzed: 🔽samānetā ati sammat eva ānetā samāgametā rajje patiṭṭhitena sakkā kātum bahubhatikassa iva
translated: “Destruction” : the destruction of the result of a deed without its ripening.

original: ijjhanato. Kattā nāma natthīti vajjaṃ paṭicchādentīti ānetvā sambandho, karonti vajjapaṭicchādanakammanti
analyzed: kattā nāma natthi iti vajjam paṭicchādenti iti ānetvā sambandho karonti vajja paṭicchādana kammanti
translated: and by one who is concealing. The construction is: “The doer is not, they conceal the offence” or “They do the action of concealing the offence.”

original: vā. Nanu vajjapaṭicchādanakammaṃ nāma sāvajjanti? Saccaṃ sāvajjaṃ saṃkiliṭṭhacittena
analyzed: vā nanu vajja paṭicchādana kammam nāma sāvajjanti saccam sāvajjam saṃkiliṭṭha cittena
translated: But is not the action of concealing an offence itself blameworthy? It is blameworthy when done by one whose mind is affected by defilement.

original: paṭicchādentassa, idaṃ pana asaṃkiliṭṭhacittena parassa uppajjanakaanatthaṃ pariharaṇavasena🔽pavattaṃ adhippetaṃ. “Ñātisaṅgahaṃ karontenā”ti etena ñātatthacariyāvasena taṃ kammaṃ
analyzed: paṭicchādentassa idam pana asaṃkiliṭṭha cittena parassa uppajjanaka anattham pariharaṇa vasena  pavattam adhippetam ñāti saṅgaham karontena ati etena ñāta attha cariyā vasena tam kammam
translated: But what is intended here is that done by one whose mind is unaffected by defilement, which occurs as a means of preventing the arising of suffering in another.

original: pavattatīti dasseti.
analyzed: pavattati iti dasseti
translated: By the words “One who is doing a favour to his relatives” he shows that the action occurs as a favour to relatives.

original: 221. Amittatāpanāti amittānaṃ tapanasīlā, amittatāpanaṃ hotu vā mā vā evaṃsabhāvāti🔽attho. Na hi cakkavattino puttānaṃ amittā nāma keci honti, ye te bhaveyyuṃ, cakkānubhāveneva
analyzed: amitta tāpanā ati amittānam tapana sīlā amitta tāpanam hotu vā mā vā evaṃsabhāvā ati  atthaḥ na hi cakkavattino puttānam amittāḥ nāma keci honti ye te bhaveyyum cakka anubhāvena iva
translated: “One who is a tormentor of enemies”: one who has the habit of tormenting enemies. The meaning is: whether or not he is a tormentor of enemies, he has that nature.

original: sabbepi khattiyādayo anuvattakā tesaṃ bhavanti.
analyzed: sabbe pi khattiya ādayaḥ anuvattakā tesam bhavanti
translated: For there are no enemies of the Wheel-turning Monarch’s sons, who might become his enemies, since all the nobles, brahmans, etc., become his subjects through the power of the Wheel.

original: Paṭhamabhāṇavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama bhāṇa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the first recitation section is finished.

original: Parimaṇḍalādilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the characteristics beginning with “circular”

original: 222. Samanti samānaṃ. Tena tena loke viññātaguṇena samaṃ samānaṃ jānāti, yato tattha🔽paṭipajjanavidhināva itarasmiṃ paṭipajjati. Sayaṃ jānātīti aparaneyyo hutvā sayameva
analyzed: samanti samānam tena tena loke viññāta guṇena samam samānam jānāti yatas tattha  paṭipajjana vidhinā āvaḥ itarasmin paṭipajjati sayam jānāti iti aparaneyyaḥ hutvā sayam eva
translated: “Equal to” : he knows the equal, the same, of one who is known in the world for his qualities in this or that respect.🔽“He knows” : he is not dependent on others; he knows by himself.

original: jānāti. Purisaṃ jānātīti vā “ayaṃ seṭṭho, ayaṃ majjhimo, ayaṃ nihīno”ti taṃ taṃ purisaṃ🔽yāthāvato jānāti. Purisavisesaṃ jānātīti tasmiṃ tasmiṃ purise vijjamānaṃ visesaṃ
analyzed: jānāti purisam jānāti iti vai ayam seṭṭhaḥ ayam majjhimaḥ ayam nihīnaḥ ti tam tam purisam  yāthāvataḥ jānāti purisa visesam jānāti iti tasmin tasmin purise vijjamānam visesam
translated: “He knows a man” : he knows a man as he really is, whether he is superior, middling, or inferior.

original: jānāti, yato tattha tattha anurūpadānapadānādipaṭipattiyā yuttapattakārī hoti. Tenāha
analyzed: jānāti yatas tattha tattha anurūpa dāna padāna ādi paṭipattiyā yutta patta kārī hoti tena āha
translated: “He knows the difference between men” : he knows the difference that exists in each man, and so he is one who acts appropriately in each instance by giving, by speech, and so on. Thus it is said:

original: “ayamidamarahatī”tiādi.
analyzed: ayam idam arahati itiādi
translated: “He knows what is fitting for each.”

original: Sampattipaṭilābhaṭṭhenāti diṭṭhadhammikādisampattīnaṃ paṭilābhāpanaṭṭhena. Samasaṅgahakammanti samaṃ jānitvā tadanurūpaṃ tassa tassa saṅgaṇhanakammaṃ.
analyzed: sampatti paṭilābha ṭṭhena ati diṭṭhadhammika ādi sampattīnam paṭilābhāpana ṭṭhena sama saṅgaha kammam ti samam jānitvā tad anurūpam tassa tassa saṅgaṇhana kammam
translated: “For the sake of obtaining success” : in the sense of obtaining the kinds of success pertaining to this life, etc. “The act of reconciliation” : the act of reconciling after having known equally.

original: 223. Tulayitvāti tīrayitvā. Paṭivicinitvāti vīmaṃsitvā. Nipuṇayogato nipuṇā, ativiya nipuṇā atinipuṇā, sā pana tesaṃ nipuṇatā saṇhasukhumā paññāti āha “sukhumapaññā”ti.🔽Sīhapubbaddhakāyādilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā🔽224. Khemakāmoti anupaddavakāmo. original: tathā vuttaṃ. Etesanti saddhādīnaṃ. Saha hānadhammenāti sahānadhammo, na sahānadhammoti
analyzed: tathā vuttam etesan ti saddhā ādīnam saha hāna dhammena ati sahāna dhammaḥ na sahāna dhammaḥ iti
translated: So it is said. ‘With them’: with faith, etc.;

original: asahānadhammo, tassa bhāvo asahānadhammatā, taṃ asahānadhammataṃ, aparihāniyasabhāvanti attho.
analyzed: a sahāna dhammaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ a sahāna dhamma tā tam a sahāna dhamma tam a parihāni yasa bhāvanti attho
translated: ‘With no-loss’: no-loss is not-loss; not no-loss is with-loss; the state of that is with-lossness; the meaning is, the state of non-loss.

original: Rasaggasaggitālakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: rasa agga saggi tā lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the characteristic of the taste-retentive-faculty

original: 226. Tilaphalamattampi bhojanaṃ. Sabbattha pharatīti sabbā rasāharaṇiyo anussarantaṃ sabhāvena sabbasmiṃ kāye pharati. Samā hutvā vahantīti avisamā ujukā hutvā pavattanti.
analyzed: tila phala mattam pi bhojanam sabbattha pharati iti sabbāḥ rasāharaṇiyaḥ anussarantam sabhāvena sabbasmin kāye pharati samāḥ hutvā vahanti iti avisamāḥ ujukāḥ hutvā pavattanti
translated: . Food even as little as a sesamum seed: it spreads everywhere: it spreads in the whole body by way of its individual essence, remembering all tastes that are to be tasted. It carries on evenly: it occurs straight, not crooked.

original: Ārogyakaraṇakammanti arogabhāvakaraṃ sattānaṃ aviheṭhanakammaṃ. Madhurādibhedaṃ rasaṃ
analyzed: ārogya karaṇa kammanti aroga bhāva karam sattānam a viheṭhana kammam madhura ādi bhedam rasam
translated: The function of making one healthy: the function of making beings free from affliction, not afflicting them. The taste that is divided into sweet, etc.,

original: gasati harati etehi, sayameva vā taṃ gasanti gilanti anto pavesentīti rasaggasā,
analyzed: gasati harati etehi sayam eva vā tam gasanti gilanti antar pavesenti iti rasaggasā
translated: is retained, is taken away, by these, or these themselves retain, consume, take in, that, thus it is a taste-retainer ;

original: rasaggasānaṃ aggā rasaggasaggā, te ettha santīti rasaggasaggī, tadeva lakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: rasagga sānam aggāḥ rasagga saggā te ettha santi iti rasagga saggī tat eva lakkhaṇaṃ
translated: the best of the taste-retainers is the taste-retainer-best; it is present here, thus it is a taste-retainer-best-er; that is the characteristic.

original: Bhavati hi abhinnepi vatthusmiṃ taggatavisesāvabodhanatthaṃ bhinnaṃ viya katvā vohāro
analyzed: bhavati hi abhinne pi vatthusmim tad gata visesa avabodhana attham bhinnam viya katvā vohāraḥ
translated: For there is usage as if it were made by distinguishing what is not distinguished in order to make known the distinction of the state of being that,🔽just as in the case of the expression “the body of the stone-infant.”

original: yathā “silāputtakassa sarīra”nti. Rasaggasaggitāsaṅkhātaṃ vā lakkhaṇaṃ rasaggasaggilakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: yathā silāputtakassa sarīran ti rasagga saggi tā saṅkhātam vā lakkhaṇam rasagga saggi lakkhaṇam
translated: Or the characteristic called “sharpness of taste and sharpness of edge” is the sharpness of taste and sharpness of edge characteristic.

original: 227. Vadha-saddo “attānaṃ vadhitvā vadhitvā rodatī”tiādīsu bādhanatthopi hotīti tato
analyzed: vadha saddo attānam vadhitvā vadhitvā rodati itiādīsu bādhana tthaḥ api hoti iti tatas
translated: The word “killing” has the meaning of “afflicting” in such passages as “Having killed himself, he cries out, ‘I am killed!’” Therefore,

original: visesanatthaṃ “māraṇavadhenā”ti vuttaṃ, māraṇasaṅkhātena vadhenāti attho. Bādhanattho
analyzed: visesana attham māraṇa vadhena ati vuttam māraṇa saṅkhātena vadhena ati atthaḥ bādhana atthaḥ
translated: in order to distinguish it from that, it is said “by killing for the purpose of killing,” the meaning being “by killing called ‘killing for the purpose of killing.’”

original: eva vā vadha-saddo, māraṇena, bādhanena cāti attho. Ubbādhanāyāti bandhanāgāre pakkhipitvā
analyzed: eva vā vadha saddaḥ māraṇena bādhanena ca ati atthaḥ ubbādhanāya ati bandhanāgāre pakkhipitvā
translated: Or the word “killing” has the meaning of “afflicting.” The meaning is “by killing and by afflicting.”🔽“For the purpose of afflicting” means for the purpose of afflicting by putting in a prison and then

original: uddhaṃ uddhaṃ bādhanena. Tenāha “bandhanāgārappavesanenā”ti.
analyzed: uddham uddham bādhanena tena āha bandhanāgāra ppavesanena ati
translated: afflicting by repeatedly taking out. Therefore it is said “by putting in a prison.”

original: Abhinīlanettādilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā🔽228. Visaṭanti kujjhanavasena vinisaṭaṃ katvā. Tenāha “kakkaṭako viyā”tiādi. Visācīti
analyzed: abhinīla netta ādi lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā 🔽kujjhana vasena vinisaṭam katvā tena āha kakkaṭakaḥ viyāti ādi visācī iti
translated: The description of the characteristic of having eyes that are very dark blue, etc.

original: virūpaṃ sācitakaṃ, vijimhanti attho. Tenāha “vaṅkakkhikoṭiyā”ti, kuṭilaakkhikoṭipātenāti
analyzed: virūpam sācitakam vijimhanti tena āha vaṅkakkhi koṭiyā iti kuṭila akkhi koṭi pātena ati
translated: “Virūpaṃ sācitakaṃ, vijimhanti” means “he looks crookedly, with a crooked glance.”

original: attho. Viceyya pekkhitāti ujukaṃ anoloketvā diṭṭhipātaṃ vicāretvā oloketvā. Tenāha
analyzed: atthaḥ viceyya pekkhitā ti ujukam an oloketvā diṭṭhipātam vicāretvā oloketvā tena āha
translated: Thus he says “vaṅkakkhikoṭiyā” . “Viceyya pekkhitā” means “looking after having considered, after having investigated, the direction of the glance, not looking straight on.”

original: “yo kujjhitvā”tiādi. Paroti kujjhito. Na oloketi taṃ sammukhā gacchantaṃ kujjhitvā
analyzed: yaḥ kujjhitvā atiādi paroti kujjhitaḥ na tam sammukhāḥ gacchantam kujjhitvā
translated: Thus he says “yo kujjhitvā” , etc. “Parā” means “the other.” “Na oloketi taṃ sammukhā gacchantaṃ” means “he does not look at him who is coming straight on, after having become angry with him.”

original: na oloketi, parammukhā. Viteyyāti virūpaṃ tiriyaṃ, viññūnaṃ olokanakkamaṃ vītikkamitvāti
analyzed: na oloketi parammukhā viteyya ati virūpam tiriyam viññūnam olokana kkamam vītikkamitvā ati
translated: “Parammukhā” means “after having turned his face away.” “Viteyya” means “virūpaṃ tiriyaṃ,” “after having gone beyond the range of vision of the wise.”

original: attho. Jimhaṃ anoloketvā ujukaṃ olokanaṃ nāma kuṭilabhāvakarānaṃ pāpadhammānaṃ abhājanaujukatacittatasseva
analyzed: attho jimham an āloketvā ujukam olokanam nāma kuṭila bhāva karānam pāpa dhammānam
translated: Thus is the meaning. “Looking straight on” means looking straight on without looking crookedly, without looking with a crooked glance. It is only for one who is straight in mind, who is not crooked in mind, who is not a receptacle for evil states, that there is looking straight on.

original: hotīti āha “ujumano hutvā ujuṃ pekkhitā”ti. Yathā ca ujuṃ pekkhitā hotīti ānetvā🔽sambandho. Pasaṭanti ummīlanavasena sammadeva patthaṭaṃ. Vipulaṃ vitthatanti tasseva
analyzed: hoti iti āha uju manaḥ hutvā ujum pekkhitā ati yathā ca ujum pekkhitā hoti iti ānetvā  ummīlana vasena sammad eva patthaṭam vipulam tassa iva
translated: Thus he says “ujumano hutvā ujuṃ pekkhitā.” And as to how there is looking straight on, after having brought it,

original: vevacanaṃ. Piyaṃ piyāyitabbaṃ dassanaṃ olokanaṃ etassāti piyadassano.
analyzed: vevacanam piyam piyāyitabbam dassanam olokanam etassa ati piya dassanaḥ
translated: the connection is made. “Pasaṭa” means “patthaṭa” , “firm,” “solid,” by way of opening wide. “Vipulaṃ vitthaṭa” is a synonym for that. “Piyaṃ piyāyitabbaṃ dassanaṃ olokanaṃ etassā” ti piyadassano.

original: Kāṇoti akkhīni nimmīletvā pekkhanako. Kākakkhīti kekarakkho. Vaṅkakkhīti jimhapekkhanako.

translated: One-eyed: one who looks by closing one eye. Crooked-eyed: one who looks by turning the eyes. Squinting: one who looks by turning the head.

original: Āvilakkhīti ākuladiṭṭhipāto. Nīlapītalohitasetakāḷavaṇṇānaṃ vasena pañcavaṇṇo. Tattha

original: “pañcavaṇṇapasādatā tirohitavidūragatadassanasamatthatā”ti evamādi cakkhusampadāya🔽kāraṇāni. Lakkhaṇasatthe yuttāti lakkhaṇasatthe āyuttā sukusalā.

translated: Causes of the perfection of the eye: the causes of the perfection of the eye are stated thus: “The five-coloured clarity, the ability to see what is hidden and what is far away.”

original: 234. Abhinditabbaparisoti parehi kenaci saṅgahena saṅgahetvā, yuttikāraṇaṃ dassetvā vā na bhinditabbapariso.🔽Apisuṇavācāyāti upayogatthe sāmivacanaṃ, pesuññassa paṭipakkhabhūtaṃ kusalakammaṃ.
analyzed: a bhinditabba pariso ti parehi kenacid saṅgahena saṅgahetvā yutti kāraṇam dassetvā vā na bhinditabba pariso  a pisuṇa vācāya ati upayoga atthe sāmi vacanam pesuññassa paṭipakkha bhūtam kusala kammam
translated: “Not to be broken down by others”: a discussion is not to be broken down by others by taking it up with some ulterior motive or by showing a reason.🔽“In the absence of malicious speech”: the possessive adjective “his” is in the locative case in the sense of purpose. The profitable action which is the opposite of malicious speech is the absence of malicious speech.🔽He who has malicious speech is a malicious speaker.

original: Pisuṇā vācā etassāti pisuṇavāco, tassa pisuṇavācassa puggalassa. Aparipuṇṇāti cattārīsato
analyzed: pisuṇā vācā etassa ati pisuṇa vācaḥ tassa pisuṇa vācassa puggalassa a paripuṇṇā ati cattārīsato
translated: “Not complete”: not complete because of being less than forty.

original: ūnabhāvena na paripuṇṇā. Viraḷāti savivarā.🔽Pahūtajivhādilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ūna bhāvena na paripuṇṇā viraḷāti sa vivarā  pahūta jivhā ādi lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: “Not full”: not full because of being without gaps.🔽The explanation of the characteristics of having a long tongue, etc.

original: 236. Ādeyyavācoti ādaragāravavasena ādātabbavacano. “Evameta”nti gahetabbavacano sirasā sampaṭicchitasāsano.
analyzed: ādeyya vācā iti ādara gārava vasena ādātabba vacano evam etat ti gahetabba vacano sirasā sampaṭicchita sāsano
translated: “Worthy of offerings”: worthy of being offered to with respect and deference. “Worthy of hospitality”: worthy of being received with hospitality. “Worthy of gifts”: worthy of being given gifts. “Worthy of reverential salutations”: worthy of being saluted with hands raised in reverential salutation.

original: Baddhajivhāti yathā sukhena parivattati, evaṃ sirādīhi palibuddhajivhā. Gūḷhajivhāti🔽rasabahalatāya gūḷhagaṇḍasadisajivhā. Dvijivhāti agge kappabhāvena dvidhābhūtajivhā.🔽Mammanāti apparippuṭatalāpā. Kharapharusakakkasādivasena saddo bhijjati bhinnakāro🔽hoti. Vicchinditvā pavattassaratāya chinnassarā vā. Anekākāratāya bhinnassarā vā.
analyzed: baddha jivhā iti yathā sukhena parivattati evam sirā ādīhi palibuddha jivhā gūḍha jivhā iti  rasa bahala tāya gūḍha gaṇḍa sadisa jivhā dvi jivhā ati agge kappa bhāvena dvidhā bhūta jivhā  apparippuṭa talāpā khara pharusa kakkasa ādi vasena saddaḥ bhijjati bhinnakāraḥ  hoti vicchinditvā pavatta ssara tāya chinna ssarā vā aneka ākāra tāya bhinna ssarā vā
translated: “Tongue-tied” : his tongue is stiff and cannot move about easily as if it were tied with a string. “ Thick-tongued” : his tongue is thick like a lump of sugar. “ Double-tongued” : his tongue is split at the tip and so is double. “ Twisted” : his tongue is twisted like a rope. “ Rough” : his tongue is rough like a saw. “ Split” : the sound breaks up as he speaks, like the sound of a saw. “ Parted” : the sound is parted as it comes out. “ Split” : the sound is split up because of the many ways in which it is articulated.

original: Kākassa viya amanuññassaratāya kākassarā vā. Madhuroti iṭṭhe, kammaphalena vatthuno🔽suvisuddhattā. Pemanīyoti pītisañjanano, piyāyitabbo vā.🔽237. Akkosayuttattāti akkosupasañhitattā akkosavatthusahitattā. Ābādhakarinti ghaṭṭanavasena🔽paresaṃ pīḷāvahaṃ. Bahuno janassa avamaddanato, pamaddābhāvakaraṇato vā bahujanappamaddanaṃ.
analyzed: kākassa viya amanuñña ssara tāya kākassarā vā madhurā iti iṭṭhe kamma phalena vatthuno 🔽pemanīyaḥ ti pīti sañjananaḥ piyāyitabbaḥ vā 🔽akkosa yutta ttā ati akkosa upasañhita ttā akkosa vatthu sahita ttā ābādha karin ti ghaṭṭana vasena 🔽paresam pīḍā vaham bahunaḥ janassa avamaddanataḥ pamadda abhāva karaṇataḥ vā bahu jana ppamaddanam
translated: “Tongue-tied” : his tongue is tied up with his palate, etc., so that it moves with difficulty. “Thick-tongued” : his tongue is like a lump of sugar cane. “Double-tongued” : his tongue is split at the tip. “Thin-tongued” : his tongue is thin like a leaf. “Crooked-tongued” : his tongue is crooked. “Loud-tongued” : his voice is loud. “Split-tongued” : his voice is split, that is, it breaks up like the sound of a donkey’s bray. “Split-voiced” : his voice is split, that is, it is broken up because it is produced with difficulty. “Crow-voiced” : his voice is unpleasant like the cawing of a crow. “Sweet-voiced” : his voice is agreeable, because his physical basis is well purified by the fruit of kamma. “Charming-voiced” : his voice is delightful, or it causes delight. “Reproach-mixed” : mixed with reproach, associated with reproach, accompanied by reproach. “Disease-causing” : causing affliction to others by striking them. “Causing the loss of confidence of many people” : causing the loss of confidence of many people, or causing the non-arising of confidence.

original: Abāḷhanti vā ettha a-kāro vuddhiattho “asekkhā dhammā”tiādīsu viya, tasmā ativiya🔽bāḷhaṃ pharusaṃ giranti evamettha attho veditabbo. Na bhaṇīti cettha “na abhaṇi na
analyzed: vā ettha akāraḥ vuddhi atthaḥ asekkhāḥ dhammā ati ādīsu viya tasmai ati viya  bāḷham pharusam giranti evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ na bhaṇi iti ca ittha na abhaṇi na
translated: Or else the prefix a- has the sense of excess, as in “asekkhā dhammā” , etc.; so the meaning here should be understood as “they speak very harshly.” “He did not say” : here the negative na is a mere negative, not a prohibition.

original: bhaṇī”ti saralopena niddeso. Susaṃhitanti suṭṭhu saṃhitaṃ. Kena pana suṭṭhu saṃhitaṃ?
analyzed: bhaṇī iti sara lopena niddeso su saṃhitanti suṭṭhu saṃhitam kena pana suṭṭhu saṃhitam
translated: The prefix a- has the sense of excess, as in “non-learners” , etc. Therefore the meaning here should be understood as “they speak very harshly.” The demonstrative pronoun na bhaṇī is formed by the elision of the negative particle na and the verbal noun bhaṇi. Well-composed: well-composed, well-put together. But by what is it well-put together?

original: “Madhura”nti anantarameva vuttattā madhuratāyāti viññāyati, kā panassa madhuratāti
analyzed: madhuranti anantaram eva vutta ttā madhura tāya ati viññāyati kā panassa madhura tā ti
translated: Since “sweetly” is mentioned immediately before, it is understood to be by sweetness. But what is its sweetness?

original: āha “suṭṭhu pemasaṃhita”nti. Upayogaputhuttavisayo yaṃ vācā-saddoti āha “vācāyo”ti,
analyzed: āha suṭṭhu pema saṃhitanti upayoga puthutta visayaḥ yam vācā saddo ti āha vācāya iti
translated: He says, “well-put together with love.” The word vācā is the object of the word upayogaputhutta.

original: sā cassā upayogaputhuttavisayatā “hadayagāminiyo”ti padena samānādhikaraṇatāya daṭṭhabbā.🔽“Kaṇṇasukha”nti pāṭhe bhāvanapuṃsakaniddesoyanti dassetuṃ “yathā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Vedayathāti
analyzed: sā ca ssā upayoga puthutta visaya tā padena samāna adhikaraṇa tāya daṭṭhabbā  kaṇṇa sukham ti pāṭhe bhāva napuṃsaka niddesoyam ti dassetum yathā itiādi vuttam vedayatha ati
translated: And that objectness of the word upayogaputhutta should be seen by the word “going to the heart” in the same case.🔽In the reading “Kaṇṇasukha,” the demonstrative pronoun is masculine. To show this, “yathā” , etc., is said. Vedayathā is the demonstrative pronoun in the present tense.

original: kālavipallāsenāyaṃ niddesoti āha “vedayitthā”ti. Brahmassaratanti seṭṭhassarataṃ,
analyzed: kāla vipallāsena ayam niddeso ti āha vedayittha iti seṭṭhassaratam
translated: Therefore he says “vedayitthā.” Brahmassara means the best sound.

original: brahmuno sarasadisassarataṃ vā. Bahūnaṃ bahunti bahūnaṃ janānaṃ bahuṃ subhaṇitanti yojanā.
analyzed: vā bahūnam bahunti bahūnam janānam yojanā
translated: or like the voice of Brahmā. The construction is: “The much-praised speech of the many.”

original: Sīhahanulakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sīhahanu lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the lion-like characteristic.

original: 238. Appadhaṃsikoti appadhaṃsiyo. Ya-kārassa hi ka-kāraṃ katvā ayaṃ niddeso yathā “niyyānikā dhammā”ti guṇatoti attanā adhigataguṇato. Ṭhānatoti yathāṭhitaṭṭhānantarato.
analyzed: appadhaṃsikaḥ ti appadhaṃsiyaḥ yakārassa hi kakāram katvā ayam niddesaḥ yathā niyyānikāḥ dhammā ti guṇataḥ ti attanā adhigata guṇataḥ ṭhānataḥ ti yathā ṭhita ṭṭhāna antarataḥ
translated: “Not easily broken”: not easily destroyed. For the demonstrative pronoun “this” is used with the substitution of “ka” for “ya,” as in the expression “niyyānikā dhammā.” “In terms of qualities”: in terms of the qualities he has attained. “In terms of place”: in terms of the immediate vicinity of the place where he is standing.

original: Palāpakathāyāti samphappalāpakathāya. Antopaviṭṭhahanukā ekato, ubhato vā saṃkucitavisukā. Vaṅkahanukā ekapassena kuṭilavisukā. Pabbhārahanukā purato olambamānavisukā.
analyzed: palāpa kathāya ati samphappalāpa kathāya anta upaviṭṭha hanukā ekatas ubhatas vā saṃkucita visukā vaṅka hanukā eka passena kuṭila visukā pabbhāra hanukā puratas olambamāna visukā
translated: “In the sense of talk that is mere prattle”: in the sense of talk that is mere frivolous chatter. The mouth is “drawn in” when the lips are closed, or when they are closed on both sides. The mouth is “crooked” when the lips are twisted to one side. The mouth is “hanging down” when the lips hang down in front.

original: 239. Vikiṇṇavacanā nāma samphappalāpino, tappaṭikkhepena avikiṇṇavacanā mahābodhisattā.
analyzed: vikiṇṇavacanāḥ nāma samphappalāpinaḥ tad paṭikkhepena avikiṇṇavacanāḥ mahā bodhisattā
translated: “One whose speech is not scattered” is the Great Bodhisattva, who is not a frivolous chatterer, by the prohibition of frivolous chatter.

original: Vācā eva tadatthādhigamupāyatāya “byāppatho”ti vuttāti āha “avikiṇṇa…pe… vacanapatho
analyzed: vācā eva tad attha adhigama upāya tāya vuttā iti āha avikiṇṇape vacana patho
translated: “The path of speech” is called “byāpātha” because it is the means of attaining the meaning of that.

original: assā”ti. “Dvīhi dvīhī”ti nayidaṃ āmeḍitavacanaṃ asamānādhikaraṇato, atha kho dvīhi
analyzed: assa ati dvīhi dvīhi iti na yidam āmeḍita vacanam a samāna adhikaraṇataḥ atha kho dvīhi
translated: “By twos” is not a reduplication, since it is not in the same construction as “by twos,” but rather it shows the twofoldness.🔽Therefore “by twos” is said to be “by fours,”

original: diguṇatādassananti āha “dvīhi dvīhīti catūhī”ti. Tasmā “dvidugamā”ti catugamā vuttāti🔽āha “catuppadāna”nti. Tathāsabhāvoti yathāssa vuttanayena kenaci appadhaṃsiyatā hoti
analyzed: diguṇa tā dassananti āha dvīhi dvīhi iti catūhi iti tasmā dvi dugamā ati catugamā vuttā ati  āha catu padānam ti tathā sabhāvaḥ ti yathā assa vutta nayena kenaci appadhaṃsiya tā hoti
translated: so he said “by four-footed animals.”

original: guṇehi, tathāsabhāvo.
analyzed: guṇehi tathā sabhāvaḥ
translated: “Of the same nature” means of the same nature as he is in that he is not surpassed by anyone in the special qualities described.

original: Samadantādilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sama danta ādi lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Characteristics of the Teeth, etc.

original: 240. Visuddhasīlācāratāya parisuddhā samantato sabbathā vā suddhā puggalā parivārā etassāti parisuddhaparivāro.
analyzed: visuddha sīla ācāra tāya parisuddhā samantataḥ sabbathā vā suddhā puggalā parivārā etassa ati parisuddha parivāraḥ
translated: He has a pure retinue because of his purified virtue and conduct, since he is pure all round in every way, or since his retinue is pure.

original: 241. Pahāsīti tadaṅgavasena, vikkhambhanavasena ca pariccaji. Tidivaṃ tāvatiṃsabhavanaṃ
analyzed: pahāsi iti tad aṅga vasena vikkhambhana vasena ca pariccaji tidivam tāvatiṃsa bhavanam
translated: He has abandoned them by suppression and by substitution of opposites.

original: puraṃ nagaraṃ etesanti tidivapurā, tāvatiṃsadevā, tesaṃ varo tidivapuravaro, indo.
analyzed: puram nagaram tidiva purā tāvatiṃsa devā tesam varaḥ tidiva pura varaḥ indo
translated: The city of the Thirty-three gods is the city of the Thirty-three. The best of the city of the Thirty-three is the best of the Thirty-three gods.🔽By that best of the city of the Thirty-three. Therefore it is said, “by Sakka.”

original: Tena tidivapuravarena. Tenāha “sakkenā”ti. Lapanti kathenti etenāti lapanaṃ, mukhanti
analyzed: tena tidiva pura varena tena āha sakkena ati lapanti kathenti etena ati lapanam
translated: They chatter, they talk, by this, thus it is chatter. The mouth is the door.

original: āha “lapanajanti mukhaja”nti. Suṭṭhu dhavalatāya sukkā, īsakampi asaṃkiliṭṭhatāya
analyzed: āha lapana janti mukha janti suṭṭhu dhavala tāya a saṃkiliṭṭha tāya
translated: He said: “The mouth-born is the lapanaja.”

original: suci. Sundarasaṇṭhānatāya suṭṭhu bhāvanato, vipassanato ca sobhanā. Kāmaṃ janānaṃ
analyzed: suci sundara saṇṭhāna tāya suṭṭhu bhāvanataḥ vipassanato ca sobhanā kāmam janānam
translated: Because of being very white, it is “white” . Because of being unsoiled even a little, it is “pure” . Because of being very beautiful in shape, it is “beautiful” . Because of being very developed, it is “lovely” . Because of being very developed by insight, it is “lovely” .

original: manussānaṃ nivāsanaṭṭhānādibhāvena patiṭṭhābhūto desaviseso “janapado”ti vuccati,
analyzed: manussānam nivāsana ṭṭhāna ādi bhāvena patiṭṭhā bhūtaḥ desa visesaḥ janapadaḥ ti vuccati
translated: Indeed, a particular country is called “janapada” in the sense of being a place of residence, etc., for people .

original: idha pana saparivāracatumahādīpasaññito sabbo padeso tathā vuttoti āha “cakkavāḷaparicchinno
analyzed: idha pana sa parivāra catu mahā dīpa saññito sabbo padeso tathā vutto ti āha cakkavāḷa paricchinno
translated: But here, the whole region, which is known as the four great continents together with their retinue, is called thus . Therefore, he said: “The region which is surrounded by the Cakkavāḷa” .

original: janapado”ti. Nanu ca yathāvutto padeso samuddaparicchinno, na cakkavāḷapabbataparicchinnoti?🔽So padeso cakkavāḷaparicchinnopi hotīti tathā vuttaṃ. Ye vā samuddanissitā, cakkavāḷapādanissitā
analyzed: janapadaḥ iti nanu ca yathā vuttaḥ padesaḥ samudda paricchinnaḥ na cakkavāḷa pabbata paricchinnaḥ ti  so padeso cakkavāḷa paricchinnaḥ api hoti iti tathā vuttam ye vā samudda nissitā cakkavāḷa pāda nissitā
translated: But is not the region, as it is described, surrounded by the ocean, not by the Cakkavāḷa mountain?🔽That region is also surrounded by the Cakkavāḷa mountain; therefore, it is said thus . Or, those beings who are dependent on the ocean, and those who are dependent on the foot of the Cakkavāḷa mountain,

original: ca sattā, tesaṃ te te padesā patiṭṭhāti tepi saṅgaṇhanto “cakkavāḷaparicchinno”ti
analyzed: ca sattā tesam te te padesā te pi saṅgaṇhanto cakkavāḷa paricchinno ti
translated: their regions are established in those places; including them also, he said: “The region which is surrounded by the Cakkavāḷa” .

original: avoca. Cakkavāḷaparicchinnoti ca cakkavāḷena paricchinnoti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: avoca cakkavāḷa paricchinnaḥ iti ca cakkavāḷena paricchinnaḥ iti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: And the meaning of “the region which is surrounded by the Cakkavāḷa” should be seen thus: “The region which is surrounded by the Cakkavāḷa” .

original: Tassāti tassa cakkavattino. Puna tassāti tassa janapadassa. Bahujana sukhanti ettha
analyzed: tassa ati tassa cakkavattino puna tassa ati tassa janapadassa bahu jana ettha
translated: Tassāti tassa cakkavattino. Puna tassāti tassa janapadassa. Bahujana sukhanti ettha

original: paccattabahuvacanalopena bahujanaggahaṇanti āha “bahujanā”ti. Yathā pana te hitasukhaṃ
analyzed: paccatta bahuvacana lopena bahu jana ggahaṇanti āha bahu jana ati yathā pana te hita sukham
translated: paccattabahuvacanalopena bahujanaggahaṇanti āha “bahujanā”ti. Yathā pana te hitasukhaṃ

original: caranti, taṃ vidhiṃ dassetuṃ “samānasukhadukkhā hutvā”ti vuttaṃ. Vigatapāpoti sabbaso
analyzed: caranti tam vidhim dassetum samāna sukha dukkhāḥ hutvā iti vuttam vigata pāpo ti sabbaso
translated: caranti, taṃ vidhiṃ dassetuṃ “samānasukhadukkhā hutvā”ti vuttaṃ. Vigatapāpoti sabbaso

original: samucchindanena viniddhutapāpadhammo. Daratho vuccati kāyiko, cetasiko ca pariḷāho.
analyzed: samucchindanena viniddhuta pāpa dhammaḥ darathaḥ vuccati kāyiko cetasiko ca pariḷāho
translated: samucchindanena viniddhutapāpadhammo. Daratho vuccati kāyiko, cetasiko ca pariḷāho.

original: Tattha cetasikapariḷāho “vigatapāpo”ti imināva vuttoti āha “vigatakāyikadarathakilamatho”ti.
analyzed: tattha cetasika pariḷāho vigata pāpo ti iminā ava vutto ti āha vigata kāyi kadaratha kilamatho ti
translated: Tattha cetasikapariḷāho “vigatapāpo”ti imināva vuttoti āha “vigatakāyikadarathakilamatho”ti.

original: Rāgādayo yasmiṃ santāne uppannā, tassa malīnabhāvakaraṇena malā. Kacavarabhāvena
analyzed: rāga ādayaḥ yasmin santāne uppannā tassa malīna bhāva karaṇena malā kaca vara bhāvena
translated: Rāgādayo yasmiṃ santāne uppannā, tassa malīnabhāvakaraṇena malā. Kacavarabhāvena

original: khilā. Sattānaṃ mahānatthakarattā visesato doso kalīti vuttaṃ “dosakalīnañcā”ti.
analyzed: khilā sattānam mahā natthakara ttā visesataḥ doso kalī iti vuttam dosa kalīnam ca ati
translated: khilā. Sattānaṃ mahānatthakarattā visesato doso kalīti vuttaṃ “dosakalīnañcā”ti.

original: Panūdehīti samucchindanavasena sasantānato nīhārakehi, pajahanakehīti attho. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: panūdehi iti samucchindana vasena sa santānataḥ nīhārakehi pajahanakehi iti attho sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: Panūdehīti samucchindanavasena sasantānato nīhārakehi, pajahanakehīti attho. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.

original: Ettha ca yasmā sabbesampi lakkhaṇānaṃ mahāpurisasantānagatapuññasambhārahetukabhāvena
analyzed: ettha ca yasmā sabbesam pi lakkhaṇānam mahāpurisa santāna gata puñña sambhāra hetuka bhāvena
translated: And here, since all the characteristics are the cause of the accumulation of merit in the continuity of a Great Man,

original: sabbaṃyeva taṃ puññakammaṃ sabbassa lakkhaṇassa kāraṇaṃ visiṭṭharūpattā phalassa.
analyzed: sabbaṃ yeva tam puñña kammam sabbassa lakkhaṇassa kāraṇam visiṭṭha rūpa ttā phalassa
translated: all that meritorious action is the cause of all the characteristics, since it is the special form of the fruit.

original: Na hi abhinnarūpakāraṇaṃ bhinnasabhāvassa phalassa paccayo bhavituṃ sakkoti, tasmā🔽yassa yassa lakkhaṇassa yaṃ yaṃ puññakammaṃ visesakāraṇaṃ, taṃ taṃ vibhāgena dassentī
analyzed: na hi abhinna rūpa kāraṇam bhinna sabhāvassa phalassa paccayaḥ bhavitum sakkoti tasmā  yassa yassa lakkhaṇassa yam yam puñña kammam visesa kāraṇam tam tam vibhāgena dassentī
translated: For a cause that is not a special form cannot be a condition for a fruit that is a special form. Therefore,🔽since it is the cause of each characteristic,

original: ayaṃ desanā pavattā. Tattha yathā yādisaṃ kāyasucaritādipuññakammaṃ suppatiṭṭhitapādatāya
analyzed: ayam desanā pavattā tattha yathā yādisam kāya su carita ādi puñña kammam su patiṭṭhita pāda tāya
translated: this teaching is given in order to show the special cause of each characteristic. Herein, the meritorious action consisting in good bodily conduct, etc.,

original: kāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ, tādisameva “uṇhīsasīsatāya” kāraṇanti na sakkā vattuṃ daḷhasamādānatāvisiṭṭhassa
analyzed: kāraṇam vuttam tādisam eva uṇhīsa sīsa tāya kāraṇanti na sakkā vattum daḷha samādāna tā visiṭṭhassa
translated: is said to be the cause of the well-placed feet, but it cannot be said to be the cause of the usnīsa-shaped head, because

original: tassa suppatiṭṭhitapādatāya kāraṇabhāvena vuttattā, itarassa ca pubbaṅgamatāvisiṭṭhassa
analyzed: tassa suppatiṭṭhita pāda tāya kāraṇa bhāvena vutta ttā itarassa ca pubbaṅgama tā visiṭṭhassa
translated: the latter is a special form of the former, since the latter is said to be the cause of the well-placed feet, and the former is🔽special because it is the forerunner.

original: vuttattā, evaṃ yādisaṃ āyatapaṇhitāya kāraṇaṃ, na tādisameva dīghaṅgulitāya, brahmujugattatāya
analyzed: evam yādisam āyata paṇhitāya kāraṇam na tādisam eva dīgha aṅgulitāya
translated: Because it is stated thus, the reason for the long and straight limbs is not the same as the reason for the long fingers, and the reason for the straightness is not the same as the reason for the long and straight limbs.

original: ca kāraṇaṃ visiṭṭharūpattā phalassa. Na hi abhinnarūpakāraṇaṃ bhinnasabhāvassa phalassa
analyzed: ca kāraṇam visiṭṭha rūpa ttā phalassa na hi abhinna rūpa kāraṇam bhinna sabhāvassa phalassa
translated: Because the fruit is distinguished in appearance. For a reason that is not distinguished in appearance cannot be a condition for a fruit that is distinguished in nature.

original: paccayo bhavituṃ sakkoti. Tattha yathā ekeneva kammunā cakkhādinānindriyuppattiyaṃ🔽avatthābhedato, sāmatthiyabhedato vā kammabhedo icchitabbo. Na hi yadavatthaṃ kammaṃ
analyzed: paccayaḥ bhavitum sakkoti tattha yathā ekena iva kammunā  avatthā bhedataḥ sāmatthiya bhedataḥ vā kamma bhedaḥ icchitabbaḥ na hi yad avattham kammam
translated: Herein, just as in the production of the eye faculty, etc., by a single kamma, a distinction of kamma is admitted as to the object or as to the potency,

original: cakkhussa kāraṇaṃ, tadavatthameva sotādīnaṃ kāraṇaṃ hoti abhinnasāmatthiyaṃ vā, tasmā
analyzed: cakkhussa kāraṇam tad avattham eva sota ādīnam kāraṇam hoti abhinna sāmatthiyam vā tasmā
translated: for the kamma that is the reason for the eye faculty is not the reason for the ear faculty, etc., or it is not of undifferentiated potency;

original: pañcāyatanikattabhāvapatthanābhūtā purimanipphannā kāmataṇhā paccayavasena visiṭṭhasabhāvā🔽kammassa visiṭṭhasabhāvaphalanibbattanasamatthatāsādhanavasena paccayo hotīti ekampi
analyzed: purima nipphannā kāma taṇhā paccaya vasena visiṭṭha sabhāvā  kammassa visiṭṭha sabhāva phala nibbattana samattha tā sādhana vasena paccayaḥ hoti iti ekam pi
translated: therefore the craving for sense desires that has arisen previously and is the desire for the state of the five aggregates is a condition for kamma by way of condition,

original: anekavidhaphalanibbattanasamatthatāvasena anekarūpataṃ āpannaṃ viya hoti, evamidhāpi
analyzed: anekavidha phala nibbattana samattha tā vasena aneka rūpa tam āpannam viya hoti evam idha api
translated: and it becomes a condition for the production of a fruit distinguished in nature by kamma by accomplishing the ability to produce a fruit distinguished in nature. Thus it is as if it has become manyfold by the ability to produce many kinds of fruit.🔽So too here,

original: “ekampi pāṇātipātā veramaṇivasena pavattaṃ kusalakammaṃ āyatapaṇhitādīnaṃ tiṇṇampi🔽lakkhaṇānaṃ nibbattakaṃ hotī”ti vuccamānepi na koci virodho. Tena vuttaṃ “so tassa🔽kammassa katattā…pe… imāni tīṇi mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhatī”ti nānākammunā pana🔽tesaṃ nibbattiyaṃ vattabbameva natthi, pāḷiyaṃ pana “tassa kammassā”ti ekavacananiddeso🔽sāmaññavasenāti daṭṭhabbo. Evañca katvā satapuññalakkhaṇavacanaṃ samatthitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: ekam pi pāṇātipātāḥ veramaṇi vasena pavattam kusala kammam āyata paṇhita ādīnam tiṇṇam pi  lakkhaṇānam nibbattakam hoti iti vuccamāne pi na koci virodhaḥ tena vuttam saḥ tassa  kammassa kata ttāpe imāni tīṇi mahāpurisa lakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati iti nānā kammunā pana  tesam nibbattiyam vattabbam eva natthi pāḷiyam pana tassa kammassa ati ekavacana niddeso  sāmañña vasena ati daṭṭhabbaḥ evam ca katvā sata puñña lakkhaṇa vacanam samatthitam hoti
translated: “Even when it is said that a single profitable action performed in the form of abstention from killing living beings is productive of all three characteristics of the great man, beginning with long life, there is no contradiction. So it is said: ‘As a result of that action … he obtains these three characteristics of a great man’ . But there is no question of their production by a single action. The singular verb ‘is produced’ in the text should be regarded as a concession to ordinary usage. And that being so, the statement of the hundred qualities of merit is justified.🔽

original: “Imāni dve mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhatī”tiādīsupi eseva nayoti.🔽Lakkhaṇasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā.
analyzed: imāni dve mahāpurisa lakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati iti ādīsu pi
translated: “Even though it is said that a single profitable action performed in the form of abstention from killing breathing things is productive of all three characteristics of the great man beginning with long-range vision, there is no contradiction. So it is said that ‘owing to his having done this profitable action … he obtains these three characteristics of a great man’ . But there is no question of their being produced by different actions. And in the text the singular number in ‘that action’s ’ should be understood as a plural in the sense of ‘general’ . And that being so, the statement of the hundred marks is justified. And the same method applies in the case of the passage ‘he obtains these two characteristics of a great man’ and so on. The explanation of the meaning of the Great Man’s marks is ended.

original: 8. Siṅgālasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: siṅgāla sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sigalaka Sutta

original: Nidānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nidāna vaṇṇanā
translated: The Introduction

original: 242. Pākārena parikkhittanti padaṃ ānetvā sambandho. Gopuraṭṭālakayuttanti dvārapāsādena
analyzed: pākārena parikkhittanti padam ānetvā sambandhaḥ gopura aṭṭālaka yuttanti dvāra pāsādena
translated: The passage to be construed with the words ‘enclosed by a rampart’ is ‘with its doors and arches’ .

original: ceva tattha tattha pākāramatthake patiṭṭhāpitaaṭṭālakehi ca yuttaṃ. Veḷūhi parikkhittattā,🔽abbhantare pupphūpagaphalūpagarukkhasañchannattā ca nīlobhāsaṃ. Chāyūdakasampattiyā,
analyzed: ca iva tattha tattha pākāra matthake patiṭṭhāpita aṭṭālakehi ca yuttam veḷūhi  abbhantare ca nīla ubhāsam chāyu udaka sampattiyā
translated: and it was provided with eight-sided pillars set up here and there on the tops of the walls.🔽It was blue-hued because it was surrounded by bamboo,

original: bhūmibhāgasampattiyā ca manoramaṃ.
analyzed: bhūmi bhāga sampattiyā ca manoramam
translated: and it was delightful because it was shaded by flowering and fruit-bearing trees inside.🔽Kāḷakavesen means in the form of a kalandaka bird.

original: Kāḷakavesenāti kalandakarūpena. Nivāpanti bhojanaṃ. Tanti uyyānaṃ.
analyzed: kāḷaka vesena ati kalandaka rūpena nivāpanti bhojanam uyyānam
translated: Nivāpanti means they feed. Tanti means the pleasure park.

original: “Kho panā”ti vacanālaṅkāramattametanti tena samayenāti atthavacanaṃ yuttaṃ. Gahapati
analyzed: kho pana ati vacana alaṅkāra mattam etat ti tena samayena ati attha vacanam yuttam gahapati
translated: Kho panā is merely an ornament of speech. Therefore the statement tena samayena is appropriate.

original: mahāsāloti gahapatibhūto mahāsāro, ra-kārassa la-kāraṃ katvā ayaṃ niddeso. Vibhavasampattiyā
analyzed: mahāsālaḥ ti gahapati bhūtaḥ mahāsāraḥ rakārassa lakāram katvā ayam niddesaḥ vibhava sampattiyā
translated: Gahapati mahāsāla means he was a householder and had great wealth. By changing the ra to la, this is the explanation.

original: mahāsārappatto kuṭumbiko. “Putto panassa assaddho”tiādi aṭṭhuppattiko yaṃ suttanikkhepoti
analyzed: mahā sāra ppattaḥ kuṭumbikaḥ putto panassa assaddho tiādi aṭṭha uppattikaḥ yam sutta nikkhepo ti
translated: Having attained great wealth through his prosperity, he was a householder. “But his son was faithless” and so on is the origin story.🔽What is called the suttanikkhepa is begun in order to show that origin story.

original: taṃ aṭṭhuppattiṃ dassetuṃ āraddhaṃ. Kammaphalasaddhāya abhāvena assaddho. Ratanattaye
analyzed: tam aṭṭhuppattim dassetum āraddham kamma phala saddhāya abhāvena assaddhaḥ rata nattaye
translated: Because of the absence of faith in the result of kamma, he was faithless. In the Three Jewels

original: pasādābhāvena appasanno. Evamāhāti evaṃ idāni vuccamānākārena vadati.
analyzed: pasāda abhāvena appasannaḥ evam āha ati evam idāni vuccamāna ākārena vadati
translated: and he is not well-disposed through lack of faith. Thus he speaks: thus he speaks in the way now being stated.

original: Yāvajīvaṃ anussaraṇīyā hoti hitesitāya vuttā pacchimā vācāti adhippāyena. Puthudisāti visuṃ visuṃ disā, tā pana anekāti āha “bahudisā”ti.🔽243. “Na tāva paviṭṭho”tiādīsu vattabbaṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva. Na idānevāti na imāya
analyzed: yāvajīvam anussaraṇīyā hoti hita īsitāya vuttā pacchimā vācā iti adhippāyena puthu disā ati visum visum disā tā pana anekā iti āha bahu disā iti  na tāva paviṭṭhaḥ ti ādīsu vattabbam heṭṭhā vuttam eva na idāneva ati na imāya
translated: It is to be remembered as long as life lasts, being spoken of for the sake of welfare, and it is the last utterance: this is the intention. In all directions: in each direction. But since there are many directions, he said “in all directions.”

original: eva velāya. Kiṃ carahīti āha “paccūsasamayepī”tiādi. Gihivinayanti gihīnaṃ gahaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: eva kim carahi iti āha paccūsa samaye pi itiādi gihi vinayanti gihīnam gaha ṭṭhānam
translated: As to “he has not yet entered”: what should be said here has already been said above. Not now only: not only at this time. What then? “At dawn too” and so on. Householders’ training: the training of householders, householders’ state, is what is meant.

original: vinayatantibhūtaṃ “gihinā evaṃ vattitabba”nti gahaṭṭhācārassa gahaṭṭhavattassa anavasesato
analyzed: vinaya tanti bhūtam gihinā evam vattitabbanti gahaṭṭha ācārassa gahaṭṭha vattassa anavasesato
translated: The training of householders is the conduct and behaviour of householders.🔽Since it is given in this sutta without omission,

original: imasmiṃ sutte savisesaṃ katvā vuttattā. Tathevāti yathā buddhacakkhunā diṭṭhaṃ, tatheva
analyzed: imasmin sutte sa visesam katvā vutta ttā tathā iva ati yathā buddha cakkhunā diṭṭham tathā iva
translated: he saw it as he saw it with the Buddha-eye.

original: passi. Namassati vattavasena kattabbanti gahetvā ṭhitattā.🔽Chadisādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: passi namassati vatta vasena kattabbanti gahetvā ṭhita ttā 🔽chadisa ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: He pays homage: he stands by taking the homage as what should be done out of respect.

original: 244. Vacanaṃ sutvāva cintesi buddhānubhāvena attasammāpaṇidhānanimittena puññabalena
analyzed: vacanam sutvā ava cintesi buddha anubhāvena atta sammāpaṇidhāna nimittena puñña balena
translated: Having heard the words, he thought, “By the power of the Buddha, and by the power of his own right aspiration, and by the power of his merit,

original: ca codiyamāno. Na kira tā etāti tā cha disā etā idāni mayā namassiyamānā puratthimādikā
analyzed: ca codiyamānaḥ na kira tāḥ etāḥ ati tāḥ cha disāḥ etāḥ idāni mayā namassiyamānā puratthima ādikā
translated: he was urged to speak. He said, ‘These six directions are not now the eastern and other directions that are worshipped by me.’

original: na honti kirāti. Nipātamattanti anatthakabhāvaṃ tassa vadati. Pucchāpadanti pucchāvacanaṃ.
analyzed: na honti anatthaka bhāvam tassa vadati pucchā padanti pucchā vacanam
translated: The word ‘kirā’ is a mere particle; it has no meaning. The word ‘pucchāpada’ is a word of question.

original: Bhagavā gahapatiputtena namassitabbā cha disā pucchito desanākusalatāya ādito eva
analyzed: bhagavā gahapati puttena namassitabbā cha disā pucchitaḥ desanā kusala tāya āditas eva
translated: The Blessed One, being skilled in teaching, was asked by the householder’s son to worship the six directions. He did not speak about them at the beginning,

original: tā akathetvā tassa tāva paṭipattiyā naṃ bhājanabhūtaṃ kātuṃ vajjanīyavajjanatthañceva
analyzed: tāḥ a kathetvā tassa tāva paṭipattiyā naṃ bhājana bhūtam kātum vajjanīya vajjana attham ca iva
translated: but in order to make him a fit vessel for the practice by first making him a fit vessel for the avoidance of what should be avoided and for the practice of what should be practised,

original: sevitabbasevanatthañca ovādaṃ dento “yato kho gahapatiputtā”tiādinā desanaṃ ārabhi.
analyzed: sevitabba sevana attham ca ovādam dentaḥ yatas kho gahapati putta ati ādinā desanam ārabhi
translated: he began the teaching with the words, “When, householder’s son.”

original: Tattha kammakilesāti kammabhūtā saṃkilesā. Kilissantīti kiliṭṭhā malīnā viya ṭhitā,
analyzed: tattha kamma kilesā ati kamma bhūtā saṃkilesā kilissantī iti kiliṭṭhā malīnā viya ṭhitā
translated: Herein, kammakilesa is defilement that is action. They defile, thus they are defiled, as if they were standing stained and soiled;

original: upatāpitā ca hontīti attho. Tasmāti kilissananimittattā. Yadipi surāpānaṃ pañcaverabhāvena
analyzed: ca honti iti tasmā ati kilissana nimitta ttā yadi pi surā pānam pañcaveḥ abhāvena
translated: the meaning is that they are brought about. Therefore, because they are the cause of defilement. Although drinking liquor is a course of bad action by reason of the five dangers,

original: upāsakehi parivajjanīyaṃ, tassa pana apāyamukhabhāvena parato vattukāmatāya pāṇātipātādike
analyzed: upāsakehi parivajjanīyam tassa pana apāya mukha bhāvena paratas vattu kāma tāya pāṇa atipāta ādike
translated: It is to be avoided by lay followers. But because it is a door of loss, it is mentioned by the Blessed One as a reason for speaking of the other four, namely, killing living beings, etc.,

original: eva sandhāya “cattāro”ti vuttaṃ, na “pañcā”ti. “Visuṃ akammapathabhāvato cā”ti apare.
analyzed: eva sandhāya cattāro ti vuttam na pañca ati visum akammapatha bhāvato ca ati apare
translated: and therefore he said “four,” not “five.” “And because it is not a course of kamma in itself” is another reason given by others.

original: “Surāpānampi ‘surāmerayapānaṃ, bhikkhave, āsevitaṃ bhāvitaṃ bahulīkataṃ nirayasaṃvattanika’ntiādi🔽vacanato visuṃ kammapathabhāvena āgataṃ. Tathā hi taṃ duccaritakammaṃ hutvā duggatigāmipiṭṭhivattakabhāvena🔽niyata”nti keci, tesaṃ matena ekādasa kammapathā siyuṃ. Tasmā yathāvuttesveva kammapathesu🔽upakārakattasabhāgattavasena anuppaveso daṭṭhabboti “visuṃ akammapathabhāvato cā”ti
analyzed: surā pānam pi surā meraya pānam bhikkhave āsevitam bhāvitam bahulīkatam niraya saṃvattanika nti ādi  vacanataḥ visum kamma patha bhāvena āgatam tathā hi tam duccarita kammam hutvā duggati gāmi piṭṭhivattaka bhāvena  keci tesam matena ekādasa kamma pathāḥ siyum tasmā yathā vuttesu eva kamma pathesu  upakāraka tta sabhā gatta vasena anuppavesaḥ daṭṭhabbo ti visum a kamma patha bhāvato ca ati
translated: “Because it is said: ‘The drinking of fermented liquor and spirits, bhikkhus, when practiced, developed, and cultivated, brings four dangers. It leads to hell, to rebirth as an animal, to the realm of ghosts, and to other unhappy destinies’ ,🔽the drinking of fermented liquor and spirits is a course of kamma in itself. For it is a bad kamma that leads to an unhappy destiny, and it is a door of loss because it is the reason for the other four courses of kamma.

original: suvuttametaṃ. Surāpānassa bhogāpāyamukhabhāvena vattukāmatāya “cattāro” tveva avoca.
analyzed: su vuttam etam surā pānassa bhoga apāya mukha bhāvena vattu kāma tāya cattāraḥ tu eva avoca
translated: Thus it is said to be a course of kamma in itself.” “And because it is not a course of kamma in itself” is well said. But because the drinking of fermented liquor and spirits is a door of loss of enjoyment, the Blessed One spoke of “four” only.

original: Tiṭṭhati ettha phalaṃ tadāyattavuttitāyāti ṭhānaṃ, hetūti āha “ṭhānehīti kāraṇehī”ti.
analyzed: tiṭṭhati ettha phalam tad āyatta vutti tāya ati ṭhānam hetu iti āha ṭhānehi iti kāraṇehi iti
translated: The fruit is present there, since it is dependent on that for its occurrence, thus it is a place . The cause is what is meant by “place,” thus he said “by place is meant by cause.”

original: Apenti apagacchanti, apeti vā etehīti apāyā, apāyānaṃ, apāyā eva vā mukhāni dvārānīti
analyzed: apenti apagacchanti apa iti vai apāyāḥ apāyānam apāyāḥ eva vā mukhāni dvārāni iti
translated: They go away, depart, thus they are bad ; they are gone away from here, thus they are bad ; or they are bad because they are gone away from here, thus they are bad .🔽The doors, the openings, are the mouths of the bad ;

original: apāyamukhāni. Vināsamukhānīti etthāpi eseva nayo.🔽Kiñcāpi “ariyasāvakassā”ti pubbe sādhāraṇato vuttaṃ, visesato pana paṭhamāya bhūmiyaṃ
analyzed: apāya mukhāni vināsa mukhāni iti ettha api nayo  kiñcā api ariya sāvakassa ati pubbe sādhāraṇataḥ vuttam visesato pana paṭhamāya bhūmiyam
translated: the same method applies here to the words “the doors to ruin.”🔽Although it was said in the first line in a general way, “of a noble disciple,” nevertheless the method of explanation that will be given is appropriate only for one who has reached the first plane,

original: ṭhitasseva vakkhamānanayo yujjatīti “soti so sotāpanno”ti vuttaṃ. Pāpaka-saddo nihīnapariyāyoti
analyzed: ṭhitassa iva vakkhamāna nayaḥ yujjati iti saḥ ti so sotāpannaḥ ti vuttam pāpaka saddaḥ nihīna pariyāyaḥ ti
translated: thus he said “he who has entered upon the way” . The word “bad” is a synonym for “low,”🔽thus he said “the low-born.”

original: “lāmakehī”ti vuttaṃ. Apāyadukkhaṃ, vaṭṭadukkhañca pāpentīti vā pāpakā, tehi pāpakehi.
analyzed: lāmakehi iti vuttam apāya dukkham vaṭṭa dukkham ca pāpenti iti vā pāpakā tehi pāpakehi
translated: They lead to the suffering of the states of loss and to the suffering of the round of rebirths, thus they are bad ;

original: Cha disā paṭicchādentoti tena tena bhāgena dissantīti “disā”ti saññite cha bhāge
analyzed: cha disā paṭicchādento ti tena tena bhāgena dissanti iti disā ati saññite cha bhāge
translated: he conceals the six directions: the six directions are the six directions of beings, which are so called because they are seen by means of the six kinds of eye, etc.,

original: satte yathā tehi saddhiṃ attano chiddaṃ na hoti, evaṃ paṭicchādento paṭisandhārento.
analyzed: satte yathā tehi saddhim attanaḥ chiddam na hoti evam paṭicchādentaḥ paṭisandhārentaḥ
translated: he conceals them, covers them up, so that he has no gaps in his protection against them.

original: Vijinanatthāyāti abhibhavanatthāya. Yo hi diṭṭhadhammikaṃ, samparāyikañca anatthaṃ
analyzed: vijinana tthāya ati abhibhavana tthāya yaḥ hi diṭṭhadhammikam samparāyikam ca anattham
translated: For the conquest of cognizance: for the conquest of the greed, etc., that are the opposite of the four foundations of mindfulness.

original: parivajjanavasena abhibhavati, tato eva tadubhayatthaṃ sampādeti, so ubhayalokavijayāya🔽paṭipanno nāma hoti paccatthikaniggaṇhanato, sakatthasampādanato ca. Tenāha “ayañceva
analyzed: parivajjana vasena abhibhavati tatas eva tat ubhayattham sampādeti saḥ ubhaya loka vijayāya  paṭipannaḥ nāma hoti paccatthika niggaṇhanato sa kattha sampādanato ca tena āha ayam ca eva
translated: For he who conquers the unprofitable here and now and in the life to come by avoiding it, accomplishes his own good in both worlds.🔽So he is said to be “practising for the conquest of both worlds” because he conquers his enemies and because he accomplishes his own good.🔽That is why “this world” is mentioned.

original: loko”tiādi. Pāṇātipātādīni pañca verāni verappasavanato. Āraddho hotīti saṃsādhito🔽hoti, tayidaṃ saṃsādhanaṃ kittisaddena idha sattānaṃ cittatosanena, verābhāvāpādanena🔽ca hotīti āha “paritosito ceva nipphādito cā”ti. Puna pañca verānīti pañca veraphalāni uttarapadalopena.

original: yathā “pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ, nīlaṃ vattha”nti ca. Sampayuttatā cettha tadekaṭṭhatāya
analyzed: yathā pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam nīlam ca sampayutta tā ca ittha tad ekaṭṭha tāya
translated: As in the case of the first jhāna, which is said to be “accompanied by happiness and pleasure” and the cloth, which is said to be “blue” .🔽Here the state of being accompanied should be understood as the state of being of the same nature,

original: veditabbā, na ekuppādāditāya. Evañca katvā pāṇātipātakammassa diṭṭhimānalobhādīhipi
analyzed: veditabbā na eka uppāda ādi tāya evam ca katvā pāṇātipāta kammassa diṭṭhi māna lobha ādīhi pi
translated: not as the state of arising together, and so on. And when this is done, the defilement of the action of killing living beings by wrong view and greed, etc.,

original: kiliṭṭhatā siddhā hoti, micchācārassa dosādīhi kiliṭṭhatā. Tenāha “saṃkilesoyevā”tiādi.
analyzed: kiliṭṭha tā siddhā hoti micchā ācārassa dosa ādīhi kiliṭṭha tā tena āha
translated: is established, and the defilement of sexual misconduct by hate, etc. Hence he said, “The defilement is only this” .

original: Pubbe vuttaatthavasena pana sammukhenapi nesaṃ kilesapariyāyo labbhateva. Etadatthaparidīpakamevāti
analyzed: pubbe vutta attha vasena pana sammukhena api na isam kilesa pariyāyaḥ labbhateva etad attha paridīpakam evā ti
translated: But the method of defilement by the actual state of being face to face is also applicable according to the meaning stated above.🔽The meaning of this is illustrated by the passage beginning with the words, “Killing living beings is of two kinds” .

original: yo “pāṇātipāto kho”tiādinā vutto, etassa atthassa paridīpakameva. Yadi evaṃ kasmā
analyzed: yaḥ pāṇa atipātaḥ kho ti ādinā vuttaḥ etassa atthassa paridīpakam eva yadi evam kasmā
translated: If that is so, then why is it said again?

original: puna vuttanti āha “gāthābandha”nti, tassa atthassa sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ bhagavā gāthābandhaṃ avocāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: puna vuttanti āha gāthābandham iti tassa atthassa sukha ggahaṇa attham bhagavā gāthābandham avoca ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: He said, “In the stanza” , intending that the Blessed One spoke in the stanza for the purpose of making the meaning easy to grasp.

original: Catuṭhānādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: catu ṭhāna ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the fourth section

original: 246. “Pāpakammaṃ karotī”ti kasmā ayaṃ uddesaniddeso pavattoti antolīnacodanaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: pāpa kammam karoti iti kasmai ayam uddesa niddeso pavatto ti antolīna codanam sandhāya
translated: Why is this exposition given in the way beginning, “He does a bad deed”?

original: “idaṃ bhagavā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Sukkapakkhavasena hi uddeso kato, kaṇhapakkhavasena ca🔽niddeso āraddho. Kāraketi pāpakammassa kārake. Akārako pākaṭo hoti yathā paṭipajjanto🔽pāpaṃ karoti nāma, tathā appaṭipajjanato. Saṃkilesadhammavivajjanapubbakaṃ vodānadhammapaṭipattiācikkhanaṃ🔽idha desanākosallaṃ. Paṭhamataraṃ kārakaṃ dassento āha yathā “vāmaṃ muñca dakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: idam bhagavā tiādi vuttam sukka pakkha vasena hi uddeso kato kaṇha pakkha vasena ca  niddesaḥ āraddhaḥ kāraka iti pāpa kammassa kārake akārakaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti yathā paṭipajjanto  pāpam karoti nāma tathā a paṭipajjanato saṃkilesa dhamma vivajjana pubbakam vodāna dhamma paṭipatti ācikkhanam  desanākosallam paṭhamataram kārakam dassentaḥ āha yathā vāmam muñca dakkhiṇam
translated: “This, Lord” and so on is said. For the summary is made by way of the bright side, and the exposition is begun by way of the dark side.🔽The doer is the doer of evil. The non-doer becomes manifest in that he does not do evil by not doing as he would do.🔽The teaching here is the instruction in the practice of purification of states after the exposition of defiling states.🔽Showing the doer first, he said: “Let go the left,🔽

original: gaṇhā”ti tathā hi bhagavā aṭṭhatiṃsa maṅgalāni dassento “asevanā ca bālāna”nti vatvā🔽“paṇḍitānañca sevanā”ti avoca. Chandāgatinti ettha sandhivasena saralopoti dassento🔽āha “chandena pemena agati”nti. Chandāti hetumhi nissakkavacananti āha “chandenā”ti.
analyzed: gaṇhāti tathā hi bhagavā aṭṭhatiṃsa maṅgalāni dassentaḥ asevanā ca bālānaṃ ti vatvā 🔽paṇḍitānam ca sevanā ati avoca ettha sandhi vasena dassento 🔽āha chandena pemena agatinti chanda ati hetumhi nissakka vacananti āha chandena ati
translated: “This, Lord, is the way” . For the recitation was done by way of the bright side, and the exposition was begun by way of the dark side. “The doer” : the doer of evil. The non-doer becomes evident in that he does not practice as the doer of evil would practice. The teaching skill here is the exposition of the practice of purification preceded by the discrimination of the dharmas of defilement. Showing the doer first, the Lord said, “Abandon the left and take the right” . For the Lord, in showing the thirty-eight qualities of enlightenment, said, “Not associating with fools” , and then said, “Associating with the wise” . “By the way of desire” : showing the sandhi by way of the word saralopa, he said, “By the way of desire, by the way of love” . “By the way of desire” : he said, “By the way of desire” , showing that chanda is a word for cause in the sense of “not going” .

original: Chanda-saddo cettha taṇhāpariyāyo, na kusalacchandādipariyāyoti āha “pemenā”ti. Parapadesūti
analyzed: chanda saddo ca ittha taṇhā pariyāyaḥ na kusala chanda ādi pariyāyaḥ iti āha pemena ati para padesu iti
translated: The word “desire” here is a synonym for craving, not for profitable desire, etc.; hence he said “by love.”🔽In other passages:🔽“Going to the extreme of hate” , etc.

original: “dosāgatiṃ gacchanto”tiādīsu vākyesu. “Eseva nayo”ti iminā “dosena kopenā”ti evamādi🔽atthavacanaṃ atidisati. Mittoti daḷhamitto, sambhattoti attho. Sandiṭṭhoti diṭṭhamattasahāyo.
analyzed: dosa āgatim gacchantaḥ iti ādīsu vākyesu iminā dosena kopena ati evamādi  attha vacanam atidisati mitto ti daḷha mitto sambhatto ti attho sandiṭṭhaḥ ti diṭṭha matta sahāyaḥ
translated: The words “this is the method” refer to the explanation of the meaning of “by hate, by anger” , etc.🔽A friend is a close friend; the meaning is, an intimate.🔽A companion is a friend seen only in that life.

original: Pakativeravasenāti pakatiyā uppannaveravasena, cirakālānubandhavirodhavasenāti attho.🔽Tenevāha “taṅkhaṇuppannakodhavasena vā”ti. Yaṃ vā taṃ vā ayuttaṃ akāraṇaṃ vatvā.
analyzed: pakati vera vasena ati pakatiyā uppanna vera vasena cira kāla anubandha virodha vasena ati attho  tena iva āha taṅkhaṇa uppanna kodha vasena vāti yam vā tam vā ayuttam akāraṇam vatvā
translated: By the enmity that has arisen naturally: by enmity that has arisen naturally, that is, by hostility that has persisted for a long time.🔽Hence he said “by anger arisen on that occasion.”🔽Or by what is improper and unreasonable.

original: Visame corādike, visamāni vā kāyaduccaritādīni samādāya vattanena nissito visamanissito.
analyzed: visame cora ādike visamāni vā kāya duccarita ādīni samādāya vattanena nissitaḥ visama nissitaḥ
translated: One who is bound by enmity is one who is bound by enmity in a difficult place such as a jungle, or one who is bound by the practice of unwholesome bodily actions, etc., that are difficult to surmount.

original: Chandāgatiādīni na gacchati maggeneva catunnampi agatigamanānaṃ pahīnattā, agatigamanānīti ca tathāpavattā apāyagamanīyā akusalacittuppādā veditabbā agati gacchati etehīti.
analyzed: chanda agati ādīni na gacchati maggena iva catunnam pi agati gamanānam pahīna ttā agati gamanāni iti ca tathā pavattāḥ apāya gamanīyāḥ akusala cittuppādāḥ veditabbāḥ agati gacchati etehi iti
translated: He does not go by the way of pleasure, etc., because he has abandoned the four ways of going by the way of pleasure, etc., which should be understood as the occurrence of unprofitable cognizance that leads to the unhappy destinations.

original: Yassati tena kittīyatīti yaso, thutighoso. Yassati tena purecarānucarabhāvena parivārīyatīti🔽yaso, parivāroti āha “kittiyasopi parivārayasopī”ti. Parihāyatīti pubbe yo ca yāvatake
analyzed: yaḥ ati tena kittīyati iti yasaḥ thuti ghosaḥ yaḥ ati tena purecara anucara bhāvena parivārīyati iti  parivāro ti āha kitti yaso pi parivāra yaso pi iti parihāyati iti pubbe yaḥ ca yāvatake
translated: He is famous: his fame is spread about. He is renowned: he is surrounded by those who go before and follow after him.🔽“Fame” is the same as “renown” .

original: labbhati, tato parito hāyati parikkhayaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: labbhati tatas paritas hāyati parikkhayam gacchati
translated: He is diminished: he is diminished, he is reduced, from what he was before.

original: Chaapāyamukhādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: cha apāya mukha ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the six kinds of beer

original: 247. Pūve bhājane pakkhipitvā tajjaṃ udakaṃ datvā madditvā katā pūvasurā. Evaṃ sesasurāpi.
analyzed: pūve bhājane pakkhipitvā tajjam udakam datvā madditvā katā pūva surā evam sesa surā api
translated: Beer made from flour is that made by putting flour in a vessel, adding water, and kneading it. The rest are obvious.

original: Kiṇṇāti pana tassā surāya bījaṃ vuccati, ye “surāmodakā” tipi vuccanti, te pakkhipitvā
analyzed: kiṇṇā ati pana tassā surāya bījam vuccati ye surāmodakā vuccanti te pakkhipitvā
translated: The seed of that beer is called “spent grains” .

original: katā kiṇṇapakkhittā. Harītakīsāsapādinānāsambhārehi saṃyojitā sambhārasaṃyuttā. Madhukatālanāḷikerādipuppharaso🔽cirapārivāsiko pupphāsavo. Panasādiphalaraso phalāsavo. Muddikāraso madhvāsavo. Ucchuraso
analyzed: katā kiṇṇa pakkhittā harītakī sāsapa ādi nānā sambhārehi saṃyojitā sambhāra saṃyuttā madhuka tāla nāḷikera ādi puppha rasaḥ  cira pārivāsikaḥ puppha āsavaḥ panasa ādi phala rasaḥ phala āsavaḥ muddikā rasaḥ madhvāsavaḥ ucchu rasaḥ
translated: and the juice of the various ingredients such as harītaki, asafoetida, etc., is mixed with them, is called “mixed with a compound.” The juice of the flowers of the madhuka, tāla, nāḷikeraka, etc.,

original: guḷāsavo. Harītakāmalakakaṭukabhaṇḍādinānāsambhārānaṃ raso cirapārivāsiko sambhārasaṃyutto.
analyzed: guḷa āsavaḥ rasaḥ cira pārivāsikaḥ sambhāra saṃyutto
translated: which has been kept for a long time, is called “flower-wine.” The juice of the fruits of the bread-fruit tree, etc., is called “fruit-wine.” The juice of the toddy palm is called “palm-wine.” The juice of the sugar-cane is called “sugar-cane-wine.” The juice of the various ingredients such as harītaki, emblic myrobalan, and bitter seeds, etc., which has been kept for a long time, is called “mixed with a compound.”

original: Taṃ sabbampīti taṃ sabbaṃ dasavidhampi. Madakaraṇavasena majjaṃ pivantaṃ madayatīti
analyzed: tam sabbam pi iti tam sabbam dasavidham pi mada karaṇa vasena majjam pivantam madayati iti
translated: All these ten kinds of liquor, when drunk, intoxicate the person who drinks them, because they cause intoxication.

original: katvā. Surāmerayamajje pamādaṭṭhānaṃ surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānaṃ. Anu anu yogoti
analyzed: katvā surā meraya majje pamāda ṭṭhānam surā meraya majja pamāda ṭṭhānam anu anu yogoti
translated: The state of being a basis for heedlessness in the case of liquor, wine, and intoxicants is called “the state of heedlessness in regard to liquor, wine, and intoxicants.” The repeated practice of it is

original: punappunaṃ taṃsamaṅgitā. Tenāha “punappunaṃ karaṇa”nti, aparāparaṃ pavattananti attho.
analyzed: punappunam taṃsamaṅgi tā tena āha punappunam karaṇam ti apara aparam pavattananti attho
translated: the repeated performance of it. Hence it is said: “The repeated performance of it” . The meaning is: the occurrence of it again and again.

original: Uppannā ceva bhogā parihāyanti pānabyasanena byasanakaraṇato. Anuppannā ca nuppajjanti
analyzed: uppannā ca iva bhogā parihāyanti pāna byasanena byasana karaṇataḥ anuppannā ca na uppajjanti
translated: And by the ruin of liquor, one is ruined both as regards one’s present wealth and as regards the acquisition of future wealth.

original: pamattassa kammantesu ñāyakaraṇābhāvato. Bhogānanti bhuñjitabbaṭṭhena “bhogā”ti laddhanāmānaṃ
analyzed: pamattassa kammantesu ñāya karaṇa abhāvataḥ bhogānanti bhuñjitabba ṭṭhena bhogāti laddha nāmānam
translated: because of the absence of right action in one who is negligent.🔽As to ‘pleasures’: the five strands of sensual desire are called ‘pleasures’ in the sense of what should be enjoyed.🔽The meaning of the word ‘mouth of disaster’ has already been given above.

original: kāmaguṇānaṃ. Apāyamukha-saddassa attho heṭṭhā vutto eva. Avelāyāti ayuttavelāya.
analyzed: kāma guṇānam apāya mukha saddassa attho heṭṭhā vuttaḥ eva avelāya ati ayutta velāya
translated: ‘At the wrong time’ is an unsuitable time,🔽when there is no protection of his life, etc., while he is wandering about.

original: Yadā vicarato attharakkhādayo na honti. Visikhāsu cariyāti racchāsu vicaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: yadā vicarataḥ attha rakkhā ādayaḥ na honti visikhāsu racchāsu vicaraṇam
translated: ‘Wandering in the streets’ is wandering about in the lanes.

original: Samajjā vuccati maho, yattha naccānipi payojīyanti, tesaṃ dassanādiatthaṃ tattha🔽abhirativasena caraṇaṃ upagamanaṃ samajjābhicaraṇaṃ. Naccādidassanavasenāti naccādīnaṃ🔽dassanādivasenāti ādisaddalopo daṭṭhabbo, dassanena vā savanampi gahitaṃ virūpekasesanayena.🔽Ālocanasabhāvatāya vā pañcaviññāṇānaṃ savanakiriyāyapi dassanasaṅkhepasambhavato
analyzed: samajjā vuccati mahaḥ yattha naccāni pi tesam dassana ādi attham tattha  abhirati vasena caraṇam upagamanam sa majja abhicaraṇam nacca ādi dassana vasena ati nacca ādīnam  dassana ādi vasena ati ādi sadda lopaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ dassanena vā savanam pi gahitam virūpa eka sesa nayena  ālocana sabhāva tāya vā pañca viññāṇānam dassana saṅkhepa sambhavato
translated: A ‘festival’ is a great gathering where dancing is performed; going there with the object of seeing that,🔽and so on, is ‘wandering at festivals’.

original: “dassanavasena” icceva vuttaṃ. Idha cittālasiyatā akāraṇanti “kāyālasiyatā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dassana vasena iccā iva vuttam idha citta alasiya tā akāraṇam ti kāya alasiya tā ati vuttam
