analyzed: tattha rukkhā su jātā sabbadā api pupphita aggā tiṭṭhanti jalāsayā api vikasita kamala kuvalaya puṇḍarīka sogandhika ādi puppha sañchannā
translated: there are trees there which are well-formed and always stand bearing flowers, and the water-basins are covered with the fragrance of fully-opened lotuses, water lilies, and white lotuses, etc.,

original: sabbakālaṃ paramasugandhaṃ samantato pavāyantā tiṭṭhanti. Sarīrampi tesaṃ atidīghatādidosarahitaṃ🔽ārohapariṇāhasampannaṃ jarāya anabhibhūtattā valipalitādidosarahitaṃ yāvatāyukaṃ
analyzed: sabbakālam parama sugandham samantataḥ tiṭṭhanti sarīram pi tesam ati dīgha tā ādi dosa rahitam  āroha pariṇāha sampannam jarāya vali palita ādi dosa rahitam yāvatā āyukam
translated: and stand diffusing a most delightful fragrance all around at all times. Their bodies are not too tall or too short,

original: aparikkhīṇajavabalaparakkamasobhameva hutvā tiṭṭhati. Anuṭṭhānaphalūpajīvitāya na
analyzed: a parikkhīṇa java bala parakkama sobham eva hutvā tiṭṭhati anuṭṭhāna phala upajīvitāya na
translated: but are well-proportioned in height and breadth. They are not overcome by old age, and so are free from the signs of old age such as wrinkles and grey hair. They stand with beauty and vigour unimpaired until the end of their lives,

original: ca nesaṃ kasivāṇijjādivasena, āhārapariyeṭṭhivasena dukkhaṃ atthi, tato eva na dāsadāsikammakarādipariggaho
analyzed: ca nesam kasi vāṇijja ādi vasena āhāra pariyeṭṭhi vasena dukkham atthi tatas eva na dāsa dāsi kammakara ādi pariggaho
translated: and because they live on the fruit of their past actions, they do not suffer from the trouble of seeking food by agriculture, trade, etc. Consequently, they do not keep slaves, servants, and so on,

original: atthi, na ca tattha sītuṇhaḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapavāḷādiparissayo atthi. Yathā
analyzed: atthi na ca tattha sītuṇha ḍaṃsa makasa vāta ātapa sarīsapa vāḷa ādi parissayaḥ atthi yathā
translated: and there is no discomfort from cold, heat, gadflies, flies, wind, sun, creeping things, or mosquitoes.

original: nāmettha gimhānaṃ pacchime māse paccūsavelāyaṃ samasītuṇhautu hoti, evameva sabbakālaṃ
analyzed: nāma ittha gimhānam pacchime māse paccūsa velāyam hoti evam eva sabbakālam
translated: Just as in the last month of the hot season at midday in summer the weather is neither too cold nor too hot,

original: samasītuṇhova utu hoti, na ca tesaṃ koci upaghāto, vihesā vā uppajjati. Akaṭṭhapākimameva🔽sāliṃ akaṇaṃ athusaṃ sugandhaṃ taṇḍulaphalaṃ paribhuñjantānaṃ nesaṃ kuṭṭhaṃ, gaṇḍo,🔽kilāso, soso, kāso, sāso, apamāro, jaroti evamādiko na koci rogo uppajjati. Na te
analyzed: hoti na ca tesam koci upaghātaḥ vihesā vā uppajjati  sālim a kaṇam a thusam su gandham taṇḍula phalam paribhuñjantānam kuṭṭham gaṇḍo  kilāsaḥ sosaḥ kāsaḥ sāsaḥ apamāraḥ evamādikaḥ na koci rogaḥ uppajjati na te
translated: so too, the weather there is neither too cold nor too hot at all times, and they are never afflicted by any discomfort or pain.🔽They eat only unhusked rice, which is free from dust and husk, fragrant and sweet-smelling, and they have no such diseases as leprosy, boils, eczema, diabetes, tumours, coughs, fevers, colds, or any other ailments.

original: khujjā vā vāmanakā vā kāṇā vā kuṇī vā khañjā vā pakkhahatā vā vikalaṅgā vā vikalindriyā🔽vā honti. Itthiyopi tattha nātidīghā nātirassā nātikisā nātithūlā nātikāḷā nāccodātā
analyzed: khujjā vā vāmanakā vā kāṇā vā kuṇī vā khañjā vā pakkha hatā vā vikalaṅgā vā vikalindriyā  vā honti itthiyaḥ pi tattha na ati dīghā na ati rassā na ati kisā na ati thūlā na ati kāḷā na accodātā
translated: They are not short-lived, ugly, or sickly, nor are they blind, deaf, or crippled.🔽The women there are not too tall or too short, not too fat or too thin, not too dark or too fair. They are perfect in beauty.

original: sobhaggappattarūpā honti. Tathā hi dīghaṅgulī tambanakhī lambatthanā tanumajjhā puṇṇacandamukhī
analyzed: sobhagga ppatta rūpāḥ honti tathā hi dīghaṅgulī tambanakhī lambatthanā tanumajjhā puṇṇacandamukhī
translated: They have long fingers and toes, copper-coloured nails, rounded limbs, slender waists, and faces like the full moon.

original: visālakkhī mudugattā saṃhitūrū odātadantā gambhīranābhī tanujaṅghā dīghanīlavellitakesī
analyzed: visa alakkhī mudu gattā saṃhita ūrū odāta dantā gambhīra nābhī tanu jaṅghā dīgha nīla vellita kesī
translated: She has large eyes, a gentle nature, well-proportioned limbs, white teeth, a deep navel, slender shanks, long dark curly hair,

original: puthulasusoṇī nātilomānālomā subhagā utusukhasamphassā saṇhā sakhilasambhāsā nānābharaṇavibhūsitā🔽vicaranti. Sabbadā hi soḷasavassuddesikā viya honti. Purisā ca pañcavīsativassuddesikā
analyzed: puthula su soṇī na atilomā anālomā subhagā utu sukha samphassā saṇhā sa khila sambhāsā nānā ābharaṇa vibhūsitā  vicaranti sabbadā hi soḷasa vassuddesikāḥ viya honti purisā ca pañcavīsati vassuddesikā
translated: a broad forehead, not too much body hair, good looks, a pleasant touch like the breeze in the cool season, a sweet voice, and is adorned with various ornaments.🔽They move about. For they are always like sixteen-year-olds. The men

original: viya, na puttadāresu rajjanti. Ayaṃ tattha dhammatā.
analyzed: viya na putta dāresu rajjanti ayam tattha dhamma tā
translated: are like twenty-five-year-olds. They are not attached to wives and children. This is the natural law there.

original: Sattāhikameva ca tattha itthipurisā kāmaratiyā viharanti, tato vītarāgā yathāsakaṃ🔽gacchanti. Na tattha idha viya gabbhokkantimūlakaṃ, gabbhapariharaṇamūlakaṃ, vijāyanamūlakaṃ🔽vā dukkhaṃ hoti. Rattakañcukato kañcanapaṭimā viya dārakā mātukucchito amakkhitā
analyzed: sattāhikam eva ca tattha itthi purisāḥ kāma ratiyā viharanti tatas vīta rāgāḥ yathāsakam  gacchanti na tattha idha viya gabbha ukkanti mūlakam gabbha pariharaṇa mūlakam vijāyana mūlakam  vā dukkham hoti ratta kañcukataḥ kañcana paṭimāḥ viya dārakāḥ mātukucchitaḥ a makkhitā
translated: For seven days only the women and men live in sexual intercourse there. After that, being free from passion, they go their🔽respective ways. There is no suffering there due to conception, carrying the fetus, or giving birth, as there is here.

original: eva semhādinā sukheneva nikkhamanti, ayaṃ tattha dhammatā.
analyzed: eva semha ādinā sukhena iva nikkhamanti ayam tattha dhamma tā
translated: The children come out of the mother’s womb unsoiled by excrement, as if from a crystal casket, with ease, unhurt, and happy, as if coming down from Trayastrimsa. This is the natural law there.

original: Mātā pana puttaṃ vā dhītaraṃ vā vijāyitvā tesaṃ vicaraṇappadese ṭhapetvā anapekkhā
analyzed: mātā pana puttam vā dhītaram vā vijāyitvā tesam vicaraṇa ppadese ṭhapetvā anapekkhā
translated: But the mother, after giving birth to a son or daughter, leaves them lying in the place where they were born, paying no attention to them,

original: yathāruci gacchati. Tesaṃ tattha sayitānaṃ ye passanti purisā, itthiyo vā, te attano
analyzed: yathāruci gacchati tesam tattha sayitānam ye passanti purisāḥ itthiyaḥ vā te attanaḥ
translated: and she goes away wherever she wishes. And those who see them there, men or women,

original: aṅguliyo upanāmenti, tesaṃ kammabalena tato khīraṃ pavattati, tena dārakā yāpenti.🔽Evaṃ pana vaḍḍhantā katipayadivaseheva laddhabalā hutvā dārikā itthiyo upagacchanti,
analyzed: aṅguliyaḥ upanāmenti tesam kamma balena tatas khīram pavattati tena dārakāḥ yāpenti  evam pana vaḍḍhantā katipaya divasehi iva laddha balāḥ hutvā dārikāḥ itthiyaḥ upagacchanti
translated: put their fingers into their mouths, and milk flows from them by the power of kamma. The children live on this.

original: dārakā purise. Kapparukkhato eva ca tesaṃ tattha tattha vatthābharaṇāni nippajjanti.🔽Nānāvirāgavaṇṇavicittāni hi sukhumāni mudusukhasamphassāni vatthāni tattha tattha🔽kapparukkhesu olambantāni iṭṭhanti. Nānāvidharaṃsijālasamujjalavividhavaṇṇaratanavinaddhāni
analyzed: dārakā purise kappa rukkhataḥ eva ca tesam tattha tattha vattha ābharaṇāni nippajjanti  nānā virāga vaṇṇa vicittāni hi sukhumāni mudu sukha samphassāni vatthāni tattha tattha  kappa rukkhesu olambantāni iṭṭhanti nānāvidha raṃsi jāla samujjala vividha vaṇṇa ratana vinaddhāni
translated: But as they grow up they become strong after a few days only, and the girls go to the men and the boys to the women. And garments and clothes for them appear on the branches of the wish-fulfilling tree.🔽For fine, soft, pleasant garments of various colours and dyes hang down from the wish-fulfilling trees🔽and shine with the lustre of various gems and jewels.

original: anekavidhamālākammalatākammabhittikammavicittāni sīsūpagagīvūpagahatthūpagakaṭūpagapādūpagāni
analyzed: anekavidha mālā kamma latā kamma bhitti kamma vicittāni sīsūpaga gīvūpaga hatthūpaga kaṭu upaga pādūpagāni
translated: And there are head-ornaments, neck-ornaments, armlets, bracelets, anklets,

original: sovaṇṇamayāni ābharaṇāni ca kapparukkhato olambanti. Tathā vīṇāmudiṅgapaṇavasammatāḷasaṅkhavaṃsavetāḷaparivānivallakīpabhutikā
analyzed: sovaṇṇa mayāni ābharaṇāni ca kappa rukkhataḥ olambanti tathā
translated: and golden ornaments hang down from the Karīra trees.

original: tūriyabhaṇḍāpi tato tato olambanti. Tattha ca bahū phalarukkhā kumbhamattāni phalāni
analyzed: tato tato olambanti tattha ca bahū phala rukkhā kumbha mattāni phalāni
translated: And musical instruments such as lutes, drums, tabours, horns, conch shells, flutes, cymbals, and tambourines hang down from here and there. And there are many fruit trees there, whose fruits, the size of a water-pot,

original: phalanti madhurarasāni, yāni paribhuñjitvā te sattāhampi khuppipāsāhi na bādhīyanti.
analyzed: phalanti madhura rasāni yāni paribhuñjitvā te sattāham pi khuppipāsāhi na bādhīyanti
translated: ripen and fall, sweet-tasting, by eating which those beings are not troubled by hunger and thirst for seven days.

original: Najjopi tattha suvisuddhajalā supatitthā ramaṇīyā akaddamā vālukatalā nātisītā nāccuṇhā
analyzed: najjā upi tattha su visuddha jalā su patitthā ramaṇīyā a kaddamā vāluka talā na ati sītā na accuṇhā
translated: There is a river there, with very clear water, a pleasant ford, delightful, without mud, with sandy banks, not too cold, not too hot,

original: surabhigandhīhi jalajapupphehi sañchannā sabbakālaṃ surabhiṃ vāyantiyo sandanti.
analyzed: surabhi gandhīhi jala ja pupphehi sañchannā sabbakālam surabhim vāyantiyaḥ sandanti
translated: covered with fragrant water-flowers, flowing with a pleasant sound all the time, fragrant.

original: Na tattha kaṇṭakatiṇakakkhaḷagacchalatā honti, akaṇṭakā pupphaphalasampannā eva honti.
analyzed: na tattha kaṇṭaka tiṇaka khaḷaga chalatāḥ honti akaṇṭakāḥ puppha phala sampannāḥ eva honti
translated: There are no thorny plants, rough trees, creepers, or shrubs there, they are all without thorns, and are endowed with flowers and fruits.

original: Candananāgarukkhā sayameva rasaṃ paggharanti. Nhāyitukāmā ca nadītitthe ekajjhaṃ
analyzed: candana nāga rukkhā sayam eva rasam paggharanti nhāyitu kāmā ca nadī titthe ekajjham
translated: The sandalwood and nāga trees exude their essence by themselves. And those who wish to bathe, at the river-banks,

original: vatthābharaṇāni ṭhapetvā nadiṃ otaritvā nhatvā uttiṇṇuttiṇṇā upariṭṭhimaṃ vatthābharaṇaṃ
analyzed: vattha ābharaṇāni ṭhapetvā nadim otaritvā nhatvā uttiṇṇa uttiṇṇā upariṭṭhimam vattha ābharaṇam
translated: They put aside their clothes and ornaments, entered the river, bathed, and came out. As they came out, they took the clothes and ornaments

original: gaṇhanti, na tesaṃ evaṃ hoti “idaṃ mama, idaṃ parassā”ti, tato eva na tesaṃ koci
analyzed: gaṇhanti na tesam evam hoti idam mama idam parassa ati tatas eva na tesam koci
translated: that were lying on the bank. They did not think, “These are mine, those are someone else’s.” And so there was no dispute between them.

original: viggaho vā vivādo vā. Sattāhikā eva ca nesaṃ kāmaratikīḷā hoti, tato vītarāgā viya
analyzed: viggahaḥ vā vivādaḥ vā sattāhikāḥ eva ca na isam kāma rati kīḍā hoti tatas vīta rāgā
translated: Their sexual intercourse lasted only seven days. After that they were as if free from passion.

original: vicaranti. Yattha ca rukkhe sayitukāmā honti, tattheva sayanaṃ upalabhanti. Mate
analyzed: vicaranti yattha ca rukkhe sayitu kāmāḥ honti tattha iva sayanam upalabhanti mate
translated: Wherever they wanted to sleep, there they found a bed.

original: ca satte disvā na rodanti, na socanti, tañca maṇḍayitvā nikkhipanti. Tāvadeva ca🔽nesaṃ tathārūpā sakuṇā upagantvā mataṃ dīpantaraṃ nenti. Tasmā susānaṃ vā asuciṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ca satte disvā na rodanti na socanti tat ca maṇḍayitvā nikkhipanti tāvat eva ca  tathārūpā sakuṇāḥ upagantvā matam dīpa antaram na inti tasmā su sānam vai a suci ṭṭhānam
translated: When they saw a dead person, they did not cry or grieve. They just decorated the body and left it there.🔽Then birds came and carried the dead body to another island. Therefore there is no cemetery or place for the disposal of the dead there.

original: vā tattha natthi. Na ca tato matā nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā pettivisayaṃ vā upapajjanti.
analyzed: vā tattha natthi na ca tatas matā nirayam vā tiracchāna yonim vā petti visayam vā upapajjanti
translated: Nor do the dead there take rebirth in hell, as an animal, or in the ghost realm.

original: “Dhammatāsiddhassa pañcasīlassa ānubhāvena te devaloke nibbattantī”ti vadanti. Vassasahassameva
analyzed: dhammatā siddhassa pañcasīlassa ānubhāvena te deva loke nibbattanti iti vadanti vassa sahassam eva
translated: They say that it is by the power of the five precepts that they are reborn in the heavenly world.🔽The lifespan there is one thousand years.

original: ca nesaṃ sabbakālaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ. Sabbametaṃ tesaṃ pañcasīlaṃ viya dhammatāsiddhaṃ
analyzed: ca nesam sabba kālam āyu ppamāṇam sabbam etam tesam pañcasīlam viya dhamma tā siddham
translated: And their life-span is fixed at all times. All this should be understood as established by the true nature of things, like their five precepts.

original: evāti veditabbaṃ. Tatthāti tasmiṃ uttarakurudīpe.
analyzed: eva ati veditabbam tattha iti tasmin uttarakuru dīpe
translated: Herein, “there” means in the Uttarakuru continent.

original: Ekakhuraṃ katvāti anekasaphampi ekasaphaṃ viya katvā, assaṃ viya katvāti attho. “Gāvi”nti
analyzed: eka khuram katvā iti aneka sapham pi eka sapham viya katvā assam viya katvā ati atthaḥ gāvin ti
translated: “Having made one hoof”: having made many hooves as if they were one hoof, having made them like a horse’s hoof, is the meaning.

original: vatvā puna “pasu”nti vuttattā gāvito itaro sabbo catuppado idha “pasū”ti adhippetoti
analyzed: vatvā puna pasu nti vutta ttā gāvito itaro sabbo catuppadaḥ idha pasu iti adhippeto ti
translated: After saying “cows,” since “cattle” is mentioned again, all four-footed animals other than cows are intended here by the word “cattle.”

original: āha “ṭhapetvā gāvi”nti.
analyzed: āha gāvinti
translated: Therefore it is said: “except cows.”

original: Tassāti gabbhinitthiyā. Piṭṭhi onamituṃ sahatīti kucchiyā garubhāratāya tesaṃ āruḷhakāle🔽piṭṭhi onamati, tesaṃ nisajjaṃ sahati pallaṅke nisinnā viya honti. Sammādiṭṭhiketi
analyzed: tassa ati gabbhi nitthiyā piṭṭhi onamitum sahati iti kucchiyā āruḷha kāle  piṭṭhi onamati tesam nisajjam sahati pallaṅke nisinnāḥ viya honti sammādiṭṭhikā iti
translated: “Her”: the pregnant woman. “Can bear the bending down of her back”: at the time of their mounting her, because of the heaviness of her belly, her back bends down;

original: kammapathasammādiṭṭhiyā sammādiṭṭhike. Etthāti jambudīpe. Ettha hi janapadavohāro,
analyzed: kamma patha sammādiṭṭhiyā sammādiṭṭhike ettha ati jambudīpe ettha hi janapada vohāro
translated: she can bear their sitting down; she is as if seated on a couch. “Those who have right view”: those who have right view by means of the right view of the path of action. “Here”: in the Rose-Apple Island.🔽Here the local usage is, not in the Uttarakuru continent.

original: na uttarakurumhi. Tathā hi “paccantimamilakkhuvāsike”ti ca vuttaṃ.
analyzed: na uttarakurumhi tathā hi ca vuttam
translated: For it is said: “The inhabitants of the border regions of the Milas.”

original: Tassa raññoti vessavaṇamahārājassa. Iti so attānameva paraṃ viya katvā vadati. Eseva
analyzed: tassa rañño ti vessavaṇa mahā rājassa iti saḥ attānam eva param viya katvā vadati esa eva
translated: The king’s: of the Great King Vessavana. Thus he speaks as if he himself were another. This is the

original: nayo paratopi. Bahuvidhaṃ nānāratanavicittaṃ nānāsaṇṭhānaṃ rathādi dibbayānaṃ upaṭṭhitameva
analyzed: paratas api bahuvidham nānā ratana vicittam nānā saṇṭhānam ratha ādi dibba yānam upaṭṭhitam eva
translated: method with the others too. Various kinds of vehicles such as chariots, etc., which are made of various precious substances and have various shapes, are always

original: hoti sudantavāhanayuttaṃ, na nesaṃ yānānaṃ upaṭṭhāpane ussukkaṃ āpajjitabbaṃ atthi.
analyzed: hoti su danta vāhana yuttam na nesam yānānam upaṭṭhāpane ussukkam āpajjitabbam atthi
translated: ready for use, and they do not have to make an effort to get them ready.

original: Etānīti hatthiyānādīni. Nesanti vessavaṇaparicārikānaṃ. Kappitāni hutvā uṭṭhitāni
analyzed: etāni iti hatthi yāna ādīni vessavaṇa paricārikānam kappitāni hutvā uṭṭhitāni
translated: These: the elephant vehicles, etc. They use: the attendants of Vessavana. Having been groomed, they stand ready

original: āruhituṃ upakappanayānāni. Nipannāpi nisinnāpi vicaranti candimasūriyā viya yathāsakaṃ vimānesu.
analyzed: āruhitum upakappana yānāni nipannā api nisinnā api vicaranti candima sūriyāḥ viya yathāsakam vimānesu
translated: to be mounted and used as vehicles. The moon and sun, as if they were resting or sitting, move about in their respective mansions.

original: Nagarā ahūti liṅgavipallāsena vuttanti āha “nagarāni bhaviṃsūti attho”ti. Āṭānāṭā nāmāti itthiliṅgavasena laddhanāmaṃ nagaraṃ āsi.
analyzed: nagarāḥ ahū iti liṅga vipallāsena vuttanti āha nagarāni bhaviṃsu iti attho ti āṭānāṭāḥ nāma ati itthi liṅga vasena laddha nāmam nagaram āsi
translated: Were cities: the meaning is “would have been cities,” he says, by a reversal of the noun gender. Āṭānāṭā was the name of a city that got its name by the feminine gender.

original: Tasmiṃ ṭhatvāti tasmiṃ padese parakusiṭanāṭānāmake nagare ṭhatvā. Tato ujuṃ uttaradisāyaṃ. Etassāti kasivantanagarassa. Aparabhāge aparakoṭṭhāse, parato icceva attho.
analyzed: tasmin ṭhatvā iti tasmin padese parakusiṭanāṭā nāmake nagare ṭhatvā tatas ujum uttara disāyam etassa ati kasivanta nagarassa apara bhāge apara koṭṭhāse paratas icca eva attho
translated: In the vicinity: in the vicinity, on the other side, is the meaning.

original: Kuveroti tassa purimajātisamudāgataṃ nāmanti teneva pasaṅgena yenāyaṃ sampatti adhigatā,
analyzed: tassa purima jāti samudāgatam tena iva pasaṅgena yena ayam sampatti adhigatā
translated: Kuvera: his name, which he had acquired in a previous existence, by which he had acquired this prosperity.

original: tadassa pubbakammaṃ ācikkhituṃ “ayaṃ kirā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ucchuvappanti ucchusassaṃ.
analyzed: tat assa pubba kammam ācikkhitum ayam kira iti ādi vuttam ucchuvappanti ucchusassam
translated: In order to explain that previous kamma of his, it is said: “It is said that he” and so on. Ucchuvappam: the sugar-cane.

original: Avasesasālāhīti avasesayantasālāhi, nissakkavacanañcetaṃ. Tatthevāti puññatthaṃ dinnasālāyameva.
analyzed: avasesa sālāhi iti avasesa yanta sālāhi nissakka vacanam ca itam tattha iva ati puññattham
translated: With the remaining halls: with the remaining halls, which he was giving away, this being a locative of separation. There itself: in the very halls given for the purpose of merit.

original: Paṭiesantoti pati pati atthe esanto vīmaṃsanto. Na kevalaṃ te vīmaṃsanti eva, atha
analyzed: paṭiesanto ti pati pati atthe esantaḥ vīmaṃsantaḥ na kevalam te vīmaṃsanti eva atha
translated: Seeking: seeking, investigating, the meaning. Not only do they investigate that meaning,

original: kho tamatthaṃ patiṭṭhāpentīti āha “visuṃ visuṃ atthe upaparikkhamānā anusāsamānā”ti.
analyzed: kho tam attham patiṭṭhāpenti iti āha visum visum atthe upaparikkhamānā anusāsamānā iti
translated: but they also establish it. Therefore it is said: “examining, investigating, the meaning in various ways.”

original: Yakkharaṭṭhikāti yakkharaṭṭhādhipatino. Yakkhā ca vessavaṇassa rañño nivesanadvāre
analyzed: yakkharaṭṭhikā ati yakkharaṭṭha adhipatinaḥ yakkhā ca vessavaṇassa rañño nivesana dvāre

original: niyuttā cāti yakkhadovārikā, tesaṃ yakkhadovārikānaṃ.
analyzed: niyuttā ca ati yakkha dovārikā tesam yakkha dovārikānam
translated: And the Yakkhas’ messengers: the Yakkhas’ servants.

translated: Since the water of the ancient lake, heated by the sun’s rays, rises up from below and comes out,🔽therefore it is said that “the water of the lake is taken up by the clouds and falls as rain.”🔽The clouds take up the water from the ancient lake and rain it down.🔽The clouds take up the water from the ancient lake and rain it down.

analyzed: sañjāta phalā nicca pupphitā ati niccam sañjāta pupphā nānā ādi jagaṇa āyutā ati nānāvidhehi

original: Koñcasakuṇehīti sārasasakuntehi.
analyzed: koñca sakuṇehi iti sārasa sakuntehi
translated: The clouds take up the water from the ancient lake and rain it down.

original: “Evaṃ viravantāna”nti iminā tathā vassitavasena “jīvañjīvakā”ti ayaṃ tesaṃ samaññāti🔽dasseti. Uṭṭhavacittakāti etthāpi eseva nayo. Tenāha “evaṃ vassamānā”ti. Pokkharasātakāti
analyzed: evam iminā tathā vassita vasena jīvañjīvakā ati ayam tesam samaññā ti  dasseti uṭṭhavacittakā ti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ tena āha evam vassamānā ati pokkharasātakā ti
translated: “Crying out thus” shows that they are called jīvañjīvakas because they cry out in that way. The same method of explanation applies to the words uṭṭhavacittaka. Hence he says, “crying out thus.” Pokkharasāti

original: pokkharasaṇṭhānatāya “pokkharasātakā”ti evaṃ laddhanāmā.
analyzed: pokkhara saṇṭhāna tāya pokkharasātakā ati evam laddha nāmā
translated: “Crying out thus” : by this he shows that the name “jīvañjīvakas” is due to their crying out in that way. The same method applies to the words “uṭṭhavacittaka” . Therefore he says, “crying out thus.” Pokkharasātikā : they are called “pokkharasātikā” because of their shape, which is like a lotus flower.

original: Sabbakālaṃ sobhatīti sabbautūsu sobhati, na tassā hemantādivasena sobhāvirato atthi.
analyzed: sabbakālam sobhati iti sabba otūsu sobhati na tassāḥ hemanta ādi vasena sobhā virataḥ atthi
translated: They are beautiful at all times : they are beautiful in all seasons; their beauty is not interrupted by the cold season, etc.

original: Evaṃbhūtā ca niccaṃ pupphitajalajathalajapupphatāya, phalabhārabharitarukkhaparivāritatāya,
analyzed: evaṃbhūtā ca niccam pupphita jalaja thalaja puppha tāya phala bhāra bharita rukkha parivārita tāya
translated: And they are always beautiful in this way because of the lotus flowers that bloom in the water and on the land, because of the trees that are laden with fruit,

original: aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatasalilatāya ca nirantaraṃ sobhati.🔽282. Parikammanti pubbupacāraṃ. Parisodhetvāti ekakkharassāpi avirādhanavasena ācariyasantike
analyzed: aṭṭhaṅga samannāgata salila tāya ca nirantaram sobhati  parikammanti pubba upacāram parisodhetvā iti eka kkharassa api avirādhana vasena ācariya santike
translated: and because of the water that possesses the eight qualities.🔽Practice : preliminary work. Having purified : having purified everything in the presence of the teacher without omitting even a single syllable.

original: sabbaṃ sodhetvā. Suṭṭhu uggahitāti parimaṇḍalapadabyañjanāya poriyā vācāya vissaṭṭhāya
analyzed: sabbam sodhetvā suṭṭhu uggahitā ati parimaṇḍala pada byañjanāya poriyā vācāya vissaṭṭhāya
translated: Well-learned : well-learned by means of the circular letters and syllables, by means of the pure Pali language,

original: anelagaḷāya atthassa viññāpanīyā sammadeva uggahitā. Tathā hi “atthañca byañjanañca🔽parisodhetvā”ti vuttaṃ. Atthaṃ jānato eva hi byañjanaṃ parisujjhati, no ajānato.
analyzed: anelagaḷāya atthassa viññāpanīyā sammadeva uggahitā tathā hi atthañca byañjanañca  parisodhetvā iti vuttam attham jānataḥ eva hi byañjanam parisujjhati no a jānataḥ
translated: and which can convey the meaning without difficulty, should be properly learned. For it is said, “Having purified the meaning and the phrasing” . And it is only when one knows the meaning that the phrasing is purified, not otherwise.

original: Padabyañjanānīti padañceva byañjanañca ahāpetvā. Evañhi paripuṇṇā nāma hotīti. Visaṃvādetvāti🔽aññathā katvā. Tejavantaṃ na hoti virajjhanato ceva vimhayatthabhāvato ca. Sabbasoti
analyzed: pada byañjanāni iti padam ca iva byañjanam ca evam hi paripuṇṇā nāma hoti iti  aññathā katvā tejavantam na hoti virajjhanataḥ ca iva vimhayattha bhāvataḥ ca sabbaso ti
translated: “Without omitting the phrasing and the words” : without omitting the phrasing and the words. For it is only then that it is complete.🔽“Misrepresenting” : misconstruing. It is not powerful because it does not inspire confidence and because it does not have the purpose of inspiring wonder.

original: anavasesato ādimajjhapariyosānato. Tejavantaṃ hotīti sabhāvaniruttiṃ avirādhetvā
analyzed: anavasesataḥ ādi majjha pariyosānataḥ tejavantam hoti iti sabhāva niruttim a virādhetvā
translated: “All” : without exception, from beginning to middle to end.

original: suppavattibhāvena sādhanato. Evaṃ payogavipattiṃ pahāya payogasampattiyā sati parittassa
analyzed: suppavatti bhāvena sādhanataḥ evam payoga vipattim pahāya payoga sampattiyā sati parittassa
translated: “Is powerful” : because it is accomplished by the method of correct utterance without violating the inherent nature of the language.

original: atthasādhakataṃ dassetvā idāni ajjhāsayavipattiṃ pahāya ajjhāsayasampattiyā atthasādhakataṃ
analyzed: attha sādhaka tam dassetvā idāni ajjhāsaya vipattim pahāya ajjhāsaya sampattiyāḥ attha sādhaka tam
translated: Having thus shown that the recitation of the Paritta is effective when the method of recitation is correct, he now shows that it is effective when the intention is correct, by abandoning the failure of intention.

original: dassetuṃ “lābhahetū”tiādi vuttaṃ. Idaṃ parittabhaṇanaṃ sattānaṃ anatthapaṭibāhanahetūti
analyzed: dassetum lābha hetu utiādi vuttam idam paritta bhaṇanam sattānam anattha paṭibāhana hetu uti
translated: “For the sake of gain” , etc., is said. This recitation of the Paritta is the cause for warding off the harm of beings.

original: tassa ñāṇakaruṇāpubbakatā nissaraṇapakkho. Mettaṃ purecārikaṃ katvāti mettāmanasikārena
analyzed: tassa ñāṇa karuṇā pubbaka tā nissaraṇa pakkhaḥ mettam purecārikam katvā ati mettā manasikārena
translated: The pre-eminent position of knowledge and compassion is the factor of escape. Having made loving-kindness the forerunner:

original: sattesu hitapharaṇaṃ purakkhatvā.
analyzed: sattesu hita pharaṇam purakkhatvā
translated: having made the spreading of welfare to beings the forerunner by means of attention to loving-kindness.

original: “Vatthuṃ vā”tiādi pubbe catuparisamajjhe katāya sādhanāya bhagavato pavedanaṃ. Gharavatthunti
analyzed: vatthum vā āti ādi pubbe catu parisamajjhe katāya sādhanāya bhagavataḥ pavedanam ghara vatthum ti
translated: “The ground” and so on: this is the announcement to the Blessed One of the proof made in the midst of the four assemblies. The ground of the house:

original: vasanagehaṃ. Nibaddhavāsanti paragehepi nevāsikabhāvena vāsaṃ na labheyya, yaṃ pana
analyzed: vasana geham para gehe ipi nevāsika bhāvena vāsam na labheyya yam pana
translated: the dwelling house. A fixed abode: he would not get a dwelling even in another’s house as a lodger, but that which

original: mahārājānaṃ, yakkhasenāpatīnañca ajānantānaṃyeva kadāci vasitvā gamanaṃ, taṃ appamāṇanti
analyzed: mahā rājānam yakkha senāpatīnam ca a jānantānam yeva kadāci vasitvā gamanam tam appamāṇam ti
translated: he has lived in at some time without the knowledge of the great kings and the generals of the yakkhas, that is immeasurable.

original: adhippāyo. Samitinti yakkhādisamāgamaṃ. Kāmaṃ pāḷiyaṃ “na me so”ti āgataṃ, itaresampi🔽pana mahārājānamattanā ekajjhāsayatāya tesampi ajjhāsayaṃ hadaye ṭhapetvā vessavaṇo
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ samitinti yakkha ādi samāgamam kāmam pāḷiyam na me āgatam itaresam pi  pana mahā rājānam attanā ekajjhāsaya tāya tesam pi ajjhāsayam hadaye ṭhapetvā vessavaṇaḥ
translated: This is the intention. An assembly: a gathering of yakkhas and so on. Although in the text it is stated as “he is not mine,”

original: tathā avoca. Kaññaṃ anu anu vahituṃ ayutto anāvayho, sabbakālaṃ kaññaṃ laddhuṃ ayuttoti
analyzed: tathā avoca kaññam anu anu vahitum ayuttaḥ anāvayhaḥ sabbakālam kaññam laddhum ayuttaḥ ti
translated: nevertheless, because of the single purpose of the other great kings, Vessavana spoke thus, having placed their intention in his heart. He is not fit to carry a girl along, is not a carrier, is not fit to get a girl at any time.

original: attho, taṃ anāvayhaṃ. Tenāha “na āvāhayutta”nti. Na vivayhanti avivayhaṃ, kaññaṃ
analyzed: attho tam anāvayham tena āha na āvāha yuttam ti na vivayhanti a vivayham kaññam
translated: and it is not proper to bring her in. Therefore he said, “Not proper to bring in.” Not proper to take out: not proper to take out a virgin.

original: gahetumayuttanti attho. Tenāha “na vivāhayutta”nti. Āhito ahaṃmāno etthāti attā,
analyzed: gahetum ayuttam ti tena āha na vivāha yuttam ti āhitaḥ ahaṃmānaḥ ettha ati attā
translated: The meaning is: not proper to marry. Therefore he said, “Not proper to marry.” It is a self because a self is placed there.

translated: The meaning is: a self-state. They have a self as their object. Therefore they are called “self-expressions.”

original: “yakkhasenāpatīnaṃ ye manassā, tesa”nti. Āṇāya avarodhitupacārā avaruddhā, te pana🔽āṇāvato paccatthikā nāma hontīti “paccāmittā verino”ti vuttaṃ. Ujjhāpetabbanti heṭṭhā
analyzed: yakkha senāpatīnam ye manassā tesanti āṇāya avarodhitu pacārāḥ avaruddhā te pana  āṇāvataḥ paccatthikāḥ nāma honti iti pacca āmittāḥ verino ti vuttam ujjhāpetabbanti heṭṭhā
translated: “The yakkha generals’ minds are not free from lust for women.” They are not free because they are restrained by the king’s command. But they are enemies of the king who has given the command. Thus it is said: “enemies, adversaries.”

original: katvā cintāpetabbaṃ, taṃ pana ujjhāpanaṃ tesaṃ nīcakiriyāya jānāpanaṃ hotīti āha “jānāpetabbā”ti.
analyzed: katvā cintāpetabbam tam pana ujjhāpanam tesam nīca kiriyāya jānāpanam hoti iti āha jānāpetabbā ati
translated: They should be made to boil with worry: they should be made to think about the matter below and be worried. But this worry is a means of making them know that they are being treated contemptuously. Thus it is said: “They should be made to know.”

original: Parittaparikammakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: paritta parikamma kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the discussion of the preliminary work for the protection

original: Parittassa parikammaṃ kathetabbanti āṭānāṭiyaparittassa parikammaṃ pubbupacāraṭṭhāniyaṃ
analyzed: parittassa parikammam kathetabbanti āṭānāṭiya parittassa parikammam pubba upacāra ṭṭhāniyam
translated: The preliminary work for the protection should be discussed: the preliminary work for the Āṭānāṭiya protection, which is a condition for the protection, should be discussed.

original: mettasuttādi kathetabbaṃ. Evañhi taṃ laddhāsevanaṃ hutvā tejavantaṃ hoti. Tenāha
analyzed: metta sutta ādi kathetabbam evam hi tam laddha āsevanam hutvā tejavantam hoti tena āha
translated: The Mettā Sutta, etc., should be discussed. For in this way it becomes powerful, having been made familiar with the protection. Thus it is said:

original: “paṭhamameva hī”tiādi. Piṭṭhaṃ vā maṃsaṃ vāti vā-saddo aniyamattho, tena macchaghatasūpādiṃ
analyzed: paṭhamam eva hi itiādi piṭṭham vā maṃsam vā ati vā saddaḥ aniyama atthaḥ tena maccha ghata sūpa ādiṃ
translated: “First of all” and so on. The back or the flesh: the word vā has the meaning of non-restriction. Thus it includes fish, meat, curry, etc.

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Otāraṃ labhanti attanā piyāyitabbaāhāravasena piyāyitabbaṭṭhānavasena
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti otāram labhanti attanā piyāyitabba āhāra vasena piyāyitabba ṭṭhāna vasena
translated: They find an opportunity: they find an opportunity to eat what is to be eaten by way of what is to be eaten that is dear to them, and by way of what is to be eaten that is a place dear to them.

original: ca. “Paritta…pe… nisīditabba”nti imināva parittakārakassa bhikkhuno parisuddhipi🔽icchitabbāti dasseti.
analyzed: ca parittape nisīditabbanti iminā ava paritta kārakassa bhikkhuno  icchitabbā ati dasseti
translated: “The one who recites the safeguard … should sit down” shows that the purification of the one who recites the safeguard is to be done by this very method.

original: “Parittakārako…pe… samparivāritenā”ti idaṃ parittakaraṇe bāhirarakkhāsaṃvidhānaṃ.
analyzed: paritta kāra kope samparivāritena ati idam paritta karaṇe bāhira rakkhā saṃvidhānam
translated: “The one who recites the safeguard … should be surrounded” shows the external protection to be arranged for the one who recites the safeguard.

original: “Mettacittaṃ …pe… kātabba”nti idaṃ abbhantararakkhā ubhayato rakkhāsaṃvidhānaṃ. Evañhi
analyzed: metta cittam pe kātabbanti idam abbhantara rakkhā ubhayatas rakkhā saṃvidhānam evam hi
translated: “With a mind of loving-kindness … should be done” shows the internal protection and the protection on both sides to be arranged. For in this way

original: amanussā parittakaraṇassa antarāyaṃ kātuṃ na visahanti. Maṅgalakathā vattabbā pubbupacāravasena.
analyzed: amanussā paritta karaṇassa antarāyam kātum na visahanti maṅgala kathā vattabbā pubba upacāra vasena
translated: demons are unable to create an obstacle for the one who recites the safeguard. The auspicious discourse should be spoken as a preliminary practice.

original: Sabbasannipātoti tasmiṃ vihāre, tasmiṃ vā gāmakhette sabbesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sannipāto.
analyzed: sabba sannipāto ti tasmim vihāre tasmim vā gāmakhette sabbesam bhikkhūnam sannipāto
translated: “The whole gathering” means the gathering of all the monks in that monastery or in that district.

original: Ghosetabbo,“cetiyaṅgaṇe sabbehi sannipatitabba”nti. Anāgantuṃ nāma na labbhati amanussena
analyzed: sabbehi sannipatitabbanti anāgantum nāma na labbhati amanussena
translated: “An announcement should be made: ‘All should gather in the shrine-courtyard.’ ” It is not allowed for anyone not to come, because of the fear of demons

original: buddhāṇābhayena, rājāṇābhayena ca. Gahitakāpadesena amanussova pucchito hotīti āha
analyzed: buddhāṇābhayena rājāṇābhayena ca gahitaka apadesena amanussaḥ uva pucchitaḥ hoti iti āha
translated: and because of the fear of the king. When the announcement is made, it is as if the demons themselves are being questioned, says the commentary.

original: “amanussaggahitako ‘tvaṃ ko nāmā’ti pucchitabbo”ti. Mālāgandhādīsu pūjanatthaṃ viniyuñjiyamānesu.
analyzed: a manussagga hitako tvam kaḥ nāma ati pucchitabbaḥ ti mālā gandha ādīsu pūjana attham viniyuñjiyamānesu
translated: When garlands, scents, etc., are offered for the purpose of worship.

original: Pattīti tuyhaṃ pattidānaṃ. Piṇḍapāte pattīti piṇḍapāte diyyamāne pattidānaṃ. Devatānanti🔽yakkhasenāpatīnaṃ. Parittaṃ bhaṇitabbanti etthāpi “mettacittaṃ purecārikaṃ katvā”ti
analyzed: patti iti tuyham patti dānam piṇḍapāte patti iti piṇḍapāte diyyamāne patti dānam devatā nanti  yakkha senāpatīnam parittam bhaṇitabbanti ettha api metta cittam purecārikam katvā ati
translated: “A bowl” means the offering of a bowl to you. “A bowl in alms food” means the offering of a bowl when alms food is being given. “To deities” means

original: ca “maṅgalakathā vattabbā”ti ca “vihārassa upavane”ti evamādi ca sabbaṃ gihīnaṃ parittakaraṇe
analyzed: ca maṅgala kathā vattabbā ati ca vihārassa upavane ti evamādi ca sabbam gihīnam paritta karaṇe
translated: to the generals of the yakkhas. “A protection formula should be recited” . Here too all the preliminary work described in the section on the protection formula for householders should be done:🔽“Having made loving-kindness the forerunner” ,

original: vuttaṃ parikammaṃ kātabbameva.🔽Sarīre adhimuccatīti sarīraṃ anupavisitvā viya āvisanto yathā gahitakassa vasena🔽na vattati, attano eva vasena vattati, evaṃ adhimuccati adhiṭṭhahitvā tiṭṭhati. Tenāha
analyzed: vuttam parikammam kātabbam eva  sarīre adhimuccati iti sarīram an upavisitvā viya āvisantaḥ yathā gahitakassa vasena  na vattati attanaḥ eva vasena vattati evam adhimuccati adhiṭṭhahitvā tiṭṭhati tena āha
translated: “a discourse on the benefits should be given” ,🔽“in the park belonging to the monastery” , etc.🔽“He becomes intent upon the body” : he becomes intent upon it as if entering into it, so that it does not act according to the will of the one who has seized it but acts according to his own will. Therefore it is said:

original: “āvisatīti tasseva vevacana”nti. Laggatīti tattheva laggo allīno hoti. Tenāha “na
analyzed: āvisati iti tassa iva laggati tena āha na
translated: “‘He enters into it’ is a synonym for that” . “He sticks to it” : he sticks to it, he is attached to it. Therefore it is said:

original: apetī”ti. Rogaṃ vaḍḍhentoti dhātūnaṃ samabhāvena vattituṃ appadānavasena uppannaṃ
analyzed: apeti iti rogam vaḍḍhento ti dhātūnam sama bhāvena vattitum appadāna vasena uppannam
translated: “He will take it away.”🔽Increasing the sickness: increasing the sickness arisen by way of not giving a chance to be digested by way of the elements being in balance.

original: rogaṃ vaḍḍhento. Dhātūnaṃ visamabhāvāpattiyā ca āhārassa ca aruccanena gahitakassa
analyzed: rogam vaḍḍhentaḥ dhātūnam visama bhāva āpattiyā ca āhārassa ca aruccanena gahitakassa
translated: And by the elements coming to be out of balance and by the food not being digested,

original: sarīre lohitaṃ sussati, maṃsaṃ milāyati, taṃ panassa yakkho dhātukkhobhanimittatāya
analyzed: sarīre lohitam sussati maṃsam milāyati tam panassa yakkhaḥ dhātu khobha nimitta tāya
translated: the blood dries up in the body and the flesh wastes away. But that spirit is as if he were making it happen by way of the elements being disturbed.

original: karonto viya hotīti vuttaṃ “appamaṃsalohitaṃ karonto”ti.
analyzed: karontaḥ viya hoti iti vuttam appa maṃsa lohitam karontaḥ ti
translated: Therefore it is said: “making it have little flesh and blood.”🔽Their names should be spoken of by way of the names of Indra and so on.🔽After that: after the announcement.

original: 283. Tesaṃ nāmāni indādināmabhāvena voharitabbato. Tatoti tato ārocanato paraṃ. Teti
analyzed: tesam nāmāni inda ādi nāma bhāvena voharitabbato tatoti tatas ārocanataḥ param
translated: Those: the spirit generals.

original: yakkhasenāpatayo. Okāso na bhavissatīti bhikkhubhikkhuniyo, upāsakaupāsikāyo viheṭhetuṃ
analyzed: yakkha senāpatayaḥ okāsaḥ na bhavissati iti bhikkhu bhikkhuniyaḥ upāsaka upāsikāyaḥ viheṭhetum
translated: There will be no opportunity: there will be no chance to harass the bhikkhus and bhikkhunis, the male and female lay followers,

original: avasaro na bhavissati sammadeva ārakkhāya vihitattāti.
analyzed: avasaraḥ na bhavissati sammadeva ārakkhāya vihita ttā ti
translated: because of the protection being properly arranged.

original: Āṭānāṭiyasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā.
analyzed: āṭānāṭiya sutta vaṇṇanāya līna ttha ppakāsanā
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the words of the Āṭānāṭiya Sutta is ended.

original: 10. Saṅgītisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saṅgīti sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourse on the Recitation

original: 296. Dasasahassacakkavāḷeti buddhakhettabhūte dasasahassaparimāṇe cakkavāḷe. Tattha
analyzed: dasa sahassa cakkavāḷā iti buddha khetta bhūte dasa sahassa parimāṇe cakkavāḷe tattha
translated: Ten thousand world-systems: in a world-system consisting of a thousand million worlds. There

original: hi imasmiṃ cakkavāḷe devamanussāyeva katādhikārā, itaresu devā visesabhāgino. Tena🔽vuttaṃ “dasasahassacakkavāḷe ñāṇajālaṃ pattharitvā”ti. Ñāṇajālapattharaṇanti ca tesaṃ
analyzed: hi imasmin cakkavāḷe deva manussāya iva kata adhikārāḥ itaresu devāḥ visesa bhāginaḥ tena  vuttam dasa sahassa cakkavāḷe ñāṇa jālam pattharitvā iti ñāṇa jāla pattharaṇam ca tesam
translated: For only gods and men in this world-sphere have made the requisite preparation for understanding the four noble truths. In the other world-spheres the gods are not destined to share in the special benefit of understanding the four noble truths. Therefore

original: tesaṃ sattānaṃ āsayādivibhāvanavasena ñāṇassa pavattanameva. Tenāha “lokaṃ volokayamāno”ti,
analyzed: tesam sattānam āsaya ādi vibhāvana vasena ñāṇassa pavattanam eva tena āha lokam volokayamānaḥ iti
translated: it is said, “Having extended his knowledge-net over the ten-thousand world-systems.” And “having extended his knowledge-net” means that he extended his knowledge by discerning the dispositions, etc., of beings in those world-systems. Therefore it is said, “looking down with his Buddha-eye upon the world.”

original: sattalokaṃ byavalokayamāno āsayānusayacaritādhimuttiādike visesato ogāhetvā passantoti🔽attho. Maṅgalaṃ bhaṇāpessanti “taṃ tesaṃ āyatiṃ visesādhigamassa vijjāṭṭhānaṃ hutvā🔽dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissā”ti. Tīhi piṭakehi sammasitvāti tipiṭakato ekakadukādinā
analyzed: satta lokam byavalokayamānaḥ āsaya anusaya carita adhimutti ādike visesataḥ ogāhetvā passanto ti  atthaḥ maṅgalam bhaṇāpessanti tam tesam āyatim visesa adhigamassa vijjāṭṭhānam hutvā  dīgharattam hitāya sukhāya bhavissāti tīhi piṭakehi sammasitvā ati ti piṭakataḥ ekaka duka ādinā
translated: Looking down upon the world of beings, seeing it in its particularities of disposition, latent tendency, temperament, and spiritual faculty.🔽“He will recite the auspicious stanzas” means: “They will be for them a basis for knowledge that will lead to the attainment of distinction in the future, and will be for their benefit and happiness for a long time.”🔽“Having examined with the three Piṭakas” means: having examined and investigated by collecting together what can be collected together in the three Piṭakas by ones, by twos, etc.

original: saṅgahetabbassa saṅgaṇhanavasena sammasitvā vīmaṃsitvā. Ñātuṃ icchitā atthā pañhā,
analyzed: saṅgahetabbassa saṅgaṇhana vasena sammasitvā vīmaṃsitvā ñātum icchitā atthā pañhā
translated: Questions are meanings that one wishes to know.

original: te pana imasmiṃ sutte ekakādivasena āgatā sahassaṃ, cuddasa cāti āha “cuddasapañhādhikena
analyzed: te pana imasmin sutte ekaka ādi vasena āgatā sahassam cuddasa ca ati āha cuddasa pañha adhikena
translated: But in this sutta they are one thousand and fourteen, coming in ones, twos, etc. Therefore it is said, “with fourteen questions in excess of one thousand.”

original: pañhasahassena paṭimaṇḍetvā”ti. Evamidha sampiṇḍetvā dassite pañhe parato suttapariyosāne
analyzed: pañha sahassena paṭimaṇḍetvā ti evam idha sampiṇḍetvā dassite pañhe paratas sutta pariyosāne
translated: and with a thousand questions it is adorned.🔽Here the questions are shown in brief. Later on, at the end of the sutta,

original: “ekakavasena dve pañhā kathitā”tiādinā vibhāgena parigaṇetvā sayameva dassessati.
analyzed: ekaka vasena dve pañhā kathitā ati ādinā vibhāgena parigaṇetvā sayam eva dassessati
translated: he will show them himself by counting them out in detail, saying, “Two questions are asked in the singular number” and so on.

original: Ubbhatakanavasandhāgāravaṇṇanā🔽297. Uccādhiṭṭhānatāya taṃ sandhāgāraṃ bhūmito ubbhataṃ viyāti “ubbhataka”nti nāmaṃ
analyzed: ucca adhiṭṭhāna tāya tam sandhāgāram bhūmitaḥ ubbhatam viyāti ubbhatakam nti nāmam
translated: The description of the high-roofed reception hall🔽The hall is called “high-roofed” because it is built high up from the ground, like a raised platform. That is why it is said, “It is called high-roofed because it is high.”

original: labhati. Tenāha “uccattā vā evaṃ vutta”nti. Sandhāgārasālāti ekā mahāsālā. Uyyogakaraṇādīsu
analyzed: labhati tena āha uccattā vā evam vutta nti sandhāgāra sālā ati ekā mahā sālā uyyoga karaṇa ādīsu
translated: The reception hall is a large hall.

original: hi rājāno tattha ṭhatvā “ettakā purato gacchantu, ettakā pacchā”tiādinā tattha nisīditvā
analyzed: hi rājāno tattha ṭhatvā ettakā puratas gacchantu ettakā pacchā atiādinā tattha nisīditvā
translated: For when kings are engaged in work such as military campaigns, they sit there and say, “So many should go in front, so many should go behind,” and so on.

original: sandhaṃ karonti mariyādaṃ bandhanti, tasmā taṃ ṭhānaṃ “sandhāgāra”nti vuccati. Uyyogaṭṭhānato
analyzed: sandham karonti mariyādam bandhanti tasmā tam ṭhānam sandhāgāranti vuccati uyyoga ṭṭhānato
translated: They make an agreement and set a limit there, and that is why the place is called “reception hall.”

original: ca āgantvā yāva gehaṃ gomayaparibhaṇḍādivasena paṭijagganaṃ karonti, tāva ekaṃ dve
analyzed: ca āgantvā yāva geham gomaya paribhaṇḍa ādi vasena paṭijagganam karonti tāva ekam dve
translated: And after coming from the place of work, they take care of the cowdung, the cleaning materials, and so on, until they go home.

original: divase te rājāno tattha santhambhantītipi sandhāgāraṃ, tesaṃ rājūnaṃ saha atthānusāsanaagārantipi🔽sandhāgāranti. Yasmā vā te tattha sannipatitvā “imasmiṃ kāle kasituṃ vaṭṭati, imasmiṃ
analyzed: divase te rājāno tattha santhambhanti itipi sandhāgāram tesam rājūnam saha  yasmai vā te tattha sannipatitvā imasmin kāle kasitum vaṭṭati imasmin
translated: And because the kings were supported there, it was also called the “Hall of Support” (sandhāgāra).🔽Or it was the “Hall of Support” (sandhāgāra) because they supported there the affairs of household life, such as “At this time it is proper to plough,” “At this time to sow,”

original: kālevapitu”ntiādinā gharāvāsakiccaṃ sandharanti, tasmā chiddāvachiddaṃ gharāvāsaṃ
analyzed: sandharanti chidda avachiddam ghara āvāsam
translated: and so on. And because they supported there the household life with its gaps and openings, it was also called the “Hall of Support.”🔽And because the gods were there, it was also called the “Hall of the Gods” (sālā).

original: tattha sandharantītipi sandhāgāraṃ, sā eva sālāti sandhāgārasālā. Devatāti gharadevatā.
analyzed: sandharanti iti pi sandhāgāram sā eva sālā ati sandhāgāra sālā devatā ati ghara devatā
translated: The gods were the household gods.🔽Because they had not lived there before, it is said: “by no human being.”

original: Nivāsavasena anajjhāvutthattā “kenaci vā manussabhūtenā”ti vuttaṃ. Kammakaraṇavasena
analyzed: nivāsa vasena anajjhāvuttha ttā kenaci vā manussa bhūtena ati vuttam kamma karaṇa vasena
translated: But because they were engaged in work,🔽the men were able to sit down there and so on.

original: pana manussā tattha nisajjādīni kappesumeva. “Sayameva pana satthu idhāgamanaṃ amhākaṃ
analyzed: pana manussā tattha nisajja ādīni kappesum eva sayam eva pana satthu idha āgamanam amhākam
translated: “The Teacher’s coming here is due to our own merit.

original: puññavaseneva, aho mayaṃ puññavanto”ti haṭṭhatuṭṭhā evaṃ sammā cintesunti dassento “amhehī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: puña vasena iva aho mayam puññavanto ti haṭṭha tuṭṭhāḥ evam sammā cintesunti dassentaḥ amhehi itiādim āha
translated: Oh, we are so meritorious!” Thus, rejoicing and delighted, they thought correctly, and showing this, he said: “By us.”

original: 298. Aṭṭakāti cittakammakaraṇatthaṃ baddhā mañcakā. Muttamattāti tāvadeva sandhāgāre
analyzed: aṭṭakā ati citta kamma karaṇa attham baddhā mañcakā mutta mattā ati tāvat eva sandhāgāre
translated: “Eight-legged” means couches made for the purpose of decoration. “Just enough” means just enough to go to the assembly hall.

original: navakammassa niṭṭhāpitabhāvamāha, tena“acirakārita”ntiādinā vuttamevatthaṃ vibhāveti.🔽Araññaṃ ārāmo āramitabbaṭṭhānaṃ etesanti araññārāmā. Santharaṇaṃ santhari, sabbo
analyzed: nava kammassa niṭṭhāpita bhāvam āha tena acirakārita nti ādinā vuttam eva attham vibhāveti  araññam ārāmaḥ āramitabba ṭṭhānam etesanti arañña ārāmā santharaṇam santhari sabbo
translated: 8. ‘Eight-legged couches’: couches made for the purpose of decoration. ‘Just enough’: he says that the work of the nine-panel gate was finished just then. Thus he explains the meaning already stated by ‘not long after it was made’ and so on.

original: sakalo santhari etthāti sabbasanthari, bhāvanapuṃsakaniddesoyaṃ. Tenāha “yathā sabbaṃ🔽santhataṃ hoti, eva”nti.🔽299. Samantapāsādikoti samantato sabbabhāgena pasādāvaho cāturiyaso. “Asītihatthaṃ🔽ṭhānaṃ gaṇhātī”ti idaṃ buddhānaṃ kāyappabhāya pakatiyā asītihatthe ṭhāne abhibyāpanato
analyzed: sakalaḥ ettha ati sabbasanthari bhāva napuṃsaka niddesaḥ yam tena āha yathā sabbam  santhatam hoti evanti  samantapāsādiko ti samantataḥ sabba bhāgena pasāda āvahaḥ cāturiyasaḥ asīti hattham  ṭhānam gaṇhāti iti idam buddhānam kāya ppabhāya pakatiyā asīti hatthe ṭhāne abhibyāpanataḥ
translated: 9. ‘Forest-dwellers’: those who dwell in the forest. ‘Spreader’: one who spreads out. ‘All-spreader’: one in whom all is spread out. This is a masculine form in -i. That is why he says ‘so that it is all spread out’.

original: vuttaṃ. Iddhānubhāvena pana anantaṃ aparimāṇaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjotateva. Nīlapītalohitodātamañjaṭṭhapabhassaravasena
analyzed: vuttam iddha anubhāvena pana anantam aparimāṇam ṭhānam nīla pīta lohita udāta mañjaṭṭha pabhassara vasena
translated: 10. ‘All-round pleasing’: all-round delightful by all means. ‘Occupies a place eighty leagues in extent’: this is said because the natural radiance of Buddhas pervades a place eighty leagues in extent. But by the power of supernormal power it illuminates an infinite, immeasurable place. By means of the radiance of blue, yellow, red, white, crimson, and crystal.

original: chabbaṇṇā. Sabbe disābhāgāti sarīrappabhāya bāhullato vuttaṃ.
analyzed: chabbaṇṇā sabbe disā bhāgā ti sarīra ppabhāya bāhullataḥ vuttam
translated: and six-coloured. All directions: this is said because of the abundance of the radiance of the body.

original: Abbhamahikādīhi upakkiliṭṭhaṃ suññaṃ na sobhati, tārakācitaṃ pana antalikkhaṃ tāsaṃ
analyzed: abbha mahika ādīhi upakkiliṭṭham suññam na sobhati tārakā citam pana antalikkham tāsam
translated: The empty sky does not shine when it is obscured by mist and so on, but the sky shines when the stars are shining all around in the sky.

original: pabhāhi samantato vijjotamānaṃ virocatīti āha “samuggatatārakaṃ viya gaganatala”nti.
analyzed: pabhāhi samantataḥ vijjotamānam virocati iti āha samuggata tārakam viya gagana talanti
translated: Therefore it is said, “like the sky with the stars shining.”

original: Sabbapāliphulloti mūlato paṭṭhāya yāva sākhaggā phullo. “Paṭipāṭiyāṭhapitāna”ntiādi
analyzed: sabba pāli phullo ti mūlataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva phullo
translated: All in full bloom: from the roots up to the tips of the branches. “As if they were planted in a row”

original: parikappūpamā. Tathā hi viya-saddaggahaṇaṃ kataṃ. Siriyā siriṃ abhibhavamānaṃ viyāti🔽attano sobhāya tesaṃ sobhanti attho. “Bhikkhūpi sabbevā”ti idaṃ nesaṃ “appicchā”tiādinā
analyzed: parikappu upamā tathā hi katam siriyā sirim abhibhavamānam viyāti  attanaḥ sobhāya tesam sobhanti atthaḥ bhikkhū upi sabbe iva ati idam nesam appicchā ti ādinā
translated: is a simile. For the word “like” is used in this way. Outshining the beauty of the beauty of the city:🔽the meaning is that by their own beauty they outshine the beauty of the city.🔽All the bhikkhus too: this should be construed in terms of the mundane qualities mentioned in the above passage beginning, “They were few in their desires.”

original: vuttaguṇesu lokiyaguṇānaṃ vasena yojetabbaṃ. Na hi te sabbeva dasakathāvatthulābhino.
analyzed: vutta guṇesu lokiya guṇānam vasena yojetabbam na hi te sabbe iva dasa kathā vatthu lābhino
translated: For not all of them were masters of the ten analytical knowledges.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “suttantaṃ āvajjetvā…pe… arahattaṃ pāpuṇissantī”ti. Tasmā ye tattha ariyā,
analyzed: tena vuttam suttantam āvajjetvā āpe arahattam pāpuṇissanti iti tasmā ye tattha ariyā
translated: Therefore it is said, “having recalled the sutta … they will attain Arahantship.”

original: te sabbesampi padānaṃ vasena bodhitā honti. Ye pana puthujjanā, te lokiyaguṇadīpakehi
analyzed: te sabbesam pi padānam vasena bodhitāḥ honti ye pana puthujjanāḥ te lokiya guṇa dīpakehi
translated: They are enlightened in all the stages. But the ordinary men are enlightened by the light of the worldly virtues.

original: padehīti na tathā heṭṭhā “asītimahātherā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Pubbe arahattabhāgino gahitā.🔽Rūpakāyassa asītianubyañjana-paṭimaṇḍita-dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇakāyappabhābyāmappabhāketumālāvicittatāva🔽buddhaveso. Chabbaṇṇā buddharasmiyo vissajjentassa bhagavato kāyassa ālokitavilokitādīsu
analyzed: padehi iti na tathā heṭṭhā asi iti mahā thera ti ādi vuttam pubbe arahatta bhāginaḥ gahitā  rūpa kāyassa asīti anubyañjana paṭimaṇḍita dvattiṃsa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇa kāya ppabhā byāma ppabhā ketumālā vicitta tāva  chabbaṇṇāḥ buddha rasmiyaḥ vissajjentassa bhagavataḥ kāyassa ālokita vilokita ādīsu
translated: The light of the Buddha is not mentioned here as it has been mentioned in the previous chapter on the eighty great elders.🔽The Buddha’s beauty is the body of the Buddha adorned with the eighty minor characteristics and the thirty-two major characteristics of a great man, and the body’s radiance, which is variegated with a garland of light.🔽The Buddha’s splendour is the Buddha’s radiance, which is the highest of all radiances, and which is unique to the Buddha, and which is the Buddha’s extreme peacefulness, and which is seen in the Blessed One’s looking straight ahead, looking to the right, looking to the left, and so on.

original: paramukkaṃsagato buddhāveṇiko accantupasamo buddhavilāso. Assanti tassaṃ.🔽Sandhāgārānumodanapaṭisaṃyuttāti “sītaṃ uṇhaṃ paṭihantī”tiādinā nayena sandhāgāraguṇūpasañhitā
analyzed: paramukkaṃsagataḥ buddha āveṇikaḥ accantupasamaḥ buddha vilāsaḥ  sandhā āgāra anumodana paṭisaṃyuttā ati sītam uṇham paṭihanti iti ādinā nayena sandhā āgāra guṇa upasañhitā
translated: The Buddha’s glory is the Buddha’s glory, which is the Buddha’s glory that is possessed by the Buddha.🔽The recitation of the verses of rejoicing connected with the Rest House is the recitation of the verses of rejoicing connected with the Rest House, which is connected with the qualities of the Rest House in the way beginning, “The cold is warded off, the heat is warded off” .

original: sandhāgārakaraṇapuññānisaṃsabhāvinī. Pakiṇṇakakathāti saṅgītianāruḷhā suṇantānaṃ
analyzed: sandhā āgāra karaṇa puññā nisaṃsa bhāvinī pakiṇṇaka kathā ati saṅgīti an āruḷhā
translated: The miscellaneous talk is the talk that is not included in the recitation, and which is for the benefit of those who listen to it.

original: ajjhāsayānurūpatāya vividhavipulahetūpamāsamālaṅkatā nānānayavicittā vitthārakathā.
analyzed: ajjhāsayā anurūpa tāya nānā naya vicittā vitthāra kathā
translated: and the detailed explanation is variegated with various methods, being adorned with various similes for the abundant causes in accordance with the inclinations of the disciples.

original: Tenāha “tadā hī”tiādi. Ākāsagaṅgaṃ otārento viya nirupakkilesatāya suvisuddhena,
analyzed: tena āha tadā hi itiādi ākāsagaṅgam nirupakkilesa tāya su visuddhena
translated: Hence he said “Then” , etc. He said “with a pure heart” as if pouring out the river of the sky, because of its being free from defilement,

original: vipulodāratāya aparimeyyena ca atthena suṇantānaṃ kāyacittapariḷāhavūpasamanato.
analyzed: vipula udāra tāya aparimeyyena ca atthena suṇantānam kāya citta pariḷāha vūpasamanato
translated: and because of its being able to allay the bodily and mental distress of the listeners by means of its immeasurable and abundant meaning.

original: Pathavojaṃ ākaḍḍhanto viya aññesaṃ sudukkaratāya, mahāsāratāya vā atthassa. Mahājambuṃ
analyzed: pathavojam ākaḍḍhantaḥ viya aññesam su dukkara tāya mahā sāra tāya vā atthassa mahājambum
translated: He said “with a great heart” as if drawing out the earth, because of the meaning being very difficult to be drawn out by others, or because of its being a great essence.

original: matthake gahetvā cālento viya cālanapaccayaṭṭhānavasena pubbenāparaṃ anusandhānato.🔽Yojaniya…pe… pāyamāno viya desanaṃ catusaccayante pakkhipitvā atthavedadhammavedasseva
analyzed: matthake gahetvā cālentaḥ viya cālana paccaya ṭṭhāna vasena pubbena aparam anusandhānato  pāyamānaḥ viya desanam catu accaya nte pakkhipitvā atthaveda dhammavedassa iva
translated: He said “with a heart that was steady” as if shaking the great rose-apple tree by seizing it at the top, because of the connection of the later with the earlier by way of the condition of shaking.🔽He said “with a heart that was full of loving-kindness” as if nourishing a child, because of the inclusion of the essence of the sweet deathless state by the attainment of the knowledge of the meaning and the knowledge of the Dhamma by placing the teaching in the four noble truths.

original: labhāpanena sātamadhuradhammāmatarasūpasaṃharaṇato. Madhugaṇḍanti madhupaṭalaṃ.
analyzed: labhāpanena madhu paṭalam
translated: Madhugaṇḍa means a layer of honey.

original: 300. “Tuṇhībhūtaṃ tuṇhībhūta”nti byāpanicchāyaṃ idaṃ āmeḍitavacananti dassetuṃ “yaṃ
analyzed: tuṇhībhūtam idam dassetum yaṃ
translated: “Tuṇhībhūtaṃ tuṇhībhūta” is a word of emphasis in order to show that it is a word of entreaty.

original: yandisa”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Anuviloketvāti ettha anu-saddo “parī”ti iminā samānattho,🔽vilokanañcettha satthu cakkhudvayenapi icchitabbanti “maṃsacakkhunā…pe… tato tato
analyzed: vuttam anuviloketvā ti ettha anu saddo pari iti iminā samānatthaḥ  vilokanam ca ittha satthu cakkhu dvayena api icchitabbanti tato tato
translated: and so on. Looking around: here the prefix anu has the same meaning as pari.🔽And looking is to be understood as by the two eyes of the Teacher.

original: viloketvā”ti saṅkhepato vatvā tamatthaṃ vitthārato dassetuṃ “maṃsacakkhunā hī”tiādi
analyzed: viloketvā iti saṅkhepataḥ vatvā tam attham vitthārataḥ dassetum maṃsa cakkhunā hi itiādi
translated: After briefly stating, “looking around with his fleshly eye,” etc., he said, “For with his fleshly eye the Exalted One,” etc., in order to show the meaning in detail.

original: vuttaṃ. Hatthena kucchitaṃ kataṃ hatthakukkuccaṃ kukatameva kukkuccanti katvā. Evaṃ
analyzed: vuttam hatthena kucchitam katam hattha kukkuccam kukatam eva kukkuccanti katvā evam
translated: The “remorse of the hand” is the remorse made by the hand, that is, the hand’s remorse. The “remorse of the foot” is to be understood in the same way.

original: pādakukkuccaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Niccalā nisīdiṃsu attano suvinītabhāvena, buddhagāravena
analyzed: pāda kukkuccam daṭṭhabbam niccalāḥ nisīdiṃsu attano su vinīta bhāvena buddha gāravena
translated: They sat down without moving, out of their own well-bred nature and out of respect for the Buddha.

original: ca. “Ālokaṃ pana vaḍḍhayitvā”tiādi kadāci bhagavā evampi karotīti adhippāyena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ca ālokam pana vaḍḍhayitvā atiādi kadāci bhagavā evam pi karoti iti adhippāyena vuttam
translated: The statement, “having increased the light,” etc., is made with the intention that sometimes the Exalted One does this.

original: Na hi satthu sāvakānaṃ viya evaṃ payogasampādanīyametaṃ ñāṇaṃ. Tirohitavidūravattanipi
analyzed: na hi satthu sāvakānam viya evam payoga sampādanīyam etam ñāṇam
translated: For this knowledge is not to be perfected by effort in the way that it is for disciples.🔽It should be investigated whether the operation of the fleshly eye in regard to hidden and distant objects is accepted.

original: rūpagate maṃsacakkhuno pavattiyā icchitattā vīmaṃsitabbaṃ. Arahattupagaṃ arahattapadaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: rūpa gate maṃsa cakkhuno pavattiyāḥ icchita ttā vīmaṃsitabbam arahatta upagam arahatta padaṭṭhānam
translated: It is the basis for the state of arahantship.

original: Cakkhutalesu nimittaṃ ṭhapetvāti bhāvanānuyogasampattiyā sabbesaṃ tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: cakkhu talesu nimittam ṭhapetvā ati bhāvanā anuyoga sampattiyā sabbesam tesam bhikkhūnam
translated: “Having established the sign in the eye-sockets” means that, through the excellence of his practice of development,

original: cakkhutalesu labbhamānaṃ santindriyavigatathinamiddhatākārasaṅkhātaṃ nimittaṃ attano
analyzed: cakkhu talesu labbhamānam santindriya vigata thinamiddha tā ākāra saṅkhātam nimittam attano
translated: “Having set up a sign in the eyes of the bhikkhus” means that, having set up in his own mind, having considered, the sign called the state of having faculties that are clear and free from faintheartedness and drowsiness, which is found in the eyes of all those bhikkhus who are endowed with the requisites for the practice of meditation.

original: hadaye ṭhapetvā sallakkhetvā. Kasmā āgilāyati koṭisatasahassahatthināgānaṃ balaṃ🔽dhārentassāti codakassa adhippāyo. Ācariyo esa saṅkhārānaṃ sabhāvo, yadidaṃ aniccatā.🔽Ye pana aniccā, te ekanteneva udayavayapaṭipīḷitatāya dukkhā eva, dukkhasabhāvesu
analyzed: hadaye ṭhapetvā sallakkhetvā kasmai āgilāyati koṭi sata sahassa hatthi nāgānam balam  dhārentassa ati codakassa adhippāyaḥ ācariyaḥ esa saṅkhārānam sabhāvaḥ yat idam anicca tā  ye pana aniccā te ekantena iva udaya vaya paṭipīḷita tāya dukkhāḥ eva dukkha sabhāvesu
translated: “Why does he get tired? Bearing the strength of a hundred thousand mighty elephants” is the intention of the questioner. This is the nature of formations, namely, impermanence.

original: tesu satthu kāye dukkhuppattiyā ayaṃ paccayoti dassetuṃ “bhagavato hī”tiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Piṭṭhivāto uppajji, so ca kho pubbe katakammapaccayā. Svāyamattho paramatthadīpaniyaṃ
analyzed: tesu satthu kāye dukkha uppattiyāḥ ayam paccayaḥ ti dassetum bhagavataḥ hi itiādi vuttam  piṭṭhivātaḥ uppajji saḥ ca kho pubbe kata kamma paccayā
translated: But those who are impermanent are entirely subject to suffering because they are oppressed by rise and fall. In order to show that the arising of suffering in the Master’s body was a condition for the arising of the wind in his back, the following was stated: “The Blessed One’s back became painful” and so on.

original: udānaṭṭhakathāyaṃ āgatanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: udāna ṭṭhakathā ayam āgata nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: The back wind arose, and that was due to a condition of kamma done in the past. This meaning should be understood by the method stated in the Udāna Commentary, which explains the ultimate sense .

original: Bhinnanigaṇṭhavatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhinna nigaṇṭha vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the naked ascetic

original: 301. Heṭṭhā vuttameva pāsādikasuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ.🔽302. Svākhyātaṃ dhammaṃ desetukāmoti svākhyātaṃ katvā dhammaṃ kathetukāmo, satthārā🔽vā svākhyātaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ kathetukāmo. Satthārā desitadhammameva hi
analyzed: heṭṭhā vuttam eva pāsādika sutta vaṇṇanāyam  su ākhyātam dhammam desetu kāmo iti su ākhyātam katvā dhammam kathetu kāmo satthārā  vā su ākhyātam dhammam sayam bhikkhūnam kathetu kāmo satthārā desita dhammam eva hi
translated: The rest is as stated in the commentary on the Pāsādikasutta .

original: tato tato gahetvā sāvakā sabrahmacārīnaṃ kathenti.🔽Ekakavaṇṇanā🔽303. Samaggehi bhāsitabbanti aññamaññaṃ samaggehi hutvā bhāsitabbaṃ, sajjhāyitabbañceva
analyzed: tatas tatas gahetvā sāvakāḥ sabrahmacārīnam kathenti  ekaka vaṇṇanā  samaggehi bhāsitabbanti aññam aññam samaggehi hutvā bhāsitabbam sajjhāyitabbam ca eva
translated: Desiring to teach the Dhamma that is well proclaimed: desiring to teach the Dhamma that is well proclaimed, having made it well proclaimed, desiring to teach the Dhamma to the bhikkhus himself, or desiring to teach the Dhamma that has been taught by the Master. For disciples teach their fellow brahma-farers, taking the Dhamma taught by the Master here and there.🔽The commentary on the first section is ended.

original: vaṇṇetabbañcāti attho. Yathā pana samaggehi saṅgāyanaṃ hoti, tampi dassetuṃ “ekavacanehī”tiādi
analyzed: vaṇṇetabbam ca iti atthaḥ yathā pana samaggehi saṅgāyanam hoti tam pi dassetum ekavacanehi itiādi
translated: To be recited in unison: the meaning is that it should be recited and recited by those who are in agreement with each other. But in order to show how the recitation is done by those who are in agreement, it is said “in a single utterance” , etc.

original: vuttaṃ. Ekavacanehīti virodhābhāvena samānavacanehi. Tenāha “aviruddhavacanehī”tiādi.
analyzed: vuttam eka vacanehi iti virodha abhāvena samāna vacanehi tena āha aviruddha vacanehi itiādi
translated: In a single utterance: in a single utterance without contradiction. Hence it is said, “in non-contradictory utterances” , etc.

original: Sāmaggirasaṃ dassetukāmoti yasmiṃ dhamme saṅgāyane sāmaggirasānubhavanaṃ icchitaṃ
analyzed: sāmaggirasam dassetu kāmaḥ iti yasmin dhamme saṅgāyane sāmaggirasa anubhavanam icchitam
translated: Desiring to show the expression of agreement: the expression of agreement is desired in the Dhamma that is being recited.

original: desanākusalatāya, tattha ekakadukatikādivasena bahudhā sāmaggirasaṃ dassetukāmo.
analyzed: desanā kusala tāya tattha ekaka duka tika ādi vasena bahudhā sāmaggi rasam dassetu kāmaḥ
translated: and he wishes to show the word “harmony” in many ways, by ones, twos, etc.,

original: Sabbe sattāti anavasesā sattā, te pana bhavabhedato saṅkhepeneva bhinditvā dassento
analyzed: sabbe sattā ati anavasesā sattā te pana bhava bhedato saṅkhepena iva bhinditvā dassento
translated: “All beings” are beings without exception. But he shows them by dividing them briefly according to the kinds of becoming,

original: “kāmabhavādīsū”tiādimāha. Byadhikaraṇānampi bāhiratthasamāso hoti yathā “urasilomo”ti
analyzed: kāma bhava ādīsu iti ādim āha bāhirattha samāsaḥ yathā
translated: saying “in the four kinds of nutriment, etc.” The compound is a bahubbīhi with a locative base, like “chest-hair” .

original: āha “āhārato ṭhiti etesanti āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti. Tiṭṭhati etenāti ṭhiti, āhāro ṭhiti
analyzed: āha āhārataḥ etesanti āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati tiṭṭhati etena ati ṭhiti āhāraḥ
translated: He says “they are called ‘beings who continue by nutriment’ because of the continuation by nutriment of those” . It continues by it, thus it is continuation ; nutriment is the continuation

original: etesanti āhāraṭṭhitikāti evaṃ vā ettha samāsaviggaho daṭṭhabbo. Āhāraṭṭhitikāti paccayaṭṭhitikā,🔽paccayāyattavuttikāti attho. Paccayattho hettha āhāra-saddo “ayaṃ āhāro anuppannassa
analyzed: etesan ti āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati evam vā ettha samāsa viggaho daṭṭhabbo āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati paccaya ṭṭhitikā  paccaya āyatta vuttikā ti attho paccaya tthaḥ ha ittha āhāra saddaḥ ayam āhāraḥ anuppannassa
translated: of those, thus it is “beings who continue by nutriment” . Or the analysis of the compound should be regarded thus: “beings who continue by nutriment” = “beings who continue by condition” .🔽The meaning is that they exist dependent on conditions. For the word “nutriment” here has the meaning of condition, as in the passage: “This nutriment is for the arising of unarisen sensual desire” , etc.

original: vā kāmacchandassauppādāyā”tiādīsu viya. Evañhi “sabbe sattā”ti iminā asaññasattāpi
analyzed: vā kāmacchandassa auppādāya atiādīsu viya evam hi sabbe sattā ati iminā asañña sattā api
translated: For if it were not so, then “all beings” would include the non-percipient beings as well.

original: pariggahitā honti. Sā panāyaṃ āhāraṭṭhitikatā nippariyāyato saṅkhāradhammo, na sattadhammo.
analyzed: pariggahitāḥ honti sā pana ayam āhāra ṭṭhitika tā nippariyāyataḥ saṅkhāra dhammo na satta dhammo
translated: But this “continuation by nutriment” is a state of ideas in the ultimate sense, not a state of beings.

original: Tenevāhu aṭṭhakathācariyā “sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikāti āgataṭṭhāne saṅkhāraloko veditabbo”ti
analyzed: tena iva āhu aṭṭhakathā cariyā sabbe sattā āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati āgata ṭṭhāne saṅkhāra loko veditabbo ti
translated: That is why the teachers of the commentary say: “In the passage ‘All beings subsist by nutriment’ the world of formations should be understood” .🔽If that is so, why is it said “all beings”?

original: yadi evaṃ “sabbe sattā”ti idaṃ kathanti? Puggalādhiṭṭhānā desanāti nāyaṃ doso. Yathāha
analyzed: yadi evam sabbe sattā ati idam kathanti puggala adhiṭṭhānā desanā ati na ayam dosaḥ yathā āha
translated: There is no fault in this, since the teaching is based on the individual . As it is said:

original: bhagavā “ekadhamme bhikkhave bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno
analyzed: bhagavā eka dhamme bhikkhave bhikkhu sammā nibbindamānaḥ sammā virajjamānaḥ sammā vimuccamānaḥ
translated: “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu becomes completely dispassionate towards one thing, when he sees completely the ending of one thing,

original: sammā pariyantadassāvī sammattaṃ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti,
analyzed: sammā pariyanta dassāvī sammattam abhisamecca diṭṭhe iva dhamme dukkhassanta karaḥ hoti
translated: then he is one who, after attaining rightness, inclines to Nibbāna.🔽What is that one thing? All beings subsist by nutriment” .

original: katamasmiṃ ekadhamme? Sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti eko dhammoti “sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti
analyzed: katamasmin eka dhamme sabbe sattāḥ āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati ekaḥ dhammo ti sabbe sattāḥ āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati
translated: The one thing called “all beings subsist by nutriment” is the general characteristic of all formations, since it is the teaching based on the individual that all formations subsist by nutriment.🔽The nutriment is the one thing called “nutriment” that is a state of conditionality,

original: yvāyaṃ puggalādhiṭṭhānāya kathāya sabbesaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ paccayāyattavuttitāya āhārapariyāyena
analyzed: yvā ayam puggala adhiṭṭhānāya kathāya sabbesam saṅkhārānam paccaya āyatta vutti tāya āhāra pariyāyena
translated: which is taught by the term “nutriment” as the conditionality of all formations.

original: sāmaññato paccayadhammo vutto, ayaṃ āhāro nāma eko dhammo. Yāthāvato ñatvāti yathāsabhāvato
analyzed: sāmaññataḥ paccaya dhammo vuttaḥ ayam āhāraḥ nāma ekaḥ dhammo yāthāvataḥ ñatvā ati yathā sabhāvato
translated: “Having understood it as it really is”: having understood it according to its true nature.

original: abhisambujjhitvā. Sammadakkhātoti teneva abhisambuddhākārena sammadeva desito.
analyzed: abhisambujjhitvā sammad akkhāto ti tena iva abhisambuddha ākārena sammat eva desitaḥ
translated: Well taught: taught just as he has fully awakened to it.

original: Codako vuttampi atthaṃ yāthāvato appaṭipajjamāno neyyatthaṃ suttapadaṃ nītatthato
analyzed: codakaḥ vuttam pi attham yāthāvataḥ appaṭipajjamāno na iyyattham sutta padam nīta atthato
translated: The questioner, not understanding the meaning of the words of the sutta as they are, misrepresents the sutta, which has a meaning requiring interpretation, as having a meaning that is literal.

original: dahanto “sabbe sattā”ti vacanamatte ṭhatvā “nanu cā”tiādinā codeti. Ācariyo aviparītaṃ
analyzed: dahanto sabbe sattā ati vacana matte nanu ca ati ādinā codeti ācariyaḥ aviparītam
translated: He questions the teacher, saying: “But surely,” etc., standing only on the words “all beings.”

original: tattha yathādhippetamatthaṃ pavedento “na virujjhatī”ti vatvā “tesañhi jhānaṃ āhāro
analyzed: tattha yathā adhippetam attham pavedentaḥ na virujjhati iti vatvā tesam hi jhānam āhāraḥ
translated: The teacher, not misrepresenting the meaning as he has understood it, says: “It does not contradict,” and then: “For their jhāna is nutriment.”

original: hotī”ti āha. Jhānanti ekavokārabhavāvahaṃ saññāya virajjanavasena pavattaṃ rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānaṃ.
analyzed: hoti iti āha jhānan ti eka vokāra bhava āvaham saññāya virajjana vasena pavattam rūpāvacara catuttha jhānam
translated: Jhāna: the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere, which occurs by means of the surmounting of perception in the sense already stated.

original: Pāḷiyaṃ pana “anāhārā”ti vacanaṃ asaññabhave catunnaṃ āhārānaṃ abhāvaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ,
analyzed: pāḷiyam pana anāhārā ati vacanam asañña bhave catunnam āhārānam abhāvam sandhāya vuttam
translated: But the words “without nutriment” in the text are said with reference to the absence of the four kinds of nutriment in the immaterial realm,🔽not with reference to the absence of the condition that is nutriment.

original: na paccayāhārassa abhāvato. “Evaṃ santepī”ti idaṃ sāsane yesu dhammesu visesato āhāra-saddo
analyzed: na paccaya āhārassa abhāvato evam sante pi iti idam sāsane yesu dhammesu visesataḥ āhāra saddo
translated: “Even so, nevertheless”: this is said because, in the Dispensation, the word “nutriment” is used in a particular way with regard to certain things,

original: niruḷho, “āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti ettha yadi te eva gayhanti, abyāpitadoso āpanno. Atha
analyzed: niruḷhaḥ āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati ettha yadi te eva gayhanti a byāpita dosaḥ āpannaḥ atha
translated: and if only those are admitted as nutriment, the fault of non-pervasion is incurred.

original: sabbopi paccayadhammo āhāroti adhippeto, imāya āhārapāḷiyā virodho āpannoti dassetuṃ
analyzed: sabbaḥ api paccaya dhammaḥ āhāraḥ ti adhippetaḥ imāya āhāra pāḷiyā virodhaḥ āpannaḥ ti dassetuṃ
translated: All states that are conditions are intended as nutriment.🔽The intention with which it is said is being explained.

original: āraddhaṃ. “Na virujjhatī”ti yenādhippāyena vuttaṃ, taṃ vivaranto “etasmiñhi sutte”tiādimāha.
analyzed: āraddham na virujjhati iti yena adhippāyena vuttam tam vivarantaḥ etasmin hi sutta itiādim āha
translated: “In this sutta” means in the Saṅgīti Sutta.

original: Kabaḷīkārāhārādīnaṃ ojaṭṭhamakarūpāharaṇādi nippariyāyena āhārabhāvo. Yathā hi kabaḷīkārāhāro🔽ojaṭṭhamakarūpāharaṇena rūpakāyaṃ upatthambheti, evaṃ phassādayo ca vedanādiāharaṇena
analyzed: kabaḷīkāra āhāra ādīnam nippariyāyena āhāra bhāvaḥ yathā hi kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ  oja ṭṭhamaka rūpa āharaṇena rūpa kāyam upatthambheti evam phassa ādayaḥ ca vedanā ādi āharaṇena
translated: The nutriment consisting of physical food, etc., is nutriment in the primary sense in the act of nourishing the material body by taking up the materiality of the octad consisting of the earth element, etc.,🔽and in the act of nourishing the immaterial body consisting of the four immaterial aggregates by taking up the materiality of the octad consisting of the earth element, etc., respectively.🔽Just as the nutriment consisting of physical food nourishes the material body by taking up the materiality of the octad consisting of the earth element, etc.,

original: nāmakāyaṃ upatthambhenti, tasmā satipi janakabhāve upatthambhakabhāvo ojādīsu sātisayo
analyzed: nāmakāyam upatthambhenti tasmā sati pi janaka bhāve upatthambhaka bhāvaḥ oja ādīsu sa atisayaḥ
translated: so too the nutriments consisting of contact, mental volition, and consciousness nourish the immaterial body consisting of the four immaterial aggregates by taking up the materiality of the octad consisting of the earth element, etc., respectively.🔽Therefore, although they are productive, the nutriments’ quality of nourishing is more outstanding in the case of the nutriments consisting of the octad consisting of the earth element, etc.,

original: labbhamāno mukhyo āhāraṭṭhoti te eva nippariyāyena āhāralakkhaṇā dhammā vuttā. Idhāti
analyzed: labbhamānaḥ mukhyaḥ āhāra ṭṭhaḥ ti te eva nippariyāyena āhāra lakkhaṇāḥ dhammāḥ vuttāḥ idha ati
translated: and for that reason they are called nutriments in the primary sense.

original: imasmiṃ saṅgītisutte. Pariyāyena paccayo āhāroti vutto sabbo paccayo dhammo attano
analyzed: imasmin saṅgīti sutte pariyāyena paccayaḥ āhāraḥ ti vutto sabbaḥ paccayaḥ dhammo attano
translated: Herein, in this Saṅgīti Sutta,🔽all states that are conditions are called nutriment in the secondary sense in the passage, “All states that are conditions are nutriment” .

original: phalaṃ āharatīti imaṃ pariyāyaṃ labhatīti. Tenāha “sabbadhammānañhī”tiādi. Tattha
analyzed: phalam āharati iti imam pariyāyam labhati iti tena āha sabba dhammānam hi itiādi tattha
translated: He obtains this secondary sense in that all conditions are nutriment in the sense that they bring about their own fruit.

original: sabbadhammānanti sabbesaṃ saṅkhatadhammānaṃ. Idāni yathāvuttamatthaṃ suttena samatthetuṃ
analyzed: sabba dhammānam ti sabbesam saṅkhata dhammānam idāni yathāvuttam attham suttena samatthetum
translated: ‘All ideas’: all formed ideas. Now, in order to establish the evidence for the meaning stated thus,

original: “tenevāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ayanti paccayāhāro.
analyzed: tena iva āha atiādi vuttam ayanti paccaya āhāro
translated: ‘Therefore it is said’ is said. ‘That’ is the condition-food.

original: Nippariyāyāhāropi gahitova hoti, yāvatā sopi paccayabhāveneva janako, upatthambhako
analyzed: nippariyāya āhāraḥ api gahitaḥ uva hoti yāvatā saḥ api paccaya bhāvena iva janakaḥ upatthambhako
translated: The non-figurative food is also included, since it is productive by way of condition,

original: ca hutvā taṃ taṃ phalaṃ āharatīti vattabbataṃ labhatīti. Tatthāti pariyāyāhāro, nippariyāyāhāroti
analyzed: ca hutvā tam tam phalam āharati iti vattabbatam labhati iti tattha ati pariyāya āhāraḥ nippariyāya āhāraḥ iti
translated: and since it is also capable of being called ‘food’ since it is a support and a promoter of this or that fruit. ‘Therein’ is in the two kinds of food, namely, the figurative food and the non-figurative food.

original: dvīsu āhāresu. Asaññabhave yadipi nippariyāyāhāro na labbhati, paccayāhāro pana labbhati
analyzed: dvīsu āhāresu asañña bhave yadi pi nippariyāya āhāro na labbhati paccaya āhāro pana labbhati
translated: Though in the non-percipient realm the non-figurative food is not found, the condition-food is found there.

original: pariyāyāhāralakkhaṇo. Idāni imamevatthaṃ vitthārena dassetuṃ “anuppanne hi buddhe”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Uppanne buddhe titthakaramatanissitānaṃ jhānabhāvanāya asijjhanato “anuppanne
analyzed: pariyāya āhāra lakkhaṇaḥ idāni imam eva attham vitthārena dassetum anuppanne hi buddha itiādi  vuttam uppanne buddhe titthakara mata nissitānam jhāna bhāvanāya a sijjhanataḥ an uppanne
translated: The figurative food is the kind that has the characteristic of the condition-food. Now, in order to show this meaning in detail, ‘When there is no Buddha arisen’ is said.🔽When there is a Buddha arisen, there is no need for the kind of meditation that depends on the doctrine of the sectarians, since the Buddha’s dispensation is available.

original: buddhe”ti vuttaṃ. Sāsanikā tādisaṃ jhānaṃ na nibbattentīti “titthāyatane pabbajitā”ti
analyzed: buddhā iti vuttam sāsanikā tādisam jhānam na nibbattenti iti titthāyatane pabbajitā ti
translated: That is why ‘when there is no Buddha arisen’ is said. The kind of meditation that is available in the Buddha’s dispensation is not produced by those who are not of his dispensation.🔽That is why ‘gone forth in a sectarians’ doctrine’ is said.

original: vuttaṃ. Titthiyā hi upattivisese vimuttisaññino, aññāvirāgāvirāgesu ādīnavānisaṃsadassino
analyzed: vuttam titthiyāḥ hi upatti visese vimutti saññinaḥ aññāvirāga avirāgesu ādīnava anisaṃsa dassinaḥ
translated: This has been said. For the sectarians, who are of the view that there is deliverance in the various kinds of rebirth, who see the danger and disadvantage in the attainment of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and in the attainment of cessation,

original: vā hutvā asaññasamāpattiṃ nibbattetvā akkhaṇabhūmiyaṃ uppajjanti, na sāsanikā. Vāyokasiṇe
analyzed: vā hutvā asañña samāpattim nibbattetvā akkhaṇa bhūmiyam uppajjanti na sāsanikāḥ vāyokasiṇe
