translated: are reborn in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, not in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.🔽Having done the preliminary work on the air kasiṇa,

original: parikammaṃ katvāti vāyokasiṇe paṭhamādīni tīṇi jhānāni nibbattetvā tatiyajjhāne ciṇṇavasī
analyzed: parikammam katvā ti vāyokasiṇe paṭhama ādīni tīṇi jhānāni nibbattetvā tatiya jhāne ciṇṇavasī
translated: having produced the first three jhānas in the air kasiṇa, and having gained mastery in the third jhāna,

original: hutvā tato vuṭṭhāya catutthajjhānādhigamāya parikammaṃ katvā. Tenāha “catutthajjhānaṃ
analyzed: hutvā tatas vuṭṭhāya catuttha jhāna adhigamāya parikammam katvā tena āha catuttha jhānam
translated: he emerges from it and does the preliminary work for the attainment of the fourth jhāna. Therefore it is said: “having produced the fourth jhāna” .

original: nibbattetvā”ti. Kasmā panettha vāyokasiṇeyeva parikammaṃ vuttanti? Yadettha vattabbaṃ,🔽taṃ brahmajālaṭīkāyaṃ vitthāritameva. Dhīti jigucchanatthe nipāto, tasmā dhī cittanti
analyzed: nibbattetvā ti kasmā pana ittha vāyokasiṇeya iva parikammam vuttan ti yat ettha vattabbam  tam brahmajālaṭīkāyam vitthāritam eva dhī iti jigucchana tthe nipāto tasmā dhī cittam ti
translated: But why is the preliminary work stated here only in the air kasiṇa?🔽What should be said here has already been stated in the commentary to the Brahmajāla Sutta .🔽The word “dhī” is a particle in the sense of disgust. Therefore, “dhī citt” means “I am disgusted with the mind.”

original: cittaṃ jigucchāmīti attho. Dhibbatetaṃ cittanti etaṃ mama cittaṃ jigucchitaṃ vata
analyzed: cittam jigucchāmi iti atthaḥ dhibbata etam cittam ti etam mama cittam jigucchitam vata
translated: “Dhī bhattetaṃ citt” means “may this mind of mine be disgusted.”

original: hotu. Vatāti sambhāvane, tena jigucchaṃ sambhāvento vadati. Nāmāti ca sambhāvane
analyzed: hotu vata ati sambhāvane tena jiguccham sambhāventaḥ vadati nāma ati ca sambhāvane
translated: “Bhattetaṃ” is a particle in the sense of “may it be.” Therefore, he says this while expressing his disgust. “Nāmā” is a particle in the sense of “may it be.”🔽“Nāmā” is a particle in the sense of “may it be.”

original: eva, tena cittassa abhāvaṃ sambhāveti. Cittassa bhāvābhāvesu ādīnavānisaṃse dassetuṃ
analyzed: eva tena cittassa abhāvam sambhāveti cittassa bhāva abhāvesu ādīnava anisaṃse dassetuṃ
translated: and he believes that there is no such state of consciousness. In order to show the danger and the advantage in the presence and absence of consciousness,

original: “cittañhī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Khantiṃ ruciṃ uppādetvāti “cittassa abhāvo eva sādhu suṭṭhū”ti
analyzed: cittam hi itiādi vuttam khantim rucim uppādetvā ati cittassa abhāvaḥ eva sādhu suṭṭhu iti
translated: he said, “For consciousness is the forerunner of mental states” , etc. Having aroused approval and liking: having aroused the approval of views and the liking for the view “The absence of consciousness is good, excellent,”

original: imaṃ diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiṃ, tattha ca abhiruciṃ uppādetvā.🔽Tathā bhāvitassa jhānassa ṭhitibhāgiyabhāvappattiyā aparihīnajjhānassa titthāyatane🔽pabbajitasseva tathā jhānabhāvanā hotīti āha “manussaloke”ti. Paṇihito ahosīti maraṇassa
analyzed: imam diṭṭhi nijjhāna kkhantim tattha ca abhirucim uppādetvā  tathā bhāvitassa jhānassa ṭhiti bhāgiya bhāva ppattiyā aparihīna jjhānassa tittha āyatane  pabbajitassa iva tathā jhāna bhāvanā hoti iti āha manussa loke iti paṇihito ahosi iti maraṇassa
translated: having aroused the approval of views and the liking for that view.🔽When the jhāna has been developed in this way, it becomes the basis for the attainment of the state of presence. The bhikkhu who has not lost the jhāna goes forth from the here and now to the world beyond.

original: āsannakāle ṭhapito ahosi. Yadi ṭhānādinā ākārena nibbatteyya, kammabalena yāva bhedā
analyzed: āsanna kāle ṭhapitaḥ ahosi yadi ṭhāna ādinā ākārena kamma balena yāva bhedā
translated: Therefore it is said, “in the human world.” He was established: at the time of his death he was established. If he were to be reborn in the form of a place, etc., he would remain in that form until the dissolution of the cosmos through the power of kamma.

original: tenevākārena tiṭṭheyya vāti āha “so tena iriyāpathenā”tiādi.
analyzed: tena iva ākārena tiṭṭheyya vā ti āha saḥ tena iriyāpathena atiādi
translated: Therefore it is said, “He would remain in that posture” , etc.

original: Eva rūpānampīti evaṃ acetanānampi. Pi-saddena pageva sacetanānanti dasseti. Kathaṃ
analyzed: eva rūpānam pi iti evam acetanānam pi pi saddena pageva sa cetanānam ti dasseti katham
translated: So too with material things: so too with even the insentient material things. The word “too” shows that it is so with the sentient beings as well.

original: pana acetanānaṃ nesaṃ paccayāhārassa upakappananti codanaṃ sandhāya tattha nidassanaṃ
analyzed: pana acetanānam na īsam paccaya āhārassa upakappananti codanam sandhāya tattha nidassanam
translated: The illustration is given in the answer to the question in order to show that the nutriment of contact is the condition for the other three nutriments, which are not conscious, and that the nutriment of mental volition is the condition for the nutriment of consciousness.

original: dassento “yathā”tiādimāha.🔽Ye uṭṭhānavīriyeneva divasaṃ vītināmetvā tassa nissandaphalamattaṃ kiñcideva labhitvā
analyzed: yathā iti ādim āha  ye uṭṭhāna vīriyena iva divasam vītināmetvā tassa nissanda phala mattam kiñcid eva labhitvā
translated: The answer is given in the way beginning, “Just as, etc.”🔽Those who spend the day working with energy and then make do with whatever fruit of that work they get are called “those who live on the fruit of their energy.” Those who live on the fruit of their merit are called “those who live on the fruit of their merit.”

original: jīvikaṃ kappenti, te uṭṭhānaphalūpajīvino. Ye pana attano puññaphalameva upajīventi,🔽te puññaphalūpajīvino. Nerayikānaṃ pana neva uṭṭhānavīriyavasena jīvikākappanaṃ,
analyzed: jīvikam kappenti te uṭṭhāna phala upajīvinaḥ ye pana attano puñña phalam eva upajīventi  te puñña phala upajīvinaḥ nerayikānam pana na iva uṭṭhāna vīriya vasena jīvikā kappanam
translated: But for the beings in hell there is no making a living by energy,

original: puññaphalassa pana lesopi natthīti vuttaṃ “ye pana te nerayikā…pe… na puññaphalūpajīvīti
analyzed: puñña phalassa pana lesaḥ api natthi iti vuttam ye pana te na puñña phala upajīvī iti
translated: and there is not even a trace of the fruit of merit. That is why it is said, “Those beings in hell, etc., are called ‘those who do not live on the fruit of their merit.’ ”

original: vuttā”ti. Paṭisandhiviññāṇassa āharaṇena manosañcetanāhāroti vuttā, na yassa kassaci
analyzed: vuttā ati paṭisandhi viññāṇassa āharaṇena manaḥ sañcetanā āhāraḥ ti vuttā na yassa kassaci
translated: The intention is that the nutriment of mental volition is so called because it brings about rebirth-linking consciousness, not because it is the nutriment of any and every fruit.

original: phalassāti adhippāyena “kiṃ pañca āhārā atthī”ti codeti. Ācariyo nippariyāyāhāre
analyzed: phalassa ati adhippāyena kim pañca āhārāḥ atthi iti codeti ācariyaḥ nippariyāya āhāre
translated: The teacher asks the question, “Are there five kinds of nutriment?” with reference to the nutriment in its ultimate sense.

original: adhippete siyā tava codanāyāvasaro, sā pana ettha anavasarāti dassetuṃ “pañca na🔽pañcāti idaṃ na vattabba”nti vatvā pariyāyāhārasseva panettha adhippetabhāvaṃ dassento🔽“nanu paccayo āhāroti vuttameta”nti āha. Tasmāti yassa kassaci paccayassa “āhāro”ti
analyzed: adhippete siyā tava codanāya avasaraḥ sā pana ettha anavasarā ti dassetum pañca na  pañca iti idam na vattabbam ti vatvā pariyāya āhārassa iva pana ittha adhippeta bhāvam dassento  nanu paccayaḥ āhāraḥ iti vuttam etat ti āha tasmā ti yassa kassaci paccayassa āhāro ti
translated: “It is possible that you may find fault with me, but that is not the proper occasion for it. This is not the occasion for it.” In order to show that the occasion for finding fault is not the occasion for asking a question, he said: “The five aggregates are not to be spoken of as five.”🔽But in order to show that the occasion for finding fault is the occasion for a reply, he said: “Is not condition spoken of as nutriment?”🔽“Therefore” means: “Therefore, since condition is spoken of as nutriment, it is not proper to find fault with me.”

original: icchitattā. Idāni vuttamevatthaṃ pāḷiyā samatthento “yaṃ sandhāyā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: icchita ttā idāni vutta mevattham pāḷiyā samatthentaḥ yam sandhāya ati ādim āha
translated: “If you are the opponent, then it is your turn to find fault. But that is not possible here. ” To show this, he said, “It is not to be said that there are five or not five. ” But to show that the opponent should be understood in a figurative sense, he said, “Is not condition a figurative sense for nutriment? ” “ Therefore” means because any condition at all is accepted as nutriment. Now, in order to show that the meaning stated is correct by the texts, he said, “What is meant by ‘nutriment’ is stated in the texts thus: ”

original: Mukhyāhāravasenapi nerayikānaṃ āhāraṭṭhitikataṃ dassetuṃ “kabaḷīkāraṃ āhāraṃ…pe…
analyzed: mukhya āhāra vasena api nerayikānam āhāra ṭṭhiti katam dassetum kabaḷīkāram
translated: To show that the nutriment of physical food is also the support of the denizens of hell, it is said: “He maintains himself by means of nutriment consisting of lumps” …

original: sādhetī”ti vuttaṃ. Yadi evaṃ nerayikā sukhapaṭisaṃvedinopi hontīti? Noti dassetuṃ
analyzed: sādheti iti vuttam yadi evam nerayikā sukha paṭisaṃvedinaḥ api honti iti no ti dassetuṃ
translated: If that is so, then the denizens of hell must also experience pleasure? To show that they do not, he said:

original: “kheḷopi hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tayoti tayo arūpāhārā kabaḷīkārāhārassa abhāvato. Avasesānanti
analyzed: kheḷaḥ api hi itiādi vuttam tayaḥ ti tayaḥ arūpa āhārā kabaḷīkāra āhārassa abhāvataḥ avasesānam ti
translated: “Even saliva” and so on. “ Three” means the three immaterial nutriments, because there is no nutriment consisting of physical food. “ The rest” means the rest of the beings,

original: asaññasattehi avasesānaṃ. Kāmabhavādīsu nibbattasattānaṃ paccayāhāro hi sabbesaṃ
analyzed: asañña sattehi avasesānam kāma bhava ādīsu nibbatta sattānam paccaya āhāraḥ hi sabbesam
translated: except the non-percipient beings. For the nutriment as condition is for all beings born in the sense-sphere, fine-material sphere, and immaterial sphere.

original: sādhāraṇoti. Etaṃ pañhanti “katamo eko dhammo”ti evaṃ coditametaṃ pañhaṃ. Kathetvāti vissajjetvā.
analyzed: sādhāraṇaḥ ti etam pañhanti katamaḥ ekaḥ dhammo ti evam ca uditam etam pañham kathetvā ati vissajjetvā
translated: “Shared” : this is the question. Having answered : having explained.

original: “Tattha tattha…pe… dukkhaṃ hotī”ti etena yathā idha paṭhamassa pañhassa niyyātanaṃ,🔽dutiyassa uddharaṇaṃ na kataṃ, evaṃ iminā eva adhippāyena ito paresu dukatikādipañhesu
analyzed: tattha tatthape dukkham hoti iti etena yathā idha paṭhamassa pañhassa niyyātanam  dutiyassa uddharaṇam na katam evam iminā eva adhippāyena itas paresu dukatika ādi pañhesu
translated: “There, there, etc., suffering comes to be” : by this he shows how the answer to the first question and the explanation of the second are given in the passage beginning “There, there, etc., suffering comes to be” .

original: tattha tattha ādipariyosānesu eva uddharaṇaniyyātanāni katvā sesesu na katanti dasseti.
analyzed: tattha tattha ādi pariyosānesu eva uddharaṇa niyyātanāni katvā sesesu na kata nti dasseti
translated: By this very intention he shows that in the remaining questions beginning with the duka he gives the explanation and the answer only at the beginning and end of each section and not in the middle.

original: Paṭicca etasmā phalaṃ etīti paccayo, kāraṇaṃ, tadeva attano phalaṃ saṅkharotīti saṅkhāroti
analyzed: paṭicca etasmā phalam eti iti paccayaḥ kāraṇam tat eva attanaḥ phalam saṅkharoti iti
translated: “Condition” : that from which a fruit comes to be is a condition, a cause. It is called “formation” because it forms its own fruit.

original: āha “imasmimpi…pe… saṅkhāroti vutto”ti. Āhārapaccayoti āharaṇaṭṭhavisiṭṭho paccayo.
analyzed: āha saṅkhāro ti vutto ti āhāra paccayo ti āharaṇa ṭṭha visiṭṭhaḥ paccayo
translated: “In this case too, etc., formation is mentioned” . “Condition for nutriment” : a condition that is distinguished by the function of nutriment.

original: Āharaṇañcettha uppādakattappadhānaṃ, saṅkharaṇaṃ upatthambhakattappadhānanti ayametesaṃ
analyzed: āharaṇam ca ittha uppāda katta ppadhānam saṅkharaṇam upatthambha katta ppadhānam ti ayam etesam
translated: Here the function of nutriment is the function of producing, and the function of formation is the function of supporting.

original: viseso. Tenāha “ayamettha heṭṭhimato viseso”ti. Nippariyāyāhāre gahite “sabbe sattā”ti🔽vuttepi asaññasattā na gahitā eva bhavissantīti padesavisayo sabba-saddo hoti yathā
analyzed: viseso tena āha ayam ettha heṭṭhimataḥ viseso ti nippariyāya āhāre gahite sabbe sattā ti  vutte api asañña sattāḥ na gahitāḥ eva bhavissanti iti padesa visayaḥ sabba saddaḥ hoti yathā
translated: The difference is this. Therefore he said: “This is the difference here below.”🔽When the nutriment non-cognizance is taken, although it is said “all beings,” still the non-percipient beings will not have been taken. Therefore the word “all” has a limited scope,

original: “sabbe tasantidaṇḍassā”tiādīsu. Na hettha khīṇāsavādīnaṃ gahaṇaṃ hoti. Pākaṭo bhaveyya
analyzed: sabbe tasanti daṇḍassa ati ādīsu na ha ittha khīṇāsava ādīnam gahaṇam hoti pākaṭaḥ bhaveyya
translated: just as in such passages as “All are afraid of punishment” , etc. And here the taking of those whose cankers are destroyed does not occur. It would be obvious

original: visesasāmaññassa visayattā pañhānaṃ. No ca gaṇhiṃsu aṭṭhakathācariyā. Dhammo nāma
analyzed: visesa sāmaññassa visaya ttā pañhānam no ca gaṇhiṃsu aṭṭhakathā cariyāḥ dhammaḥ nāma
translated: because the scope of questions is the particular and the general. But the teachers of the commentary did not take it thus. The intention is that there is no

original: natthi saṅkhatoti adhippāyo. Idha dutiyapañhe “saṅkhāro”ti paccayo eva kathitoti sambandho.
analyzed: natthi saṅkhatoti adhippāyaḥ idha dutiya pañhe saṅkhāro ti paccayaḥ eva kathito ti sambandho
translated: thing called “Dhamma” that is formed. Here in the second question the condition is stated as “a formation.”

original: Yadā sammāsambodhisamadhigato, tadā eva sabbañeyyaṃ sacchikataṃ jātanti āha “mahābodhimaṇḍe
analyzed: yadā sammāsambodhi samadhigataḥ tadā eva sabbañeyyam sacchikatam jātan ti āha mahā bodhimaṇḍe
translated: When he attained supreme enlightenment, then he knew all that is to be known. Therefore it is said: “Sitting in the Great

original: nisīditvā”ti. Sayanti sāmaṃyeva. Addhaniyanti addhānakkhamaṃ cirakālāvaṭṭhāyi pārampariyavasena.
analyzed: nisīditvā ati sayanti sāmaṃyā iva addhaniyanti addhānakkhamam cira kāla avaṭṭhāyi pārampariya vasena
translated: Enlightenment Place” . They lie down by themselves. “Enduring for a while”: able to endure a period, lasting for a long time, in succession.

original: Tenāha “ekena hī”tiādi. Paramparakathāniyamenāti paramparakathākathananiyamena, niyamitatthabyañjanānupubbiyā
analyzed: tena āha ekena hi itiādi parampara kathā niyamena ati parampara kathā kathana niyamena niyamita attha byañjana anupubbiyā
translated: The meaning is: by the order of the telling of the story.🔽By the one question: it has one measure, thus it is one; the question.🔽By the one question.

original: kathāyāti attho. Ekakavasenāti ekaṃ ekaṃ parimāṇaṃ etassāti ekako, pañho. Tassa ekakassa🔽vasena. Ekakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ vissajjananti adhippāyoti.
analyzed: kathāya iti attho ekaka vasena ati ekam ekam parimāṇam etassa ati ekakaḥ pañhaḥ tassa ekakassa  vasena ekakam niṭṭhitam vissajjananti adhippāyaḥ ti
translated: The answer is finished. This is the purport.

original: Ekakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ekaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the one question is ended.

original: Dukavaṇṇanā
analyzed: duka vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the two questions

original: 304. Cattāro khandhāti tesaṃ tāva nāmanaṭṭhena nāmabhāvaṃ paṭhamaṃ vatvā pacchā nibbānassa🔽vattukāmo āha. Tassāpi hi tathā nāmabhāvaṃ parato vakkhati. “Nāmaṃ karoti nāmayatī”ti
analyzed: cattāro khandhā ti tesam tāva nāmanaṭṭhena nāma bhāvam paṭhamam vatvā pacchā nibbānassa  vattu kāmaḥ āha tassa api hi tathā nāma bhāvam paratas vakkhati nāmam karoti nāmayati iti
translated: Four aggregates: he first stated the state of being a name by the method of naming them, and then he said,🔽“Nibbāna is not included in the four aggregates” because he wanted to state the state of being a name of that .🔽For he will later say: “He makes a name, he names” .🔽Herein, the making of a name is a name, he said: “By the method of naming” by the method of making a name.🔽By itself: this is the purport.

original: ettha yaṃ nāmakaraṇaṃ, taṃ nāmanti āha “nāmanaṭṭhenāti nāmakaraṇaṭṭhenā”ti, attanovāti🔽adhippāyo. Evañhi sātisayamidaṃ tesaṃ nāmakaraṇaṃ hoti. Tenāha “attano nāmaṃ karontāva
analyzed: ettha yam nāmakaraṇam tam nāmanti āha nāmana ṭṭhena āti nāmakaraṇa ṭṭhena āti attano vā ati 🔽adhippāyaḥ evam hi sa atisayam idam tesam nāmakaraṇam hoti tena āha attanaḥ nāmam karontāva
translated: For this is the excessive making of a name by them. Hence he said: “They make a name by themselves.

original: uppajjantī”tiādi. Idāni tamatthaṃ byatirekamukhena vibhāvetuṃ “yathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: uppajjanti itiādi idāni tam attham byatireka mukhena vibhāvetum yathā hi itiādi vuttam
translated: “For it is not so with feeling, etc.”

original: Yassa nāmassa karaṇeneva te “nāma”nti vuccanti, taṃ sāmaññanāmaṃ, kittimanāmaṃ, guṇanāmaṃ
analyzed: yassa nāmassa karaṇena iva te nāmanti vuccanti tam sāmañña nāmam kittima nāmam guṇa nāmam
translated: “Name” is a general name, a name for fame, a name for a quality,

original: vā na hoti, atha kho opapātikanāmanti purimāni tīṇi nāmāni udāharaṇavasena dassetvā
analyzed: vā na hoti atha kho opapātika nāmanti purimāni tīṇi nāmāni udāharaṇa vasena dassetvā
translated: or it is not a name at all, but a name for spontaneous rebirth. Having shown the first three kinds of names by way of an example,

original: “na evaṃ vedanādīna”nti te paṭikkhipitvā itaranāmameva nāmakaraṇaṭṭhena nāmanti dassento🔽“vedanādayo hī”tiādimāha. “Mahāpathaviādayo”ti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu pathaviāpādayo
analyzed: na evam vedanā ādīnam ti te paṭikkhipitvā itara nāmam eva nāma karaṇa ṭṭhena nāman ti dassento  vedanā ādayaḥ hi iti ādim āha mahā pathavi ādayo ti kasmai vuttam nanu
translated: he rejects the fourth kind by saying, “For it is not so with feeling, etc.” and shows that the other kind of name is a name in the sense of naming.

original: idha nāmanti anadhippetā, rūpanti pana adhippetāti? Saccametaṃ, phassavedanādīnaṃ🔽viya pana pathaviādīnaṃ opapātikanāmatāsāmaññena “pathaviādayo viyā”ti nidassanaṃ
analyzed: idha nāman ti anadhippetā rūpan ti pana adhippetā ati saccam etam phassa vedanā ādīnam  viya pana pathavi ādīnam opapātika nāma tā sāmaññena pathavi ādayaḥ viya ati nidassanam
translated: Why is it said “the great earth, etc.”? Are not the earth, water, fire, and air elements not intended here as “name”? But the material form is intended.🔽This is true, but the earth, etc., are shown by the example “as the great earth, etc.” because of their similarity to the name for spontaneous rebirth,🔽just as feeling, etc., are shown by the example “as a name, a designation, a conventional expression for feeling, etc.”, not because material phenomena have the nature of name, as do immaterial phenomena.

original: kataṃ, na arūpadhammā viya rūpadhammānaṃ nāmasabhāvattā. Phassavedanādīnañhi arūpadhammānaṃ
analyzed: katam na arūpa dhammāḥ viya rūpa dhammānam nāma sabhāva ttā phassa vedanā ādīnam hi arūpa dhammānam
translated: For feeling, etc., are immaterial phenomena.

original: sabbadāpi phassādināmakattā, pathaviādīnaṃ kesakumbhādināmantarāpatti viya nāmantarānāpajjanato🔽ca sadā attanāva katanāmatāya catukkhandhanibbānāni nāmakaraṇaṭṭhena nāmaṃ. Atha🔽vā adhivacanasamphasso viya adhivacananāmamantarena ye anupacitasambhārānaṃ gahaṇaṃ
analyzed: sabbadā api phassa ādi nāmaka ttā pathavi ādīnam kesa kumbha ādi nāma ntara āpatti viya nāma ntara an āpajjanato  ca sadā kata nāma tāya catu khandha nibbānāni nāma karaṇa ṭṭhena nāmam atha  vā adhivacana samphassaḥ adhivacana nāmam antarena ye
translated: and because of the absence of any other name in between the name earth and the name head hairs, etc., as there is in the case of the name of the four aggregates and the name of Nibbāna, which are separated by the name of the five aggregates.

original: na gacchanti, te nāmāyattaggahaṇā nāmaṃ. Rūpaṃ pana vināpi nāmasādhanaṃ attano ruppanasabhāvena🔽gahaṇaṃ upayātīti rūpaṃ. Tenāha “tesu uppannesū”tiādi. Idhāpi “yathāpathaviyā”tiādīsu
analyzed: na gacchanti te nāma āyatta ggahaṇāḥ nāmam rūpam pana vinā api nāma sādhanam attanaḥ  upayāti iti rūpam tena āha tesu uppannesu itiādi idha api yathā pathaviyāti ādīsu
translated: Or alternatively, just as the contact called “contact with the name” is not apprehended without the name called “name,” so too, these are “name” in the sense of being apprehended as “name” and “matter” in the sense of being apprehended as “matter” without the name called “name” and the matter called “matter” respectively.🔽But matter is apprehended by its own individual essence, which is the act of deformation, even without the establishment of the name “matter.”🔽That is why it is called “matter.” Hence he said “when these have arisen” .

original: vuttanayeneva attho veditabbo nidassanavasena āgatattā. “Atītepī”tiādinā vedanādīsu🔽nāmasaññā niruḷhā, anādikālikā cāti dasseti.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva atthaḥ veditabbaḥ nidassana vasena āgata ttā atīte pi itiādinā vedanā ādīsu  nāma saññā niruḷhā anādikālikā ca ati dasseti
translated: Here too the meaning should be understood in the way already given under the phrase “as with the earth” .

original: Iti atītādivibhāgavantānampi vedanādīnaṃ nāmakaraṇaṭṭhena nāmabhāvo ekantiko, tabbibhāgarahite
analyzed: iti atīta ādi vibhāgavantānam pi vedanā ādīnam nāma karaṇa ṭṭhena nāma bhāvaḥ ekantikaḥ tad vibhāga rahite
translated: By the words “in the past, too” , etc., he shows that the designation of feeling, etc., by the name “name” is not only in the present but also in the past and the future, and that it is beginningless.

original: pana ekasabhāve nicce nibbāne vattabbameva natthīti dassento “nibbānaṃ pana…pe… nāmanaṭṭhena🔽nāma”nti āha. Nāmanaṭṭhenāti nāmakaraṇaṭṭhena. Namantīti ekantato sārammaṇattā tanninnā
analyzed: pana eka sabhāve nicce nibbāne vattabbam eva natthi iti dassentaḥ nibbānam panape nāmanaṭṭhena  nāman ti āha nāmana ṭṭhena ati nāma karaṇa ṭṭhena namanti iti ekantato sārammaṇa ttā tad ninnā
translated: “Nibbana, however, is not so in the sense of name” : in the sense of naming.🔽“They name it” : they are exclusively intent upon it, they are absorbed in it, is the meaning; they do not occur without it.

original: honti, tehi vinā nappavattantīti attho. Sabbanti khandhacatukkaṃ, nibbānañca. Yasmiṃ
analyzed: honti tehi vinā na ppavattanti iti attho sabbanti khandha catukkam nibbānam ca yasmin
translated: “All” : the four aggregates and nibbana.

original: ārammaṇeyeva vedanākkhandho pavattati, taṃsampayuttatāya saññākkhandhādayopi tattha
analyzed: ārammaṇe iya iva vedanā khandho pavattati tad sampayutta tāya saññā khandha ādayaḥ api tattha
translated: In the object in which the feeling aggregate occurs, the perception and the other aggregates occur too, because they are associated with it.

original: pavattantīti so ne tattha nāmento viya hoti vinā appavattanato. Esa nayo saññākkhandhādīsupīti
analyzed: pavattanti iti so ne tattha nāma intaḥ viya hoti vinā a pavattanato esa nayo saññākkhandha ādīsu pi iti
translated: Therefore it is not as if it were not naming it, because it occurs without it. The same method applies to the perception aggregate, etc.🔽Thus it is said: “They name each other in the object.”

original: vuttaṃ “ārammaṇe aññamaññaṃ nāmentī”ti. Anavajjadhamme maggaphalādike. Kāmaṃ kesuci
analyzed: vuttam ārammaṇe aññam aññam nāmenti iti anavajja dhamme magga phala ādike kāmam kesuci
translated: In the stainless states, such as the path and fruit, etc.

original: rūpadhammesupi ārammaṇādhipatibhāvo labbhateva, nibbāne panesa sātisayo tassa accantasantapaṇītatākappabhāvatoti
analyzed: rūpa dhammesu pi ārammaṇa adhipati bhāvaḥ labbhateva nibbāne pana esa sa atisayo tassa accanta santa paṇīta tā kappa bhāvato ti
translated: In some material dhammas too, of course, the object-predominance is found, but in nibbana it is very strong, because it is the supreme peace and calm.

original: tadeva ārammaṇādhipatipaccayatāya “attani nāmetī”ti vuttaṃ. Tathā hi ariyā sakalampi
analyzed: tat eva ārammaṇa adhipati paccaya tāya attani nāma iti iti vuttam tathā hi ariyā sakalam pi
translated: It is said to be “named in oneself” as object-predominance condition. For the noble ones,

original: divasabhāgaṃ taṃ ārabbha vītināmentāpi tittiṃ na gacchanti.
analyzed: divasa bhāgam tam ārabbha tittim na gacchanti
translated: even though they spend the whole day with that as their object, they are not satisfied.

original: “Ruppanaṭṭhenā”ti etena ruppatīti rūpanti dasseti. Tattha sītādivirodhipaccayasannipāte🔽visadisuppatti ruppanaṃ. Nanu ca arūpadhammānampi virodhipaccayasamāgame visadisuppatti
analyzed: ruppana ṭṭhena āti etena ruppati iti rūpan ti dasseti tattha sītā ādi virodhi paccaya sannipāte  visadisuppatti ruppanam nanu ca arūpa dhammānam pi virodhi paccaya samāgame visadisuppatti
translated: By “in the mode of impinging,” he shows that it is called “materiality” because it impinges. Herein, impinging is the occurrence of a different kind of state🔽when the conditions that are adverse to cold, etc., are present. But is not the occurrence of a different kind of state found in immaterial dhammas too when the conditions that are adverse to them are present?

original: labbhatīti? Saccaṃ labbhati, na pana vibhūtataraṃ. Vibhūtatarañhettha ruppanaṃ adhippetaṃ
analyzed: labbhati iti saccam labbhati na pana vibhūtataram vibhūtataram ha ittha ruppanam adhippetam
translated: It is, but not so very clearly. For what is intended here as impinging is that which is very clearly so.

original: sītādiggahaṇato. Vuttañhetaṃ “ruppatīti kho bhikkhave tasmā ‘rūpa’nti vuccati. Kena
analyzed: sītā ādi gahaṇataḥ vuttam ha etam ruppati iti kho bhikkhave tasmā rūpanti vuccati kena
translated: That is why it is said: “Bhikkhus, it impinges, thus it is material (rūpa);🔽by what does it impinge? It impinges by cold, it impingesa by heat” , and so on.

original: ruppati? Sītenapi ruppati, uṇhenapi ruppatī”tiādi. Yadi evaṃ kathaṃ brahmaloke rūpasamaññāti?
analyzed: ruppati sītena api ruppati uṇhena api ruppati itiādi yadi evam katham brahma loke rūpa samaññā ati
translated: If that is so, how is it that the world of Brahmā is called “material” ?

original: Tatthāpi taṃsabhāvānativattanato hotiyeva rūpasamaññā. Anuggāhakapaccayavasena vā
analyzed: tattha api taṃsa bhāva anativattanato hotiyā iva rūpa samaññā anuggāhaka paccaya vasena vā
translated: There too the designation “material” is due to the fact that it does not exceed the nature of materiality. Or alternatively,

original: visadisapaccayasannipāteti evamattho veditabbo. “Yo attano santāne vijjamānassayeva🔽visadisuppattihetubhāvo, taṃ ruppana”nti aññe. Imasmiṃ pakkhe rūpayati vikāramāpādetīti
analyzed: visadisa paccaya sannipātā iti evamatthaḥ veditabbaḥ yaḥ attanaḥ santāne vijjamānassa yā iva  visadisa uppatti hetu bhāvaḥ tam ruppananti aññe imasmin pakkhe rūpayati vikāram āpādeti iti
translated: The meaning should be understood thus: “The arising of the dissimilar condition.”🔽Others say: “Rupana is that which, in one’s own continuum, is the cause for the arising of the dissimilar.”🔽In this case, they say, “Rupa” means “that which is formed” , i.e., “that which is made to undergo change.”

original: rūpaṃ. “Saṅghaṭṭanena vikārāpattiyaṃ ruppana-saddo niruḷho”ti keci. Etasmiṃ pakkhe
analyzed: rūpam saṅghaṭṭanena vikāra āpattiyam ruppana saddo niruḷhaḥ ti keci etasmin pakkhe
translated: Some say: “The word ‘rupana’ is used in the sense of ‘undergoing change through impact.’“

original: arūpadhammesu rūpasamaññāya pasaṅgo eva natthi saṅghaṭṭanābhāvato. “Paṭighato ruppana”nti
analyzed: arūpa dhammesu rūpa samaññāya pasaṅgaḥ eva natthi saṅghaṭṭana abhāvato paṭighato ruppana nti
translated: In this case, they say, there is no possibility of the term “rupa” being used figuratively for immaterial dhammas, because there is no impact in the immaterial dhammas.🔽Others say: “Rupana is that which is impacted.”

original: apare. “Tassāti rūpassā”ti vadanti, nāmarūpassāti pana yuttaṃ. Yathā hi rūpassa,
analyzed: apare tassa ati rūpassa ati vadanti nāma rūpassa ati pana yuttam yathā hi rūpassa
translated: They say: “Tassa” means “of the rupa.” But it is proper to say “of the name-and-form.”🔽For just as there is an exposition of the rupa,

original: evaṃ nāmassāpi vedanākkhandhādivasena, madanimmadanādivasena ca vitthārakathā visuddhimagge
analyzed: evam nāmassa api vedanā khandha ādi vasena mada nimmadana ādi vasena ca vitthāra kathā visuddhi magge
translated: so there is an exposition of the name in the Visuddhimagga in terms of the aggregates of feeling, etc., and in terms of the intoxicants, etc.

original: vuttā evāti. Iti ayaṃ duko kusalattikena saṅgahite sabhāvadhamme pariggahetvā pavattoti.
analyzed: vuttā evā ti iti ayam duko kusala ttikena saṅgahite sabhāva dhamme pariggahetvā pavatto ti
translated: Thus this dyad occurs in the analysis of the dhammas of individual essence included in the section on the wholesome.

original: Avijjāti avindiyaṃ “attā, jīvo, itthī, puriso”ti evamādikaṃ vindatīti avijjā. Vindiyaṃ
analyzed: avijjā ati avindiyam attā jīvaḥ itthī purisaḥ iti evam ādikam vindati iti avijjā vindiyam
translated: “Ignorance” : that which is not to be found , i.e., the self, the soul, the woman, the man, etc., is found .

original: “dukkhaṃ, samudayo”ti evamādikaṃ na vindatīti avijjā. Sabbampi dhammajātaṃ aviditakaraṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: dukkham samudayo ti evamādikam na vindati iti avijjā sabbam pi dhamma jātam avidita karaṇa ṭṭhena
translated: “He does not find ‘suffering’ and ‘origin’ and so on,” thus it is ignorance. All dhammas are ignorance in the sense of making the unknown.

original: avijjā. Antarahite saṃsāre satte javāpetīti avijjā. Atthato pana sā dukkhādīnaṃ catunnaṃ
analyzed: avijjā anta rahite saṃsāre satte java apeti iti avijjā atthato pana sā dukkha ādīnam catunnam
translated: Ignorance causes beings to run in the round of rebirths, thus it is ignorance. But in meaning it is the delusion that covers up the individual essences of the four truths,

original: saccānaṃ sabhāvacchādako sammoho hotīti āha “dukkhādīsu aññāṇa”nti. Bhavapatthanā
analyzed: saccānam sabhā avacchādako sammohaḥ hoti iti āha dukkha ādīsu aññāṇam ti bhava patthanā
translated: suffering and the rest. Hence it is said: “Ignorance is the unknowing of suffering, and so on.”

original: nāma kāmabhavādīnaṃ patthanāvasena pavattataṇhā. Tenāha “yo bhavesu bhavacchando”tiādi.
analyzed: nāma kāma bhava ādīnam patthanā vasena pavatta taṇhā tena āha yaḥ bhavesu bhava chandaḥ itiādi
translated: Craving for becoming is craving that occurs as the wish for sense-desire becoming, and so on. Hence it is said: “The wish for becoming, and so on.”

original: Iti “ayaṃ duko vaṭṭamūlasamudācāradassanatthaṃ gahito.
analyzed: iti ayam dukaḥ vaṭṭa mūla samudācāra dassana attham gahitaḥ
translated: Thus this dyad is included in order to show the root of the round and its actual occurrence.

original: Bhavadiṭṭhīti khandhapañcakaṃ “attā ca loko cā”ti gāhetvā taṃ “bhavissatī”ti gaṇhanavasena
analyzed: bhavat iṭṭhī iti khandha pañcakam attā ca loko ca ati gāhetvā tam bhavissati iti gaṇhana vasena
translated: The view of becoming is the eternalist view that occurs in the mode of grasping the five aggregates as “self” and “world” and of grasping that as “existing.”🔽Hence it is said: “Becoming is called . . .” The view of non-becoming is the annihilationist view that occurs in the mode of grasping the five aggregates as “self” and “world” and of grasping that as “not existing.”

original: niviṭṭhā sassatadiṭṭhīti attho. Tenāha “bhavo vuccatī”tiādi. Bhavissatīti bhavo,
analyzed: niviṭṭhā sassata diṭṭhī iti attho tena āha bhavaḥ vuccati itiādi bhavissati iti bhavaḥ
translated: Hence it is said: “Non-becoming is called . . .”

original: tiṭṭhati sabbakālaṃ atthīti attho. Sassatanti sassatabhāvo. Vibhavadiṭṭhīti khandhapañcakameva
analyzed: tiṭṭhati sabbakālam atthi iti attho sassatanti sassata bhāvaḥ vibhava diṭṭhi iti khandha pañcakam eva
translated: “Becoming” is what exists, what endures for all time, what is; “eternity” is the state of being eternal.

original: “attā”ti ca “loko”ti ca gahetvā taṃ “na bhavissatī”ti gaṇhanavasena niviṭṭhā ucchedadiṭṭhīti
analyzed: attā ati ca loko ti ca gahetvā tam na bhavissati iti gaṇhana vasena niviṭṭhā uccheda diṭṭhī iti
translated: “Self” and “world” are taken as a basis for the assumption that they will not exist.

original: attho. Tenāha “vibhavo vuccatī”tiādi. Vibhavissati vinassati ucchijjatīti vibhavo, ucchedo.🔽Yaṃ na hirīyatīti yena dhammena taṃsampayuttadhammasamūho, puggalo vā na hirīyati
analyzed: atthaḥ tena āha vibhavaḥ vuccati itiādi vibhavissati vinassati ucchijjati iti vibhavaḥ ucchedaḥ  yam na hirīyati iti yena dhammena tad sampayutta dhamma samūhaḥ puggalaḥ vā na hirīyati
translated: The meaning is that they are fixed on annihilationism by taking that as a basis for the assumption that they will not exist. Hence he said, “non-existence is called ….” It will not exist, it will be destroyed, it will be annihilated, thus it is non-existence, annihilation.🔽By what he is not ashamed: the meaning should be understood as follows: by that state, by the aggregate of associated states, or by the person, he is not ashamed,

original: na lajjati, liṅgavipallāsaṃ vā katvā yo dhammoti attho veditabbo. Hirīyitabbenāti
analyzed: na lajjati liṅga vipallāsam vā katvā yaḥ dhammaḥ ti atthaḥ veditabbaḥ hirīyitabbena ati
translated: he is not embarrassed. Or else, by the state that is the opposite of the state of shame. He is not ashamed of what he ought to be ashamed of:

original: upayogatthe karaṇavacanaṃ, hirīyitabbayuttakaṃ kāyaduccaritādidhammaṃ na jigucchatīti🔽attho. Nillajjatāti pāpassa ajigucchanā. Yaṃ na ottappatīti etthāpi vuttanayeneva
analyzed: upayoga atthe karaṇa vacanam hirīyitabba yuttakam kāya duccarita ādi dhammam na jigucchati iti  atthaḥ nillajjatā ati pāpassa a jigucchanā yam na ottappati iti ettha api vutta nayena iva
translated: the accusative is in the sense of instrument. He does not feel disgust for the state of bodily misconduct, etc., which ought to be felt as shameful.🔽The meaning is: he is not embarrassed by evil. He is not afraid of what he ought to be afraid of: the meaning should be understood here in the same way as above.

original: attho veditabbo. Ottappitabbenāti pana hetuatthe karaṇavacanaṃ, ottappitabbayuttakena
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ottappitabbena ati pana hetu atthe karaṇa vacanam ottappitabba yuttakena
translated: But the accusative is in the sense of reason. He is not afraid of what ought to be feared,

original: ottappassa hetubhūtena kāyaduccaritādināti attho. Hirīyitabbenāti etthāpi vā evameva
analyzed: ottappassa hetu bhūtena kāya duccarita ādinā ati atthaḥ hirīyitabbena ati ettha api vā evam eva
translated: of the reason for fear, of the state of bodily misconduct, etc., which is the cause of fear. Or else, the meaning can be understood here in the same way as in the case of “what he ought to be ashamed of.”

original: attho veditabbo. Abhāyanakaākāroti pāpato anuttāsanākāro.
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ abhāyanaka ākāraḥ ti pāpataḥ anutta āsana ākāraḥ
translated: The meaning should be understood. The mode of non-fear: the mode of non-terror from evil.

original: “Yaṃ hirīyatī”tiādīsu anantaraduke vuttanayena attho veditabbo. Niyakajjhattaṃ jātiādisamuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: yam hirīyati iti ādīsu anantara duke vutta nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ niyaka ajjhattam jāti ādi samuṭṭhānam
translated: In the case of “What one is ashamed of” and so on, the meaning should be understood in the way already stated in the case of the preceding pair.🔽The shame that arises in one’s own person from one’s own birth, etc.,🔽is called “arisen internally.”🔽The shame that arises in the external person, in the continuity of another,

original: etissāti ajjhattasamuṭṭhānā. Niyakajjhattato bahibhāvato bahiddhā parasantāne samuṭṭhānaṃ🔽etissāti bahiddhā samuṭṭhānā. Attā eva adhipati attādhipati, ajjhattasamuṭṭhānattā
analyzed: etissa ati ajjhatta samuṭṭhānā niyaka jjhattataḥ bahi bhāvataḥ bahiddhā para santāne samuṭṭhānam  etissa ati bahiddhā samuṭṭhānā attā eva adhipati attā adhipati ajjhatta samuṭṭhāna ttā
translated: is called “arisen externally.”🔽The self is the lord of the self, thus it is “self-lordly.”🔽It is “self-lordly” because it arises in one’s own person.

original: eva attādhipatito āgamanato attādhipateyyā. Lokādhipateyyanti etthāpi eseva nayo.
analyzed: eva attā adhipatitaḥ āgamanataḥ attā ādhipateyyā loka ādhipateyyanti ettha api eṣā iva nayaḥ
translated: It is “world-lordly” because it comes from the world.🔽It is “endowed with the nature of shame” because it is established in the form of disgust with evil.

original: Lajjāsabhāvasaṇṭhitāti pāpato jigucchanarūpena avaṭṭhitā. Bhayasabhāvasaṇṭhitanti🔽tato uttāsanarūpena avaṭṭhitaṃ. Ajjhattasamuṭṭhānāditā ca hirottappānaṃ tattha tattha
analyzed: lajjā sabhāva saṇṭhitā ati pāpataḥ jigucchana rūpena avaṭṭhitā bhaya sabhāva saṇṭhita nti  tatas uttāsana rūpena avaṭṭhitam ajjhatta samuṭṭhāna ādi tā ca hirottappānam tattha tattha
translated: It is “endowed with the nature of fear” because it is established in the form of terror of it.

original: pākaṭabhāvena vuttā, na pana tesaṃ kadācipi aññamaññavippayogato. Na hi lajjanaṃ
analyzed: pākaṭa bhāvena vuttāḥ na pana tesam kadācipi aññamañña vippayogato na hi lajjanam
translated: And the fact that shame and fear are arisen internally, etc., is stated according to their prominence in the various cases, but they are never divorced from each other. For it is not possible to be disgusted with evil and yet not to fear it, or to fear it and yet not to be disgusted with it.

original: nibbhayaṃ, pāpabhayaṃ vā alajjanaṃ atthīti.🔽Dukkhanti kicchaṃ, aniṭṭhanti vā attho. Vippaṭikūlagāhimhīti dhammānudhammapaṭipattiyā
analyzed: nibbhayam pāpa bhayam vā alajjanam atthi iti  dukkhanti kiccham aniṭṭhanti vā attho vippaṭikūla gāhimhi iti dhamma anudhamma paṭipattiyā
translated: or that there is no fear of evil or of shame.🔽The meaning of ‘painful’ is ‘difficult’ or ‘unpleasant.’ The words ‘contrary and adverse’ mean ‘going against’ the practice of the Dhamma in conformity with the Dhamma.

original: vilomagāhake. Tassā eva vipaccanīkaṃ duppaṭipatti sātaṃ iṭṭhaṃ etassāti vipaccanīkasāto,
analyzed: viloma gāhake tassāḥ eva vipaccanīkam duppaṭipatti sātam iṭṭham etassa ati vipaccanīka sāto
translated: The opposite of that is ‘contrary and agreeable.’ The meaning is: ‘agreeable to one who is contrary.’

original: tasmiṃ vipaccanīkasāte. Evaṃbhūto ca ovādabhūte sāsanakkame ovādake ca ādarabhāvarahito
analyzed: tasmim vipaccanīka sāte evaṃbhūto ca ovāda bhūte sāsana kkame ovādake ca ādara bhāva rahito
translated: One who is such is devoid of respect for the instruction, i.e. for the teaching which is the means of instruction, and for the instructor.

original: hotīti āha “anādare”ti. Tassa kammanti tassa dubbacassa puggalassa anādariyavasena🔽pavattacetanā dovacassaṃ. Tassa bhāvoti tassa yathāvuttassa dovacassassa atthibhāvo🔽dovacassatā, atthato dovacassameva. Tenevāha “sā atthato saṅkhārakkhandho hotī”ti.
analyzed: hoti iti āha anādare ti tassa tassa dubbacassa puggalassa anādariya vasena  pavatta cetanā dovacassam tassa bhāvaḥ ti tassa yathāvuttassa dovacassassa atthi bhāvaḥ  dovacassatā atthataḥ dovacassam eva tena iva āha sā atthataḥ saṅkhāra kkhandhaḥ hoti iti
translated: ‘In disrespect’ means in the volition that occurs through disrespect for that person who is difficult to admonish.🔽‘The state of that’ means the existence of that difficulty in admonishing as described.🔽‘The state of being difficult to admonish’ is the same as ‘difficulty in admonishing.’ Therefore it is said: ‘It is the formation aggregate in meaning.’

original: Cetanāppadhānatāya hi saṅkhārakkhandhassa evaṃ vuttaṃ. Etenākārenāti appadakkhiṇaggāhitākārena.
analyzed: cetanā appadhāna tāya hi saṅkhāra kkhandhassa evam vuttam etena ākārena ati appadakkhiṇa ggāhita ākārena
translated: For the formation aggregate is so called because of the predominance of volition. ‘In this way’ means in the way of being difficult to admonish.

original: Assaddhiyadussīlyādipāpadhammayogato puggalā pāpā nāma hontīti dassetuṃ “ye te puggalā
analyzed: assaddhiya dussīlya ādi pāpa dhamma yogato puggalā pāpā nāma honti iti dassetuṃ ye te puggalā
translated: People are called wicked because they are associated with wicked states such as non-faith, immorality, etc. In order to show this, the Exalted One said: “Those people who are faithless …

original: assaddhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Yāya cetanāya puggalo pāpasampavaṅko nāma hoti, sā cetanā🔽pāpamittatā, cattāropi vā arūpino khandhā tadākārappavattā pāpamittatāti dassento
analyzed: assaddha atiādi vuttam yāya cetanāya puggalo pāpa sampavaṅkaḥ nāma hoti sā cetanā  pāpa mitta tā cattāraḥ api vā arūpino khandhā tad ākāra ppavattā pāpa mitta tā ti dassento
translated: The persons who are associated with evil states such as non-faith are called “evil” . To show this, the text says: “Those persons who are without faith” . The volition by which a person becomes “associated with evil” is

original: “sāpi atthato dovacassatā viya daṭṭhabbā”ti āha.🔽“Sukhaṃ vaco etasmiṃ padakkhiṇaggāhimhi anulomasāte sādare puggaleti subbacotiādinā,🔽“kalyāṇā saddhādayo puggalā etassa mittāti kalyāṇamitto”tiādinā ca anantaradukassa🔽attho icchitoti āha sovacassatā…pe… vuttapaṭipakkhanayena veditabbā”ti. Ubhoti sovacassatā,
analyzed: sā api atthataḥ dovacassatā viya daṭṭhabbā iti āha  sukham vacaḥ etasmin padakkhiṇa ggāhimhi anuloma sāte sādare puggala iti sup baca uti ādinā  kalyāṇā saddhā ādayaḥ puggalāḥ etassa mittā ati kalyāṇa mittā iti ādinā ca anantara dukassa  atthaḥ icchito ti āha sovacassatā āpe vutta paṭipakkha nayena veditabbā ati ubho ti sovacassatā
translated: evil friendship. Or the four immaterial aggregates occurring in that form are evil friendship. Showing this, the text says: “This should be regarded as similar to the explanation of difficult to correct” .🔽“The person who is obedient, who is easy to speak to, who is respectful, who is full of loving-kindness, is called ‘one who is easy to speak to.’“

original: kalyāṇamittatā ca. Tesaṃ khandhānaṃ pavattiākāravisesā “sovacassatā, kalyāṇamittatā”ti
analyzed: kalyāṇa mitta tā ca tesam khandhānam pavatti ākāra visesā sovacassatā kalyāṇa mitta tā ati
translated: “The person who has good friends is called ‘one who has good friends.’“ The meaning intended in the next clause is the same as that in the preceding clause. Therefore the text says: “Easy to correct should be understood in the opposite sense to difficult to correct” . Both are easy to correct and good friendship. The particular modes of occurrence of these aggregates are called “easy to correct” and “good friendship” .

original: ca vuccanti, te lokiyāpi honti lokuttarāpīti āha “lokiyalokuttaramissakā kathitā”ti.
analyzed: ca vuccanti te lokiyā api honti lokuttarā api iti āha lokiya lokuttara missakā kathitā ati
translated: They are called “ordinary and supramundane mixed” .

original: Vatthubhedādinā anekabhedabhinnā taṃtaṃjātivasena ekajjhaṃ katvā rāsito gayhamānā
analyzed: vatthu bheda ādinā aneka bheda bhinnā taṃ taṃ jāti vasena ekajjham katvā rāseḥ gayhamānā
translated: They are called “offenses” when they are collected together by being put into one class according to the various kinds of rebirth.

original: āpattiyova āpattikkhandhā. Tā pana antarāpattīnaṃ aggahaṇe pañcapi āpattikkhandhā
analyzed: āpattiyaḥ va āpatti kkhandhā tāḥ pana antarāpattīnam aggahaṇe pañca api āpatti kkhandhāḥ
translated: But if the offenses that are “in the interval” are not included, there are five classes of offenses.

original: āpattiyo, tāsaṃ pana gahaṇe sattapi āpattikkhandhā āpattiyo. “Imā āpattiyo, ettakā
analyzed: āpattiyaḥ tāsam pana gahaṇe āpatti kkhandhāḥ āpattiyaḥ imāḥ āpattiyaḥ ettakā
translated: But if they are included, there are seven classes of offenses.

original: āpattiyo, evañca tesaṃ āpajjanaṃ hotī”ti jānanapaññā āpattikusalatāti āha “yā tāsa”ntiādi.🔽Tāsaṃ āpattīnanti tāsu āpattīsu. Tattha yaṃ sambhinnavatthukāsu viya ṭhitāsu, duviññeyyavibhāgāsu
analyzed: āpattiyo evam ca tesam āpajjanam hoti iti jānana paññā āpatti kusala tā ti āha yā tāsam tiādi  tāsam āpattīnam ti tāsu āpattīsu tattha yam sambhinna vatthukāsu viya ṭhitāsu du viññeyya vibhāgāsu
translated: The knowledge of how many there are, what they are, and how they are committed, is skill in offenses.🔽In regard to those offenses: in regard to those offenses.🔽Herein, the defining of the offenses that are mixed up and not mixed up, and that are difficult to distinguish, is skill in offenses in particular.

original: ca āpattīsu asaṅkarato vavatthāna, ayaṃ visesato āpattikusalatāti dassetuṃ dutiyaṃ
analyzed: ca āpattīsu asaṅkarataḥ ayam visesataḥ āpatti kusala tā ti dassetum dutiyam
translated: In order to show this, the second🔽“offense” is mentioned.

original: āpattiggahaṇaṃ kataṃ. Saha kammavācāyāti kammavācāya saheva. Āpattito vuṭṭhāpanapayogatāya
analyzed: āpatti ggahaṇam katam saha kamma vācāya ati kamma vācāya saha iva āpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāpana payoga tāya
translated: With the announcement of the transaction: together with the announcement of the transaction.

original: kammabhūtā vācā kammavācā, tathābhūtā anusāvanavācā ceva “passissāmī”ti evaṃ pavattavācā
analyzed: kamma bhūtā vācā kamma vācā tathābhūtā anusāvana vācā ca iva passissāmi iti evam pavatta vācā
translated: Or else speech is action, and so speech that is such is the speech of the resolution and the speech that occurs as ‘I will see’ and so on.

original: ca. Tāya kammavācāya saddhiṃ samakālameva “imāya kammavācāya ito āpattito vuṭṭhānaṃ🔽hoti, hontañca paṭhame vā tatiye vā anusāvaneyyakārappatte, ‘saṃvarissāmī’ti vā pade
analyzed: ca tāya kamma vācāya saddhim sama kālam eva imāya kamma vācāya itas āpattitaḥ vuṭṭhānam  hoti hontam ca paṭhame vā tatiye vā anusāvaneyya kāra ppatte saṃvarissāmi iti vā pade
translated: With that speech of action, the knowledge of discerning the delimitation of the deliverance from the several kinds of offence thus ‘Deliverance from this offence is by this speech of action;

original: pariyosite hotī”ti evaṃ taṃ taṃ āpattīhi vuṭṭhānaparicchedaparijānanapaññā āpattivuṭṭhānakusalatā.
analyzed: pariyosite hoti iti evam tam tam āpattīhi vuṭṭhāna pariccheda parijānana paññā āpatti vuṭṭhāna kusala tā
translated: and it is when the first or the third announcement of the resolution has been made, and it is when the words “I will restrain myself” have been completed’ is skill in deliverance from offences.

original: Vuṭṭhānanti ca yathāpannāya āpattiyā yathā tathā anantarāyatāpādanaṃ, evaṃ vuṭṭhānaggahaṇeneva
analyzed: vuṭṭhānam ti ca yathā āpannāya āpattiyāḥ yathā tathā anantarāyata āpādanam evam vuṭṭhāna ggahaṇena iva
translated: ‘Deliverance’ is the making of an offence that has been committed no longer an obstruction by whatever means. So by the mention of ‘deliverance’

original: desanāyapi saṅgaho siddho hoti.🔽“Ito pubbe parikammaṃ pavattaṃ, ito paraṃ bhavaṅga majjhe samāpattī”ti evaṃ samāpattīnaṃ
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ siddhaḥ hoti  itas pubbe parikammam pavattam itas param bhavaṅga majjhe samāpatti iti evam samāpattīnam
translated: the declaration of it is included as well.

original: appanāparicchedajānanapaññā samāpattikusalatā. Vuṭṭhāne kusalabhāvo vuṭṭhānakusalatā,
analyzed: appanā pariccheda jānana paññā samāpatti kusala tā vuṭṭhāne kusala bhāvaḥ vuṭṭhāna kusala tā
translated: ‘The preliminary work has taken place up till now; from now on there is jhāna in the middle of the life-continuum’—this is the knowledge of discerning the delimitation of the attainment. The skill in attainment is the state of being skilled in the attainment.

original: pageva vuṭṭhāna paricchedakaraṃ ñāṇaṃ. Tenāha “yathāparicchinnasamayavasenevā”tiādi.
analyzed: pagā iva vuṭṭhāna pariccheda karam ñāṇam tena āha yathā paricchinna samaya vasena iva atiādi
translated: and still more so the knowledge that defines the end of the jhāna. Hence he said, “according to the time as delimited” and so on.

original: Vuṭṭhānasamatthāti vuṭṭhāpane samatthā.
analyzed: vuṭṭhāna samatthā ati vuṭṭhāpane samatthā
translated: Capable of ending: capable of ending the jhāna.

original: “Dhātukusalatā”ti ettha pathavīdhātuādayo, sukhadhātuādayo, kāmadhātuādayo ca dhātuyo
analyzed: ettha pathavī dhātu ādayo sukha dhātu ādayo kāma dhātu ādayo ca dhātuyo
translated: In the passage “Skill in elements” the elements are the earth element, etc., the pleasure element, etc., and the sense-desire element, etc.

original: etāsveva antogadhāti etāsu kosalle dassite tāsupi kosallaṃ dassitameva hotīti “aṭṭhārasa
analyzed: etāsu eva etāsu kosalle dassite tāsu pi kosallam dassitam eva hoti iti aṭṭhārasa
translated: Included in these: the skill in these is also shown by the skill in those.

original: dhātuyo cakkhudhātu…pe… manoviññāṇadhātū”ti vatvā “aṭṭhārasannaṃ dhātūnaṃ sabhāvaparicchedakā”ti
analyzed: dhātuyaḥ cakkhu dhātu pe manaḥ viññāṇa dhātū ti vatvā aṭṭhārasannam dhātūnam sabhāva paricchedakā ati
translated: Thus, after saying “The eighteen elements are the eye element … the mind-consciousness element,” he said, “The knowledge that defines the individual essences of the eighteen elements” .

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha sabhāvaparicchedakāti yathābhūtasabhāvāvabodhinī. “Savanapaññā dhāraṇapaññā”tiādinā
analyzed: vuttam tattha sabhāva paricchedakā ati yathā bhūta sabhāva avabodhinī savana paññā dhāraṇa paññā ati ādinā
translated: Herein, the knowledge that defines the individual essences is the knowledge that penetrates the individual essences as they really are.🔽The word “knowledge” should be construed with each of the terms “heard,” “stored,” and so on.

original: paccekaṃ paññā-saddo yojetabbo. Dhātūnaṃ savanadhāraṇapaññā sutamayā, itarā bhāvanāmayā.
analyzed: paccekam paññā saddaḥ yojetabbaḥ dhātūnam savana dhāraṇa paññā suta mayā itarā bhāvanā mayā
translated: The knowledge of the elements as heard and stored is the knowledge consisting in what is heard and what is stored up. The other is that consisting in development.🔽And here too the knowledge of exploring is mundane. For that is insight knowledge. The other is supramundane.

original: Tatthāpi sammasanapaññā lokiyā. Vipassanā paññā hi sā, itarā lokuttarā. Lakkhaṇādivasena,
analyzed: tattha api sammasana paññā lokiyā vipassanā paññā hi sā itarā lokuttarā lakkhaṇa ādi vasena
translated: By the characteristics, etc.,

original: aniccādivasena ca manasikaraṇaṃ manasikāro, tattha kosallaṃ manasikārakusalatā. Taṃ
analyzed: anicca ādi vasena ca manasikaraṇam manasikāro tattha kosallam manasikāra kusala tā taṃ
translated: And the attention given to the aggregates, etc., by way of impermanence, etc., is attention. Skill in that is skill in attention.

original: pana ādimajjhapariyosānavasena tidhā bhinditvā dassento “sammasanapaṭivedhapaccavekkhaṇapaññā”ti
analyzed: pana ādi majjha pariyosāna vasena tidhā bhinditvā dassento sammasana paṭivedha paccavekkhaṇa paññā ti
translated: But in order to show that it is threefold as beginning, middle, and end, he said “understanding of defining, of penetrating, and of reviewing.”

original: āha. Sammasanapaññā hi tassā ādi, paṭivedhapaññā majjhe, paccavekkhaṇapaññā pariyosānaṃ.🔽Āyatanānaṃ ganthato ca atthato ca uggaṇhanavasena tesaṃ dhātulakkhaṇādivibhāgassa🔽jānanapaññā uggahajānanapaññā. Sammasanapaṭivedhapaccavekkhaṇavidhino jānanapaññā
analyzed: āha sammasana paññā hi tassāḥ ādi paṭivedha paññā majjhe paccavekkhaṇa paññā pariyosānam  āyatanānam ganthato ca atthato ca uggaṇhana vasena tesam dhātu lakkhaṇa ādi vibhāgassa  jānana paññā uggaha jānana paññā sammasana paṭivedha paccavekkhaṇa vidhinaḥ jānana paññā
translated: For understanding of defining is the beginning of skill in aggregates, etc., understanding of penetrating is the middle, and understanding of reviewing is the end.🔽Understanding of learning is the understanding that knows the analysis of the elements, etc., by learning the aggregates, etc., by heart in the sense of the round of existences and in the sense of the meaning.🔽Understanding of attention is the understanding that knows the method of attending to the aggregates, etc., by the method of defining, penetrating, and reviewing.

original: manasikārajānanapaññā. Yasmā āyatanānipi atthato dhātuyova manasikāro ca uggaṇhanādivasena
analyzed: manasikāra jānana paññā yasmai atthataḥ ca uggaṇhana ādi vasena
translated: Since the aggregates, etc., are elements in the sense of the meaning, and since the method of attending to them is just the method of learning them by heart, etc.,

original: tesameva manasikāravidhi, tasmā dhātukusalatādikā tissopi kusalatā ekadese katvā
analyzed: tesam eva manasikāra vidhi tasmā dhātu kusala tā ādikā tissā api kusala tā ekadese katvā
translated: all three kinds of skill are included in the first kind of skill,🔽which is why “Furthermore” is said in order to show them all.

original: dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Savanaṃ viya uggaṇhanapaccavekkhaṇānipi parittañāṇakattukānīti
analyzed: dassetum api ca atiādi vuttam savanam viya uggaṇhana paccavekkhaṇāni pi paritta ñāṇa kattukāni iti
translated: Learning, reviewing, and defining are all of them only limited knowledge.

original: āha “savana uggahaṇapaccavekkhaṇā lokiyā”ti. Ariyamaggakkhaṇe sammasanamanasikārānaṃ🔽nipphatti pariniṭṭhānanti tesaṃ lokuttaratāpariyāyopi labbhatīti vuttaṃ “sammasanamanasikārā
analyzed: āha savane uggahaṇa paccavekkhaṇā lokiyā ti ariya magga kkhaṇe  nipphatti pariniṭṭhānanti tesam lokuttara tā pariyāyaḥ api labbhati iti vuttam sammasana manasikārā
translated: At the moment of the noble path, the mundane and supramundane are mixed in the case of the directing of attention that is the outcome of the path.

original: lokiyalokuttaramissakā”ti. Paccayadhammānaṃ hetuādīnaṃ attano paccayuppannānaṃ hetupaccayādibhāvena
analyzed: lokiya lokuttara missakā ti paccaya dhammānam hetu ādīnam attanaḥ paccaya uppannānam hetu paccaya ādi bhāvena
translated: The state of being a condition is the mode of being a condition of the conditions such as root cause, etc., in the sense of being a condition that has arisen with the occurrence of the conditioned states such as root cause, etc.

original: paccayabhāvo paccayākāro, so pana avijjādīnaṃ dvādasannaṃ paṭiccasamuppādaṅgānaṃ🔽vasena dvādasavidhoti āha “dvādasannaṃ paccayākārāna”nti. Uggahādivasenāti uggahamanasikārasavanasammasanapaṭivedhapaccavekkhaṇavasena.🔽Ṭhānañceva tiṭṭhati phalaṃ tadāyattavuttitāyāti kāraṇañca hetupaccayabhāvena karaṇato
analyzed: paccaya bhāvaḥ paccaya ākāro saḥ pana avijjā ādīnam dvādasannam paṭiccasamuppāda aṅgānam  vasena dvādasavidhaḥ ti āha uggaha ādi vasena ati uggaha manasikāra savana sammasana paṭivedha paccavekkhaṇa vasena  ṭhānam ca iva tiṭṭhati phalam tad āyatta vutti tāya ati kāraṇam ca hetu paccaya bhāvena karaṇato
translated: But that is of twelve kinds according to the twelve factors of dependent origination beginning with ignorance.🔽The meaning should be understood in this way: “The state of being a condition of the twelve kinds of conditions, etc., is the state of being a condition of the twelve factors of dependent origination beginning with ignorance, in the sense of being a condition that has arisen with the occurrence of the conditioned states such as root cause, etc.”🔽The meaning should be understood in this way: “The state of being a condition of the twelve kinds of conditions, etc., is the state of being a condition of the twelve factors of dependent origination beginning with ignorance, in the sense of being a condition that has arisen with the occurrence of the conditioned states such as root cause, etc.”

original: nipphādanato. Tesaṃ sotaviññāṇādīnaṃ. Etasmiṃ duke attho veditabboti sambandho. Ye
analyzed: nipphādanato tesam sota viññāṇa ādīnam etasmin duke atthaḥ veditabbaḥ iti sambandhaḥ ye
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way: “The state of being a condition of the twelve kinds of conditions, etc., is the state of being a condition of the twelve factors of dependent origination beginning with ignorance, in the sense of being a condition that has arisen with the occurrence of the conditioned states such as root cause, etc.”

original: dhammā yassa dhammassa kāraṇabhāvato ṭhānaṃ, teva dhammā taṃvidhurassa dhammassa🔽akāraṇabhāvato aṭṭhānanti paṭhamanaye phalabhedena tasseva dhammassa ṭhānāṭṭhānatā
analyzed: dhammā yassa dhammassa kāraṇa bhāvataḥ ṭhānam te iva dhammā taṃ vidhurassa dhammassa  akāraṇa bhāvataḥ aṭṭhānan ti paṭhama naye phala bhedena tassa iva dhammassa ṭhāna aṭṭhāna tā
translated: The states that are the ground for a given state by being its cause are the ground for the state that is devoid of that cause🔽by not being its cause. In the first method the ground and nonground of a given state are shown by the distinction of its result.

original: dīpitā; dutiyanaye pana abhinnepi phale paccayadhammabhedena tesaṃ ṭhānāṭṭhānatā
analyzed: dīpitā dutiya naye pana abhinne pi phale paccaya dhamma bhedena tesam ṭhānāṭṭhāna tā
translated: In the second method the ground and nonground of those states are shown by the distinction of the states that are conditions for the result, although the result is undifferentiated. This is the difference between the two methods.

original: dīpitāti ayametesaṃ viseso. Na hi kadāci ariyā diṭṭhisampadā niccaggāhassa kāraṇaṃ🔽hoti, akiriyatā pana siyā tassa kāraṇanti.🔽Ujuno bhāvo ajjavaṃ, ajimhatā akuṭilatā avaṅkatāti atthoti tamatthaṃ anajjavapaṭikkhepamukhena🔽dassetuṃ “gomuttavaṅkatā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Svāyaṃ anajjavo bhikkhūnaṃ yebhuyyena anesanāya,
analyzed: dīpitā ati ayam etesam visesaḥ na hi kadāci ariyā diṭṭhi sampadā nicca ggāhassa kāraṇam  hoti akiriya tā pana siyā tassa kāraṇanti  ujunaḥ bhāvaḥ ajjavam a jimha tā a kuṭila tā a vaṅka tā ati attho ti tam attham an ajjava paṭikkhepa mukhena  dassetum gomutta vaṅka tā tiādi vuttam su ayam anajjavaḥ bhikkhūnam yebhuyyena an esanāya
translated: For the noble ones’ right view is never a cause for the apprehension of permanence. But the latter’s non-performance can be a cause for it.🔽The meaning of straightness is the state of being straight, not crooked, not bent. In order to show this meaning by way of the exclusion of its opposite, “crookedness like a cow’s” is said. This crookedness is mostly found among monks who are not seekers

original: agocaracāritāya ca hotīti āha “ekacco hi…pe… caratī”ti. Ayaṃ gomuttavaṅkatā nāma
analyzed: a gocara cāritāya ca hoti iti āha ekaccaḥ hipe carati iti ayam gomuttavaṅkatā nāma
translated: and who wander outside the proper domain. Therefore it is said: “For some, etc.” This crookedness is called “crookedness like a cow’s”🔽because it is like the crookedness of a cow’s tail.

original: ādito paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā paṭipattiyā vaṅkabhāvato. Purimasadisoti paṭhamaṃ🔽vuttabhikkhusadiso. Candavaṅkatā nāma paṭipattiyā majjhaṭṭhāne vaṅkabhāvāpattito.
analyzed: āditas paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā paṭipattiyā vaṅka bhāvato purima sadisaḥ ti paṭhamam  vutta bhikkhu sadisaḥ canda vaṅka tā nāma paṭipattiyāḥ majjha ṭṭhāne vaṅka bhāva āpattito
translated: From the beginning to the end, the practice is not crooked in its progress. “ Like the first” : like the bhikkhu mentioned first . “ Crooked like the moon” : because of the crookedness of the practice in the middle.🔽“ Crooked like the tip of an ox-goad” : because of the crookedness at the end. This is called “straightforwardness” .

original: Naṅgalakoṭivaṅkatā nāma pariyosāne vaṅkabhāvāpattito. Idaṃ ajjavaṃ nāma sabbatthakameva🔽ujubhāvasiddhito. Ajjavatāti ākāraniddeso, yenākārenassa ajjavo pavattati, tadākāraniddesoti
analyzed: naṅgala koṭi vaṅka tā nāma pariyosāne vaṅka bhāva āpattitaḥ idam ajjavam nāma sabbatthakam eva  uju bhāva siddhitaḥ ajjavatā ati ākāra niddesaḥ yena ākārena assa ajjavaḥ pavattati tad ākāra niddesaḥ ti
translated: It is established everywhere as uprightness. “ Straightforward” is a description of the mode by which it occurs. The meaning is: a description of that mode by which it occurs straightforwardly.

original: attho. Lajjatīti lajjī, hirimā, tassa bhāvo lajjavaṃ, hirīti attho. Lajjā etassa
analyzed: atthaḥ lajjati iti lajjī hirimā tassa bhāvaḥ lajjavam hirī iti atthaḥ lajjā etassa
translated: “ He is ashamed” : he is ashamed of evil, he is modest. The meaning is: he has shame, he has modesty. “ He is ashamed” : he is ashamed of evil, he is modest. The meaning is: he has shame, he has modesty.

original: atthīti lajjī yathā “mālī, māyī”ti ca, tassa bhāvo lajjībhāvo, sā eva lajjā.
analyzed: atthi iti lajjī yathā mālī māyī iti ca tassa bhāvaḥ lajjī bhāvaḥ sā eva lajjā
translated: “ He has shame” : he has shame. “ He has modesty” : he has modesty. “ He has shame” : he has shame. “ He has modesty” : he has modesty.

original: Parāparādhādīnaṃ adhivāsanakkhamaṃ adhivāsanakhanti. Sucisīlatā soraccaṃ. Sā hi sobhanakammaratatā, suṭṭhu vā pāpato oratabhāvo viratatā soraccaṃ. Tenāha “suratabhāvo”ti.
analyzed: para aparādha ādīnam adhivāsana kkhamam adhivāsana khanti suci sīla tā soraccam sā hi sobhana kamma rata tā suṭṭhu vā pāpataḥ orata bhāvaḥ virata tā soraccam tena āha surata bhāva iti
translated: “ Forbearance in enduring” : the ability to endure the offences of others. “ Gentleness” : good virtue. For that is the state of being fond of good deeds, or it is the state of being well turned away from evil, the state of being well turned away being gentleness. Hence it is said: “the state of being well turned” .

original: “Nāmañca rūpañcā”tiādīsu ayaṃ aparo nayo – nāmakaraṇaṭṭhenāti aññaṃ anapekkhitvā🔽sayameva attano nāmakaraṇasabhāvatoti attho. Yañhi parassa nāmaṃ karoti, tassa ca
analyzed: nāman ca rūpam ca ati ādīsu ayam aparaḥ nayaḥ nāma karaṇa ṭṭhena ati aññam an apekkhitvā  sayam eva attanaḥ nāmakaraṇa sabhāvato ti atthaḥ yat hi parassa nāmam karoti tassa ca
translated: In the case of the words “name-and-form,” etc., there is this other method: “As to the meaning of ‘naming’: it is the state of being a name in the sense of naming, independently of anything else,

original: tadapekkhattā aññāpekkhaṃ nāmakaraṇanti nāmakaraṇasabhāvatā na hoti, tasmā mahājanassa🔽ñātīnaṃ, guṇānañca sāmaññanāmādikārakānaṃ nāmabhāvo nāpajjati. Yassa ca aññehi nāmaṃ🔽karīyati, tassa ca nāmakaraṇasabhāvatā natthīti, natthiyeva nāmabhāvo. Vedanādīnaṃ
analyzed: tad apekkha ttā añña apekkham nāmakaraṇan ti nāmakaraṇa sabhāva tā na hoti tasmā mahājanassa  ñātīnam guṇānam ca sāmañña nāma ādi kārakānam nāma bhāvaḥ na āpajjati yassa ca aññehi nāmam  tassa ca nāma karaṇa sabhāva tā natthi iti nāma bhāvaḥ vedanā ādīnam
translated: the individual essence that is the cause of the designation of individual essences. For when one names another, then, since that is dependent on that, it is not the state of being a cause of the designation of individual essences that is called ‘naming.’ Therefore the state of being a name does not belong to such names as ‘mother,’ ‘father,’ ‘brother,’ ‘sister,’ ‘friend,’ ‘relative,’ ‘virtue,’ ‘good,’ etc.,

original: pana sabhāvasiddhattā vedanādināmassa nāmakaraṇasabhāvato nāmatā vuttā. Pathavīādi🔽nidassanena nāmassa sabhāvasiddhataṃyeva nidasseti, na nāmabhāvasāmaññaṃ, niruḷhattā
analyzed: pana sabhāva siddha ttā vedanā ādi nāmassa nāma karaṇa sabhāvataḥ nāma tā vuttā pathavī ādi  nidassanena nāmassa nidasseti na nāma bhāva sāmaññam niruḷha ttā
translated: which are designations of other things. And it does not belong to the names of such things as the earth, water, fire, and wind, which are designations of mere groups of material form, etc., since they are not the state of being a cause of the designation of individual essences. And it does not belong to the names of such things as the earth kasiṇa, the water kasiṇa, etc., since they are designations of mere groups of mental data. And it does not belong to the names of such things as the earth element, the water element, etc., since they are designations of mere groups of properties. And it does not belong to the names of such things as the earth-based, the water-based, etc., since they are designations of mere groups of beings. And it does not belong to the names of such things as the past, the future, etc., since they are designations of mere groups of states. And it does not belong to the names of such things as the seen, the heard, etc., since they are designations of mere groups of ideas. And it does not belong to the names of such things as the seen, the heard, etc., since they are designations of mere groups of ideas.

original: pana nāma-saddo arūpadhammesu eva vattati, na pathavīādīsūti na tesaṃ nāmabhāvo.
analyzed: pana nāma saddaḥ arūpa dhammesu eva vattati na pathavī ādīsu iti na tesam nāma bhāvo
translated: “As to the meaning of ‘naming’: it is the state of being a name in the sense of naming, independently of anything else, the individual essence that is the cause of the designation of individual essences. For when one names another, then, since that is dependent on that, it is not the state of being a cause of the designation of individual essences that is called ‘naming.’ Therefore the state of being a name does not belong to such names as ‘mother,’ ‘father,’ ‘brother,’ ‘sister,’ ‘friend,’ ‘relative,’ ‘virtue,’ ‘good,’ etc.,

original: Na hi pathavīādināmaṃ vijahitvā kesādināmehi rūpadhammānaṃ viya vedanādināmaṃ vijahitvā🔽aññena nāmena arūpadhammānaṃ voharitabbena piṇḍākārena pavatti atthīti.
analyzed: na hi pathavī ādi nāmam vijahitvā kesa ādi nāmehi rūpa dhammānam viya vedanā ādi nāmam vijahitvā  aññena nāmena arūpa dhammānam voharitabbena piṇḍa ākārena pavatti atthi iti
translated: For there is no occurrence of the formless states in the way that there is of the material states, which occur in the form of a mass that can be pointed to by such names as “head hairs,” “body hairs,” etc., after abandoning the names “earth,” etc.

original: Atha vā rūpadhammā cakkhādayo rūpādayo ca, tesaṃ pakāsakapakāsitabbabhāvato vināpi
analyzed: atha vā rūpa dhammā cakkha ādayaḥ rūpa ādayaḥ ca tesam pakāsaka pakāsitabba bhāvataḥ vinā api
translated: Or alternatively, the material states, such as the eye, etc., and visible data, etc., are evident by means of their names, which are their manifestor and manifested, even without the names being grasped as “name”;

original: nāmena pākaṭā honti, na evaṃ arūpadhammāti te adhivacanasamphasso viya nāmāyattaggahaṇīyabhāvena🔽“nāma”nti vuttā. Paṭighasamphasso ca na cakkhādīni viya nāmena vinā pākaṭoti “nāma”nti
analyzed: nāmena pākaṭāḥ honti na evam arūpa dhammā ati te adhivacana samphassaḥ viya nāma āyatta ggahaṇīya bhāvena  nāman ti vuttā paṭigha samphasso ca na cakkha ādīni viya nāmena vinā pākaṭaḥ ti nāman ti
translated: but the formless states are not like that. So they are called “name” in the sense of being graspable as “name” by the contact that is mental-object-contact,

original: vutto, arūpatāya vā aññanāmasabhāgattā saṅgahitoyaṃ, aññaphassasabhāgattā vā. Vacanatthopi🔽hi rūpayatīti rūpaṃ, nāmayatīti nāmanti idha pacchimapurimānaṃ sambhavati. Rūpayatīti
analyzed: vuttaḥ arūpa tāya vā añña nāma sabhāga ttā saṅgahitaḥ ayam añña phassa sabhāga ttā vā vacana atthaḥ api  hi rūpayati iti rūpam nāmayati iti idha pacchima purimānam sambhavati rūpayati iti
translated: like the contact called “contact with the name” . And the contact called “contact with impingement” is not evident without a name, as are the eye, etc., so it is called “name” . Or alternatively, it is included because it is not of the same nature as the other names, that is, as the material states, or because it is not of the same nature as the other kinds of contact.🔽For the meaning of the words is this: “It is material, thus it is matter” , and “It is named, thus it is name” . Here the latter is appropriate,

original: vināpi nāmena attānaṃ pakāsetīti attho. Nāmayatīti nāmena vinā apākaṭabhāvato attano
analyzed: vinā api nāmena attānam pakāseti iti atthaḥ nāmayati iti nāmena vinā apākaṭa bhāvataḥ attanaḥ
translated: “It is material, thus it manifests itself even without a name”: that is the meaning. “It is named, thus it is not evident without a name”:

original: pakāsakaṃ nāmaṃ karotīti attho. Ārammaṇādhipatipaccayatāyāti satipi rūpassa ārammaṇādhipatipaccayabhāve
analyzed: pakāsakam nāmam karoti iti atthaḥ ārammaṇa adhipati paccaya tāya ati sati pi rūpassa ārammaṇa adhipati paccaya bhāve
translated: As object-predominance condition: although visible form is an object-predominance condition,

original: na taṃ paramassāsabhūtaṃ nibbānaṃ viya sātisayaṃ nāmanabhāvena paccayoti nibbānameva “nāma”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: na tam parama ssāsa bhūtam nibbānam viya sa atisayam nāmana bhāvena paccayaḥ ti nibbānam eva nāmanti vuttam
translated: it is not a condition in the way that Nibbāna is, which is the supreme object, by means of the name-making faculty. So it is Nibbāna that is called ‘name.’

original: “Avijjā ca bhavataṇhā cā”ti ayaṃ duko sattānaṃ vaṭṭamūlasamudācāradassanattho. Samudācaratīti
analyzed: avijjā ca bhava taṇhā ca ati ayam duko sattānam vaṭṭa mūla samudācāra dassana ttho samudācarati iti
translated: The dyad ‘ignorance and craving for being’ is given in order to show the actual occurrence of the roots of the round.🔽For ‘actual occurrence’ is the same as ‘occurrence’ .

original: hi samudācāro, vaṭṭamūlameva samudācāro vaṭṭamūlasamudācāro, vaṭṭamūladassanena vā🔽vaṭṭamūlānaṃ pavatti dassitā hotīti vaṭṭamūlānaṃ samudācāro vaṭṭamūlasamudācāro,
analyzed: hi samudācāraḥ vaṭṭa mūlam eva samudācāraḥ vaṭṭa mūla samudācāraḥ vaṭṭa mūla dassanena vā  vaṭṭa mūlānam pavatti dassitā hoti iti vaṭṭa mūlānam samudācāraḥ vaṭṭa mūla samudācāro
translated: Or the actual occurrence of the roots of the round is the actual occurrence of the roots of the round.🔽Or the actual occurrence of the roots of the round is the occurrence of the roots of the round.

original: taṃdassanatthoti attho.🔽Ekekasmiñca “attā”ti ca “loko”ti ca gahaṇavisesaṃ upādāya “attā ca loko cā”ti vuttaṃ,
analyzed: tad dassana tthaḥ ti attho  eka ekasmin ca attā ati ca loko iti ca gahaṇa visesam upādāya attā ca ca ati vuttam
translated: The meaning is that it is given in order to show the roots of the round.🔽And in each case the words ‘self and world’ are used because of a difference in the way in which the self and the world are apprehended.

original: ekaṃ vā khandhaṃ “attā”ti gahetvā aññaṃ attano upabhogabhūtaṃ “loko”ti gaṇhantassa,
analyzed: ekam vā khandham attā ati gahetvā aññam attanaḥ upabhoga bhūtam loko ti gaṇhantassa
translated: For one who apprehends one of the aggregates as a self may apprehend another as the world that is owned by that self.

original: attano attānaṃ “attā”ti gahetvā parassa attānaṃ “loko”ti gaṇhantassa vā vasena “attā🔽ca loko cā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: attanaḥ attānam attā ati gahetvā parassa attānam loko ti gaṇhantassa vā vasena attā  ca loko ca iti vuttam
translated: Or else, “self and world” is said with reference to one who, having taken himself as “self,” takes the self of another as “world.”

original: Saha sikkhitabbo dhammo sahadhammo, tattha bhavaṃ sahadhammikaṃ, tasmiṃ sahadhammike.
analyzed: saha sikkhitabbaḥ dhammaḥ saha dhammaḥ tattha bhavam sahadhammikam tasmim sahadhammike
translated: “The same training” is the same Dhamma. “The same Dhamma” is that which exists there. “The same Dhamma” is that which exists in that.

original: Dovacassa-saddato āya-saddaṃ anaññattaṃ katvā “dovacassāya”nti vuttaṃ, dovacassassa
analyzed: do vacassa saddataḥ āya saddam an aññattam katvā do vacassa āyanti vuttam do vacassassa
translated: “For the difficult-to-cure” is said by making the word “cure” the same as the word “ayana.”🔽Or else, “for the difficult-to-cure” is the going, the occurrence, of the difficult-to-cure.🔽“For the one who is practicing” is the training by way of the inclination to practice.

original: vā ayanaṃ pavatti dovacassāyaṃ. Āsevantassāpi anusikkhanā ajjhāsayena bhajanāti āha🔽“sevanā…pe… bhajanā”ti. Sabbatobhāgena bhatti sambhatti.
analyzed: vā ayanam āsevantassa api anusikkhanā ajjhāsayena bhajanā ti āha  sevanāpe sabbatobhāgena bhatti sambhatti
translated: “For the one who is using” is the one who is using by way of the inclination to use.🔽“For the one who is devoted” is the one who is devoted by way of the inclination to be devoted.🔽“For the one who is devoted to” is the one who is devoted to by way of the inclination to be devoted to.🔽“For the one who is using” is the one who is using by way of the inclination to use.🔽“For the one who is devoted” is the one who is devoted by way of the inclination to be devoted.🔽“For the one who is devoted to” is the one who is devoted to by way of the inclination to be devoted to.🔽“For the one who is using” is the one who is using by way of the inclination to use.

original: Saha kammavācāyāti abbhānatiṇavatthārakakammavācāya, “ahaṃ bhante itthannāmaṃ āpattiṃ
analyzed: saha kamma vācāya ati abbhāna tiṇavatthāraka kamma vācāya aham bhante itthannāmam āpattim
translated: “For the one who is devoted” is the one who is devoted by way of the inclination to be devoted.🔽“For the one who is devoted to” is the one who is devoted to by way of the inclination to be devoted to.🔽“For the one who is using” is the one who is using by way of the inclination to use.

original: āpajji”ntiādikāya ca saheva. Saheva hi kammavācāya āpattivuṭṭhānañca paricchijjati,
analyzed: ca saha iva saha iva hi kamma vācāya āpatti vuṭṭhānam ca paricchijjati
translated: “For the one who is devoted” is the one who is devoted by way of the inclination to be devoted.🔽“For the one who is devoted to” is the one who is devoted to by way of the inclination to be devoted to.🔽“For the one who is using” is the one who is using by way of the inclination to use.🔽“For the one who is devoted” is the one who is devoted by way of the inclination to be devoted.

original: “paññattilakkhaṇāya āpattiyā vā kāraṇaṃ vītikkamalakkhaṇaṃ kāyakammaṃ, vacīkammaṃ
analyzed: paññatti lakkhaṇāya āpattiyāḥ vā kāraṇam vītikkama lakkhaṇam kāya kammam vacī kammam
translated: “For the one who is devoted to” is the one who is devoted to by way of the inclination to be devoted

original: vā, vuṭṭhānassa kāraṇaṃ kammavācā”ti kāraṇena saha phalassa jānanavasena “saha kammavācāyā”ti
analyzed: vā vuṭṭhānassa kāraṇam kamma vācā ati kāraṇena saha phalassa jānana vasena saha kamma vācāya ati
translated: The meaning of “together with the announcement of the act” is known by the cause together with the fruit.

original: vuttaṃ.“Saha kammavācāyā”ti. Iminā nayena saha parikammenāti etthāpi attho veditabbo.
analyzed: vuttam saha kamma vācāya ati iminā nayena saha parikammena ati ettha api atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: “Together with the announcement of the act”: in this way, the meaning of “together with the directions” should be understood here.

original: Dhātuvisayā sabbāpi paññā dhātukusalatā. Tadekadesā manasikārakusalatāti adhippāyena
analyzed: dhātu visayā sabbā api paññā dhātu kusala tā tad eka desā manasikāra kusala tā ti adhippāyena
translated: All the understanding that has the elements as its object is skill in the elements. Skill in attention is a part of that.

original: purimapadepi sammasanapaṭivedhapaññā vuttā. Yasmā pana nippariyāyato vipassanādipaññā
analyzed: purima pade api sammasana paṭivedha paññā vuttā yasmā pana nippariyāyataḥ vipassana ādi paññā
translated: The intention is this: in the first part, the understanding of discerning and penetrating is stated. But since, in the ultimate sense, the understanding of insight, etc.,

original: eva manasikārakosallaṃ, tasmā “tāsaṃyeva dhātūnaṃ sammasanapaṭivedhapaccavekkhaṇapaññā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: eva manasikāra kosallam tasmā tāsam yeva dhātūnam sammasana paṭivedha paccavekkhaṇa paññā ti vuttam
translated: is skill in attention, it is said: “The understanding of discerning, penetrating, and reviewing those same elements.”

original: Āyatanavisayā sabbāpi paññā āyatanakusalatāti dassento “dvādasannaṃ āyatanānaṃ uggahamanasikārajānanapaññā”ti
analyzed: āyatana visayā sabbā api paññā āyatana kusala tā ti dassento dvādasannam āyatanānam uggaha manasikāra jānana paññā ti
translated: Showing that all the understanding that has the bases as its object is skill in the bases, he says: “The understanding of knowing the attention and the learning sign of the twelve bases.”

original: vatvā puna “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Dvīsupi vā padesu vācuggatāya āyatanapāḷiyā, dhātupāḷiyā
analyzed: vatvā puna api ca atiādi vuttam dvīsu pi vā padesu āyatana pāḷiyā dhātu pāḷiyā
translated: After that, he says “Furthermore,” etc. In both passages, the learning sign of the bases is the text of the bases, and the learning sign of the elements is the text of the elements.

original: ca manasikaraṇaṃ manasikāro. Tathā uggaṇhantī, manasi karontī, tadatthaṃ suṇantī,
analyzed: ca manasikaraṇam manasikāro tathā uggaṇhantī manasi karontī tad attham suṇantī
translated: And attention is the act of attending. So the understanding that learns, attends, listens to the meaning,

original: ganthato ca atthato ca dhārentī, “idaṃ cakkhāyatanaṃ nāma, ayaṃ cakkhudhātu nāmā”tiādinā🔽sabhāvato, gaṇanato ca paricchedaṃ jānantī ca paññā uggahapaññādikā vuttā. Manasikārapade
analyzed: ganthato ca atthato ca dhārentī idam cakkha āyatanam nāma ayam cakkhu dhātu nāma ati ādinā  sabhāvataḥ gaṇanataḥ ca paricchedam jānantī ca paññā uggaha paññā ādikā vuttā manasikāra pade
translated: and knows the delimitation by individual essence and by location thus, “This is called the eye base, this is called the eye element,” is called “understanding of learning” and so on.

original: pana catubbidhāpi paññā uggahoti tato pavatto aniccādimanasikāro “uggahamanasikāro”ti🔽vutto. Tassa jānanaṃ pavattanameva, “yathā pavattaṃ vā uggahaṃ, evameva pavatto uggaho”ti
analyzed: pana catubbidhā api paññā uggahaḥ ti tatas pavatto anicca ādi manasikāro uggaha manasikāro ti  vuttaḥ tassa jānanam pavattanam eva yathā pavattam vā uggaham evam eva pavattaḥ uggaho ti
translated: But in the clause “understanding of attention” the fourfold understanding is called “learning” and the attention given to impermanence, etc., which occurs subsequently is called “attention of learning.”

original: jānanaṃ uggahajānanaṃ. “Manasikāro evaṃ pavattetabbo, evañca pavatto”ti jānanaṃ manasikārajānanaṃ.
analyzed: jānanam uggaha jānanam manasikāraḥ evam pavattetabbaḥ evam ca pavattaḥ iti jānanam manasikāra jānanam
translated: The knowing of that is the mere occurrence of that attention. Or the knowing of learning is the knowing that the attention occurs in the way in which it has been learned. The knowing of attention is the knowing that attention should occur in this way and that it is occurring in this way.

original: Tadubhayampi “manasikārakosalla”nti vuttaṃ. Uggahopi hi manasikārasampayogato manasikāraniruttiṃ
