analyzed: tat ubhayam pi manasikāra kosallanti vuttam uggahaḥ api hi manasikāra sampayogataḥ manasikāra niruttim
translated: Both these are called “skill in attention.” For learning is called “attention” because it is associated with attention.

original: laddhuṃ arahati. Yo ca manasikātabbo, yo ca manasikaraṇūpāyo, sabbo so “manasikāro”ti
analyzed: laddhum arahati yaḥ ca manasikātabbaḥ yaḥ ca manasikaraṇa upāyo sabbo so manasikāro ti
translated: and the way in which it is to be given attention is called “skill in giving attention.”

original: vattuṃ vaṭṭati, tattha kosallaṃ manasikārakusalatāti. Sammasanaṃ paññā, sā maggasampayuttā
analyzed: vattum vaṭṭati tattha kosallam manasikāra kusala tā ati sammasanam paññā sā magga sampayuttā
translated: The understanding that is the act of comprehending is associated with the path.

original: aniccādisammasanakiccaṃ sādheti niccasaññādipajahanato. Manasikāro sammasanasampayutto,🔽so tattheva aniccādimanasikārakiccaṃ maggasampayutto sādhetīti āha “sammasanamanasikārā🔽lokiyalokuttaramissakā”ti. “Iminā paccayenidaṃ hotī”ti evaṃ avijjādīnaṃ saṅkhārādipaccayuppannassa
analyzed: anicca ādi sammasana kiccam sādheti nicca saññā ādi pajahanataḥ manasikāraḥ sammasana sampayutto  saḥ tattha eva anicca ādi manasikāra kiccam magga sampayuttaḥ sādheti iti āha sammasana manasikārā  lokiya lokuttara missakā ti iminā paccayena idam hoti iti evam avijjā ādīnam saṅkhāra ādi paccaya uppannassa
translated: It accomplishes the function of comprehending what is impermanent, etc., by abandoning the perception of permanence, etc.🔽The giving attention is associated with the act of comprehending.🔽It accomplishes the function of giving attention to what is impermanent, etc., in the same place, being associated with the path.🔽That is why it is said that the act of comprehending and the giving attention are mixed in the mundane and supramundane.

original: paccayabhāvajānanaṃ paṭiccasamuppādakusalatā.🔽Adhivāsanaṃ khamanaṃ. Tañhi paresaṃ dukkaṭaṃ duruttañca paṭivirodhākaraṇena attano
analyzed: paccaya bhāva jānanam paṭiccasamuppāda kusala tā  adhivāsanam khamanam tat hi paresam dukkaṭam duruttam ca paṭivirodha akaraṇena attano
translated: Skill in conditionality is the knowing of the state of condition of ignorance, etc., which has as its outcome formations, etc., in the way beginning, “This being, that is; from the arising of this, that arises” .🔽Tolerance is patience.🔽For that is called “tolerance” in the sense of bearing , in the sense of not taking offence, when one does not take offence at the wrong-doing and harshness of others by laying hold of oneself .

original: upari āropetvā vāsanaṃ “adhivāsana”nti vuccati. Acaṇḍikkanti akujjhanaṃ. Domanassavasena
analyzed: upari āropetvā vāsanam adhivāsananti vuccati a caṇḍikkam ti a kujjhanam domanassa vasena
translated: Not being downcast is not being dejected through distress.

original: paresaṃ akkhīsu assūnaṃ anuppādanā anassuropo. Attamanatāti sakamanatā. Cittassa
analyzed: paresam akkhīsu assūnam an uppādanā an assu ropaḥ attamana tā ati sa kamana tā cittassa
translated: Not causing tears to be shed in others’ eyes is non-vexation. Gladness is self-satisfaction.

original: abyāpanno sako manobhāvo attamanatā. Cittanti vā cittappabandhaṃ ekattena gahetvā🔽tassa antarā uppannena pītisahagatamanena sakamanatā. Attamano vā puggalo, tassa
analyzed: a byāpannaḥ sakaḥ manaḥ bhāvaḥ atta mana tā cittanti vā citta ppabandham ekattena gahetvā  tassa antarā uppannena pīti sahagata manena sa kamana tā atta manaḥ vā puggalaḥ tassa
translated: The mental state of non-ill-will is gladness. Or else, taking the continuity of consciousness as a unity,

original: bhāvo attamanatā, sā na sattassāti puggaladiṭṭhinivāraṇatthaṃ “cittassā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvaḥ attamanatā sā na sattassa ti puggala diṭṭhi nivāraṇa attham cittassa ati vuttam
translated: self-satisfaction with the mental state of joy arisen in the interval is gladness. Or else, a person is glad, and the state of that person is gladness. But that is not a living being. To prevent the view of a living being, etc., it is said: “of consciousness.”

original: Adhivāsanalakkhaṇā khanti adhivāsanakhanti. Sucisīlatā soraccaṃ. Sā hi sobhanakammaratatā.🔽Suṭṭhu pāpato oratabhāvo viratatā soraccaṃ. Tenāha “suratabhāvo”ti.
analyzed: adhivāsana lakkhaṇā khanti adhivāsana khanti suci sīla tā soraccam sā hi sobhana kamma rata tā  suṭṭhu pāpataḥ orata bhāvaḥ virata tā soraccam tena āha surata bhāva iti
translated: Patience has the characteristic of acquiescence. Acquiescence is patience. Gentleness is good character. For that is the state of one who delights in good conduct.🔽The state of one who turns away from evil is abstinence. Gentleness is that. Therefore it is said: “The state of one who turns away.”

original: Sakhilo vuccati saṇhavāco, tassa bhāvo sākhalyaṃ, saṇhavācatā. Taṃ pana byatirekamukhena
analyzed: sakhilaḥ vuccati saṇha vācaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ sākhalyam saṇha vāca tā tam pana byatireka mukhena
translated: Friendliness is said to be a soft voice. Its state is amiability, a soft voice. But that is analyzed by way of excess

original: vibhāventī yā pāḷi pavattā, taṃ dassento “tattha katamaṃ sākhalya”ntiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: vibhāventī yā pāḷi pavattā tam dassento tattha katamam tattha
translated: in the text that occurs. Showing that, he said: “Herein, what is amiability?” Therein,

original: aṇḍakāti sadosavaṇe rukkhe niyyāsapiṇḍiyo, ahicchattakādīni vā uṭṭhitāni “aṇḍakānī”ti🔽vadanti. Pheggurukkhassa pana kuthitassa aṇḍāni viya uṭṭhitā cuṇṇapiṇḍiyo, gaṇṭhiyo🔽vā aṇḍakā. Idha pana byāpajjanakakkasādibhāvato aṇḍakapakatibhāvena vācā “aṇḍakā”ti
analyzed: aṇḍakā ati sadosavaṇe rukkhe niyyāsa piṇḍiyaḥ ahicchattaka ādīni vā uṭṭhitāni aṇḍakāni iti  vadanti pheggu rukkhassa pana kuthitassa aṇḍāni viya uṭṭhitā cuṇṇa piṇḍiyaḥ gaṇṭhiyaḥ  vā aṇḍakāḥ idha pana byāpad jana kakkasa ādi bhāvataḥ aṇḍaka pakati bhāvena vācā
translated: “Eggs” are lumps of sap that ooze out from a tree with sap, or they are the lumps that ooze out from the ahicchattaka tree, etc., and are called “eggs.” But the lumps that ooze out from a rotten pheggu tree are called “eggs” because they are like the eggs of a hen, or because they are lumps or knots. But here the word “eggs” is used because of the nature of the eggs of the byābajjhaka bird, etc., or because of the nature of the eggs of the hen.🔽

original: vuttā. Padumanāḷaṃ viya sotaṃ ghaṃsayamānā pavisantī kakkasā daṭṭhabbā. Kodhena nibbattattā🔽tassa parivārabhūtā kodhasāmantā. Pure saṃvaddhanārī porī, sā viya sukumārā mudukā
analyzed: vuttā paduma nāḷam viya sotam ghaṃsayamānā pavisantī kakkasā daṭṭhabbā kodhena nibbatta ttā  tassa parivāra bhūtā kodha sāmantā pure saṃvaddha nārī porī sā viya su kumārā mudukā
translated: “Eggs” : the lumps of clay in a cracked clay pot, or the lumps of clay that have come out of a clay pot that has been dug up, are called “eggs.” But the lumps of clay that have come out of a broken clay pot are like the eggs of the pheggu tree, or they are like the knots in a tree trunk. Here, however, the word “eggs” is used because of the nature of the eggs of the byāpajjana bird, the kakka bird, etc. The kakka bird should be regarded as entering the ear, piercing it like a lotus stalk.🔽Because it is produced by anger, it is “surrounded by anger.”

original: vācā porī viyāti porī. Tatthāti “bhāsitā hotī”ti vuttāya kiriyāyātipi yojanā sambhavati,
analyzed: vācā porī viyāti porī tattha ati bhāsitā hoti iti vuttāya kiriyāya atipi yojanā sambhavati
translated: A woman who has been brought up in the past is a “former woman” . Speech that is as delicate and soft as a former woman is “like a former woman.” Here the construction is possible as follows: “tattha” is connected with the verb “is spoken” ,

original: tattha vācāyāti vā. “Saṇhavācatā”tiādinā taṃ vācaṃ pavattayamānaṃ cetanaṃ dasseti.🔽Sammodakassa puggalassa mudukabhāvo maddavaṃ sammodakamudukabhāvo. Āmisena alabbhamānena,
analyzed: tattha vācāya iti vā saṇha vāca tā ati ādinā tam vācam pavattayamānam cetanam dasseti 🔽sammodakassa puggalassa muduka bhāvaḥ maddavam sammodaka muduka bhāvaḥ āmisena a labbhamānena
translated: or “tattha” is connected with “speech.” “Gentleness of speech” shows the volition that occurs in that speech.

original: tathā dhammena cāti dvīhi chiddo. Āmisassa, dhammassa ca alābhena attano parassa🔽ca antare sambhavantassa hi chiddassa vivarassa bhedassa paṭisantharaṇaṃ pidahanaṃ
analyzed: tathā dhammena ca ati dvīhi chiddaḥ āmisassa dhammassa ca alābhena attano parassa  ca antare sambhavantassa hi chiddassa vivarassa bhedassa paṭisantharaṇam pidahanam
translated: And likewise with the Dhamma: thus there are two kinds of breach. For the breach, the gap, the split that arises between oneself and others🔽through failure to get material things and the Dhamma is called “breach.” The covering, the concealing, the concealing of that,

original: saṅgaṇhanaṃ paṭisanthāro. Taṃ sarūpato, paṭipattito ca pāḷidassanamukhena vibhāvetuṃ
analyzed: saṅgaṇhanam paṭisanthāro tam sarūpataḥ paṭipattitaḥ ca pāḷi dassana mukhena vibhāvetum
translated: is “reconciliation.” To make that clear in its individual essence and as a state,

original: “abhidhammepī”tiādimāha. Aggaṃ aggahetvāti aggaṃ attano aggahetvā. Uddesadānanti🔽pāḷiyā, aṭṭhakathāya ca uddisanaṃ. Pāḷivaṇṇanāti pāḷiyā atthavaṇṇanā. Dhammakathākathananti
analyzed: abhidhamme pi itiādim āha aggam agga hetvā iti aggam attanaḥ agga hetvā uddesa dānam ti  pāḷiyā aṭṭhakathāya ca uddisanam pāḷi vaṇṇanā ati pāḷiyā attha vaṇṇanā dhamma kathā kathanan ti
translated: he said, “In the Abhidhamma too” and so on. Without taking the highest for himself: without taking the highest for himself.🔽Giving a recitation: reciting the texts and the commentaries. Expounding the texts: expounding the meaning of the texts.

original: sarabhaññasarabhaṇanādivasena dhammakathanaṃ.
analyzed: sarabhañña sarabhaṇana ādi vasena dhamma kathanam
translated: Giving a talk on the Dhamma: giving a talk on the Dhamma by means of the “Great Forty” and so on.

original: Karuṇāti karuṇābrahmavihāramāha. Karuṇāpubbabhāgoti tassa pubbabhāgaupacārajjhānaṃ
analyzed: karuṇā iti karuṇā brahmavihāram āha karuṇā pubbabhāgaḥ ti tassa pubbabhāga aupacāra jhānam
translated: Compassion: this is a term for the divine abiding of compassion. The preliminary work for compassion: this is said to be the access of the jhāna that is the preliminary work for it.

original: vadati. Pāḷipade pana yā kāci karuṇā “karuṇā”ti vuttā, karuṇācetovimuttīti pana appanāppattāva.
analyzed: vadati pāḷi pade pana yā kāci karuṇā karuṇā ati vuttā karuṇā cetaḥ vimuttī iti pana appanā appattā ava
translated: But in the line of the text any kind of compassion is called “compassion,” while only that which has reached absorption is called “liberation of the mind through compassion.”

original: Mettāyapi eseva nayo. Suci-saddato bhāve yya-kāraṃ, i-kārassa ca e-kārādesaṃ katvā
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ su ci saddataḥ bhāve yyakāram ikārassa ca ekāra ādesam katvā
translated: The word bhāve is derived from the verb bhāvaya, and the i-vowel is changed to e-vowel.

original: ayaṃ niddesoti āha “soceyyanti sucibhāvo”ti. Hotu tāva sucibhāvo soceyyaṃ, tassa
analyzed: ayam niddeso ti āha soceyyanti suci bhāvo ti hotu tāva suci bhāvo soceyyam tassa
translated: Soceyya is the state of being pure.

Yasmā paṭipakkhe sati tassa vasena sativigatā vippavutthā🔽nāma hoti, tasmā vuttaṃ “sativippavāso”ti. “Assatī”tiādīsu a-kāro paṭipakkhe daṭṭhabbo,🔽na sattapaṭisedhe. Udake lābu viya yena cittaṃ ārammaṇe pilavantā viya tiṭṭhati,

translated: Let that be so. But how is it that loving-kindness is a prior state of that?

original: Yathā vijjāpaṭipakkhā avijjā vijjāya pahātabbato, evaṃ sampajaññapaṭipakkhaṃ asampajaññaṃ, avijjāyeva.
analyzed: yathā vijjā paṭipakkhā avijjā vijjāya pahātabbataḥ evam sampajañña paṭipakkham asampajaññam avijjāya iva
translated: As ignorance is the opposite of clear knowing and is to be abandoned by clear knowing, so lack of clear knowing is the opposite of clear comprehension and is just ignorance.

original: Indriyasaṃvarabhedoti indriyasaṃvaravināso. Appaṭisaṅkhāti apaccavekkhitvā ayoniso ca āhāraparibhoge ādīnavānisaṃse avīmaṃsitvā.
analyzed: indriya saṃvara bhedo ti indriya saṃvara vināso a paṭisaṅkhāti a paccavekkhitvā ayonisaḥ ca āhāra paribhoge ādīnava anisaṃse a vīmaṃsitvā
translated: “Lack of restraint of the faculties” is the opposite of restraint of the faculties. “Without scrutiny” : without reviewing, without examining the danger and the advantage in the use of the requisites.

original: Appaṭisaṅkhāyāti itikattabbatāsu appaccavekkhaṇāya nāmaṃ. Aññāṇaṃ appaṭisaṅkhāta
analyzed: a paṭisaṅkhāya ati itikattabba tāsu ap paccavekkhaṇāya nāmam aññāṇam appaṭisaṅkhāta
translated: “Without scrutiny” is a name for the non-reviewing of the duties to be performed. Ignorance is the lack of scrutiny.

original: nimittaṃ. Akampanañāṇanti tāya anabhibhavanīyaṃ ñāṇaṃ, tattha tattha paccavekkhaṇāñāṇañceva
analyzed: nimittam akampana ñāṇan ti tāya an abhibhavanīyam ñāṇam tattha tattha paccavekkhaṇā ñāṇam ca iva
translated: “The sign” : the object. “Unshakable knowledge” : knowledge that is not overcome by that , knowledge of reviewing here and there,🔽and supramundane knowledge that is the climax of reviewing.

original: paccavekkhaṇāya muddhabhūtaṃ lokuttarañāṇañca. Nippariyāyato maggabhāvanā bhāvanā
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇāya muddha bhūtam lokuttara ñāṇañca nippariyāyataḥ magga bhāvanā bhāvanā
translated: The development of the path in the ultimate sense is called “development” .

original: nāma, yā ca tadatthā, tadubhayañca bhāventasseva icchitabbaṃ, na bhāvitabhāvanassāti
analyzed: nāma yā ca tad atthā tat ubhayam ca bhāventassa iva icchitabbam na bhāvita bhāvanassa ati
translated: And it is only one who is developing that should wish for both of these, not one who has already developed.

original: vuttaṃ “bhāventassa uppannaṃ bala”nti. Tenāha “yā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ āsevanā bhāvanā bahulīkamma”nti.
analyzed: vuttam bhāventassa uppannam balan ti tena āha yā kusalānam dhammānam āsevanā bhāvanā bahulīkamman ti
translated: Therefore it is said: “The strength that has arisen in one who is developing is called ‘repeated practice of profitable things, development, cultivation’” .

original: Kāmaṃ sampayuttadhammesu thirabhāvopi balaṭṭho eva, paṭipakkhehi pana akampanīyatā
analyzed: kāmam sampayutta dhammesu thira bhāvaḥ api balaṭṭhaḥ eva paṭipakkhehi pana akampanīya tā
translated: The meaning of “strength” is also firmness in the associated states. But the meaning of “strength” in the sense of unbending is

original: sātisayaṃ balaṭṭhoti vuttaṃ “assatiyā akampanavasenā”ti. Paccanīkadhammasamanato
analyzed: sa atisayam balaṭṭho ti vuttam assatiyā a kampana vasena āti paccanīka dhamma samanato
translated: said to be “the unbending by forgetfulness.”

original: samatho samādhi. Aniccādinā vividhenākārena dassanato vipassanā paññā. Taṃ ākāraṃ
analyzed: samatho anicca ādinā vividhena ākārena dassanataḥ vipassanā paññā tam ākāram
translated: Tranquillization is concentration. Insight is understanding.🔽Having taken up that mode: having taken up the mode of concentration.

original: gahetvāti samādhānākāraṃ gahetvā. Yenākārena pubbe alīnaṃ anuddhataṃ majjhimaṃ bhāvanāvīthipaṭipannaṃ🔽hutvā cittaṃ samāhitaṃ hoti, taṃ ākāraṃ gahetvā sallakkhetvā. Nimittavasenāti kāraṇavasena.🔽“Eseva nayo”ti iminā paggahova taṃ ākāraṃ gahetvā puna pavattetabbassa paggāhassa
analyzed: gahetvā ti samādhāna ākāram gahetvā yena ākārena pubbe alīnam anuddhatam majjhimam bhāvanā vīthi paṭipannam  hutvā cittam samāhitam hoti tam ākāram gahetvā sallakkhetvā nimitta vasena ati kāraṇa vasena  esā iva nayo ti iminā paggahaḥ uva tam ākāram gahetvā puna pavattetabbassa paggāhassa
translated: By means of which mode the mind, previously made neither sluggish nor restless, is concentrated in the middle way,🔽having taken up that mode, having considered it. By means of the sign: by means of the reason.🔽By this he shows that the sign of the act of adverting is the adverting itself, which is to be done again and again after apprehending that mode.

original: nimittavasena paggāhanimittanti imamatthaṃ atidisati, tassattho samathe vuttanayānusārena
analyzed: nimitta vasena paggāha nimittam ti imam attham atidisati tassa atthaḥ samathe vutta naya anusārena
translated: The meaning of this should be understood in the way already stated under tranquillity.

original: veditabbo. Paggāho vīriyaṃ kosajjapakkhato cittassa patituṃ adatvā paggaṇhanato.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ paggāhaḥ vīriyam kosajja pakkhataḥ cittassa patitum a datvā paggaṇhanato
translated: The act of adverting is energy, because it adverts by not allowing the mind to fall into the slothful side.

original: Avikkhepo ekaggatā vikkhepassa uddhaccassa paṭipakkhabhāvato. Paṭisaṅkhānakiccanibbattibhāvato
analyzed: avikkhepaḥ ekagga tā vikkhepassa uddhaccassa paṭipakkha bhāvataḥ paṭisaṅkhāna kicca nibbatti bhāvataḥ
translated: Non-distraction is unification, because it is the opposite of distraction, which is agitation.

original: lokuttaradhammānaṃ paṭisaṅkhānabalabhāvo, tathā pubbe pavattākārasallakkhaṇavasena
translated: The supramundane states are the power of reflection because they are produced by the function of reflection.

original: samathapaggāhānaṃ upari pavattisabbhāvato samathanimittadukassapi missakatā vuttā.
analyzed: samatha paggāhānam upari pavatti sabbhāvato samatha nimitta dukassa api missaka tā vuttā
translated: And because they are the condition for the arising of the higher states of serenity, the sign of serenity is said to be mixed with the sign of equanimity, which is the reflection on the way in which the states occurred previously.

original: Yathāsamādinnassa sīlassa bhedakaro vītikkamo. Sīlavināsako asaṃvaro. Sammādiṭṭhivināsikāti “atthi dinna”ntiādi nayappavattāya sammādiṭṭhiyā dūsikā.
analyzed: yathā samādinnassa sīlassa bheda karaḥ vītikkamaḥ sīla vināsakaḥ asaṃvaro sammādiṭṭhi vināsikā ati atthi dinna nti ādi naya ppavattāya sammādiṭṭhiyā dūsikā
translated: The transgression that breaks the virtue that has been undertaken, the lack of restraint that destroys virtue, the corruption of right view that destroys right view—that is, the corruption of the right view that occurs in the way beginning, “There is nothing given” .

original: Sīlassa sampādanaṃ nāma sabbabhāgato tassa anūnatāpādananti āha “sampādanato paripūraṇato”ti.
analyzed: sīlassa sampādanam nāma sabba bhāgataḥ tassa anūna tā āpādananti āha sampādanataḥ paripūraṇato ti
translated: The fulfilment of virtue is the non-deficiency of virtue in every way. Thus he said, “By fulfilment, by completion.”

original: Pāripūrattho hi sampadā-saddoti. Mānasikasīlaṃ nāma sīlavisodhanavasena abhijjhādippahānaṃ.
analyzed: pāripūra atthaḥ hi sampadā saddaḥ ti mānasika sīlam nāma sīla visodhana vasena abhijjhā ādi ppahānam
translated: For the word “fulfilment” has the meaning of completion. Mental virtue is the abandoning of covetousness, etc., by way of purifying virtue.

original: Diṭṭhipāripūribhūtaṃ ñāṇanti atthikadiṭṭhiādisammādiṭṭhiyā pāripūribhāvena pavattaṃ ñāṇaṃ.
analyzed: diṭṭhi pāripūri bhūtam ñāṇan ti atthika diṭṭhi ādi sammādiṭṭhiyā pāripūri bhāvena pavattam ñāṇam
translated: Knowledge is that which is the fulfilment of view. Knowledge that occurs by way of the fulfilment of right view, which is the view of the existent, etc.

original: Visuddhiṃ pāpetuṃ samatthanti cittavisuddhiādiuparivisuddhiyā paccayo bhavituṃ samatthaṃ.
analyzed: visuddhim pāpetum samatthanti citta visuddhi ādi upari visuddhiyā paccayaḥ bhavitum samattham
translated: Capable of bringing about purification: capable of being a condition for the purification of the mind, etc., up to the higher purification.

original: Suvisuddhameva hi sīlaṃ tassā padaṭṭhānaṃ hotīti. Visuddhiṃ pāpetuṃ samatthaṃ dassananti
analyzed: su visuddham eva hi sīlam tassā padaṭṭhānam hoti iti visuddhim pāpetum samattham dassanan ti
translated: For virtue that is well purified is the proximate cause for that. Capable of bringing about the seeing of purification:

original: ñāṇadassanavisuddhiṃ, paramatthavisuddhinibbānañca pāpetuṃ upanetuṃ samatthaṃ kammassakatāñāṇādisammādassanaṃ.🔽Tenāha “abhidhamme”tiādi. Ettha ca “idaṃ akusalaṃ kammaṃ no sakaṃ, idaṃ pana kammaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇa dassana visuddhim paramattha visuddhi nibbānañca pāpetum upanetum samattham kammassaka tā ñāṇa ādi sammādassanam  tena āha abhidhamma itiādi ettha ca idam akusalam kammam no sakam idam pana kammam
translated: capable of bringing about, of leading to, the purification by knowledge and vision and to the Nibbāna that is the ultimate purification. The right seeing consisting in the knowledge of the ownership of kamma, etc., is meant here.

original: saka”nti evaṃ byatirekato anvayato ca kammassakatājānanañāṇaṃ kammassakatāñāṇaṃ.🔽Tenāha “ettha cā”tiādi. “Parena katampī”ti idaṃ nidassanavasena vuttaṃ yathā parena
analyzed: sakanti evam byatirekataḥ anvayato ca kammassaka tā jānana ñāṇam kammassaka tā ñāṇam  tena āha ettha ca ati ādi parena katampi iti idam nidassana vasena vuttam yathā parena
translated: Hence he said “in the Abhidhamma” and so on. And here the knowledge that discerns the ownership of kamma thus, “This unwholesome kamma is not one’s own , but this kamma is one’s own” is the knowledge of the ownership of kamma.

original: kataṃ, evaṃ attanā katampi sakakammaṃ nāma na hotīti. Attanā vā ussāhitena parena
analyzed: katam evam attanā katam pi saka kammam nāma na hoti iti attanā vā ussāhitena parena
translated: Hence he said “Herein, too” and so on. “Even though done by another” is said by way of illustration. Just as kamma done by another is not one’s own kamma, so also kamma done by oneself through the instigation of another is not one’s own kamma.

original: kataṃpīti evaṃ vā attho daṭṭhabbo. Yañhi taṃ parassa ussāhanavasena kataṃ, tampi
analyzed: katam pi iti evam vā atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ yat hi tam parassa ussāhana vasena katam tam pi
translated: The meaning may be regarded as “done by oneself” in the sense of “done by one’s own self.” The intention here is this: what is done by one’s own self by way of urging another is also one’s own kamma.

original: sakakammaṃ nāma hotīti ayañhettha adhippāyo. Atthabhañjanatoti diṭṭhadhammikādisabbaatthavināsanato.
analyzed: saka kammam nāma hoti iti ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ attha bhañjanataḥ ti diṭṭhadhammika ādi sabba attha vināsanato
translated: “Because it destroys welfare”: because it destroys all welfare pertaining to this world and the next.

original: Atthajananatoti idhalokatthaparalokatthaparamatthānaṃ uppādanato. Ārabbhakāle “aniccaṃ
analyzed: attha jananato ti idha loka ttha para loka ttha paramatthānam uppādanataḥ ārabbha kāle aniccam
translated: “Because it generates welfare”: because it generates welfare pertaining to this world, welfare pertaining to the next world, and the highest welfare.

original: dukkhaṃ anattā”ti pavattampi vacīsaccañca lakkhaṇāni paṭivijjhantaṃ vipassanāñāṇaṃ
analyzed: dukkham anattā ti pavattam pi vacī saccam ca lakkhaṇāni paṭivijjhantam vipassanā ñāṇam
translated: “It is in conformity with the truth of suffering, etc., because it penetrates the characteristics of impermanence, etc.,” means that even speech and virtue that occur at the time of arousing the thought of enlightenment are in conformity with insight knowledge that penetrates the characteristics of impermanence, etc., because they penetrate the characteristics of impermanence, etc., right there.

original: anulometi tattheva paṭivijjhanato. Paramatthasaccañca nibbānaṃ na vilometi na virodheti
analyzed: anulomā iti tattha eva paṭivijjhanato paramattha saccam ca nibbānam na vilomā iti na virodhā iti
translated: “It is not in conflict with the truth of the highest goal” means that it is not in conflict with or opposed to the highest truth, Nibbāna,

original: ekanteneva sampāpanato.
analyzed: ekantena iva sampāpanataḥ
translated: because it is attained in every way.

original: Ñāṇadassananti ñāṇabhūtaṃ dassanaṃ, tena maggaṃ vadati. Taṃsampayuttameva vīriyanti
analyzed: ñāṇa dassananti ñāṇa bhūtam dassanam tena maggam vadati tad sampayuttam eva vīriyanti
translated: “Knowledge-vision”: the vision that is knowledge. By this he shows the path. “The energy associated with it”:

original: paṭhamamaggasampayuttaṃ vīriyamāha. Sabbāpi maggapaññā diṭṭhivisuddhiyevāti dassetuṃ
analyzed: paṭhama magga sampayuttam vīriyam āha sabbā api magga paññā diṭṭhi visuddhiyā eva āti dassetuṃ
translated: he shows the energy associated with the first path. “All the wisdom of the path is the purification of view”: in order to show this, he says,

original: “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ayameva ca nayo abhidhammapāḷiyā sametīti dassento “abhidhamme panā”ti ādiṃ avoca.🔽Yasmā saṃvego nāma sahottappañāṇaṃ, tasmā saṃvegavatthuṃ bhayato bhāyitabbato dassanavasena
analyzed: apica atiādi vuttam ayam eva ca nayaḥ abhidhamma pāḷiyā sameti iti dassentaḥ abhidhamme pana iti ādim avoca  saṃvegaḥ nāma saha uttappa ñāṇam tasmā saṃvega vatthum bhayataḥ bhāyitabbataḥ dassana vasena
translated: “Besides” : etc. He said “But in the Abhidhamma” , etc., in order to show that this method is in agreement with the Abhidhamma Piṭaka.🔽Since “distress” is knowledge accompanied by fear,

original: pavattañāṇaṃ. Tenāha “jātibhaya”ntiādi. Bhāyanti etasmāti bhayaṃ, jāti eva bhayaṃ
analyzed: pavatta ñāṇam tena āha bhāyanti etasmā ati bhayam eva bhayam
translated: it is knowledge that occurs by seeing the danger in the grounds for distress, by seeing that one should be afraid of them. Hence he said “The danger in birth” , etc. It is a danger because one is afraid of it. Birth itself is a danger.🔽It is a ground for being distressed, for being afraid, for being terrified.

original: jātibhayaṃ. Saṃvejanīyanti saṃvijjitabbaṃ bhāyitabbaṃ uttāsitabbaṃ. Ṭhānanti kāraṇaṃ,
analyzed: jāti bhayam saṃvejanīyanti saṃvijjitabbam bhāyitabbam uttāsitabbam ṭhānam ti kāraṇam
translated: “Ground” means reason, cause.🔽“One who has become distressed” means one in whom distress has arisen.

original: vatthūti attho. Saṃvegajātassāti uppannasaṃvegassa. Upāyapadhānanti upāyena pavattetabbaṃ vīriyaṃ.
analyzed: vatthu uti attho saṃvega jātassa ati uppanna saṃvegassa upāya padhānam ti upāyena pavattetabbam vīriyam
translated: “The endeavour by means of the means” is the energy that should be undertaken by means of the means.🔽“The profitable ideas” are the blameless ideas such as virtue, etc.

original: Kusalānaṃ dhammānanti sīlādīnaṃ anavajjadhammānaṃ. Bhāvanāyāti uppādanena vaḍḍhanena
analyzed: kusalānam dhammānam ti sīla ādīnam anavajja dhammānam bhāvanāya ati uppādanena vaḍḍhanena
translated: “Development” is production and increase.

original: ca. Asantuṭṭhassāti “alaṃ ettāvatā, kathaṃ ettāvatā”ti saṅkocāpattivasena na santuṭṭhassa.
analyzed: ca asantuṭṭhassa ati alam ettāvatā katham ettāvatā iti saṅkoca āpatti vasena na santuṭṭhassa
translated: “One who is not content” is one who is not satisfied with the thought “That is enough. What is the use of more?” in the way beginning “He is not content with the village, the town, the district, the province, or the kingdom” .

original: Bhiyyokamyatāti bhiyyo bhiyyo uppādanicchā. Vosānanti saṅkocaṃ asamatthanti. Tussanaṃ
analyzed: bhiyyokamyatā ati bhiyyas bhiyyas uppāda nicchā vosāna nti saṅkocam asamattha nti tussanam
translated: ‘Greater eagerness’: desire for more and more. ‘Discouragement’: contraction, inability.🔽‘Satisfaction’: contentment. ‘Dissatisfaction’: he has no contentment.

original: tuṭṭhi santuṭṭhi, natthi etassa santuṭṭhīti asantuṭṭhi, tassa bhāvo asantuṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tuṭṭhi santuṭṭhi natthi etassa santuṭṭhi iti asantuṭṭhi tassa bhāvaḥ asantuṭṭhi tā
translated: ‘Lack of satisfaction’: the state of that.

original: Vīriyappavāhe vattamāne antarā eva paṭigamanaṃ nivattanaṃ paṭivānaṃ, taṃ tassa atthīti
analyzed: vīriya pavāhe vattamāne antarā eva paṭigamanam nivattanam paṭivānam tat tassa atthi iti
translated: ‘Turning back’: turning back in the middle while the exertion is going on. He has that, thus he is a ‘turner back’; not a turner back is a ‘non-turner back’;

original: paṭivānī, na paṭivānī appaṭivānī, tassa bhāvo appaṭivānitā. Sakkaccakiriyatāti kusalānaṃ🔽karaṇe sakkaccakiriyatā ādarakiriyatā. Sātaccakiriyatāti satatameva karaṇaṃ. Aṭṭhitakiriyatāti🔽antarā aṭṭhapetvā khaṇḍaṃ akatvā karaṇaṃ. Anolīnavuttitāti na līnappavattitā. Anikkhittachandatāti
analyzed: paṭivānī na paṭivānī appaṭivānī tassa bhāvaḥ appaṭivāni tā kusalānam  karaṇe ādara kiriya tā sātacca kiriya tā ati satatam eva karaṇam aṭṭhita kiriya tā ati  antarā aṭṭhapetvā khaṇḍam a katvā karaṇam anolīna vutti tā ati na līna ppavatti tā a nikkhitta chanda tā ati
translated: ‘Lack of turning back’: the state of that. ‘Zeal for activity’: zeal for doing what is profitable.🔽‘Zeal for continuity’: doing it all the time. ‘Zeal for steadiness’: doing it without interruption in the middle, without making a break.

original: kusalacchandassa anikkhipanaṃ. Anikkhittadhuratāti kusalakaraṇe vīriyadhurassa anikkhipanaṃ.
analyzed: kusala chandassa a nikkhipanam a nikkhitta dhura tā ati kusala karaṇe vīriya dhurassa a nikkhipanam
translated: ‘Non-sluggishness in conduct’: non-sluggishness in occurrence. ‘Non-abandoning of desire’: non-abandoning of desire for what is profitable. ‘Non-abandoning of persistence’: non-abandoning of persistence in doing what is profitable.

original: Āsevanāti ādarena sevanā. Bhāvanāti vaḍḍhanā brūhanā. Bahulīkammanti punappunaṃ karaṇaṃ.🔽Tisso vijjāti pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇaṃ, dibbacakkhuñāṇaṃ āsavakkhayañāṇanti imā tisso🔽vijjā. Paṭipakkhavijjhanaṭṭhena pubbe nivutthakkhandhādīnaṃ viditakaraṇaṭṭhena visiṭṭhā
analyzed: āsevanā ati ādarena sevanā bhāvanā ati vaḍḍhanā brūhanā bahulīkammanti punappunam karaṇam  tissaḥ vijjā ti pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇam dibba cakkhu ñāṇam āsava kkhaya ñāṇan ti imā tissaḥ  vijjā paṭipakkha vijjhana ṭhena pubbe nivuttha kkhandha ādīnam vidita karaṇa ṭṭhena visiṭṭhā
translated: “Cultivation” is repeated practice. “Development” is increase, growth. “Abundance” is doing again and again.🔽“The three kinds of true knowledge”: the knowledge of recollecting past lives, the knowledge of the divine eye, and the knowledge of the destruction of the taints.🔽“Liberation” is the special kind of release that is the opposite of the three kinds of true knowledge.

original: muttīti vimutti. Svāyaṃ viseso paṭipakkhavigamanena, paṭiyogivigamanena ca icchitabboti
analyzed: mutti iti vimutti svāyam viseso paṭipakkha vigamanena paṭiyogi vigamanena ca icchitabbo ti
translated: This distinction should be understood as the removal of the opposite and the removal of the counteragent.

original: tadubhayaṃ dassetuṃ “ettha cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha yena visesena samāpattiyo paccanīkadhammehi🔽suṭṭhu muttā, tato nirāsaṅkatāya ārammaṇe ca abhiratā, taṃ visesaṃ upādāya tā adhikaṃ
analyzed: tat ubhayam dassetum ettha ca atiādi vuttam tattha yena visesena samāpattiyaḥ paccanīka dhammehi  suṭṭhu muttā tatas nirāsaṅka tāya ārammaṇe ca abhiratā tam visesam upādāya tā adhikam
translated: In order to show both of these, it is said: “And here,” etc. Herein, the jhānas are well released from the states that are their opposites, and because of the absence of fear they delight in their object.

original: muccanato, ārammaṇe adhimuccanato ca adhimuttiyo nāmāti vuttaṃ “cittassa ca adhimuttī”ti.
analyzed: muccanataḥ ārammaṇe adhimuccanataḥ ca adhimuttiyaḥ nāma ati vuttam cittassa ca adhimutti iti
translated: Because of this distinction, they are called “adhimukti” (adhimukti = adhimutti) because of their superior release and because of their superior delight in the object.

original: Muttattāti sabbasaṅkhārehi visesena nissaṭattā vimutti.
analyzed: mutta ttā ati sabba saṅkhārehi visesena nissaṭa ttā vimutti
translated: “Liberation” is the special kind of release because of the complete escape from all formations.

original: Khaye ñāṇanti samucchedavasena kilese khepetīti khayo, ariyamaggo, tappariyāpannaṃ
analyzed: khaye samuccheda vasena kilese khepeti iti khayaḥ ariya maggo tad pariyāpannam
translated: Knowledge of destruction: destruction is the noble path, since it destroys defilements by cutting them off.

original: ñāṇaṃ khaye ñāṇaṃ. Paṭisandhivasenāti kilesānaṃ taṃtaṃmaggavajjhānaṃ uppannamagge
analyzed: ñāṇam khaye ñāṇam paṭisandhi vasena ati kilesānam tad tad magga vat jhānam uppanna magge
translated: Knowledge that is included in that is knowledge of destruction.🔽By way of rebirth-linking: in the case of the defilements abandoned by each path, the path arises and then the aggregates are reconnected in the continuum by way of rebirth-linking.

original: khandhasantāne puna sandahanavasena. Anuppādabhūteti taṃtaṃphale. Anuppādapariyosāneti
analyzed: khandha santāne puna sandahana vasena anuppāda bhūtā iti taṃ taṃ phale anuppāda pariyosānā iti
translated: In the state of non-arising: in the state of the fruit of each path.

original: anuppādakaro maggo anuppādo, tassa pariyosāne, kilesānaṃ vā anuppajjanasaṅkhāte pariyosāne, bhaṅgeti atthoti.
analyzed: anuppāda karaḥ maggaḥ anuppādaḥ tassa pariyosāne kilesānam vā anuppajjana saṅkhāte pariyosāne bhaṅge ti atthaḥ ti
translated: In the end of non-arising: the path that brings about non-arising is non-arising. In the end of that, or in the end consisting in the non-arising of defilements, is the meaning of “in the end of non-arising.” “In the state of dissolution” is the meaning of “in the end.”

original: Dukavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: duka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the word “suffering” is finished.

original: Tikavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tika vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the word “three”

original: 305. Dhammato añño kattā natthīti dassetuṃ kattusādhanavasena “lubbhatīti lobho”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Lubbhati tena, lubbhanamattametanti karaṇabhāvasādhanavasenapi attho yujjateva.
analyzed: dhammataḥ aññaḥ kattā natthi iti dassetum kattu sādhana vasena lubbhati iti  vuttam lubbhati tena lubbhana mattam etat ti karaṇa bhāva sādhana vasena api atthaḥ yujjatā iva
translated: In order to show that there is no doer other than the state of being , it is said: “It clings, thus it is greed” by way of establishing the doer.🔽The meaning is also appropriate by way of establishing the instrument: “It clings by that, it is mere clinging.”🔽The same method applies to the words “It torments, thus it is hate” and “It deludes, thus it is delusion.”

original: Dussati muyhatīti etthāpi eseva nayo. Akusalañca taṃ akosallasambhūtaṭṭhena ekantākusalabhāvato
analyzed: dussati muyhati iti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ akusalam ca tam akosalla sambhūta ṭṭhena ekanta akusala bhāvato
translated: It is unwholesome and it is the root of unwholesome states.

original: mūlañca attanā sampayuttadhammānaṃ suppatiṭṭhitabhāvasādhanato, na akusalabhāvasādhanato.🔽Na hi mūlakato akusalānaṃ akusalabhāvo, kusalādīnañca kusalādibhāvo. Tathā sati momūhacittadvaye
analyzed: mūlam ca attanā sampayutta dhammānam su patiṭṭhita bhāva sādhanataḥ na akusala bhāva sādhanataḥ  na hi akusalānam akusala bhāvaḥ kusala ādīnam ca kusala ādi bhāvaḥ tathā sati momūha citta dvaye
translated: And the root is the means of establishing the conascent states in a firm basis, not the means of establishing them in the unprofitable.🔽For the unprofitableness of the unprofitable and the profitableness of the profitable, etc., is not due to the root. If it were, then the two kinds of consciousness accompanied by delusion would not be unprofitable.

original: mohassa akusalabhāvo na siyā. Tesanti lobhādīnaṃ. “Na lubbhatīti alobho”tiādinā paṭipakkhanayena.🔽Duṭṭhu caritānīti paccayato, sampayuttadhammato, pavattiākārato ca na suṭṭhu asammā
analyzed: mohassa akusala bhāvo na siyā tesan ti lobha ādīnam na lubbhati iti alobho ti ādinā paṭipakkha nayena  duṭṭhu caritāni iti paccayataḥ sampayutta dhammato pavatti ākārato ca na suṭṭhu asammā
translated: “Theirs” : of greed, etc. “By the opposite of the unprofitable, etc.,” is by the opposite of the unprofitable, etc., namely, non-greed, etc.🔽“Misconducts” : misconducts that are not well conducted, not rightly conducted,

original: pavattitāni. Virūpānīti bībhacchāni sampati, āyatiñca aniṭṭharūpattā. Kāyenāti kāyadvārena
analyzed: virūpāni iti bībhacchāni sampati āyatiñca kāyena ati kāya dvārena
translated: by way of condition, by way of conascent states, and by way of mode of activity. “Badly conducted” : frightening, because of the appearance of what is undesirable in the present and in the future. “By body” : by means of the body door as the means.

original: karaṇabhūtena. Kāyatoti kāyadvārato. “Suṭṭhu caritānī”tiādīsu vuttavipariyāyena attho
analyzed: karaṇa bhūtena kāyato ti kāya dvārato suṭṭhu caritāni iti ādīsu vutta vipariyāyena attho
translated: “From the body” : from the body door. The meaning should be understood in the opposite sense to that stated in the case of “well conducted.”

original: veditabbo. Yassa sikkhāpadassa vītikkame kāyasamuṭṭhānā āpatti hoti, taṃ kāyadvāre
analyzed: veditabbaḥ yassa sikkhāpadassa vītikkame kāya samuṭṭhānā āpatti hoti tam kāyadvāre
translated: In the case of an offence originating in body that is an offence in connection with which a training precept has been laid down, the body is the means.

original: paññattasikkhāpadaṃ. Avītikkamo kāyasucaritanti vārittasīlassa vasena vadati, cārittasīlassapi
analyzed: paññatta sikkhāpadam a vītikkamo kāya su caritan ti vāritta sīlassa vasena vadati cāritta sīlassa pi
translated: The training precept that is laid down. The transgression of the training precept that is laid down is bodily misconduct. He says this in terms of the virtue of refraining from doing wrong,

original: vā, yassa akaraṇe āpatti hoti. Vacīduccaritasucaritaniddhāraṇampi vuttanayānusārena
analyzed: vā yassa a karaṇe āpatti hoti vacī duccarita su carita niddhāraṇam pi vutta naya anusārena
translated: or in terms of the virtue of doing good.

original: veditabbaṃ. Ubhayattha paññattassāti kāyadvāre, vacīdvāre ca paññattassa. Sikkhāpadassa
analyzed: veditabbam ubhayattha paññattassa ati kāya dvāre vacī dvāre ca paññattassa sikkhāpadassa
translated: The definition of verbal misconduct and verbal good conduct should be understood in the same way as above.

original: vītikkamova manoduccaritaṃ manodvāre paññattassa sikkhāpadassa abhāvato, tayidaṃ
analyzed: vītikkamaḥ uva manaḥ duccaritam manaḥ dvāre paññattassa sikkhāpadassa abhāvato tayidam
translated: The transgression of the training precept that is laid down in both doors is mental misconduct. Because there is no training precept laid down in the mind door.

original: dvāradvaye akiriyasamuṭṭhānāya āpattiyā vasena veditabbaṃ. Avītikkamoti yathāvuttāya
analyzed: dvāra dvaye akiriya samuṭṭhānāya āpattiyāḥ vasena veditabbam avītikkamaḥ ti yathā vuttāya
translated: This should be understood in terms of the offense that originates by way of non-action in the two doors.🔽The non-transgression of the training precept that is laid down is mental good conduct.

original: āpattiyā avītikkamo manosucaritaṃ. “Sabbassāpi sikkhāpadassa avītikkamo manosucarita”nti🔽keci. Tadubhayañhi cārittasīlaṃ uddissapaññattaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ, tassa avītikkamo siyā
analyzed: āpattiyāḥ avītikkamaḥ manaḥ su caritam sabbassa api sikkhāpadassa avītikkamaḥ manaḥ su caritam ti  keci tad ubhayam hi cāritta sīlam uddissa paññattam sikkhāpadam tassa avītikkamaḥ siyā
translated: Some say that the non-transgression of all training precepts is mental good conduct.

original: kāyasucaritaṃ, siyā vacīsucaritanti.
analyzed: kāya su caritam siyā
translated: For both of these are training precepts laid down in terms of the virtue of doing good. The non-transgression of that may be bodily good conduct or it may be verbal good conduct.

original: Pāṇo atipātīyati etāyāti pāṇātipāto, tathāpavattā cetanā, evaṃ adinnādānādayopīti
analyzed: pāṇaḥ atipātīyati tathā apavattā cetanā evam adinna ādāna ādayaḥ api iti
translated: Killing breathing things is “killing breathing things” . So too with the other two kinds of bodily misconduct.🔽The three kinds of verbal misconduct are verbal misconduct consisting in false speech, in malicious speech, and in harsh speech.🔽The three kinds of mental misconduct are mental misconduct consisting in covetousness, in ill will, and in wrong view.

original: āha “pāṇātipātādayo pana tisso cetanā”ti. Vacīdvārepi uppannā kāyaduccaritaṃ dvārantare
analyzed: āha pāṇa atipāta ādayaḥ pana vacī dvāre pi uppannā kāya duccaritam dvāra antare
translated: The three kinds of good conduct are good conduct consisting in abstention from killing breathing things, in abstention from taking what is not given, and in abstention from misconduct in sensual pleasures.

original: uppannassāpi kammassa sanāmāpariccāgato yebhuyyavuttiyā, tabbahulavuttiyā ca. Tenāhu aṭṭhakathācariyā –🔽“Dvāre caranti kammāni, na dvārā dvāracārino;🔽Tasmā dvārehi kammāni, aññamaññaṃ vavatthitā”ti. ;🔽Vacīduccaritaṃ kāyadvārepi vacīdvārepi uppannāti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Cetanāsampayuttadhammāti
analyzed: uppannassa api kammassa yebhuyya vuttiyā tad bahula vuttiyā ca tena āhu aṭṭhakathā cariyāḥ  dvāre caranti kammāni na dvārā dvāra cārino  tasmai dvārehi kammāni aññamaññam vavatthitā ati  vacī duccaritam kāya dvāre pi vacī dvāre pi uppannā ati ānetvā sambandhitabbam cetanā sampayutta dhammā ati
translated: The three kinds of good conduct consisting in abstinence are good conduct consisting in abstinence from false speech, in abstinence from malicious speech, and in abstinence from harsh speech.🔽The three kinds of good conduct consisting in volition are good conduct consisting in volition of abstinence from covetousness, in volition of abstinence from ill will, and in volition of abstinence from wrong view.

original: manokammabhūtāya cetanāya sampayuttadhammā. Kāyavacīkammabhūtāya pana cetanāya sampayuttā🔽abhijjhādayo taṃ taṃ pakkhikā vā honti abbohārikā vāti. Cetanāsampayuttadhammā manosucaritanti
analyzed: manaḥ kamma bhūtāya cetanāya sampayutta dhammā kāya vacī kamma bhūtāya pana cetanāya sampayuttā 🔽abhijjha ādayaḥ tam tam pakkhikāḥ vā honti abbohārikāḥ vā ati cetanā sampayutta dhammā mano su caritan ti
translated: The three kinds of good conduct consisting in volition associated with consciousness are good conduct consisting in volition associated with consciousness of abstinence from covetousness, in volition associated with consciousness of abstinence from ill will, and in volition associated with consciousness of abstinence from wrong view.🔽The three kinds of good conduct consisting in volition associated with consciousness are good conduct consisting in volition associated with consciousness of abstinence from covetousness, in volition associated with consciousness of abstinence from ill will, and in volition associated with consciousness of abstinence from wrong view.🔽The three kinds of good conduct consisting in volition associated with consciousness are good conduct consisting in volition associated with consciousness of abstinence from covetousness, in volition associated with consciousness of abstinence from ill will, and in volition associated with consciousness of abstinence from wrong view.

original: etthāpi eseva nayo. Tividhassa duccaritassa akaraṇavasena pavattā tisso cetanāpi🔽viratiyopi kāyasucaritaṃ kāyikassa vītikkamassa akaraṇavasena pavattanato, kāyena
analyzed: ettha api esā iva nayo tividhassa duccaritassa akaraṇa vasena pavattā cetanā api  viratiyā api kāya su caritam kāyikassa vītikkamassa a karaṇa vasena pavattanato kāyena
translated: Here too the same method applies. The three volitions and the three abstinences that occur as the non-doing of the three kinds of misconduct are

original: pana sikkhāpadānaṃ samādiyane sīlassa kāyasucaritabhāve vattabbameva natthi. Eseva nayo vacīsucarite.
analyzed: pana sikkhāpadānam samādiyane sīlassa kāya su carita bhāve vattabbam eva natthi esa iva nayaḥ vacī su carite
translated: virtues because they occur as the non-doing of bodily transgression. But when the training precepts are undertaken by body, there is no need to say that virtue is bodily good conduct. The same method applies to verbal good conduct.

original: Kāmapaṭisaṃyuttoti ettha dve kāmā vatthukāmo ca kilesakāmo ca. Tattha vatthukāmapakkhe🔽ārammaṇakaraṇavasena kāmehi paṭisaṃyutto vitakko kāmavitakko. Kilesakāmapakkhe pana
analyzed: kāma paṭisaṃyuttaḥ ti ettha dve kāmāḥ vatthu kāmo ca kilesa kāmo ca tattha vatthu kāma pakkhe  ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena kāmehi paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakkaḥ kāma vitakkaḥ kilesa kāma pakkhe pana
translated: “Associated with sense desires”: here there are two kinds of sense desires, sense desires as object and sense desires as defilements. Herein,🔽the thought associated with sense desires as object is sense-desire thought. But in the case of sense desires as defilements,

original: sampayogavasena kāmena paṭisaṃyuttoti yojetabbaṃ. “Byāpādapaṭisaṃyutto”tiādīsu sampayogavaseneva
analyzed: sampayoga vasena kāmena paṭisaṃyuttaḥ ti yojetabbam byāpāda paṭisaṃyuttaḥ ti ādīsu sampayoga vasena iva
translated: the meaning should be construed as “associated with sense desire.” In the case of the phrases “associated with ill will” and so on,

original: attho veditabbo. Byāpādavatthupaṭisaṃyuttopi byāpādapaṭisaṃyuttoti gayhamāne ubhayathāpi
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ byāpāda vatthu paṭisaṃyuttaḥ api byāpāda paṭisaṃyuttaḥ iti gayhamāne ubhayathā api
translated: the meaning should be understood as “associated” in the same way. If it is taken as “associated with ill will as object,” it is so in both cases.

original: yojanā labbhateva. Vihiṃsāpaṭisaṃyuttoti etthāpi eseva nayo. Vihiṃsanti etāya satte,
analyzed: yojanā labbha tā iva vihiṃsā paṭisaṃyutto ti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ vihiṃsanti etāya satte
translated: It is possible to interpret it thus. “ Associated with ill will” : the method is the same here. Beings are harmed by it,

original: vihiṃsanaṃ vā esā sattānanti vihiṃsā, tāya paṭisaṃyutto vihiṃsāpaṭisaṃyuttoti evaṃ
analyzed: vihiṃsanam vai esā sattānanti vihiṃsā tāya paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vihiṃsā paṭisaṃyuttaḥ ti evam
translated: or it is the harming of beings, thus it is ill will. Associated with that is associated with ill will. The meaning of the word should be understood thus.

original: saddattho veditabbo. Appiye amanāpe saṅkhāre ārabbha byāpādavitakkappavatti aṭṭhānāghātavasena
analyzed: sadda atthaḥ veditabbaḥ appiye amanāpe saṅkhāre ārabbha byāpāda vitakka ppavatti aṭṭhāna āghāta vasena
translated: The occurrence of the thought of ill will in regard to formations that are unlovely and disagreeable should be illustrated by way of the eight grounds for resentment.

original: dīpetabbā. Byāpādavitakkassa avadhiṃ dassetuṃ “yāva vināsanā”ti vuttaṃ. Vināsanaṃ🔽pana pāṇātipāto evāti. “Saṅkhāro” hi dukkhāpetabbo nāma natthī”ti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu
analyzed: dīpetabbā byāpāda vitakkassa avadhim dassetum yāva vināsanā iti vuttam vināsanam  pana pāṇātipātaḥ evā ti saṅkhāro hi dukkha apetabbaḥ nāma natthi iti kasmā vuttam nanu
translated: “As far as destruction” is said in order to show the limit of the thought of ill will. But destruction is nothing other than killing.

original: ye “dukkhāpetabbā”ti icchitā sattasaññitā, tepi atthato saṅkhārā evāti? Saccametaṃ,🔽ye pana indriyabaddhā saviññāṇakatāya dukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, tasmā te vihiṃsāvitakkassa
analyzed: ye dukkha apetabbā ati icchitā satta saññitā te pi atthataḥ saṅkhārāḥ eva ati saccam etam  ye pana indriya baddhā sa viññāṇaka tāya dukkham paṭisaṃvedenti tasmā te vihiṃsā vitakkassa
translated: Why is it said, “There are no formations that can be made to suffer”? Are not those called “beings,” which are desired to be made to suffer, in reality formations?🔽That is true,🔽but those that are bound to the faculties and are conscious experience suffering. Therefore those called “beings,” which are desired to be the objects of the thought of ill will,

original: visayā icchitā sattasaññitā. Ye pana na dukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti vuttalakkhaṇāyogato,
analyzed: visayāḥ icchitā satta saññitāḥ ye pana na dukkham paṭisaṃvedenti vutta lakkhaṇa ayogato
translated: are not those that do not experience suffering because they lack the characteristics stated.

original: te sandhāya “vihiṃsāvitakko saṅkhāresu nuppajjatī”ti vuttaṃ. Yattha pana uppajjati,
analyzed: te sandhāya vihiṃsā vitakko saṅkhāresu nu uppajjati iti vuttam yattha pana uppajjati
translated: “The thought of ill will does not arise in regard to formations” is said with reference to them.🔽But where it does arise and how it arises,

original: yathā ca uppajjati, taṃ dassetuṃ “ime sattā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: yathā ca uppajjati tam dassetum ime sattā itiādi vuttam
translated: in order to show that, “These beings” is said.

original: Nekkhammaṃ vuccati lobhato nikkhantattā alobho, nīvaraṇehi nikkhantattāpi paṭhamajjhānaṃ,
analyzed: nekkhammam vuccati lobhataḥ nikkhanta ttā alobhaḥ nīvaraṇehi nikkhanta ttā api paṭhama jhānam
translated: “Renunciation” is non-greed because it has gone out from greed , and it is the first jhāna because it has gone out from the hindrances,

original: sabbākusalehi nikkhantattā sabbo kusalo dhammo, sabbasaṅkhatehi pana nikkhantattā,
analyzed: sabba akusalehi nikkhanta ttā sabbaḥ kusalaḥ dhammaḥ sabba saṅkhatehi pana nikkhanta ttā
translated: and it is any profitable state because it has gone out from all unprofitable states, and it is Nibbāna because it has gone out from all formations,

original: nibbānaṃ. Upanissayato, sampayogato, ārammaṇakaraṇato ca nekkhammena paṭisaṃyuttoti
analyzed: nibbānam upanissayataḥ sampayogataḥ ārammaṇa karaṇataḥ ca nekkhammena paṭisaṃyuttaḥ ti
translated: and it is associated with renunciation because it is related to renunciation by way of root, by way of association, and by making it its object.

original: nekkhammapaṭisaṃyutto. Nekkhammavitakko sammāsaṅkappo. Idāni taṃ bhūmivibhāgena dassetuṃ
analyzed: nekkhamma paṭisaṃyuttaḥ nekkhamma vitakko sammāsaṅkappo idāni tam bhūmi vibhāgena dassetuṃ
translated: Renunciation-associated thought is right thinking. Now, in order to show that by way of the plane of existence,🔽“That” is said, etc. The preliminary stage of foulness: in the preliminary stage of the foulness jhāna.

original: “so”tiādi vuttaṃ. Asubhapubbabhāgeti asubhajjhānassa pubbabhāge. Asubhaggahaṇañcettha
analyzed: so ti ādi vuttam asubha pubbabhāge ti asubha jjhānassa pubbabhāge asubha ggahaṇam ca ittha
translated: The mention of foulness here is made

original: kāmavitakkassa ujuvipaccanīkadassanatthaṃ kataṃ. Kāmavitakkapaṭipakkho hi nekkhammavitakkoti.
analyzed: kāma vitakkassa uju vipaccanīka dassana attham katam kāma vitakka paṭipakkhaḥ hi nekkhamma vitakko ti
translated: in order to show the direct opposite of the thought of sensual desire. For renunciation-associated thought is the opposite of the thought of sensual desire.

original: Evañca katvā uparivitakkadvayassa bhūmiṃ dassentena sapubbabhāgāni mettākaruṇājhānādīni
analyzed: evam ca katvā upari vitakka dvayassa bhūmim dassentena sa pubba bhāgāni mettā karuṇā jhāna ādīni
translated: And in this way, by showing the plane of the two kinds of reflection, he shows the first jhāna of loving-kindness, etc., with their preliminaries.🔽The “foulness meditation” is the first jhāna whose object is foulness.

original: uddhaṭāni. Asubhajjhāneti asubhārammaṇe paṭhamajjhāne. Avayave hi samudāyavohāraṃ
analyzed: uddhaṭāni asubha jjhāne iti asubha ārammaṇe paṭhama jhāne avayave hi samudāya vohāram
translated: For the designation of a collection by the name of a component is a figurative expression,🔽like the expression “The tree is crying” .

original: katvā niddisati yathā “rukkhe sākhā”ti. Jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvāti nidassanamattaṃ. Taṃ
analyzed: katvā niddisati yathā rukkhe sākhā ati jhānam pādakam katvā ati nidassana mattam tam
translated: The words “having made the jhāna his footing” are said figuratively.

original: jhānaṃ sammasitvā uppannamaggaphalakālepi hi so lokuttaroti. Byāpādassa paṭipakkho,
analyzed: jhānam sammasitvā uppanna magga phala kāle pi hi so lokuttaraḥ ti byāpādassa paṭipakkho
translated: For even at the time of the path and the fruit that have arisen by the arousing of the jhāna, it is still supramundane.

original: kiñcipi na byāpādeti etenāti vā abyāpādo, mettā, tāya paṭisaṃyutto abyāpādapaṭisaṃyutto.
analyzed: na etena ati vā abyāpādaḥ mettā tāya paṭisaṃyuttaḥ abyāpāda paṭisaṃyuttaḥ
translated: It is the opposite of ill will, or it is that by which ill will is not committed, thus it is non-ill will , which is loving-kindness. original: Mettājhāneti mettābhāvanāvasena adhigate paṭhamajjhāne. Karuṇājhāneti etthāpi eseva
analyzed: mettā jhāna iti mettā bhāvanā vasena adhigate paṭhama jhāne karuṇā jhāna iti ettha api esā eva
translated: The “jhāna of compassion” is that reached by the development of compassion.

original: nayo. Vihiṃsāya paṭipakkho, na vihiṃsanti vā etāya satteti avihiṃsā, karuṇā.
analyzed: nayaḥ vihiṃsāya paṭipakkhaḥ na vihiṃsanti vai etāya sattā iti avihiṃsā karuṇā
translated: It is the opposite of cruelty, or it is that by which cruelty is not committed, thus it is non-cruelty , which is compassion.

original: Rūpādipañcavatthu kāmavisayā balavarāgabhūtā taṇhā kāmataṇhāti paṭhamanayo, “sabbepi🔽tebhūmakadhammā kāmanīyaṭṭhena kāmā”ti vacanato te ārabbha pavattā diṭṭhivippayuttā
analyzed: rūpa ādi pañca vatthu kāma visayāḥ balava rāga bhūtā taṇhā kāma taṇhā ti sabbe pi  tebhūmaka dhammā kāmanīya ṭṭhena kāmā ati vacanataḥ te ārabbha pavattā diṭṭhi vippayuttā
translated: The craving that is a strong passion for the five strands of sensual desire beginning with visible forms is called sensual craving in the first method.🔽All states belonging to the three planes are sensual desires in the sense of being desirable as sensual desires. original: sabbāpi taṇhā kāmataṇhāti dutiyanayoti ayametesaṃ viseso.🔽Abhidhamme panāti pana-saddo visesatthajotano, tena pañcakāmaguṇikarāgato aññopi

original: kāmanīyaṭṭhena. Pariyādiyitvāti pariggahetvā. Tatoti kāmataṇhāya. Nīharitvāti niddhāretvā.

original: rūparāgo arūparāgoti dasseti. Nirodhataṇhāti bhavanirodhe bhavasamucchede taṇhā.
