original: dibbacakkhuñāṇapaṭilābhatthāya. Dibbacakkhuñāṇañhi rūpagatassa dibbassa, itarassa🔽ca dassanaṭṭhena idha “ñāṇadassana”nti adhippetaṃ. “Ālokasaññaṃ manasi karotī”ti
analyzed: dibba cakkhu ñāṇa paṭilābha tthāya dibba cakkhu ñāṇam hi rūpa gatassa dibbassa itarassa  ca dassana ṭṭhena idha ñāṇa dassanan ti adhippetam āloka saññam manasi karoti iti
translated: For the attainment of the knowledge of the divine eye. For the divine eye is called “knowledge and vision” here in the sense of seeing the visible form of the divine eye and the other.🔽The light mentioned in the words “he directs his mind to the perception of light” is the light that dispels sloth and torpor. The light of preliminary work is the light that occurs in the performance of the preliminary work for the knowledge of the divine eye. Herein, it is said: “The light of preliminary work is mentioned in the words ‘he directs his mind to the perception of light’ in order to show the cause for the arising of the knowledge of the divine eye. For the knowledge of the divine eye arises only through the light of preliminary work, not otherwise. And that light of preliminary work arises only through the jhāna that is its support, not without jhāna. And that jhāna is only the fourth jhāna, not the others. And that fourth jhāna is only of the purity kasiṇa, not of the other kasiṇas. And that fourth jhāna of the purity kasiṇa is only when it possesses the special qualities of being “bright, clear, and radiant,” not when it does not possess them. Therefore, in order to show the cause for the arising of the knowledge of the divine eye, the light of preliminary work is mentioned in the words ‘he directs his mind to the perception of light.’ ”

original: ettha vuttaāloko thinamiddhavinodanaāloko. Parikammaālokoti dibbacakkhuñāṇāya parikammakaraṇavasena🔽pavattitaāloko. Tattha purimassa vasena “khīṇāsavassā”ti visesetvā vuttaṃ. Tassa🔽hi thinamiddhaṃ suppahīnaṃ hoti, na aññesaṃ. Dutiyassa vasena “tasmiṃ vā āgatepī”tiādi
analyzed: ettha vutta āloko thinamiddha vinodana āloko parikamma āloko ti dibba cakkhu ñāṇāya parikamma karaṇa vasena  tattha purimassa vasena khīṇāsavassa ati visesetvā vuttam tassa  hi thinamiddham su pahīnam hoti na aññesam dutiyassa vasena tasmin vā āgate pi itiādi
translated: Herein, the light of preliminary work is the light that occurs in the performance of the preliminary work for the knowledge of the divine eye. The light that dispels sloth and torpor is the light that arises in one who is free from sloth and torpor. The light of jhāna is the light that occurs in the jhāna that is the support for the knowledge of the divine eye. The light of the knowledge of the divine eye is the light that occurs in the knowledge of the divine eye itself.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha tasminti dibbacakkhuñāṇe. Āgatepīti paṭiladdhepi. Anāgatepīti appaṭiladdhepi.🔽Yasmā tathārūpassa pādakajjhānasseva vasena parikammaālokassa sambhavo, yato taṃ🔽parisuddhapariyodātatādiguṇavisesupasaṃhitaṃ, tasmā āha “pādaka…pe… bhāvetīti vutta”nti.
analyzed: vuttam tattha tasmin ti dibba cakkhu ñāṇe āgate api iti paṭiladdhe api anāgate api iti appaṭiladdhe api 🔽yasmā tathārūpassa pādaka jjhānassa iva vasena parikamma ālokassa sambhavaḥ yatas tam 🔽parisuddha pariyodāta tā ādi guṇa visesa upasaṃhitam tasmai āha bhāveti iti vuttam ti
translated: Herein, the light of preliminary work is mentioned in the words “he directs his mind to the perception of light” in order to show the cause for the arising of the knowledge of the divine eye. For the knowledge of the divine eye arises only through the light of preliminary work, not otherwise. And that light of preliminary work arises only through the jhāna that is its support, not without jhāna. And that jhāna is only the fourth jhāna, not the others. And that fourth jhāna

original: Sattaṭṭhānikassāti “abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hotī”tiādinā vuttassa sattaṭṭhānikassa.
analyzed: satta ṭṭhānikassa ati abhikkante paṭikkante sampajāna kārī hoti itiādinā vuttassa satta ṭṭhānikassa
translated: “In the seven ways” : in the seven ways stated thus: “He is one who acts with clear comprehension in going forward and returning” .

original: Satipi sekkhānaṃ pariññātabhāve ekantato pariññātavatthukā nāma arahanto evāti vuttaṃ🔽“khīṇāsavassa vatthu viditaṃ hotī”tiādi. Vatthārammaṇaviditatāyāti vatthuno, ārammaṇassa
analyzed: sati api sekkhānam pariññāta bhāve ekantataḥ pariññāta vatthukāḥ nāma arahantaḥ eva ati vuttam  khīṇāsavassa vatthu viditam hoti itiādi vattha ārammaṇa vidita tāya ati vatthuno ārammaṇassa
translated: Although the training principles are also objects of full understanding for the trainee, only the arahat has objects of full understanding in the absolute sense.🔽Thus it is said: “The arahat’s object is fully understood” .🔽“The object and the object-condition are fully understood” : the object and the object-condition are fully understood.

original: ca yāthāvato viditabhāvena. Yathā hi sappapariyesanaṃ carantena tassa āsaye vidite🔽sopi vidito eva ca hoti mantāgadabalena tassa gahaṇassa sukarattā, evaṃ vedanāya🔽āsayabhūte vatthumhi, ārammaṇe ca vidite ādikammikassapi vedanā viditā eva hoti salakkhaṇato,
analyzed: ca yāthāvataḥ vidita bhāvena yathā hi sappa pariyesanam carantena tassa āsaye vidite  saḥ api viditaḥ eva ca hoti mantā gada balena tassa gahaṇassa evam vedanāya  āsaya bhūte vatthumhi ārammaṇe ca vidite ādikammikassa api vedanā viditā eva hoti salakkhaṇato
translated: Just as when one is searching for a snake and he finds its abode,🔽then the snake itself is also found, because it is easy to catch the snake by the power of knowing its abode, so too,🔽when the object and the object-condition are fully understood, then the feeling is also fully understood in its specific and general characteristics,

original: sāmaññalakkhaṇato ca tassā gahaṇassa sukarattā, pageva pariññātavatthukassa khīṇāsavassa.
analyzed: sāmañña lakkhaṇato ca tassāḥ gahaṇassa sukara ttā pagā iva pariññāta vatthukassa khīṇa āsavassa
translated: because it is easy to apprehend feeling, even for a beginner, since it is the abode and the object of feeling.🔽All the more so for the arahat whose objects are fully understood.

original: Tassa hi uppādakkhaṇepi ṭhitikkhaṇepi bhaṅgakkhaṇepi vedanā viditā pākaṭā honti.
analyzed: tassa hi uppāda khaṇe api ṭhiti khaṇe api bhaṅga khaṇe api vedanā viditā pākaṭā honti
translated: For the arahat, feeling is fully understood and evident at the moment of its arising, at the moment of its presence, and at the moment of its cessation.

original: Tenāha “evaṃ vedanā uppajjantī”tiādi. Nidassanamattañcetaṃ, yadidaṃ pāḷiyaṃ vedanāsaññāvitakkaggahaṇanti
analyzed: tena āha evam vedanāḥ uppajjanti itiādi yat idam pāḷiyam vedanā saññā vitakka ggahaṇam ti
translated: If this is only a mere indication, then the apprehension of feeling, perception and thought in the text is only a mere indication.

original: dassento “na kevala”ntiādimāha, tena avasesato sabbadhammānampi uppādādito viditabhāvaṃ dasseti.🔽Idāni na kevalaṃ khaṇato eva, atha kho paccayatopi aniccāditopi na kevalaṃ khīṇāsavānaṃyeva
analyzed: dassentaḥ na kevala nti ādim āha tena avasesataḥ sabba dhammānam pi uppāda āditaḥ vidita bhāvam dasseti  idāni na kevalam khaṇataḥ eva atha kho paccayataḥ pi anicca āditaḥ pi na kevalam
translated: In order to show this, he said: “Not only,” etc. By this he shows the known state of all dhammas other than feeling, etc., from their arising.

original: vasena, atha kho ekaccānaṃ sekkhānampi vasena vedanādīnaṃ viditabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi
analyzed: vasena atha kho ekaccānam sekkhānam pi vasena vedanā ādīnam vidita bhāvam dassetum apica atiādi
translated: Now, in order to show the known state of feelings, etc., not only from the instant but also from the condition, from the impermanent, etc., not only from the standpoint of those with cankers destroyed, but also from the standpoint of certain disciples in higher training, he said: “Moreover,” etc.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha avijjāsamudayāti avijjāya uppādā, atthibhāvāti attho. Nirodhavirodhī🔽hi uppādo atthibhāvavācakopi hotīti tasmā purimabhavasiddhāya avijjāya sati imasmiṃ
analyzed: vuttam tattha avijjā samudayā ti avijjāya uppādāḥ atthi bhāvā ti atthaḥ nirodha virodhī  hi uppādaḥ atthi bhāva vācakaḥ api hoti iti tasmai purima bhava siddhāya avijjāya sati imasmin
translated: Herein, with the arising of ignorance means with the arising of ignorance, with its existence, is the meaning.🔽For arising is opposed to cessation, and it also expresses existence.🔽Therefore the meaning is: with the existence of ignorance established in a previous becoming, there is the arising of feeling in this becoming.

original: bhave vedanāya uppādo hotīti attho. Avijjādīhi atītakālikādīhi tesaṃ sahakāraṇabhūtāni
analyzed: bhave vedanāya uppādaḥ hoti iti atthaḥ avijjā ādīhi atīta kālika ādīhi tesam saha kāraṇa bhūtāni
translated: With ignorance, etc., which are past, etc., he shows the co-operative conditions for the arising of feeling, etc., in this becoming.

original: uppādādīnipi gahitānevāti veditabbaṃ. Vedanāya pavattipaccayesu phassassa balavabhāvato
analyzed: uppāda ādīni pi gahitān eva ati veditabbam vedanāya pavatti paccayesu phassassa balava bhāvato
translated: and the arising, etc., should be understood as included.🔽Since contact is the most powerful among the conditions for the occurrence of feeling,

original: so eva gahito “phassasamudayā”ti. Tasmiṃ pana gahite pavattipaccayatāsāmaññena vatthārammaṇādīnipi
analyzed: saḥ eva gahitaḥ phassa samudayā ti tasmin pana gahite pavatti paccaya tā sāmaññena vattha ārammaṇa ādīni pi
translated: it alone is stated as “with the arising of contact.” But when that is included, the bases, objects, etc., are included too, by the common characteristic of being conditions for occurrence.

original: gahitāneva hontīti sabbassāpi vedanāya anavasesato paccayato udayadassanaṃ vibhāvitanti
analyzed: gahitāna eva honti iti sabbassa api vedanāya anavasesataḥ paccayataḥ udaya dassanam vibhāvitan ti
translated: Thus it should be seen that the demonstration of the arising of all feeling without exception by way of conditions is accomplished by this.🔽The phrase “the characteristic of arising” refers to the arising by moment.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Nibbattilakkhaṇa”ntiādinā khaṇavasena udayadassanamāha. Uppajjati etasmāti
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam nibbatti lakkhaṇam ti ādinā khaṇa vasena udaya dassanam āha uppajjati etasmā iti
translated: Arising is that from which something arises;

original: uppādo, uppajjanaṃ uppādoti paccayalakkhaṇaṃ, khaṇalakkhaṇañca ubhayaṃ ekajjhaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: uppādaḥ uppajjanam uppādaḥ ti paccaya lakkhaṇam khaṇa lakkhaṇañca ubhayam ekajjham gahetvā
translated: the characteristic of arising is the characteristic of a condition. Taking both the characteristic of a condition and the characteristic of a moment together,

original: āha “evaṃ vedanāya uppādo vidito hotī”ti.
analyzed: āha evam vedanāya uppādaḥ viditaḥ hoti iti
translated: he says, “Thus the arising of feeling is well seen.”

original: Aniccato manasi karototi vedanā nāmāyaṃ anaccantikatāya ādiantavatī udayabbayaparicchinnā
analyzed: aniccataḥ manasi karoti iti vedanā nāma ayam an accantika tāya ādi antavatī udaya bbaya paricchinnā
translated: When he brings to mind as impermanent: feeling is impermanent because it is not lasting, having a beginning and an end, limited by rise and fall,

original: khaṇabhaṅgurā tāvakālikā, tasmā “aniccā”ti aniccato manasi karoto. Tassā khayato,
analyzed: khaṇa bhaṅgurā tāvakālikā tasmai aniccā ati aniccataḥ manasi tassā khayato
translated: momentary, and temporary. Therefore, when he brings to mind as impermanent, seeing it as subject to destruction,

original: vayato ca upaṭṭhānaṃ viditaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti. Dukkhato manasi karototi aniccattā eva
analyzed: vayataḥ ca upaṭṭhānam viditam pākaṭam hoti dukkhataḥ manasi karoto ti anicca ttā eva
translated: And the appearance of the feeling is known and evident to him as it actually is when he brings it to mind as fearful.🔽When he brings it to mind as painful, the appearance of the feeling is known and evident to him as it actually is when he brings it to mind as impermanent,

original: vedanā udayabbayapaṭipīḷitatāya, dukkhamatāya, dukkhavatthutāya ca “dukkhā”ti manasi🔽karoto bhayato bhāyitabbato tassā upaṭṭhānaṃ viditaṃ pākaṭaṃ hotīti. Tathā aniccattā,🔽dukkhattā eva ca vedanā attarahitā asārā nissārā avasavattinī tucchāti vedanaṃ anattato
analyzed: vedanā udaya bbaya paṭipīḍita tāya dukkhama tāya dukkha vatthu tāya ca dukkhā ati manasi  karotaḥ bhayataḥ bhāyitabbataḥ tassāḥ upaṭṭhānam viditam pākaṭam hoti iti tathā anicca ttā  dukkhattā eva ca vedanā atta rahitā asārā nissārā avasavattinī tucchā ati vedanam an attataḥ
translated: because feeling is oppressed by rise and fall, because it is painful by nature, and because it is the basis for pain.🔽When he brings it to mind as not-self, the appearance of the feeling is known and evident to him as it actually is when he brings it to mind as void, empty, ownerless, and insubstantial, because feeling is devoid of anything that can be described as a self, is without any core of substantiality, is not one to be exercised control over, and is void.

original: manasi karoto suññato rittato asāmikato upaṭṭhānaṃ viditaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti. “Khayato”tiādi
analyzed: manasi karotaḥ suññataḥ rittataḥ asāmikataḥ upaṭṭhānam viditam pākaṭam hoti khayato tiādi
translated: The words “as subject to destruction,” etc., are a summing up of the meaning stated by the words “as impermanent,” “as painful,” and “as not-self.”

original: vuttasseva atthassa nigamanaṃ. Tasmā vedanaṃ khayato bhayato suññato jānātīti atthavasena
analyzed: vuttassa iva atthassa nigamanam tasmā vedanam khayataḥ bhayataḥ suññataḥ jānāti iti attha vasena
translated: Therefore the construction should be read as follows: “He knows feeling as subject to destruction, as fearful, as void,” and so on.

original: vibhattipariṇāmo veditabbo. Avijjānirodhā vedanānirodhoti aggamaggena avijjāya anuppādanirodhato
analyzed: vibhatti pariṇāmaḥ veditabbaḥ avijjā nirodhā vedanā nirodhaḥ ti aggamaggena avijjāya anuppāda nirodhato
translated: With the cessation of ignorance there is cessation of feeling: with the non-arising of ignorance through the attainment of the supramundane path,

original: vedanāya anuppādanirodho hoti paccayābhāve abhāvato. Sesaṃ samudayavāre vuttanayānusārena
analyzed: vedanāya anuppāda nirodhaḥ hoti paccaya abhāve abhāvato sesam samudaya vāre vutta naya anusārena
translated: With the cessation of the condition there is the cessation of feeling, because of the absence of a condition. The rest should be understood in the way already stated in the section on the origin of suffering.

original: veditabbaṃ. Idha samādhibhāvanāti sikhāppattā ariyānaṃ vipassanāsamādhibhāvanā. Tassā
analyzed: veditabbam idha samādhi bhāvanā ati sikhā appattā ariyānam vipassanā samādhi bhāvanā tassā
translated: Herein, the development of concentration is the development of the concentration of insight of the noble ones who have reached the culmination of the path.

original: pādakabhūtā jhānasamāpatti veditabbā.
analyzed: pādaka bhūtā jhāna samāpatti veditabbā
translated: The attainment of jhāna, which is the footing for that, should be understood.

original: Vuttanayameva mahāpadāne.🔽308. Pamāṇaṃ aggahetvāti asubhabhāvanā viya padesaṃ aggahetvā. Ekasmimpi satte pamāṇāggahaṇena
analyzed: mahā padāne  pamāṇam aggahetvā ti asubha bhāvanā viya padesam aggahetvā ekasmin pi satte pamāṇa aggahaṇena
translated: It is in the way already stated in the Mahāpadāna Sutta.🔽Without taking measure: without taking a part, as in the case of the development of foulness.🔽In the case of the development of loving- kindness, the measure is not to be taken by apprehending a limited number of beings,

original: anavasesapharaṇena. Natthi etāsaṃ gahetabbaṃ pamāṇanti hi appamāṇā, appamāṇā eva appamaññā.🔽Apassayitabbaṭṭhena apassenāni, idha bhikkhu yāni apassāya tisso sikkhā sikkhituṃ
analyzed: anavasesa pharaṇena na atthi etāsam gahetabbam pamāṇam ti hi appamāṇāḥ appamāṇā eva appamaññā  a passayitabba ṭṭhena a passenāni idha bhikkhu yāni a passāya tisso sikkhā sikkhituṃ
translated: by extending it only to a limited number of beings. For there is no measure to be taken in this, thus it is immeasurable ; the immeasurable is the same as the measureless .🔽They are called “measureless” because they are to be extended ,

original: samattho hoti, tesameva adhivacanaṃ. Tāni panetāni paccayānaṃ saṅkhāya sevitā adhivāsanakkhanti,
analyzed: samatthaḥ hoti tesam eva adhivacanam tāni pana etāni paccayānam saṅkhāya sevitā adhivāsana kkhanti
translated: Herein, the measureless states are a designation for the three trainings that a bhikkhu is able to train in when he has extended the measure of loving- kindness, compassion, gladness and equanimity to their limit.🔽But these are also called “measureless” because they are developed by taking the conditions in brief, because they are borne with, because they are extended, and because they are not to be avoided.

original: vajjanīyavajjanaṃ, vinodetabbavinodanañca. Tenāha “saṅkhāyekaṃ adhivāsetī”tiādi.
analyzed: vajjanīya vajjanam vinodetabba vinodanam ca tena āha saṅkhāya ekam adhivāsa iti itiādi
translated: Hence it is said: “He bears one in brief” , and so on.

original: Tattha sammadeva khāyati upaṭṭhāti paṭibhātīti saṅkhā, ñāṇanti āha “saṅkhāyāti ñāṇenā”ti.
analyzed: tattha sammat eva khāyati upaṭṭhāti paṭibhāti iti saṅkhā ñāṇanti āha saṅkhāya ati ñāṇena ati
translated: Herein, it is reckoned thus, it is manifested thus, it appears thus, it is known thus, is what is said.

original: Saṅkhāya sevitā nāma yaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti,
analyzed: saṅkhāya sevitā nāma yam sevataḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ parihāyanti kusalāḥ dhammāḥ abhivaḍḍhanti
translated: What is reckoned as profitable is what, when it is practised, unprofitableness is abandoned and profitableness increases.

original: tassa sevanāti āha “sevitabbayuttakameva sevatī”ti. Adhivāsanādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: tassa sevanā ti āha sevitabba yuttakam eva sevati iti adhivāsana ādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ
translated: He practises what is reckoned as profitable is what is said. The same method of explanation applies in the case of what is reckoned as to be experienced here and now, and what is reckoned as to be experienced in some future life, and what is reckoned as to be experienced at some specified time, and what is reckoned as to be experienced in the next rebirth, and what is reckoned as to be experienced in some subsequent rebirth.

original: Anto pavisitunti abbhantare attano citte pavattituṃ na deti.
analyzed: antar pavisitum ti abbhantare attanaḥ citte pavattitum na deti
translated: He does not allow to enter within himself is what is said.

original: Ariyavaṃsacatukkavaṇṇanā
translated: The fourfold noble lineage

original: 309. Vaṃsa-saddo “piṭṭhivaṃsaṃ atikkamitvā nisīdatī”tiādīsu dvinnaṃ dvinnaṃ gopānasīnaṃ sandhānaṭṭhāne ṭhapetabbadaṇḍake āgato.
analyzed: vaṃsa saddaḥ piṭṭhi vaṃsam atikkamitvā nisīdati itiādīsu dvinnam dvinnam gopānasīnam sandhānaṭṭhāne ṭhapetabba daṇḍake āgataḥ
translated: The word lineage is found in the passage, “He sits down overcoming the hip-bone” , where it refers to a stick to be placed at the junction of two rafters.

original: “Vaṃso visālova yathā visatto,🔽Puttesu dāresu ca yā apekkhā;🔽Vaṃse kaḷīrova asajjamāno,
analyzed: vaṃsaḥ visālaḥ uva yathā visattaḥ  puttesu dāresu ca yā apekkhā  vaṃse kaḷīraḥ uva a sajjamānaḥ
translated: “As a reed is unattached to its fruit,🔽And as a fig to seeds that it bears,🔽So let a man go forth alone like a rhinoceros,

original: Eko care khaggavisāṇakappo”tiādīsu. ;
analyzed: ekaḥ care khagga visāṇa kappoti ādīsu
translated: Unattached to any earthly thing” .

original: Akaṇḍake. “Bherisaddo mudiṅgasaddo vaṃsasaddo kaṃsatāḷasaddo”tiādīsu tūriyavisese,
analyzed: akaṇḍake bheri saddaḥ mudiṅga saddaḥ vaṃsa saddaḥ kaṃsa tāḷa saddo ti ādīsu tūriya visese
translated: In the passage, “The sound of a drum, the sound of a tabor, the sound of a conch, the sound of a lute” , it refers to a kind of musical instrument.

original: yo “veṇū” tipi vuccati. “Abhinnena piṭṭhivaṃsena mato hatthī”tiādīsu hatthiādīnaṃ🔽piṭṭhivemajjhe padese. “Kulavaṃsaṃ ṭhapessāmī”tiādīsu kulavaṃse. “Vaṃsānurakkhako
analyzed: yaḥ veṇū tipi vuccati abhinnena piṭṭhi vaṃsena mataḥ hatthi iti ādīsu hatthi ādīnam  piṭṭhi vemajjhe padese kula vaṃsam ṭhapessāmi iti ādīsu kula vaṃse vaṃsa anurakkhako
translated: “Veṇu” is what is called a bamboo. In such passages as “The elephant died with a sound of its backbone” , etc., it is a part of the elephant’s body, etc.,

original: paveṇīpālako”tiādīsu guṇānupubbiyaṃ guṇānaṃ pabandhappavattiyaṃ. Idha pana catupaccayasantosabhāvanārāmatāsaṅkhātaguṇānaṃ
analyzed: paveṇī pālaka uti ādīsu guṇa anupubbiyam guṇānam pabandha ppavattiyam idha pana catu paccaya santosa bhāvanā ārāma tā saṅkhāta guṇānam
translated: in the middle of its back. In such passages as “I will establish a family lineage” , it is a family lineage. In such passages as “The protector of the lineage, the guardian of the lineage” , it is a succession of qualities, a continuity of qualities. But here it should be regarded as a continuity of qualities called contentment with the four requisites and delight in development.

original: pabandhe daṭṭhabbo. Tassa pana vaṃsassa kulanvayaṃ, guṇanvayañca nidassanavasena
analyzed: pabandhe daṭṭhabbo tassa pana vaṃsassa kula nvayam guṇa nvayam ca nidassana vasena
translated: In order to show the family lineage and the lineage of qualities of that lineage,

original: dassetuṃ “yathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha khattiyavaṃsoti khattiyakulanvayo. Eseva
analyzed: dassetum yathā hi itiādi vuttam tattha khattiya vaṃso ti khattiya kula anvayaḥ esā eva
translated: “Just as” , etc., is said. Herein, the khattiya lineage is the family lineage of the khattiyas.

original: nayo sesapadesupi. Samaṇavaṃso pana samaṇatanti samaṇapaveṇī. Mūlagandhādīnanti ādi-saddena
analyzed: nayo sesa padesu pi samaṇa vaṃso pana samaṇa tanti samaṇa paveṇī ādi saddena
translated: The same method applies in the case of the other terms. But the recluse lineage is the recluse lineage.🔽By the word “etc.” in “root-juice, etc.” ,

original: yathā sāragandhādīnaṃ saṅgaho, evamettha gorasādīnampi saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Dutiyena
analyzed: yathā sāra gandha ādīnam saṅgahaḥ evam ettha gorasa ādīnam pi saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ dutiyena
translated: the inclusion of the essence-juice, etc., should be regarded, as well as the inclusion of the milk, etc. By the second

original: pana ādi-saddena kāsikavatthasappimaṇḍādīnaṃ. Ariya-saddo amilakkhūsupi manussesu
analyzed: pana ādi saddena kāsikavattha sappimaṇḍa ādīnam ariya saddaḥ manussesu
translated: But the word “etc.” includes Kāsi cloth, ghee, cakes, and so on.🔽The word ariya is used for good people in the world too,🔽as in the passage beginning, “Ānanda, as far as there are ariyan abodes of animals …

original: vattati, yesaṃ pana nivāsanaṭṭhānaṃ “ariyaṃ āyatana”nti vuccati. Yathāha “yāvatā,
analyzed: vattati yesam pana nivāsana ṭṭhānam ariyam āyatanan ti vuccati yathā āha yāvatā
translated: as far as there are ariyan abodes of human beings” .🔽And in the passage beginning, “Ānanda, those who are ariyan, who have purified their bodily action, their verbal action, and their mental action,

original: ānanda, ariyaṃ āyatana”nti lokiyasādhujanesupi “ye hi vo ariyā parisuddhakāyakammantā…pe…
analyzed: ānanda ariyam lokiya sādhu janesu pi ye hi vaḥ ariyā
translated: who have purified their livelihood, and who have right mindfulness and right concentration,🔽I am one of them” .

original: tesaṃ ahaṃ aññataro”tiādīsu. Idha pana ye “ārakā kilesehī”tiādinā laddhanibbacanā
analyzed: tesam aham aññataro ti ādīsu idha pana ye ārakā kilesehi iti ādinā laddha nibbacanā
translated: But here only those who have penetrated the noble truths are intended, since they have received the designation “noble” in the passage beginning, “They are far from the defilements” .

original: paṭividdhaariyasaccā, te eva adhippetāti dassetuṃ “ke pana te ariyā”ti pucchaṃ katvā
analyzed: paṭividdha ariya saccā te eva adhippetā ati dassetum ke pana te ariyā ti puccham katvā
translated: In order to show this, the question “But who are the ariyans?” is asked,

original: “ariyā vuccantī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ariyāḥ vuccanti itiādi vuttam
translated: and the answer is given beginning with the words, “Ariyans are called those who are free from lust for sensual desires.”

original: Tattha ye mahāpaṇidhānakappato paṭṭhāya yāvāyaṃ kappo, etthantare uppannā sammāsambuddhā,
analyzed: tattha ye mahāpaṇidhāna kappataḥ paṭṭhāya yāvā ayam kappo etthantare uppannā sammāsambuddhā
translated: Herein, the fully enlightened Buddhas who have appeared in the world from the time of the great aspiration up to the present world-cycle are shown in their own individual characteristics.

original: te tāva sarūpato dassetvā tadaññepi sammāsambuddhe, paccekabuddhe, buddhasāvake ca
analyzed: te tāva sarūpataḥ dassetvā tad aññe pi sammāsambuddhe paccekabuddhe buddha sāvake ca
translated: The other fully enlightened Buddhas, the paccekabuddhas, and the Buddhas’ disciples are shown in general.

original: saṅgahetvā anavasesato ariye dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha yāva sāsanaṃ na
analyzed: saṅgahetvā anavasesataḥ ariye dassetum api ca atiādi vuttam tattha yāva sāsanam na
translated: and in order to show the Noble Ones without exception, he said: “Moreover, bhikkhus, there are these four noble families. ”🔽Herein, as long as the Dispensation does not disappear, the Master is said to “bear” it, and it is the Blessed One himself who does so.

original: antaradhāyati, tāva satthā dharati eva nāmāti imameva bhagavantaṃ, ye cetarahi buddhasāvakā,
analyzed: antaradhāyati tāva satthā dharati eva nāma ati imam eva bhagavantam ye ca itarahi buddha sāvakā
translated: And it is the present disciples of the Enlightened One that are referred to by the words “at present.”

original: te ca sandhāya paccuppannaggahaṇaṃ. Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ vā kāle te te paccuppannāti ce,🔽atītānāgataggahaṇaṃ na kattabbaṃ siyā. Idāni yathā bhagavā “dhammaṃ vo, bhikkhave,🔽desessāmi ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ
analyzed: te ca sandhāya paccuppanna ggahaṇam tasmin tasmin vā kāle te te paccuppannā ati ce  atīta anāgata gahaṇam na kattabbam siyā idāni yathā bhagavā dhammam vaḥ bhikkhave  desessāmi ādi kalyāṇam majjhe kalyāṇam pariyosāna kalyāṇam sa attham sa byañjanam kevala paripuṇṇam
translated: If it be said that “at present” refers to the present in each of the three periods of time,🔽then the words “in the past” and “in the future” would be superfluous.

original: parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsessāmi, yadidaṃ chachakkānī”ti chakkadesanāya aṭṭhahi
analyzed: parisuddham brahmacariyam pakāsessāmi yat idam cha chakkāni iti chakka desanāya aṭṭhahi
translated: Now, just as the Blessed One extolled the teaching of the six sense bases in eight terms, saying: “Bhikkhus, I will teach you a doctrine that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own intrinsic meaning, with its own intrinsic spirit, a pure way of life, a teaching that is perfectly complete and pure.🔽That is to say, the six sense bases” ,

original: padehi vaṇṇaṃ abhāsi, evaṃ mahāariyavaṃsadesanāya ariyānaṃ vaṃsānaṃ “cattārome, bhikkhave,🔽ariyavaṃsā aggaññā rattaññā vaṃsaññā porāṇā asaṃkiṇṇā asaṃkiṇṇapubbā na saṅkīyanti
analyzed: padehi vaṇṇam abhāsi evam mahā ariya vaṃsa desanāya ariyānam vaṃsānam cattāro me bhikkhave 🔽ariya vaṃsāḥ aggaññāḥ rattaññāḥ vaṃsaññāḥ porāṇāḥ a saṃkiṇṇāḥ a saṃkiṇṇa pubbāḥ na saṅkīyanti
translated: so too he extolled the teaching of the noble families in eight terms, saying: “Bhikkhus, there are these four noble families.🔽These are the four noble families in the world that are rare, hard to find in the world.

original: na saṅkīyissanti appaṭikuṭṭhā samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti yehi navahi padehi vaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: na saṅkīyissanti appaṭikuṭṭhāḥ samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi iti yehi navahi padehi vaṇṇam
translated: and will not be despised by wise recluses and brahmins.”

original: abhāsi, tāni tāva ānetvā thomanāvaseneva vaṇṇento “te kho panete”tiādimāha. Aggāti
analyzed: abhāsi tāni tāva ānetvā thomanā vasena iva vaṇṇentaḥ te kho panetā iti ādim āha aggā ti
translated: The Blessed One first of all brought up the nine terms of praise and then, in the section on the “thrice-purified one,” he said, “They are …,” etc., praising them by the method of the “thrice-purified one.”

original: jānitabbā sabbavaṃsehi seṭṭhabhāvato, seṭṭhabhāvasādhanato ca. Dīgharattaṃ pavattāti
analyzed: jānitabbā sabba vaṃsehi seṭṭha bhāvato seṭṭha bhāva sādhanataḥ ca dīgharattam pavattā ati
translated: The “foremost” should be understood as the best in all clans, and as the means of attaining the best.

original: jānitabbā rattaññūhi, buddhādīhi tehi ca tathā anuṭṭhitattā. Vaṃsāti jānitabbā buddhādīnaṃ
analyzed: jānitabbāḥ rattaññūhi buddha ādīhi tehi ca tathā anuṭṭhita ttā vaṃsā ati jānitabbāḥ buddha ādīnam
translated: “Long-practised” should be understood as long-practised by the long-lived, and as long-practised by the Buddhas, etc., and by those who have practised in that way.🔽“Clan” should be understood as the clan of the noble Buddhas, etc.

original: ariyānaṃ vaṃsāti jānitabbā. Porāṇāti purātanā. Na adhunuppattikāti na adhunātanā.
analyzed: ariyānam jānitabbā porāṇā ati purātanā na adhunuppattikā ati na adhunātanā
translated: “Ancient” means long-standing. “Not newly arisen” means not recent.🔽“Unbroken” means not rejected, not discarded. Hence it is said, “not taken away.”

original: Asaṃkiṇṇāti na khittā na chaḍḍitā. Tenāha “anapanītā”ti. Na apanītapubbāti na chaḍḍitapubbā
analyzed: a saṃkiṇṇā iti na khittā na chaḍḍitā tena āha an apanītā ati na apanīta pubbā ati na chaḍḍita pubbā
translated: “Not previously broken” means not previously discarded.

original: tissannaṃ sikkhānaṃ paripūraṇūpāyabhāvato na paricattapubbā. Tato eva idānipi na
analyzed: tissannam sikkhānam paripūraṇa upāya bhāvataḥ na paricatta pubbā tatas eva idāni pi na
translated: Since it is the means of fulfilling the three trainings, it has not been previously taken away. And since it is the same now,

original: apanīyanti, anāgatepi na apanīyissanti. Ye dhammasabhāvassa vijānaneva viññū samitapāpasamaṇā
analyzed: apanīyanti anāgate pi na apanīyissanti ye dhamma sabhāvassa vijānanā iva viññū samita pāpa samaṇā
translated: it will not be taken away in the future. Those who are wise in the discernment of the nature of things, who are recluses with passions calmed,

original: ceva bāhitapāpabrāhmaṇā ca, tehi appaṭikuṭṭhā appaṭikkhittā. Ye hi na paṭikkositabbā,
analyzed: ca iva bāhitapāpa brāhmaṇā ca tehi appaṭikuṭṭhāḥ appaṭikkhittāḥ ye hi na paṭikkositabbā
translated: and the Brahmins who have expelled evil are not to be despised, not to be rejected.

original: te aninditabbā agarahitabbā. Apariccajitabbatāya appaṭikkhipitabbā hontīti.
analyzed: te a ninditabbāḥ a garahitabbāḥ a pariccajitabba tāya a paṭikkhipitabbāḥ honti iti
translated: They are not to be despised, not to be blamed, not to be rejected because they are not to be rejected.

original: Santuṭṭhoti ettha yathādhippetasantosameva dassento “paccayasantosavasena santuṭṭho”ti
analyzed: santuṭṭhaḥ ti ettha yathā adhippeta santosam eva dassento paccaya santosa vasena santuṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: As to “content with whatever is obtained”: showing just the contentment with what is obtained, it is said, “content in the sense of contentment with requisites.”

original: vuttaṃ. Jhānavipassanādivasenapi idha bhikkhuno santuṭṭhatā hotīti. Itarītarenāti🔽itarena itarena. Itara-saddoyaṃ aniyamavacano, dvikkhattuṃ vuccamāno yaṃkiñci-saddehi🔽samānattho hotīti vuttaṃ “yena kenacī”ti. Svāyaṃ aniyamavācitāya eva yathā thūlādīnaṃ🔽aññataravacano, evaṃ yathāladdhādīnampi aññataravacanoti tattha dutiyapakkhasseva
analyzed: vuttam jhāna vipassanā ādi vasena api idha bhikkhuno santuṭṭha tā hoti iti itarītarena ati  itarena itarena itara saddaḥ ayam aniyama vacanaḥ dvi kkhattum vuccamānaḥ yaṃkiñci saddehi  samāna atthaḥ hoti iti vuttam yena kenaci iti aniyama vācitāya eva yathā thūla ādīnam  evam yathā laddha ādīnam pi aññatara vacanaḥ ti tattha dutiya pakkhassa iva
translated: For a bhikkhu is also content by means of jhāna, insight, and so on. As to “with this or that”:🔽this or that.

original: idha icchitabhāvaṃ dassento “atha kho”tiādimāha. Nanu ca yathāladdhādayopi thūlādayo
analyzed: idhas icchita bhāvam dassentaḥ atha kho ti ādim āha nanu ca yathā laddha ādayaḥ api thūla ādayaḥ

original: eva? Saccametaṃ, tathāpi atthi viseso. Yo hi yathāladdhesu thūlādīsu santoso, so🔽yathālābhasantoso eva, na itaro. Na hi so paccayamattasannissayo icchito, atha kho
analyzed: eva saccam etam tathā api atthi visesaḥ yaḥ hi yathā laddhesu thūla ādīsu santosaḥ so  yathā lābha santosaḥ eva na itaraḥ na hi so paccaya matta sannissayaḥ icchitaḥ atha kho
translated: Is it so? It is so. But there is this difference. For the contentment with what is obtained of the kinds beginning with the coarse robe is

original: attano kāyabalasāruppabhāvasannissayopi. Thūladukādayo ca tayopi cīvare labbhanti.
analyzed: attano kāya bala sāruppa bhāva sannissayo api thūla duka ādayo ca cīvare labbhanti
translated: the contentment with what is obtained, not the other. For it is not held to be dependent on mere conditions, but rather on the dependence of what is suitable to one’s own bodily strength and appearance. And the coarse robe, etc., are found among the three kinds of robes.

original: Majjhimo catupaccayasādhāraṇo, pacchimo pana cīvare, senāsane ca labbhatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽“Ime tayo santose”ti idaṃ sabbasaṅgāhikavasena vuttaṃ. Ye hi parato gilānapaccayaṃ
analyzed: majjhimo catu paccaya sādhāraṇo pacchimo pana cīvare senāsane ca labbhati iti daṭṭhabbam  ime tayo santose ti idam sabba saṅgāhika vasena vuttam ye hi paratas gilāna paccayam
translated: The middle one is common to the four requisites, but the last should be regarded as found in the robe and in the resting place.

original: piṇḍapāte eva pakkhipitvā cīvare vīsati, piṇḍapāte pannarasa, senāsane pannarasāti
analyzed: piṇḍapāte eva pakkhipitvā cīvare vīsati piṇḍapāte pannarasa senāsane pannarasa ati
translated: “These three kinds of contentment”: this is said by way of inclusion. For those who include the requisite of medicine in the alms food and say that there are twenty kinds of contentment with the robe, fifteen with alms food, and fifteen with the resting place,

original: samapaṇṇāsasantosā vuccanti, te sabbepi yathārahaṃ imesu eva tīsu santosesu saṅgahaṃ🔽samosaraṇaṃ gacchantīti.
analyzed: sama paṇṇāsa santosāḥ vuccanti te sabbe pi yathāraham imesu eva tīsu santosesu saṅgaham 🔽samosaraṇam gacchanti iti
translated: making fifty altogether, all these are included in, and fall into, these three kinds of contentment as appropriate.

original: Cīvaraṃ jānitabbanti “idaṃ nāma cīvaraṃ kappiya”nti jātito cīvaraṃ jānitabbaṃ. Cīvarakkhettanti
analyzed: cīvaram jānitabbanti idam nāma cīvaram kappiyanti jātitaḥ cīvaram jānitabbam cīvara khettam ti
translated: “A robe should be known”: a robe should be known as to kind, “This kind of robe is allowable.” “A field for robes”:

original: cīvarassa uppattikkhettaṃ. Paṃsukūlanti paṃsukūlacīvaraṃ, paṃsukūlalakkhaṇappattaṃ
analyzed: cīvarassa uppatti kkhettam paṃsukūlanti paṃsukūla cīvaram paṃsukūla lakkhaṇa ppattam
translated: a field for the arising of robes. “Rag-robes”: rag-robes are robes that have reached the characteristic of rags.

original: cīvaraṃ jānitabbanti attho. Cīvarasantosoti cīvare labbhamāno sabbo santoso jānitabbo.🔽Cīvarapaṭisaṃyuttāni dhutaṅgāni jānitabbāni, yāni tosanto cīvarasantosena sammadeva🔽santuṭṭho hotīti. Khomakappāsikakoseyyakambalasāṇabhaṅgāni khomādīni. Tattha khomaṃ
analyzed: cīvaram jānitabbanti atthaḥ cīvara santoso ti cīvare labbhamānaḥ sabbaḥ santosaḥ jānitabbo  cīvara paṭisaṃyuttāni dhutaṅgāni jānitabbāni yāni tosantaḥ cīvara santosena sammad eva  santuṭṭhaḥ hoti iti khoma kappāsika koseyya kambala sāṇabhaṅgāni khoma ādīni tattha khomam
translated: The meaning is that a robe should be known. “Satisfaction with robes”: all satisfaction with robes that can be obtained should be known.🔽The ascetic practices connected with robes should be known, being satisfied with which one is truly satisfied with satisfaction with robes.

original: nāma khomasuttehi vāyitaṃ khomapaṭacīvaraṃ, tathā sesānipi. Sāṇanti sāṇavākasuttehi
analyzed: nāma khoma suttehi vāyitam khoma paṭa cīvaram tathā sesāni api sāṇanti sāṇavāka suttehi
translated: “Silk, wool, cotton, linen”: silk, etc. Herein, silk is a robe made of silk thread, and so too the rest. Linen is a robe made of flax thread.

original: katacīvaraṃ. Bhaṅganti pana khomasuttādīni sabbāni ekaccāni vomissetvā katacīvaraṃ.
analyzed: kata cīvaram pana khoma sutta ādīni sabbāni ekaccāni vomissetvā kata cīvaram
translated: But “mixed” is a robe made by mixing some silk thread, etc., with all the others.

original: “Bhaṅgampi vākamayamevā”ti keci. Chāti gaṇanaparicchedo. Yadi evaṃ ito aññā vatthajāti
analyzed: bhaṅgam pi vāka mayam evā ti keci chā ati gaṇana paricchedaḥ yadi evam itas aññā vattha jāti
translated: Some say that “mixed” is only made of flax thread. “Six” is the number. If so, then other kinds of cloth

original: natthīti? No natthi, sā pana etesaṃ anulomāti dassetuṃ “dukūlādīnī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: natthi iti no natthi sā pana etesam anulomā ti dassetum dukūla ādīni itiādi vuttam
translated: Is there? No, there is not. But it is a substitute for them. In order to show this, the following words are stated: “linen, etc.”

original: Ādi-saddena paṭṭuṇṇaṃ, somārapaṭṭaṃ, cīnapaṭṭaṃ, iddhijaṃ, devadinnanti etesaṃ saṅgaho.
analyzed: ādi saddena paṭṭuṇṇam somārapaṭṭam cīnapaṭṭam iddhijam devadinnam ti etesam saṅgahaḥ
translated: The word “etc.” includes cotton, silk, wool, and what is produced by psychic power, and what is given by deities.

original: Tattha dukūlaṃ sāṇassa anulomaṃ vākamayattā. Paṭṭuṇṇadese sañjātavatthaṃ paṭṭuṇṇaṃ.
analyzed: tattha dukūlam sāṇassa anulomam paṭṭuṇṇa dese sañjāta vattham paṭṭuṇṇam
translated: Herein, linen is a substitute for hemp because it is made of flax. Cotton is what grows in the cotton shrub.

original: “Paṭṭuṇṇaṃ koseyyaviseso”ti hi amarakose vuttaṃ. Somāradese, cīnadese ca jātavatthāni
analyzed: paṭṭuṇṇam koseyya viseso ti hi amarakose vuttam somāra dese cīna dese ca jāta vatthāni
translated: “Cotton is a kind of silk,” says the Amarakoṣa. Silk is what grows in the silkworm.

original: somāracīnapaṭṭāni. Paṭṭuṇṇādīni tīṇi koseyyassa anulomāni pāṇakehi katasuttamayattā.
analyzed: soma āracīna paṭṭāni paṭṭuṇṇa ādīni tīṇi koseyyassa anulomāni pāṇakehi kata suttama yattā
translated: These three—cotton, etc.—are substitutes for silk because they are made of threads spun by insects.

original: Iddhijaṃ ehibhikkhūnaṃ puññiddhiyā nibbattaṃ cīvaraṃ, taṃ khomādīnaṃ aññataraṃ hotīti
analyzed: iddhi jam ehibhikkhūnam puññiddhiyā nibbattam cīvaram tam khoma ādīnam aññataram hoti iti
translated: What is produced by psychic power is a robe produced by the psychic power of one who has attained psychic power and who has gone forth by the going forth of the bhikkhus. It is one of the kinds beginning with khomā.

original: tesameva anulomañca. Devatāhi dinnaṃ cīvaraṃ devadinnaṃ, taṃ kapparukkhe nibbattaṃ
analyzed: tesam eva anulomam ca devatāhi dinnam cīvaram deva dinnam tat kapparukkhe nibbattam
translated: It is a substitute for those. What is given by deities is a robe given by deities. It is one of the kinds beginning with silk.

original: jāliniyā devakaññāya anuruddhattherassa dinnavatthasadisaṃ, tampi khomādīnaṃyeva
analyzed: jāliniyā deva kaññāya anuruddha ttherassa dinna vattha sadisam tam pi
translated: It is like the cloth produced in the Kappa tree and given by the deity Jālinī, a deva maiden, to the Elder Anuruddha.🔽It is one of the kinds beginning with silk.

original: anulomaṃ hoti tesu aññatarabhāvato. Imānīti antogadhāvadhāraṇavacanaṃ, imāni evāti
analyzed: anulomam hoti tesu aññatara bhāvataḥ imāni iti imāni eva ati
translated: It is in conformity with them in the sense of being one of them. ‘These’ is a demonstrative pronoun referring to what is included. ‘These only’ is a restrictive statement.

original: attho. Buddhādīnaṃ paribhogayogyatāya kappiyacīvarāni.
analyzed: atthaḥ buddha ādīnam paribhoga yogya tāya kappiya cīvarāni
translated: It is in conformity with them in being one of them. The words “these” are a restrictive term; the meaning is “these only.” They are “allowable robes” because they are fit to be used by Buddhas, etc.

original: Idāni avadhāraṇena nivattitāni ekadesena dassetuṃ “kusacīra”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha🔽kusatiṇehi, aññehi vā tādisehi tiṇehi katacīvaraṃ kusacīraṃ. Potakīvākādīhi vākehi
analyzed: idāni avadhāraṇena nivattitāni ekadesena dassetum kusa cīra nti ādi vuttam tattha  kusa tiṇehi aññehi vā tādisehi tiṇehi kata cīvaram kusa cīram potakīvāka ādīhi vākehi
translated: Now, in order to show by way of a part those that are excluded by the restrictive term, “bark of the kusa grass” is said, etc. Herein,

original: katacīvaraṃ vākacīraṃ. Catukkoṇehi, tikoṇehi vā phalakehi katacīvaraṃ phalakacīraṃ.
analyzed: kata cīvaram vāka cīram catukkoṇehi tikoṇehi vā phalakehi kata cīvaram phalaka cīram
translated: a robe made of kusa grass or of other grass of that sort is “bark of the kusa grass.” A robe made of bark of the potakīvāka, etc., is “bark of the potakīvāka, etc.” A robe made of rectangular or triangular wooden tablets is “bark of wooden tablets.”

original: Manussānaṃ kesehi katakambalaṃ kesakambalaṃ. Cāmarīvālaassavālādīhi kataṃ vālakambalaṃ.🔽Makacitantūhi vāyito potthako. Cammanti migacammādi yaṃ kiñci cammaṃ. Ulūkapakkhehi
analyzed: manussānam kesehi kata kambalam kesa kambalam cāmarī vāla assa vāla ādīhi katam vāla kambalam  maka citantūhi vāyito potthako cammanti miga camma ādi yam kiñci cammam ulūka pakkhehi
translated: A blanket made of human hair is “hair blanket.” One made of the hair of the chamari deer, the horse, etc., is “hair blanket of the chamari deer, etc.”

original: ganthetvā katacīvaraṃ ulūkapakkhaṃ. Bhujatacādimayaṃ rukkhadussaṃ, tirīṭakanti attho.
analyzed: ganthetvā kata cīvaram ulūka pakkham bhuja taca ādi mayam rukkha dussam tirīṭakam tirīṭakam
translated: A cloth woven of the fibres of the makappa plant. “Hide” is any kind of hide, such as that of an animal. A robe woven with the feathers of owls is “owl-feather robe.” “Tree-bark” is a cloth made of bhujataca, etc.; the meaning is “cloth of the tiriya tree.”

original: Sukhumatarāhi latāvākehi vāyitaṃ latādussaṃ. Erakavākehi kataṃ erakadussaṃ. Tathā
analyzed: sukhumatarāhi latā vākehi vāyitam latā dussam eraka vākehi katam eraka dussam tathā
translated: A cloth-roof is one made of finer creepers. A reed-roof is one made of reeds. So too

original: kadalidussaṃ. Sukhumehi veḷuvilīvehi kataṃ veḷudussaṃ. Ādi-saddena vakkalādīnaṃ saṅgaho.
analyzed: kadali dussam su khumehi veḷu vilīvehi katam veḷu dussam ādi saddena vakkala ādīnam saṅgahaḥ
translated: a plantain-leaf roof. A bamboo-roof is one made of fine bamboo. The word “etc.” includes a roof of leaves, etc.

original: Akappiyacīvarāni titthiyaddhajabhāvato.
analyzed: a kappiya cīvarāni titthiya ddhaja bhāvato
translated: The robes made of these are called “forbidden robes” because they are the robes of sectarians.

original: Aṭṭhannañca mātikānaṃ vasenāti “sīmāya deti, katikāya detī”tiādinā āgatānaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ
analyzed: vasena ati sīmāya deti katikāya deti iti ādinā āgatānam aṭṭhannam
translated: “According to the eight rules for determining a robe-cloth” means according to the eight rules for determining a robe-cloth given in the passage beginning, “He gives it in the monastery; he gives it on an appointed day” .

original: cīvaruppattimātikānaṃ vasena. Cīvarānaṃ paṭilābhakkhettadassanatthañhi bhagavatā
analyzed: cīvara uppatti mātikānam vasena cīvarānam paṭilābha khetta dassana attham hi bhagavatā
translated: For the purpose of showing the sources for obtaining robe-cloths, the Blessed One set up the following eight rules:

original: “aṭṭhimā, bhikkhave, mātikā”tiādinā mātikā ṭhapitā. Mātikāti hi mātaro cīvaruppattijanikāti.🔽Sosānikanti susāne patitakaṃ. Pāpaṇikanti āpaṇadvāre patitakaṃ. Rathiyanti puññatthikehi
analyzed: aṭṭhimā bhikkhave mātikā ati ādinā mātikā ṭhapitā mātikā ati hi mātaro cīvara uppatti janikā ati  sosānikanti susāne patitakam pāpaṇikanti āpaṇa dvāre patitakam rathiyanti puññatthikehi
translated: “Monks, there are eight rules for determining a robe-cloth.” The word mātikā is derived from the words mātā and ka, and it means “that which gives rise to a robe-cloth.”

original: vātapānantarena rathikāya chaḍḍitacoḷakaṃ. Saṅkārakūṭakanti saṅkāraṭṭhāne chaḍḍitacoḷakaṃ.
analyzed: vātapāna antarena rathikāya chaḍḍita coḷakam saṅkāra kūṭakam ti saṅkāra ṭṭhāne chaḍḍita coḷakam
translated: A charnel-house robe is one that has been discarded in a charnel house. A shop robe is one that has been discarded at the door of a shop. A street robe is one that has been discarded by the side of a street by people who are making merit. A rubbish-heap robe is one that has been discarded on a rubbish heap.

original: Sinānanti nhānacoḷaṃ, yaṃ bhūtavejjehi sīsaṃ nhāpetvā “kāḷakaṇṇīcoḷaka”nti chaḍḍetvā
analyzed: nhāna coḷam yam bhūtavejjehi sīsam nhāpetvā kāḷakaṇṇī coḷakanti chaḍḍetvā
translated: A bathing robe: a robe for bathing, which they throw away after bathing the head with the help of the “black-necked” people.

original: gacchanti. Titthanti titthacoḷakaṃ sinānatitthe chaḍḍitapilotikā. Aggidaḍḍhanti agginā
analyzed: gacchanti titthanti tittha coḷakam sināna titthe chaḍḍita pilotikāḥ aggi daḍḍhanti agginā
translated: A riverbank robe: a piece of cloth thrown away on a bathing place bank. A robe burnt by fire:

original: daḍḍhappadesaṃ. Tañhi manussā chaḍḍenti. Gokhāyitakādīni pākaṭāneva. Tānipi hi manussā chaḍḍenti.🔽Dhajaṃ ussāpetvāti nāvaṃ ārohantehi vā yuddhaṃ pavisantehi vā dhajayaṭṭhiṃ ussāpetvā tattha baddhaṃ pārutacīvaraṃ, tehi chaḍḍitanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: daḍḍha ppadesam tam hi manussā chaḍḍenti gokhāyitaka ādīni pākaṭāni eva tāni api hi manussā chaḍḍenti  dhajam ussāpetvā ti nāvam ārohantehi vā yuddham pavisantehi vā dhaja yaṭṭhim ussāpetvā tattha baddham pāruta cīvaram tehi chaḍḍitam ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: a piece of cloth burnt by fire which people throw away. A robe gnawed by cattle, etc., are obvious. People throw these away too.🔽Having hoisted a flag: the intention is that a robe is thrown away when people go on board a ship or go into battle after hoisting a flagstaff there and tying a cloth to it.

original: Sādakabhikkhunāti gahapaticīvarassa sādiyanabhikkhunā. Ekamāsamattanti cīvaramāsasaññitaṃ
analyzed: sādaka bhikkhunā ti gahapati cīvarassa sādiyana bhikkhunā eka māsa mattam ti cīvara māsa saññitam
translated: A robe that is accepted: a robe that is accepted by a monk who accepts lay people’s robes. For a month: for a month consisting of robe-material.

original: ekamāsamattaṃ. Vitakketuṃ vaṭṭati, na tato paranti adhippāyo. Sabbassāpi hi taṇhāniggahatthāya
analyzed: eka māsa mattam vitakketum vaṭṭati na tato paranti adhippāyaḥ sabbassa api hi taṇhā niggaha tthāya
translated: It is allowable to think of it for a month, not longer than that. For the intention is that all practice in the Dispensation is for the purpose of eliminating craving.

original: sāsane paṭipattīti. Paṃsukūliko addhamāseneva karotīti aparapaṭibaddhattā paṭilābhassa.
analyzed: sāsane paṭipatti iti paṃsukūlikaḥ addha māsena iva karoti iti apara paṭibaddha ttā paṭilābhassa
translated: A refuse-rag wearer makes it in half a month: because of the dependence on others for the acquisition of robes.

original: Itarassa pana parapaṭibaddhattā māsamattaṃ anuññātaṃ. Iti māsaddha…pe… vitakkasantoso
analyzed: itarassa pana para paṭibaddha ttā māsa mattam anuññātam iti māsa ddha pe vitakka santoso
translated: So the satisfaction of the bhikkhu with a limited time is

original: vitakkanassa parimitakālikattā.🔽Mahātheraṃ tattha attano sahāyaṃ icchantopi garugāravena gāmadvāraṃ “bhante gamissāmi”
analyzed: vitakkanassa parimita kālika ttā  mahā theram tattha sahāyam icchantaḥ api garu gāravena gāma dvāram bhante gamissāmi
translated: the satisfaction of his thought.🔽Even though he wanted a companion for himself, he said, “Venerable sir, I shall go,” out of respect for the elder.

original: iccevamāha. Mahātheropissa ajjhāsayaṃ ñatvā “ahaṃ pāvuso gamissāmī”ti āha. “Imassa
analyzed: icca ivam āha mahā theraḥ upissa ajjhāsayam ñatvā aham pāvuso gamissāmi iti āha imassa
translated: The elder, knowing his intention, said, “I shall go, friend.”

original: bhikkhuno vitakkassa avasaro mā hotū”ti pañhaṃ pucchamāno gāmaṃ pāvisi. Uccārapalibuddhoti
analyzed: bhikkhuno vitakkassa avasaraḥ mā hotu uti pañham pucchamānaḥ gāmam pāvisi uccāra palibuddhaḥ ti
translated: He entered the village asking a question, thinking: “Let there be no opportunity for this bhikkhu’s thought.”🔽Oppressed by a bowel complaint:🔽afflicted by a bowel complaint.

original: uccārena pīḷito. Tadā bhagavato dukkarakiriyānussaraṇamukhena tathāgate uppannapītisomanassavegassa
analyzed: uccārena pīḍitaḥ tadā bhagavataḥ dukkara kiriyā anussaraṇa mukhena tathāgate uppanna pīti so manassa vegassa
translated: At that time, the Blessed One, by the force of the strong faith and joy that had arisen in him through recollecting the Blessed One’s performance of austerities,

original: balavabhāvena kilesānaṃ vikkhambhitattā tasmiṃyeva…pe… tīṇi phalāni patto.
analyzed: balava bhāvena kilesānam vikkhambhita ttā tasmin yevape tīṇi phalāni
translated: had suppressed the defilements in that same place, and he reached the three fruitions.

original: “Kattha labhissāmī”ti cintanāpi lābhāsāpubbikāti tathā “acintetvā”ti vuttaṃ, “sundaraṃ
analyzed: kattha labhissāmi iti cintanā api lābha a sāpubbikā ti tathā a cintetvā iti vuttam sundaram
translated: The thought “Where shall I get it?” is called “the desire for gain.” Therefore it is said: “Without thinking.”

original: labhissāmi, manāpaṃ labhissāmī”ti evamādicintanāya kā nāma kathā. Kathaṃ pana vattabbanti
analyzed: labhissāmi manāpam labhissāmi iti evamādi cintanāya kā nāma kathā katham pana vattabbam ti
translated: But how should it be done?

original: āha “kammaṭṭhānasīseneva gamana”nti, tena cīvaraṃ paṭicca kiñcipi na cintetabbaṃ evāti dasseti.
analyzed: āha kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva gamanan ti tena cīvaram paṭicca kiñcipi na cintetabbam eva ati dasseti
translated: He said: “One should go with meditation as one’s sole concern.” He shows that one should not think about anything else, even about a robe.

original: Apesalo appatirūpāyapi pariyesanāya paccayo bhaveyyāti “pesalaṃ bhikkhuṃ gahetvā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: apesalaḥ appatirūpāya api pariyesanāya paccayaḥ bhaveyya ati pesalam bhikkhum gahetvā iti vuttam
translated: A pesala bhikkhu is one who would be a condition for the search even by an unseemly and improper search.

original: Āhariyamānanti susānādīsu patitakaṃ vatthaṃ “ime bhikkhū paṃsukūlapariyesanaṃ carantī”ti ñatvā kenaci purisena tato ānīyamānaṃ.
analyzed: āhariyamānam ti susāna ādīsu patitakam vattham ime bhikkhū paṃsukūla pariyesanam caranti iti ñatvā kenacid purisena tatas ānīyamānam
translated: Brought: cloth that has been discarded in a charnel ground, etc., and brought from there by some man who knows that “These bhikkhus are wandering about seeking refuse rags.”

original: Evaṃ laddhaṃ gaṇhantassāpīti evaṃ paṭilābhasantosaṃ akopetvāva laddhaṃ gaṇhantassāpi.
analyzed: evam laddham gaṇhantassa api iti evam paṭilābha santosam a kopetvā ava laddham gaṇhantassa api
translated: One who accepts what is found: one who accepts what is found without disturbing the contentment that is proper to one who has attained.

original: Attano pahonakamattenevāti yathāladdhānaṃ paṃsukūlavatthānaṃ ekapaṭṭadupaṭṭānaṃ atthāya🔽attano pahonakapamāṇeneva, avadhāraṇena uparipaccāsaṃ nivatteti.
analyzed: attano pahonakam attena iva ati yathā laddhānam paṃsu kūla vatthānam eka paṭṭad upaṭṭānam atthāya 🔽attanaḥ pahonaka pamāṇena iva avadhāraṇena upari paccāsam nivatteti
translated: With just what is sufficient for one’s own use: for the purpose of a single cloak or double cloak made of refuse rags obtained in whatever way.

original: Gāme bhikkhāya āhiṇḍantena sapadānacārinā viya dvārapaṭipāṭiyā caraṇaṃ loluppavivajjanaṃ nāma cīvaraloluppassa dūrasamussāritattā.🔽Yāpetunti attabhāvaṃ pavattetuṃ.
analyzed: gāme bhikkhāya āhiṇḍantena sa padāna cārinā viya dvāra paṭipāṭiyā caraṇam loluppavivajjanam nāma cīvara loluppassa dūra samussārita ttā  atta bhāvam pavattetum
translated: Begging for alms in a village, he should go from house to house in proper order, like one who is looking for a lost cow. This is called “avoiding greed.” Because he has shaken off greed for fine food,🔽“To maintain” : to keep going.

original: Dhovanupagenāti dhovanayoggena.🔽Paṇṇānīti ambajambādipaṇṇāni.
analyzed: dhovan upagena ati dhovana yoggena  paṇṇāni iti amba jamba ādi paṇṇāni
translated: “With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.🔽“Without causing annoyance” : without causing dissatisfaction. “With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.🔽“With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.🔽“With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.

original: Akopetvāti santosaṃ akopetvā. Pahonakanīhārenevāti antaravāsakādīsu yaṃ kātukāmo, tassa pahonakaniyāmeneva yathāladdhaṃ thūlasukhumādiṃ gahetvā karaṇaṃ.🔽Timaṇḍalapaṭicchādanamattassevāti “nivāsanaṃ ce nābhimaṇḍalaṃ; jāṇumaṇḍalaṃ, itaraṃ
analyzed: a kopetvā iti santosam a kopetvā pahonaka nīhārena iva ati antaravāsaka ādīsu yam kātu kāmo tassa pahonaka niyāmena iva yathā laddham thūla su khuma ādim gahetvā karaṇam  nivāsanam ce nābhi maṇḍalam jāṇu maṇḍalam itaram
translated: “With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.🔽“With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.🔽“With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.🔽“With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.

original: ce galavāṭamaṇḍalaṃ, jāṇumaṇḍala”nti evaṃ timaṇḍalapaṭicchādanamattasseva karaṇaṃ;🔽taṃ pana atthato tiṇṇaṃ cīvarānaṃ heṭṭhimantena vuttaparimāṇameva hoti.
analyzed: ce galavāṭa maṇḍalam evam ti maṇḍala paṭicchādana mattassa iva karaṇam  tam pana atthataḥ tiṇṇam cīvarānam heṭṭhimantena vutta parimāṇam eva hoti
translated: “With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.🔽“With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.🔽“With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.🔽“With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.🔽“With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.🔽“With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.

original: Avicāretvāti na vicāretvā.
analyzed: a vicāretvā ati na vicāretvā
translated: “With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made a store.🔽“With what is obtained by mere wandering for alms” : with what is obtained by mere wandering for alms without having made

original: Kusibandhanakāleti maṇḍalāni yojetvā sibbanakāle. Sattavāreti sattasibbanavāre.
analyzed: kusibandhana kāle iti maṇḍalāni yojetvā sibbana kāle satta vāre iti satta sibbana vāre
translated: “At the time of weaving” means at the time of weaving after the threads have been made into a warp and a woof. “For seven years” means for seven weaving-periods.

original: Kappabinduapadesena kassaci vikārassa akaraṇaṃ kappasantoso.
analyzed: kappa bindu apadesena kassaci vikārassa akaraṇam kappa santoso
translated: “Satisfaction with what is obtained” means not making any alteration in what is obtained, by the method of the Kappabindu.🔽“The purpose of using the robe is established by the avoidance of harm from cold, etc.”

original: Sītapaṭighātādi atthāpattito sijjhatīti mukhyameva cīvaraparibhoge payojanaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: sīta paṭighāta ādi atthāpattitaḥ sijjhati iti mukhyam eva cīvara paribhoge payojanam dassetum
translated: In order to show that the primary purpose of using the robe is🔽“merely to cover the parts of the body that should be kept covered and to remove embarrassment,”

original: “hirikopīnapaṭicchādanamattavasenā”ti vuttaṃ. Tenāha bhagavā “yāvadeva hirikopīnapaṭicchādanattha”nti.
analyzed: hiri kopīna paṭicchādana matta vasena ati vuttam tena āha bhagavā yāvat eva hiri kopīna paṭicchādana atthan ti
translated: the Blessed One said, “For the purpose of merely covering the parts of the body that should be kept covered and to remove embarrassment.”

original: Vaṭṭati, na tāvatā santoso kuppati sambhārānaṃ, dakkhiṇeyyānañca alābhato.
analyzed: vaṭṭati na tāvatā santosaḥ kuppati sambhārānam dakkhiṇeyyānam ca alābhato
translated: “Satisfaction” means that one is not dissatisfied with what is obtained, because one has not obtained requisites or worthy recipients.

original: Sāraṇīyadhamme ṭhatvāti sīlavantehi bhikkhūhi sādhāraṇato paribhoge ṭhatvā.
analyzed: sāraṇīya dhamme ṭhatvā ati sīlavantehi bhikkhūhi sādhāraṇataḥ paribhoge ṭhatvā
translated: “Having established oneself in the practice of endearing speech” means having established oneself in the practice of sharing with virtuous bhikkhus.

original: “Itī”tiādinā paṭhamassa ariyavaṃsassa paṃsukūlikaṅgatecīvarikaṅgānaṃ, tesañca tassa🔽paccayataṃ dassento iti ime dhammā aññamaññassa samuṭṭhāpakā, upatthambhakā cāti
analyzed: iti iti ādinā paṭhamassa ariya vaṃsassa paṃsukūlikaṅga tecīvarikaṅgānam tesam ca tassa  paccaya tam dassento iti ime dhammā aññamaññassa samuṭṭhāpakā upatthambhakā ca ati
translated: “Thus” and so forth. By this he shows that the ascetic practices of the refuse-rag-wearer and the triple-robe-wearer are the originators and supporters of the first noble heritage, and that the latter

original: dīpeti. Esa nayo ito paratopi.
analyzed: dīpa iti e sa nayoḥ i taḥ paratas pi
translated: is the originator and supporter of the former.🔽This is the method of explanation in the case of the other noble heritages as well.

original: “Santuṭṭho hoti vaṇṇavādī”ti ettha catukkoṭikaṃ sambhavati, tattha catutthoyeva pakkho🔽satthārā vaṇṇito thomitoti mahātherena tathā desanā katā. Eko santuṭṭho hoti, santosassa
analyzed: santuṭṭhaḥ hoti vaṇṇa vādī iti ettha catukkoṭikam sambhavati tattha catutthaḥ eva pakkho  satthārā vaṇṇito thomitaḥ iti mahā therena tathā desanā katā ekaḥ santuṭṭhaḥ hoti santosassa
translated: “He is content and speaks in praise of contentment” : here a fourfold permutation arises. Therein, the fourth permutation alone

original: vaṇṇaṃ na katheti seyyathāpi thero nālako (suttanipāte nālakasutte vitthāro) eko🔽na santuṭṭho hoti, santosassa vaṇṇavādī seyyathāpi upanando sakyaputto. Eko neva🔽santuṭṭho hoti, na santosassa vaṇṇaṃ katheti. Seyyathāpi thero lāḷudāyī eko santuṭṭho🔽ceva hoti, santosassa ca vaṇṇavādī seyyathāpi thero mahākassapo.
analyzed: vaṇṇam na katheti seyyathā api theraḥ nālakaḥ suttanipāte nālaka sutte vitthāraḥ ekaḥ  na santuṭṭhaḥ hoti santosassa vaṇṇa vādī seyyathā api upanandaḥ sakyaputto ekaḥ na iva  santuṭṭhaḥ hoti na santosassa vaṇṇam katheti seyyathā api theraḥ lāḷudāyī ekaḥ santuṭṭhaḥ  ca iva hoti santosassa ca vaṇṇa vādī seyyathā api theraḥ mahākassapo
translated: is praised and extolled by the Teacher. One is content but does not speak in praise of contentment. For example, the Elder Nālaka (see Suttanipāta, Nālakasutta, for details). One is not content but speaks in praise of contentment. For example, the monk Upananda, the son of the Sakyans. One is neither content nor does he speak in praise of contentment. For example, the Elder Lāḷudāyī. One is content and speaks in praise of contentment. For example, the Elder Mahākassapa.

original: Anesananti ayuttaṃ esanaṃ. Tenāha “appatirūpa”nti, sāsane ṭhitānaṃ na patirūpaṃ asāruppaṃ
analyzed: anesanam ti ayuttam esanam tena āha appatirūpam ti sāsane ṭhitānam na patirūpam asāruppam
translated: “Improper search” : improper search is unsuitable. Therefore it is said, “unbecoming” , not becoming, not proper for those who have entered the Dispensation.

original: ayogyaṃ. Kohaññaṃ karontoti cīvaruppādanimittaṃ paresaṃ kuhanaṃ vimhāpanaṃ karonto.
analyzed: ayogyam kohaññam karonto ti cīvara uppāda nimittam paresam kuhanam vimhāpanam karonto

original: Uttasatīti taṇhāsantāsena uparūpari tasati. Paritasatīti parito tasati. Yathā sabbe🔽kāyavacīpayogā tadatthā eva jāyanti, evaṃ sabbabhāgehi tasati. Gadhitaṃ vuccati gaddho,🔽so cettha abhijjhālakkhaṇo adhippeto. Gadhitaṃ etassa natthīti agadhitoti āha “agadhito…pe…🔽lobhagiddho”ti. Mucchanti taṇhāvasena muyhanaṃ, tassa vā samussayaṃ adhigataṃ. Anāpanno
analyzed: uttasati iti taṇhā santāsena upari upari tasati paritasati iti paritas tasati yathā sabbe  tad atthāḥ eva jāyanti evam sabba bhāgehi tasati gadhitam vuccati gaddhaḥ  saḥ ca ittha abhijjhā lakkhaṇaḥ adhippetaḥ gadhitam etassa na atthi iti agadhitaḥ iti āha agadhita upe  lobha giddhaḥ ti mucchanti taṇhā vasena muyhanam tassa vā samussayam adhigatam an āpannaḥ
translated: Utta-sati means it is scattered upwards by the scattering of craving. Parita-sati means it is scattered around. Just as all bodily and verbal activities are born for that purpose, so it is scattered in all parts. Gadhita is said to be gaddha.🔽That is the characteristic of greed, which is intended here. It is said that it does not have that, so it is agadhita. He said: “Agadhita…pe…🔽lobhagiddho.” They are released by way of craving, or the state of delusion has been attained. Not fallen into🔽🔽

original: anupagato. Anotthatoti anajjhotthato. Apariyonaddhoti taṇhāchadanena acchādito. Ādīnavaṃ🔽passamānoti diṭṭhadhammikaṃ, samparāyikañca dosaṃ passanto. Gadhitaparibhogato nissarati🔽etenāti nissaraṇaṃ, idamatthikatā, taṃ pajānātīti nissaraṇapañño. Tenāha “yāvadeva…pe… pajānanto”ti.
analyzed: an upagataḥ an otthato ti an ajjhotthataḥ a pariyonaddhaḥ ti taṇhā chadanena a chāditaḥ ādīnavam 🔽passamānaḥ ti diṭṭhadhammikam samparāyikam ca dosam passantaḥ gadhita paribhogataḥ nissarati 🔽etena ati nissaraṇam idam atthika tā tam pajānāti iti nissaraṇa pañño tena āha yāva devape pajānanto ti
translated: Utta-sati : it sizzles on and on with the simmering of craving. Parita-sati : it simmers all round. Just as all bodily and verbal activities are born for that purpose, so it simmers in all its aspects. Gadhita is said to be gaddha . The characteristic of greed is intended here. He has no gaddha , thus he is agaddhita . He is not greedy, thus he is agaddhita . They are released by way of craving, by the state of being deluded, or by the state of being addicted to it. He has not fallen into it, he has not gone into it, he has not risen up in it, he has not been covered by it. He sees the danger in it. He is released from the enjoyment of what is clung to by this, thus it is a way of escape. He understands that which is intended by this, thus he is wise in the way of escape. Therefore it is said: “Understanding only as far as … he understands.”

original: Nevattānukkaṃsetīti attānaṃ neva ukkaṃseti na ukkhipati na ukkaṭṭhato dahati. “Aha”ntiādi
analyzed: na iva attā anukkaṃseti iti attānam na iva ukkaṃseti na ukkhipati na ukkaṭṭhataḥ dahati ahantiādi
translated: He does not exalt himself: he does not exalt himself, does not hold himself high, does not exalt his own view. “I” and so on.

original: ukkaṃsanākāradassanaṃ. Na vambhetīti na hīḷayati nihīnato na dahati. Tasmiṃ cīvarasantoseti
analyzed: ukkaṃsana ākāra dassanam na vambheti iti na hīḷayati nihīnataḥ na dahati tasmim cīvara santoseti
translated: He does not advertise himself: he does not advertise, proclaim, or make known himself, his name, family, etc., in order to obtain robe-material. “I am such and such” is the way of advertising oneself. He does not despise: he does not despise, look down upon, or disparage others. In that contentment with robe-material:

original: tasmiṃ yathāvutte vīsatividhe cīvarasantose. Kāmañcettha vuttappakārasantosaggahaṇena
analyzed: tasmin yathā vutte vīsatividhe cīvara santose kāmam ca itthā vutta ppakāra santosa ggahaṇena
translated: in that contentment with robe-material of the kind stated in the twenty-two ways. Although the obtaining of robe-material without importunity, etc., is included by the inclusion of the kind of contentment stated here,

original: cīvarahetu anesanāpajjanādipi gahitameva tasmiṃ sati tassa bhāvato, asati ca abhāvato,🔽vaṇṇavāditānattukkaṃsanā paravambhanāni pana gahitāni na hontīti “vaṇṇavāditādīsu
analyzed: cīvara hetu gahitam eva tasmin sati tassa bhāvataḥ asati ca abhāvataḥ  vaṇṇa vāditā anattukkaṃsanā para vambhanāni pana gahitāni na honti iti vaṇṇa vāditā ādīsu
translated: nevertheless, since it exists when there is that kind of contentment and does not exist when there is not,

original: vā”ti vikappo vutto. Ettha ca “dakkho”tiādi yesaṃ dhammānaṃ vasenassa yathāvuttasantosādi
analyzed: vā ti vikappaḥ vuttaḥ ettha ca dakkha uti ādi yesam dhammānam vasena assa yathā vutta santosa ādi
translated: the alternative “or” is stated in the words “or in the obtaining of robe-material without importunity, etc.” Herein, “he is clever” is the seeing of those things by means of which he is content, etc., as they are in actuality.

original: ijjhati, taṃ dassanaṃ. Tattha “dakkho”ti iminā tesaṃ samuṭṭhāpanapaññaṃ dasseti,
analyzed: tam dassanam tattha dakkho ti iminā tesam samuṭṭhāpana paññam dasseti
translated: Herein, by “clever” he shows the understanding that produces them;

original: “analaso”ti iminā paggaṇhanavīriyaṃ, “sampajāno”ti iminā pāṭihāriyapaññaṃ “paṭissato”ti
analyzed: analasaḥ ti iminā paggaṇhana vīriyam sampajānoti iminā pāṭihāriya paññam paṭissatoti
translated: by “not lazy,” the energy of exertion; by “fully aware,” the understanding of the performance; by “heedful,” the understanding of the result.

original: iminā tattha asammosavuttiṃ dasseti.🔽Piṇḍapāto jānitabboti pabhedato piṇḍapāto jānitabbo. Piṇḍapātakkhettanti piṇḍapātassa
analyzed: iminā tattha asammosa vuttim dasseti  piṇḍapātaḥ jānitabboti pabhedataḥ piṇḍapātaḥ jānitabbo piṇḍapāta khettam piṇḍapātassa
translated: He shows that he is not confused about that.🔽The alms-food should be known by its classification. The alms-food field is the source of the alms-food.

original: uppattiṭṭhānaṃ. Piṇḍapātasantoso jānitabboti piṇḍapāte santoso pabhedato jānitabbo.
analyzed: uppatti ṭṭhānam piṇḍapāta santoso jānitabbo ti piṇḍapāte santoso pabhedataḥ jānitabbo
translated: The satisfaction with alms-food should be known by its classification.

original: Idha bhesajjampi piṇḍapātagatikameva. Āharitabbato hi sappiādīnampi gahaṇaṃ kataṃ.
analyzed: idha bhesajjam pi piṇḍapāta gatikam eva āharitabbataḥ hi sappi ādīnam pi gahaṇam katam
translated: Here the medicine is included in the alms-food because it is brought in the alms-bowl.

original: Piṇḍapātakkhettaṃ piṇḍapātassa uppattiṭṭhānaṃ. Khettaṃ viya khettaṃ. Uppajjati ettha,
analyzed: piṇḍapāta khettam piṇḍapātassa uppatti ṭhānam khettam viya khettam uppajjati ettha
translated: The alms-food field is the source of the alms-food. It is a field as if it were a field. It arises here,

original: etenāti ca uppattiṭṭhānaṃ. Saṅghato vā hi bhikkhuno piṇḍapāto uppajjati uddesādivasena🔽vā. Tattha sakalassa saṅghassa dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ saṅghabhattaṃ. Katipaye bhikkhū uddisitvā
analyzed: etena ati ca uppatti ṭṭhānam saṅghataḥ vā hi bhikkhuno piṇḍapātaḥ uppajjati uddesa ādi vasena  vā tattha sakalassa saṅghassa dātabbam bhattam saṅgha bhattam katipaye bhikkhū uddisitvā
translated: therefore it is a source. For the alms-food of a monk arises from the Sangha, or from a recitation, etc.,🔽or from a nomination, or from an invitation.

original: uddesena dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ uddesabhattaṃ. Nimantetvā dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ nimantanaṃ.
analyzed: uddesena dātabbam bhattam uddesa bhattam nimantetvā dātabbam bhattam nimantanam
translated: Herein, the meal given to the whole Sangha is a Sangha meal. The meal given to a number of monks designated by the word “monks” is a recitation meal. The meal given after inviting is an invitation meal.

original: Salākadānavasena dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ salākabhattaṃ. Ekasmiṃ pakkhe ekadivasaṃ dātabbaṃ🔽bhattaṃ pakkhikaṃ. Uposathe dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ uposathikaṃ. Pāṭipadadivase dātabbaṃ🔽bhattaṃ pāṭipadikaṃ. Āgantukānaṃ dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ āgantukabhattaṃ. Dhuragehe eva🔽ṭhapetvā dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ dhurabhattaṃ. Kuṭiṃ uddissa dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ kuṭibhattaṃ.
analyzed: salāka dāna vasena dātabbam bhattam salāka bhattam ekasmim pakkhe eka divasam dātabbam  bhattam pakkhikam uposathe dātabbam bhattam uposathikam pāṭipada divase dātabbam  bhattam pāṭipadikam āgantukānam dātabbam bhattam āgantuka bhattam dhura gehe eva  ṭhapetvā dātabbam bhattam dhura bhattam kuṭim uddissa dātabbam bhattam kuṭi bhattam
translated: The meal given by means of a ticket is a ticket meal. The meal given on one day in one period to one who is on one side is a side meal.🔽The meal given on the observance day is an observance-day meal. The meal given on the fourteenth or fifteenth day is a fourteenth- or-fifteenth-day meal. The meal given to those who have arrived is an arrival meal.🔽The meal given to those who are staying in a particular place is a staying-on meal. The meal given to those who are building a dwelling is a building-dwelling meal.

original: Gāmavāsīādīhi vārena dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ vārabhattaṃ. Vihāraṃ uddissa dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ🔽vihārabhattaṃ. Sesāni pākaṭāneva.🔽Vitakketi “kattha nu kho ahaṃ ajja piṇḍāya carissāmī”ti. “Kattha piṇḍāya carissāmā”ti🔽therena vutte “asukagāme bhante”ti kāmametaṃ paṭivacanadānaṃ, yena pana cittena “cintetvā”ti
analyzed: gāmavāsī ādīhi vārena dātabbam bhattam vārabhattam vihāram uddissa dātabbam bhattam 🔽vihāra bhattam sesāni pākaṭāni eva 🔽vitakka iti kattha nu kho aham ajja piṇḍāya carissāmi iti kattha piṇḍāya carissāma ati 🔽therena vutte asuka gāme bhante iti kāmam etam paṭivacana dānam yena pana cittena cintetvā ati
translated: The meal given by means of a ticket is a ticket meal. The meal given on one day in one fortnight is a fortnightly meal. The meal given on the observance day is an observance-day meal. The meal given on the fourteenth day is a fourteenth-day meal. The meal given to visitors is a visitor’s meal. The meal given to those who have been appointed is an appointed meal. The meal given to those who are traveling is a traveling-by-vehicle meal. The meal given to those who are building is a building-work meal. The meal given to those who are sick is a sick-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are nursing the sick is a nursing-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are taking an examination is an examination-meal. The meal given to those who are teaching is a teaching-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by boat is a boat-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by ship is a ship-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by caravan is a caravan-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by foot is a foot-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by chariot is a chariot-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by elephant is an elephant-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by horse is a horse-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by donkey is a donkey-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by ox-cart is an ox-cart-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by foot is a foot-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by chariot is a chariot-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by elephant is an elephant-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by horse is a horse-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by donkey is a donkey-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by ox-cart is an ox-cart-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by foot is a foot-person’s meal. The meal given to those who are traveling by chariot is a chariot-person’s

original: vuttaṃ, taṃ sandhāyāha “ettakaṃ cintetvā”ti. Tato paṭṭhāyāti vitakkamāḷake ṭhatvā🔽vitakkitakālato paṭṭhāya. “Tato paraṃ vitakkento ariyavaṃsā cuto hotī”ti idaṃ tiṇṇampi
analyzed: vuttam tam sandhāya āha ettakam cintetvā iti tatas paṭṭhāya ati vitakka māḷake ṭhatvā  vitakkita kālato paṭṭhāya tato param vitakkento ariya vaṃsā cutaḥ hoti iti idam tiṇṇam pi
translated: From then on: from the time of standing in the thinking-place and thinking.

original: ariyavaṃsikānaṃ vasena gahetabbaṃ, na ekacārikasseva. Sabbopi hi ariyavaṃsiko ekavārameva
analyzed: ariyavaṃsikānam vasena gahetabbam na ekacārikassa iva sabbaḥ api hi ariyavaṃsikaḥ eka vāram eva
translated: The words “after that he is outside the Noble Ones’ heritages if he thinks” should be taken as applying to all three kinds of Noble Ones’ heritages, not to the once-returner’s only. For all three kinds of Noble Ones’ heritages are allowed only one thinking, not more than that.

original: vitakketuṃ labhati, na tato paraṃ. Paribāhiroti ariyavaṃsikabhāvato bahibhūto. Svāyaṃ
analyzed: vitakketum labhati na tatas param ariyavaṃsika bhāvataḥ bahibhūtaḥ
translated: Outside: become outside the Noble Ones’ heritages.

original: vitakkasantoso kammaṭṭhānamanasikārena na kuppati, visujjhati ca. Ito paresupi eseva
analyzed: vitakka santoso kammaṭṭhāna manasikārena na kuppati visujjhati ca itas paresu pi esā eva
translated: This satisfaction with thinking is not broken by giving attention to the meditation subject, and it is purified. The same method applies in the case of the rest.

original: nayo. Tenevāha “kammaṭṭhānasīsena gantabba”nti.
analyzed: nayo tena iva āha kammaṭṭhāna sīsena gantabbanti
translated: That is why he said “should be taken by way of the meditation subject’s head.”

original: Gahetabbamevāti aṭṭhānappayutto eva-saddo. Yāpanamattameva gahetabbanti yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: gahetabbam eva āti aṭṭhāna ppayuttaḥ eva saddaḥ yāpana mattam eva gahetabbam iti yojetabbam
translated: Should be taken: the word eva is connected with aṭṭhānappayutto . Only enough for maintenance should be taken is the construction.

original: Etthāti etasmiṃ piṇḍapātapaṭiggahaṇe. Appanti attano yāpanapamāṇatopi appaṃ. Gahetabbaṃ
analyzed: ettha iti etasmim piṇḍapāta paṭiggahaṇe appanti attanaḥ yāpana pamāṇataḥ pi appam gahetabbam
translated: Herein: in this case of accepting alms food. Little: even by way of the amount needed for one’s own maintenance.

original: dāyakassa cittārādhanatthaṃ. Pamāṇenevāti attano yāpanappamāṇeneva appaṃ gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: dāyakassa citta ārādhana tham pamāṇena iva ati attanaḥ yāpana pamāṇena iva appam gahetabbam
translated: Just the right amount: only as much as is needed for one’s own sustenance.

original: “Pamāṇena gahetabba”nti ettha kāraṇaṃ dassetuṃ “paṭiggahaṇasmiñhī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Makkhetīti
analyzed: pamāṇena gahetabbanti ettha kāraṇam dassetum paṭiggahaṇasmin hi itiādi vuttam makkheti iti
translated: “One should take just the right amount” is said in order to show the reason for this.🔽To make it disappear: to destroy it, to remove it.🔽To throw away: to destroy it by not using it.

original: viddhaṃseti apaneti. Vinipātetīti vināseti aṭṭhānaviniyogena. Sāsananti satthu sāsanaṃ
analyzed: viddhaṃseti apaneti vinipāteti iti vināseti aṭṭhāna viniyogena sāsananti satthu sāsanam
translated: The Dispensation: the Teacher’s Dispensation,🔽the instruction.

original: anusiṭṭhiṃ. Na karoti nappaṭipajjati.
analyzed: anusiṭṭhim na karoti na paṭipajjati
translated: He does not do, he does not practice.

original: Sapadānacārino viya dvārapaṭipāṭiyā caraṇaṃ loluppavivajjanasantosoti āha “dvārapaṭipāṭiyā gantabba”nti.
analyzed: sa padāna cārinaḥ viya dvāra paṭipāṭiyā caraṇam loluppa vivajjana santoso ti āha dvāra paṭipāṭiyā gantabbanti
translated: The practice of going by turns like those who go on a round for alms is the contentment that arises from the avoidance of greed. Therefore it is said: “One should go by turns.”

original: Harāpetvāti adhikaṃ apanetvā.
analyzed: harā petvā iti adhikam apanetvā
translated: Having taken away: having removed the excess.

original: Āhāragedhato nissarati etenāti nissaraṇaṃ. Jighacchāya paṭivinodanatthaṃ kathā, kāyassaṭhitiādipayojanaṃ pana atthāpattito āgataṃ evāti āha “jighacchāya…pe… santoso nāmā”ti.
analyzed: āhāra gedhataḥ nissarati etena ati nissaraṇam jighacchāya paṭivinodana attham kathā kāyassa saṭhiti ādi payojanam pana atthāpattitaḥ āgatam eva ati āha santosaḥ nāma ati
translated: It is called contentment because it is the satisfaction that arises from the avoidance of greed for the purpose of the maintenance of the body, etc., which is included in the prohibition against the pursuit of the enjoyment of flavor.

original: Nidahitvā na paribhuñjitabbaṃ tadahupīti adhippāyo. Itaratthā pana sikkhāpadeneva vāritaṃ. Sāraṇīyadhamme ṭhitenāti sīlavantehi bhikkhūhi sādhāraṇabhogibhāve ṭhitena.
analyzed: nidahitvā na paribhuñjitabbam tat ahupi iti adhippāyaḥ itaratthā pana sikkhāpadena iva vāritam sāraṇīya dhamme ṭhitena ati sīlavantehi bhikkhūhi sādhāraṇa bhogi bhāve ṭhitena
translated: The intention is that it should not be used after being stored. But the other meaning is already prohibited by the training rule. “By one who is established in the Dhamma that is conducive to amity”: by one who is established in the state of sharing the same aims with virtuous bhikkhus.

original: Senāsanenāti sayanena, āsanena ca. Yattha yattha hi mañcādike, vihārādike ca seti,
analyzed: senāsanena ati sayanena āsanena ca yattha yattha hi mañca ādike vihāra ādike ca
translated: “A dwelling” : a bed and a seat. For wherever one lies down on a bed, etc.,

original: taṃ senaṃ. Yattha yattha pīṭhādike āsati, taṃ āsanaṃ. Tadubhayaṃ ekato katvā “senāsana”nti
analyzed: tam yattha yattha pīṭha ādike āsati tam āsanam tat ubhayam ekatas katvā
translated: that is a dwelling. Wherever one sits on a chair, etc., that is a seat. Both together are called “a dwelling.”

original: vuttaṃ. Tenāha “mañco”tiādi. Tattha mañco masārakādi, tathā pīṭhaṃ. Mañcabhisi, pīṭhabhisīti
analyzed: vuttam tena āha mañca utiādi tattha mañcaḥ masāraka ādi tathā pīṭham mañca bhisi pīṭha bhisī iti
translated: Hence it is said: “a bed,” etc. Herein, a bed is a couch, etc., and a chair is a chair, etc.

original: duvidhā bhisi. Vihāro pākāraparicchinno sakalo āvāso. “Dīghamukhapāsādo”ti keci.🔽Aḍḍhayogoti dīghapāsādo. “Ekapassacchadanakasenāsana”nti keci. Pāsādoti caturassapāsādo.
analyzed: duvidhā vihāraḥ pākāra paricchinno sakalaḥ āvāsaḥ dīgha mukha pāsādaḥ iti keci  dīgha pāsādo eka passacchadanaka senāsananti keci pāsādo ti catur assa pāsādo
