original: paṭhamamaggo kathito”ti. Idhāti imasmiṃ sutte. Catūsupi maggesu sammādiṭṭhi diṭṭhiggahaṇena
analyzed: paṭhama maggaḥ kathito ti idha ati imasmim sutte catūsu pi maggesu sammādiṭṭhi diṭṭhi ggahaṇena
translated: The first path is stated. Herein, in this Thread, right view is stated in the four paths.

original: gahitāti āha “cattāropi maggā kathitā”ti.
analyzed: gahitā ati āha cattāro api maggā kathitā ati
translated: So it is said that the four paths are stated.

original: Vivādamūlachakkavaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Root of Disputes

original: 325. Kodhanoti kujjhanasīlo. Yasmā so appahīnakodhatāya vigatakodhano nāma na hoti,
analyzed: kodhano ti kujjhana sīlaḥ yasmā so appahīna kodhatāya vigata kodhanaḥ nāma na hoti
translated: One who is angry is one with the habit of being angry. Since he is not called one who is without anger because he has not abandoned anger,

original: tasmā “kodhena samannāgato”ti āha. Upanāho etassa atthi, upanayhanasīloti vā upanāhī.🔽Vivādo nāma uppajjamāno yebhuyyena paṭhamaṃ dvinnaṃ vasena uppajjatīti vuttaṃ “dvinnaṃ
analyzed: tasmā kodhena samannāgataḥ iti āha upanāhaḥ etassa atthi upanayhana sīlaḥ iti vā upanāhī  vivādaḥ nāma uppajjamānaḥ yebhuyyena paṭhamam dvinnam vasena uppajjati iti vuttam dvinnam
translated: therefore it is said that he is possessed of anger. One who has resentment, or one with the habit of resenting, is a resenter.

original: bhikkhūnaṃ vivādo”ti. So pana yathā bahūnaṃ anatthāvaho hoti, taṃ nidassanamukhena
analyzed: bhikkhūnam vivādaḥ ti so pana yathā bahūnam anattha āvahaḥ hoti tam nidassana mukhena
translated: When a dispute arises it arises in the majority of cases on the part of two people. So it is said that the dispute is between two bhikkhus.

original: dassento “katha”ntiādimāha. Abbhantaraparisāyāti parisabbhantare.🔽Paraguṇamakkhanāya pavattopi attano kārakaṃ gūthena paharantaṃ gūtho viya paṭhamataraṃ
analyzed: dassento kathaṃ ti ādim āha abbhantara parisāya iti parisa abbhantare 🔽para guṇa makkhanāya pavattaḥ api attanaḥ kārakam gūthena paharantam gūthaḥ viya paṭhamataram
translated: But that is shown by the expression “argument” as being a source of harm to many people.🔽In the midst of the assembly: in the midst of the assembly.

original: makkhetīti makkho, so etassa atthīti makkhī. Palāsatīti palāso, parassa guṇe ḍaṃsitvā🔽viya apanetīti attho, so etassa atthīti palāsī. Palāsī puggalo hi dutiyassa dhuraṃ
analyzed: makkheti iti makkho saḥ etassa atthi iti makkhī palāsati iti palāsaḥ parassa guṇe ḍaṃsitvā  viya apaneti iti attho saḥ etassa atthi iti palāsī palāsī puggalaḥ hi dutiyassa dhuram
translated: “Malice” is the state of being malicious. He who has that is “malicious.” “Spite” is the state of being spiteful. It means that he is as if he were to take away the other’s virtue,🔽etc. He who has that is “spiteful.” For the spiteful person, as if taking away the other’s virtue, etc.,🔽

original: na deti, samaṃ pasāretvā tiṭṭhati. Tenāha “yugaggāhalakkhaṇena palāsena samannāgato”ti.
analyzed: na deti samam pasāretvā tiṭṭhati tena āha yuga ggāha lakkhaṇena palāsena samannāgataḥ ti
translated: “He is contemptuous” : he is contemptuous , and he has that , thus he is contemptuous . “He is overbearing” : he is overbearing , and he has that , thus he is overbearing . For when a person is overbearing he does not give the other a chance to speak but stands in his way as it were by his very presence. Hence it is said: “He is overbearing in the sense of standing in the way of another’s yoke animal” .

original: “Issukī”tiādīnaṃ padānamattho heṭṭhā vuttanayattā suviññeyyova. Kammapathappattāya
analyzed: issukī iti ādīnam padānam atthaḥ heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā su viññeyyaḥ iva kammapatha ppattāya
translated: The meaning of the terms “envious” , etc., is easy to understand, as it is given below .

original: micchādiṭṭhiyā vasenettha micchādiṭṭhi veditabbāti āha “natthikavādī ahetukavādī akiriyavādī”ti.
analyzed: micchādiṭṭhiyāḥ vasena ittha micchādiṭṭhi veditabbā ti āha natthika vādī ahetuka vādī akiriya vādī iti
translated: Here “wrong view” should be understood as the wrong view that has reached the plane of kamma-formation . Hence it is said: “He is a nihilist, a non-causer theorist, a non-doer theorist” .

original: Nissaraṇiyachakkavaṇṇanā🔽326. Hāpetvāti kusalacittaṃ parihāpetvā pavattitumeva appadānavasena. Abhūtaṃ byākaraṇaṃ
analyzed: hāpetvā iti kusala cittam parihāpetvā pavattitum eva appadāna vasena abhūtam byākaraṇam
translated: The exposition of the eye of deliverance

original: byākaroti “mettā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā”tiādinā attani avijjamānaṃ guṇabyāhāraṃ
analyzed: byākaroti mettā hi kho me cetaḥ vimutti bhāvitā ati ādinā attani a vijjamānam guṇa byāhāram
translated: “By the abandoning of” : by the non-occurrence of. “Falsely”: he makes a false declaration of his attainments, saying: “I have developed the mind-deliverance of loving-kindness,” etc., and he makes a false declaration of his special qualities, saying: “I am one of the arahants.”

original: byāharati. Cetovimutti-saddaṃ apekkhitvā “nissaṭā”ti vuttaṃ. Puna byāpādo natthīti
analyzed: byāharati cetaḥ vimutti saddam apekkhitvā nissaṭā ati vuttam puna byāpādaḥ natthi iti
translated: He speaks. “Emancipated” is said with reference to the expression “liberation of mind.”🔽Now, since there is no ill will in me,

original: idāni mama byāpādo nāma natthi sabbaso natthīti ñatvā.
analyzed: idāni mama byāpādaḥ nāma natthi sabbaso natthi iti ñatvā
translated: having known that there is no ill will in me at all,🔽having spoken of the signless,

original: “Animittā”ti vatvā yesaṃ nimittānaṃ abhāvena arahattaphalasamāpattiyā animittatā,
analyzed: animittā iti vatvā yesam nimittānam abhāvena arahatta phala samāpattiyāḥ animitta tā
translated: in order to show the signlessness of the attainment of the fruit of arahantship,

original: taṃ dassetuṃ “sā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha rāgassa nimittaṃ, rāgo eva vā nimittanti
analyzed: tam dassetum sā hi itiādi vuttam tattha rāgassa nimittam rāgaḥ eva vā nimittan ti
translated: he said, “It is free from the sign of lust, etc.” Herein, the sign of lust is either the sign of lust or lust itself.

original: rāganimittaṃ. Ādi-saddena dosanimittādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Rūpavedanādisaṅkhāranimittaṃ
analyzed: rāga nimittam ādi saddena dosa nimitta ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo rūpa vedanā ādi saṅkhāra nimittam
translated: The word “etc.” should be understood to include the sign of hate, etc. The sign of form, feeling, etc.,

original: rūpanimittādi. Tesaññeva niccādivasena upaṭṭhānaṃ niccanimittādi. Tayidaṃ nimittaṃ
analyzed: rūpa nimitta ādi tesaññeva nicca ādi vasena upaṭṭhānam nicca nimitta ādi tayidam nimittam
translated: is the sign of form, etc. The appearance of these same things as permanent, etc., is the sign of permanence, etc.

original: yasmā sabbena sabbaṃ arahattaphale natthi, tasmā vuttaṃ “sā hi…pe… animittāti vuttā”ti.
analyzed: yasmā sabbena sabbam arahatta phale na atthi tasmā vuttam sā hipe animittā ati vuttā iti
translated: Since this sign is absent in the fruit of arahantship in every respect, it is said that the fruit is called “signless” because it is free from the sign of lust, etc.

original: Nimittaṃ anusaratīti taṃ nimittaṃ anugacchati ārabbha pavattati.
analyzed: nimittam anusarati iti tam nimittam anugacchati ārabbha pavattati
translated: “It follows the sign”: it follows that sign, it occurs in dependence on it.

original: Asmimānoti “asmī”ti pavatto attavisayo māno. Ayaṃ nāma ahaṃ asmīti rūpalakkhaṇo,
analyzed: asmimāno ti asmi iti pavattaḥ atta visayaḥ mānaḥ ayam nāma aham asmi iti rūpa lakkhaṇo
translated: “I am” is the conceit that occurs with the thought “I am.” This is the conceit that has the characteristic of “I am such and such,” or the characteristic of “This self is such and such.”

original: vedanādīsu vā aññataralakkhaṇo ayaṃ nāma attā ahaṃ asmi. “Asmī”ti māno samugghāṭīyati
analyzed: vedanā ādīsu vā aññatara lakkhaṇaḥ ayam nāma attā aham asmi asmi iti māno samugghāṭīyati
translated: The conceit “I am” is uprooted🔽by this,

original: etenāti asmimānasamugghāto, arahattamaggo. Puna asmimāno natthīti tassa anuppattidhammatāpādanaṃ
analyzed: etena ati asmimāna samugghātaḥ arahatta maggo puna asmimānaḥ natthi iti tassa anuppatti dhamma tā āpādanam
translated: thus it is the uprooting of the conceit “I am,” which is the path of arahatship. The non-arising of the conceit “I am” again is the establishment of its non-arising.

original: kittento samugghātattameva vibhāveti.
analyzed: vibhāveti
translated: The word “uprooting” shows the same thing.

original: Anuttariyādichakkavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anuttariya ādi chakka vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the six kinds of unsurpassedness, etc.

original: 327. Natthi etesaṃ uttarāni visiṭṭhānīti anuttarāni, anuttarāni eva anuttariyāni
analyzed: natthi etesam uttarāni visiṭṭhāni iti anuttarāni anuttarāni eva anuttariyāni
translated: There is nothing higher or more distinguished than these, thus they are unsurpassed ; the unsurpassed are the unsurpassed states .

original: yathā anantameva ānantariyanti āha “anuttariyānīti anuttarānī”ti. Dassanānuttariyaṃ
analyzed: yathā anantam eva ānantariyanti āha anuttariyāni iti anuttarāni iti dassana anuttariyam
translated: Since they are unsurpassed, he says, “The unsurpassed are the unsurpassed states.”🔽The unsurpassedness of vision is the unsurpassedness of the fruit of arahantship. The same method applies to the rest.

original: nāma anuttaraphalavisesāvahattā. Esa nayo sesesupi. Sattavidhaariyadhanalābhoti sattavidhasaddhādilokuttaradhanalābho.
analyzed: nāma anuttara phala visesa āvaha ttā esa nayo sesesu pi sattavidha ariya dhana lābho ti sattavidha saddhā ādi lokuttara dhana lābho
translated: The acquisition of the seven kinds of noble wealth is the acquisition of the seven kinds of supramundane wealth beginning with faith.

original: Sikkhattayapūraṇanti adhisīlasikkhādīnaṃ tissannaṃ sikkhānaṃ paripūraṇaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: sikkhattaya pūraṇam ti adhi sīla sikkhā ādīnam tissannam sikkhānam paripūraṇam tattha
translated: The fulfillment of the three trainings is the fulfillment of the three trainings in higher virtue, etc.

original: paripūraṇaṃ nippariyāyato asekkhānaṃ vasena veditabbaṃ. Kalyāṇaputhujjanato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: paripūraṇam nippariyāyataḥ asekkhānam vasena veditabbam kalyāṇa puthujjanataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: The fulfilment should be understood as the fulfilment of the three kinds of training in the case of the adepts, who are beyond training.

original: hi satta sekkhā tisso sikkhā pūrenti nāma, arahā pana paripuṇṇasikkhoti. Iti imāni
analyzed: hi satta sekkhā tissaḥ sikkhā pūrenti nāma arahā pana paripuṇṇasikkho ti iti imāni
translated: For the seven kinds of trainee beginning with the good ordinary man fulfil the three kinds of training, but the Arahant has fulfilled the training.

original: anuttariyāni lokiyalokuttarāni kathitāni.
analyzed: anuttariyāni lokiya lokuttarāni kathitāni
translated: So these are the kinds of excellence, mundane and supramundane, that have been expounded.

original: Anussatiyo eva diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikādihitasukhānaṃ kāraṇabhāvato ṭhānānīti anussatiṭṭhānāni.🔽Evaṃ anussaratoti yathā buddhānussati visesādhigamassa ṭhānaṃ hoti, evaṃ “itipi so
analyzed: anussatiyaḥ eva diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika ādi hita sukhānam kāraṇa bhāvato ṭhānāni iti anussati ṭṭhānāni  evam anussarato ti yathā buddha anussati visesa adhigamassa ṭhānam hoti evam iti pi so
translated: The foundations are the bases for the recollection that is the cause of the kinds of good of the here and now and the life to come, and so on.

original: bhagavā”tiādinā buddhaguṇe anussarantassa. Upacārakammaṭṭhānanti paccakkhato upacārajjhānāvahaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā tiādinā buddha guṇe anussarantassa upacāra kammaṭṭhānan ti paccakkhataḥ upacāra jjhāna āvaham
translated: “When he recollects the special qualities of the Enlightened One in this way”: when he recollects the special qualities of the Enlightened One in the way beginning, “The Blessed One is such since he is accomplished, fully enlightened, endowed with vision and conduct, sublime, the knower of worlds, the incomparable leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, enlightened and blessed” .

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ, paramparāya pana yāva arahattā lokiyalokuttaravisesāvahaṃ.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam paramparāya pana yāva arahattā lokiya lokuttara visesa āvaham
translated: The meditation subject for beginners: the meditation subject that brings about access concentration is called “for beginners” in the direct sense. But in the indirect sense it is so called up to the attainment of Arahantship, since it brings about mundane and supramundane distinction.

original: Satatavihārachakkavaṇṇanā
analyzed: satatavihāra chakka vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the three foundations of mindfulness that are basic .

original: 328. Niccavihārāti sabbadā pavattanakavihārā. Ṭhapetvā hi samāpattivelaṃ, bhavaṅgavelañca
analyzed: nicca vihārā ti sabbadā pavattanaka vihārā ṭhapetvā hi samāpatti velam bhavaṅga velam ca
translated: “Constant abidings”: abidings that occur all the time.

original: khīṇāsavā imināva chaḷaṅgupekkhāvihārena sabbakālaṃ viharanti. Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvāti🔽nissayavohārena vuttaṃ. Sasambhārakathā hesā yathā “dhanunā vijjhatī”ti. Tasmā nissayasīsena
analyzed: khīṇa āsavā iminā ava chaḷaṅgu pekkhā vihārena sabbakālam viharanti cakkhunā rūpam disvā ati  nissaya vohārena vuttam sa sambhāra kathā ha isā yathā dhanunā vijjhati iti tasmā nissaya sīsena
translated: Those whose cankers are destroyed dwell all the time in equanimity about these six sense doors by means of this equanimity consisting in neutrality. On seeing a visible object with the eye:🔽This is said with reference to the physical eye as its support. For this is a way of speaking by metonomy, as in the passage, “He fights with a bow” . Consequently, what is meant is that he sees with eye-consciousness.

original: nissitassa gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbanti āha “cakkhuviññāṇena disvā”ti. Iṭṭhe arajjantoti
analyzed: nissitassa gahaṇam daṭṭhabbanti āha cakkhu viññāṇena disvā ti iṭṭhe a rajjanto ti
translated: Not excited by pleasant visible objects:🔽he does not arouse lust for pleasant objects because they have been cut off by the path.

original: iṭṭhe ārammaṇe rāgaṃ anuppādento maggena samucchinnattā. Neva sumano hoti gehasitapemavasenapi.
analyzed: iṭṭhe ārammaṇe rāgam an uppādentaḥ maggena samucchinna ttā na iva sumanaḥ hoti geha sita pema vasena api
translated: Nor is he depressed, because confidence and the like are not absent.

original: Na dummano pasādaññathattavasenapi. Asamapekkhaneti iṭṭhepi aniṭṭhepi majjhattepi🔽ārammaṇe na samaṃ na sammā ayoniso gahaṇe. Yo akhīṇāsavānaṃ moho uppajjati, taṃ anuppādento
analyzed: na dummanaḥ pasāda aññathatta vasena api a samapekkhanā iti iṭṭhe pi aniṭṭhe pi majjhatte pi  ārammaṇe na samam na sammā ayonisaḥ gahaṇe yaḥ akhīṇāsavānam moho uppajjati tam an uppādento
translated: Not looking for equanimity: he does not look for equanimity, that is, he does not look for a state of neutrality, in a pleasant object, an unpleasant object, or a neutral object by an act of attention that is even, or by an act of attention that is uneven, or by an act of attention that is neither even nor uneven.🔽Not giving rise to delusion: he does not give rise to the delusion that arises in those whose cankers are not destroyed because it has been eradicated by the path.

original: maggeneva tassa samugghāṭitattā. Ñāṇupekkhāvaseneva upekkhako viharati majjhatto.
analyzed: maggena iva tassa samugghāṭita ttā ñāṇa upekkhā vasena iva upekkhakaḥ viharati majjhattaḥ
translated: He dwells in equanimity, mindful and fully aware.

original: Ayañcassa paṭipattivepullappattiyā, paññāvepullappattiyā vāti āha “satiyā”tiādi.
analyzed: ayam ca assa paṭipatti vepulla ppattiyā paññā vepulla ppattiyā vā ti āha satiyā atiādi
translated: This is the fulfilment of practice and the fulfilment of understanding. Therefore it is said, “Through mindfulness” and so on.

original: Chaḷaṅgupekkhāti chasu dvāresu pavattā satisampajaññassa vasena chāvayavā upekkhā.
analyzed: chaḷaṅgu upekkhā ti chasu dvāresu pavattā sati sampajaññassa vasena cha avayavā upekkhā
translated: “Equanimity as to the six sense- bases” is equanimity as a factor of the seventh and eighth paths as the six bases of contact that occur in the six doors by means of mindfulness and full awareness.🔽The eight great functional consciousnesses are possible,

original: Ñāṇasampayuttacittāni labbhanti tehi vinā sampajānatāya asambhavato. Mahācittānīti🔽aṭṭhapi mahākiriyacittāni labbhanti. Satatavihārāti ñāṇuppattipaccayarahitakālepi🔽pavattibhedanato. Dasa cittānīti aṭṭha mahākiriyacittāni hasituppādavoṭṭhabbanacittehi
analyzed: ñāṇa sampayutta cittāni labbhanti tehi vinā sampajānatāya asambhavataḥ mahā cittāni iti  aṭṭha pi mahā kiriya cittāni labbhanti satata vihārā ati ñāṇa uppatti paccaya rahita kāle pi  pavatti bhedanataḥ dasa cittāni iti aṭṭha mahā kiriya cittāni hasita uppāda voṭṭhabbana cittehi
translated: because it is impossible to be fully aware without them.🔽“Constant abiders” are the eight great functional consciousnesses, plus the consciousnesses of smiling, speaking, and shaking off torpor,🔽which make ten consciousnesses possible.

original: saddhiṃ dasa cittāni labbhanti. Arajjanādussanavasena pavatti tesampi sādhāraṇāti.“Upekkhako🔽viharatī”ti vacanato chaḷaṅgupekkhāvasena āgatānaṃ imesaṃ satatavihārānaṃ “somanassaṃ
analyzed: saddhim dasa cittāni labbhanti a rajjana ādussana vasena tesam pi sādhāraṇa ati upekkhako  viharati iti vacanataḥ chaḷaṅgu pekkhā vasena āgatānam imesam satata vihārānam somanassam
translated: The occurrence of these ten is common to both the equanimity of the sixth and seventh paths and the equanimity of the eighth path.🔽“But how can there be joy in the constant abiders?”

original: kathaṃ labbhatī”ti codetvā “āsevanato labbhatī”ti sayameva pariharatīti. Kiñcāpi
analyzed: katham labbhati iti codetvā āsevanataḥ labbhati iti sayam eva pariharati iti kiñca api
translated: The answer is that it is possible because of repetition.

original: khīṇāsavo iṭṭhāniṭṭhepi ārammaṇe majjhatte viya bahulaṃ upekkhako viharati attano
analyzed: khīṇa āsavaḥ iṭṭha aniṭṭhe pi ārammaṇe majjhatte viya bahulam upekkhakaḥ viharati attanaḥ
translated: Although an Arahant usually abides in equanimity towards desirable and undesirable objects as if they were the same,

original: parisuddhapakatibhāvāvijahanato, kadāci pana tathā cetobhisaṅkhārābhāve yaṃ taṃ sabhāvato🔽iṭṭhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ, tattha yāthāvasabhāvaggahaṇavasenapi arahato cittaṃ somanassasahagataṃ
analyzed: kadāci pana tathā cetaḥ bhisaṅkhāra abhāve yam tam sabhāvataḥ  iṭṭham ārammaṇam tattha yāthāvasa bhāva ggahaṇa vasena api arahataḥ cittam somanassa sahagatam
translated: because he does not abandon the natural purity of his state. But if there is no such mental volition, then whatever object is agreeable in itself🔽is accompanied by joy in the Arahant’s cognizance through his apprehending it as it actually is.

original: hutvā pavattateva, tañca kho pubbāsevanavasena. Tenāha “āsevanato labbhatī”ti.
analyzed: hutvā tat ca kho pubba āsevana vasena tena āha āsevanataḥ labbhati iti
translated: Because he does not abandon the natural purity of his individual essence. But sometimes, when there is no such mental volition, then the Arahant’s consciousness occurs with joy in the case of a desirable object that is in itself desirable, and that is because of his having previously cultivated the meditation subject. That is why it is said, “It is obtained through cultivation.”

original: Abhijātichakkavaṇṇanā
analyzed: abhijāti chakka vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the kinds of generation

original: 329. “Abhijātiyo”ti ettha abhi-saddo upasaggamattaṃ, na atthavisesajotakoti āha “jātiyo”ti.🔽Abhijāyatīti etthāpi eseva nayo. Jāyatīti ca antogadhahetuatthapadaṃ, uppādetīti
analyzed: abhijātiyaḥ ti ettha abhi saddaḥ upasagga mattam na attha visesa jotakaḥ ti āha jātiyaḥ ti  abhijāyati iti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ jāyati iti ca antogadha hetu attha padam uppādeti iti
translated: Here the prefix abhi is a mere prefix; it does not indicate any distinction of meaning. That is why it is said, “the kinds of generation” .

original: attho. Jātiyā, taṃnibbattakakammānañca kaṇhasukkapariyāyatāya yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ jātiyā tad nibbattaka kammānam ca kaṇha sukka pariyāyatāya yat vattabbam tam
translated: The same explanation applies here to the word abhijāyati . The word jāyati is a synonym for “cause” . The meaning is, “he causes to arise.” And what is to be said about generation and the kinds of kamma that generate it as dark and bright can be understood from what has already been said🔽about the dark and bright kinds of kamma .

original: heṭṭhā vuttameva. Paṭippassambhanavasena kilesānaṃ nibbāpanato nibbānaṃ sace kaṇhaṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhā vuttam eva paṭippassambhana vasena kilesānam nibbāpanataḥ nibbānam sace kaṇham
translated: Nibbāna is called “bright” because it is the extinguishing of defilements by means of substitution of opposites.

original: bhaveyya yathā taṃ dasavidhaṃ dussīlyakammaṃ. Sace sukkaṃ bhaveyya yathā taṃ dānasīlādikusalakammaṃ.
analyzed: bhaveyya yathā tam dasavidham dussīlya kammam sace sukkam bhaveyya yathā tam dāna sīla ādi kusala kammam
translated: and if it were white, it would be like the ten kinds of profitable action consisting in giving, virtue, etc.,

original: Dvinnampi kaṇhasukkavipākānaṃ. Arahattaṃ adhippetaṃ “abhijāyatī”ti vacanato. Taṃ
analyzed: dvinnam pi kaṇha sukka vipākānam arahattam adhippetam abhijāyati iti vacanato tam
translated: and it would be the extinction of both kinds of kamma, namely, that with an agreeable experience and that with a disagreeable experience, since it is said “it is born in the extinction of lust, etc.,”

original: kilesanibbānante jātattā nibbānaṃ yathā rāgādīnaṃ khayante jātattā rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayoti.
analyzed: kilesa nibbāna ante jāta ttā nibbānam yathā rāga ādīnam khaya ante jāta ttā rāga kkhayaḥ dosa kkhayaḥ moha kkhayaḥ iti
translated: and it is called “extinction” because it is born in the extinction of defilements, just as “destruction of lust,” “destruction of hatred,” and “destruction of delusion” are.

original: Nibbedhabhāgiyachakkavaṇṇanā🔽Nibbedho vuccati nibbānaṃ maggañāṇena nibbijjhitabbaṭṭhena, paṭivijjhitabbaṭṭhenāti
analyzed: nibbedhabhāgiya chakka vaṇṇanā  nibbedhaḥ vuccati nibbānam magga ñāṇena nibbijjhitabba ṭṭhena paṭivijjhitabba ṭṭhena ati
translated: The Description of the Vision-Faculty🔽Nibbana is called “vision” in the sense of being what should be seen by the knowledge of the path. The meaning is that it is what should be penetrated by the path.

original: attho. Nirodhānupassanāñāṇeti nirodhānupassanāñāṇe nissayapaccayabhūte uppannā saññā,
analyzed: atthaḥ nirodha anupassanā ñāṇe iti nirodha anupassanā ñāṇe nissaya paccaya bhūte uppannā saññā
translated: The perception that arises with the knowledge of contemplation of cessation as its support and condition is called “the perception of cessation.”

original: tena sahagatāti attho.
analyzed: tena sahagatā ati attho
translated: The meaning is that it is associated with that.

original: Chakkavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: chakka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the vision-faculty is ended

original: Sattakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sattaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Faculty of Masculinity

original: 330. Sampattipaṭilābhaṭṭhenāti sīlasampattiādīnaṃ sammāsambodhipariyosānānaṃ sampattīnaṃ
analyzed: sampatti paṭilābha aṭṭhena ati sīla sampatti ādīnam sammāsambodhi pariyosānānam sampattīnam
translated: in the sense of the acquisition of excellence. The excellence of virtue, etc.,

original: paṭilābhāpanaṭṭhena, sampattīnaṃ vā paṭilābho sampattipaṭilābho, tassa kāraṇaṃ sampattipaṭilābhaṭṭho,
analyzed: paṭilābhāpana ṭhena sampattīnam vā paṭilābhaḥ sampatti paṭilābho tassa kāraṇam sampatti paṭilābhaṭṭho
translated: The cause of the acquisition of excellence is the cause of the acquisition of the excellences.

original: tena sampattipaṭilābhaṭṭhena. Tenevāha “sampattīnaṃ paṭilābhakāraṇato”ti. Saddhāva
analyzed: tena sampatti paṭilābha ṭṭhena tena iva āha sampattīnam paṭilābha kāraṇa tā iti
translated: By that cause of the acquisition of excellence. Hence it is said: “because it is the cause of the acquisition of the excellences.”

original: ubhayahitatthikehi dhanāyitabbaṭṭhena dhanaṃ saddhādhanaṃ. Etthāti etesu dhanesu.
analyzed: ubhaya hitatthikehi dhanāyitabba ṭṭhena dhanam saddhā dhanam ettha ati etesu dhanesu
translated: Faith is the wealth of faith. Herein, among these kinds of wealth,

original: Sabbaseṭṭhaṃ sabbesaṃ paṭilābhakāraṇabhāvato, tesañca saṃkilesavisodhanena mahājutikamahāvipphārabhāvāpādanato.
analyzed: sabba seṭṭham sabbesam paṭilābha kāraṇa bhāvato tesam ca saṃkilesa visodhanena mahājutika mahā vipphāra bhāva āpādanato
translated: it is the best of all because it is the cause of the acquisition of all the others, and because it brings about the state of having great radiance and great range by the purification of those others.

original: Tenāha “paññāya hī”tiādi. Tattha paññāya ṭhatvāti kammassakatāpaññāya patiṭṭhāya
analyzed: tena āha paññāya hi itiādi tattha paññāya ṭhatvā ti kammassaka tā paññāya patiṭṭhāya
translated: Hence it is said: “By wisdom” and so on. Herein, standing on wisdom means standing on the wisdom of the ownership of kamma.

original: sucaritādīni pūretvā saggūpagā honti. Tattha ceva pāramitā paññāya ca ṭhatvā sāvakapāramiñāṇādīni paṭivijjhanti.
analyzed: su carita ādīni pūretvā saggu upagāḥ honti tattha ca iva pāramitā paññāya ca ṭhatvā sāvaka pārami ñāṇa ādīni paṭivijjhanti
translated: Having fulfilled good conduct, etc., they go to heaven. And standing on wisdom there, and on the pāramīs, they penetrate the knowledge of the disciple-perfections, and so on.

original: Samādhiṃ parikkharonti abhisaṅkharontīti samādhiparikkhārā, samādhissa sambhārabhūtā sammādiṭṭhiādayo. Idha pana sahakārīkāraṇabhūtā adhippetāti āha “samādhiparivārā”ti.🔽Asataṃ asādhūnaṃ dhammā tesaṃ asādhubhāvasādhanato. Asantāti asundarā gārayhā. Tenāha
analyzed: samādhim parikkharonti abhisaṅkharonti iti samādhi parikkhārā samādhissa sambhāra bhūtā sammādiṭṭhi ādayaḥ idha pana sahakārī kāraṇa bhūtā adhippetā iti āha samādhi parivārā iti  asatam asādhūnam dhammā tesam asādhu bhāva sādhanato asantā ati asundarā tena āha
translated: They are requisites of concentration because they are the requisites for it, that is, right view, etc., which are the conditions for concentration. But here they are intended as the co-operating conditions, thus he said “requisites of concentration.”🔽They are the states that are not good and not bad because they establish the unprofitableness of those states. They are “not good” in the sense of not beautiful and blameworthy. Hence he said “inferior.”

original: “lāmakā”ti. “Vipassakasseva kathitā”ti vatvā tassa vipassanānibbattiṃ dassetuṃ “tesupī”tiādi
analyzed: lāmakā ati vipassakassa iva kathitā ati vatvā tassa vipassanā nibbattim dassetum tesu pi itiādi
translated: “They are called the states of one who is not a true man” : after saying this, in order to show the arising of his insight he said “In them too” .

original: vuttaṃ. Catunnampi hi saccānaṃ visesena dassanato maggapaññā sātisayaṃ “vipassanā”ti🔽vattabbā, taṃsamaṅgī ca ariyo vipassanakoti.🔽Sappurisānaṃ dhammāti sappurisānaṃyeva dhammā, na asappurisānaṃ. Dhammānudhammapaṭipattiyā
analyzed: vuttam catunnam api hi saccānam visesena dassanataḥ magga paññā sa atisayam vipassanā ti  vattabbā tad samaṅgī ca ariyaḥ vipassanakaḥ ti  sappurisānam dhammā ati sappurisānam yeva dhammāḥ na asappurisānam dhamma anudhamma paṭipattiyā
translated: For it is the path understanding that should be called “insight” in the sense of seeing in particular the four truths, and the noble one who possesses it is one who has insight.🔽The states of true men: the states of only true men, not of untrue men.🔽For it is only by practice in conformity with the states of true men that one becomes a knower of the states of true men, and so on, not by mere recitation of the texts.

original: eva hi dhammaññuādibhāvo, na pāḷidhammapaṭhanādimattena. Bhāsitassāti suttageyyādibhāsitassa
analyzed: eva hi dhammaññu ādi bhāvaḥ na pāḷi dhamma paṭhana ādi mattena bhāsitassa ati sutta geyya ādi bhāsitassa
translated: The teaching: the teaching in the form of the discourses, mixed prose and verse, etc.

original: ceva tadaññassa ca attatthaparatthabodhakassa padassa. Atthakusalatāvasena atthaṃ
analyzed: ca iva tad aññassa ca atta ttha para attha bodhakassa padassa attha kusala tā vasena attham
translated: and also of other words that express one’s own and others’ welfare. He knows the meaning by means of skill in the meaning.

original: jānātīti atthaññū. Attānaṃ jānātīti yāthāvato attano pamāṇajānanavasena attānaṃ jānāti.
analyzed: jānāti iti atthaññū attānam jānāti iti yāthāvataḥ attano pamāṇa jānana vasena attānam jānāti
translated: He knows the self by means of knowing the self’s measure as it actually is.

original: Paṭiggahaṇaparibhogamattaññutāhi eva pariyesanavissajjanamattaññutāpi bodhitā hontīti
analyzed: paṭiggahaṇa paribhoga mattaññu tāhi eva pariyesana vissajjana mattaññu tā api bodhitāḥ honti iti
translated: And by knowing the mere acceptance and mere enjoyment, he is also understood to know the mere seeking and the mere giving up.

original: “paṭiggahaṇaparibhogesu” icceva vuttaṃ. Evañhi tā anavajjā hontīti. Yogassa adhigamāyāti
analyzed: paṭiggahaṇa paribhogesu icca eva vuttam evam hi tāḥ anavajjāḥ honti iti yogassa adhigamāya ati
translated: So only “in the case of acceptance and enjoyment” is said. For in this way they are blameless.🔽For one who is devoted to development: for one who is devoted to development by means of meditation.

original: bhāvanāya anuyuñjanassa. Atisambādhanti atikhuddakaṃ atikkhapaññassa tāvatā kālena🔽tīretuṃ asakkuṇeyyattā. Aṭṭhavidhaṃ parisanti khattiyaparisādikaṃ aṭṭhavidhaṃ parisaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvanāya anuyuñjanassa ati sambādhanti ati khuddakam ati khapaññassa tāvatā kālena  tīretum a sakkuṇeyya ttāḥ aṭṭhavidham parisanti khattiya parisādikam aṭṭhavidham parisam
translated: Too confined: too small. Because one who is very wise cannot cross over it in that time.🔽The eightfold assembly: the eightfold assembly beginning with the assembly of nobles.

original: Bhikkhuparisādikaṃ catubbidhaṃ khattiyaparisādikaṃ manussaparisaṃyeva puna catubbidhaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu parisādikam catubbidham khattiya parisādikam manussa parisam yā iva puna catubbidham
translated: Others take the fourfold assembly beginning with the assembly of bhikkhus and the fourfold assembly beginning with the assembly of nobles and add them together to make an eightfold assembly.

original: gahetvā aṭṭhavidhaṃ vadanti apare. “Imaṃ me sevantassa akusalā dhammā parihāyanti,
analyzed: gahetvā aṭṭhavidham vadanti apare imam me sevantassa akusalāḥ dhammāḥ parihāyanti
translated: “When I serve this, unwholesome states diminish in me and wholesome states increase;

original: kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, tasmā sevitabbo, vipariyāyato tadañño asevitabbo”ti
analyzed: kusalāḥ dhammāḥ abhivaḍḍhanti tasmā sevitabbaḥ vipariyāyataḥ tad aññaḥ a sevitabbaḥ ti
translated: and unwholesome states decline. Therefore he should be cultivated. The opposite of this is the person who should not be cultivated.”

original: evaṃ sevitabbāsevitabbaṃ puggalaṃ jānātīti puggalaññū. Evaṃ tesaṃ puggalānampi bodhanaṃ
analyzed: evam sevitabba asevitabbam puggalam jānāti iti puggalaññū evam tesam puggalānam pi bodhanam
translated: So he knows the person who should be cultivated and the person who should not be cultivated.

original: ukkaṭṭhaṃ, nihīnaṃ vā jānāti nāma.
analyzed: ukkaṭṭham nihīnam vā jānāti nāma
translated: He knows the person who is superior and the person who is inferior.

original: 331. “Niddasavatthūnī”ti. “Ādi-saddalopenāyaṃ niddeso”ti āha “niddasādivatthūnī”ti.
analyzed: niddasa vatthūni iti ādi sadda lopena ayam niddeso ti āha niddasa ādi vatthūni iti
translated: “The questions that have an end”: the word “end” is used here in the sense of “having an end,” the word “end” being dropped, as in the expression “a rice-field having an end” .

original: Natthi dāni imassa dasāti niddaso. Pañhoti ñātuṃ icchito attho. Puna dasavasso na🔽hotīti tesaṃ matimattanti dassetuṃ “so kirā”ti kirasaddaggahaṇaṃ. “Niddaso”ti cetaṃ
analyzed: natthi dāni imassa dasa ati niddasaḥ pañhaḥ ti ñātum icchitaḥ attho puna dasa vassaḥ na  hoti iti tesam matimatta nti dassetum saḥ kirāti ca itaṃ
translated: He has no more to learn, thus he is “one who has ended” . A question is a matter that is wished to be known. He is not one who has ten years’ standing, thus he is “not one who has ten years’ standing” .🔽In order to show that he is a wise man, the expression “it is said” is used.

original: desanāmattaṃ, tassa nibbīsādibhāvassa viya ninnavādibhāvassa ca icchitattāti dassetuṃ
analyzed: desanā mattam tassa nibbīsa ādi bhāvassa viya ninnava ādi bhāvassa ca icchita ttā ati dassetuṃ
translated: The expression “one who has ended” is merely a statement; for it is wished that he should be one who has gone to the end, etc., like one who has gone to the end of his life, and so on.🔽In order to show this, the expression “not only” is used.

original: “na kevalañcā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Gāme vicarantoti gāme piṇḍāya vicaranto.🔽Na idaṃ titthiyānaṃ adhivacanaṃ tesu tannimittassa abhāvā. Sāsanepi sekkhassāpi na
analyzed: na kevalam ca atiādi vuttam gāme vicaranto ti gāme piṇḍāya vicaranto 🔽na idam titthiyānam adhivacanam tesu tad nimittassa abhāvā sāsane pi sekkhassa api na
translated: He goes about in the village means he goes about in the village for alms.

original: idaṃ adhivacanaṃ, kimaṅgaṃ pana puthujjanassa. Yassa panetaṃ adhivacanaṃ, yena ca🔽kāraṇena, taṃ dassetuṃ “khīṇāsavasseta”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Appaṭisandhikabhāvo hissa paccakkhato🔽kāraṇaṃ. Paramparāya itarāni, yāni pāḷiyaṃ āgatāni.🔽Sikkhāya sammadeva ādānaṃ sikkhāsamādānaṃ, taṃ panassā pāripūriyā veditabbanti āha
analyzed: idam adhivacanam kimaṅgam pana puthujjanassa yassa pana itam adhivacanam yena ca  kāraṇena tam dassetum khīṇāsavassa itaṃ tiādi vuttam appaṭisandhika bhāvaḥ hissa paccakkhataḥ  kāraṇam paramparāyaḥ itarāni yāni pāḷiyam āgatāni  sikkhāya sammadeva ādānam sikkhā samādānam tat panassā pāripūriyā veditabbanti āha
translated: and so on. What need be said then about the ordinary man? But in order to show what the word “arahant” signifies and the reason for its use, the following passage is given: “The one whose cankers are destroyed” . For the fact of his not taking up a new becoming is the reason for his being called an “arahant” in the direct sense of the word. The other reasons given in the text are indirect reasons.🔽The “taking up of the training” is the proper undertaking of the training. It should be understood that this is fulfilled by the perfection of the training.

original: “sikkhattayapūraṇe”ti. Sikkhāya vā sammadeva ādito paṭṭhāya rakkhaṇaṃ sikkhāsamādānaṃ,
analyzed: sikkhattaya pūraṇā iti sikkhāya vā sammadeva āditas paṭṭhāya rakkhaṇam sikkhā samādānam
translated: and this is a designation for the noble person, so how much more so for the ordinary man? But in order to show what this designation is and the reason for it, it is said, “For one whose cankers are destroyed” . For his non- reappearance is the reason in the direct sense. The others are the reason in the indirect sense, which are given in the texts. The undertaking of training is the proper undertaking of the training. It should be understood that that is fulfilled by his perfecting it. Hence he said “in fulfilling the three trainings” . Or alternatively, the undertaking of training is the proper guarding of the training from the beginning,

original: tañca atthato pūraṇe paricchinnaṃ arakkhaṇe sabbena sabbaṃ abhāvato, rakkhaṇe ca🔽paripūraṇato. Bahalacchandoti daḷhacchando. Āyatinti anantarānāgatadivasādikālo adhippeto,
analyzed: tat ca atthataḥ pūraṇe paricchinnam arakkhaṇe sabbena sabbam abhāvato rakkhaṇe ca  paripūraṇataḥ bahala chando ti daḷha chando anantara anāgata divasa ādi kālaḥ adhippeto
translated: and that is defined as fulfilled by its being perfected in the sense of being guarded, and as not fulfilled in the sense of not being guarded, because of the absence of all of it.

original: na anāgatabhavoti āha “anāgate punadivasādīsupī”ti. Sikkhaṃ paripūrentassa tattha
analyzed: na anāgata bhavaḥ ti āha anāgate punadivasa ādīsu pi iti sikkham paripūrentassa tattha
translated: He has great desire: he has strong desire. Future: the future time consisting of the next day, etc., is intended, not the future state of existence. Hence he said “in the future, on the next day, etc., too” . For one who is perfecting the training,

original: niviṭṭhaatthitā avigatapematā, tebhūmakadhammānaṃ aniccādivasena sammadeva nijjhānaṃ
analyzed: niviṭṭha atthi tā avigata pema tā tebhūmaka dhammānam anicca ādi vasena sammad eva nijjhānam
translated: The meaning of “established” is non-abandonment of desire for the attainment of the goal. The meaning of “contemplation” is the proper contemplation of the states of the three planes as impermanent, etc.

original: dhammanisāmanāti āha “vipassanāyetaṃ adhivacana”nti. Taṇhāvinayaneti virāgānupassanādivipassanāñāṇānubhāvasiddhe
analyzed: dhamma nisāmanā iti āha vipassanāya etam adhivacanam ti taṇhā vinayanā iti virāga anupassanā ādi vipassanā ñāṇa anubhāva siddhe
translated: The meaning of “penetration of ideas” is insight. The meaning of “penetration of craving” is the suppression of craving by the power of the knowledge of insight consisting in contemplation of dispassion, etc.

original: taṇhāvikkhambhane. Ekībhāveti gaṇasaṅgaṇikākilesasaṅgaṇikāvigamasiddhe vivekabhāve.
analyzed: taṇhā vikkhambhane ekībhāve iti gaṇa saṅgaṇikā kilesa saṅgaṇikā vigama siddhe viveka bhāve
translated: The meaning of “unification” is the state of solitude accomplished by the abandonment of the defilements of socializing and of companionship.

original: Vīriyārambheti sammappadhānavīriyassa paggaṇhane, taṃ pana sabbaso vīriyassa paribrūhanaṃ
analyzed: vīriya ārambhe ti sammappadhāna vīriyassa paggaṇhane tam pana sabbasas vīriyassa paribrūhanam
translated: The meaning of “rousing of energy” is the exertion of right effort. But that is the complete arousing of energy,

original: hotīti āha “kāyikacetasikassa vīriyassa pūraṇe”ti. Satiyañceva nepakkabhāve cāti🔽satokāritāya ceva sampajānakāritāya ca. Satisampajaññabaleneva vīriyārambho ijjhati.
analyzed: hoti iti āha kāyika cetasikassa vīriyassa pūraṇā iti satiyam ca iva nepakka bhāve ca ati  satokāritāya ca iva sampajāna kāritāya ca sati sampajañña balena iva vīriya ārambhaḥ ijjhati
translated: so he said: “in the fulfilment of bodily and mental energy.” The meaning of “mindfulness” and “full awareness” is🔽the function of mindfulness and the function of full awareness. It is only when energy is aroused by the power of mindfulness and full awareness that the function of mindfulness and the function of full awareness are fulfilled.

original: Diṭṭhipaṭivedheti sammādiṭṭhiyā paṭivijjhane. Tenāha “maggadassane”ti. Saccasampaṭivedhe
analyzed: diṭṭhi paṭivedhe iti sammādiṭṭhiyā paṭivijjhane tena āha magga dassane iti sacca sampaṭivedhe
translated: The meaning of “penetration of views” is the penetration of the four noble truths by right view.

original: hi ijjhamāne maggasammādiṭṭhi siddhā eva hoti.
analyzed: hi ijjhamāne magga sammādiṭṭhi siddhā eva hoti
translated: For when penetration of the truths succeeds, right view is already accomplished.

original: Asubhānupassanāñāṇeti dasavidhassa, ekādasavidhassāpi vā asubhassa anupassanāvasena🔽pavattañāṇe. Idañhi dukkhānupassanāya paricayañāṇaṃ. Ādīnavānupassanāñāṇeti saṅkhārānaṃ
analyzed: asubha anupassanā ñāṇā iti dasavidhassa ekādasavidhassa api vā asubhassa anupassanā vasena  pavatta ñāṇe idam hi dukkha anupassanāya paricaya ñāṇam ādīnava anupassanā ñāṇā iti saṅkhārānam
translated: Knowledge of contemplation of foulness: knowledge occurring as the contemplation of the ten kinds of foulness or of the eleven kinds of foulness. For this is the knowledge of familiarizing with contemplation of suffering.

original: aniccadukkhavipariṇāmatāsaṃsūcitassa ādīnavassa anupassanāvasena pavattañāṇe. Appahīnaṭṭhenāti🔽maggena asamucchinnabhāvena. Anusentīti santāne anu anu sayanti. Kāraṇalābhe hi sati
analyzed: anicca dukkha vipariṇāma tā saṃsūcitassa ādīnavassa anupassanā vasena pavatta ñāṇe a pahīna ṭṭhena ati  maggena asamucchinna bhāvena anusenti iti santāne anu anu sayanti kāraṇa lābhe hi sati
translated: Knowledge of contemplation of danger: knowledge occurring as the contemplation of the danger that is indicated by impermanence, suffering, and change in the formed.🔽Not yet abandoned: not yet cut off by the path.

original: uppannārahā kilesā santāne anu anu sayitā viya honti, tasmā te tadavatthā “anusayā”ti🔽vuccanti. Thāmagatoti thāmappatto. Thāmagamanañca aññehi asādhāraṇo kāmarāgādīnameva
analyzed: uppanna arahā kilesā santāne anu anu viya honti tasmā te tad avatthāḥ  vuccanti thāma gataḥ ti thāma ppatto thāma gamanam ca aññehi asādhāraṇaḥ kāma rāga ādīnam eva
translated: They lie latent: they lie in the continuity, in the stream. For when a cause is obtained, defilements that are capable of arising lie in the continuity as if they were lying down. Therefore they are called “latent tendencies” in that state.

original: āveṇiko sabhāvo daṭṭhabbo. Tathā hi vuttaṃ abhidhamme “thāmagatānusayaṃ pajahatī”ti.
analyzed: āveṇikaḥ sabhāvaḥ daṭṭhabbo tathā hi vuttam abhidhamme thāma gata anusayam pajahati iti
translated: They have reached the state of lying latent: they have reached the state of lying latent. And the state of lying latent should be regarded as the individual essence of lust, etc., which is not shared by others. For it is said in the Abhidhamma: “He abandons the latent tendency that has reached the state of lying latent” .

original: Kāmarāgo eva anusayo kāmarāgānusayo. Ye pana “kāmarāgassa anusayo kāmarāgānusayo”ti
analyzed: kāma rāgaḥ eva anusayaḥ kāma rāga anusayaḥ ye pana kāma rāgassa anusayaḥ kāma rāga anusayaḥ ti
translated: Lust is a latent tendency, thus it is the lust-tendency . But some say that it is the latent tendency of lust, thus it is the lust-tendency .

original: vadanti, taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ. Na hi kāmarāgavinimutto kāmarāgānusayo nāma koci atthi.
analyzed: vadanti tam tesam matimattam na hi kāma rāga vinimuttaḥ kāma rāga anusayaḥ nāma koci atthi
translated: They are only their opinion. For there is no such thing as a ‘underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires’ that is unmixed with lust for sensual desires.

original: Yadi “tassa bīja”nti vadeyyuṃ, tampi tabbinimuttaṃ paramatthato na upalabbhatevāti.
analyzed: yadi tassa bījam ti vadeyyum tam pi tad vinimuttam paramatthataḥ na upalabbhate iva ati
translated: If they were to say that it is the seed, that too, being unmixed with it, is not found in the ultimate sense.

original: Eseva nayo sesesupi.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ sesesupi
translated: The same method applies in the other cases.

original: Adhikaraṇasamathasattakavaṇṇanā
translated: The seven kinds of grounds for a legal issue

original: Adhikarīyanti etthāti adhikaraṇāni. Ke adhikarīyanti? Samathā. Kathaṃ adhikarīyantīti?
analyzed: adhikarīyanti etthā ati adhikaraṇāni ke adhikarīyanti samathā katham adhikarīyanti iti
translated: Legal issues are what are dealt with here. What deals with them? The settling. How does it deal with them?

original: Samanavasena, tasmā te tesaṃ samanavasena pavattantīti āha “adhikaraṇāni samentī”tiādi.
analyzed: samana vasena tasmā te tesam samana vasena pavattanti iti āha adhikaraṇāni samenti itiādi
translated: By means of the settling, therefore it is said that they are settled by means of the settling.

original: Uppannānaṃ uppannānanti uṭṭhitānaṃ uṭṭhitānaṃ. Samathatthanti samanatthaṃ.
analyzed: uppannānam uppannānanti uṭṭhitānam uṭṭhitānam samathattham iti samanattham
translated: Arisen with arisen: with those that have arisen. For the sake of settling: for the sake of settling them.

original: “Aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhī”ti lakkhaṇavacanametaṃ yathā “yadi me byādhī dāheyyuṃ dātabbamidamosadha”nti,
analyzed: aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi iti lakkhaṇa vacanam etam yathā yadi me byādhī dāheyyum dātabbam idam osadhanti
translated: The eighteen bases: this is a defining clause, like the clause “If my illness were to get worse, this medicine should be given to me” .

original: tasmā tesu aññataraññatarena vivadantā “aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi vivadantī”ti vuccanti.
analyzed: tasmā tesu aññatara ññatarena vivadantā aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi vivadanti iti vuccanti
translated: Therefore those who dispute about any one of them are said to “dispute about the eighteen bases.”

original: Upavadanāti akkoso. Codanāti anuyogo.
analyzed: upavadanā ati akkosaḥ codanā ati anuyogaḥ
translated: Abuse: reviling. Charge: accusation.

original: Adhikaraṇassa sammukhāva vinayanato sammukhāvinayo. Sannipatitaparisāya dhammavādīnaṃ🔽yebhuyyatāya yebhuyyasikakammassa karaṇaṃ yebhuyyasikā. Ayanti ayaṃ yathāvuttā catubbidhā
analyzed: adhikaraṇassa vinayanato sammukha avinayaḥ sannipatita parisāya dhamma vādīnam  yebhuyyatāya yebhuyyasika kammassa karaṇam yebhuyyasikāḥ ayanti ayam yathāvuttā catubbidhā
translated: Because of the carrying out of the majority decision by the greater number of those who speak in accordance with the Dhamma in an assembly that has met together, there is a majority decision.

original: sammukhatā sammukhāvinayo nāma.
analyzed: sammukha tā sammukhāvinayaḥ nāma
translated: This is called a face-to-face meeting, which is of four kinds as stated.

original: Saṅghasāmaggivasena sammukhībhāvo, na yathā tathā kārakapuggalānaṃ sammukhātā. Bhūtatāti🔽tacchatā. Saccapariyāyo hi idha dhamma-saddo “dhammavādī”tiādīsu viya. Vineti etenāti
analyzed: saṅgha sāmaggi vasena sammukhībhāvaḥ na yathā tathā kāraka puggalānam bhūta tā ati  tad śatā sacca pariyāyaḥ hi idha dhamma saddo dhamma vādī iti ādīsu viya vinā iti etena ati
translated: The presence face-to-face of the unity of the Sangha, not the presence face-to-face of the persons who do the act in any way whatsoever.🔽The truth is the reality.🔽For the word “Dhamma” here is in the sense of truth, as in the passages beginning, “One who speaks in accordance with the Dhamma” .

original: vinayo, tassa tassa adhikaraṇassa vūpasamanāya bhagavatā vuttavidhi, tassa vinayassa
analyzed: vinayaḥ tassa tassa adhikaraṇassa vūpasamanāya bhagavatā vutta vidhi tassa vinayassa
translated: It is a settling by means of that, thus it is a settlement . It is the method stated by the Blessed One for the quieting of this or that legal issue.🔽The presence face-to-face of that settlement is the face-to-face meeting of the settlement.🔽Hence it is said, “The presence face-to-face of the persons who do the act in any way whatsoever” .

original: sammukhatā vinayasammukhatā. Tenāha “yathā taṃ…pe… sammukhatā”ti. Yenāti yena puggalena.
analyzed: sammukha tā vinaya sammukha tā tena āha yathā taṃpe sammukha tā ati yena ati yena puggalena
translated: By means of which: by means of which person.🔽The opponents of the matter called the ground for a legal issue are opponents of the matter.

original: Vivādavatthusaṅkhāte atthe paccatthikā atthapaccatthikā. Saṅghasammukhatā parihāyati
analyzed: vivāda vatthu saṅkhāte atthe paccatthikā attha paccatthikā saṅgha sammukha tā parihāyati
translated: The face-to-face meeting of the Sangha is absent

original: sammatapuggaleheva vūpasamanato.
analyzed: sammata puggalehi iva vūpasamanataḥ
translated: because of the quieting by only the persons agreed upon.

original: Nanti vivādādhikaraṇaṃ. “Na chandāgatiṃ gacchatī”tiādinā vuttaṃ pañcaṅgasamannāgataṃ.
analyzed: vivāda adhikaraṇam na chanda āgatim gacchati iti ādinā vuttam pañcaṅga samannāgatam
translated: “Dispute” is a legal issue arising from a dispute. “He does not side with those who side with one of the parties” is the five-factored impartiality.

original: Guḷhakādīsu alajjussannāya parisāya guḷhako salākaggāho kātabbo lajjussannāya vivaṭako,
analyzed: guḷhaka ādīsu a lajju ssannāya parisāya guḷhakaḥ salāka ggāhaḥ kātabbaḥ lajju ssannāya vivaṭakaḥ
translated: In the case of a vote by means of a token in a closed fist, the token should be cast in a closed fist if the assembly is shameless. It should be cast openly if the assembly is shameless.

original: bālussannāya sakaṇṇajappako. Yassā kiriyāya dhammavādino bahutarā, sā yebhuyyasikāti
analyzed: yassa kiriyāya dhamma vādinaḥ bahutarā sā yebhuyyasikā ati
translated: It should be cast by whispering in the ear if the assembly is ignorant. The majority decision is the decision in favor of the one who has the greater number of votes.

original: āha “dhammavādīnaṃ yebhuyyatāyā”tiādi.
analyzed: āha dhamma vādīnam yebhuyyatāya atiādi
translated: “By a majority of the regular monks” is said.

original: “Catūhi samathehi sammatī”ti idaṃ sabbasaṅgāhikavasena vuttaṃ. Tattha pana dvīhi
analyzed: catūhi samathehi sammatī ti idam sabba saṅgāhika vasena vuttam tattha pana dvīhi
translated: “It is settled by means of the four settlements” is said in terms of all together. But it should be seen that it is settled by means of two and two.

original: dvīhi eva vūpasamanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Evaṃ vinicchitanti sace āpatti natthi, ubho khamāpetvā,
analyzed: dvīhi eva vūpasamanam daṭṭhabbam evam vinicchitanti sace āpatti natthi ubho khamāpetvā
translated: “It is decided like this”: if there is no offense, after having had them both ask for forgiveness,

original: atha atthi, āpattiṃ dassetvā ropanavasena vinicchitaṃ. Paṭikammaṃ pana āpattādhikaraṇasamathe parato āgamissati.
analyzed: atha atthi āpattim dassetvā ropana vasena vinicchitam paṭikammam pana āpatta adhikaraṇa samathe paratas āgamissati
translated: if there is an offense, after having pointed out the offense, it is decided by means of covering over as if with grass. But the covering over as if with grass will come later in the settlement of legal issues arising from an offense.

original: Na samaṇasāruppaṃ assāmaṇakaṃ, samaṇehi akattabbaṃ, tasmiṃ. Ajjhācāre vītikkame sati.
analyzed: na samaṇa sāruppam a ssāmaṇakam samaṇehi a kattabbam tasmin ajjhācāre vītikkame sati
translated: “Not proper for a monastic, not a monastic act, not to be done by a monastic” in regard to that. If there is a transgression in the instruction.

original: Paṭicaratoti paṭicchādentassa. Pāpussannatāya pāpiyo, puggalo, tassa kattabbakammaṃ🔽tassa pāpiyasikaṃ. Sammukhāvinayeneva vūpasamo natthi paṭiññāya tathārūpāya, khantiyā
analyzed: paṭicarato ti paṭicchādentassa pāpussanna tāya pāpiyaḥ puggalo tassa kattabba kammaṃ  tassa pāpiyasikam sammukha avinayena iva vūpasamaḥ natthi paṭiññāya tathārūpāya khantiyā
translated: The offense is worse: the person is worse. The action to be done for him

original: vā vinā avūpasamanato.
analyzed: vā vinā
translated: is worse. There is no settlement by resolution face-to-face without admission or consent.

original: Etthāti āpattidesanāya. Paṭiññāte āpannabhāvādike karaṇaṃ kiriyā “āyatiṃ saṃvareyyāsī”ti, parivāsadānādivasena ca pavattaṃ vacīkammaṃ paṭiññātakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: ettha ati āpatti desanāya paṭiññāte āpanna bhāva ādike karaṇam kiriyā āyatim saṃvareyyāsi iti parivāsa dāna ādi vasena ca pavattam vacī kammam paṭiññāta karaṇam
translated: Here: in the acknowledgment of an offense. The action of acknowledgment is the action of speech that occurs by way of giving probation, etc., after the admitted facts of the offense, etc., have been acknowledged.

original: Yathānurūpanti “dvīhi samathehi catūhi tīhi ekenā”ti evaṃ vuttanayena yathānurūpaṃ.
analyzed: yathānurūpam ti dvīhi samathehi catūhi tīhi ekena ati evam vutta nayena yathānurūpam
translated: As appropriate: in the way stated thus, “By two, by four, by three, by one.”

original: Etthāti imasmiṃ sutte, imasmiṃ vā samathavicāre. Vinicchayanayoti vinicchaye nayamattaṃ.
analyzed: ettha ati imasmin sutte imasmin vā samatha vicāre vinicchaya nayoti vinicchaye naya mattam
translated: Here: in this sutta, or in this investigation of settlement. The method of the legal procedure: just the method in the legal procedure.

original: Tenāha “vitthāro panā”tiādi. Samantapāsādikāyaṃ vinayaṭṭhakathāya vutto, tasmā vuttanayeneva
analyzed: tena āha vitthāraḥ pana atiādi samantapāsādikāyam vinaya ṭṭhakathāya vutto tasmā vutta nayena iva
translated: Therefore he says, “The details,” etc. It is stated in the commentary on the Monastic Law, the Samantapāsādikā. Therefore

original: veditabboti adhippāyo.🔽Sattakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ iti adhippāyaḥ  sattaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: it should be understood in the way stated there.🔽The explanation of the seven is finished.

original: Niṭṭhitā ca dutiyabhāṇavāravaṇṇanā.
analyzed: niṭṭhitā ca dutiya bhāṇa vāra vaṇṇanā
translated: And the explanation of the second recitation section is finished.

original: Aṭṭhakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aṭṭhaka vaṇṇanā
translated: Commentary on the Verses

original: 333. Ayāthāvāti na yāthāvā. Aniyyānikatāya micchāsabhāvā. Viparītavuttikatāya yāthāvā. Niyyānikatāya sammāsabhāvā aviparītavuttikā.🔽334. Kucchitaṃ sīdatīti kusīto da-kārassa ta-kāraṃ katvā. Yassa dhammassa vasena🔽puggalo “kusīto”ti vuccati, so kusītabhāvo idha kusīta-saddena vutto. Vināpi hi bhāvajotanaṃ🔽saddaṃ bhāvattho viññāyati yathā “paṭassa sukka”nti, tasmā kusītabhāvavatthūnīti🔽attho. Tenāha “kosajjakāraṇānīti attho”ti. Kammaṃ nāma samaṇasāruppaṃ īdisanti āha
analyzed: ayāthāvā ati na yāthāvā a niyyānika tāya micchā sabhāvā viparīta vuttika tāya yāthāvā niyyānika tāya sammāsabhāvā aviparīta vuttikā  kucchitam sīdati iti kusītaḥ dakārassa takāram katvā yassa dhammassa vasena  puggalo kusīto ti vuccati saḥ kusīta bhāvaḥ idha kusīta saddena vuttaḥ vinā api hi bhāva jotanam  saddam bhāva tthaḥ viññāyati yathā paṭassa tasmā kusīta bhāva vatthūni iti  tena āha kosajja kāraṇāni iti attho ti kammam nāma samaṇa sāruppam īdisanti āha
translated: Not as it is: not as it is in reality. Because of not being in conformity with the path, it is wrong. Because of being in conformity with the path, it is as it is in reality. Because of being in conformity with the path, it is right. Because of not being in conformity with the path, it is wrong.

original: “cīvaravicāraṇādī”ti. Vīriyanti padhānavīriyaṃ, taṃ pana caṅkamanavasena karaṇe “kāyika”ntipi🔽vattabbataṃ labhatīti āha “duvidhampī”ti. Pattiyāti pāpuṇanatthaṃ. Osīdananti bhāvanānuyoge
