original: saṅkoco. Māsehi ācitaṃ nicitaṃ viyāti māsācitaṃ, taṃ maññe. Yasmā māsā tintāvisesena
analyzed: saṅkocaḥ māsehi ācitam nicitam viyāti māsa ācitam tam maññe yasmā māsā tintā visesena
translated: “Shrinking” means shrinking back. “Accumulated by months” is what is meant by “accumulated in months” . Because the months are heavy with the special dyeing,

original: garukā honti, tasmā “yathā tintamāso”tiādi vuttaṃ. Vuṭṭhito hoti gilānabhāvāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: garukāḥ honti tasmā yathā tintamāso tiādi vuttam vuṭṭhitaḥ hoti gilāna bhāvā ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: therefore it is said, “like a dyed month.” The intention is that he has recovered from his sick state.

original: 335. Tesanti ārambhavatthūnaṃ. Imināva nayenāti iminā kusītavatthūsu vutteneva nayena.
analyzed: tesam ti ārambha vatthūnam iminā ava nayena ati iminā kusīta vatthūsu vuttena iva nayena
translated: “These” : the bases for the launching of energy. “In this way” : in the way stated in the case of the grounds for sloth.

original: “Duvidhampi vīriyaṃ ārabhatī”tiādinā, “idaṃ paṭhamanti idaṃ handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmīti🔽evaṃ bhāvanāya abbhussahanaṃ paṭhamaṃ ārambhavatthū”tiādinā ca attho veditabbo. Yathā🔽tathā paṭhamaṃ pavattaṃ abbhussahanañhi upari vīriyārambhassa kāraṇaṃ hoti. Anurūpapaccavekkhaṇāsahitāni
analyzed: duvidham pi vīriyam ārabhati itiādinā idam idam handa aham vīriyam ārabhāmi iti  evam bhāvanāya abbhussahanam paṭhamam ca atthaḥ veditabbaḥ yathā  tathā paṭhamam pavattam abbhussahanam hi upari vīriya ārambhassa kāraṇam hoti anurūpa paccavekkhaṇā sahitāni
translated: “He launches twofold energy” , and so on. The meaning should be understood in this way: “This is the first. Now I will launch energy.”🔽The first launching is the first base for launching energy.

original: hi abbhussahanāni, tammūlakāni vā paccavekkhaṇāni aṭṭha ārambhavatthūni veditabbāni.
analyzed: hi abbhussahanāni tammūlakāni vā paccavekkhaṇāni aṭṭha ārambha vatthūni veditabbāni
translated: The launching that occurs first in any way is the cause for the launching of energy afterwards. The eight bases for launching energy should be understood as the launchings accompanied by the appropriate kinds of reflection or as the reflections rooted in those launchings.

original: 336. Āsajjāti yassa deti, tassa āmodanahetu tena samāgamanimittaṃ. Tenāha “ettha🔽āsādanaṃ dānakāraṇaṃ nāmā”ti. Bhayāti bhayahetu. Nanu bhayaṃ nāma laddhukāmatā rāgādayo🔽viya cetanāya avisuddhikaraṃ, taṃ kasmā idha gahitanti? Na idaṃ tādisaṃ corabhayādiṃ🔽sandhāya vuttanti dassetuṃ “tatthā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Adāsi meti yaṃ pubbe kataṃ upakāraṃ🔽cintetvā dīyati, taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Dassati meti paccupakārāsīsāya yaṃ dīyati,
analyzed: āsajjāti yassa deti tassa āmodana hetu tena samāgama nimittam tena āha ettha  āsādanam dāna kāraṇam nāma ati bhaya ati bhaya hetu nanu bhayam nāma laddhu kāma tā rāga ādayaḥ  cetanāya a visuddhi karam tam kasmai idha naḥ idam tādisam  sandhāya vuttanti dassetum tattha atiādi vuttam adāsi mā iti yam pubbe katam upakāram  cintetvā dīyati tam sandhāya vuttam dassati mā iti paccupakāra āsīsāya yam dīyati
translated: “Hope” is the reason for giving in order to get something in return. Hence it is said: “The reason for giving is the hope of getting something in return.” “Fear” is the reason for giving out of fear. But is not fear a corruption of the will, like greed, etc., that leads to the wish to get something? Why then is it mentioned here? It is not mentioned as such. It is mentioned with reference to the fear of thieves, etc. “He gave to me” is said with reference to the giving that is done in consideration of a past service.

original: taṃ sandhāya vadati. Sāhu dānanti “dānaṃ nāmetaṃ paṇḍitapaññatta”nti sādhusamācāre🔽ṭhatvā deti. Alaṅkāratthanti upasobhanatthaṃ. Parivāratthanti parikkhāratthaṃ. Dānañhi🔽datvā taṃ paccavekkhantassa pāmojjapītisomanassādayo uppajjanti, lobhadosaissāmaccherādayo
analyzed: tam sandhāya vadati sāhu dānam ti dānam nāma etam paṇḍita paññattam ti sādhu samācāre 🔽ṭhatvā deti alaṅkāra tthanti upasobhana tthanti parivāra tthanti parikkhāra tthanti dānañhi 🔽tam paccavekkhantassa pāmojja pīti somanassa ādayaḥ uppajjanti
translated: 1. “Hope” is the reason for giving to one who gives in the hope of getting something in return. Hence it is said: “The reason for giving is the hope of getting something in return.” 2. “Fear” is the reason for giving out of fear. But is not fear a form of desire, a corruption of the will, like greed? Why then is it mentioned here? It is not mentioned as a form of desire. It is mentioned as fear of thieves, etc. To show this, the commentator says: “Herein, fear is the reason for giving out of fear of thieves, kings, etc.” 3. “Because he did for me” is said with reference to one who gives in return for a service already rendered. 4. “He will do for me” is said with reference to one who gives in the hope of getting something in return. 5. “It is the right thing to do” is said with reference to one who gives, thinking: “This is not the way to behave for a wise man.” 6. “For the sake of adornment” is said with reference to one who gives in order to adorn himself. 7. “For the sake of a retinue” is said with reference to one who gives in order to get a retinue. For when a man gives a gift, he is elated and gladdened by the joy of generosity. Greed, hatred, envy, and avarice are abandoned in him.

original: vidūrī bhavanti. Idāni dānaṃ anukūladhammaparibrūhanena, paccanīkadhammavidūrībhāvakaraṇena
analyzed: vidūrī bhavanti idāni dānam anukūla dhamma paribrūhanena paccanīka dhamma vidūrībhāva karaṇena
translated: Now, giving is for the adorning and the equipment of the mind’s development by increasing the qualities that are in conformity with it and by keeping far away the qualities that are not in conformity with it.

original: ca bhāvanācittassa upasobhanāya ca parikkhārāya ca hotīti “alaṅkāratthaṃ, parivāratthañca🔽detī”ti vuttaṃ. Tenāha “dānañhi cittaṃ mudukaṃ karotī”tiādi. Muducitto hoti laddhā
analyzed: ca bhāvanā cittassa upasobhanāya ca parikkhārāya ca hoti iti alaṅkāra attham parivāra attham ca  deti iti vuttam tena āha dānam hi cittam mudukam karoti itiādi mudu cittaḥ hoti laddhā
translated: So it is said that it is “for the sake of adornment and equipment.”

original: dāyake “iminā mayhaṃ saṅgaho kato”ti, dātāpi laddhari. Tena vuttaṃ “ubhinnampi cittaṃ mudukaṃ karotī”ti.
analyzed: dāyake iminā mayham saṅgaho kato ti dātā api laddhari tena vuttam ubhinnam api cittam mudukam karoti iti
translated: Hence it was said above: “Giving makes the mind pliant” . The giver becomes pliant of mind when he has given, thinking “I have helped him,” and the receiver becomes pliant of mind when he has received, thinking “He has helped me.” That is why it was said above: “It makes the minds of both pliant” .

original: Adantadamananti adantā anassavāpissa dānena dantā assavā honti vase vattanti. Adānaṃ
analyzed: adanta damananti adantāḥ anassava apissa dānena dantāḥ assavāḥ honti vase vattanti adānam
translated: “Taming the untamed”: the untamed, the disobedient, become tamed and obedient through giving.

original: dantadūsakanti adānaṃ pana pubbe dantānaṃ assavānampi vighātuppādanena cittaṃ dūseti.
analyzed: danta dūsakam ti adānam pana pubbe dantānam assavānam pi vighāta uppādanena cittam dūseti
translated: “Giving corrupts the tamed”: but non-giving corrupts the tamed by causing them to break their word.

original: Unnamanti dāyakā, piyaṃvadā ca paresaṃ garucittīkāraṭṭhānatāya. Namanti paṭiggāhakā
analyzed: unnamanti dāyakā piyaṃvadā ca paresam garu cittīkāra ṭṭhāna tāya namanti paṭiggāhakā
translated: “Givers are exalted”: givers are exalted because they are objects of affection and respect for others.

original: dānena, piyavācāya laddhasaṅgahā saṅgāhakānaṃ.
analyzed: dānena piya vācāya laddha saṅgahā saṅgāha kānam
translated: “Receivers bow down”: receivers bow down to givers because they are helped by the giving.🔽“The giver is the one who exalts himself” : the giver exalts himself by giving.🔽“The receiver is the one who bows down” : the receiver bows down by receiving.

original: Cittālaṅkāradānameva uttamaṃ anupakkiliṭṭhatāya, suparisuddhatāya, guṇavisesapaccayatāya ca.
analyzed: citta alaṅkāra dānam eva uttamam an upakkiliṭṭha tāya su parisuddha tāya guṇa visesa paccaya tāya ca
translated: The gift of mental adornment is the best because it is unadulterated, because it is quite pure, and because it is a condition for the special qualities.

original: 337. Dānapaccayāti dānakāraṇā, dānamayapuññassa katattā upacitattāti attho. Upapattiyoti
analyzed: dāna paccayā ti dāna kāraṇā dāna maya puññassa katattā upacita ttā ati atthaḥ upapattiyā ti
translated: “Condition for rebirth”:🔽for rebirth among human beings and gods.

original: manussesu, devesu ca nibbattiyo. Ṭhapetīti ekavārameva anuppajjitvā yathā uparūpari
analyzed: manussesu devesu ca nibbattiyaḥ ṭhapeti iti eka vāram eva an uppajjitvā yathā upari upari
translated: “Establishes”: having arisen once, it causes rebirth to occur again and again in that same mode.

original: tenevākārena pavattati, evaṃ ṭhapeti. Tadeva casa adhiṭṭhānanti āha “tasseva vevacana”nti.
analyzed: tena iva ākārena pavattati evam ṭhapeti tat eva āha tassa iva vevacanan ti
translated: “That is called a resolution”: he says, “It is a synonym for that.”🔽“It increases”: it is extended, not diminished.

original: Vaḍḍhetīti brūheti, na hāpeti. Vimuttanti adhimuttaṃ, ninnaṃ poṇaṃ pabbhāranti attho.
analyzed: vaḍḍheti iti brūha iti na hāpa iti vimuttanti adhimuttam ninnam poṇam pabbhāram ti attho
translated: “It is inclined to freedom”: it is bent on, inclined to, and directed to freedom.🔽“It is inclined to freedom”: it is distinguished.

original: Vimuttanti vā visiṭṭhaṃ. Nippariyāyato uttari nāma paṇītaṃ majjhepi hīnamajjhimavibhāgassa
analyzed: vimuttam ti vā visiṭṭham nippariyāyataḥ uttari nāma paṇītam majjhe pi hīna majjhima vibhāgassa
translated: “Not developed further”: what is called “higher” is excellent, and because the division into inferior and medium is possible even in the middle,

original: labbhanatoti vuttaṃ “uttari abhāvitanti tato upari maggaphalatthāya abhāvita”nti.
analyzed: labbhanato ti vuttam uttari abhāvitanti tatas upari magga phala atthāya abhāvitanti
translated: he says, “not developed further for the attainment of the higher path and fruit.”🔽“It leads to”: the mind of giving, thus dedicated, leads to.

original: Saṃvattati tathā paṇihitaṃ dānamayacittaṃ. Yaṃ pana pāḷiyaṃ “tañca kho”tiādi vuttaṃ,
analyzed: saṃvattati tathā paṇihitam dāna maya cittam yam pana pāḷiyam tat ca kho ti ādi vuttam
translated: But what is said in the text beginning with “that” is this:

original: taṃ tatrūpapattiyā vibandhakāradussīlyābhāvadassanaparaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, na dānamayassa
analyzed: tam tatrūpapattiyā vibandha kāra dussīlya abhāva dassana param daṭṭhabbam na dāna mayassa
translated: The meaning should be regarded thus: “He is not reborn there because he has no moral depravity which would obstruct rebirth there, not because he has only given gifts.”

original: puññassa kevalassa taṃsaṃvattanatādassanaparanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: puññassa kevalassa tad saṃvattana tā dassana paran ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: It should not be regarded as meaning that he has only given gifts and that that leads to rebirth there.

original: Samucchinnarāgassāti samucchinnakāmarāgassa. Tassa hi siyā brahmaloke upapatti, na🔽samucchinnabhavarāgassa. Vītarāgaggahaṇena cettha kāmesu vītarāgatā adhippetā, yāya
analyzed: samucchinna rāgassa ati samucchinna kāma rāgassa tassa hi siyā brahma loke upapatti na  samucchinna bhava rāgassa vīta rāga ggahaṇena ca ittha kāmesu vīta rāga tā adhippetā
translated: “One whose lust is cut off”: whose lust for sensual desires is cut off. For he might be reborn in the Brahmā-world,🔽but not one whose lust for becoming is cut off. And here the expression “free from lust” refers to freedom from lust for sensual desires, by means of which one might be reborn in the Brahmā-world. Hence it is said: “Only by giving gifts … ”

original: brahmalokūpapatti siyā. Tenāha “dānamattenevā”tiādi. Yadi evaṃ dānaṃ tattha kiṃ atthiyanti
analyzed: siyā tena āha dāna mattena iva atiādi yadi evam dānam tattha kim
translated: If that is so, then what is the use of giving gifts there?🔽He said: “But giving” … etc.

original: āha “dānaṃ panā”tiādi. Dānena muducittoti baddhāghāte verīpuggalepi attano dānasampaṭicchanena mudubhūtacitto.
analyzed: āha dānam pana atiādi dānena mudu cittaḥ ti baddha āghāte verī puggalaḥ pi attanaḥ dāna sampaṭicchanena mudu bhūta cittaḥ
translated: “With mind softened by giving”: with mind softened by his own giving of gifts even to a person who is an enemy and who has done him harm.

original: Parisīdati parito ito cito ca samāgacchatīti parisā, samūho.
analyzed: parisīdati paritas itas citas ca samāgacchati iti parisā samūhaḥ
translated: “An assembly” is a gathering, a collection, from this side and that side .

original: Lokassa dhammāti sattalokassa avassambhāvī dhammā. Tenāha “etehi mutto nāma natthī”tiādi.
analyzed: lokassa dhammā ti satta lokassa avassambhāvī dhammā tena āha etehi muttaḥ nāma natthi itiādi
translated: “The world’s way”: the world’s unavoidable way. Hence he said: “There is no one exempt from them.”

original: Yasmā te lokadhammā aparāparaṃ kadāci lokaṃ anupatanti, kadāci te loko, tasmā tañcettha🔽atthaṃ dassento “aṭṭhime”ti suttapadaṃ āhari. Ghāsacchādanādīnaṃ laddhi lābho, tāni
analyzed: yasmai te loka dhammāḥ apara aparam kadācid lokam anupatanti kadācid te tasmai tat ca itthā  attham dassentaḥ aṭṭhimā iti sutta padam āhari ghāsa chādana ādīnam tāni
translated: Since these worldly ideas sometimes follow the world in succession and sometimes the world follows them, therefore,🔽in order to show that meaning here, he cited the passage beginning with “Eight worldly ideas” . Gain is the acquisition of food, clothing, etc., or they are to be gained , thus they are gain ;

original: eva vā laddhabbato lābho. Tadabhāvo alābho. Lābhaggahaṇena cettha tabbisayo anurodho🔽gahito, alābhaggahaṇena virodho. Yasmā lohite sati tadupaghātavasena pubbo viya anurodhe
analyzed: eva vā laddhabbataḥ lābhaḥ tad abhāvaḥ alābhaḥ lābha ggahaṇena ca ittha tad visayaḥ anurodhaḥ  gahitaḥ alābha ggahaṇena virodhaḥ yasmā lohite sati tad upaghāta vasena pubbaḥ viya anurodhe
translated: the absence of that is nongain. And here, by the word “gain” its object, conformity, is included,🔽and by the word “nongain” its opposite, opposition, is included. Since opposition has opportunity only when there is conformity, as does a boil when there is blood,

original: sati virodho laddhāvasaro eva hoti, tasmā vuttaṃ “lābhe āgate alābho āgato evā”ti.
analyzed: sati virodhaḥ laddha avasaraḥ eva hoti tasmā vuttam lābhe āgate alābho āgataḥ eva ati
translated: therefore it was said, “When gain comes, nongain comes too” .

original: Esa nayo yasādīsupi.
analyzed: e sa nayaḥ yas ādī supi
translated: The same method applies in the case of fame, etc., too.

original: Aṭṭhakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: aṭṭhaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the section on the eight worldly ideas is ended.

original: Navakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: navaka vaṇṇanā
translated: Commentary on the section on the nine worldly ideas

original: 340. Vasati tattha phalaṃ tannimittakatāya pavattatīti vatthu, kāraṇanti vuttovāyamattho.
analyzed: vasati tattha phalam tad nimittaka tāya pavattati iti vatthu kāraṇam ti vuttaḥ uva ayam atthaḥ
translated: The fruit occurs there, and it occurs with that as its cause, thus that is a “ground” ; the meaning is “reason.”

original: Tenāha “āghātavatthūnīti āghātakāraṇānī”ti. Kopo nāmāyaṃ yasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ uppajjati,
analyzed: tena āha āghāta vatthūni iti āghāta kāraṇāni iti kopaḥ nāma ayam yasmim vatthusmim uppajjati
translated: Hence he said, “The grounds for annoyance are the reasons for annoyance” . Anger is what arises in a particular instance.

original: na tattha ekavārameva uppajjati, atha kho punapi uppajjatevāti vuttaṃ “bandhatī”ti.
analyzed: na tattha eka vāram eva uppajjati atha kho puna api uppajjateva ati vuttam bandhati iti
translated: It is not that it arises there once only, but rather that it arises again and again. That is why it is said, “It binds him.”

original: Atha vā yo paccayavisesena uppajjamāno āghāto savisaye baddho viya na vigacchati,🔽punapi uppajjeyyeva, taṃ sandhāyāha “āghātaṃ bandhatī”ti. Taṃ panassa paccayavasena
analyzed: atha vā yaḥ paccaya visesena uppajjamānaḥ āghātaḥ sa visaye baddhaḥ viya na vigacchati  puna api uppajjeyya eva tam sandhāya āha āghātam bandhati iti tam panassa paccaya vasena
translated: Or else, when resentment arises through a special condition, it does not depart as if bound to its object.

original: nibbattanaṃ uppādanamevāti vuttaṃ “karoti uppādetī”ti.
analyzed: nibbattanam uppādanam eva ati vuttam karoti uppādeti iti
translated: It arises again and again. With reference to that, it is said, “It binds him.” But its production through a condition is just its arising. That is why it is said, “He makes it arise.”

original: Taṃ kutettha labbhāti ettha tanti kiriyāparāmasanaṃ, padajjhāhārena ca attho veditabboti
analyzed: tam kuta ittha ettha tanti kiriyā parāmasanam padajjhāhārena ca atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ti
translated: “Where can it be found?” Here the question is asked in order to find fault. And the meaning should be understood by the method of word-commentary.

original: dassento “taṃ anatthacaraṇaṃ mā ahosī”tiādimāha. Kena kāraṇena laddhabbaṃ niratthakabhāvato.
analyzed: dassentaḥ tam anattha caraṇam mā ahosi itiādim āha kena kāraṇena laddhabbam niratthaka bhāvataḥ
translated: Showing this, he says, “Let there be no doing of what is not good” . Why should it be found? Because it is useless.

original: Kammassakā hi sattā, te kassa ruciyā dukkhitā, sukhitā vā bhavanti, tasmā kevalaṃ
analyzed: kammassakāḥ hi sattā te kassa ruciyā dukkhitā sukhitāḥ vā bhavanti tasmai kevalam
translated: For beings are owners of their kamma. Through whose wish do they become miserable or happy? Therefore

original: tasmiṃ mayhaṃ kujjhanamattaṃ evāti adhippāyo. Atha vā taṃ kopakaraṇamettha puggale
analyzed: tasmin mayham kujjhana mattam eva ati adhippāyaḥ atha vā tam kopa karaṇam ettha puggale
translated: the intention is that it is only my own resentment. Or else, this person is the means of his resentment.

original: kuto labbhā paramatthato kujjhitabbassa, kujjhanakassa ca abhāvato. Saṅkhāramattañhetaṃ,
analyzed: kutas labbhā paramatthataḥ kujjhitabbassa kujjhanakassa ca abhāvataḥ saṅkhāra mattam hetam
translated: How could there be any occasion for annoyance, since there is no one to be annoyed with and no one to be annoyed?🔽For this pentad of aggregates is a mere formation.

original: yadidaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ. Yaṃ “satto”ti vuccati, te saṅkhārā ittarakālā khaṇikā, kassa
analyzed: yat idam khandha pañcakam yam sattā ti vuccati te saṅkhārāḥ ittara kālā khaṇikā kassa
translated: The one who is called a “living being” is a formation of limited duration, momentary.🔽The meaning is: “Who is annoyed with whom?”

original: ko kujjhatīti attho. Lābhā nāma ke siyuṃ aññatra anuppattito.
analyzed: kaḥ kujjhati iti atthaḥ lābhāḥ nāma ke siyum aññatra anuppattito
translated: What is there to be gained, apart from the mere occurrence of the aggregates,

original: 341. Sattā āvasanti etesūti sattāvāsā. Nānattakāyā nānattasaññī ādibhedā sattanikāyā.🔽Yasmā te te sattanikāyā tappariyāpannānaṃ sattānaṃ tāya eva tappariyāpannatāya ādhāro
analyzed: sattāḥ āvasanti etesu iti sattāvāsā nānatta kāyā nānatta saññī ādi bhedā satta nikāyā  yasmā te te satta nikāyā tad pariyāpannānam sattānam tāyai eva tad pariyāpanna tāyai ādhāraḥ
translated: The “abodes of beings” are so called because beings dwell in them. The “beings” are the five kinds of beings, namely, the beings of the four planes and the unformed element.

original: viya vattabbataṃ arahanti samudāyādhāratāya avayavassa yathā “rukkhe sākhā”ti, tasmā
analyzed: viya vattabba tam arahanti samudāya ādhāra tāya avayavassa yathā rukkhe tasmā
translated: Since these abodes of beings are the support for beings included in them, in the same way that the word “tree” is used to denote the parts of a tree,🔽they are called “abodes of beings” in the sense of being the support for the collection of beings.

original: “sattānaṃ āvāsā, vasanaṭṭhānānīti attho”ti vuttaṃ. Suddhāvāsāpi sattāvāsova “na so,
analyzed: sattānam āvāsāḥ vasana ṭṭhānāni iti atthaḥ ti vuttam suddhāvāsā api satta āvāsaḥ uva na so
translated: The “pure abodes” are also abodes of beings.

original: bhikkhave, sattāvāso sulabharūpo, yo mayā anāvutthapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā aññatra
analyzed: bhikkhave sattāvāsaḥ sulabha rūpaḥ yaḥ mayā an āvuttha pubbaḥ iminā dīghena addhunā aññatra
translated: “Bhikkhus, it is not easy to find a world of beings where these beings have not formerly lived the life of purity.

original: suddhāvāsehi devehī”ti vacanato. Yadi evaṃ kasmā idha na gahitāti tattha kāraṇamāha
analyzed: suddha āvāsehi devehi iti vacanataḥ yadi evam kasmai idha na gahitā ati tattha kāraṇam āha
translated: If that is so, why are they not included here? The reason is given

original: “asabbakālikattā”tiādi. Vehapphalo pana catutthaṃyeva sattāvāsaṃ bhajatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: asabbakālika ttā atiādi vehapphalo pana catuttham yeva sattāvāsam bhajati iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: “Because they are not always so.” But Vehapphala should be regarded as belonging to the fourth class of beings only.

original: 342. Opasamikoti vaṭṭadukkhassa upasamāvaho, taṃ pana vaṭṭadukkhaṃ kilesesu upasantesu
analyzed: opasamiko ti vaṭṭa dukkhassa upasamāvaho tam pana vaṭṭa dukkham kilesesu upasantesu
translated: “The one who brings cessation” is the one who brings about the cessation of the suffering of the round. But that suffering of the round ceases

original: upasamati, na aññathā, tasmā “kilesūpasamakaro”ti vuttaṃ. Takkaraṃ sambodhaṃ gametīti sambodhagāmī.
analyzed: na aññathā tasmā kilesūpasamakaroti vuttam takkaram sambodham gameti iti sambodha gāmī
translated: when the defilements cease, not otherwise. That is why it is said, “the one who brings about the cessation of the defilements.” “The one who goes to the state of no-more-conflict” is the one who goes to the state of no-more-conflict.

original: Yasmiṃ devanikāye dhammadesanā na viyujjati savanasseva abhāvato, so pāḷiyaṃ “dīghāyuko devanikāyo”ti adhippetoti āha “asaññabhavaṃ vā arūpabhavaṃ vā”ti.
analyzed: yasmin devanikāye dhamma desanā na viyujjati savanassa iva abhāvataḥ so pāḷiyam dīgha āyukaḥ devanikāyaḥ iti adhippetaḥ iti āha asañña bhavam vā arūpa bhavam vā iti
translated: The class of gods in which the teaching of the Dhamma is not found is intended here in the text as “the class of gods of long life.” That is why it is said, “the existence of non-percipient beings or the existence in the immaterial world.”

original: 343. Anupubbato viharitabbāti anupubbavihārā. Anupaṭipāṭiyāti anukkamena. Samāpajjitabbavihārāti samāpajjitvā samaṅgino hutvā viharitabbavihārā.
analyzed: anupubbataḥ viharitabbā ati anupubba vihārā anupaṭipāṭiyā ati anukkamena samāpajjitabba vihārā ati samāpajjitvā samaṅginaḥ hutvā viharitabba vihārā
translated: “The successive abidings” are the successive abidings. “In due succession” means in due order. “The abidings to be entered upon” are the abidings to be entered upon and possessed.

original: 344. Anupubbanirodhāti anupubbena anukkamena pavattetabbanirodhā. Tenāha “anupaṭipāṭiyā nirodhā”ti.
analyzed: anupubba nirodhā ati anupubbena anukkamena pavattetabba nirodhā tena āha anupaṭipāṭiyā nirodhā iti
translated: In the order in which they cease: in the order in which they cease one after the other, successively. Hence he said “in the order in which they cease” .

original: Navakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: navaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the nine is ended.

original: Dasakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dasaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the ten

original: 345. Yehi sīlādīhi samannāgato bhikkhu dhammasaraṇatāya dhammeneva nāthati īsati
analyzed: yehi sīla ādīhi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu dhamma saraṇatāya dhammena iva nāthati īsati
translated: The bhikkhu who possesses virtue, etc., is “self-dependent” in the sense of being a lord, a master, because he is a lord of the Dhamma, a master of the Dhamma.

original: abhibhavatīti nāthoti vuccati, te tassa nāthabhāvakarā dhammā “nāthakaraṇā”ti vuttāti
analyzed: abhibhavati iti nāthaḥ ti vuccati te tassa nātha bhāva karā dhammā nātha karaṇā ati vuttā ati
translated: The dhammas that cause him to be self-dependent in this way are called “conducive to self-dependence” .

original: āha “sanāthā…pe… patiṭṭhākarā dhammā”ti. Tattha attano patiṭṭhākarāti yassa nāthabhāvakarā,
analyzed: āha sa nātha āpe patiṭṭhā karā dhammā ti tattha attano patiṭṭhā karā ti yassa nātha bhāva karā
translated: Hence he said “conducive to self-dependence, conducive to independence” . Herein, the dhammas that cause him to be self-dependent are his own self-dependence,

original: tassa attano patiṭṭhāvidhāyino. Appatiṭṭho anātho, sappatiṭṭho sanāthoti patiṭṭhattho nāthattho.
analyzed: tassa attanaḥ patiṭṭhā vidhāyinaḥ appatiṭṭhaḥ anātho sappatiṭṭhaḥ sanātho iti patiṭṭha atthaḥ nātha tthaḥ
translated: his own independence. He who is without self-dependence is without independence; he who has self-dependence has independence. The meaning of “self-dependence” is the meaning of “independence.”

original: Kalyāṇaguṇayogato kalyāṇāti dassento “sīlādiguṇasampannā”ti āha. Mijjanalakkhaṇā
analyzed: kalyāṇa guṇa yogataḥ kalyāṇā ati dassento sīla ādi guṇa sampannā iti āha mijjana lakkhaṇā
translated: Showing that it is good because it possesses good qualities, he said “endowed with the qualities of virtue, etc.”

original: mittā etassa atthīti mitto, so vuttanayena kalyāṇo assa atthīti tassa atthitāmattaṃ
analyzed: mittā etassa atthi iti mittaḥ saḥ vutta nayena kalyāṇaḥ assa atthi iti tassa atthi tā mattam
translated: He who has friends is a “friend-possessor” . He is good in the way already stated. He has that,

original: kalyāṇamittapadena vuttaṃ. Assa tena sabbakālaṃ avijahitavāsoti taṃ dassetuṃ “kalyāṇasahāyo”ti
analyzed: kalyāṇa mitta padena vuttam assa tena sabbakālam a vijahita vāsaḥ ti tam dassetum kalyāṇa sahāyaḥ ti
translated: In order to show that, it is said: “A good friend, etc.”🔽He should have good friends, i.e., the bhikkhu should have good friends.

original: vuttanti āha “tevassā”tiādi. Tevassāti te eva kalyāṇamittā assa bhikkhuno. Saha ayanatoti
analyzed: vuttanti āha tevassa atiādi tevassa ati te eva kalyāṇa mittāḥ assa bhikkhuno saha ayanato ti
translated: By the word “together” is meant “by association.”

original: saha vattanato. Asamodhāne cittena, samodhāne pana cittena ceva kāyena ca sampavaṅko.
analyzed: saha vattanataḥ a samodhāne cittena samodhāne pana cittena ca iva kāyena ca sampavaṅkaḥ
translated: He is pliable in mind in the matter of not being angry, and in the matter of being angry he is pliable both in mind and in body.

original: Sukhaṃ vaco etasmiṃ anukūlagāhimhi ādaragāravavati puggaleti suvaco. Tenāha “sukhena
analyzed: sukham vacaḥ etasmin anukūla gāhimhi ādara gāravavati puggala iti su vacaḥ tena āha sukhena
translated: The word “good” is used in the sense of agreeable and easy to live with.

original: vattabbo”tiādi. Khamoti khantā, tamevassa khamabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “gāḷhenā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vattabbā utiādi khamaḥ ati khantā tam eva assa khama bhāvam dassetum gāḷhena atiādi vuttam
translated: The word “bearing” is used in the sense of enduring. In order to show that very state of bearing, it is said: “with a heavy burden.”🔽He takes up wrongly, i.e., he takes up perversely or unskillfully.

original: Vāmatoti micchā, ayoniso vā gaṇhāti. Paṭippharatīti paṭāṇikabhāvena tiṭṭhati. Padakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: micchā ayonisaḥ vā gaṇhāti paṭippharati iti paṭāṇika bhāvena tiṭṭhati padakkhiṇam
translated: He stands in the way, i.e., he stands in the way by the state of opposition.

original: gaṇhātīti sammā yoniso vā gaṇhāti.
analyzed: gaṇhāti iti sammā yonisas vā gaṇhāti
translated: He takes up rightly, i.e., he takes up skillfully.🔽Great and small, i.e., extensive and limited.

original: Uccāvacānīti vipulakhuddakāni. Tatrupagamanīyāti tatra tatra mahante, khuddake ca
analyzed: uccāvacāni iti vipula khuddakāni tatra tatra mahante khuddake ca
translated: In this and that, i.e., in the great and in the small.

original: kamme sādhanavasena upāyena upagacchantiyā, tassa tassa kammassa nipphādanena samatthāyāti
analyzed: kamme sādhana vasena upāyena upagacchantiyā tassa tassa kammassa nipphādanena samatthāya ati
translated: The meaning is that they are devoted to the undertaking of the various kinds of work by way of the means for accomplishing it, and they are capable of producing the various kinds of work.

original: attho. Tatrupāyāyāti vā tatra tatra kamme sādhetabbe upāyabhūtāya.🔽Dhamme assa kāmoti dhammakāmoti byadhikaraṇānaṃpi bāhirattho samāso hotīti katvā
analyzed: attho tatrupāyāya ati vā tatra tatra kamme sādhetabbe upāya bhūtāya  dhamme assa kāmo ti dhamma kāmo ti byadhikaraṇānam pi bāhirattho samāsaḥ hoti iti katvā
translated: Or the meaning is that they are devoted to the means for accomplishing the various kinds of work.🔽The compound dhammakāmo is analysed as follows: dhamme assa kāmo, or dhamme kāmo assa. The meaning is that he delights in the True Idea.

original: vuttaṃ. Kāmetabbato vā piyāyitabbato kāmo, dhammo; dhammo kāmo assāti dhammakāmo.🔽Dhammoti pariyattidhammo adhippetoti āha “tepiṭakaṃ buddhavacanaṃ piyāyatīti attho”ti.
analyzed: vuttam kāmetabbataḥ vā piyāyitabbataḥ kāmaḥ dhammaḥ dhammaḥ kāmaḥ assa ati dhamma kāmaḥ  dhammo ti pariyatti dhammaḥ adhippeto ti āha tepiṭakam buddha vacanam piyāyati iti atthaḥ ti
translated: The word dhammo is intended here in the sense of the verbally expressed True Idea.

original: 346. Sakalaṭṭhenāti nissesaṭṭhena, anavasesapharaṇavasena cettha sakalaṭṭho veditabbo,
analyzed: sakala aṭṭhena ati nissesa ṭṭhena anavasesa pharaṇa vasena ca ittha sakala aṭṭhaḥ veditabbo
translated: As to the whole: as to the remainderless; here the meaning of “the whole” should be understood as the meaning of “pervading without remainder.”

original: asubhanimittādīsu viya ekadese aṭṭhatvā anavasesato gahetabbaṭṭhenāti attho. Tadārammaṇānaṃ
analyzed: asubha nimitta ādīsu viya eka dese anavasesataḥ gahetabba ṭṭhena ati attho tad ārammaṇānam
translated: The meaning is that it should be apprehended without leaving out any part, as in the case of the sign of foulness, and so on.🔽As to the object: as to the things that occur with that as their object.

original: dhammānanti taṃ kasiṇaṃ ārabbha pavattanakadhammānaṃ. Khettaṭṭhenāti uppattiṭṭhānaṭṭhena.
analyzed: dhammānam ti tam kasiṇam ārabbha pavattanaka dhammānam khetta ṭṭhena āti uppatti ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena
translated: As to the field: as to the place of their arising.🔽As to the foundation: as to the state of their occurrence.

original: Adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhenāti pavattiṭṭhānabhāvena. Yathā khettaṃ sassānaṃ uppattiṭṭhānaṃ vaḍḍhiṭṭhānañca,
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena āti pavatti ṭṭhāna bhāvena yathā khettam sassānam uppatti ṭṭhānam vaḍḍhi ṭṭhānam ca
translated: Just as a field is the place of the arising and the growing of crops,

original: evametaṃ jhānaṃ taṃsampayuttānaṃ dhammānanti, yogino vā sukhavisesānaṃ kāraṇabhāvena.🔽“Paricchinditvā” ti idaṃ uddhaṃ adhoti etthāpi yojetabbaṃ. Paricchinditvā eva hi
analyzed: evam etam jhānam tad sampayuttānam dhammānanti yoginaḥ vā sukha visesānam kāraṇa bhāvena  paricchinditvā ti idam uddham adhas ti ettha api yojetabbam paricchinditvā eva hi
translated: so this jhāna is the foundation for those things associated with it, or it is the cause for the various kinds of special knowledge, and so on, in one who has acquired jhāna and has emerged from it.🔽Having defined it: this should be construed with above, below, around, and in all quarters too.🔽For it is only by defining it in this way that the kasiṇa should be extended in all directions.

original: sabbattha kasiṇaṃ vaḍḍhetabbaṃ. Tena tena vā kāraṇenāti tena tena upariādīsu kasiṇavaḍḍhanakāraṇena.
analyzed: sabbattha kasiṇam vaḍḍhetabbam tena tena vā kāraṇena ati tena tena upari ādīsu kasiṇa vaḍḍhana kāraṇena
translated: By means of this or that cause: by means of this or that cause for extending the kasiṇa upwards, downwards, etc.

original: Yathā kinti āha “ālokamiva rūpadassanakāmo”ti. Yathā dibbacakkhunā uddhaṃ ce rūpaṃ🔽daṭṭhukāmo, uddhaṃ ālokaṃ pasāreti, adho ce adho, samantato ce rūpaṃ daṭṭhukāmo samantato
analyzed: yathā kim ti āha ālokam iva rūpa dassana kāmaḥ ti yathā dibba cakkhunā uddham ce rūpam  daṭṭhu kāmaḥ uddham ālokam pasāreti adho ce adho samantataḥ ce rūpam daṭṭhu kāmo samantataḥ
translated: “As when one who wants to see visible objects opens his eyes” is said by way of the eye-element. As when one who wants to see visible objects above opens his eyes upwards, below opens them downwards, all around opens them all around, so too, when one who wants to see visible objects above opens his eyes upwards, below opens them downwards, all around opens them all around,

original: ālokaṃ pasāreti; evamayaṃ kasiṇanti attho.🔽Ekassāti pathavīkasiṇādīsu ekekassa. Aññabhāvānupagamanatthanti aññakasiṇabhāvānupagamanadīpanatthaṃ,🔽aññassa vā kasiṇabhāvānupagamanadīpanatthaṃ, na hi aññena pasāritakasiṇaṃ tato aññena
analyzed: ālokam pasāreti evam ayam attho  ekassa ati pathavī kasiṇa ādīsu ekekassa añña bhāva anupagamana attham ti añña kasiṇa bhāva anupagamana dīpana ttham  aññassa vā kasiṇa bhāva an upagamana dīpana ttham na hi aññena pasārita kasiṇam tatas aññena
translated: “As what?” He says, “As light, one who desires to see visible objects.” As one who desires to see visible objects above, below, or all round, by means of the divine eye, extends the light above, below, and all round, so too this kasiṇa. This is the meaning.🔽In one: in each one of the earth kasiṇa, etc.,

original: pasāritakasiṇabhāvaṃ upagacchati, evampi nesaṃ aññakasiṇasambhedābhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: pasārita kasiṇa bhāvam upagacchati evam pi na isam añña kasiṇa sambheda abhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: For the purpose of showing that it does not take on the appearance of another kasiṇa: for the purpose of showing that it does not take on the appearance of another kasiṇa, such as the water kasiṇa, etc.; for one does not extend the light of one kasiṇa and then take up the appearance of another kasiṇa. This is how it should be understood that they are not mixed up with one another.

original: Na aññaṃ pathavīādi. Na hi udake ṭhitaṭṭhāne sasambhārapathavī atthi. Añño kasiṇasambhedoti
analyzed: na aññam pathavī ādi na hi udake ṭhita ṭṭhāne sa sambhāra pathavī atthi aññaḥ kasiṇa sambhedo ti
translated: Not another earth, etc.: there is no earth element with its accessories in the place occupied by the water element, and so on. Another classification of kasiṇas: the confusion of the water kasiṇa, etc.,

original: āpokasiṇādinā saṅkaro. Sabbatthāti sabbesu sesakasiṇesu. Ekadese aṭṭhatvā anavasesapharaṇaṃ
analyzed: āpokasiṇa ādinā saṅkaro sabbattha ati sabbesu sesa kasiṇesu eka dese aṭṭhatvā anavasesa pharaṇam
translated: Everywhere: in all the remaining kasiṇas. Without leaving out any part: without omitting any part.

original: pamāṇassa aggahaṇato appamāṇaṃ. Teneva hi nesaṃ kasiṇasamaññā. Tathā cāha “tañhī”tiādi.🔽Cetasā pharantoti bhāvanācittena ārammaṇaṃ karonto. Bhāvanācittañhi kasiṇaṃ parittaṃ
analyzed: pamāṇassa aggahaṇato appamāṇam tena iva hi na isam kasiṇa samaññā tathā ca āha tat hi itiādi  cetasā pharanto ti bhāvanā cittena ārammaṇam karontaḥ bhāvanā cittam hi kasiṇam parittam
translated: It is immeasurable because it has no measure. That is why they are called kasiṇas. Hence it is said: “That is why it is called the kasiṇa” .

original: vā vipulaṃ vā sakalameva manasi karoti, na ekadesaṃ.
analyzed: vā vipulam vā sakalam eva manasi karoti na eka desam
translated: Spreading with the mind : making the object with the development consciousness. For the development consciousness makes the kasiṇa object either limited or measureless, not in part.

original: Kasiṇugghāṭimākāse pavattaviññāṇaṃ pharaṇaappamāṇavasena “viññāṇakasiṇa”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kasiṇugghāṭim ākāse pavatta viññāṇam pharaṇa appamāṇa vasena viññāṇakasiṇan ti vuttam
translated: The consciousness occurring in the space that has been delimited by the kasiṇa is called the “kasiṇa of consciousness” because of the measurelessness of the spreading.🔽For that is called “consciousness” .

original: Tathā hi taṃ “viññāṇañca”nti vuccati. Kasiṇavasenāti yathāugghāṭitakasiṇavasena.
analyzed: tathā hi tam viññāṇañcanti vuccati kasiṇa vasena ati yathā ugghāṭita kasiṇa vasena
translated: By the kasiṇa : by the kasiṇa as delimited.

original: Kasiṇugghāṭimākāse uddhaṃadhotiriyatā veditabbā. Yattakañhi ṭhānaṃ kasiṇaṃ pasāritaṃ,
analyzed: uddhan adhotiriya tā veditabbā yattakam hi ṭhānam kasiṇam pasāritam
translated: The space that has been delimited by the kasiṇa should be understood as extending upwards, downwards, and across. For as far as the kasiṇa was extended,🔽for that much the space becomes space by the development of the space kasiṇa.

original: tattakaṃ ākāsabhāvanāvasena ākāso hotīti; evaṃ yattakaṃ ṭhānaṃ ākāsaṃ hutvā upaṭṭhitaṃ,
analyzed: tattakam ākāsa bhāvanā vasena ākāsaḥ hoti iti evam yattakam ṭhānam ākāsam hutvā upaṭṭhitam
translated: And for as much as the space appears as space,

original: tattakaṃ sakalameva pharitvā viññāṇassa pavattanato āgamanavasena viññāṇakasiṇepi
analyzed: tattakam sakalam eva pharitvā viññāṇassa pavattanataḥ āgamana vasena viññāṇa kasiṇe pi
translated: for that much the consciousness occurs by spreading over the whole of it. This is how the “kasiṇa of consciousness” should be understood.

original: uddhaṃadhotiriyatā vuttāti āha “kasiṇugghāṭiṃ ākāsavasena tattha pavattaviññāṇe uddhaṃadhotiriyatā veditabbā”ti.
analyzed: uddhaṃ adhas tiriya tā vuttā iti āha kasiṇugghāṭim ākāsa vasena tattha pavatta viññāṇe uddhaṃ adhas tiriya tā veditabbā ti
translated: “Above and below, in the breadth” is said with reference to the consciousness occurring there in the kasiṇa that has been expanded above and below.

analyzed: akusala kammapatha dasaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The ten courses of unwholesome kamma

original: pavattitassa vasena tayo balakkārena pavattitassa vasena tayoti sabbepi aggahitaggahaṇena
analyzed: pavatti tassa vasena tayaḥ balakkārena pavatti tassa vasena tayaḥ ti sabbe pi aggahita ggahaṇena
translated: and by way of the three kinds of strength of the one who is engaged in the act, there are three. All these are included in the expression “four requisites.”

original: “cattāro sambhārā”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Upasaggavasena atthavisesavācino dhātusaddāti “abhijjhāyatī”ti padassa “parabhaṇḍābhimukhī”tiādinā
analyzed: cattāraḥ sambhārā iti vuttam  upasagga vasena attha visesa vācinaḥ dhātu saddā ti abhijjhāyati iti padassa parabhaṇḍa abhimukhī iti ādinā
translated: “Four requisites” is said.

original: attho vutto. Tattha tanninnatāyāti tasmiṃ parabhaṇḍe lubbhanavasena ninnatāyāti ayamettha
analyzed: atthaḥ vuttaḥ tattha tad ninna tāya ati tasmin parabhaṇḍe lubbhana vasena ninna tāya ati ayam ettha
translated: The word “dhātu” is one that expresses a special meaning by way of prefix. The meaning of the expression “abhijjhāyati” is expressed by the words “parabhaṇḍābhimukhī” , etc. Herein, the intention should be understood thus: “Tassā ninnatāya” means “by reason of the bent towards that, i.e., towards the other’s property, by way of greed.”

original: adhippāyo veditabbo. Abhipubbo vā jhā-saddo lubbhane niruḷho daṭṭhabbo. Upasaggavasena
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ veditabbaḥ abhipubbaḥ vā jhā saddaḥ lubbhane niruḷhaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ upasagga vasena
translated: Or the word “abhi” should be regarded as being used in the sense of “lubbhanā” , i.e., greed.🔽The word “dhātu” is one that expresses a special meaning by way of prefix.

original: atthavisesavācino eva dhātusaddā. Adinnādānassa appasāvajjamahāsāvajjatā brahmajālavaṇṇanāyaṃ🔽vuttāti āha “adinnādānaṃ viya appasāvajjā, mahāsāvajjā cā”ti. Tasmā “yassa bhaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: attha visesa vācinaḥ eva dhātu saddāḥ adinnādānassa appa sāvajja mahāsāvajja tā brahmajāla vaṇṇanāyam  vuttā iti āha adinnādānam viya appasāvajjā mahāsāvajjā ca ati tasmai yassa bhaṇḍam
translated: The less blameworthy and the more blameworthy nature of covetousness is stated in the Brahmajāla Sutta.🔽Therefore it is said: “Like taking what is not given, covetousness is less blameworthy or more blameworthy.”

original: abhijjhāyati, tassa appaguṇatāya appasāvajjatā, mahāguṇatāya mahāsāvajjatā”tiādinā
analyzed: abhijjhāyati tassa appaguṇa tāya appa sāvajja tā mahāguṇa tāya mahā sāvajja tā ati ādinā
translated: “By reason of the smallness of the good qualities of the one whose property is coveted, covetousness is less blameworthy; by reason of the greatness of the good qualities of the one whose property is coveted, covetousness is more blameworthy.”

original: appasāvajjamahāsāvajjavibhāgo veditabbo. Attano pariṇāmanaṃ cittenevāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: appasāvajja mahāsāvajja vibhāgaḥ veditabbaḥ attanaḥ pariṇāmanam cittena iva ati veditabbam
translated: The distinction between the less and more serious should be understood as follows.

original: Hitasukhaṃ byāpādayatīti yo naṃ uppādeti, tassa yaṃ pati cittaṃ uppādeti, tassa tassa
analyzed: hita sukham byāpādayati iti yaḥ nam uppādeti tassa yam pati cittam uppādeti tassa tassa
translated: The one who arouses it is the one who causes the harm and the benefit and the happiness to be destroyed.

original: sati samavāye hitasukhaṃ vināseti. Pharusavācāya appasāvajjamahāsāvajjatā brahmajālavaṇṇanāyaṃ🔽vibhāvitāti āha “pharusavācā viyā”tiādi. Tasmā “yaṃ pati cittaṃ byāpādeti, tassa
analyzed: sati samavāye hita sukham pharusa vācāya appa sāvajja mahā sāvajja tā brahmajāla vaṇṇanāyam  āha pharusa vācā tasmai yam pati cittam tassa
translated: The harsh speech is explained in the Brahmajāla Sutta.

original: appaguṇatāya appasāvajjo, mahāguṇatāya mahāsāvajjo”tiādinā tadubhayavibhāgo veditabbo.
analyzed: appaguṇa tāya appasāvajjaḥ mahā guṇa tāya mahāsāvajjaḥ iti ādinā tad ubhaya vibhāgaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: Therefore the distinction between the two should be understood in this way: “The less serious is less reprehensible because of the smallness of its virtue, and the more serious is more reprehensible because of the greatness of its virtue.”

original: “Aho vatā”ti iminā parassa accantāya vināsacintanaṃ dīpeti. Evañhi ssa dāruṇappavattiyā kammapathappavatti.
analyzed: aho vata iti iminā parassa accantāya vināsa cintanam dīpeti evam hi ssa dāruṇa pavattiyā kammapatha ppavatti
translated: “Oh, that they might be destroyed” : this shows the thinking of utter destruction of another. For the occurrence of the course of action is in this way, by the occurrence of a cruel thought.

original: Yathābhuccagahaṇābhāvenāti yāthāvagahaṇassa abhāvena aniccādisabhāvassa niccādito
analyzed: yathābhucca gahaṇa abhāvena ati yāthāva gahaṇassa abhāvena anicca ādi sabhāvassa nicca ādeḥ
translated: “Because of the absence of grasping as it really is” : because of the absence of grasping as impermanent, etc., the real nature of what is impermanent, etc., as permanent, etc.

original: gahaṇena. Micchā passatīti vitathaṃ passati. “Samphappalāpo viyā”ti iminā āsevanassa🔽mandatāya appasāvajjataṃ, mahantatāya mahāsāvajjataṃ dasseti. Gahitākāraviparītatāti
analyzed: gahaṇena micchā passati iti vitatham passati samphappalāpaḥ viyā ti iminā āsevanassa  manda tāya appasāvajja tam mahanta tāya mahāsāvajja tam dasseti gahita ākāra viparīta tā ati
translated: By the act of taking up. He sees wrongly: he sees falsely. By “as if he were talking nonsense” he shows that it is less blameworthy when done slightly, more blameworthy when done much.

original: micchādiṭṭhiyā gahitākāraviparītabhāvo. Vatthunoti tassa ayathābhūtasabhāvamāha.
analyzed: micchādiṭṭhiyā gahita ākāra viparīta bhāvaḥ vatthunoti tassa ayathābhūta sabhāvam āha
translated: By taking up. He sees wrongly: he sees falsely. By “as if he were talking nonsense” he shows that it is less blameworthy when the repetition is slight and more blameworthy when it is great. The state of being the opposite of the way the object is taken up: the state of being the opposite of the way the wrong view is taken up. The object: he says this of its being not as it really is.

original: Tathābhāvenāti gahitākāreneva viparītākāreneva. Tassa diṭṭhigatikassa, tassa vā vatthuno
analyzed: tathābhāvena ati gahita ākārena iva viparīta ākārena iva tassa diṭṭhigatikassa tassa vā vatthuno
translated: In that way: in the way it is taken up. In the opposite way: in the way it is wrongly taken up. The appearance of that view-holder, or of that object,

original: upaṭṭhānaṃ, “evametaṃ na ito aññathā”ti.
analyzed: upaṭṭhānam evam etam naḥ itas aññathā ti
translated: as “This is thus, not otherwise.”

original: Dhammatoti sabhāvato. Koṭṭhāsatoti phassapañcamakādīsu cittaṅgakoṭṭhāsesu ye koṭṭhāsā honti, tatoti attho.
analyzed: dhammato ti sabhāvato koṭṭhāsato ti phassa pañcamaka ādīsu cittaṅga koṭṭhāsesu ye koṭṭhāsāḥ honti tatas ti attho
translated: The state of being: the individual essence. The part: the meaning is, from among the five-part consciousnesses, etc., from the part that is consciousness.

original: Cetanādhammāti cetanāsabhāvā.🔽“Paṭipāṭiyā sattā”ti ettha nanu cetanā abhidhamme kammapathesu na vuttāti paṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: cetanā dhammā ati cetanā sabhāvā  paṭipāṭiyā sattā ti ettha nanu cetanā abhidhamme kamma pathesu na vuttā ati paṭipāṭiyā
translated: The state of being a volition: the individual essence of volition.

original: sattannaṃ kammapathabhāvo na yuttoti? Na, avacanassa aññahetukattā. Na hi tattha
analyzed: sattannam kammapatha bhāvaḥ na yutto ti na avacanassa añña hetuka ttā na hi tattha
translated: “In the seven ways” here: now, isn’t volition not mentioned in the Abhidhamma in the courses of kamma? So isn’t it inappropriate to speak of the seven courses of kamma in the seven ways? No, because the omission has another reason. For it is not

original: cetanāya akammapathappattattā kammapatharāsimhi avacanaṃ, kadāci pana kammapatho
analyzed: cetanāya a kamma patha ppatta ttā kamma patha rāsimhi avacanam kadāci pana kamma patho
translated: because of the non-attainment of the path of action by volition, there is no mention of it in the mass of the path of action, but sometimes it is the path of action.

original: hoti, na sabbadāti kammapathabhāvassa aniyatattā avacanaṃ. Yadā pana kammapatho hoti,
analyzed: hoti na sabbadā ti kamma patha bhāvassa aniyata ttā avacanam yadā pana kamma pathaḥ hoti
translated: Because of the non-attainment of the state of a path of action by volition, it is not mentioned in the list of the paths of action. But sometimes it is a path of action, and not always, so it is not mentioned because the state of being a path of action is not fixed. But when it is a path of action,

original: tadā kammapatharāsisaṅgaho na nivārito.
analyzed: tadā kamma patha rāsi saṅgahaḥ na nivārito
translated: then its inclusion in the list of the paths of action is not excluded.

original: Etthāha – yadi cetanāya sabbadā kammapathabhāvābhāvato aniyato kammapathabhāvoti🔽kammapatharāsimhi avacanaṃ, nanu abhijjhādīnampi kammapathabhāvaṃ appattānaṃ atthitāya
analyzed: ettha āha yadi cetanāya sabbadā kamma patha bhāva abhāvataḥ aniyataḥ kamma patha bhāvo ti  kamma patha rāsimhi avacanam nanu abhijjha ādīnam pi kamma patha bhāvam appattānam atthi tāya
translated: Here it may be asked: “If the state of being a path of action is not fixed because of the non-existence of the state of being a path of action by volition at all times,🔽then, since covetousness, etc., are not paths of action because they do not exist when they have not reached the state of being paths of action,

original: aniyato kammapathabhāvoti tesampi kammapatharāsimhi avacanaṃ āpajjatīti? Nāpajjati
analyzed: aniyataḥ kammapatha bhāvo ti tesam pi kammapatha rāsimhi avacanam āpajjati iti na āpajjati
translated: are they not also not mentioned in the list of the paths of action because the state of being a path of action is not fixed in their case too? ” They are not.

original: kammapathatātaṃsabhāgatā hi tesaṃ tattha vuttattā. Yadi evaṃ cetanāpi tattha vattabbā
analyzed: kamma patha tā ātaṃsa bhāga tā hi tesam tattha vutta ttā yadi evam cetanā api tattha vattabbā
translated: Because of the fact that they have the nature of being paths of action, they are mentioned there. If that is so, then volition should be mentioned there too,

original: siyāti? Saccametaṃ, sā pana pāṇātipātādikāvāti pākaṭo tassā kammapathabhāvoti na
analyzed: siyā ti saccam etam sā pana pāṇa atipāta ādikā avāti pākaṭaḥ tassā kamma patha bhāvo ti na
translated: since it has the nature of being a path of action? That is true, but its state of being a path of action is obvious because it is the instigator of killing living beings, etc., so it is not mentioned.

original: vuttaṃ siyā. Cetanāya hi “cetanāhaṃ, bhikkhave, kammaṃ vadāmi, tividhā, bhikkhave,
analyzed: vuttam siyā cetanāya hi cetanā aham bhikkhave kammam vadāmi tividhā bhikkhave
translated: “Yes, it could be said. For it is said: ‘I say, bhikkhus, that kamma is intention. Intention, bhikkhus, is a cetanā.

original: kāyasañcetanā akusalaṃ kāyakamma”nti vacanato kammabhāvo pākaṭo; kammaṃyeva ca sugatiduggatīnaṃ,
analyzed: kāya sañcetanā akusalam vacanato kamma bhāvaḥ pākaṭaḥ ca sugati duggatīnam
translated: It might be said that it is. For the fact that volition is a kind of action is evident from the words, “I say that volition, bhikkhus, is kamma; volition is the kind of action that is bodily action, akusala, and volition is the kind of action that is verbal action, akusala” .🔽And the fact that it is a course of action is evident from the fact that it is action that is the way to the good and bad destinations,

original: taduppajjanasukhadukkhānañca pathabhāvena pavattaṃ “kammapatho”ti vuccatīti pākaṭo
analyzed: tad uppajjana sukha dukkhānam ca patha bhāvena pavattam kamma patho ti vuccati iti pākaṭaḥ
translated: and to the happiness and suffering that arise there.

original: tassā kammapathabhāvo. Abhijjhādīnaṃ pana cetanāsamīhanabhāvena sucaritaduccaritabhāvo,
analyzed: kamma patha bhāvaḥ abhijjhā ādīnam pana cetanā samīhana bhāvena su carita duccarita bhāvaḥ
translated: But the fact that covetousness, etc., are courses of action is not so evident. For their being good and bad conduct is evident only as the kind of volition that is the act of wishing;

original: cetanājanitabhāvena [cetanājanitataṃbandhatibhāvena ] sugatiduggatitaduppajjanasukhadukkhānaṃ🔽pathabhāvo cāti na tathā pākaṭo kammapathabhāvoti te eva tena sabhāvena dassetuṃ
analyzed: cetanā janita bhāvena cetanā janita taṃbandhati bhāvena sugati duggati tad uppajjana sukha dukkhānam  patha bhāvo ca ati na tathā pākaṭaḥ kamma patha bhāvo ti te eva tena sa bhāvena dassetuṃ
translated: and their being the way to the good and bad destinations and to the happiness and suffering that arise there is evident only as the kind of volition that generates that.🔽So in order to show that they are courses of action in their own individual characteristics,

original: abhidhamme cetanā kammapathabhāve na vuttā, atathājātiyattā vā cetanā tehi saddhiṃ
analyzed: abhidhamme cetanā kamma patha bhāve na vuttā atathā jāti yattā vā cetanā tehi saddhiṃ
translated: volition is not mentioned in the Abhidhamma as a course of action, or it is mentioned as a course of action in the Suttas because it is of the same nature as those states.

original: na vuttāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Mūlaṃ patvāti mūladesanaṃ patvā, mūlasabhāvesu dhammesu desiyamānesūti attho.
analyzed: na vuttā ati daṭṭhabbam mūlam patvā ati mūla desanam patvā mūla sabhāvesu dhammesu desiyamānesu iti attho
translated: should be taken as not stated. “Having reached the root”: having reached the root-teaching, that is, when the dhammas that are the root-nature are being taught.

original: “Adinnādānaṃ sattārammaṇa”nti idaṃ “pañcasikkhāpadā parittārammaṇā evā”ti imāya pañhapucchakapāḷiyā🔽virujjhati. Yañhi pāṇātipātādidussīlyassa ārammaṇaṃ, tadeva taṃveramaṇiyā ārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: adinnādānam satta ārammaṇanti idam pañca sikkhāpadā paritta ārammaṇā eva ati imāya pañha pucchaka pāḷiyā  virujjhati yat hi pāṇa atipāta ādi dussīlyassa ārammaṇam tat eva taṃ veramaṇiyāḥ ārammaṇam
translated: “Stealing has a living being as its object” is contradicted by the passage of the question-section that states: “The five training precepts have only a limited object.”🔽For the object of the unvirtuousness of killing living beings, etc., is the same as the object of the virtue of refraining from them.

original: Vītikkamitabbavatthuto eva hi viratīti. Sattārammaṇanti vā sattasaṅkhātasaṅkhārārammaṇaṃ,
analyzed: vītikkamitabba vatthutaḥ eva hi virati iti satta ārammaṇam ti vā satta saṅkhāta saṅkhāra ārammaṇam
translated: For abstinence is only from the object that is to be transgressed. Or else, “a living being as its object” means that it has as its object formations that are called a “living being.”

original: tameva upādāya vuttanti na koci virodho. Tathā hi vuttaṃ sammohavinodaniyaṃ “yāni
analyzed: tam eva upādāya vuttanti na koci virodhaḥ tathā hi vuttam sammoha vinodaniyam yāni
translated: It is said with reference to that. There is no contradiction. For it is said in the Sammohavinodani:

original: sikkhāpadāni ettha ‘sattārammaṇānī’ti vuttāni, tāni yasmā sattoti saṅkhaṃ gate saṅkhāreyeva
analyzed: sikkhāpadāni ettha satta ārammaṇāni iti vuttāni tāni yasmā satto ti saṅkham gate
translated: “The training precepts stated here as having a living being as their object have as their object only formations that are called a living being.”

original: ārammaṇaṃ karontī”ti. esa nayo ito paresupi. Visabhāgavatthuno “itthī puriso”ti gahetabbato
analyzed: ārammaṇam karonti iti esa nayaḥ itas paresu pi visa bhāga vatthunaḥ itthī puriso ti gahetabbato
translated: The same method applies to the rest. “A woman, a man” should be taken as the dissimilar object.

original: “sattārammaṇo”ti eke. “Eko diṭṭho, dve sutā”tiādinā samphappalāpena diṭṭhasutamutaviññātavasena.
analyzed: satta ārammaṇaḥ ti eke ekaḥ diṭṭhaḥ dve suta ati ādinā samphappalāpena diṭṭha suta muta viññāta vasena
translated: “One seen, two heard, three cognized,” etc., is idle chatter with what is seen, heard, sensed, and cognized as object.

original: Tathā abhijjhāti ettha tathā-saddo “diṭṭhasutamutaviññātavasenā” tidampi upasaṃharati,
analyzed: tathā ettha tathā saddaḥ diṭṭha suta muta viññāta vasena upasaṃharati
translated: So too in the case of covetousness. The word “so too” is also to be construed with “with what is seen, heard, sensed, and cognized as object.”

original: na sattasaṅkhārārammaṇatameva dassanādivasena abhijjhāyanato. “Natthi sattā opapātikā”ti
analyzed: na satta saṅkhāra ārammaṇatam eva dassana ādi vasena abhijjhāyanataḥ natthi sattā opapātikā ti
translated: It is not only the formations of a being that are the object of covetousness, which occurs with seeing, etc., as its means.

original: pavattamānāpi micchādiṭṭhi tebhūmakadhammavisayā evāti adhippāyenassā saṅkhārārammaṇatā
analyzed: pavattamānā api micchādiṭṭhi tebhūmaka dhamma visayā eva ti adhippāyena assā saṅkhāra ārammaṇa tā
translated: And although the wrong view “There is no being reappearing in accordance with kamma” occurs, it has only states of the three planes as its domain.🔽So the object of wrong view is stated to be formations in the sense of the intention of the one who holds the view.

original: vuttā. Kathaṃ pana micchādiṭṭhiyā sabbe tebhūmakadhammā ārammaṇaṃ hotīti? Sādhāraṇato.
analyzed: vuttā katham pana micchādiṭṭhiyā sabbe tebhūmaka dhammāḥ ārammaṇam hoti iti sādhāraṇato
translated: But how can all states of the three planes be the object of wrong view?🔽They are so in a general way.

original: “Natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko”ti pavattamānāya atthato rūpārūpāvacaradhammāpi gahitā eva hontīti.
analyzed: natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti pavattamānāya atthataḥ rūpa arūpa avacara dhammā api gahitāḥ eva honti iti
translated: For when it occurs thus, “There is no fruit and result of good and bad actions,” states of the fine-material and immaterial spheres are included in the sense that they are not nonexistent.

original: Sukhabahulatāya rājāno hasamānāpi “ghātethā”ti vadanti, hāso pana nesaṃ attavūpasamādiaññavisayoti
analyzed: sukha bahula tāya rājānaḥ hasamānā api ghātetha ati vadanti hāso pana nesam atta vūpasama ādi añña visayaḥ ti
translated: Kings, because of their great happiness, say “Kill” and “Strike” even while laughing, but their laughter has as its domain something quite different, namely, the removal of their own displeasure, and so on.

original: āha “sanniṭṭhāpaka…pe… hotī”ti. Majjhattavedano na hoti, sukhavedanova ettha sambhavatīti.
analyzed: āha hoti iti majjhatta vedanaḥ na hoti sukha vedanā u ettha sambhavati iti
translated: … is the pleasant feeling. There is no neutral feeling here, only the pleasant one can be found.

original: Musāvādo lobhasamuṭṭhāno sukhavedano vā siyā majjhattavedano vā, dosasamuṭṭhāno dukkhavedano
analyzed: musāvādaḥ lobha samuṭṭhānaḥ sukha vedanaḥ vā siyā majjhatta vedanaḥ vā dosa samuṭṭhānaḥ dukkha vedano
translated: Lying is of three kinds of feeling: it is of pleasant feeling when rooted in greed, or of neutral feeling when rooted in greed; it is of painful feeling when rooted in hate.

original: vāti musāvādo tivedano. Iminā nayena sesesupi yathārahaṃ vedanābhedo veditabbo.
analyzed: vāti musāvādaḥ ti vedanaḥ iminā nayena sesesu pi yathāraham vedanā bhedaḥ veditabbo
translated: So lying is of three kinds of feeling. The analysis of feeling should be understood in this way in each instance according to the context.

original: Dosamohavasena dvimūlakoti sampayuttamūlameva sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tassa hi mūlaṭṭhena🔽upakārakabhāvo. Nidānamūle pana gayhamāne “lobhamohavasenapī”ti vattabbaṃ siyā. Āmisakiñjakkhahetupi
analyzed: dosa moha vasena dvimūlakaḥ ti sampayutta mūlam eva sandhāya vuttam tassa hi mūla aṭṭhena  upakāraka bhāvaḥ nidāna mūle pana gayhamāne lobha moha vasena api iti vattabbam siyā āmisa kiñjakkha hetu pi
translated: “Rooted in two causes, in hate and delusion”: this is said with reference to the associated cause, for that is the cause in the sense of root.

original: pāṇaṃ hananti. Tenevāha – “lobho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāyā”tiādi. Sesesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: pāṇam hananti tena iva āha lobhaḥ nidānam kammānam samudayāya atiādi sesesu pi esa iva nayo
translated: But if the causal cause were taken, it would have to be said that it is rooted in greed and delusion too, since they kill for the sake of wealth and women. That is why it is said: “Greed is a cause for the arising of kamma” , and so on. The same method applies to the rest.

original: Kusalakammapathadasakavaṇṇanā
translated: The ten profitable courses of action

original: Pāṇātipātā …pe… veditabbāni lokiyalokuttaramissakavasenettha kusalakammapathānaṃ
analyzed: pāṇātipātā pe veditabbāni lokiya lokuttara missaka vasena ittha kusala kammapathānam
translated: Killing living beings … should be understood here in the way beginning “Profitable kamma is of three kinds” .

original: desitattā. Verahetutāya verasaññitaṃ pāṇātipātādipāpadhammaṃ maṇati “mayi idha ṭhitāya🔽kathaṃ āgacchasī”ti tajjantī viya nīharatīti veramaṇī, viramati etāyāti vā “viramaṇī”ti
analyzed: desita ttā vera hetutāya vera saññitam pāṇa atipāta ādi pāpa dhammam maṇati mayi idha ṭhitāya  katham āgacchasi iti tajjantī nīharati iti veramaṇī viramati vā viramaṇī iti
translated: because it is taught. It is called “restraint” because it restrains, that is, it keeps away, evil states such as killing breathing things, etc., which are called “bonds” because they are a cause of bondage. It is as if it were saying: “As long as I am here,🔽how can they come to you?” It is called “restraint” because it restrains, or because one refrains by means of it. But the form “veramaṇī” is used instead of “viramaṇī” because of the rule of the metrical foot.

original: vattabbe niruttinayena “veramaṇī”ti vuttaṃ. Samādānavasena uppannā virati samādānavirati.
analyzed: vattabbe nirutti nayena veramaṇī iti vuttam samādāna vasena uppannā virati samādāna virati
translated: The abstinence that arises through undertaking is abstinence through undertaking.

original: Asamādinnasīlassa sampattato yathāupaṭṭhitavītikkamitabbavatthuto virati sampattavirati.
analyzed: a samādinna sīlassa sampattataḥ yathā upaṭṭhita vītikkamitabba vatthutaḥ virati sampatta virati
translated: The abstinence from what is to be transgressed as it occurs in one who has not undertaken the virtue of refraining is abstinence through possession.

original: Kilesānaṃ samucchindanavasena pavattā maggasampayuttā virati samucchedavirati. Kāmañcettha
analyzed: kilesānam samucchindana vasena pavattā magga sampayuttā virati samuccheda virati kāmam ca ittha
translated: The abstinence associated with the path that occurs by way of the severing of defilements is abstinence through cutting off. But here,🔽although only abstinence is mentioned in the text, volition is also included in the exposition of the training precepts.

original: pāḷiyaṃ viratiyeva āgatā, sikkhāpadavibhaṅge pana cetanāpi āharitvā dassitāti tadubhayampi🔽gaṇhanto “cetanāpi vattanti viratiyopī”ti āha. Anabhijjhā hi mūlaṃ patvāti kammapathakoṭṭhāse
analyzed: pāḷiyam viratiyā iva āgatā sikkhāpada vibhaṅge pana cetanā api āharitvā dassitā ati tat ubhayam pi 🔽gaṇhanto vattanti viratiyā api iti āha anabhijjhāḥ hi mūlam patvā ati kammapatha koṭṭhāse
translated: Therefore, taking both, he said, “Either volition or abstinence.”🔽For non-greed is the root, and non-hate and non-delusion are the roots, of the training precepts.

original: “anabhijjhā”ti vuttadhammo mūlato alobho kusalamūlaṃ hotīti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: anabhijjhā ti vutta dhammaḥ mūlataḥ alobhaḥ kusala mūlam hoti iti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The meaning here should be regarded as follows: the state of non-greed is the profitable root non-greed from the root.

original: Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: sa isa pada dvaye pi e sa iva nayoḥ
translated: The same method of explanation applies to the other two terms.

original: Dussīlyārammaṇā tadārammaṇajīvitindriyādiārammaṇā kathaṃ dussīlyāni pajahantīti taṃ
analyzed: dussīlya ārammaṇā tad ārammaṇa jīvitindriya ādi ārammaṇā katham dussīlyāni pajahanti iti tam
translated: How can the abandoning of the unvirtuous states be shown by the life faculty, etc., which have virtue as their object?

original: dassetuṃ “yathā panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Pajahantīti veditabbā pāṇātipātādīhi viramaṇavaseneva
analyzed: dassetum yathā pana atiādi vuttam pajahanti iti veditabbā pāṇa atipāta ādīhi viramaṇa vasena iva
translated: In order to show this, the following is said: “But just as … ” . It should be understood that the abandoning of the life faculty, etc., is the abandoning of the unvirtuous states, because they occur only through abstention from killing living beings, etc.

original: pavattanato. Atha tadārammaṇabhāve, na so tāni pajahati. Na hi tadeva ārabbha taṃ🔽pajahituṃ sakkā tato avinissaṭabhāvato.
analyzed: pavattanataḥ atha tad ārammaṇa bhāve na saḥ tāni pajahati na hi tat eva ārabbha tam  pajahitum sakkā tatas a vinissaṭa bhāvataḥ
translated: But if they have the same object, then he does not abandon them. For it is not possible to abandon that by means of that, because there is no escape from it.

original: Anabhijjhā…pe… viramantassāti abhijjhaṃ pajahantassāti attho. Na hi manoduccaritato virati atthi anabhijjhādīheva tappahānasiddhito.
analyzed: viramantassa ati abhijjham pajahantassa ati atthaḥ na hi manaḥ duccaritataḥ virati atthi anabhijjha ādīhi iva tad pahāna siddhitaḥ
translated: “He abstains from covetousness, etc.”: the meaning is that he abandons covetousness. For there is no abstention from wrong bodily action, since the abandoning of covetousness, etc., is itself the establishment of abstention.

original: Ariyavāsadasakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ariyavāsadasaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the tenfold base consisting of noble states

original: 348. Ariyānameva vāsāti ariyavāsā anariyānaṃ tādisānaṃ asambhavato. Ariyāti cettha
analyzed: ariyānam eva ariya vāsāḥ an ariyānam asambhavataḥ ca ittha
translated: Noble states are so called because they are the states of only noble persons, since such are impossible for others, that is, for ordinary people. Herein,

original: ukkaṭṭhaniddesena khīṇāsavā gahitā, te ca yasmā tehi sabbakālaṃ avirahitavāsā eva,
analyzed: ukkaṭṭha niddesena khīṇa āsavā gahitā te ca yasmā tehi sabbakālam avirahita vāsāḥ eva
translated: The phrase “the best” includes those who are cankers-destroyed. And since they are always and everywhere accompanied by these four,

original: tasmā vuttaṃ “ariyā eva vasiṃsu vasanti vasissantī”ti. Tattha vasiṃsūti nissāya vasiṃsu.
analyzed: tasmā vuttam ariyāḥ eva vasiṃsu vasanti vasissanti iti tattha vasiṃsu iti nissāya vasiṃsu
translated: it was said, “The Noble Ones have dwelt, dwell, and will dwell.” Herein, “have dwelt” means “have dwelt by depending.”

original: Pañcaṅgavippahīnattādayo hi ariyānaṃ apassayā. Tesu pañcaṅgavippahānapaccekasaccapanodanaesanāsamavayavissajjanāni
analyzed: pañcaṅga vippahīna tta ādayaḥ hi ariyānam apassayā tesu pañcaṅga vippahāna paccekasacca panodana esanā samavaya vissajjanāni
translated: For the Noble Ones’ dependence is on the abandoning of the five factors, etc.,

original: “saṅkhāyekaṃ paṭisevati, adhivāseti, parivajjeti, vinodetī”ti vuttesu apassenesu
analyzed: saṅkhāya ikam paṭisevati adhivāseti parivajjeti vinodeti iti vuttesu apassenesu
translated: Among the four kinds of dependence stated thus, “He depends on the abandoning of the five factors, on the full understanding of the four noble truths, on the development of the four paths, and on the direct knowledge of Nibbāna” ,🔽the dependence on the abandoning of the five factors, on the full understanding of the four noble truths, and on the development of the four paths are fulfilled by the path itself,

original: vinodanañca maggakiccāneva, itare maggeneva samijjhanti.
analyzed: vinodanañca itare maggena iva samijjhanti
translated: while the dependence on the direct knowledge of Nibbāna is fulfilled by the path’s function of direct knowledge.

original: Ñāṇādayoti ñāṇañceva taṃsampayuttadhammā ca. Tenāha “ñāṇanti vutte”tiādi. Tattha vattabbaṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva.
analyzed: ñāṇa ādayaḥ ti ñāṇam ca iva tad sampayutta dhammā ca tena āha ñāṇam ti vutta itiādi tattha vattabbam heṭṭhā vuttam eva
translated: “Knowledge, etc.”: both the knowledge and the states associated with it. Hence it is said, “When it is said ‘knowledge,’ etc.” Herein, what should be said has already been said above.

original: Ārakkhakiccaṃ sādheti sativepullappattattā. “Carato”tiādinā niccasamādānaṃ dasseti, taṃ vikkhepābhāvena daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: ārakkha kiccam sādheti sati vepulla ppatta ttā carataḥ iti ādinā nicca samādānam dasseti tam vikkhepa abhāvena daṭṭhabbam
translated: It fulfils the function of guarding because it reaches the state of mindfulness’s abundance. By the words “while he is walking” , etc., he shows the constant practice of mindfulness. This should be understood as the absence of distraction.

original: Pabbajjupagatāti yaṃ kiñci pabbajjaṃ upagatā, na samitapāpā. Bhovādinoti jātimattabrāhmaṇe
analyzed: pabbajja upagatā iti yam kiñci pabbajjam upagatā na samita pāpāḥ bho vādinaḥ iti jātimatta brāhmaṇe
translated: “Gone forth” : gone forth in any way, not only those whose evil is destroyed. “Sir” : to those who are only brahmans by birth.

original: vadati. Pāṭekkasaccānīti tehi tehi diṭṭhigatikehi pāṭiyekkaṃ gahitāni “idameva sacca”nti🔽abhiniviṭṭhāni diṭṭhisaccādīni. Diṭṭhigatānipi hi “idameva sacca”nti gahaṇaṃ upādāya
analyzed: vadati pāṭekka saccāni iti tehi tehi diṭṭhi gatikehi pāṭiyekkam gahitāni idam eva saccanti  abhiniviṭṭhāni diṭṭhi sacca ādīni diṭṭhi gatāni pi hi idam eva saccanti gahaṇam upādāya
translated: “Their several truths” : the truths of view, etc., held separately by this or that speculator, clung to thus, “This alone is the truth,”

original: “saccānī”ti voharīyanti. Tenāha “idamevā”tiādi. Nīhaṭānīti attano santānato nīharitāni
analyzed: saccāni iti tena āha idam eva atiādi nīhaṭāni iti santānataḥ nīharitāni
translated: and spoken of as “truths” because of the clinging to the view “This alone is the truth.” Hence he said, “This alone is the truth” , etc.🔽“Cast out” : removed from their own continuity, discarded.

original: apanītāni. Gahitaggahaṇassāti ariyamaggādhigamato pubbe gahitassa diṭṭhigāhassa.
analyzed: apanītāni gahita gahaṇassa ti ariya magga adhigamataḥ pubbe gahitassa diṭṭhi gāhassa
translated: “The clinging to the clinging” : the clinging to views that was clung to before the attainment of the noble path.

original: Vissaṭṭhabhāvavevacanānīti ariyamaggena sabbaso pariccāgabhāvassa adhivacanāni.
analyzed: vissaṭṭha bhāva vevacanāni iti ariya maggena sabbaso pariccāga bhāvassa adhivacanāni
translated: “Synonyms for the state of being completely abandoned” : synonyms for the state of being completely given up by means of the noble path.

original: Natthi etāsaṃ vayo vekalyanti avayāti āha “anūnā”ti, anavasesāti attho. Esanāti heṭṭhā vuttakāmesanādayo.
analyzed: natthi etāsam vayaḥ vekalyanti avayā iti āha anūnā iti anavasesā ti attho esanā ti heṭṭhā vutta kāma isana ādayaḥ
translated: “They have no age-limit” : they are not subject to aging, thus they are “without age-limit” . He says “without remainder” : without exception.🔽“Their quest” : the quest, etc., mentioned above.

original: Maggassa kiccanipphatti kathitā rāgādīnaṃ pahīnabhāvadīpanato.
analyzed: maggassa kicca nipphatti kathitā rāga ādīnam pahīna bhāva dīpanataḥ
translated: The result of the path is stated by the expression “their cankers are destroyed” .

original: Paccavekkhaṇāya phalaṃ kathitanti paccavekkhaṇamukhena ariyaphalaṃ kathitaṃ. Adhigate
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇāya phalam kathitanti paccavekkhaṇa mukhena ariya phalam kathitam adhigate
translated: The fruit of reviewing is stated: the noble fruit is stated by way of reviewing.

original: hi aggaphale sabbaso rāgādīnaṃ anuppādadhammataṃ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṃ paccavekkhaṇañāṇanti.
analyzed: hi agga phale sabbasas rāga ādīnam anuppāda dhamma tam pajānāti tat ca pajānanam paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam ti
translated: The fruit of reviewing is stated: the noble fruition is stated under the heading of reviewing. For when the noble fruition has been reached, he understands the state of the non-arising of lust, etc., in all aspects, and that understanding is knowledge of reviewing.

original: Asekkhadhammadasakavaṇṇanā🔽Phalañca te sampayuttadhammā cāti phalasampayuttadhammā, ariyaphalasabhāvā sampayuttā🔽dhammāti attho. Phalasampayuttadhammāti phaladhammā ceva taṃsampayuttadhammā cāti
analyzed: asekkha dhamma dasaka vaṇṇanā  phalañca te sampayutta dhammā ca ati phala sampayutta dhammā ariya phala sabhāvā sampayuttā  dhammā ati attho phala sampayutta dhammā ti phala dhammā ca iva tad sampayutta dhammā ca ati
translated: The ten states of the adept

original: evamettha attho veditabbo. Dvīsupi ṭhānesu paññāva kathitā sammā dassanaṭṭhena sammādiṭṭhi,🔽sammā jānanaṭṭhena sammāñāṇanti ca. Atthi hi dassanajānanānaṃ savisaye pavattiākāraviseso,
analyzed: evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ dvīsu pi ṭhānesu paññā ava kathitā sammā dassana ṭṭhena sammādiṭṭhi  sammā jānana ṭṭhena sammāñāṇanti ca atthi hi dassana jānanānam sa visaye pavatti ākāra viseso
translated: The states associated with the fruit and the states associated with the fruit-path are the states associated with the fruit and the states associated with the path to the fruit. The states associated with the fruit are the states associated with the noble fruition. The states associated with the path to the fruit are the states associated with the path to the noble fruition. The states associated with the fruit and the states associated with the path to the fruit are the states associated with the fruit and the states associated with the path to the fruit.

original: svāyaṃ heṭṭhā dassito eva. Phalasamāpattidhammāti phalasamāpattiyaṃ dhammā, phalasamāpattisahagatadhammāti
analyzed: svāyam heṭṭhā dassitaḥ eva phala samāpatti dhammā ati phala samāpattiyam dhammā phala samāpatti sahagata dhammā ati
translated: The states of the fruition attainment are the states in the fruition attainment. The states associated with the fruition attainment are the states associated with the fruition attainment.

original: attho. Ariyaphalasampayuttadhammāpi hi sabbaso paṭipakkhato vimuttataṃ upādāya “vimuttī”ti
analyzed: atthaḥ ariya phala sampayutta dhammā api hi sabbaso paṭipakkhataḥ vimutta tam upādāya vimutti iti
translated: For the states associated with the noble fruition are also called “deliverances” because they are completely free from their opposites.

original: vattabbataṃ labhanti. Kenaci pana yathā asekkhā phalapaññā dassanakiccaṃ upādāya
analyzed: vattabba tam labhanti kenaci pana yathā asekkhā phala paññā dassana kiccam upādāya
translated: But just as the fruit-knowledge of the trainer is called “right view” because it has the function of seeing,

original: “sammādiṭṭhī”ti vuttā, jānanakiccaṃ upādāya “sammāñāṇa”ntipi vuttā eva; evaṃ ariyaphalasamādhi
analyzed: sammā diṭṭhi iti vuttā jānana kiccam upādāya sammāñāṇam ti pi vuttā eva evam ariya phala samādhi
translated: and it is also called “right knowledge” because it has the function of knowing, so the concentration associated with the noble fruition

original: samādānaṭṭhaṃ upādāya “sammāsamādhī”ti vutto, vimuccanaṭṭhaṃ upādāya “sammāvimuttī”
analyzed: samādāna ṭham upādāya sammāsamādhī iti vuttaḥ vimuccana ṭṭham upādāya sammāvimuttī
translated: is called “right concentration” because it has the function of steadying, and it is also called “right deliverance” because it has the function of delivering.

original: tipi vutto. Evañca katvā “anāsavaṃ cetovimutti”nti dutiyavimuttiggahaṇañca samatthitaṃ hotīti.
analyzed: tipi vuttaḥ evam ca katvā anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim ti dutiya vimutti ggahaṇam ca samatthitam hoti iti
translated: And in that way the second deliverance, called “the deliverance of the mind through the element of the wholesome” , is also established.

original: Dasakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dasaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the tenth chapter is finished.

original: Pañhasamodhānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañha samodhāna vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the summing up of the questions

original: Samodhānetabbāti samāharitabbā.
analyzed: samodhānetabbā ati samāharitabbā
translated: What is to be summed up: what is to be brought together.

original: 349. Okappanāti balavasaddhā. Āyatiṃ bhikkhūnaṃ avivādahetubhūtaṃ tattha tattha bhagavatā
analyzed: āyatim bhikkhūnam avivāda hetu bhūtam tattha tattha bhagavatā
translated: “Inclination”: strong faith. The Blessed One, in order to be a cause for the future bhikkhus of not disputing,

original: desitānaṃ atthānaṃ saṅgāyanaṃ saṅgīti, tassa ca kāraṇaṃ ayaṃ suttadesanā tathā pavattattāti🔽vuttaṃ “saṅgītipariyāyanti sāmaggiyā kāraṇa”nti. Samanuñño satthā ahosi “paṭibhātu
analyzed: desitānam atthānam saṅgāyanam saṅgīti tassa ca kāraṇam ayam sutta desanā tathā pavatta ttā ti  vuttam saṅgīti pariyāyanti sāmaggiyā kāraṇanti samanuññaḥ satthā ahosi paṭibhātu
translated: The recitation of the Teaching is the recitation of the meaning of what has been taught, and the reason for that is this discourse teaching, which is so called because it occurs in this way.🔽It is said: “The recitation is the reason for the concord.” The Teacher approved: “Let it be clear to you, Sāriputta, that the Teaching is for the monks.”

original: ta,ṃ sāriputta, bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathā”ti ussāhetvā ādito paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā
analyzed: tam sāriputta bhikkhūnam dhammim kathā ati ussāhetvā āditaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā
translated: Having encouraged them, he listened from the beginning to the end.

original: suṇanto, sā panettha bhagavato samanuññatā “sādhu, sādhū”ti anumodanena pākaṭā jātāti
analyzed: suṇanto sā pana ittha bhagavato samanuññatā sādhu sādhu iti anumodanena pākaṭā jātā ati
translated: But here the Blessed One’s approval is evident through his expression of appreciation: “Good, good, Sāriputta!” Therefore it is said: “He approved through appreciation.”

original: vuttaṃ “anumodanena samanuñño ahosī”ti. Jinabhāsito nāma jāto, na sāvakabhāsito.
analyzed: vuttam anumodanena samanuñño ahosi iti jina bhāsitaḥ nāma jātaḥ na sāvaka bhāsitaḥ
translated: It became known as “spoken by the Victor,” not “spoken by a disciple.”

original: Yathā hi rājayuttehi likhitapaṇṇaṃ yāva rājamuddikāya na lañjitaṃ hoti, na tāva “rājapaṇṇa”nti🔽saṅkhyaṃ gacchati, lañjitamattaṃ pana rājapaṇṇaṃ nāma hoti. Evameva “sādhu, sādhu
analyzed: yathā hi rāja yuttehi likhita paṇṇam yāva rāja muddikāya na lañjitam hoti na tāva  saṅkhyam gacchati lañjita mattam pana rājapaṇṇam nāma hoti evam eva sādhu sādhu
translated: For just as a document written by royal scribes does not become a “royal document”🔽until it is sealed with the royal seal, but as soon as it is sealed it becomes a royal document, so too, the words of appreciation beginning with “Good, good, Sāriputta!”

original: sāriputtā”tiādi anumodanavacanasaṃsūcitāya samanuññāsaṅkhātāya jinavacanamuddāya
analyzed: sāriputta atiādi anumodana vacana saṃsūcitāya samanuññā saṅkhātāya jina vacana muddāya
translated: indicate the approval called “the Victor’s word,” which is the Blessed One’s seal.

original: lañjitattā ayaṃ suttanto jinabhāsito nāma jāto āhaccavacano. Yaṃ panettha atthato
analyzed: lañjita ttā ayam suttantaḥ jinabhāsitaḥ nāma jātaḥ āhacca vacanaḥ yam pana ittha atthataḥ
translated: Because of this, this sutta is called “spoken by the Victor” and is a “direct statement.” But as to the meaning of this sutta,

original: na vibhattaṃ, taṃ suviññeyyamevāti.
analyzed: na vibhattam tam su viññeyyam eva ati
translated: Because of this, this Thread is called “spoken by the Victor” and is a “word-by-word” reading. But what here is not commented on as to meaning is quite easy to understand.

original: Saṅgītisuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā.
translated: The explanation of the Thread of the Recitation is ended.

original: 11. Dasuttarasuttavaṇṇanā🔽350. Āvuso bhikkhaveti sāvakānaṃ ālapananti sāvakānaṃ āmantanavasena ālapanasamudācāro,
analyzed: āvuso bhikkhave iti sāvakānam ālapanam ati sāvakānam āmantana vasena ālapana samudācāraḥ
translated: The explanation of the Dasuttara Sutta

original: na kevalaṃ “bhikkhave”ti, so pana buddhānaṃ ālapanaṃ. Tenāha “buddhā hī”tiādi. Satthusamudācāravasena
analyzed: na kevalam bhikkhave ti saḥ pana buddhānam ālapanam tena āha buddhāḥ hi itiādi satthu samudācāra vasena
translated: “Friends, bhikkhus”: this is the usage of address to disciples, namely “friends, bhikkhus”. It is not only “ bhikkhus” . But that is the Buddhas’ usage of address. Hence he said “For the Buddhas” , etc. The placing of the Master in a high position is the usage of address here.

original: asamudācāro evettha satthu uccaṭṭhāne ṭhapanaṃ. Sampati āgatattā katthaci na nibaddho
analyzed: asamudācāraḥ eva ittha satthu ucca ṭṭhāne ṭhapanam sampati āgata ttā katthaci na nibaddhaḥ
translated: Because of coming up to the present, the dwelling is not fixed anywhere.

original: vāso etesanti anibaddhavāsā, antevāsikā. Kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā sappāyasenāsanaṃ gavesantā
analyzed: vāsaḥ etesanti a nibaddha vāsā antevāsikā kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā sa pāyasena āsanam gavesantā
